text: ------EDIT-------  August 2014One of the very first reviews I ever wrote in the US was in 2004 on epinions, about this GPS V.  I found it, and am therefore posting it here.The Garmin GPS V deserves a 2014 mention because I've had quite a bit of experience with a variety of other GPS's in the last decade and am still really stunned at the reliability of my Garmin GPS V.The tech is very old, the automotive navigation is next to useless, and the interface to a computer to download maps is agonizingly slow and a nearly pointless 19MB (without an SD card expansion slot).But, without question, while many high-tech GPS's I've purchased have broken, or become unusable, or have had the internal (and uncheangeable) battery die, the GPS V is still working exactly as efficiently (or inefficiently, depending on how you use it) as it did the day I got it.This GPS should not be used as an automotive navigation device.It's true power comes from simply always working, never failing.  It will give you your GPS coordinates always, and if you have the base maps loaded, it will show you approximately where you are, and if you have the detailed topo or marine maps loaded, it will show that information as well.As I have had quite a bit of gear fail in the field (I like backpacking and go out fairly often), I've come to realize that my electronic gear needs to be two things absolutely and always, to prevent failure in the field: - Rugged - WaterproofNot rugged'ish....rugged.  And that means seriously shock proof.  i've dropped this GPS V going 40 mph (don't ask, hahaha)And not "water resistant".  Water resistant is the most meaningless con ever.  Water proof...completely water proof is an absolute requirement when you're out in the field.I find it impressive that after all these years, while other electronic gear comes and goes, works for a while and then fails, the Garmin GPS V has stayed as consistently reliable as the day i bought it.  And while I don't take it out much anymore, since I'm now a satellite messenger and gps combo user, I will never sell my Garmin GPS V.Because when all my other GPS gear fails, I know that this will tell me GPS location, next year, or a decade from now. ------EDIT-------September 2009 Just used the Garmin recently for a multi-city trip and was able to install map data for key parts of Boston, Chicago, and College Town (TX) all in 19mbs. There's not doubt that more memory would be better (say, 256 or 512), but 19 can get the job done in a pinch.   In case anyone is interested, with all the construction going on in Boston, even the latest map is pretty worthless, with lots of road errors and directiion errors. In developing Boston, they're not only adding roads, but removing them as well. Somewhat frustrating. Luckily, College Town and Chicago were mostly unchanged since the last release and were both very accurate.   The key for Macintosh users, as mentioned earlier, is having VPC and a Keyspan serial adapter (or an IOGear serial adapter). If you install VPC, you can install the MapSource data on top of it.   There seems to be no problem with this as long as you set up COM1 in the VPC settings to be the serial port. Don't set USB for this as it won't work.   Which has lead to another discovery. When using USB based GPS devices (like the Garmin Quest), there seem to be numerous problems that simply don't exist with the serial adaptor set to COM1. That's both a relief and a disappointment. I was looking forward to the quest as my next device even though it only had 115mbs of memory (13mb for the base map comes to the expected 128mbs). Interestingly enough, in Europe they sell the 243mb version (which is 256mb minus 13mb for the base map). Either way, a major disappointment.------EDIT-------    Based on request, here are some additional opinions regarding the GPS V. I've had this for a few months now and have taken it on several trips.   Let's start with the interface.  Depending on who you ask or which review you read, the opinions of the interface range from hard to use to easy. But for me, it doesn't seem difficult at all. A few features were a little unintuitive at first, but I assume mostly because this is my first GPS. Now, though, I have a pretty good idea of all of the key funtions. It's easy to get to do just about anything. All the functions you would want in City/Street driving and walking are easy. The points of interest are really detailed and thhe inclusion of phone numbers is particularly useful. Of course, the only way to bring up phone numbers is to do a find. Wish they made that and the address easier to access after you made it a waypoint....  What is a little bit difficult is entering long/lat. It's so difficult, that it's just easier to do it with the MapSource software and then download the waypoints. I recently entered a series of waypoints from an off road trail (Used "Back Country Roads" book)    Physical buttons.  The buttons are designed to be waterproof along the edges, so the entire pad and all the buttons seem to be a single contiguous rubber piece.  The main navigation button in the center is a little "mushy" for lack of a better word. Trying to press "down" and end up pressing "right" or "left", well, you get the idea.   Visibility of the display.  Okay, so maybe I'm new to GPS's so my opinions are based on what I originally thought were ideal instead of in relation to other GPS's I have used, but I think the GPS V's screen (and every other GPS I've ever seen) is just too smal. You really can't read street names.  Having said this, I like this screen's size and resolution more than the Magellans I played around with.The best screen on a handheld I've seen to date is the iQue3600. Wow, lot's of pixels, more screen realestate, and color. But I read around that the iQue3600 breaks so easily as to be nearly worthless....  That's the complaint, but in reality, apart from being unable to read the names without squinting and leaning in a little, I have to say that the screen is easy to see. if you guide yourself by the street lines, then there's no problem. Especially if there's enough variation in the street lines that you can quickly gauge where you are. In Manhattan New York....you can't do that easily because the grid is so close to perfect in midtown. Sort of similar for San Francisco. But in Northern California's South Bay area, it's very easy to gauge where you are.  As to the screen's brightness, glaring sunlight is no problem. Almost no glare or reflection (certainly not enough to complicate screen viewing). And the backlight works really well. Several months and there seems to be no fading of the backlight. The screen's brightness controls and ability to see in daylight far surpass the iQue3600 or my Tungsten C.   Battery life.  About 20 hours contiguous on Duracell   Weight and durability.  Heavier than any Magellan. Will easily sink if dropped in water. Then again, it's very rugged. I can see why the military uses these. I've dropped it several times and there has been absolutely no damage to the functionality of the device, though scrathces abound throughout. Heck, i dropped it on asphalt from a motorcycle going 40mph...went back to pick it up...and it still worked fine.   Carrying on your hip.  Not easy. instead of being flat, it's a triangular cylinder (Like a Toblerone), with a rotating antenna on the one of the back planes. It's really not convenient compared to other GPS's out there.   Antenna....  okay, in a city with a bunch of skyscrapers, it's pretty bad. you get reception, but it's highly inaccurate. But since I set the software to always lock the GPS to a street, it's often the wrong street.  under a canopy of trees (recently went East to some national parks), it really depends on the density of the trees. If you're on the road and there's Redwood branches above and trees all around, I was surprised to get decent accuracy. But if you're hiking and walking in a dense forest where the trees are just a couple of feet away from you as you walk past them, the reception is highly inaccurate and often you lose the connection.   One thing that bothers me here is the inordinate amount of time the GPS takes to find satellites. Okay, let me re-phrase that. Sometimes it's really fast, but sometimes it can take several minutes. The manual says that it should take several minutes only if you turn it off, and move somewhere far away....this is not accurate. because if, for instance, you move to the other side of a building, or come out from an underground garage, it can take several minutes as well.   Routing  What can I say? It's slow as molasses. If you've been looking at a Roadmate, a Navman, or a Garming StreetPilot, don't look at the GPS V. It's ultra slow comparatively speaking. the interface is sluggish, routing and re-routing are slow, everything about it is slow.  As a side note,  WAAS  All I can say about WAAS is....wow!  it works much better than the StreetPilot if the reception is good enough. And though it takes a while to get several sattelites, once it does, it's very accurate and definitely good enough for walking. I recently went to New Mexico and was stunned at how accurate it was while walking in Old town Albequerque and Santa Fe's town square area.  I haven't seen any other WAAS enabled device in action, so I can't really comment on how it compares to other WAAS devices   What other impressions.....  Oh, I might point out here that the new Garmin Quest looks like it has all the features I wish the Garmin GPS V had. I didn't really thinkg the 60cs, or 76cs was a replacement possibility for the GPS V....But the Quest? Yeah, I think that could be my next device.  Last complaint..... If you use a Mac, then don't forget to get VPC, because MapSource won't work on the Mac, and there are no third party developers where you can use the POI database and routing functions that make the Garmin street capable.--Original Review:  September 1st, 2004--This is my first GPS device.  Having read a lot of reviews (many on this epinions), I was struggling with several different models and brands of GPS to choose from. In the end, I chose on price/performance.  The Garmin GPS V, is by now (April 2004), rather dated. There are newer models from Garmin out that are better at dealing with shortcomings from the Garmin GPS V. The newer model has color, an antenna port where removing the main antenna is not required, separate power/serial/USB ports, more memory, color touch screen, and more.  But the newer models, of course, don't come with a completely unlocked US street map. The Garmin, being discontinued, has a deluxe package that unlocks not just a particular region, but the entire United States. And the GPS V, has all the basics: WAAS, some memory (19MBs), high resolution screen, very good backlit screen, and more than anything else, is very tough.  Compared to the newer 60C/CS or 76 C/CS models, it's missing several keys, but even these newer models don't overcome key shortcomings in most Garmin handheld GPS's. Key among these shortcomings is memory. the GPS V has 19MBs, the 76c/cs has 100+MBs, the latest 60C/CS has 56MBs. California alone requires more than 100MBs. What's needed is expandable memory. Magellan GPS handhelds have SD memory card slots.   One might argue that the iQue3600 from Garmin has expandable features and a host of other really amazing features integrating PDA features and GPS features in a seemless unit. But the iQue3600 was $500 plus anywhere I looked. Someone mentioned getting one for less than $300, but I couldn't find such good deals, even including rebates, anywhere. The iQue3600 has another key fault: durability. There were as many complaints about how easily these devices broke down as there were praises for the great integration. And wanting to take the GPS with me on all business trips, off-road travel, and local routing info when visiting new places locally, my GPS was bound to get a lot of abuse. the lack of durability turned me off completely.   Of course, everyone complains about the lack of memory, but my addendum complaints are: Screen is so small, difficult to read on dashboard, have to bring the device somewhat closer to read effectively in map mode. the the turn-by-turn is great. Secondly, there should be a Mac version of MapSource. No matter how you cut it. It's worth it to do. No other manufacturer offers a Mac version. Sure, there are third party GPS software options, but MapSource has the detailed maps, points of interest, and routing information....it's one thing to get a software, but without good content, too much work is required to get it to work right and you still don't get routing. Garmin should make a Macintosh compatible version. They might be surprised at how much of a market opportunity there is. Especially if they are the only ones to do it.   Having used the Garmin GPS V for a little over a month, and having tested the iQue3600, Magellan Platinum, Magellan Sportstrac, Streetwise, and the Hertz GPS, as well as the etrex in the past 2 months, I can say that the GPS V Deluxe is the only device under $400 that I've seen so far with the most flexible configuration for Marine, off-road hiking/driving, on-road driving, and around town walking feautres and a full US (+ parts of Canada) street map. Though this probably doesn't need to be said, the MapSource CitySelect CD also includes obscure off-road trails that are usually not found anywhere except on "backroads" off-road maps. Oh, and updated maps are free from Garmin.   Magellan's bundle-packaged Platinum, Gold, and Color Meridians come very close, but no other Garmin, Magellan or Navman GPS comes close in terms of overall flexibility. The Garmin GPS V is heavier, but smaller than the Magellan handhelds (well, just thinner, so easier to pack in tight places when traveling). For hiking/off-road/and citiy driving, the Garmin GPS V is the best device for me.

I'm a pretty big fan of wood stoves.  Starting a fire in the woods is always a chore for me since I don't have the skills to really get a fire going without a little help.But this little guy makes starting a fire using a magnesium fire starter fairly simple.Compared to the Emberlit Titanium mini, this wood stove is a little heavier and a little smaller.  It has a few features enhancements over the emberlit mini, with features more commonly seen in larger devices.The first is that there are two base plates.  one is the ash pan and one holds the wood.  the one for holding the wood has holes in it to draw air from below and also to drop ashes to the ash pan.This is very helpful as a buildup of ash decreases air flow to embers and fuel, which reduces heat.  With this unit, a few taps on the stove shakes ash loose so it drops to the ash pan.Interestingly, this unit also adds the ability to raise the fuel plate.You can notice from the image that this device is basically 4 walls, one of which has a larger opening.  The fuel plate has two rims, or wings, or flaps, if you will.  and these are designed to normally slot into two slits built into two of the walls.  but the fuel plate can actually rest on the base of that larger opening as well, bringing the fuel a lot higher and closer to the upper rim.  Great innovation.When the base plate is on the lower position, you can easily fit an alcohol stove in there as well, so this unit, combined with a trangia alcohol stove and a bottle of denatured alcohol, makes for a very versatile cooking setup.  Ideal for a weekend jaunt alone when the weather isn't too cold.Tougher campers could probably make due with just this in colder weather, but for me, winter camping requires a lot more heat and a lot more cooking efficiency, so I bring a gas canister stove or multi-fuel stove alone with a larger wood stove to help boil water faster, and act as a tiny campfire.All in all, I would say, from a feature, durability, and flexibility perspective, this is my new favorite miniature wood stove.Great job Bushbox.  Awesome piece of gear.

Really wish there was a lot to say about this, but it's best feature is really the price.You get a bagless vacuum for under $100.  It's hugely popular so hepa filters should be easy to get for a good while yet, and it has all the basic features you'd expect, including the detachable hose, and nifty extender design that keeps everything out of the way until you need it.  the extension cord is reasonably long, and the vacuum is not prohibitively heavy.Really...not sure what else there is to say about it.If you want a bagless vacuum, and just need the basics, but want something that lasts and something for which you will likely be able to get hepa filters for a long time, this is kind of it....anything else will jump in price fast.

When I'm out backpacking, this little device is a must have.I usually have a few batteries in my pack, to help power my satellite GPS and headlamp.  one uses AA and the other AAA.  This little tester is feather light, has no wires, and is ridiculously easy to break out and adjust with one hand while holding batteries in the other.The lack of wires also means less prone to breaking.There's a dial to switch to a few different battery type settings.I use it with rechargeable batteries too.It works on mini cell (those flat batteries that go in some cameras, garage door openers, etc.  AA, AAA, C, D, 9 volt.Even at home, the fact that I can hold and adjust the gadget with one hand while holding the battery in the other means that for all of the above types of batteries, I grab this first, and not my more complex, voltage adjustable and customizable tester.Really is just too useful not to have around the house and in the backpack.

I can't say enough good things about this water filter.  Of all of Sawyer's portable water filters (all pointone family), this one is by far the most useful and the most used.It comes with the reverse "syringe" to back wash the filter, a small aluminum dirty water back and a rubber hose/straw.This thing is so unbelievably light, it's hard to believe it is a 0.1 micro filter.  and it works fast.  It may not be as hands free as a gravity filter, but it's way less work than a water pump.  And water pumps have far great mechanical failure chances than this little guy.  heck, I could carry two sets of these and still be lighter than just about every portable water filter I've seen (and those other ones are .2 microns).It fits on most cheap water bottles with the smaller bottle cap.  so you can re-cycle soda bottles or water bottles.  the aluminum bag is best though, and Sawyer sells a larger 2 liter version that is super light, and rolls up to be compact.  I bring two of the larger bags and one of the smaller bags.  The smaller bag I use during hiking.  the two larger ones I fill and cap at the camp site.  It's dirty water, of course, so I just screw on the water filter when I want clean water and pour into a pot and boil.0.1 microns is good for most things.  and certainly better than 0.2 micron filters.But, it's important to note that this is NOT a water purifier.  if there are toxic chemicals in the "dirty" water, this will not filter them out.  It will filter out bacteria, viruses, etc.  So you should be able to just drink water collected from a stream or lake in the mountains.  Just don't collect water from likely toxic areas like a large lake that has buildings and such.  Generally, I hike in the emigrant wilderness, where there are no buildings by the lakes at 7500 feet and about.  In fact, there's no one up there apart from park rangers and other backpackers, so this type of filter is more than adequate up there.If you backpack in the wilderness...I would recommend this over a pump without a doubt.  And frankly, I think it's better than a fravity filter because....again...fewer points of failure, and less weight to carry.

If there's one thing I'm a huge fan of, it's rugged gadgets.I purchased this because I recently went on a  camping trip and the el cheapo blue tooth speaker I purchased just stopped working.  I realized that it had gotten a little wet.  not soaked, mind you, just a little wet.But it got me thinking, if I were to fall into a stream while crossing it, or maybe my pack gets soaked from the rain and seeps through, or maybe my pack rips and falls, or when in a raft my pack gets wet....well...under these circumstances, rugged and water "resistant" just won't cut it.  I need water proof.Without doing a ton of research, I focused on strictly waterproof blue tooth speakers and this little guy popped up.  Really, I shouldn't need a speaker while backpacking at all, but when you're out alone, sometimes a little music can cheer you up, and headphones can be a tad scary since you can't hear anything else.  Since the smart phone's speakers are horrendous, a small bluetooth speaker is a reasonable compromise.This guy is a lot smaller than you'd think.  That carabiner you see in the photo is the same as the small ones you see at sports store.  it feels sturdy and a good weight for its size, though still light enough to disappear in the pack.I just took it hiking in the emigrant wilderness, and it was really great.  I won't take it on every camping trip I go, but if the rest of my pack is light, it's a good little morale booster to have with you.Sound quality, because it's waterproof, is a tad...uhhh...I guess you could say it's a tad muffled.  But all in, surprisingly decent.  the bass comes through okay, but treble comes through muddy and muted.  violins and flutes sound like you're listening through a wall, sort of.  but even at that, the sound is dramatically improved over using a smart phones speakers.It's small enough to fit in the top pocket of most packs, and disappears into most small backpacks and shoulder bags too.Surprisingly, this also has a microphone.  doesn't really work that well, but I guess you could use it as a speaker phone in a pinch.All in all, this was a rock solid purchase and I'm glad to have found it.If you want waterproof (because you just never know), and you want as small and compact as possible, with surprisingly good sound for its size, than this is definitely the one to get.The battery lasts a good 6+ hours right now. Don't know if it'll last that long in a year or so, but for now, I'm satisfied.

A quick gander at my list of reviews, and you'll find that I'm mostly positive about the things I purchase.This one was a huge mistake.You'd think that with 4 microphones to be more omnidirectional, the mic pickup on this thing would be a lot better.Nope.  It sucks.Sitting at your desk in a low ceilinged room and an area with little to no reverb from hard walls, and this works just fine.  About about maybe 2 feet away max, probably a little less.But try using this in a larger room still two feet away, and the folks on the other side can baaaaarely hear you.Have you ever been on the phone talking to someone, and you hear a that person talking, just for a moment, to someone else in the house, maybe that person's spouse, and you can sort of hear that "spouse"?  At least, enough to understand what that distant person is saying?Yeah....this isn't even that good...and we're talking about 2-4 feet away.Sorry, but the reason I spend money on a bluetooth audio conferencing unit is NOT because I want it on my desk in my hotel room....The reason I purchased this is because I do a lot of audio conferencing, and when I go onsite somewhere, I want a way to have a few people around a table on the call.-----Having said all that, if you want to turn your iPhone or Android into a speakerphone, while in a small, quiet, hotel room, having it on your desk while you are sitting there and working...this'll serve.As far as i'm concerned, this is the worst purchase I have ever made on Amazon.

I now have three backpacking chairs, they all wei about the same, or, at least, close enough to be negligible for me.  I would likely select a different chair for different types of trips.When hiking alone, I'd probably go with a competitor's chair that has the same seat height.When hiking in a small group for extended trips, I'd probably go with a competitor's chair that sits lowerFor hiking in larger groups, I'd definitely take the Helinox Chair One.  And really it comes to two simple reasons: - It's build to withstand a lot of abuse, the most of any backpacking chair - It's built wide, to accommodate a broad range of body types. - easier for most folks to get into and out of.Hiking in a larger group means all kinds of body types and personalities will be together.  There'll typically be a central campfire to gather around for food and relaxing, and chairs get strewn about and a lot of folks just don't care what chair they sit in.  So, likely, if I have my chair out, it'll be first come first serve.  Or I might get up for a sec to gather firewood, collect water, do some cooking, or maybe go check on my tent, or whatever, and come back and find someone in my chair.Now, that's not a big deal, of course.  But what I wouldn't want is for someone to have an accident because the chair wasn't really sturdy and possibly get hurt, or maybe someone's body type is stockier and becomes extremely uncomfortable in the chair where the front digs into the thighs or the sides put too much pressure, making the chair uncomfortable.The Helinox chair is significantly wider seating than my other two chairs.  Where the other two backpacking chair fits, not snug, but almost snug, the Helinox almost feel like a hammock.  There is plenty of room for stockier folks to be comfortable, and nothing digs in.  it’s also built to withstand 350 lbs.And it does seem immensely strong.  Not sure it would hold up to the same rigors as my lower seat height camp chair, but it sure looks like it can take a beating, and when you don't know how a "community property" piece of backpacking gear is going to be treated, you want it as risk free as possible.As I said in the beginning, all three camp chairs I have are essentially the same weight and they really are basically the same bulk.  whichever one I throw in my pack, there is no noticeable difference in weight, nor can I fit any more or less gear, meaning their in-pack build is roughly the same.I guess the only reason I wouldn't take this backpacking chair on all trips with me is that...well...it's kinda big for my butt, and the other camp chairs are a little more comfortable for me because they are a bit more snug.  btw, I measure 5'8" when barefoot, 140lbs (maybe a touch more now).Oh, one more thing, it does seem to have you in a slightly more “sitting up” position than the other chairs.  Not quite a straight back chair, but a little closer to that.

If you've read my other reviews on camping knives, you know well that I don't know much about them.For me, a camping knife needs to be just sharp enough to do camping chores and be able to baton/split wood, and maybe do some occasional hacking and maybe just enough chopping so that I can snap a branch by stepping on it.  Other than that, I don't know or care much about the type of steel used, how well it holds an edge, etc. etc.  Most camping knives fit that bill......so if you're looking for a blade review about steel quality, holding an edge, combat, stop here, this review won't help.Other things I can talk about regarding camping knives since I've been heading out regularly, and things that have evolved for me over time include: - Full tine.  I get it now...full tine is a must. - No serrated portion to the knife.  A lot of hard core campers will disagree with me, and that's okay.  I'm sure they're right and I'm wrong.  But for me, serrated edges are much more trouble to maintain than they're worth for the very basic chores I do. - No weird notches.  I've had two blades now with funky notches along the non-blade side of a single sided blade knife (e.g. belt cutting, etc.)  this creates a weak point along the blade, and...it snaps.  I kid you not...it really snaps....crazy, I know. - 3/16" is plenty thick enough for my uses, even splitting wood. - solid finger guard to prevent slippage to the blade.  Yeah, this is a biggy.  For backpacking, anything I can do to avoid any injury is a big deal because even a small injury can become very dangerous very quickly.  And when you're 10 miles from your car and 20 miles from the nearest building that might have a first aid kit, even little injuries aren't worth it.  Every blade I take into the woods must have some kind of perpendicular guard or shape to prevent fingers sliding forward to the blade. - removable handles.  I have had only one situation where I wanted to attach a knife to a long stick, so I admit that this is a rare need, and you can tie a knife to a stick without taking the handles off.  But being able to do so, splitting the end of a straight'ish branch a little, and inserting the thinner blade with handles removed and tying it all together....well...the difference in stability is noticeable. - A good sheath....you know, even the cheapest plastic and canvas sheaths with a drain hole work just fine.  I attach mine as close to a drop leg setup as possible, but it really doesn't matter, they all work well.The Esee 6 meets all these criteria, and then some.But, the real reason I love this knife?Drum roll please.The micarta handles.I don't know much about handles, but I do know that the hard Glock plastic material, and some other plastics get slippery when wet.  Again...injury = bad.The micarta handles do not slip even when wet.They feel like a very fine grain.  almost like a surface made with sand, but not as abrasive and skin tearing.  Somehow, this knife is reasonably smooth to the touch, but just rough enough that it doesn't slip....It's really rather incredible.But just as importantly, micarta is lighter than I would have expected.  Much lighter.The other reason i like the Esee 6 is that, for my uses, I just recently discovered that 6 is the perfect blade length.  I have a 9, 7, and 5, and all are great, but all have little disadvantages.  The 6" blade with the simple, abuse bearing lines along the blade and the back edge, means I can beat the crap out of this knife and it'll keep on ticking.One last interesting note.  The sheath comes in two parts, the belt clip portion and the actual sheath.  You can attach the belt clip portion to either side, but it screws on, so just note that once it's on, you won't want to switch the side while out in the field, so think about the rest of your setup and where you want your knife to be before attaching the clip to the sheath.Of all the knives I've purchased as I continue to learn about backpacking, the Esee 6 is by far the most perfect fit.Rock on Esee, I'm impressed.

When backpacking in the Emigrant Wilderness, you're not allowed to setup camp near the edge of the lakes, so it's always a good idea to have a bucket with you, to have access to water at the camp site.This bucket is about 10 litres realisitically, 11 would be pushing it.  that's about 2.5 gallons, or close enough.Plenty of water for two to drink, hydrate food, do a few dishes, and wash your face.  If you're conservative, that's plenty for the next morning too.I backpack along sometimes, and this bucket is more than enough for one.  For two people it works just fine.  For three you'd probably want a second bucket.Either way, backpacking buckets sure have come a long way.  I used to use the bear can to transport water, but once we started bear hanging, we switched to a folding bucket like this one, which was heavier and took up more space.This Seattle Sports PVC Free pocket bucket is quite a bit lighter, folds a little smaller, and also stands upright.  I wouldn't hang this from a tree when filled with water because I think the lifespan of this bucket may be considerably less than the other folding bucket.  But treated well, this bucket should work just fine to lug water to the camp site, and then you can use a filter to get clean water as you need it.Note:  use filtered water to wash your face.  lake water, especially the water near the surface, can get warm, and that is a breeding ground for some bacteria and viruses that can cause real harm.  It's highly unlikely, of course, but there have been news reports of warn lake water being a touch dangerous.If you're on the hunt for the lightest, free standing water bucket for backpacking, this is definitely the one to get.

This is a really nice backpack! Even though it is designed for yoga, it really is quite multi-functional and can be used in a ton of different ways.I use it mostly when I am headed to the gym, because it is so nice to be able to carry everything that I need inside of the bag, and roll up my yoga mat and carry it using the straps on the side. It really frees my hands up and makes things a lot easier for me.There are plenty of compartments inside the bag, and I have plenty of room to carry everything that I like to take with me. The bag is very well made, all of the stitching is nice and tight and I did not find any loose threads anywhere. The zippers all work well, and open and close easily without having to tug.The bag is comfortable to wear, the straps are nice and thick and I love that there is a hidden pocket on the strap that can be used to carry a cellphone or MP3 player. This could also be used for backpacking or taking a hike in the woods, it really is so versatile. I received one to review and am very pleased with it. It definitely makes lugging all my things to the gym a much easier task!I hope that you found this review to be helpful. If you have any questions, please let me know and I will do my best to answer what I can for you.

My niece has always been interested in dance, but once she started playing with the doll and read the book, she couldn't wait to get signed up for some local classes. I love how this is helping her to take an interest in living an active and athletic lifestyle as she grows.This doll itself is very cute and very well made. She comes dressed in her little pink dance outfit and also comes with a backpack and towel to carry with her. I checked over the doll's clothing when it arrived, and from what I could tell the stitching was nice and tight and I could not find any loose threads at all. I received one to review and it's been a great source of fun for my sweet little niece. I love seeing her smiling face every time she plays with this doll.I hope that you found this review to be helpful. If you have any questions, please let me know and I will do my best to answer what I can for you.

I gave this doll to my niece as a gift and her eyes lit up as soon as she opened it up and saw what it was. She has had a blast playing with it, and loves reading the story about Soccer Girl Cassie.This is a really nice doll, I love that it comes with the motivational story that teaches her about playing soccer and helps her learn about being the best that she can be. She has spent hours setting up fake soccer games in the living room between this doll and her other doll where they kick the little soccer ball that was included back and forth.The doll itself is really well made and very soft and plush.  Also, I love the yarn style hair, it really reminds me of the hair that my Cabbage Patch dolls used to have when I was growing up. The little outfit is very cute and was made nicely with no loose threads. I received one to review and it's been a bit hit around here. Thumbs up from us!I hope that you found this review to be helpful. If you have any questions, please let me know and I will do my best to answer what I can for you.

Boy has it been a looong time since I have played with a yoyo, but since these arrived I've learned that it is something that is still fun even as an adult. This set of yoyos is really nice and would make an awesome gift for any Star Wars fan.Everyone in the family has been having a blast playing with the for the past week or so. I am having a great time remembering all of the little tricks that I used to do when I played with yoyos as a child. The quality of these is very nice, and I have been able to do most of the basic yoyo tricks with ease thanks to the flared body shape, wide string gap and steel axle. As far as tricks go, the sleeper and walking the dog were always two of my faves as a kid, and my nieces and their friends were thoroughly impressed and have spent hours upon hours working on perfecting the tricks themselves.This is a really nice and inexpensive set that is a lot of fun and a really great way for kids to learn to yoyo. I received one to review and I have been getting a ton of use out of these since they arrived. I think I'll be ordering a few more sets to give away as gifts for the holidays.I hope that you found this review to be helpful. If you have any questions, please let me know and I will do my best to answer what I can for you.

I am 36DD and purchased this in XLarge Blue.  Great value sports bra. The color is very pretty and the interior fabric is grey.  I like that the pads are removable and they are appropriately sized for larger bust (I hate when the pads are tiny in a larger bra.)  The pads are decently thick and will not have show-through.  The holes in the sides to insert the pads have a large enough access hole.  The band under the bust is comfortable and the entire bra seems really well-made.  I like that this bra does not dig into my armpits but it also has adequate side coverage to keep me from side exposure in yoga poses.  The multi pack is a really great buy and I'm considering purchasing that too!  I received a discount on this item for my review.  I have included photos and am happy to answer any questions.  I hope this review was helpful to you.

Sized TINY.  I normally wear a L or XL, I am 36DD.  I ordered the L and it fits like a small.  The sleeves did not even cover my elbows (that is how small it was.)  IF the model in the picture is 5'2" and 120 pounds, then maybe she is wearing a Large.  If you want that look, size up. Sadly, I had to send it back.

I really liked this flavor!  I cook as directed, then add one slice of jack cheese to top and microwave for additional 45 seconds.  The melted cheese makes this PERFECT! Decently high in protein and fiber.  Will buy again. Yum

I own quite a few BOBs from Sketchers shoes.  I am very happy with most of them.  This particular BOB's shoe is a complete miss!  The fabric is shiny and cheap looking.  The fabric is very tight over the top of the foot and has no give or stretch.  The fabric is scratchy and rough.  I could not send them back fast enough!  Even at the markdown price (less than 30 bucks), I knew I would never wear them.  Sent back.

I found the Jessica GELeration Start and Finish to be FAR superior to Gelish brand foundation and top coats.  The Jessica brand goes on smoother and thinner, does not pool at the edges of the nail bed, and dries without bubbles.  I have a LED light at home and do my own nails (for the most part.)  This brand is SHINY as a top coat (F Finish one).  The Start (S) coat goes on super thin, but it makes soaking off my nails MUCH faster.  It keeps the color coats from bonding to my nail and soaking with acetone, the color (from any brand) comes off in about 4-5 minutes (versus 10-15 minutes with a Gelish base coat.)  The size of bottle is large and the price is great for quality.  Does not yellow, chip, or dull.  I could not be happier with this product!  Hope they never stop making it.  This is a real review and I paid full price for it.  Hope my review was helpful to you.

These sleeves are BEAUTIFUL and are very high quality.  The seller was prompt with shipping and they are just as pictured!  So glad I snagged them at the discount and also glad I got the bigger pack!  I even used double sided tape and put a few on the inside of my planner to keep credit cards and stamps handy. (perfect size!)  Cards are easy to slide in and out, but they are not so loose they fall out.  The seller also offers them in CUSTOM prints, which would be cool to use your business logo and give to your employees for company business cards or to print family photos and give to members of family.  Would purchase again and will be buying more as Christmas gifts.  Great value!

This item works great at quickly charging my iPhone with a factory iPhone cord.  I also used the included cord to charge my navigation device and it charged fast without issues.  The size of the block is small enough to fit within a power strip and does not block entry from other devices into a standard outlet.  I received a coupon discount.  Overall, I am very happy with the wall charger and recommend it. Would purchase again.

I LOVE these shoes!  I am always a 9 or 9.5 and the 9.5 fit me best.  These can be worn with no-show socks and are the most comfortable shoes I own.  They kind of look like slippers, but are so comfy I don't mind.  I just came back to order my second pair.  I am a person who generally hates to wear flats because I get blisters and pain.  These shoes cause neither.  Also, I almost always get blisters on the back of my heel from this type of shoe, but this particular brand and model caused no blisters at all.  I prefer this model (PureFlex) to some of the other Sketchers shoes that have the weird monster-teeth looking bottoms.  These are the perfect shoe for the 2 months of the year in California where it is too chilly for flip-flops.  (Eat your heart out Minnesota!) ;)  Hope this review was helpful to you.
This worked well for the purpose I needed.  I used it to repair jump rings in jewelry. (Heated at the lowest setting).  A good tool.

Light worked well for being so small.  The case is made of aluminum and is very sturdy.  I had to hold the light pretty close to the surface to achieve the desired detection, but it did its job when held within 8 inches or so.  Packaging is exactly as shown in photo.  A good tool for any pet owner. Sample provided. Happy with product and would recommend.

This is one of the best office products I have found.  Will order more.  The only expanding divider I have found that holds 50 pages and does not cover up the tabs.  Perfect for school and work folders where you need to keep track of handouts, brochures, etc.  I'm even making a folder with my taxes from each year so I can just put in the receipts too and tab them.  Durable, but not so thick it overwhelms the space.

This product was very effective at freshening my dog's breath.  Unfortunately, both of my dogs hated the taste.  I followed the directions and squirted less than one full pump in each of their mouths.  They both reacted the same and began spitting and hacking and shaking their heads.  To be truthful, it was quite funny to watch.  I don't think I would use the product again (despite its effectiveness) since my dogs hated it so much.  I received a sample of the product in exchange for an honest review.

I was pleased to find the one pound bag was much larger than I expected.  The flavor and aroma are great.  I like fruit based teas, but only ones with a black tea base and this fits the bill perfectly.  Smooth, great flavor.  Delicious and refreshing iced as well.  With an orange slice and a teaspoon of sugar, this is my favorite tea right now.  I will be back for more when this runs out. :)

I included a photo that shows the very fine strainer over the drinking hole.  The reason why I love this is that I can put lemon or orange slices in my bottle and not worry about getting a sip with a seed in it.  But I think what I like best about this bottle is that I can fill it (almost full) and FREEZE it.  The silicone allows for enough give and it is going to be perfect to use as an ice block in a small cooler (that doubles as drinking water after melting).  The caribeaner clip is not so useful for me, but I can see how some people would want it.  The silicone also passed the "pinch test"...meaning that it does not turn white where pinched, but retains its color.  I have heard that this is the mark of high-grade silicone.  Overall, a useful bottle for anytime space is at a premium (travel/hiking/sports, etc).  It fits in my standard car cup holder too.  Sample given for review.
I love the long length on the inseam, however these are REALLY low-rise.  I couldn't pull this off unless I was 20 years old....so my "almost middle age" butt is returning them.

Measurements:  40/30/40 5'9/160/36DD fits an XXL perfectly.  It is fitted at my bust and hips, but not so snug that my bra lines show from the back.  It is long like the model photo.  It is not snug in my stomach area so it decently hides tummy.  And FINALLY it is a decent quality t-shirt with normal SLEEVES.  As for me, I can't stand cap sleeves.  The sleeves on this shirt are fitted without being constricting and long enough to get out of the dreaded 90's "cap-sleeve" trend.  A great buy and I am back for more colors :)

The back pockets are so far apart that my average size butt looks HUGE.  If you are thin/tiny then these pants might look great.  Does this look like a size 10?  The fit is great (5'9"/160/36DD--40" hips and 30" waist).  Length is perfect, and the material has a nice drape.  But these pockets are sewn ridiculous!  The edges of the pockets are 1/4 inch from the SIDE seams.  Even on the model photo she looks like she has a big rear and I'm pretty sure she is a size zero.  I know I have some junk in the trunk, but it shouldn't look like a garage sale back there... As for me, I am looking for something else.  Back they go.
These work with NOW foods essential oils 4 ounce brown bottles.
I really like the material.  Drapes like cotton but without the wrinkles.  Fit is great and sleeves are long enough for my 5'9" frame.

To be fair, I actually love the shirts....(5'9"/36DD/165 ordered the 2XL). They fit great! But I hate that they use Photoshop on the colors. I ordered the envy green color and it is nothing like the photo. The actual shirt is a Kelly green (straight from the color wheel), not the light aqua pictured. I also ordered the yellow (banana cream) which is darker than the photo. I will say that I really like the shirts and they fit a little loose on me (which is what I prefer.) I also LOVE that the sleeves are a decent length. As another reviewer stated, these sleeves are long enough to be out of the "cap-sleeve" category (yay!)I am only giving 3 stars because of the color discrepancies. I wish vendors would just take one photo of all their shirts stacked with the color name printed over the image. The photo-shop issue is irritating if you (like me) are shopping for something to match an existing outfit.

I have long dark blonde hair that is very dry.  I tried this mask on dry hair and washed it out after two hours.  ( I applied heavily and wrapped my head in saran wrap).  I would say it worked "okay" as a moisturizer...but I get much better results from putting plain coconut oil on my dry hair and washing that out after a few hours.  My biggest complaint is the SMELL of this product.  It is VERY flowery/ rosey and way too heavy.  I hate the smell.  Overpowering and smells like an old lady drenched in heavy perfume.  YUCK.  I will probably give away the remaining product.  There is no way to even wash out the stench.  It will follow you for at least two days.  For reference, I like fragrances like Pantene and Herbal Essences products.  This smells like "Beautiful" perfume at the Estee Lauder counter. :P

One of my biggest concerns about this was storage space. I attached a photo showing how they stack. The photo contains all pieces for four kits 1-Lunch Blox Entree Kit, 2- Sandwich kits and 1 Salad kit.) They take up approximately 11"x6" footprint and stack approx 11" high. (Note: the ice blocks are not in the photo, they are in my freezer). Another issue I wanted to know is if I could freeze the individual food containers (you CAN). I put cool whip in some of the small containers to top on fruit salad. It is an item that thaws fast and so I wanted to be sure it was cold enough at lunchtime. The blue freezer blocks are actually blue ice inside (gel) not water, so they do not sweat as much and stay frozen longer. I like that the ice blocks can be used with other items (coolers, other lunch boxes, etc.) I have enough pieces that I can prepare several lunches at the beginning of the week and just add the freshest ingredients the night before. So far, they are great. Will update if I encounter any problems. See my added photo for storage space. I hope this review was helpful to you.

I live in an urban city so there are a lot of great Chinese food places around.  My favorite part of going to a great Chinese restaurant is the TEA.  I was never able to find anything remotely close until now.  I purchased the "Lapsang Souchong Tea" in the pale yellow and red package.  It is fantastic and actually tastes better than any I have had at a restaurant.  I brewed it a little too strong for my first cup (used about 1.5 Tbsp for 16 oz.) next time I will use a little less because it is so strong and flavorful!This tea needs a little space to bloom in hot water, so don't pack it into to one of those little balls.  Put into a large diffuser and you will be very pleased with the results!This Lapsang Souchong Tea is a black tea.  Much like traditional Chinese teas, it has a very crisp and clean flavor.  I can not wait to make some iced tea with this!!  I like my tea sweetened and found that the Teavana Perfectea Rock Sugar pairs well with this and does not distort the authentic Chinese flavor.  The only downfall of this item is the high price...I am afraid I will become addicted to this brand and will keep coming back for more.  It's going on my permanent wishlist if anyone wants to buy me a present  :)

5'9"/165/36DD ordered the 10.  They fit great everywhere but the length, too short.  The inseam on this pant in size 10 is 32" (the vendor says it is 33", but it isn't, I measured with a tape measure).  I needed an inseam closer to 34" for my tall frame.I also ordered the Jag Jean in PALEY cut which had a 33.5" inseam and fit me perfect!  (The vendor claims the PALEY has a 34" inseam, it is actually 33.5").  Purchased multiple colors in the PALEY....linked here...https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00C9HC226/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s02?ie=UTF8&psc=1Hope this review was helpful to you.

5'9"/165 and ordered a 10 Long.  These literally have a 32.5" inseam.  On what planet is that "long"?  Way too short to be considered a long inseam.  I ordered two pair and both were the same.  The thighs were also really loose and old-fashioned looking (think 1980's "dress" pant)....going back.  Way too short Lee!!

Long??  I ordered two of these pants in long.  They literally have a 32.5" inseam.  This (by no means) is a "long" or tall inseam.  Too short. Going back.  I'm 5'9" and ordered a size 10 Long.  The thighs are very loose and old-fashioned.

5'9"/165/36DD purchased L.  I normally don't buy anything with wool because it's too itchy for my sensitive skin.  This sweater is not itchy and the coloring is SO pretty!  I have all three colors and they are just as pictured.  Sleeves are cuffed in model photos so they can be uncuffed and adjusted for longer length. (yay for us tall people!)  I prefer to wear mine open instead of tied.

5'9"/160/36DD purchased the L and it fits great.  I think it actually looks better on me than the model.  This is a very flattering basic shirt if you are busty like me :)  The heathered coloring makes it look nice even after washing.  Will order another color.  Washed up very nice in cold with a cool dryer.

I am 5'9"/160/36DD and purchased the L in ivory.  I am going to exchange for the 1X.  In the photo I am trying on the L.  It fits fine except it is just a tad tight under the bust and the back of the shirt is about 2" shorter than the front.  I think the 1X will fit me better.  The ivory color is BEAUTIFUL in person.  It is a nice warm toned ivory (with a hint of pink) and much nicer than the photo shows.  I might get another color as well.  Just love that this top feels like I am only wearing a tank top (zero heat retention) but covers all my problem areas.  In the photo, I am wearing a white tank underneath, the garment is completley sheer so you will need a tank underneath it. Hope this review and photo are helpful to your shopping.*sigh* so I had to edit my original review from 5 stars to 4.  I received the XL in Ivory and it is a COMPLETELY different color.  The XL is more of a band-aid beige and not near as pretty as the L color (even though both were ordered as "IVORY" -only difference was supposed to be the size).  So I will keep the L and wear white spanx under it....because I love the L color so much more.  One star removed for inconsistency in product line....other than that, a fantastic shirt.*update*--ordered a second color "Floral Lace- Off White" in XL.  Love that one as well.  Looks pure white (not off-white) and length is (sadly) shorter, but still a beautiful shirt.....I'm tempted to order the coral too. :)

Fits great as a TOP....not a dress.  Although I never expected it to fit like a dress since I am NOT 4'11" and petite like the model....instead, I am 5'9"/160/36 DD and curvy.  Looks great as a shirt and at a great price.  I purchased the black/white paisley pattern top.  I like that the pattern is off-center, it adds  interest to the shirt.  Yeah, it's cheap and I won't put it in the dryer, I will line dry it.  But what do people expect to get for under $10?  Overall great buy.  Hope this review was helpful.
Another great Patty Boutik purchase!  5'9"/160/36DD purchased in XL.  It is form-fitting and looks great.  Nice material.  LOVE the long sleeves!

For me, this fits true to size and as pictured.  I think it is offered at a great value (price for quality).  I purchased in the pink/mint flower print and it is exactly as pictured.  5'9"/160/34DD purchased the L.  Fits great, not binding, but not loose either.  My waist is 30" and my hips are 40".  Love that the vendor listed measurements are spot on! <3 Hits just below my natural waist like the picture and just above my knees like the picture.  (On someone short, this skirt will be at or below the knee, I have long legs and a curvy backside.)  I hope this review was helpful to you.

5'9"/160/36DD purchased the XL in Ecco Royal.  Color and fit are as pictured.  Please be aware this is JUNIORS sizing and would probably not fit as a loose-fit style anyone larger than me.  Sleeves are nice and long.  I might order another color.  Also, the "ecco" material has a washed, "lived-in" look to the material (slightly pilled, nubby) so if you hate that, look for something else.  I like the unfinished neckline and length.  Have not washed it yet and do expect it to shrink a little to the perfect fit. See photo.  I hope this review was helpful to you.**update** purchased in ecco wheat and ecco fuchsia colors as well.  Both the wheat and fuchsia colors fit slightly smaller than the Royal in my photo.  I will still keep them, but will not put them in the dryer.

I do love the fit and color of this item.  However, I must have gotten a defective one.  I ordered the "Grey Marble Fleece" in XXL.  I am 5'9"/160/36 DD.  It fit great (a little loose, how I like it) and the sleeves were actually long enough for my tall frame.  However (very unlike the photo) the bottom seam of this garment is so wavy and sewn so poorly that I won't even wear it.  See my photo for the strange ripple in the fabric.  I really wish this would have worked and hope the vendor sends a replacement.  This is how it looked out of the bag, which would be ok I guess for a $5 sweatshirt, but not a $30 one.  Bummed.  Hope the review and photo are helpful.  I will update if I receive a replacement.

People were not joking when they said the sizing is off.... Based on reviews, I bought the shirt in 3x my normal size.  Normally I wear a large.  I purchased the "midnight" dark blue color with the seam down the front in a 3X....yes....3X (which I NEVER wear)....and it FITS!  I have exactly the same amount of "slack" as shown in the model photo.  For reference, I am 5'9"/160/36 DD and the 3X fits me.  I can't imagine anyone bigger than me trying to wear this shirt, it would look tight and ridiculous if I were any bigger.  Hope this clears up any sizing confusion.  Also, even though I ordered the dark blue color, it is still somewhat see-though.  The fabric is really thin and if I wear a black bra, you can see it through the shirt (so I will have to go with nude perhaps.)  The length of body and sleeves is nice on my tall frame.

My pups really like this AvoDerm Duck food.  (Had a horrible experience with Taste of The Wild that made them very sick.)  When I switched to this food, my dogs immediately felt better and now that it has been two months, their coats are more shiny and healthy looking.  It sounds weird, but they actually eat less of this product because the ingredients are quality.  So The 22 lb bag of this lasts as long as a 40 lb bag of cheap food with lots of fillers.  This means they poop less and there is less mess to clean up.  Their energy is great and they free-feed because of my work schedule (so they eat whenever they are hungry).  Very happy with this food and love that it gets delivered right to my door.UPDATE:  Ordered the Trout & Pea Seafood variety for my third bag.  I had to remove a star because my pups don't seem to like that flavor as well.  If I put a bowl of the duck out and a bowl of the trout and pea, my dogs will gobble up the duck and let the trout and pea sit for a day before they eat it.  They seem to prefer the duck and the AvoDerm triple protein varieties.  I'll stick with those two flavors.  Overall,  great food made in California. <3

I have purchased other shirts from MBJ that were sized differently.  For this shirt, choose your normal size (as expected).  I tried to size down and the shirts were too small.  I am 5'9"/160/36 DD and purchased a Medium.  I really needed a Large (the medium was too small in the chest, sleeves, and stomach.)  The return cost is at buyers' expense, so be aware of that when you buy.  Also the "jade" color is not as pictured.  In the photograph, it looks to be a teal-based green.  The item I received is more kelly-green based.  The quality and cut of the shirts are great and I will be buying the Large size in other colors.  My normal shirt size is a Large.  Hope this review was helpful.**Update.  I received the Large size and they fit great in the shoulders and chest.  The Large is, however, still pretty snug in the waist/hips.  I have a 30" waist and 40" hips and you can see the top of my jeans through the shirt.  If you are pear-shaped or have larger hips, I would suggest to size up.

I bought the hand pump to go with it.  At first I sucked the water with my mouth, but only one try of aquarium water made me want to get something else.  I bought the Python Squeeze Starter Aquarium Adapter pump found here: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0017JHPA6/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o08_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1#Askhttp://www.amazon.com/Python-Squeeze-Starter-Aquarium-Adapter/dp/B0017JHPA6/ref=sr_1_3?ie=UTF8&qid=1426087932&sr=8-3&keywords=python+syphonThe hand pump fits at the small end of the tubing.  It works great for my two small 5 gallon aquariums.  The guy saying this was "too big" for a 10 gallon is mistaken since both my aquariums are tiny.  You just need to read the instructions and know how to use it.  I can take the water out of my aquariums without even getting my hands wet now.  And for partial water changes, I can suck the dirty water out from the gravel and top off with clean water (all while leaving my fish in the tank).  Works great!  And in the event of the zombie apocalypse, I'll use it to syphon gasoline. ;)

If you have long hair, I'm sure you've heard that you should never brush it while it's wet. You should only comb it gingerly, fussing from the bottom up to remove the snags and snarls you get when you shampoo. On the other hand, you probably want to spend less than two hours detangling your hair.This brush is the answer that works for me. The bristles are firm enough to remove the tangles, but soft enough that they keep me from getting terrible and ugly split ends. I don't yank on wet hair of course, just brush it gently from the bottom. The many bristles do the work of detangling a bunch of hair at a time, which makes the job go faster. I have nearly waist length hair, and it takes me less than five minutes to detangle and brush my hair. My hair is very, very fine; so I can't say that this would work for everyone. But it works for me, and if you have very fine, long hair, I expect that it would work for you.The fact that there are two brushes is wonderful, and very necessary. That's because if you have another family member with long hair (as I do), that person will steal it in no time.

I bought this pulse oximeter because I am a severe asthmatic, and I don't always recognize when I need medical attention. For years, I had a pulse oximeter like they use in the doctor's office, which is the size of a paperback book and weighs about a pound. I got this one for my purse, because lugging around the big oximeter is inconvenient and it's impossible to take a reading without attracting attention.However, I was very concerned that this little guy wouldn't be accurate enough to keep me safe. After all, it cost me about 1/10th what I paid for the big "hospital type" oximeter (and that was used! My doc told me that what I paid was the deal of a lifetime) If you're using this to keep track of your stats while you're exercising, a percent or two reading that's off doesn't mean a lot. For me, a percentage point is the difference between treating myself and calling an ambulance.No fear. When I got this, I put it on one finger, and put the professional model on the next finger. They were exactly alike. At my next hospital visit, I compared this little guy with the giant cart model oximeter that also takes your temperature and blood pressure. Both had pulse and oxigen readings that were exactly alike. I now feel I can trust this little guy when I go out.Another nice touch was the purple rubber cover that came with the oximeter. It's not 100% necessary, but it will protect the meter from everyday bumps, whacks and squishes as it travels around in a purse or pocket. It also takes the writing of a Sharpie, so I was able to personalize my pulse oximeter. That way, it won't grow legs the next time I'm in the emergency room. :-)

These are the most amazing little tools I've ever seen, and I don't know how I gave myself a manicure without them. They are little markers which have extra tips in one end, and a barely moist tip on the other. The barely moist tip removes any smudges you make when you polish your nails, leaving your cuticles and fingers so clean that it looks as if you never made any mistakes at all.I sometimes have shaky fingers when I'm applying polish, and there are sometimes smears and globs on my fingers after my nails dry. I've tried the suggested solution of dipping a cotton swab in nail polish remover and using that to clean your hands. But that doesn't work - the swab dries too quickly, and the bendy stick can cause problems all its own. This has straight acetone (the active ingredient in most nail polish removers), and there is enough in the body of the marker to remove any number of smears. After removing dark purple mistakes, I understood why they gave me extra nibs: using the dark purple nib to remove light nail polish would just make a mess.The package of five pens seems very generous. I had enough pens to give to a friend, my daughter and my Mom, and I still have two for myself. With all the extra nibs, I should have enough to clear up months worth of nail polish flubs!

I was highly disappointed with this novella. This book is another volume in "The Selection"  series, which has been so popular. It supposedly tells the tale of the Prince Maxon's mother, Amberly, and how she managed to snag Prince Clarkson, who would become King upon his marriage.***Spoilers*** Stop reading now if you don't want to know what happens!Unlike "The Selection", this doesn't have the charm of America and Maxon's courtship and all the ups and downs they have before they finally tie the knot. It also doesn't portray Clarkson as the abusive beast he turns out to be. This is a guy who beats his son until his whole back is a network of scars, if you remember from "The Selection."The novella really felt a lot more like an outline of a book to be written, with so little fleshed out. I wanted to know about Amberly's life and family before the selection, and how she felt filling out the application. I also wanted to find out about her feelings upon leaving her family and the farm where she worked, and shy she worked so much harder than her caste should have determined.This booklet left me with far more questions than it answered, and left me annoyed that I didn't get the rest of the book.

These are delicious. They have the lovely color of fresh apricots, and I was unable to detect any trace of sulfur, which is the usual way of keeping apricots from browning as they dry. I thought that the apricots were dried to the perfect level, with just the right amount of chewiness and not so tough that I feared for the fillings in my teeth. They taste delectable, and the four, one-pound bags are very convenient. There's no chance of the apricots going stale while you eat them, as there would be if they were all in one bag.

This brace was terribly uncomfortable, because it bunched and rolled within seconds of my putting it on. I was unable to find a setting that kept it in place. I had hoped that it would support my back enough that I could exercise, but because I cannot move while wearing it, it's fairly useless. In this photo, they show the brace worn over clothing, so I tried that as well, without success. It took a little longer to bunch up, but in the end, it couldn't be worn over clothing, either. I'd pass on this one.

When I got these towels, I gasped. They are certainly the nicest dish towels I've ever seen, by far. The damask of the top part is clearly visible, even more so than in the picture, and the fleur de lis in the trim coordinates with the rest of the towel. I was most surprised by the black towel. I'm sure I've never seen a black dish towel before. I found it the most concerning, considering how much black cotton usually runs.  I washed that with the dark laundry, and the other two with light colored laundry. There were no problems, although the towels didn't soften much at all, and are not absorbant. They're going to need many more washes before they stop being decorative and start being useful.

I wish I could write a better review for this book. It's made for use in the bathroom, to read in the limited time one has in there. I've been putting other Bathroom Readers on the hamper in our bathroom for our family members to entertain themselves during the time they're in there. But this one isn't getting used. I asked why, especially because I'm not reading it either, and wanted to know if my family members had the same reason."It's just too big!" my daughter complained. "I can barely life it before I'm done!"Bingo. I didn't read it for the same reason. It's way too heavy and the hardback format makes it hard to handle on your lap.I'm sure it's a good book otherwise. Too bad it probably will go unread.

I never knew that one wasn't supposed to use polish remover to thin old nail polish until I read it in an article about the beauty things I was doing wrong. Gee - that's why it never worked well. I had always thought it was because the polish was old and nothing could save it. So I bought this - in the smallest possible container available. I saw offers for containers of up to a quart of thinner, which is hopefully more than I'd need in a lifetime! I'm sure that nail salons are glad for that option, though.I had a polish had thickened significantly and was no longer usable, although it wasn't to the point where it was solid. I figured that would be the perfect trial for this thinner. I opened the package and found a nail-polish sized bottle and a separate dropper with a screw-on cap that fits the bottle of thinner.I thre away the normal cap for the thinner, although on second thought, that probably wasn't the smartest thing to do - the dropper bottle isn't nearly as solid as the cap in preventing evaporation!Back to the thinner - it worked perfectly. Two droppersful were enough to make the old nail polish as thin and smooth as new polish, and it took no real time at all. I'm sure that I'll be purchasing a larger bottle next time!

The picture on the package shows a Manga girl, with four triangular lashes on the top and bottom of her eye. Unfortunately, with the way this product clumped, that's about the look I got - four lashes on the top and four on the bottom of the eye!The next day (yeah, I'm a glutton for punishment, but I do try to judge these things fairly), I used this product on my right eye, and opened a new tube of my normal mascara and used it on my left eye. By the end of the day, I got tired of hearing people ask me if I was all right. The Manga mascara made me look as if I had hurt my eye. It didn't smudge, it just looked "wrong" to the people around me.I have to give it three stars because it did what it said it would: it didn't smudge, didn't wear off during the day, and gave me a look just like the one on the package. I can't give it more stars because I prefer to look like I have more than eight eyelashes.

The people at Belkin who designed this should be given heaps of praise for what I consider to be the excellent job they've done in designing this case. It adds full laptop functionality to your iPad Air without adding the weight of a laptop. (although this case is no featherweight)  After reading some of the reviews, I was concerned that this case would have connectivity issues, but that hasn't happened. If there were problems, Belkin has corrected them by now (June, 2015)For me, the most important part of this case was the keyboard. I was concerned that the keys would be mushy, rubbery or slow, or that the battery would give out every couple of hours. Not to fear - the keyboard had the same familiar feel I've gotten used to with the various Apple laptops I've used, and I can make it give you the same "click" I'm used to. Most of all, this keyboard had all the keys I have on my laptop, so I have no problem going back and forth between machines.There are three levels of backlighting on the keyboard, if you like working in a dark or dim room. I found it distracting, so I simply disabled it. The battery life is supposed to be a year, but I can't comment on that, since I've only been using it for a few days. But it doesn't die every couple of hours, as I feared - it keeps a charge long enough to get where you're going. (4 days). I prefer to keep the keyboard and the iPad together while I'm typing, but I tried to type this while the two were separated and had no problems.I love the two tilt angles. One is very comfortable for me, and is what I'll probably use most of the time. In the past, I've been stuck trying to get an acceptable angle with all sorts of things propping up the tablet. Having an angle to fit me is a huge benefit.I like the aluminum that this is made of (the case, not the keyboard). It's not too heavy, and should be very protective. On the day, hopefully far into the future, when I stop using this cover or the iPad, I should be able to simply drop the cover in my weekly recycle bin, and hold onto the keyboard for the annual "computer recyclables" collection. If reuse isn't an issue to you, then the extra weight this adds could be problematic. There are lighter cases out there.This isn't the least expensive solution to the lack of a keyboard on an iPad by a long shot. However, it has proven to be the least problematic, most useful solution I've found. The designers of this cover/keyboard made this with someone like me in mind, and for that, I am very thankful (and happy).

I got this book to review, and was not sure what to think before I got it. I made sure I didn't look up anything about the author or the book in advance, so I wouldn't make up my mind before reading. As it turns out, the author is a Presbyterian Protestant minister with four adult children, one of whom is gay. When that child "came out" to him and his wife, he began a spiritual journey to discover exactly what the Bible says about same-sex love. His first stop was the Bible, checking out the verses that appear to command Christians about homosexuality. (Anyone who has done the slightest research in this area will know these verses, as they are trotted out each time anyone wants to discriminate against gay people) Rev. Regele used the newest translations available, and began to read while keeping in mind the norms of society at the time each verse was written.At the beginning of the book, the Pastor asks nine questions of himself, ranging from whether homosexuality is biologically caused or is a personal choice to is same sex marriage acceptable from a Christian standpoint and whether being LGBT makes one ineligible for leadership in a Christian church. He then discusses each question as he sees it, then talks about the Bible verses that appear to discuss the question, and talks about the question in light to the place and time when it was written, and how the verse should be viewed today, in an entirely different time, place and political atmosphere.I believe that this book was written for two distinct sets of people: church/prayer groups looking for a text to guide them through these questions and how their church should handle them; and/or Christian parents of gay children. Fortunately, Rev. Regele has experience in both points of view. The book is organized in a way that discusses each question, then summarizes the questions and the answers to which he's been led in the last chapter. He definitely knows how strapped people can be for time, and even suggests which portions one can skip while still getting to the "meat" of the question.Rev. Regele includes copious notes and references, as well as the results of a survey that encompasses some of his questions. Even with all of this material, the book has been kept to approximately 260 pages (I read a review copy. The final book may be a little shorter or longer). It's not the kind of book you can sit and read in a couple of hours, though. I found myself stopping and reflecting after reading short sections, which is why it took me almost three weeks to read it.In the end, I don't think it matters which viewpoint you're coming from; this book isn't going to change your mind. It will give you a researched, well-thought out and prayed over view by someone who has more experience in this matter than most of us. I think it's a very valuable book for any Christian who is searching for answers about what Scripture is saying, although in the end, each reader is going to make up his/her mind.

Spoilers ahead -- Please skip if you don't want to know!I got this book because the lead character and I are multi-generational residents of Quincy, MA. Her Quincy, of course, was fictional, and I live in the real world (or so it seems). However, the author has definitely lived here, because so much of her fictional Quincy collides with the real thing. Naturally, the story cannot match the real city in every way, but there are many remarkable similarities.The lead character, Mimi, was born in Quincy as one of seven daughters, her mother dying in childbirth. One child was sent to away to Ireland to be "taught how to behave" and never returned. Later, Mimi and her sisters learn that the missing child died of malnutrition in Ireland. Mimi has few memories of her childhood, except that she loathed her stepmother (brought in so her Da could raise his daughters after his wife died), because the woman was cruel. Mimi has some passing memories that the stepmother beat her and worse, but very little besides that. But one of her sisters grandchildren is doing a family tree for a school assignment, and therein lies the beginning of her troubles.  During the day, she cannot remember much of her family life hen she sleeps, she dreams of her now deceased older sisters prompting her to remember - remember everything.During the day, she has other problem: One of her daughters thinks she's got Alzheimers or is going broke and wants her to live in an assisted living facility. Two of her other daughters sided with her husband during her divorce (about which she is bitter), so she has mainly written them off. Another daughter refuses to speak with her, so she doesn't bother to try and start any sort of dialogue. And so on. Mimi has such rough relationships with both her daughters and her sister that I got confused as to who was who.The only bright spot in her life is her budding friendship with the janitor of her building, Dick Duffy, a WWII veteran who walks with a limp, but is otherwise oh-so-charming. They become friends (and perhaps more than that), but Dick has a secret or two of his own. While Mimi is remembering her own secrets, Mr. Duffy is trying to work out how he'll tell Mimi about his secret without losing her.The story winds up exactly as you suppose it will, with Mimi remembering everything, Mr. Duffy telling is secret, and everything is mostly resolved.Maybe. I found it charming at first that Mimi and Dick spoke quite formally to one another; but even after they slept together? Come on!Also, when exactly did this story take place? Some of the details are 20 years old: the Fore River Bridge, for example, was replaced by a "temporary bridge" and is only now being reconstructed, and WWII veterans are not in their sixties, but in their eighties. The price of real estate is current, however, as are some of the news stories. Ms. MacDonell is 100% right about the current state of the shipyard (formerly a major Quincy employer) I felt as if the story should have been set in the 1980's, where a 68 year old Mimi would really have been able to remember the Depression.I was left wanting more - how does Mimi reconcile her relationship with her daughters? She's "okay" with a couple of them, but that's it. And her possible strokes? Does she recover? She believes that the brain anomalies on her MRI will become happy swirls and rainbows, but I'd have liked to hear about some medical confirmation. Also, does she end up having to leave her home?

Yummy. These apricot dices were moist but not gooey, and the flavor of fresh apricots sang out when I tasted them. I used the dices in a recipe for apricot nut bread, and the apricots stole the show. Then I used them in a spread with dates and pineapple. The apricots overpowered the dates, but was mostly hidden by the pineapple. After a few days, the apricot flavor emerged.Overall, I was very, very happy with these apricots, and will likely buy them again once they're gone.

Secret Confession:  I love lace curtains, and nearly every curtain in my home is lace, or at least has lace underneath drapes. I spent some of my growing up in a part of Germany where everyone has lace curtains. They come in many, many varieties, and my Oma (grandmother) would gossip with her neighbor friends about who had nice lace, and who had the cheap stuff.When I saw these curtains offered here, I couldn't have been happier. We have a sliding door in our apartment that shows all of Boston Harbor, and lace curtains have set it off perfectly.
