The floral lace is pretty, but shows enough of the Harbor that you can enjoy both. I swear it even cut the noise from the street a bit. The fabric is 100% polyester, and is heavy enough that the sun won't destroy them. The edges are especially well done with a heavy satin stitch accentuating the hem. I swear, Oma couldn't have found fault with them.I'm happy, too. Curtains that fit beautifully, will wear well, and are easy to wash (throw in machine with detergent and oxygen bleach.) I couldn't ask for more. Except for my Oma to come and tell me that she likes them

Wow. I put off reading this book, thinking that the comics, anime, and Internet  stuff was just meant to be a publicity measure, and not a vital part of the plot.  I should have read it the moment it arrived from Amazon.  It's that good.The story begins with two somewhat unpopular new girls who become best friends by writing their own secret graphic novel, called "Princess X" Princess X is not your typical princess: she goes around with a samurai sword (almost), red Chuck Taylor high tops, and blue hair. She has many adventures, with Libby (the amazing, rich one) doing the drawing and May (the introverted, less than middle class one) doing all the writing. The girls kept a small portion of their things in their shared school locker and the bulk of their Princess X material in the large closet at Libby's home.Then disaster strikes: Libby's mother drives her car off a bridge and both Libby and her mother are drowned. May is inconsolable, and when she finally comes around to get their Princess X stuff out of Libby's closet, it's all gone! The maid (told you Libby was rich!) said that her father disposed of all the personal effects, then sold the house's contents and moved to Michigan with his new fiance. May falls into a deep depression which isn't helped by the fact that her parents divorce shortly thereafter, and May needs to move with Mom to Atlanta. (quite a way from Seattle, where the story starts out).A few years later, May is in Seattle, on visitation with her father for the summer. While walking along her old stomping grounds and missing Libby, she begins to see "Princess X" stickers and web sites that ask "Who is Princess X/" May is astonished, and begins to explore the case. She soon learns that everything she has been told about Libby's death is a lie.  She becomes obsessed with finding the truth.... And that's where I stop. I once wrote a couple of book reports for people, so I now only write down part of the plot.But I did find this book absolutely riveting, and I couldn't put it down until I discovered the answers for myself. I found out that there really is a Princess X web site, and lots more, and that the "Internet Breaks" are a real thing. The book I had first thought was hokey and juvenile is a great read. If you like being online, great friendships, and a cool mystery, this is just right for you. Anyone from a top reading level fifth grader on up should have no problem reading it, and for the parents, there is no gratuitous sex or violence. Heck, if you can bear to give up the book when you're done, your parents might want to spend an evening or two reading it!

I LOVE this little guy, while acknowledging it's not 100% perfect. I own the big brother to this pressure cooker (the 8 qt.) and was delighted to see that they fixed one main problem: opening and closing the lid. While the other pot has a lid that supposedly tilts upward to see the food, it made the locking and unlocking function very difficult.  You had to have the heavy (and often hot) lid in the exact place, at the exact angle, or it wouldn't close, which is really important when using a pressure cooker.  I saw that this cooker allows you to easily open the lid, by trying it many times in my kitchen. If you are short, as I am, this is important because when the cooker is on your kitchen counter, you're doing all this at eye level, and hot steam is in your eyes.I wish that the manual came with a bit more of a cookbook. There are a very few pages of recipes and some "helpful hints"  but that's it. If you have used a pressure cooker before this one, there will be far less of a learning curve. I was a complete newbie when it came to pressure cookers, so I started with some of our favorites: pot roast, soups and when they came our perfectly, I did a bit more experimenting. So far, everything has come out deliciously. If you've never used a pressure cooker and want a real treat, try some vegetables, setting the time for a few minutes less than you would in a microwave oven. The first time I did this, we even ran out of vegetables at dinner (a first).My other complaint with this pressure cooker is that the internal liner (where you cook all your food), is not stick resistant with a coating like Teflon(r). They have a nonstick coating on the outer liner, which makes it twice as confusing to have it missing from the inner pot. Food isn't supposed to touch the outer liner, yet it has a nonstick coating. (huh?!?) The booklet that comes with the cooker states that the pot has a nonstick liner, but it doesn't have one. Perhaps I got a rare and collectable un-coated pot, like those postal stamps that are printed upside down. (No, I didn't think so, either.)Despite this, the food that I've make in this cooker is delicious. Because none of the water cooks away, the food has a more concentrated flavor. It also means that you add almost no water when cooking. I just use the tiniest bit of water at the bottom of the pot, but not no water, as the pressure cooker depends of the higher boiling temperature of water when under pressure to work. That also means that you cannot overfill the pot, meaning six qts. is a maximum, even though you could probably add another quart or two to the inner pot liner. The water needs someplace to boil and convert into steam.It might not be perfect, but it's darned close, and I still love it.Edited to correct "creative" spelling and grammar. I should know not to write reviews when I'm operating without two nights' sleep. So sorry.

Great kit - a bottle of clear nail polish, one of a white-tinted matter underpolish, and the last has a blue cuticle conditioner. I've tried them all, and they all work beautifully. The clear one is an amazing nail protector. I like clear nail polish for daytime wear, and this is as shiny and pretty a clear as you'll find. It is also holding my nail together - one of them mostly tore off the other day and I tried putting another coat of the nail protectant on and using it as a sort of glue. It has worked perfectly, and no one knows which nail is torn - and I'm not telling!One gotcha - the writing on the bottles and the instruction sheet is almost unreadable because it is so tiny. This is because the package uses about four different languages on it, and it's not like a nail polish bottle is overly spacious anyway. I got out my glasses and a magnifying glass and it was fine. Nothing really funky about the instructions, but it would be nice to be able to read it easily.Overall, a fine purchase of great products at a fair price. Can't really ask for much more.

Huge and Unwearable. I have a black pair of these shoes and they fit fine, so I stupidly thought that buying the same size in a different color would be okay. Silly me.  I put them in the closet after purchase, waiting for spring to arrive.  Several months later, I decided to wear these with a pair of shorts. No dice. I put them on and they fell off my feet as I tried to take my first step.Now I have a pair of brand new, unwearable Propets.

This is the scariest product I have ever bought for my dog. I had head rumors that if your dog was a vigorous chewer who would bite big hunks off the bone, a piece of the bone could become lodged in the dog's digestive tract, requiring surgery or worse. I wasn't worried, my dog is the opposite of a vigorous chewer, and figured licking couldn't cause a problem.WRONG! Something in the flavor of these things made my dog start chewing vigorously for the first time in his life. As soon as I saw that, about ten seconds after he got the bone, I screamed to my daughter to grab it from the dog. My daughter is an adult, but when the dog started growling and protecting his treat (another first), she backed right off. So, I had to grab the dog, who bit the whole top off the bone in one chunk right that second. Getting the long, unbroken piece of the bone was not too terrible, but the broken-off piece was something else.  The dog tried to swallow it, and I got my hand in his mouth. He was trying to keep the piece of bone and bite me at the same time. I had to try and give him the Heimlich maneuver and keep my hand from being that days' lunch at the same time.  Somehow, I got the big piece of bone out of his throat and I didn't get too badly bitten.If the dog had swallowed the piece of bone, he would have asphyxiated, no doubt about it.  That this bone would break so darned easily is a crime, in my opinion. IF YOU LOVE YOUR DOG, DO NOT GIVE HIM OR HER THESE TREATS! "Healthy Edibles" my left toe! Scary Bones that will Kill Your Dog is more like it.Save your money and stay away.

Not that this is world peace or anything, but for a wire corner shelf, this is as good as it gets. Not only is the wire made of Stainless Steel, to prevent rusting, the design of the shelf includes a guard to make sure that what you put on the shelf, stays on the shelf. But the biggest deal are the "suction cups."  They make sure that the shelf you put in the corner of your shower doesn't come crashing down onto your toes on a chilly, dark morning.The key to making sure that this goal is met is to combine suction with a removable adhesive. It grips into the smooth, often glassy surface of a bathroom shower to hold tight. If you happen to have the more modern matte tiles, special squares of adhesive plastic are enclosed to make sure that you have the proper surface for the best adhesion of the suction cups. After I installed my shelf, I discovered that its ten lb (4.5kilo) weight limit is more than adequate for  shampoo, conditioner, facial cleanser and a wet washcloth. I don't know how you would fit ten lbs of items on such a small shelf unless you piled rocks on your shelf!All in all, I am more than happy with my little corner shelf I plan to purchase a few more for my mother who has had inferior shelves in the past which always fall down while she is in the shower!  Never again.

This book took me a while to get used to, mostly because of the protagonist's self-absorbtion.  Richard, the protagonist is a slacker and a user, but he's glad to describe all the flaws he sees in people. He accepts all all sorts of good things without even thanking his benefactors. Almost everything is due to him so that he might finish his thesis, and the project his father was never able to finish. Even in the face of horrendous tragedy, he thinks about himself, what he wants...I wanted to like this book. It is literary, intelligent, and integrates the third and last crusade of Richard "The Lion Hearted", King of England. The historical part the novel is the understandable and coherent part of the book. It's the other part, the modern stream of consciousness that the current Richard writes that is difficult.  I found the character to be totally unlikeable, even though he finds what he's looking for and is happy with that. When I finished the book, I asked myself "Is that all there is?" Even though I had read somewhere around 350 pages.I hope for the present day Richard that he finds the answers to the questions that haunt him, and that he does a better job than his father. First, he has to learn how to join the world and learn to give, not just take and treat it all as if it was due to him.

Most kids' scissors are lousy. They are poorly made, don't cut well, and hurt if you are left handed and aren't assigned one of the two pair of "leftie" scissors in the class.Not these. They cut paper, cloth, thin plastic (like a milk jug or a sheet of "Shrinky Dinks"), and hair (warn the little guys if you don't want a bald kitten). For an adult, they cut yarn, Spectra fishing line (for needlework or beadwork), or thread. There aren't many light-duty things that won't cut easily with these scissors. The soft grips are nice when cutting oaktag or heavier weight items. The grips are comfortable on either right or left hands, and don't even need that little "L" stamped on the blade!This size package should cover half a classroom or so, and I can't imagine them lasting less than several years. Even if you're considering supplying a Brownie troop or a big family or a person who loses the "good scissors" on a regular basis (like me) this would be a great purchase.

I have long hair. REALLY long hair that ends about two inches from my behind, so a great conditioner is important to me. You might even say that a great conditioner is one of life's essentials in my mind. And this is one fabulous conditioner.  It seems to have sealed all of my split ends (even though I cut off an inch or two every month or three, split ends are usually a fact of life for someone with hair as long as mine.But not today. I washed my hair with my normal Pantene shampoo, then used this conditioner, especially on the ends.  When I rinsed it off a couple of minutes later, it was astonishing. I could comb my hair with my fingers, and when I got out of the shower, I could comb my hair with no tangles. After it dried, I was amazed. My hair looks as if I never did anything with it but go to the hairdresser and let my hair glisten in the sun.I think I now have a new conditioner.

What would you do if you were two seconds away from dying, and your mother said a secret spell to save your life? But this secret spell caused all sorts of evilness to be set loose in the world: blood raining from the skies, Death Walkers who try to eat souls, and worst of all (to you, anyway), your mother disappears and you're only twelve?Alex and his best friend, Ren, who is also twelve, are headed to London because they've heard that the blood rain is happening there, too; and maybe this is a way that Alex can find his mother. His cousin, Luke, is on the same flight, headed for athletic camp. Luke's parents are Alex's guardians, so the less Luke knows about this, the better. Luke has different ideas about being totally left out.And then they hear about people disappearing.This book is a great summer read for kids who are too old for Harry Potter, but want to read about magic, scary things and mysteries. I am a grown person and there are even a few moments where I jumped out of my chair! Danger and creepy things are around every corner. My advice:  never forget to be kind whenever you can! (What does that mean?  Read the book and find out!)It would be nice if you read the first book in the Tomb Quest series, but I didn't and I knew what was happening without a lot of guessing. But, getting the first book would make the rest of the series (all five parts!) make a whole lot more sense. The book isn't long, since I read it in an evening, but the author sure packs an awful lot of action in just a few chapters. Most kids between elementary and middle school up through middle school will like this, especially if their teachers hate it. :-)

A couple of years ago, I discovered this kind of kitchen towel, which isn't terrycloth, but dries plenty of dishes anyway, and leaves no lint. The cloth is thin, a little thinner than I'd like, because I want my kitchen towels to last for many years, not "almost a year." The description says that they are cotton-rayon (not my favorite blend) to 100% cotton. Still, which one is right?Before laundering, the towels started out at 19" x 28". The color was a bright red stripe on white (not the blue in the picture). After washing in warm water with Tide Free detergent, they shrunk significantly. (will edit when I find the tape measure again) However, I recently bought some tea towels that started the same size as these did, and after a few washes, those came in at 13" x 20, and looked years old.These look great. I am not in love with the color red (especially when the towels were blue in the picture), but they only had minimal fading and minimal shrinkage. Unlike the other ones, I think that they should last in my kitchen a long time.

This makeup is perfect for oily skin, which is something quite amazing. It dried very quickly to an extremely matte but not 100% poreless finish. (I haven't found any makeup that gets rid of the pores on my right cheek) This comes close, though, and dries to a powdery finish. None of my facial oil showed, and I put it on unwashed, greasy skin the first time. It remained greaseless for hours, which is also pretty amazing. When I applied the makeup, it dried within seconds into a powder, and was somewhat difficult to blend. If I knew where I wanted it to be beforehand and applied it accordingly, it was fine.So, why did I give it three stars instead of five? Because of the color. The ivory I got matched my facial skin, for a few seconds.  Within a few moments of application, I saw the color change to a slightly orange cast, which is the exact opposite of what I want. It remained orange despite the fact that it remained completely matte and powdery. I was working and sweaty, which normally causes my makeup to shine and turn really orange.  It stayed the same color (slightly orange) Then, I put on a light coat of ivory facial powder, which hid the orange.Washing off the makeup was a dream. I used my normal facial soap and water, and it removed every trace instantly. If every foundation was this easy to remove, I'd wear it more often. Something that stays in place all day, yet removes with soap and water is very special.To me, having to add another makeup to hide the bad effect of the first makeup is a problem. But, if you can't find anything else that stays oil-free, then this would be an option.

To understand this book:Lettice Knollys and Beatrice are two separate people. One existed and one is the star of this book. I should have said that at the beginning of each chapter!Queen Elizabeth I of England had many companions/maidservants around her at all times. If unmarried they were called her Maids of Honor, if married, they were Ladies in Waiting. The Queen was never left alone - she even had a Maid or a Lady while she slept, sleeping with her on a trundle. Many teens at or approaching marriageable age would spend some time as a Maid of Honor as a kind of "finishing school" that not only polished their manners, but also let them be seen by the People That Mattered and hopefully enabled them to find a rich, titled husband. That last bit was the supreme prize. If he was not a total scumbag was icing on the cake. A decent looking and kind man was more than could be dreamed for.Beatrice Knowles is a Maid of Honor, and the protagonist of this story. She is bit of a flirt, and is able to get any guy to spill his guts. This is _very_ handy skill at any time, and priceless beyond imagining in Tudor England, where people would keep their secrets while being tortured. Beatrice is about to wind up her service to the Queen and marry her intended, a Lord Cavanaugh. Before she can skedaddle, all hell breaks loose between England and its feisty neighbor to the North, Scotland. The wedding is put on hold, and the Queen sends Beatrice to get all the dirt she can get from Alasdair McLeod. Because this is a historical romance, you can probably guess what happens.I really enjoyed this book, despite the formula must use to become a historical romance. The action moves swiftly, and many of the real Maid of Honor and Ladies in Waiting weave in and out, interacting with our two fictional characters. Real events are included as well, like England and Spain's ongoing hatred of one another. The problems that England had in switching from Catholicism to the Anglican Church are well treated and the struggle the Queen had in forcing her subjects to view her as their conduit to God.The biggest problem I had with the whole book was that I kept mixing up Beatrice Knowles with Lettice Knollys, a real cousin and Maid of Honor to Queen Elizabeth. I have read extensively  about the Elizabethan court, and when Beatrice did something I kept thinking, "Lettice didn't do that, she married Robert Dudley in secret and was banished for life by the Queen."

This was an out and out waste of money. It was far too small across the shoulders (why?), and had an odd odor. Then, when I tossed it in the hamper, it left black stains on a wet towel. I don't dare wash it for few that everything I own would be darkened.Oh well, it didn't fit, had multiple other problems. Good thing it was very, very inexpensive. That way, I didn't feel guilty when I tossed it.

I love this story, even though it's a little corny. Poor, unloved orphan ex-con finds love with insane, unwanted bastard child.  Really?!?  Oh Come On.But Ms. Spencer's writing is good enough that the story is a great one, even teasing a few tears out of my granite hard, heartless eyes. I haven't read anything else she's written, having found my original copy of this on an airplane and just recently rediscovered it. It still coaxed a few tears out of me, and I loved the story just as well as ten years ago.If you're looking for a slightly corny, ever so sweet romance, this is it.  Give it a whirl.

Great features, OK look.***Update 8/30/15****After having it for a couple of months, I've grown pretty bored with it. For a Double-Din it really does have a lot of empty face space.2 other issues that I have are faint LED lighting and the volume being pushed in for Menu.For whatever reason (and I've seen others say this on their reviews), the LED on both the keys and the face go very dim. And they do that randomly. Checked my Dim setting while it was like this and it was maxed out.When it does look normal and it's sunny outside, forget about it, you're not even going to see the clock. The color variations are nice and prevent early bordem, but still, in this 2015 they won't put animation on it?!? I feel like this would be seen in my car back in 2000. I regret not getting the Kenwood double din.However for the price, this is solid. Just very plain.

I first bought a Metra harness that fit my Trailblazer but wouldn't even power on after installation. This was b/c the radio works with the door/chime. What's pathetic is that neither Pioneer nor the Chevy dealership could tell me what the problem was. I can tell you that THIS was the solution. If you have a vehicle that has its radio and doors sync'd together, but this harness with the interface bus. This should be something that needs to be explained. Hope this helps someone. I spent an extra $38 b/c of this, plus I also need to use the after market plug in the original harness for the new CD player. So I actually did need to use both Metra products because the Interface Bus did NOT come with the connector for the aftermarket Deck.

Gift for my girlfriend. I knew she wanted another pair to replace ones that she lost. She loves these and says they're very comfortable. This comes from a woman who has 3 other different brands of sandals.

I'm a size 35 waist and ordered a 36 based on a previous review from someone that stated they fit too small. Thought it'd be a perfect fit. Couldn't have been more wrong. Just order your true size (without lying to yourself), and you should be fine. Person gave them self credit b/c he doesn't know his waist size.Shorts are thin, if you didn't know. You'll def need to wear briefs underneath so your man parts aren't showing. Good length. I'm 6' and they came right to my knees. Overpriced to me. Paying for the name brand.****Update 6/8/15****I received the correct size (35) in the mail and they fit just fine. I recommend ordering your normal waist size for these Boardshorts. Don't listen to any reviews stating that they fit too big. Some people don't know where their waist is.

It totally fits in to the factory harness no problem. However, b/c Chevy decided to be mentally challenged, they make it nearly impossible for you to change over to an aftermarket deck. The car is fit to ONLY work with the CD player in the car. Not just a stock one, the one in your car. The wiring is hooked up with Onstar and everything interacts with your door. If you've ever noticed, the radio doesn't shut off until your door is opened. I just sent out for another harness that is equipped with some sort of Chime receiver. It's also available on Amazon and supposedly works around the stock radio issue. I'll update once solved. Hope this helps. I know I needed it myself with little answers. Nothing like installing it yourself only to find that it doesn't even have power.
nothing to this belt. Not sure why it's not sold for $5 like the other sellers. Poor material that is hard and thin. Paid $9. You're welcome.

I was happy that I even ordered the correct one for my car. However, I had to break almost every single tab on each side. Made me think, why can't they just make different ones instead of one. Why should I pay for it and still have to do all the work. It's like the last guy on the assembly line quit that day.So this also wouldn't stay clipped in on the side and left too much open space on the top and bottom.Thank god I have a heavy bag after installing with this.

You always take a chance when you buy clothing without seeing or trying it on. I was pleased with how this hat for upon arrival. Good color (just like the original picture. It's not a worn/faded green.), and easy to adjust. There isn't a wide open back on it because of the strap either. I never liked a huge hole showing the back of anyone's head with an adjustable. Looks sloppy and goofy. This doesn't.I would say, though, that the brim is a little on the flimsy side. Be careful if you like to form your brim. It might fold instead of curve. Besides that and being overpriced for a brands name,  All-in-all, very nice.

Yes, this is a great classic game. Same Tiger Woods but better than most. I'm not going to give it 5 or even 4 stars, however. This is because of the annoyance, repetitive, and sometimes inaccurate features of the game.I had been playing Tiger '08 for a few years and got bored with it. Saw the reviews on all Golf games and this came out best. Graphics have improved (even though when you're playing through a windy front 9 the wind somehow blows the tree truck the same as the leafs). Tiger Challenge has also improved. I wouldn't say it's more challenging than most, but you don't have to worry about finishing Bronze, Silver, or Gold in events anymore. Was pointless anyways.You'll have Tiger's  caddy as your golf pro trainer. I thought this would be cool, at first, but quickly realized that this was a pain in the neck. I'd say after every other event, they demote your built up attributes for pretty much no reason, then make you do multiple practice challenges to re-lift your attributes for Power, Accuracy, Short Game, and Putting. NO Power Boost or Spin attributes anymore. It's already provided when playing (which is a good thing). But the worst part about this training is that it doesn't matter if you played a tournament going -50. It'll still demote your attributes. You can hit the ball off the tee, hit every fairway, and average 370 yds and still, he'll tell you that your power isn't where it should be. It is VERY frustrating. That's really the only bad part of the game. If they made that part more accurate and less predictable and unfair, it'd be a 5-star game.

Makes for as good a shave as I would get with pre shave oil. It also doesn't make a greasy mess. I expect it to last a long time. A little does go a long way, but not the "dime size" amount that some say. More like a quarter.

I've found out quickly that this camera burns through battery life like our cars do gas. Highly disappointed that it takes 4-AA Batteries! Wow! That's right, no rechargeable or flat batteries for a Nikon camera.This part being my own fault, I've also found that camera is just too big to bring anywhere. We bought a separate carrying case for it, but it's really just another thing to lug around. Not to mention turning the camera on/off constantly between pictures kills the battery faster. For example, Disneyworld is not a place that you want to be lugging this around for a 12 hour day. Just saying, make sure you really want a big camera instead of a more convenient, pocket/purse one.

First of all, this item took 3 WEEKS to receive! Unbelievable.Second, it came in a bubble wrap envelope with no paperwork whatsoever. Not even the receipt of purchase.Third, and most important, it doesn't work at all! I couldn't even get to the point of putting the kinect sensor on it because a small amount of pressure makes this thing fold. If it clicked into place, then it would be fine...but it doesn't. Disappointed 👎

Fits perfect, thank god. Never bought a pair of Nautica jeans before.I'm 34 and bought these to go with all clothes that are popular for my age group. Needed a replacement pair of light-wash jeans. These were a good choice. They aren't tough or stiff, and not too thin either. Reasonable pocket depth, good zipper and button.

I bought this for my lady friend because she's interested in all things disney. Thought this would be a nice add-on birthday gift. Honestly, she doesn't seem that interested. It looks like she got about 30 pages in. I figure it just may not be that interesting.

My foot size is a true 12 1/2. I bought the Chestnut pair in 12 since there wasn't a half size. The size and overall fit is perfect! So, if you're buying a pair, you might want to order a half size smaller than your true size. I bought mine through the Uggs website. Always be careful with where your product comes from on Amazon. They may be second hand or refurbed.These are really impressive and the leather is so soft that they already feel broken in. I've only worn them twice and received multiple complements. There won't be another shoe walking around like this one. Definitely has its own style.The only thing that I was concerned with was the color. Seemed like it was a light tan/blonde color with a darker toe. It ended up being a little darker than I thought but still looks really awesome. It's pricey but I plan on having them for a long time. If you don't like the Chestnut, buy the Black for over $100 cheaper. I might!

These work pretty good when you're buying a hat online that you are unable to try on first. In fact I'm still buying several hats online that are all different sizes so I'm finding myself needing more of these.
If you like John Wayne movies add this to your collection. It's funny, action-packed and is a good story.

First of all the brim of the hat is way too long. It does not even line up with the center seem, so it looks off when you're looking at somebody. Secondly it comes down to low to where it pushes my ears. Third I'm not a fan of the hard material in the front of the hat that gives it shape. They should just leave that part out and let form naturally. I don't even wear it anymore because it just feels so unnatural, and I'm sick of trying to adjust it on my head every time I wear it out.

This is a nice patch that I actually had sewn on to a hat. It's not made to be on a hat and I had a really hard time finding someone that would actually see it on. But hey I have a custom-made Coast Guard hat.
I noticed that the right glove fits different around the thumb. It actually digs in because it's too tight. Got to be a quality issue. why would the left foot different than the right?

The kids, ages 3 to 8, played with these briefly when they opened the package but the interest didn't last more than a few minutes.  They got the Play Doh "bin" out, and the 3 year old was interested in filling in the molds on the outsides of the fighters.  None of the kids thought much of the Can-heads.  The kids like Play-Doh and on a rainy day, all three will play well together for easily over an hour so the lack of interest was in the product.  They like any of the extruders (hair makers) and the "mouth" dental kit best.This isn't a good starter set, but if kids are interested in Star Wars and enjoy other Play-Doh sets, then it's a good addition.  I took one star off, came close to taking two off, for the kid's reaction to the Can-heads and when you don't use them, the fighters don't look like much.

It works!  Can't beat this for the price.  Took a chance based on the description that it might let me look in my own ear as well as quickly looking at PC board solder joints.  It is 11 mm OD, 12 mm at two ribs back about a cm from the business end.  That's small enough to fit in my very small outer ear.What makes this work is the variable focus. The magnification varies with distance from the object and it can be focused as close as 3 mm from the front to about 30 mm from the front.  That's smaller in diameter, and more range than I've found with anything similar.  Many of these inexpensive cameras have a fixed focus.
These are hard to find locally.  Happy here, they work as advertised and expected, grip fine and easy release.  I use these for the cables to a seasonal antenna.

Depends upon use.  This is a good value, perhaps the "best" value for most applications. One star off for "wimpy when wet."I compared four brands of "paper towels."  Sellars (blue) shop towels from Lowes.  Kroger brand 2 ply.  Bounty 2 ply and the Georgia Pacific Sparkle Professional Series 2 ply.  The texture, overall feel and weight of the Sparkle, Kroger and Bounty are very similar; close your eyes, you can't tell them apart.  The blue shop towel is softer, no embossing, but actually weighs twice as much.  No idea what makes this "Professional Series."The postal scale weight for similar sized towels (had to cut the Kroger brand down a bit to be comparable) was 2 grams for the Sparkle, 2 grams for Bounty, 3 grams for Kroger and 4 grams for the blue.  I put each towel in water, held it up until it stopped dripping and put it on the postal scale.  Sparkle 16 grams, Bounty 32 grams, Kroger 26 grams, blue 40 grams.  No idea if that's any kind of valid test, probably depends upon what you need it to do at the time.  To be blunt though, the Sparkle is "wimpy when wet," wad it up, it fits on a table spoon.It gets complicated because the towels differ slightly in size, number of sheets per roll and of course price.  Bottom line, all things being close to equal, Sparkle and Sellars Blue Shop are very close in price. Bounty is about twice their price but Kroger is only about 20% higher.  There are 85 Sparkle towels on a roll, 48 Bounty and 103 Kroger "half sheets" (closer to 2/3).  The Sellars Blue Shop are the overall best buy based price per sheet and being a clear absorbency winner, but you're probably not going to put those in your kitchen.  Kroger comes in second because the price is slightly more than Sparkle, but it's more absorbent and isn't "wimpy when wet."  If absorbency is your only measure Bounty comes in second on a dollars per gram of absorbency measure.So, where does that leave you... my guess is in most applications a paper towel is only fractionally consumed so "efficiency" isn't particularly relevant and occasionally grabbing a second or third towel is more than balanced by the lower price.  For general use, this Georgia-Pacific's Sparkle brand is a good value.

The first thing, of course, is the appearance.  Rugged with molded, protective corners all around and an undeniable sense of bulk.  Nothing streamlined.  It looks like a military grade paper shredder. It rolls more smoothly than anyother luggage I’ve experienced. The wheels are partially recessed, which, according to Tumi’s literature, provides “a more spacious interior compared to bags with surface mounted wheels. “  That may be true for two bags with the same overall height. The handle is really smooth.  A relatively large, rigid, plastic briefcase hook is included.The interior is divided into two compartments separated by a zippered cloth panel that opens all the way out.  This is a major differentiator; this Tumi zippers more-or-less down the middle, rather than along one edge.  When you open the bag, you get two halves rather than a “container with a zippered lid.”  The 2” expansion may be useful; the only time I’ve taken advantage of that feature is returning with souvenirs from overseas.Inside, there are two, nearly full length zippered, tie sized side pouches that also hinge along the sides as well as various straps to hold things in place.  There’s also a clothes hanger strap that appears to be designed for a Tumi hanger (2 for $35, not included).  There are full sized, zippered compartments in both halves as well.  The interior is highly functional. One zipper pull was missing, easily resolved with a small nylon zip tie.I’m a frequent traveler and I still have and occasionally use my much repaired original 1990 vintage Travelpro Rollaboard.  I compared this new Tumi to three other carry-ons we have.  The spec says the Tumi is 11.2 lbs and that may be accurate but it weighed in at 11.8 lbs. on the office postal scale.  Not quibbling, just noting that I weighed the other three bags on the same scale.  The original Travelpro came in at 10.2 lbs and the newest Travelpro was 7.9 lbs.  The 3 pound difference may not matter most of the time, but in the US carry-on bags are limited to 40 lbs. and overseas I’ve been on flights where the baggage limit was 15 kg. (33 lbs.) for domestic flights and paying a weight penalty was not an option.The next issue is the size for a carry on.  The spec says 24” X 14” X 9”. The 24” and 14” dimensions are accurate, but you’re going to have to sit on the bag to get it down to 9”.  Freestanding, without the 2” expansion, it’s 10”.  Even at 9” the linear sum of L+W+H=47, which is more than the 45” limit on some airlines (i.e. Delta). Other airlines permit the sum to be as large as 62 (i.e. Southwest).  Most US airlines have a 22” “official” limit on the long dimension and the Tumi exceeds that by 2” so theoretically could never be carried on. But if you travel much, you already know that the rules are rarely enforced in the US and the overheads may be so full there isn’t room even if the bag will fit in the compartment.  This bag will simply not fit in some overheads though; that’s why I still occasionally travel with the original Travelpro.  On regional jets it’s going to be checked anyway. For reference, the original Travelpro is 8.5” and the newer version is 10” and the original’s length is 24”, the updated version is 23”.The main functional feature of the bag is the way it opens into two halves, rather than one compartment with a lid.  It is large enough, exceeding most formal limits for size, that every boarding will be a crap-shoot as to whether it will fit or have to be checked.  Tumi is Tumi, it’s inherently pricey and you expect it to last.  The risk is, and it is discussed periodically, a single, enforced standard for carry-on baggage across all carriers.  The problem is that the proposed standard is so small, we’ll all need new luggage anyway. The warranty is 5 years.5 stars for functionality and execution.  I considered deducting a star or two for size, but between regional jets and full aircraft, carry-on is only a probability, not a certainty anyway.  Don’t be surprised though if you have to check this bag.

Nothing beats Play-Doh when you can't go outside.  This is good fun for all three grand-kids from 3 to 7 and they will all play at the same table.  The oldest is most likely to use the extruder as it is intended to be used, but other than that, these molds and tools probably aren't used as the designers intended.  We have several different Play-Doh sets, this is small and most "universal."  The one they seem to like the best extrudes "hair" on various heads, but the molds from this set are the ones they spend the most overall time with.Play-Doh is entertaining by itself, this is the best kind of set for the younger ones, say 2 to 4, as they get older the extruders are more fun, but not longer fun, the older kids still come back to the molds.

As advertised.  Revitalized the phone.  Easy fit. Perfect replacement.  I was down to 10 minutes of talk time on the old batteries if I was lucky.  Replaced four of these and I'm guessing based upon the indicator on the phone that now I could go for a couple of hours if that ever happens.

1 1/2 year old loves it. He sits on it side-saddle as often as straddle, using it as a chair while he watches everything going on around him.  He easily moves it wherever he wants to be.  He loves to push buttons, and this has buttons that make a variety of predictable noises, such as the motorcycle noise, but there are also a bunch of songs (15?) that he loves to "dance" to.  Very stable in tricycle mode as either a seat or scoot around toy.  It is light, colorful, well made and entertaining.The "proof" of this Zoom Motorbike is that it's the preferred place to sit, and push buttons, when he has other options.

Beautiful scale, easy to read.Unfortunately, accessing many of the features requires downloading software onto you smartphone and agreeing to their user agreement. Yeah, I actually read the things. The User Agreement is a showstopper for me as follows: "Your use of the Mobile App shall constitute a grant to JCS of the right, but not the obligation, to verify correctness of registration and services eligibility requirements, print, publish, broadcast and use, worldwide, in any media now known or hereafter discovered and at any time, personal information such as your name, address, picture, voice, likeness and/or biographical information for compliance and promotional purposes without additional compensation and without additional consent."You can use it as a plain digital scale without linking it to the software, works fine, accurate enough for a home scale, and is beautiful.  As a warning sticker says, it's slippery when wet, the surface is tempered glass.

This is a beautifully executed watch, especially at that price point.  The bezel is real, inside the crystal, and rotates smoothly.  No stamped sheet metal on this watch like so many others, some even more expensive.  What you notice on this immediately is the workmanship, everything around the bezel is machined and polished or knurled; you can see it and definitely feel it.  The case is 45 mm across (1 3/4") and the watch with all the links it's shipped with is 174 g (6+ oz.).  There isn't much contrast between the hands and the face, you can see that in the photo; the hands are polished gold, the face is satin gold.  The hands are luminous (Tritnite, night glow), visible in the dark but you may have to look closely.  The stop watch function is intuitive and easy to employ and reset; it is good for 60 minutes, measured in seconds on the dial and can be used for intervals, though there is no mechanism to store intervals as there would be on a digital watch. Accurate, checked against NIST time.5 stars for the quality of execution, accuracy and overall value at the price point.

Surprised how much fun the kids had with these. Even the 1 1/2 year old quickly understood that pushing the button on the bottom changed the light pattern.  At first I was disappointed, but I opened one in my well lighted office and they're not very impressive, but after dark or in a typical residential room, they're bright enough.  Reasonably durable, batteries seem to last, haven't replaced any yet and they have several hours of use.

I have three versions of this case for different cameras.  They all protect the camera well, especially the moderately delicate automatic lens cover.This comes with a strap, has a belt loop that will handle 2 3/4" and has an open internal pocket.I bought this for a Panasonic ZS50.  You can also stuff the ZS50 in a slightly smaller Case Logic DCB-302, but it's tight.

I have a couple of the Brinno cameras and have used this wall mount.  It is what it is, but that said, it's really limited.  If you want to use it to mount the camera facing out from a wall, indoors, it's fine, anything else is questionable.  It's also tricky to install...the top screw is right behind the ball head so it's difficult to mark the screw pattern, then even more difficult to actually get that top screw in.A simple angle brace with a camera mini ball head mounted on it offers far more rigidity and flexibility at a lower price.Most of us, as customers, would be ahead if Brinno skipped this attachment and knocked a few bucks off the product.

Bought 1, then a second after seeing the results.  With four Energizer lithium AA batteries and a 32 G SD card, the camera will run for a year on the 5 minute (no night pics) setting.  Amazing.  The setup is mostly intuitive, but a few minutes with the manual is helpful.  Bottom line is that this is a terrific value and the next step up in complexity and quality is a quantum leap.  There are lots of options if you only need a system to work for a few hours, but when you're interested in documenting days, weeks and months, it gets bulky and messy.  It's a very wide angle view and understand the resolution is low, so you will generally not be able to identify people you don't know; if you need a high resolution image, this isn't your choice.I have these set up monitoring the exterior of a remote cabin.If you're mounting outside, using the clear housing and expect rain, I recommend polishing the lens area with Rain-X or something similar. You may not be comfortable with the included mounting options.  I mounted a couple of $6 camera swivels on a cheap angle brace.

Flexible, tough.  For regular running I don't need to tape my toes to prevent blisters and "black nails."  When I go for longer distances a couple of toes on each foot are likely to blister without the tape.  The tape is thin, flexible, durable and stays in place, the edges don't roll in use. The tape and a thin coat of either Body Glide or Gold Bond Friction Defense, and no blisters or skin tears.

For non-medical, light use, disposable gloves the question is vinyl or nitrile? I"m sure there are cases where chemicals will dictate which is better, but the "disposable" class of gloves are all thin, not for rugged use. Either vinyl or nitrile are far more durable than latex. Vinyl is either side of half the price of nitrile though both are cheap enough.  Nitrile provides a little more dexterity and is better for fine work.  I use vinyl for things like oil changes, handling the occasional dead animal in the yard and applying oil stains.  I use nitrile for finer things like cleaning small parts and oiling the grandfather clock.  Mostly vinyl in the garage, nitrile on the work bench.These Ammex gloves go on easily, contain no contaminating powder and are more than reasonably durable; I don't have to worry about a tear during an oil change for example. Though it isn't a big deal to find a bad glove in a box, with Ammex it's rare.

I can assure you the hummingbirds like this stuff.  We use it at a cottage, but we were using some with dye in it.  In early June a woman walking the beach and looking at cottages knocked on our door and introduced herself as "the hummingbird professor."  She had university credentials and wanted to ask a couple of questions, and asked to watch our hummingbird feeder.  She counted the number of birds that came in 15 minute increments.  She wanted to know what nectar we were using and told us not to use the stuff with dye.  She said use straight sucrose, don't worry about vitamins and minerals, the birds get all they need from natural flowers.  They only need energy from the feeders.  She specifically recommended the Perky Pet sucrose because she was confident the label was accurate.  That wasn't a knock on other brands, she said she didn't know for sure.

If you have the tool, you already know how incredibly well these work.  A caution though.  If you have a beat up lawnmower blade, machete or axe, this isn't where you start - these coarse grit belts are no substitute for a coarse grinding wheel or more often a lot of work with a file and the tool in a vise.  The Work Sharp product is a finishing tool.  These belts last a long time as a first step on a dull, but not abused, knife blade. Just because they're "coarse" doesn't mean they're for heavy stock removal.

Impressive that someone can write a 300 page book about a book that's five short chapters.  McCartney does a terrific job providing and explaining reference to the original Greek as well as a thorough review of other commenters, both ancient and modern.  That's one of the reasons for the Baker series and it's done well.  He provides both the actual Greek, in Greek letters for those who are fond of it (a struggle for me), and a more accessible transliteration.  So, at times this is a bit of a slog, but worth the effort.One short, and incomplete example from the classic "faith without works": "Another rhetorical question begins 2:20, this one addressed to the hypothetical interlocutor as 'vain human.' A certain play on words is evident in Greek because the word for 'vain' (Greek word, kenos) also means 'empty.' The one who claims to separate faith and works is an 'empty human' because he or she has an empty faith, just as a body without a spirit is empty (2:26)." (page 161)

Do the job as they're supposed to.  Plastic is better than stainless, the stainless is too hot to touch right after brewing.  The top of this basket is plastic as well, so you can pull it out and knock the grounds out without burning your fingers.  Tried a couple of cheaper brand X and they were built well enough but the mesh went to near the top and they occasionally leaked and were too hot to handle.  These Ekobrews are a tad more expensive, but worth the difference.

Spoiler Alert.  This is part SciFi part "espionage."  It lost three stars for one reason, it stopped; it just stopped.  It's as if the author just decided not to write any more.  Of course, this could be part one of a series but even at that, the active characters need some kind of resolution of their current circumstances and sitting on the beach looking up at distant sniper/guards isn't much resolution.  No resolution for one of the key characters, this book just stops.  There isn't even some tickler, a hint of direction, anything that would want you to pick up the next book in the series (if there is one).  As others have observed, the characters aren't compelling, largely stereotypical, no one is particularly unique.  Spoiler alert... the simple plot is some type of alien craft broke up into three pieces and crashed on earth in the early 1900's.  The Russians have a piece, the Americans have a piece.  The Russian piece calls home to a moon of Jupiter.  The Americans in an alien ship chase the Russians with an adapted alien drive to Europa, the moon.  It doesn't work out well and some of the Americans and one Russian make it back to Earth with nothing but their lives and a lot of questions.FWIW., I bought Starfire because I read a couple of Larson's "World" books; they were much more interesting.

This is obviously a compact gun cleaning kit, covers about every size.  I like the Otis system, the cables instead of a rod.  But what isn't clear is that it isn't really a gun cleaning system, it's a bore cleaning system.  You need a brush, something like a small toothbrush for example to get into the slide grooves on a handgun even if you're only field stripping it, but there's nothing like that included. Think about how you're going to use it before you decide what to buy.  Most of us have one or two calibers to clean in the field and this is great for that.  If you're buying for working on a bench, this probably shouldn't be your first choice.Happy with it for what it is.
Plug it in, it works.  Seems well made.  Less expensive than several alternatives. Needed a charger cable, but it's both charger and sync. Great value.
Reasonably well made, typical notebook/notepad sleeve.  Bought for a Dell Inspiron 11 3000 Series.  It is TIGHT but fits; exactly what I wanted, no excess bulk.  Happy.
Hard wood, consistent dimensions, clean finish.  Note the plug end is tapered.  See more info in my answer to the "What size...?" question.

As another poster, used for snow blower skids so doesn't scratch a ground aggregate decorative drive.  4 skids, 8 surfaces out of the 12 X 12X 1 piece.  Works better than the original on an uneven sidewalk. They'll far outlast the snow blower.  Understand the side cuts are rough, the piece I got was reasonable well packed but had some minor surface scratches.  Also as other posters have noted the actual dimensions are 11 3/4 X 11 3/4, didn't matter in my application.

Been using these for several years, carry them constantly, use them a couple of times a day.  Both the glasses and the case hold up well.  Glasses are clear, inconspicuous.  It isn't a big deal but dust builds up in the case and you will have to wipe it out every couple of weeks.  I use a glasses wipe on the glasses then use it to wipe out the inside of the case.  If you're hard on glasses, keep in mind the lens is plastic, not glass and they will scratch if you're not careful.  I'm careful, they're fine.

It is as advertised.  The 3 1/4" fitter is fine, the globe seems like good quality, uniform, round.  It will easily accommodate a standard 100W incandescent bulb.  The opening is maybe 1/32" diameter too small for a standard 150W incandescent so in my case a bit of a problem.
Work fine, as expected. I was not able to "push" them in, recommend putting a small block of wood on top before you "hammer" on them.

As advertised.  You can find the diagnostic "blink" codes on the internet on a troubleshooting sheet or in the "Professional Installer" Guide for the humidifier.  If your unit is overhead, as mine was, you may be able to work with a mirror and not take the whole humidifier down.  There are only two screws, one for the top cover that's on the outside and a T27 torx to remove the clamp/bracket that holds the Water Level Sensor down.  There's a good probability both the sensor and gaskets are shot.While you have the sensor out, make sure the two parts of the tank it covers have clean drain ports, just shine a light through the bottom.  You can clean them from the bottom outside, easy.
Hardwood, round, smooth, excellent quality, completely as advertised.  Happy here.

This is first a standard, full face over-the-nose balaclava, with hook-n-loop patches on each side.  The "heat exchanger" piece just wraps over the top, an overlay that wraps around to each side. So when you're breathing, you are doing so through first the cloth balaclava, then the heat exchanger, so moisture collects on the balaclava cloth as well as in the heat exchanger.  The overlay is very stiff, I can't get it to conform to my face comfortably.  It does not work at all well with goggles, it mounts too high so goggles can't seal.  I'll keep it for the balaclava and trash the overlay heat exchanger.  No idea whether the heat exchanger works, it's a small piece of very open cell plastic foam which wouldn't seem to have any inherent ability to work as a periodic flow heat exchanger.I have an older PSolar product, apparently no longer manufactured, similar in concept, but the heat exchanger is actually built into a mesh pocket stitched into the balaclava so the flexible fit is provided easily by the balaclava and works more successfully with goggles.

Full featured.  My 2 cents with the instructions...don't try to read and understand them, just go through the steps as listed punching the buttons on the clock as directed and you'll have an epiphany and won't need the instructions again. This clock will do what you want it to do, lots of flexibility and it's actually easy to get there.  The instructions could use some white space to make an easier read, but they're accurate.

I replace the factory insoles with these in my running shoes.  Makes a big difference.  The factory insoles may be OK for a week or so, then they compress and loose their shock absorbing functionality.  These last for years and are marvelously effective.  I've literally run injury free for over a decade and this is part of the program.The 10 - 10.5 fit perfectly in either size.
They are what they're advertised to be and a lot cheaper.  If there's a difference between this and the OEM, I can't identify it.  Happy with the brushes.  Perfect Fit.

Works as advertised, but for most applications no need to worry about linking it to the garage door.  The little eyelets are included and the string is long enough to tie this to a garage door so that when the door is down, the ball is up and out of the way.  When the door opens, the ball drops into position.  NOT included though are anchors for the eyelets, so if you're installing this in a sheet rock ceiling (finished garage) you'll need your own plastic anchors.The ball is soft, so no worry about scratching a car and it's easy to tie to the string.  Yeah, you can use a tennis ball and it too will be fine, but did you ever actually drill a hole in a tennis ball and thread a small rope or string through it?  The fuzzy cover wants to wrap up in the drill bit and drag the ball out of your hand.  You can use an Exacto knife too and hope there's no blood letting in the process.Bottom line, worth the price, completely functional.

I'd give this thing 5 stars for convenience if it could produce a decent cup of coffee.  It's a great idea but the execution is poor.Doesn't matter what coffee source you use or what size you choose of the three, the coffee is weak.  Doesn't matter what size you chose, it dispenses the same, 6 oz. cup.Yeah you can buy the Keurig cups if you like to spend a buck for a cup of coffee, but the refillable containers work just as well.  The disposables are nice if you're using the machine somewhere away from a sink.It's bulky and briefly noisy too.  Bottom line, you have no control over anything but the "launch" button. The Keurig concept makes perfect sense in an office as a replacement for a refrigerator sized coffee machine, a place with bottled water and 6 oz. foam cups, otherwise...The Keurig success is baffling.
Pricey.  It works fine, easy to apply and buff, but so are the cheaper alternatives.  Two stars off for price/quantity.  Would give it five stars for functionality

Two cockers, perfect.  Sturdy, easy to use, easy to set up and release.  Much, much easier to step over.  One key difference, the way the pads are on the ends allows this to go to the floor; the positioning of the pads on some gates requires that they be mounted above the base boards, leaving a gap at the bottom and making the gate difficult to step over.

As advertised.  Mounted one of these on the front license plate bracket to trigger an alarm when the bracket pushes against something, anything.  Wrapped the connections with waterproof tape.  Seem solid and durable, but at this price, no big deal to swap one out.
The short version is I bought one for my wife to try, worked as advertised, fit as advertised, no headache, don't really even feel it's on.  Bought four other colors.

Bright.  Others have covered the details.  I also have a "NEBO Larry" light.  They're similar in size and form.  The two features that make the Cliplight the preferred version are 1) it's brighter and 2) the lens is slightly protected by the softer body around the edges of the lens.  My NEBO Larry's lens is scratched and showing wear.  Granted, I used it a lot when replacing a clutch in a dark garage.
Bulky of course, but it works.  Made of covered steel, very, very durable.

It is what it is and works as advertised and expected.  It's marked in 32's of an inch around the barrel so just a bit of a pain to read.  After using this, which is fine, I decided to get a more expensive digital gage.  Two advantages to this.  One, it's very light and OK in your shirt pocket.  Two, it will fit in a very thin tread, much thinner than any digital gage I've tried.I took one star off because of the difficulty reading it, but don't know what they could do to solve that problem.

Works as well as more expensive alternatives, see thru, standard cartridges.  I use this when I added a charcoal filter to take out any algae residue from lake water.  Easy to drain and replace the cartridge.

I bought this to clear a gravel driveway after two different users got flat tires.  We weren't sure the driveway was the source, but it was one of two common areas.  Very powerful and we've found regular use for it, now wonder why we didn't get one long ago.  I've used it under a work bench, to clear the gravel driveway, to go around a cottage and catch a few remaining roofing nails, on a beach to find bolts that fell in the sand from mounting a winch.  Very powerful, relatively compact.

Stretches to fit, used this on rocker panels with enough left to put on the rear quarter panel.  Custom splash shields (mud flaps) are $150 each, yeah each, not for a set, so decided to try the "Clear Bra" instead. A bit tricky to install for one person, but starting with the front bottom and moving back and up on a progressive basis with a squeegy sold for the job got it done.  Things need to be clean, but this isn't quite as sensitive to microscopic dust as a tablet/phone screen.  Nearly invisible.
Perfect.  I use these for mounting the transmitters on Chassis Ears.  Sturdy, easy release, don't have to put my glasses on.

I use this twice a year when I change out snow tires to map the tread wear on the tires both for overall wear and for even wear inside, center and outside in hopes of capturing any inflation or alignment problems.  This is so, so easy and consistent compared to trying to read a tube type gage.  The probe is wide and won't fit in "slits" but fits fine in the large grooves, that's all I need.  Checked a single point with a gage block, perfect.

Quickly, cleanly sliced through high density foam expansion joint material an inch thick.  I bought these to cut a couple of hydraulic jack pads out of high density construction foam.  Sharp and fast enough to both cut, and shave thin slivers to clean things up.  My saw doesn't have an "orbital" setting.  Keep in mind when you're trying to decide whether to buy the 4" or 6" version of this that the mount on the saw makes almost 1 1/2" of the blade unusable.

This is big enough to easily apply serious torque if you have to without pain.  Easy to adjust.Some things are just too important to guess at.  My most consistent use is final torque on all the lug nuts when I change out the snow tires twice a year.  That means both the OEM lugs AND their proprietary "key" wrenches. You don't want to torque down lug nuts with an impact wrench and you don't want to over torque "key" wrenches (like keyed Gorilla lugs or McGard keys), you might stretch or break the studs or wreck the key, but the more likely problem is getting a flat on the road and having the dinky lug wrench that comes with most cars.  And you don't want to under-torque the lugs and run the obvious risk of a wheel coming loose.

Understand the title, the book is true to its title, it is not a comprehensive book about debt resolution. Read the book and you may recognize an un-fair practice, but you can't stop it, and you may be at risk if you ignore it.Short book, 55 pages that with different formatting might have been 30.  Debt is complicated, but the book offers and adequate overview.  Covers some absolutely critical points, such as "are you really responsible for the debt" AND "is the debt collector legitimate."  One essential admonition, get a signed contract BEFORE you pay a cent.  Second, make sure the collection agent is in fact authorized to collect and representing the principal.  Third, you have to make sure the paperwork covers you or you can pay and it won't be over. You might even pay the wrong person, effectively throwing your payments away.  The point again is, that in the context of the scope of this book, un-fair debt collection practices, a collector may not even have a legitimate interest.Also, the author point out that most debt is settled for a fraction of the original amount.You need a lawyer or you'll get screwed.  It doesn't have to cost $ thousands.  Read this book and you'll understand why you need the protection a lawyer can provide and in the end, the lawyer's fees, one way or another, will come out of what you owe unless you're in a weird situation, either way there's a heads up in this story.  The collection agents are bottom feeders. The book doesn't push for hiring legal help, but there's too much paperwork that has to be right; you have to be skilled in this stuff or you'll end up paying and still have people chasing you.  The book doesn't explain how it can happen, but once a debt goes to "collection" there's a possibility that some how the same debts will end up with multiple collectors and they don't talk to each other.I've had a cell phone for almost two years that was previously owned by someone who obviously owes many people money.  At least two collection agents call a week.  Whether they're convinced I know the debtor, or just think they can intimidate me into paying something to make them go away, no idea, but they can be ugly.  The collection agents call from all over the world, thought they always show up as US phone numbers.Major criticism, and the reason for 4 rather than 5 stars, if you're facing un-fair debt collection practices, the book will tell you how to recognize them, but doesn't offer any effective tools to stop it.  You'll know what they're doing is illegal, immoral and unethical but knowing it doesn't much help, they're not going to change.  For example, most states actually have laws on the books that say a collector can't threaten to do something they either can't do, or don't plan to do.  So they can't threaten to take your retirement.  But there's no penalty in law if they do make the threat.The book deals with consumer debt, but doesn't mention taxes, so if you owe taxes this doesn't offer a perspective.  Second, it doesn't emphasize the differences between states or the feds for example.  So if you read the book, you might assume a debt more than 7 years old isn't collectible.  Ohio though, as one example, has the longest statute of limitations on debt in the country, 15 years and the Feds are usually 10 years.The book avoids the issue of bankruptcy.

Simple, convenient, well made, good value. Of course these are brass and you want brass, which is relatively soft, if you need to drive out or seat a pin and you want to be sure not to scratch any surrounding base metal or finish.  These are straight, nice grip and finish, simple case that hangs easily on a peg board.  Happy with the result.

Fascinating and effective tool.  Easy to use.  The transducer/microphone is built into the handle of the alligator clip, connected by wire to the small numbered box.  The box is mostly 4 AAA batteries.  So you apply the alligator clip to whatever you want to evaluate and go for a drive, and mount the sending unit with nylon zip ties, the built in clip or built in magnet.  Switching between sensors is as simple as pushing a button.  If your vehicle has an "aux in" port on your radio, you'll need a patch cord and it's really easy then to listen over the radio, rather than a headset.Some noises sound as you'd expect although amplified.  If you clip to a brake caliper, you'll hear the sort of grinding noise you'd expect.  Other noises, like a clicking when mounted to an axle control arm, aren't so easy to interpret BUT it is easy to know that the sound is indeed coming from something directly connected to the control arm and that's the power of this tool.Sometimes for example, when you're driving you think an unexpected sound is coming from the front of the car, but in fact it's coming from the rear or the other way around.  A friend had an old Honda with a noise he was sure was coming from the right rear so I drove while he rode along side on a bike and it was clearly right front.  With the ChassisEAR, it takes only a few minutes to narrow the source, no need to "run" along side.  Some noises are so intermittent they're probably impossible to find any other way.Most recently we traced the source of a "thunk" to the inside of a strut, and it turns out there's a service bulletin on the strut.A couple of other reviewers have commented on problems with feedback or extraneous noise, but we haven't experienced that.Biggest surprise after using this is that it's only $200. Comes in a sturdy, roomy case.For convenience, you might want to buy a package of releasable zip ties such as Monoprice Releasable cable tie 6 inch 50LBS, 100pcs/Pack - Black (Amazon)to mount and unmount the sending unit.

I have a couple of these for cold weather running.  Perfect.  There is enough hat to go down well over your ears, more than I've found in any other watch style hat.  They wick the sweat away as well.  Can't imagine anything more you could want in a watch cap.  Well made, less expensive than smaller alternatives.

It works well for the price if you understand what you're getting.  The camera head is 7.5 mm diameter and 46 mm long.  It has a very flat field of focus about 40 mm from the front of the lens, so if that's what you're interested in, then it's a good buy.  As others have indicated, there is no focus adjustment.  The lights are bright enough.  Software installed easily and works intuitively.

Bought this primarily for automotive work; inspection of things you can't easily see including brake pads without removing the wheels, water pump weep holes, timing belts and clutch plates (through the inspection port), inside doors and body panels for early signs of rust.  Tried it out and am delighted.  This is so convenient and effective.  It takes pics and video.  You have to supply your own AA batteries (4) and a micro SD card.  The screen image is clear and adequate, though it doesn't match the resolution of a smart phone.  The closest focus is maybe 2", anything closer starts to blur.  The camera tube and cable is 8.1 mm so will fit about anywhere there's a 5/16" opening.The cable is goose-neck, so you can form it to whatever shape you need, on the other hand it isn't floppy flexible.Seems well made; I'm expecting to find a lot of unexpected uses for this.

It is what it says it is.  Writes like a pen, stylus works.  Cheaper than Space Pen.  I carry a pen at all times, even when running.  Gave it five stars because it is totally as advertised.  It's longer than is convenient for me and an bit of a nuisance, but I cut the clip off. It's way, way to bulky for me to clip on a key chain.  Haven't had the caps come off, but it's a pain to keep track of one, the pen I use briefly, but the stylus can get a workout from time to time.
Hyundai shop manual and owners manual refers to this as "fuel line air filter" perfect replacement. A bit of a nuisance to install, but not difficult.
This is 20 cm X 22 CM fits perfectly in Hyundai's with the frame for the filter, see photo.

These lights are perfect for areas where its challenging to run a power cord.  That bush or tree in the front yard, your mailbox or even draped around the inside of your car.  The solar panel makes these very portable, versatile and energy efficient.  If you like the dragonfly design and have a need for either energy efficient or "wireless" (a far as power goes) colored lights, these would be a good option.  I was provided a complimentary set for review purposes and my unbiased opinion was given above.

This set of bluetooth headphones is very stylish and it looks like something that would be a high end accessory for your iPhone.  It paired up with my phone easily and the controls are intuitive.  Sound was well rounded and was as good as my ole trusty Sony ear buds.The only thing that would cause me not to give this a 100% recommendation is that they won't stay in my ears!  I'll admit that I have notoriously bad ears for ear bud style head phones and this set was no exception.  They are not very grippy and they would fall out even if I wasn't moving much.  Its too bad because liked everything else about them.  I was given a complimentary set for review purposes and my unbiased opinion was given above.

I was excited to try this little speaker out.  Something nice and compact would be a great feature for the ultimate in portability.  Unfortunately, the sound was so shallow and flat that I could not get through a whole song.  Only part of the mids and mostly highs were audible and bass was non-existent.I will say that there is one area in which this little speaker excels is with voice reproduction.  I'll sometimes listen to a sermon, audio book or even stand up comedy and it was able to reproduce and carry the sound of these types of audio fairly well.For the price, you can't expect the moon, but if you are buying this for music, I would recommend spending a few more dollars for a decent bluetooth speaker better suited for music.  If you will be using this primarily for audio books, then I would say its a good value and could give this my recommendation.  I was provided a complimentary unit for review purposes and my unbiased opinion was given above.

I've tried a few different bluetooth headsets and haven't found the one I'd call a complete winner, however, these nudge out the others as my current favorite.  I'll list some of the pros and cons below:Pros:- Controls built into earpiece.  Other headsets have the controls on one of the wires which tends to pull the earpiece out when you are walking.- Earpiece stays in reasonably well.  My ears are usually pretty hard to fit, but I like that these use two methods of securing the earpiece.  First the grommet that goes in your ear and then using a flap that you can tuck in your ear for additional support.- Decent sound.  The 'overall' sound is pretty good, but it does tend to fall apart when there is punchy bass.  Other than that, it has sound as good as my old trusty Sony ear buds.Cons:- Controls are not intuitive.  There are a lot of speakers and head phones that utilize 3 buttons where one will play/pause and the other two advance tracks and adjust volume depending on if you long press or short press.  My preferred sequence is (+) short press = advance track, (+) long press = increase volume, (-) short press = rewind track and (-) long press = decrease volume.  These use short presses for volume and long presses for tracks, which I can deal with.  The odd part is that (+) increases volume, but rewinds the track.  (-) decreases volume, but advances tracks.  It just seems reversed and I don't know if I'll ever get used to it.- The plastics and button presses feel a little cheap.  Kind of a subjective comment, but it just didn't have the smooth button clicks that I prefer.Overall its a decent set of bluetooth headphones that can get you going if you need a set for working out at the gym without breaking the bank.  There are probably better options out there, but it will also cost you more.  I received a complimentary set for review purposes and my unbiased opinion was given above.

I was aware of pressure points and even had a foam roller, but for some reason had never heard of these Massage Balls before.  The concept is super simple and it is really efficient at working knots out.  I was initially a little put off that they were just lacrosse balls, but if you look around, this is about what they cost and this is just a way to re-purpose them.  I was also emailed a PDF with tips and links to videos on how to use these, so I would not have been able to use regular lacrosse balls to their fullest potential if I hadn't had access to that information.Overall, this is a welcomed product to work out daily aches and pains and it doesn't take up a lot of space when not in use.  I received this item at a discounted rate in exchange for a review and my unbiased opinion was given above.

I love the look of Edison bulbs, it just ads a great atmosphere for your vintage themed rooms.  LED is also a great thing of the modern era that gives you decent light for little energy.  Now this particular bulb makes an effort to combine the old and the new.  I really wished it worked for me.  Functionally, the bulb works fine.  It gives off a fair amount of light and is energy efficient.  Where is falls short is in style.  One of the most interesting aspects of the Edison bulbs is the long filaments that run up and down the bulb.  Not that an LED version would not work, but I feel it should make some effort to imitate this look.  This appears much like the product photo (unfortunately) with a bunch of little dots.  The shape of the glass is only part of the overall look.The color temperature was also not very warm.  Certainly not as warm as pictured.  If I were decorating a vintage themed room, I just would not feel comfortable making this bulb a part of the decor.I will add that if the bulb will be at a distance, then the LEDs tend to run together and its not as obvious, but if it will be close (hanging over a bar or table) then the little dots will be easy to see.  I was provided a complimentary unit for review purposes and my unbiased opinion was given above.

We happen to have Dr Brown bottles, so we got this brush hoping it would be able to wash all the little parts and pieces.  The head it a nice design to ensure you wash the bottom and sides of the bottle well.  I also like the suction cup stand to keep it up and out of the way when not in use.The bottom end is supposed to be able to clean the inside of the bottle nipple and while it does look like a good fit, there are no bristles to really wash well in there.  I can only assume that the folks at Dr Brown thought of that and that it is really cleaning well enough.Overall its a good option to keep your bottles clean and hope it stands up to daily use.

If you are looking for a bluetooth speaker right now, I bet your head is spinning.  With the sea of 100s to choose from, where do you start?  I myself have test driven a handful of them and was happy to get to try this one.  When I look at a new speaker, I try to break it down into several aspects, which I'll touch on below:PORTABILITYThe Sinoband S400S is not the smallest speaker on the market, so if you are looking to stick this thing into a jacket pocket or small purse, move along.  This is a good size, though, to toss into your backpack or even clip it on with the included lanyard ring.  The included oversized stuff sack also makes it a little easier to grab and go.  Given the sound and included power bank, its really as small as you could wish for with all the included features.FUNCTIONALITYMan, does this speaker shine on functionality: Bluetooth w/NFC, large battery which doubles as a power bank, handsfree voice calling, Aux input and rugged, weather resistant construction.  There really isn't anything more you could ask for with regard to pure function.SOUND QUALITYWith regards to sound quality, its probably one of the cleanest and crisp speakers I've tried.  I like to listen to acoustic and singer/songwriter type music and the mids and highs are so clean.  With such emphasis on mids and highs, the bass is not the strongest, but I've got a love/hate thing with bass.  I see many speakers making bass their big claim to fame.
