The charger has a neat little plastic-imprinted outline of a battery with some data in it, but the printing is very small and the texturing of the plastic essentially makes what I guess to be battery information unreadable.All I can guess is that the cost of the package for this light, charger and battery would push it close to $50.  At $35, it’s relatively expensive to begin with, but I’ll give on that, as this looks like a pretty rugged and well-constructed piece of gear.The product images show a white zoom graphic on the next of the light; mine does not have that.  The images also shows what appears to be a white/gray imprinted battery outline on the charger.  Again, mine does not have that.So, the item seems pretty cool but is completely unusable as purchased.  That’s too bad.Bottom line: This seems to be a pretty awesome piece of gear, but I’ve got no way to completely evaluate it, as I’ve got no battery to make it go…and the seller offers no information on how to get one.

Disclosure: I was contacted by the manufacturer and offered this product.  I accepted, promising a fair and honest review in return.For $20, this is a superb pair of earbuds.  The sound is crisp and clear, and I especially like the very distinct low-end bass reproduction.  Greg Nagy’s “Walk That Fine Thin Line,” David Sanborn’s “Chicago Song,” the “Hawaii-5-O” theme by Big Kahuna and the Kopa Cat Pack, and everything from Sadao Watanabe’s “How’s Everything?” release all sounded fantastic on these buds, very impressive.In the package you get the earbuds and two pairs of extra tips—that’s it.  No case, no warranty card or user’s manual.  Some kind of documentation/instruction would be good, as there is a small control module on the left-side cord; one click stops/starts playback and two skips to the next song, at least this is what happened when I auditioned these on my iPod classic.  The box provides the technical specs, and that’s all you get.The box does offer an email address for support, support@soundpeatsaudio.com.The listed standard price of $99.99 is absolutely ridiculous for this product.  The Prime price of $20 is much more reasonable, and is a good deal for this product.Bottom line: This is a low-cost earbuds set, but most definitely not low-budget.  You don’t get flash and a ton of extras, but you do get an inexpensive pair of buds that spit out some very, very good sound.

The dog absolutely loved these things.  She would literally inhale them.  They did not last long at all.They smell really good, just like human meat sticks.  Go figure, as the ingredients are beef, salt, sugar, citric acid, dextrose, paprika (for color), black pepper and garlic.  The appearance, though, is not quite up to human speed.  They don’t really look like those pictured on the packaging.  They are much more uniform and smooth, not the rich variegation shown, and their color is more of a dull brown, not the vibrant red-brown shown.As with all the dog treats, I tried one.  Uh, not really that tasty, despite its appetizing smell and its appearance like human-intended beef jerky.There is a ton of info here about how great these are for your dog, with protein and fiber, really natural and not artificial.  Yeah, sure, I guess.  I have no way to verify or test any of the claims.  I do note that the analysis says these things are 40% moisture.  All I can tell you is that the dog loved these things.Bottom line: If I were to see these in the store, I would not hesitate to buy another package.  The dog digs 'em.

Disclosure: I was contacted by the manufacturer and offered this product.  I accepted, promising a fair and honest review in return.First off, my apologies to Brainwavz.  I received these a number of months ago, got really busy at home and work, had to be out of the country for a while, and forgot about my promise to review this product.  It’s taken longer than it should have, but I’m finally fulfilling my promise.I’ve got some history with Brainwavz—this is my seventh product from them--and I consistently have been impressed with their work.  I have passed these products on to my kids, and they also have enjoyed them and praised them.  I like the construction, feel, extras, and especially the sound these products deliver.  This earbud set is no different.You get the standard black/red pouch, with two interior pockets, the six additional pairs of different-sized earbud tips including the super-squishy-moldable ones, a little hook-and-loop keeper for the cord, and a little clothing clip.  And the earbuds, too.The buds are clearly marked L and R, which I like.  The construction is meal, but the earbuds are not heavy.  Online under technical details the attribute “noise isolation” is listed.  It is not listed on the product packaging.  I note once again that this is a meaningless attribute, as there is no active action taking place with these earbuds; they are not “noise canceling,” like the very expensive, active Bose headphones.  These earbuds isolate noise only by keeping it from your ears by overriding it with the signal from your device.The cord is “tangle-free,” thin, and appears braided, with some nice texture.  I had no problem with tangles.  There is no device or earbud control on the cord.  There also is no little device at the cord’s Y to snug the two separate cords up under your chin.Sound.  The box says, “Intense, Detailed Bass” as the first product attribute, so that’s what I auditioned them for, with Karl Denson’s rocking cover of “Seven Nation Army,” “Bust a Move,” “My City Was Gone,” Sanborn’s “Hideaway,” (live), Stanley Clarke’s “School Days,” and a few more.  The sound was good, clear and crisp, with a nice low-end thrum.The product documentation is sparse, as always, with a tiny card offering user info, warnings, and the warranty, with the flip side being the product registration/warranty card.Price: The regular price for this product is far too high.  The Prime price also seems somewhat spendy.Bottom line: this is another well made Brainwavz product, good materials and strong workmanship combining to provide a good earbud set with excellent sound reproduction.

Disclosure: I was contacted by the manufacturer and offered this product.  I accepted, promising a fair and honest review in return.I like the design, the shape and size/dimensions reminiscent of the 2001: A Space Odyssey monolith, with that green on the bottom for some New Millennium flair (other colors available!).  This portable battery is thin and smooth, with a nice pseudo-rubberized exterior so it’s easy to grip.  That’s a good thing, as it has a shake-to-wake feature.  It has no on/off button; you just shake it.Interesting is that the status light shows a wonderful deep green when depleted and a nice, glowing, striking red when fully charged (with a nice cobalt blue in between).  This is a Chinese product, and of course, in China a deep, glowing red is always a good thing, so this makes sense.  But this product is being offered for sale in the West, where everything good is green, green means go and on, and red means danger and stop and off.  So just remember that for this product red is good.The flat, no-tangle charging cord comes in at about 21”; I’d like to see it a little bit longer, so you can set the battery on a table and still use a connected/charging device.  The cord ends are USB and Micro USB, so Apple users are going to have to get an adapter to make this thing work for their product.Use is highly intuitive; plug the cord into the respective outlets and let the battery charge or be charged.  It’s that simple.  I’ve had no problem with its charging or discharging.  It’s got plenty of juice left over after charging a phone.The documentation/user’s manual could be better.  It’s in both Chinese and English, mostly Chinese, and the English is not that great.  It’s passable, and the meaning is clear, but it could be better (see my Umu battery review).Bottom line: This is a nice portable battery, easy to use.

Disclosure: I was contacted by the manufacturer and offered this product.  I accepted, promising a fair and honest review in return.Overall, I like this product, a lot.  It’s small, so it’s easy to carry, and it charges quickly and fully.  When providing charge to another device, it does so quickly and has some juice left over when done.The simple addition of both the lightning adapter (iPhone, etc.) and the Micro USB adapter (Androids) is very smart, which means both I and my kids can use this quickly and easily, as we all have different devices.  The lightning adapter just snaps onto the Micro USB, and you’re in business.  I would make one small design change, though: the addition of a graphic on both adapters to show how they line up, so to make it all go more quickly and prevent the mis-alignment of the two adapters and physical damage to either.There are four little status lights on the body of the battery; all four lighting up means it’s fully charged.  I like this simple design, but the lights are very tiny; a little bit bigger would be better.The USB-adapater cord comes in at at little more than 24”, so you’ve got room to set this on a nightstand and still work your phone in bed.The user’s manual is small, well written and clearBottom line: This is a great little portable battery, very easy to use, that charges up quickly and easily, holds that charge for a good long time, and then connects quickly and easily to a number of devices.

I’ve said it before: what’s the difference between weird and kinky?  Weird is when you use a feather; with kinky, you use the whole chicken.So, this is my 11th one of these, as I work my way through them all.  Sigh…15 still to go.The Alison Tyler intro is surprisingly sparse; it seems phoned it in, even ghost-written, too thick with story excerpts, with no real effort to say anything unique or interesting about what exactly kink is and is about.  The intro says only that it’s “the unexpected.”  That comes across as a cop-out.So, whaddaya get here?  Well, you get:• a lady who likes to be written upon—not a bad opener• some subtle sexual conditioning—not that kinky, more like psychological B&D• a whiny sub—it’s got a nice comic twist at the end, but is clearly B&D• some BDSM equine play--okay, sufficiently kinky• some Halloween costume play--nope, not really, more like dress-up/cosplay• some light watersport—okay, but disappointingly shallow• spanking--yawn• a senior citizen dirty story teller about a hot jazz nursey-dress-up—not bad, getting closer to kinky• an intense spinning class, with a penetrative twist--much better• a man become a coin-operated toy--better• spanking, again--yawn, again• a writing exercise playing on feline personification with BDSM—okay, if completely predictable• a plastic surgeon who gets off on sex n’ cars—think JG Ballard’s magnificent Crash, but dumbed way down, involving low-end hookers• some lesbian kleptomania and cutting—not badSome of this was kinda kinky, but a lot of it just wasn’t.  Sure, for the dull brown suit churchgoers in Middle America, this book is indisputable evidence of Satanic presence in daily life, but for anyone who’s read a book or two of adult fiction, this collection is not kinkily cutting it.  Where was the frottage, electro-stim, the adult baby fetish, immobilization, asphyxiation, the plushies, the really intense watersports story, statues and mannequins, bestiality, not to mention the subjects that I can’t mention here?  There’s a lot of wild and varied kinky out there, and this collection barely scratches the surface.Yeah, I get it: most folks don’t want to read that kind of way-out content.  This is book is mainstream, acceptable kink.I did find a couple choice lines, though: “…There would always be more [urine].  It was her birthright…” “’You’re kinky,’ says Leticia, ‘I appreciate that in a medical professional…’”Bottom line: this is entry-level kink, best for someone who is happy with vanilla sex and may wonder what kind of moderately acceptable additional activities may be had for the just-a-little sexually adventurous.  If you’re looking for real kink, unflinching adult fiction riffing on all of the really esoteric sexual proclivities out there, this one isn’t it.

This set is a pair of ambidextrous oven mitts.  Both are identical, to include the little clothing hanging loop.Yep, they work very well on hot items, both on the stove top and especially for items going into/coming out of the oven.I had no problem with the fit; I usually wear a men's size Large glove.  These may be a bit loose on ladies with small hands.The neoprene business end of the mitts is not very flexible.  They could use a little bit of modification in the construction to put a small break in the thumb at the 2/3 point and the same for the fingers to allow these mitts to be more flexible and increase their utility.  I understand that this alteration would make them somewhat more expensive.turning the mitts a little inside out, I see the interior construction, while not exactly shoddy, is not that detailed.  Te cross-hatch/diamond sewing pattern on the lower part of the mitts did not line up very well, and this was reflected on the inside.  There is some excess cloth where the seams were cut, and this is shedding both the cotton covering and the polyster fill.  This was evident on the first (separate) wash, which is recommended in the care label of both mitts.  This construction doesn't necessarily compromise these mitts, as they are for home-kitchen purposes; they are not a fashion item.Both have held up well in the wash, with no splitting of seams or shedding of the internal padding.

Disclosure: I was contacted by the manufacturer and offered this product.  I accepted, promising a fair and honest review in return, and received it at a large discount.This is not a bad product at all.  I’ve seen lots of sprocket-and-chain-inspired jewelry, and it’s pretty hard to get really creative with bicycle chain, but this one comes off pretty nicely.  It is a simple and relatively understated piece.  The metal has a nice shine, and the colored sections are well done.  It’s a nice feature of the product that you have color choices.This is a relatively heavy piece of jewelry.  It does not “clink” or make a lot of noise, but there is some subtle metallic ring to it as you wear it.  It has some play in it, but given the nature of the interlocking bicycle chain parts, it is also relatively stiff, meaning that it bends in only one direction and most definitely does not twist at all.It arrived in a nice presentation box, wrapped diligently in cling-plastic that was infuriatingly tedious to pull off.The product description says, “Function:Anti-Radiation.”  What in the world is that all about?I note that I received the blue-silver model, and the one I received indeed was that, but the actual blue is very, very dark, at first glance easily mistaken for black.  In bright light and if turned to the side the blue does come through.Fit.  I’m a 52-year-old guy, and this fits just fine.  By my measurement, this would comfortably  fit a wrist up to 8”.  The overall length of the bracelet comes in at just a little over 8 ”.My son digs this bracelet, and has laid claim to it.Bottom line: If you’re a guy that goes in for man-jewelry, you could do a lot worse than this item.  It is simple but also has a bit of color flair, a good mix in any kind of personal jewelry statement.

Disclosure: I was contacted by the manufacturer and offered this product.  I accepted, promising a fair and honest review in return.This is a simple cubic zirconia pendant in a snowflake pattern.  The product description of it as 1.4cm in diameter is accurate.  It is not that big, so gets credit in the small-and-understated-elegance department.  The necklace has a 5cm-long section through which you can adjust your fit.I’m no diamond or QZ expert, but the pendant has a very nice sparkle to it, its total of 15 stones throwing off some nice, eye-catching glints.I note that buying a couple of these and altering them a bit to be matching earrings would be a pretty cool move.  Or buy three, make two earrings, and wear the other as part of matching three-piece set.My daughter likes this piece, and has claimed it.Bottom line: This is a nice little piece of costume jewelry.

Note first that you can't just buy one box, as we Vine Voices received.  You can only buy this in a lot of ten boxes, which comes in at just a little over $65 (as currently priced).  So,that's about $6.50 for one box, and a truly miniscule $06.5 per sheet.  That's a pretty good price for these sheets, which are highly durable and relatively reusable.  They perform well when wet and don't melt down into glop in no time flat.Note that this lot of ten boxes comes in at more than 22 pounds, so make sure you're getting free shipping.Each sheet measures 17" x 9".I used these wipes for everyday cleaning around the house, particularly in the bathroom and in the kitchen.  They held up very well, with one usually easily handling the entire cleaning job.  They wring out well and dry pretty quickly.  I did put one through the washing machine for a test, where it did in fact come apart--they are not THAT reusable.The box has a perforated pullout for dispensing, which also serves as a simple carrying handle.

Disclosure: I was contacted by the manufacturer and offered this product.  I accepted, promising a fair and honest review in return.For less than $20 this is an excellent starter kitchen set.  You get 11 well-made and durable products you will use just about every day.  But there are a few minor problems.You get five steel nesting measuring spoons, from ¼ teaspoon to 1 full tablespoon.  They’ve also got metric notation on them, which is nice, and expected.  All are connected by a split ring to keep them all together.You get five steel nesting measuring cups, from ¼ cup to one full cup.  For some strange reason, they do not have metric measurements on them like the spoons do; someone was smart enough to do it with the spoons, so why not on the measuring cups?  That just don’t make no sense.  I like the cups because they resemble little saucepans.  They’re also all connected by a split ring, so you can keep track of them.The glass measuring cup is also a puzzle: both sides have the exact same graduation, with 100-500 mL on one side and 4 to 16 ounces on the left, with a little ½ liter line above.  Where is the notation for cups?  What about pints?  The box says it’s a two-cup measuring cup, but there is no indication on the cup where exactly that two cups is.  This is a surprisingly incompetent oversight on the part of Teikis design and manufacturing—how could someone not notice this and do something about it?  Also, the glass carries no official glass manufacturing logos, such as Pyrex.All of the metal items were completely smooth and free of burrs.  There was some manufacturing debris on them; make sure you give these a good wash first.I can confirm that all items are indeed fully dishwasher safe, as stated on the box.  I have successfully used the glass measuring cup in the microwave, although I’m unsure if it’s okay to do so—there is nothing on the box or in the online product description that states this is the case.  This is another pretty basic oversight on the part of Teikis, either to make the item microwave safe, or at least just tell us yes or no on the question.Bottom line: This is a nice basic kitchen set that is seriously compromised by some very basic mistakes: the lack of metric markings on the measuring cups, the lack of full markings on the measuring cup, the question of microwave use for the glass cup.  It doesn’t ruin the set, but these little things shouldn’t be there in the first place.  Some minor design and manufacturing changes could fix this pretty quickly; I’m quite surprised no one caught these things before this went into production.

Disclosure: I was contacted by the manufacturer and offered this product. I accepted, promising a fair and honest review in return.This Jolly Gear jump rope set is being sold here by Bella Naturals/Naturalico, but as far as I can tell, it is almost exactly the same as the jump rope set I reviewed in April 2014, strangely enough logo'd as "Naturalico."  So, here is that review, modified just a little, which applies fully to this one, except for this set the "rope" itself is coated in clear red plastic (they do offer a nice choice of colors).This set also comes with two extra rubber nubs for the end of the rope/wire and two extra thumbscrew sets for the end of the wire--nice.The black nylon bag has a Jolly Gear stencil on it, as do the two black handles.So, here's my original review, for what seems to be the exact same product, under a different vendor name:I'm not a boxer or a serious health nut, just an older guy who needs to get in better shape. This proved to be a nice diversion from the traditional exercise routine, an exercise activity I have not undertaken in many a year. It's easy to do, and this product was a nice way to do it. And yeah, it gives you one helluva workout.I've never experienced an adjustable jump rope before, and this impressed me. You can adjust the rope length by way of twin thumbscrew-locking keepers at each end of the rope. The "rope" is really plastic-coated braided wire, so some serious shears are needed if you're going to modify it.  There are little plastic/rubber caps on each end, which are not glued on, so you can use them again if you choose to shorten your rope.The logo'd handles each have two separate bearings in them to keep the rope moving and untangled. Flawless performance here.I was worried about rope wear, but a number of sessions on both smooth and rough concrete showed no real wear. Of course, if you're jumping the hell out of this thing, sooner or later you're going to wear it out. Bug given its price, it would not be that much of a burden to get a new one.And it comes with a nice little logo'd nylon bag with a barrel-lock closure. Nice way to take this on the road with you for a portable workout.Price.  The regular price of about $20 seems right for this product, so it's great to see it down to less than $13.  That's a good deal for this product.  Given the components I figured it would be closer to $25.And for all you international contract assassins out there, the rope can be used as a handy garrote. Neato!Bottom line: This is a nice compact bit of training gear, easy to use and easy to transport, at a more than reasonable price.

Yeah, I’m a big, hairy man, but I’m secure enough to state that this stuff smells great.  It pumps easily from the original bottle (or any pump bottle you may choose to use).  It washes up well, cleaning quickly and thoroughly, and then rinses quickly and without a slippery residue.  The best part is that when you’re done your hands smell just like this soap.True decadence would be to use this as your bathing soap.Price: This bottle comes in at about $20.  That’s spendy.  But then again, it’s got great indegrients, and it’s imported from France.  This is not knockoff soap; this is the real deal, and you get what you pay for.  Our family of three has already gone through about half of this bottle, which means for more than a month this single (roughly) 17-ounce bottle will wash bathroom hands.  If you look at it that way, the value isn’t really that far out of whack.Bottom line: This is a very luxurious, maybe even decadent, product.  It’s a bit spendy, but is well worth the price.

Disclosure: I was contacted by the manufacturer and offered this product.  I accepted, promising a fair and honest review in return.Overall, this is a nice pair of budget binoculars.  Even DBPower themselves say they are “pretty well built.”In the box you get: The binos, with pliable “rubbery” covers for both the eyepieces and opposite ends A thin nylon neck strap (not shown in the product images) A one-page “manual” A carrying case with nylon shoulder strap A small lens clothThe binos have a nice feel in the hands, with some nice ergonomic ridges built into the rubber housing cover to help grip.  They adjust to size easily and quickly.  Both the eye ring and the binos also adjust quickly and easily, all of them nice and smooth.The main selling point is they are purported to be “waterproof.”  Of course, nothing is waterproof, and not wanting to inadvertently ruin this item, I did not rigorously test the moisture permeability of this product.  I will provide updates as needed as this items gets a more thorough workout.It takes some work to get the loose neck strap through the slots on the binos—this took far longer than it should have.The case is a thin, pseudo-padded neoprene, and its nylon shoulder strap adjusts fully.  The shoulder strap is not removable.  The case closes with a single centered 3” velcro strip.  A nice addition to the carrying case would be a couple of nylon belt loops on the backside, so that you could put this onto your belt, or strap easily to the outside of a pack.The owner’s manual is just an 8 ½” x 11” piece of paper, folded in eighths.  It’s in English, French, German and Italian.  The English text is better than I expected, more or less correct in syntax, usage, grammar, spelling and punctuation.  The word spacing is out to lunch, though.Not mentioned in the manual is a screw-in mounting for a tripod.  This is located at the front of the binos, along the axle.  I’m not too sure how this would work exactly, to screw onto a tripod through the very front of the binos; I guess you’re going to have a multi-directional mounting head…Price: Less than $40 for a pair of nicely functional and notionally weather-proof binos is a pretty good deal.Bottom line: This is a nice pair of entry-level binoculars.  The look good, feel good, and perform petty well.

I saw this 1972 movie in the main post theater at Fort Riley, Kansas in mid-1975, for a whopping 25 cents.  Somehow this title and a few choice images and scenes stuck with me all these years, so I find myself once again drawn, as if by some dark, unseen force...that I cannot comprehend or control...from beyond the depths of oblivion, erh, ah...back into this screen gem for the first time in 40 years.Yeah, it's pretty low-budge.  But a fun low-budge passing of an hour and a half.Plot: Assorted post-flower child hippies and stereotypical California drifters end up commune-like in a Topanga Canyon mansion, and a super-hip guru steps in to help lead them onto another path to immortality, by turning them into vampires.You get the entire stock hippie rainbow here, the bearded dude in the bib overalls, the bard with the guitar, the flower girl, the flouncy Hispanic girl in a peasant blouse (non-speaking role), the pseudo-Beatnik in her shockingly tiny waist, midriff shirt and tight pants, the big-afro chick in a tight turtleneck with a big colorful scarf around it, no less, a fuzzy and sunglassed biker dude, and our "hero" with his modified hippie Prince Valiant haircut and as Frank Zappa famously said in "Who Needs the Peace Corps?," "a leather band to go around [his] head."  All the ladies support the full palette of early 70s eye shadow, lots of seaform green and sky blue--far out, man.The bad guy is bearded and smooth and well-dressed kind of like an Arabian sheik with some Indian pasha and Jesus robes thrown in, with a very heavy layer of Charlie Manson crazy eyes (and the beard).  This is Topanga Canyon, after all.  The vampire's trusted helper, his hippie Renfield, if you will, is a dashiki-wearing dude with his very own cool-70s theme percussion by the name of Barbado; it seems that Clarence Williams III was busy, or most likely too expensive, so they went with his smaller-fro'd, non-union counterpart.  There is a lot of laughable stock 70s terminology, delivered horribly, about where your head's at, goin' on your trip, getting' it together, man, etc.You get the contemporary soft focus of waves and the sun and heartfelt folk music about life and spirituality and stuff.  You get a teeny-tiny bit of nudity in the form of a single female bare backside.  And when the vampires finally do their horror thing, you get the traditional 1950s/1960s ultra-schlocky white-face makeup and that stereotypical evil eyes and open-mouth-to-show-the-vampire-fangs gawping of the traditional movie-vampire menace.The plot holes are massive and start right from the opening minutes, with vampires apparently unable to open doors or go down stairs...and able to go out during the day.  But it's all over and done in a mere 94 minutes, so you can get on to something more cinematically worthwhile.The only real name star you're going to get is the nicely doomed Pop, played by John Fiedler (b. 1925, d. 2005).  You'll remember him as the similarly doomed Chief Hengist, unfortunately possessed by Redjac in the Star Trek TOS episode "Wolf in the Fold" (that's Episode 36, for those of you keeping score at home).  I guess you could cite the lead, Robert Quarry, as a name actor, but his star had risen and mostly fallen by the time this came out.As an American International Pictures film, yes, you do get the traditional schlocky-horror dark-and-cloudy nighttime sky with the cheezy lightning bolts.  Kinda like a visual Wilhelm Scream.Bottom line: This is prime B-list horror from the early 70s, updating the traditional vampire bit to the fading culture of Flower Power and the cult horrors of the Manson era.  It's not the worst film I've ever seen (Madonna's Swept Away remake), but it's also not the best.

Disclosure: I was contacted by the good, er, jolly folks at Jolly Gear and offered this product.  I accepted, promising a fair and honest review in return.This review is for the single, black “Medium” (two-dot) resistance band.  The product page could use some additional explanation and better management/standardization of product images.  You’ll see the prices increase from left to right, as the bands increase in thickness and strength; lightest/cheapest band is on the left with the heaviest/most expensive on the right.First off, no, it does not come with the coins, as shown…This is a pretty simple product, a big rubber band.  If you’re a home slingshot hobby enthusiast, this might be just the kind of thing you need to outfit your ultimate mega-slingshot.  But I digress…The band comes in at about 40” long, and it’ll stretch as far as you need it to.  I go 6’4” and had no issues with the length or stretchiness of the product.  Yes, indeed, as you stretch it farther, the resistance increases.  Nice how physics works, eh?Function: I did not attempt to use this for pull-up assistance, but instead used it for a series of arm, shoulder and leg workouts.  This product’s utility is limited only by your imagination, whether you use it in/around your body or you tie it off on a fixed object.Price: At close to $14 for a big rubber band, it seems expensive.  But this is well manufactured, with no seams and consistent texture and uniformity, so this price does not seem too far off.  A full set of all six of these bands, though, is going to run you more than $150.Bottom line: This is an extremely simple device, well manufactured, that serves a multitude of exercise purposes.

Disclosure: I was contacted by the manufacturer and offered this product.  I accepted, promising a fair and honest review in return.  The ASIN on the package I received is different from the ASIN on this page, but this is the only pair of Ixion gloves that I could find that matched…Disclaimer: I’m not weightlifting stud, at least not anymore.  I go intermittently at home with some barbells and a heavy bar with variable weights.  That being said, these gloves are a nice addition to the activity.  The 16-year-old rugby player-son also digs these gloves and has claimed them for his gym workouts.First, I just plain like the look of these gloves.  Nice color combination and accenting.Fit: I got them in Large, and this is just about right.  They fit snug, so they’re easy on but take a little of effort to get off, a little bit more effort with sweaty hands after working out.  The addition of a sizing chart on this product’s page would be a good idea.  The fingers go right to the second knuckle, while the fit goes a little over the knuckle on the thumb.Function: they are intuitive to figure out, wrist wrapping and all.  The glove wrist closure is adjustable with a Velcro closure.  The wrap goes around—depending on your size—twice.  I’ve found that the wrist wrap also doubles as a good way to bind both gloves together for storage/travel.Materials:  Good mix of leather, rubber padding and grip assistance and nylon mesh for breathing.Construction: the palm is all leather with some nice ergonomic padding and rubber grip assistance.  The front of the fingers is all leather with padding and some rubber grippies, with the sides in mesh for ventilation.  The back of the gloves is all leather, with some nice articulated construction to assist movement and it has some mesh channels for ventilation.  The back of the thumb is all mesh for ventilation.Price: at less than $22, these gloves are a good deal.  I like the materials and construction, they fit well, feel good, and I have confidence that they will do what they are supposed to and last for a while.  Even if they wear out in a year, at this price it’s a good deal.Bottom line: These are really nice weightlifting gloves, well constructed and padded, which feel good on and work just like they’re supposed to.

Disclosure: I was contacted by the manufacturer and offered this product.  I accepted, promising a fair and honest review in return.First off, the leash I received is not 6’ long; it is 5’, and that’s even giving a couple of inches for the brass connector at the end.This is a nice, simple leash that would be suitable for taking your dog out in public.The leash is all-leather, and the leather is well cut, nicely trimmed, uniform in width and thickness throughout, with no imperfections or warping.  Both the handle and the connector-end have a nice flair of four braids.  This means that there is no sewing; there is nothing physically securing the handle or the dog-end of the leash except for that little strip ¼” of leather.  I would think that over time this might wear and eventually tear, and then you’d be faced with a repair; we will have to see how this fares and how long it lasts.On the first few uses with a 95-pound black lab, the braids tightened somewhat, but not a great deal.  There does not appear to be a great deal of stress upon the end-portions of the braids. It looks like the handle end will be the part receiving the most stress.  Time will tell.At the end there is a nice heavy brass spring connector on swivel.Price: at less than $20, this seems to be a pretty good deal.  The materials appear to be good quality and other than my concern over the longevity of the braids, this seems to be a good value for what you get.Bottom line: This is a nice, simple five-foot-long leather dog leash.

This is the 1981 original release of a seminal song in French popular music, basically the introduction of US-style rap en Francais.What exactly is this guy rappin’ about?  I have no idea; my specialty is German and Indonesian.  Apparently the title comes across as “I do whatever I want to do,” or something similar.  Actually, it doesn’t matter, as it’s a catchy tune, is interesting and fun, and, yes, you can dance to it.  Having rediscovered this song after not hearing it even one time in close to 30 years, it holds up pretty well.I used to play this song on the campus radio at Washington University in St. Louis, and it was way popular with the kids of the time…who also didn’t understand its lyrics.Bottom line: This is ancient Euro-pop at its best, just like jazz and rock ‘n roll before, taking an American musical innovation (rap) and making it their own.

Title: Simple, Sterile CoverThis is a peaceful instrumental cover of the 1978 10cc classic about a Jamaican holiday that doesn’t quite go as planned.When I see “orchestra” in a group’s name, I anticipate big sound.  Now, for this original song, a white reggae tune led by a single rhythm guitar with a little bass and a vocal, I was looking forward to something alternative, something with a big fat orchestral sound.  Nope.At a duration of 4:09 it comes in about 13 seconds shorter than the original.  Given that this is, I believe, an artistic cover/interpretation of the original, I was thinking it would go longer.  Actually, I’m thinking it should go longer, by maybe offering an interesting solo, a change in instrumentation/arrangement, another key change, something.  But sadly, no.You get some good cowbell from the outset and throughout, some nice, quiet, peaceful organ and vibes, with that signature rhythm guitar twanging steadily throughout.  You get the same change in key of the original, and it’s on to the board fade, nothing special, nothing soaring, nothing spewing fireworks or excitement or really any kind of musical flair.Bottom line: This is a nice, simple, instrumental cover of a rock classic, best suited to your karaoke library for you to add the vocals and therefore the musical fun that this cover is lacking.

This is a fascinating read, but you definitely need to read the first Wildestern Saga book first.  There are just too many plot elements that will be difficult to understand without the background of the much earlier book.With that in mind, this book set in an alternate Victorian England is an absolute winner.  It's a superb mystery for teens and hey, adults will enjoy it too.  Writing is skillful and plotting is quite good.  Characters are all believable.  So do read this, but do read the previous one first even if you have to find a copy at your library.

It's important to realize that no lamination machine needs to be used in order to create your laminated labels.  It's easy to use with inkjet and laser printers.  You can customize with Avery templates and designs.There's lots of places where these can be used.  I found these ideal  for my purposes and highly recommend them.
This is indeed "comfort food".  The "ultra gentle" description is also 100% right on.  It certainly is the best available when switching to formula.  Definitely recommended.

This is a good one use pan for whatever use you want to put it too be it frying bacon, baking a cake, whatever.  Just don't expect to get more than one use out of it, although  with han washing, you might find it reusable.  It is non=stick.  Price seems a bit high, but otherwise I can happily (I'd hate to give a bad review to a company bearing my family name) recommend.

This is a surprisingly short little book for a comprehensive biography.  Yet, it is a tremendously rewarding volume covering a life that is a triumphant and yet tragic one.  This is more than a biography of the subject.  It's also a comprehensive history of the nation, Pakistan  It's certainly readable.  It's suitable for students and for general readers alike.  I do certainly recommend it without reservation to all readers.

This is a great follow up to the first book in the series.  This is pure space opera well written.  Each book is by a different author and I personally couldn't see any difference in style in these first two books.BTW, you don't have to read the first book to enjoy this one, but I recommend that you do so as to have the complete story of the eight characters.  This one has some very interesting twists in it.The action is non-stop and definitely right up a middle grader's alley.  Heck, we parents and grandparents, if science fiction fans, can enjoy it too.  Highly recommended as quite intelligent science fiction adventure for kids.
This definitely is a serviceable case.  It's slim enough and it protects.  It looks good too, although that isn't all that big a deal.  Whatever, this is worth the price and I recommend it.

This is a tough case and just what else could you expect from OtterBox?  I haven't been disappointed in that brand yet.  It doesn't add much bulk.  Above all, there's no slipperiness.  You don't go wrong with this brand.

I'm certainly well satisfied with this as a protective case.  After all, this is OtterBox and that itself speaks highly for quality.  It's sleek looking and above all it works splendidly.  Nobody should have any complaints at all about this case.

I certainly don't agree with these negative reviews.  I guess different folks have different experiences, but I find this to nbe a perfect fit and a great protective item.  Not only that, it sports a sharp look.  I certainly didn't find it the least bit slippery.  I wouldn't call it vulky either.  As nI say, to each their own experience, but I'm very happy with this
I miss having a stylus holder.  Otherwise, this is okay but nothing special.

These are quite easy to swallow.  At 82, I do have joint problems and while it could be imagination, I feel a bit more strength in my bones and joints.  I will update this in time to let you know end results.  So far, I'm quite pleased with the results.
Touugh two layer construction makes this a super case.  It looks sharp and it's good reliable protection.  There's no question but that this is the best protector you're liable to find.
Excellent quality and super looks.  I do especially appreciate the coloring.  This is one truly super case and I do urge you to buy and use it.
This is a great case.  It's super easy to use.  It has an elegant look to it, but most importantly, it protects.  I give it my highest recommendation.

This quite disappointed me.  I did rave about the first book in the trilogy but somehow missed the second one.  That didn't hurt since the author did a good job in bringing us up to date.  However, the middle part bogged down and was overly long.  And the characterization wasn't as fresh.  Win especially wasn't as strong a character as he was originally.Don't get me wrong.  If you've read the others, do read this one.  It isn't bad, not at all.  But it is disappointing.

This is a rich, vibrant story that spans four generations.  It is deeply a woman's story, but I don't really call it "chick lit" because I consider that a somewhat derogatory term.  This is true literature and it wraps itself around the reader.  The writing is beautiful.  Not only that, the characters are absolutely real life.  They are people you can embrace and love.All in all, this is an extraordinary novel.  Yes indeed, it is targetted for women, but the more sensitive male will also find this a tremendous read.  I recommend this highly with absolutely no hesitation.

I learned to like pomegranates as a kid although I considered eating them to be a bit of work to get such a short burst of flavor.  During the last few years, I've become fond of pomegranate juice.This is the first pomegranate candy I've tasted and it's certainly a winner.  Coated with dark chocolate, there's a wonderful balance of flavors.  The rich dark chocolate flavor blends wonderfully with the sharp fruit flavor.  It was my honest intention to make this bag last for a week, but my mistake was to have the bag too close to my reading chair, with the result that I'm finishing the bag in five days.  I love the pomegranate taste and am glad the flavor is finally being used in candy.As an irrelevant aside, no I'm hoping soft drink manufacturers discover pomegranate...maybe Pepsi could come out with a pom flavored Mountain Dew....or a pom flavored Dr. Pepper might work.  LOLAnyway, if you love chocolare and if you love pomegranate, you'll certainly love this Brookside candy.

I've introduced this game to the game players in the senior citizen apartment complex where I reside.  This is a complex game to learn, but the players do enjoy it.  It's not necessary to be familiar with the TV series to enjoy playing, although the whow's fans certainly will like it.  It can be played by 3-6 players.  It is an exciting board game and I do recommend it.

This is a good start to a new mystery series and will of course appeal to dog lovers.  The author goes into detail of Robo's training and the partnership between the dog and the heroine, Matte.  The author has been compared to C. J. Box and I agree.  The description of a small Colorado town rings true.I did find this disappointing as a whodunnit.  The denouement is no surprise.  Therefore, the book's strength is in the relationship between Matte and Robo.  We are also introduced to characters including the veterinarian, Cole, and his family and police personell such asdispatcher Rainbow who I imagine will be regulars in the series.All in all, this promises to be a good series for mystery fans and dog lovers

This is a five star grass if you're living in the deep south or the tropics.  It's fast growing and easy to maintain.  Scott is an established leader for grass seed.  My parents in the nursery business always recommended Scotts.  Of course, they wouldn't have recommended perennial rye..  That doesn't flourish in California.  But in the right location, it's ideal.

Educators will get the most from this inspirational book, but that doesn't mean others can't read it and get value from it.  This is yet another book listing  key strategies to improve your career.  Actually, you could say there are five, but two of them, autonomy and cooperation, work together.  The others are simplicity, feedback, and accountability,This is an easy to read inspirational call to action.  Yes, it's primarily for educators and students preparing for PHDs will sure benefit from this book.  But the advice can be made to fit in any vocation.  Highly recommended to all.

It's not often that I can flat out tell you to read this book and know beforehand that you'll thank me for that.  The book is bursting with optimism, and I'm talking about the real thing, not a phony act planned to get you to buy the book..  Bert and John Jacobs are indeed enthusiastic about life and they spread this enthusiasm.Others have listed the  10 superoiwers, so I wasn't going to....but what the heck, I might as well: Openness, Courage, Simplicity, Humor, Gratitude, Fun, Compassion, Creativity, Authenticity, and Love.Oh yes, I must mention the illos.  If you come across this book at a bookstore...the hardbound copy, that is...do flip through it.  The wild illustrations will sell this book to you if nothing else does.Once again, just read this book whether you buy it or check it out of the library.  If you do the latter, chances are you'll end up buying a copy just to have it on hand for whenever you need some smiles and some inspiration.'Nuff said.

This is sort of an oddball type novel.  It is highly readable.  The characters are real.  However, parts seemed unnecessary, and the middle did drag a bit.  However, it was enjoyable.  Some will find parts rather offensive, so be ye warned.  Parts are good, near brilliant, and others are a major letdown.  Basically, it's an okay but quite odd read.

I turned 13 in June, 1946, and started high school a year ahead having skipped a grade.  I was of course unaware that this was indeed a pivotal year.  I was puzzled that Russia considered an ally during the war suddenly became a menace.  Stalin suddenly became a bad guy after having been a good guy during the war.  Otherwise, I was ignorant of world events and this book is indeed a revelation.  It is a well done history and I recommend it to students as well as to adults.  Those my age will of course quite devour it, but it's for all readers.

This lis a good book for reference and also a good coffee table book.  I don't consider it "definitive".  I don't quite agree with the differentiation between filmed operettas, particularly those starring Jeanette McDonald and Nelson Eddy, and musicals.  However, there's lots of good information on stage and screen musicals.The illustrations help make the book.  This is a book you can read from beginning to end, or one which you can skim through looking for information on a particular musical, performer, or composer.  It is a heavy book...4.6 pounds.  And it's definitely worthwhile.

This type of exercise is brand new to me, plus at 82 years old, and one who hasn't exercised for a while, it is goinjg to take some getting used to on my part.  I may never get past the yellow band, but that will function for me.  I had a slight difficulty getting it set up, but otherwise it's definitely okay.  I've already felt a little better even with very light exercise.  For those who are in more fit shape than I am, these should work very well in giving you a good workout.

These are good gloves for a whole batch of purposes.  I use them especially for cleaning purposes to protect my hands from the chemicals of the cleaning fluid.  They don't seem that large on my slim hands.  They're just easy to slip on and off.  I do recommend them for whatever purpose you may use them for.

This is okay for a light reading.  I did want to like the main character more than I did.  As a mystery, it is rather predictable.  It's good for a light leisurely read, but it isn't terribly involving.
I'd call this a strange and yet wonderful novel.  I can't say a whole lot about it.  It is indeed magical and it is indeed surreal.  It's a book to just read and waft away with.

This is a good gift set consisting of three pairs of earrings.  These are freshwater cultured pearl, Aquamarine, and jade.  The jade is dyed.  These are for modest women who like the extra touch small earrings give their ears but don't want larger and more noticeable ones.  The price for the three pair is certainly reasonable.  I do imagine they will appeal more to the middle aged and senior women.  This is good for giving to a loved one.

I've been taking CoQ10 for about a month now and do feel that the nutrient is helping me maintain a better energy level.  As an 82 year old, that's important to me.  These are small and easy to swallow gels and you only need one a day.  I do recommend this to fellow seniors for energy, for heart health, and for skin health.  They're well priced and worth it.

This isn't as bad as some of these reviews indicate.  On the other hand, it certainly isn't as good as the one 5 star review indicates.  It is a helicopter, not a drone.  It looks cheap and flimsy but it does fly.  It does need to be handled gingerly because it looks and feels like it would be easily damaged.  I'm not sure why it's labelled for inside use only.  It does work outside.It seems to be overpriced.  I wouldn't expect it to be priced over $25.  All in all, seems to be okay, but if I had paid for it rather than receiving it for review purposes, I wouldn't be too happy with it.  It is rather amusing to use, but I don't think it would last very long in the hands of an 8-12 year old.  Shop around to see if you can't find something a bit sturdier and less expensive.

Tests for graduate study programs are important and indeed challenging.  There's no guarantee that this guide will give you a high score.  That's up to you.  However, this volume of practice questions should heighten your confidence and that's extremely important.  I do recommend purchasing this and use it for your preparation.  It may be well to acquire additional material and not rely on this alone, but it's bound to help.  Good luck.

This certainly does what it's supposed to and that is clean up pet stains leaving a clean and pleasant odor.  This will work in any carpet cleaning machine and leaves your rug clean and sharp looking.  It's not cheap, but it's sure effective, so I do give it a high rating.  I'm presently getting my apartment ready for inspection, and this certainly is taking good care of making my carpet spotless.  Yeah, this gets my highest recommendation.

This is a fast paced beginning to a new series for middle graders.  Set in the 1930's and in New York City, we're introduced to a freak show which includes four quite unusual youngsters.  The plot centers around the theft of the show's latest acquisition, a shrunken head.  The four kids band together to solve the theft.The book is enhanced by some really creepy artwork.  It's a marvelous read (accent on the "marvel" which will probably attract the attention of parents as well as the kids that the book is targeted for.  The tone is creepy, but not really scary.  It's not likely to give young readers nightmares.It truly captures the spirit of the great depression years.  While quite entertaining, there's learning value here too.  Highly recommended.
This works well in any rug cleaning device.  It does what it's supposed to and leaves a fresh and clean scent.  There's no need to call in professional rug cleaners when you have this.

Fleas and ticks certainly are not the problem they once were.  Of the  various products available, I found Big Spot to be the easiest and most effective.  The price is reasonable considering the product's effectiveness.  Highly recommended for dogs of all sizes.

To be honest, there isn't a whole lot here for the more mature reader.  The book is what it's supposed to be, a lightweight romantic piece of fluff.  If that's what you're looking for, you'll be pleased with this.  Those in my age group aren't likely to find this to be a book to get involved in.
This is as good a guide as you'll find for getting ready for the GMAT exams.  Highly recommended.

Please note!!! Many of the reviews posted here are incorrectly referencing a Belkin HDMI switcher for a home entertainment system. This 3-port headset switch has NOTHING to do with HDMI or TVs/consoles, so any poor reviews mentioning HDMI have been incorrectly posted here and do not reflect this product.As for my review, I love this little switch. It was very easy to set up with my Windows 10 PC for Skype calls, my iPhone 6 Plus and my in-home landline. This has simplified my life in a big way. The device itself has a very small footprint and tucks nicely under the edge of my monitor in a way that still allows me to access the buttons without it taking up any space. I wear my bluetooth headset (Plantronics Voyager Legend, love love love) and can answer any call with it using this amazing little switch. It doesn't matter if the call comes in over the house phone, iPhone or PC, I can receive and make all calls from one headset without having to say "Hang on!!!" while I make the caller wait to set up my headset if it was previously paired with a different device. It seems like such a small thing but it's made a huge difference in the few weeks I've had it already. It's definitely a necessity for anyone who spends a lot of time with phone or video chat communication on a daily basis, be it for business or otherwise. I find myself wishing I had one of these for all my bluetooth devices as pairing and unpairing becomes a huge hassle when you're sharing bluetooth over multiple devices and machines. Having this effectively eliminates the need to have multiple headsets like I was using previously. Great little device and highly recommended.

Excellent addition to your whitening regimen. I have had professional whitening done by my dentist, followed up by the "cheap" at home solutions used with my professional dentist tray to keep my teeth white as they do start to fade over time, regardless of whether you had it done at a dentist or not. Usually whitening toothpaste keeps the whiteness going for a good while longer than regular toothpaste, but I found this to be absolutely the best whitening product I've tried. After a brush in the morning, I feel there's definitely an improvement over my prior all-in-one (including whitening) toothpaste. The first step is a deep cleaning whitening toothpaste and there's a clear improvement after this step, but the real improvement comes with the finisher in step 2, which Crest calls a "whitening finisher." I noticed a very clear improvement immediately after brushing. I don't think this is intended to whiten teeth that haven't been treated before, but as a touch up for previously treated teeth and as a followup to the excellent Crest 3D Luxe whitening strips, this is a great product and one I'm definitely keeping in my cabinet. Recommended!!

Very clever design. We have a boat trailer that we use throughout the spring and summer and I never even knew this product existed. It bolts directly to the frame of your trailer with ease and has everything you need for a tire change. It's not waterproof, but most of it is coated with an anti-rust treatment so I'm not really concerned about it. I haven't used it myself yet, but my fiance swears by it. The scissor jack, handles and lug wrench are all inside so once it's on the frame, you don'tr have to think about it again. Great addition for any trailer owners.

Great durable ball! Holds up to lots of abuse from my 50lb golden. She loves squeak toys and will usually focus all her energy on removing the squeaker as soon as she receives a new toy, but not so with this one! It's lasted through many chew sessions and still squeaks like new. She loves it! It isn't the best ball for bouncing, but I highly recommend it for fetch and water play as it does float. If you need a bouncy ball, Squeakair balls are also great!

It has a strong smell so I notice it all the time. I was willing to overlook this if my girls liked it, but they don't. They are 2.5 years old and have been fed fresh fruit and veggies their entire lives, so I guess I'm not surprised that they don't love this dry, hard kibble. I need to leave them home for a few days while I go on a short trip as I'm not able to take them with me as I usually do, and thought this would fill in nicely as I can't leave fresh food out for that many days without it spoiling. I mixed this up with dried meal worms, dried fruit and sunflower seeds to give them a variety to munch on while I'm gone and wanted to test it out before I leave. Unfortunately, they devoured everything BUT these pellets.I don't want to preach, but if you have exotic animals like sugar gliders, you need to be prepared to feed them properly. Their teeth are not meant to bite into or chew hard foods like this, and no kibble is going to give them the balanced diet that they need. They need real, fresh fruit, veggies and nuts on a daily basis as chewing on hard kibble hurts their teeth and gums. If you can get your glider to eat this, please only use it as a temporary filler when fresh food is not available, such as my case when you're out of town and can't bring them with you.

I've been using the smaller SteelSeries Stratus for almost a year now, and while I have loved it, this Stratus XL feels soooo much better in my hands. It feels weighty and well built, very similar to an Xbox One/360 controllers with very similar button layout. The only difference is the D-pad and left joystick are swapped, more akin to the PS4 Dual Shocks. The shoulder buttons are almost identical to the Xbox One so it feels very familiar right off the bat. The smaller Stratus controller is fantastic for portable use, but nothing beats a full size controller for comfort and familiarity. Pairing is very simple and the battery indicator lets you know when you're running low and need to replace your 2 AA's. Controls are quick and responsive. I've never noticed any lag at all when playing games on my iPad either directly or via my Apple TV. In this generation of mobile gaming, there are so many good games out there that take full advantage of the Stratus XL and more are jumping on the bandwagon all the time. If you're at all into gaming on your tablet or phone, you owe it to yourself to pick one of these up. Most people who own a tablet or smartphone also own a similar device for streaming to your TV (Apple TV, Chromecast, etc) so paired with the Stratus, your tablet or smartphone becomes a portable gaming console. Best controller yet from SteelSeries. Totally in love!

Love this charging cable. It's slightly longer than the standard Apple (about 6" longer) and works just as well, plus doesn't bind up as easily due to it being flat. I got this to match my product red leather Apple case and it's fantastic! No complaints!

My golden loves this so much and I am so impressed with the ingredients and the honesty of this company that I may be switching over permanently. My golden has about half high quality kibble and half "human" food and she is extremely healthy and energetic, but I admit I have always felt some guilt over giving her dry kibble. No matter how much you spruce it up or how high quality the ingredients are, it's still dry kibble. She gets a variety of foods daily in addition to the kibble, usually a portion of our family meals, but there are times when she is just bored with the dry dog food and won't eat it. It's always good to switch up your dog's diet because too much of anything is never good, but no matter how many different types of kibble you give your dog, it's still kibble.I fed my dogs raw before my son was born, but ever since then, I've been very hesitant to handle raw meat in my home. I can just never be 100% sure that I've cleaned up enough to prevent illness. While I still hold that Blue Buffalo Wilderness is one of the best dry dog foods you can give your dog, "real" healthy food is always better. This is the first time I've ever seen a dog food that is FDA approved and considered human grade quality. At first the price seems ludicrous, but when you realize that after preparation it makes four times that amount, it's more economical. It's still pricey but not much more than the top quality dry brands out there. I'd like to see the price come down to be more comparable with top brands so more people are tempted to try it out. My golden loves it so much and I'm thrilled about the quality of the ingredients, and giving wet food is better for digestion. I really have no reasons to not love it. I'm sold!

I have a very picky golden that needs to be fed different things each day or she will stop eating. Even the very best top quality kibble doesn't satisfy her if she's been eating the same thing for days, so she will just refuse to eat it. To combat this, she always receives something in addition to her kibble, usually something from the meals the rest of the family is eating, like chicken, steak, etc. I found this to be a simple way to spice up her food but it definitely won't replace giving her actual "real" food. She seems to enjoy it thoroughly, and the ingredient list is indeed impressive, but I'm confused about how a dry kibble could be considered "raw." Raw is highly beneficial because it contains the nutrients in their raw form, with nothing lost to the cooking or preparation process. This is why eating raw fruits and veggies is better for you than canned which not only contain preservatives and usually added sugar, they also lose some of their nutritional value. I understand they freeze dry it to preserve all the goodness of the food, but it still just doesn't make sense in my mind that anything other than true fresh, raw food can be called raw. In any sense though, she loves it and it appears to be of quality ingredients, so it's a nice extra little treat for her.

True plug and play. Installed software, prompted to plug in the adapter, and voila, working. Make sure you give it a minute or two to download drivers every time you pair a new bluetooth device. I've had no issue pairing any of my devices. You can't beat the price for how much functionality this adds to your computer and it literally takes up no space. Love it!!

I complaind to my doctor that I had chronic diarrhea that came and went, e.g. I'd be bad for a few days, then not so bad for a few days, and then bad again (I think you know what I mean by "bad").  He asked me if my stool smelled. I paused and re-examined the medical degree he has hanging on the wall. Of course it smells. What he meant was, really, really smelled. I reconsidered leaving him and answered yes. He got an "ah ah" look on his face and said that I needed to take a probiotic because the increased odor was a sign that I must have had some sort of problem that cleared up but my body wasn't producing good bacteria fast enough to overtake the bad bacteria. So, I started taking a probiotic every day.If you aren't currently taking a probiotic you have my sympathies because you're probably researching the subject and I suspect that you're as confused as I was. With most medications, if I can call this that, my doctor gives me a script and I have it filled at the pharmacy. Simple. But not the case with over the counter products. I was on my own. I was using Philips probiotics and was pleased with the results. My diarrhea subsided, cramping went away and I wasn't as gassy as I was before not to mention there were fewer stinkers (sorry, I'm trying to keep this as family friendly as possible).I used some Viva Laps products in the past and was pleased with the quality and effectivenes. When I was offered their probiotic I didn't hesitate and started taking it instead of the Philips product. I haven't noticed a difference, which is a good thing because I was doing well.Will I permanently switch to the Viva Labs product over the Philips? I don't know. They both work fine so it will probably get down to price.

Not long ago I built a MeccaNoid G15 KS along with my able sidekicks - an 11 year old and a 13 year old.  The KS is identical to this robot except the KS is four feet tall and this one is two feet tall.  That build went well and you can see my review, and others, on that product page.Meccano MeccaNoid G15 KS.Building this robot wasn't quite as challenging for two reasons. First, it's smaller so there weren't as many parts and second, we learned a lot from the first build. That said the instructions, complemented with youtube videos, were pretty clear. It's hard to mess up and when you do it becomes obvious pretty quickly. Even though this was our second robot build we did have to take a leg apart to fix an error.I think it helps if you do a few things. First, we unpacked everything and got them organized.  There are a lot of screws and nuts and we kept those in plastic containers. The other parts were put together by the name used in the instructions.  Second, we put aside the entire day to work. It turned out we didn't need the entire day but it was nice not feeling rushed because we had to do or go somewhere else. Third, read the reviews, watch the youtube videos, etc.  Just search for MeccaNoid G15 and you're going to find a lot of useful information (OK, some of it isn't very useful).  Finally, patience matters, especially when you're building this with a youngster.  We walked away from it a few times.We had fun building it together but that was nothing compared to the fun when you finish.  We did some quick testing and found that we had one servo wired incorrectly. Fixed that and the little guy was ready to go.  He's (or is it a she? - you decide) easy to control and the app (iPhone and Android) is easy to use.FYI - I saw the KS fully assembled at a local Brookstone store at the mall. It was more expensive than Amazon but if you want to see the robot live you can check and see if your local store has one on the floor.

My daughter is a teacher and I'll proudly hang this on my tree in honor of her.  Like any Lenox product I've ever owned this is a quality piece. The design is simple but sends the right message - you're a teacher and we love you!  If you look closely you'll see a small apple at the top of the heart.The ornament comes in a nice box if you're giving this as a gift. The box can also be used to store the ornament and keep it from chipping.Overall, very attractive. Perfect gift for a teacher who will certainly be impressed with the quality and the brand name.

I have two older dogs that have gotten a bit overweight and since they aren't as active as they used to be I try to control their weight with food. I thought this food would be an alternative to the food I was using but it's not going to be a temporary or permanent replacement.Both dogs walked up their bowls, sniffed it, looked at me with their "what is this?" look, and then slowly started eating. I think it was more because they were hungry than anything else. Neither one of them finished their meal and that's very unusual.Although the description of this product led me to believe that the first ingredient is chicken it's not. After I read the description a few more times it hit me that they were describing the weight maintenance product and then added a short blurb about the weight control product; in my mind I put the two together. As I write this Eukanuba hasn't listed the ingredients for the product. I took a picture of the bag but I apologize for the quality. White letters on a pink bag are difficult to capture but I think you'll get the idea.  The first ingredient is corn meal followed by chicken by-product (I don't even want to know what that is but I'm guessing it isn't meat).  That's followed by simply "chicken" and then a long list of grains and things I can't pronounce.

Although my wife and I live in Arizona we are both Vitamin D deficient.  My wife is also calcium deficient and Vitamin D helps with the absorption of calcium.  We've been taking Vitamin D for years and while I can't attest to any change in the way I feel I do know that our Vitamin D levels are now in the normal range.I'll admit that I was leery about trying an unknown brand. I've seen less expensive brands being offered from off-shore companies and I've passed. I don't see any reason to save money to buy something that doesn't work.  I did some research into Viva Labs and they appear to be legitimate. They don't sell in retail stores which may be why they are unfamiliar to me. I found enough information on them to feel comfortable that their product is what they say it is.Like most Vitamin D on the market the pills are very small - pea size making them easy to swallow. I've included a picture.

I don't use the word "adorable" very often but I can't think of another word to describe this ornament.  It's very nicely made; I looked over it very closely and couldn't find a flaw.  The arms and the headpiece aren't the same as the Frozen character - they're a bright gold color and sparkle under the light.  They captured that same goofy look on his face nicely but there's no contrast between his mouth and the rest of his head so you have to look closely to see, for example, his overbite.Definitely an ornament that will be placed on the front of the tree for everyone to see.

My name is Joe and I'm a chocoholic. Part of my rehab is to occasionally treat myself to some very good chocolate and this bar fits that requirement just fine.While this brand may not be as recognizable in the US as other Swiss chocolates I think it's as good as the others that I've tried. The milk chocolate is smooth and doesn't have that waxy feel and taste you get with popular US brands like Hershey and Mars. I find it comparible to Lindt and Ghirardelli. Note, unlike M&M's this will melt in your hands because there isn't any paraffin.The roasted hazelnuts are a nice complement to the chocolate. The hazelnuts are ground small (think Nestlé Crunch) and very flavorful. I wouldn't mind having a container of the nuts.

I've been using a Tech Solutions shredder for the past seven or eight years. It's been fine but it has some quirks and it doesn't do a good a job as it used to.This shredder is essentially a shredder (motor, controls, blades) that sits on top of an included plastic trash container that's been customized for use. The controls are simple enough. It's pretty much on/off, forward/backward.  There's also an overheat and bin full indicator. After you attach the top and plug it in you're ready to go. It turns on automatically when you feed it and stops when it's finished.A few observations.It's much quieter than my old shredder. That's not to say it's quiet but you can hold a conversation while it's running.There's a window on the side of the container so you have an idea of how full it is.A very nice feature is the ability to compact your cuttings. You just unlock the top, remove the power cord and push down. A nice feature that doesn't leave a mess.Emptying the container is also simple. Remove the top and dump the container into a trash bag. With my old shredder I had to slide the container out to empty it which always made a mess.The slit for feeding paper is just over 8 1/2 inches; if you have anything larger you're going to have to fold it and you are going to have to pay attention when you feed it.While I was able to feed it 12 sheets of standard 20 pound paper it did groan and slow down a bit when I did. Ten sheets went as smoothly as one.I'm happy with this. I'm not sure I'd use it in a high volume setting like an office but for a good, well built home or home office shredder it does the trick.

I've been using Windows for as long as Windows has existed. I think I've used every version except Vista over the years. I recently upgraded a laptop from Windows 8 to Windows 10 and, like almost every other time I've upgraded, I felt a bit lost and wanted to learn about the new features.I've tried using online tools but I've always found that sitting down with a good reference book next to my PC is the best way to go.  This book, at over 850 pages, has something for everyone. My wife isn't very techy but she's gotten some use out of the less advanced topics that I just pass over.  While the book appears intimidating - did I mention that it's over 850 pages? - it's laid out very nicely with gray "tabs" to get you to the right chapter.  The authors provide more than enough explanation and examples to guide you but if you're just looking for a quick explanation there's a "Wrapping Up" section at the end of each chapter that has bullet points for the major topics from that chapter.Good book that will live on my desk for the next month or so and then will go into the bookcase with all of it's predecessors.

I did an unfair comparison of this soundbar to my much more expensive home theater system and wish I wouldn't have because the Definitive Technology product fared pretty well for a lot less money and real estate.My family room has a fairly new Samsung 60 inch 4K TV. It's connected to an Onkyo TX-NR838 receiver which sends audio out to a 5.1 Aperion Audio speaker system that includes a dual 8 inch powered subwoofer.  I have all of my inputs going into the Onkyo so the video is sent to the TV from the receiver and the sound is sent out to the speakers and subwoofer.  My inputs include cable TV, an Oppo BD player, and two game consoles.  I also use the receiver to play music from my media player and from the Internet. For this test I connected everything directly to the TV and then connected the TV to the soundbar, i.e., I took the Onkyo and Aperion speakers out of the equation.Setup:  Very easy. Simply unpack the soundbar, subwoofer, and accessories (cables, remote) and hook everything up.  A basic manual is included (note, it's under the Styrofoam in a black folder that you're bound to overlook).  You can download a more extensive manual from Definitive Technology's website.  I installed the soundbar on a cabinet under the TV but if you're going to wall mount it you should be aware that the power cable that goes from the soundbar to the brick is 56 inches long. There's an additional 6 feet (roughly) of power cable coming out of the brick at the other end to go into a wall receptacle. All of the connections on the back of the soundbar are side-mounts so you shouldn't have any gaps between the soundbar and the wall with a bit of pre-planning on where to drill the hole in the wall.  the soundbar also comes with a very thin digital optical cable (about 6 1/2 feet). The soundbar has two keyhole slots for mounting.  Also keep in mind that the pairing buttons are on the back of the soundbar.  If you're going to connect to your home WiFi you will probably want to connect it before you mount it to the wall.Basic Use:  I tried this out with cable TV before I connected it to WiFi.  The soundbar found the wireless subwoofer with no problem and began giving me more than decent audio from a television program.  The front panel isn't annoying at all - you won't even know it's there.  When you adjust the volume you'll see a row of LEDs light up and turn on/off as you increase or decrease the volume level; they disappear within a few seconds.  The included remote is probably a lot bigger than it needs to be but it does fit nicely into your hand. I do have a complaint about the remote - it's black and the lettering is an off-white and the + and - symbols are black but raised from the surface. It's very difficult to see in a low lit room and the buttons aren't back-lit.  In addition to power and volume control, the remote allows you to switch sources (2 optical and 1 aux), mute, switch between optimized settings for music or movie/tv, and adjust the subwoofer and center channel levels.  I plan on adding this soundbar to my Harmony Ultimate remote so it won't be a problem in the future.  FYI, the manual I downloaded from their website has all the remote codes if you run into a problem with your universal remote. I've included a picture of the remote.WiFi:  In order to connect directly to music sources you have to connect the soundbar to your home WiFi. After you download the Definitive Technology app (iPhone or Android) it will search for WiFi networks and PlayFi devices.  When it's done you can choose your source using the app and begin playing music.  I couldn't connect at first but after I put the soundbar back into pairing mode it all went OK.Sound: I realize this is very subjective but I'm impressed.  I've always found that my Onkyo/Aperion setup weren't doing a very good job of processing dialog from my cable box. The dialog from this soundbar is noticeably better.  I was getting some odd subwoofer sound that I didn't get with my 5.1 setup. Clearly the crossover between the Onkyo and the Definitive Technology soundbar aren't the same. I adjusted the subwoofer and the problem went away.  TV aside, I put it to the test listening to some music.  First I connected to my home media server. I have a few very poor quality recordings (ripped from CDs) on my server and the soundbar didn't make them sound any better. To be fair, neither did the Onkyo.  Streaming and digital downloads sounded much better.  Maybe not quite as good as my Onkyo/Aperion setup but not that you'd notice unless you were focusing on it.  My home theater system does a much better job with bass but my subwoofer cost about the same as this soundbar.  I'm not saying this subwoofer is bad I'm just saying that if you're an audiophile you may not be thrilled.  But, for the average person? No problem.For the real test I fired up the BD player.  My go-to test movie is the first five or so minutes of 'Saving Private Ryan'. With my Onkyo/Aperion system and the volume jacked up you feel like you're in the middle of the battle.  The Definitive Technology soundbar did an admirable job but I missed not having the rear speakers and, as I said earlier, the Aperion subwoofer does a better job.  If you've never had rears then you probably won't notice and you'll be much happier than listening to anything compared to your TV speakers.Overall, this is a nice, high end soundbar/sub combination. While you can certainly get less expensive alternatives I think you'll definitely notice the difference in sound and usability of this product.

This is a well made LED bulb that puts out a lot of light. But, it's a daylight white bulb meaning that it's a pretty bright white light.
