That's not a problem but if you're used to a soft white light you may not like the effect.I first tried this bulb in a reading lamp. No problems except, because of the design, most of the light went up. Obviously for reading I needed the light to go down and out. I had to put the CFL bulb back into that lamp for my needs.I found the perfect use for it in my living room. I have an accept spot that shines up from the floor and highlights a sculpture in that corner. The daylight white coupled with the light mostly coming from the top was perfect for this application.  I had a 100 watt incandescent bulb in that fixture and it's on a timer so it comes on for about 4 hours each day.  Getting about the same light output with 88 fewer watts is a definite plus. This bulb will save me a few dollars every year and last, by my calculations, about 14 years.

My wife dropped her $50 sunglasses and the frame just under the lens snapped. The lens didn't come out but it was just a matter of time.  I thought about using glue but two problems - 1. if I used something like Gorilla glue I would have had to somehow clamp it until the glue cured. With rounded frames that's almost impossible. 2. if I used SuperGlue or Gorilla glue I would have to get the two pieces to touch each other and that wasn't possible.I saw Bondic advertised before and thought it was a clever idea. Since the sunglasses had a small space between the broken sides this seemed like the perfect solution since I could fill the space and I didn't need to clamp it.This is incredibly easy to use. Clean the two sides the best you can, squeeze the glue into the area and hold the ultraviolet light over it for a few seconds. You can actually see it cure.  For the sunglasses I had to apply the glue then cure it and then build on top of that layer. The entire repair took less than five minutes.  I noticed that the frame had some hairline cracks under the other lens. As long as I had everything out I applied some glue to that area as well to fill in the cracks that were eventually going to split.  I overfilled them which left a small lump on the frame but I used a nail file to smooth it out.  On both areas you have to look very closely to even notice that they were repaired.Yes, this product costs about 20 bucks but it just saved a $50 pair of sunglasses and there's plenty of glue left for future repairs.

Is this dog food or a treat? I ask that somewhat in jest because of the reaction I'm getting to it from my two dogs. One of them will eat anything put in front of her. The other one is very picky so before I bother filling his bowl with new food I offer him some by hand to see if he goes into what  call "cat mode" and snub his nose at it and walk away. He not only devoured the first offering but kept begging for more.I'm happy that they both like the taste but, as their Lord and Master (ha!) I have a responsibility to make sure they are eating stuff that's good fr them. I'm not a dog nutritionist but it didn't take long for me to feel good about giving this food to them based on the ingredients, reviews here and elsewhere and just good old common sense.This is certainly a hit with me and the dogs.

I have two dogs. One would eat rotting tree bark (and has). The other is an extremely picky eater.  He'll even snub his nose at human food. It's possible he was a cat in a previous life.I always mix some canned food in with their kibble in the morning. They both devour it and, unbeknownst to them, they also eating some powered joint medicine that I mix in.The first time I mixed this with their kibble the aforementioned bark eater didn't miss a beat and wolfed her food down without coming up for air.  The picky eater took a look, then looked up at me for assurance, then sniffed it, then looked back at me with a "What is this?" look.  I encouraged him and he eventually ate it, but very slowly. The next day he skipped the looking at me ritual and just started eating. After a few days he didn't skip a beat and at it like he was getting it for the past five years.So, from a dog's perspective, it's OK. They like it. From an owner's perspective I'm OK with it too. Yes, it does have a bit of an odor but only if you stick your nose in the can and seriously, how often are you going to do that?  It mixes well, but not as well as a chunky/gravy canned food with kibble. I had to add a bit of water to make the powdered medicine completely disappear.While I would normally consider fish to be something I would serve to a cat the dogs seem to like the food and the variation to their diet.

After years of enjoying stir fry at restaurants I decided it was something I wanted to do at home. Yes, stir fry is supposed to be healthier but I really wanted to make it because it tastes good.I did some research on Woks and got totally confused.  One site said to get carbon steel. Another said stainless steel. And another said to get cast iron.  I found sites that said a nonstick coating was bad and just as many that said it didn't matter.  Arrrggghhhh!  I finally did what I should have done in the first place and just checked here for the most popular Wok. This Joyce Chen was the second most popular. I think because it was slightly more money since it came with a lid, a tool, and a cookbook.I seasoned the wok per the instructions and that seemed to work out OK except the bottom of the wok turned dark. At first I thought it was burned oil but it was also dark on the outside.  I ignored it.For my first time out I decided to make stir fry chicken with snap peas and red bell pepper served over rice.  I didn't get the recipe from the included cookbook (which is very small btw) but found thousands of recipes online.  It really turned out well.  Clean-up was pretty easy. As advised, I didn't use soap but just rinsed the wok and scrubbed it a bit with a nylon scrubber to get the sticky parts off.  I then towel dried it and placed it on my cooktop at medium head for a few minutes to totally dry.  After putting a bit of oil on the surface I put it in a cabinet. A nice feature is that the long handle is easy to remove and re-attach to save space.A few notes.First - if you like super shiny, pretty cookware I don't think you're going to like this one. It got a patina on it when I was conditioning it and I can already see parts of the sides turning color as I use it.  I'm told this is a good thing.Second - I'm not convinced that I can't simply use my large saute pan. But, I really feel like I'm a pro when I use the wok.Third - I have an induction cooktop and this works great.Overall, I'm pretty happy I got this. The cookbook isn't of much use but it does include the basic instructions for conditioning and use. The bamboo tool is very nice and did a nice job of moving the ingredients around. I haven't had much use for the lid but I think it'll come in hand when I steam something.

Like the vast majority of people I hate flossing. I just do - for a number of reasons including an old injury to my left hand that makes it difficult to hold the floss. That aside, it's boring and time consuming.Four or five years ago I started using a WaterPik. To test the effectiveness I started using it the day after my six month checkup/cleaning so I'd start with a clean slate so to speak. Lo and behold, six months later and the hygienist commented on how much better my gums looked and there was very little plaque.For those of you who have used a WaterPik you know it's not without its issues. The biggest problem is that it can be a bit messy. You learn quickly that opening your mouth even a little bit means you're going to be wiping down the mirror.  The other problem is that you can't really aim the wand because your mouth is closed.I was reluctant to try the Philips Airfloss at first because I was pretty happy with my WaterPik.  But, I figured that if I always thought that way I'd still be using an Apple II computer. After charging it for a few hours (the manual says 24 hours but it came over half charged) I filled up the little reservoir with my mouthwash (ACT), turned it on, and put it in  my mouth. But, like an idiot, I didn't close my lips.  Bad idea - but my mirror needed cleaning anyway.  I quickly learned that it was OK to open my mouth to position it but to close my lips when I pressed the button. Learned behavior - Pavlov would be so proud of me.Poof...poof...poof...whirrrrr. That's what happens. The poofs are the air/mouthwash pulses between your teeth. The whirrrr is the air pump.  I kept moving the little wand between my teeth and pressing the button.  What's kind of cool is that when I get a poof my cheek on the other side of my mouth moves.  My whole mouth was done in about a minute - not bad!  What's better is that it did a really nice job.  Just before using it I ate a bagel. A really doughy bagel that left a lot of stuff between my teeth.  When I spit after I was done with the Airfloss I was amazed at how much stuff came out - the bagel and what I hope were sesame seeds. I inspected my teeth and everything was gone.  Better yet, my mouth felt very clean.  I should note that the reservoir on the Airfloss won't hold two days' worth of mouthwash or water if you have it set to three pulses. I think it will for one or two pulses though.  But, it takes all of five seconds to fill it up.Is it better than the WaterPik? I think as far as cleaning it's a draw. The WaterPik does a good job and I've gotten good reports from my hygienist. But, the Airfloss is easier to use and it's not as messy. It also takes up much less valuable counter space.  For now I'm sticking with the Airfloss.

I have a seven year old Husky electric power washer that I picked up on sale at a big box store. I bring it out every month or so to mostly clean the walkway in the front of my house and the pool deck.  I have a dog that refuses to do his business on the grass so those areas get stained and stinky. Washing with a hose doesn't get the job done. The Husky has performed well but it was starting to have some issues. So, the timing was perfect for this to show up.Assembly was pretty straight forward. Attach the handle pieces, then the hose. All you need is a Phillips screwdriver.My first use was to clean the badly stained walkway. I had to put the nozzle at the thinnest setting which gave me a pencil sized spray that blasted through the stains.  As long as I was there I cranked it down to a fan spray and cleaned the rest of the walkway which had mostly ground in dirt. I also blasted some plant shelves that had some bird poop. No problems. But, after I switched the spray settings a few times the spray selector became loose.  It didn't leak but it was awkward to hold the wand and change the setting.I was curious about the noise level. I have a meter so I tested the Briggs & Stratton at 94 decibels when I was using the highest setting.  That's not quiet but it's not terrible - it's the equivalent of a gas powered lawn mower.Happy with the walkway cleaning I went to the pool deck.  The deck is concrete aggregate so it has a lot of nooks and crannies for dirt (and dog waste) to hide.  Like the walkway I was able to use a fan spray to clean the deck but the deck is sealed so while the dog stains look bad they usually aren't hard to clean.  But, about half way through water started dripping and then streaming out of the connection between the hose and the wand. I think what's happening is when you move the wand back and forth you're also slowly loosening this connection. I checked my Husky and they have a quick connect hose attachment so it doesn't leak and is able to swivel a bit.  If I keep using this power washer I may have to invest in one - otherwise I'll be wearing a swimming suit when I use it because I got soaked.The other problem with this unit, and I have exactly the same problem with the Husky, is the hose going from the unit to the wand. It's very stiff and I don't care how hard you try it won't straighten out. I live in the Phoenix area and stretched the hose out in 105 degree weather loosened up a bit but it's still a bit stiff.  When you're using the power washer the hose curls up and if you pull too hard it'll actually kink and cut off water to the nozzle (the Husky is just as unforgiving but it's never kinked). The stiffness of the hose is also a problem when you store the unit.  Good luck trying to wrap the hose around the back like they show in the picture.  Mine is attached but I used a long Velcro strap to hold it in place. Again, I have the same problem with the Husky.Overall, it's OK. It leaks but I think I can fix that problem. I'm not sure what to do about the hose stiffness though. If I come up with a solution I'll update this review - if you have any ideas please share them.

This kit is great fun and a nice diversion from electronic games and the plethora of building sets we have accumulated over the years (Legos, etc).It comes with a number of parts - I've included a picture showing the box contents before everything was opened.  I put it in the hands of an 11 year old boy. He loves building things and the idea that he could make them move was intriguing. Even at his age he had some difficulty putting some of the pieces together and asked for help.The projects are fun and they actually do move with the aid of the rubber band. But, don't expect break neck speed. They sort of putter along but that's fine.  We have RC cars that go fast and let's face it, this is rubber band powered.Overall it's a nice kit and it kept the 11 year old busy for a few hours. I strongly suspect that he'll get tired of it and it'll go off into the black hole closet. But, I think it's the kind of kit that may get pulled out again on a rainy day.

I've used the Nutro cat food brand in the past and thought I'd give a different flavor a try. Our two cats aren't very picky eaters but they have snubbed their noses at food in the past. They did walk up to it, sniff it, give me a funny look and then dove in - I took that as a good sign.As a cat owner I was of course interested in the healthiness of this food.  I can actually recognize and pronounce the top ten or so ingredients. We were first introduced to the Nutro brand by our vet. It wasn't the only brand she recommended but it was on her short list. I feel fairly confident that I'm feeding them something that's good for them and they clearly like the taste.

We now have four building kits in our house. The Zoob, Lincoln Logs, Magformers, and Lego. Interest in the Lincoln Logs and Magformers has dwindled over time but they still come out of the closet occasionally.  The Lego's are always the "go-to" building toy and are likely to stay in the top spot for the next generation or two. Like any new toy, the Zoob became the most popular as soon as the box was opened.The pieces are easy to put together and you can make a number of shapes because they swivel on each other; you can make a circle, a snake, etc. There's a nice booklet included with step-by-step instructions for a number of projects.  I prefer the, "here - go build something" approach but having the instructions was a nice way to get started.  After a few of those were tackled the booklet was discarded and the creativity began. That's what I really like about toys like this. The kids have fun and, as an adult, it's fun to watch their little brains work.This is a nice beginner kit with plenty of pieces for completing projects.  Another plus - unlike Lego's there aren't any small pieces so clean up is easier and you're not likely to walk across the floor barefooted in the middle of the night and step on one.

Life is moving along pretty easily for County Sheriff Ed McCoy.  His office is in the quiet backwater town of Nugget City, Colorado.  Formerly a wild mining boomtown, Nugget City was tamed by his father, Sheriff Fist McCoy.  As the ore played out, the town changed from a raucous mining camp to a tranquil ranching community.  With the death of Fist, young Ed has taken his father's place and become the Law in the County.  But tensions are simmering just under this peaceful facade.  There is a persistent threat of range war over water rights between the two largest ranchers in the county, Pete Egan of the Rafter E and Curt Mauldin of the M Bar, and now Pete has hired a gunslinger.  Add to this troubling escalation, the fact that the local banker, Sam Thorn, holds mortgages on most of the land in the County and has his own plan to foreclose on both ranches and the pot of trouble is beginning to boil.  Then one day a stranger, with the singularly unremarkable name of John Brown, comes to town on the stage and starts sitting in front of the hotel all day, every day.  The stranger is wearing two tied down guns and suddenly Ed has his hands full.  Why is the stranger in town and what is he doing just sitting and watching?  Can Ed solve the mystery?  Can he prevent a range war?  Can he stay alive long enough to marry the love of his life, Curt Mauldin's daughter, Judy?  And how the heck did the seamstress and the school teacher get involved in all of this?Next to Louis L'Amour, Wayne Overholser is one of my favorite Western authors and Nugget City is one of his better novels.  The first half of the book has none of the violence that is characteristic of most Western stories, but instead focuses on the mysterious stranger and the various sub-plots that swirl around him.  These narrative threads come crashing together in the second half of the book with plenty of suspense and sudden plot twists.  If you like Westerns, you will really enjoy reading Nugget City.  The narrative has a limited, believable level of violence and a well structured series of sub-plots that will hold your interest to the last page.

In Surf Safari Nurse by Jane Converse, our protagonist, Laurie Davis, a plucky young nurse, is having a very bad week.  Her boyfriend, the dashing Ron Tercotte, a surgery student/surfer dude, just broke up with her and, to top it off, she has been demoted from OR nurse to general duty on the maternity ward.  What's a girl to do?  (Cue Beach Boys music.)  Why, go on a surf safari!  Can she win Ron's heart back among the white beach sands and rolling waves and convince him to return to school instead of surfing his life away?  Or is Linc, not Ron, the man for her?  Can she bring peace and healing to Eddie Barclay, a troubled young man with domineering parents?  But most of all, will she have to punch Ron's new surf bunny girlfriend, Diane Etheridge, in the face?  Don't worry this trip won't be just another lame "ho-dad rockout" (whatever that is).  With Goofyfoot, Elephant, Beast, Preacher, and, of course, Ron, along, you can be sure this will be one wild ride.Published in 1966, this is an old fashioned romance novel.  There is no sex and just a few kisses.  Romantic passion is only very subtly implied.  The majority of the book reads like a daytime soap opera with everyone just sitting around talking and thinking about relationships and the meaning of life.  It was kind of boring for me.  Strangely, the few exciting events that occur are written "off camera" and only revealed through re-telling to Laurie.  I can understand such a budget-saving technique for a television soap opera, but, of course, the author has no such constraints.  I would have enjoyed the story more if Laurie had been directly involved as events unfolded.  On the other hand, the last couple of chapters throw Laurie right into the action with plenty of suspense and excitement.  Overall, I am only giving it four stars simply because I feel with a little tweaking in the narrative structure it could have been a much more enjoyable read.

Sun-Maid Raisins & Dried Fruits: Serving American Families & The World Since 1912 is a history/recipe book put together by the Sun-Maid Growers of California and published by DK Publishing in New York in 2011.  Anna L. Palecek, Gary H. Marshburn, and Barry F. Kriebel are listed as the "creative team".  The hardcover edition (8 1/4" by 10 1/4") is 176 pages with an index.  It is a commemorative book that recognizes the 100 year anniversary of Sun-Maid.  Being printed on high quality paper with beautiful illustrations, I would describe it as a "coffee table book".  There really isn't a narrative as such (maybe that is why there is a "creative team" rather than authors listed), rather the story is laid out as a series of images with accompanying blurbs.  The presentation gives the impression of a high end marketing brochure, which I guess in one sense it is.In general, the six chapter titles are fairly explanatory.  Chapter 1, The Basics, provides an interesting Sun-Maid time-line followed by some random blurbs on the use of raisins and other dried fruits such as Holidays and Festivals that feature dried fruits (although the Children's Day in Japan blurb makes no mention of raisins or dried fruit).  Oh, BTW, did you know that March 1st is Fruit Compote Day?  There is also a comparison of hamburgers and boxes of raisins and a blurb on Sir Isaac Newton's Laws of Motion...as I mentioned earlier, the blurbs tend to be very random.  Chapter 2, The Background Story, is a bit more organized, chronologically starting somewhat before the founding of Sun-Maid with the use of dried fruit by the ancient Egyptians and ending with the introduction of the Thompson seedless grape at the 1915 Panama Pacific International Exposition.  Chapter 3, The Sun-Maid Story, has some really neat random blurbs; the real-life Sun-Maid girl then and later in life, the evolution of the Sun-Maid girl logo, Norman Rockwell and Sun-Maid (!), games, recipe books, etc.  Chapter 4, From Field to Table, discusses the process of growing and making raisins, complete with "Sun-Maid experts" pictured looking through refractometers and magnifying glasses.  Chapter 5, The Facts on Raisins and Dried Fruit, highlights the various kinds of dried fruit sold by Sun-Maid and the health benefits of eating dried fruit.  Various international food guidelines are provided, but no negative issues are addressed.  And finally, Chapter 6, Recipes, presents 52 recipes (by my count) ranging from the mundane (Oatmeal Raisin Cookies) to the bizarre (Grilled Baby Eggplant with Raisins, Pine Nuts, and Rosemary).  To be honest, some of the recipes are pretty darn good.In conclusion, this is a beautiful coffee table book that is obviously a marketing brochure for Sun-Maid.  It is laid out as a series of images and blurbs, some of which are really interesting, that is meant to be browsed rather than read.  It is certainly not a detailed centennial history of Sun-Maid and doesn't address some of the more controversial issues that range from the humorous (the revamping of a modern animated Sun-Maid girl in tight fitting clothing) to the more serious (immigrant labor and working conditions).  In general, the history of the fruit growing industry in California's Central Valley is a fascinating subject that is a case study for the growth of American commerce and industry.  It is filled with struggle and changes in labor rights and working conditions and increasing mechanization of production.  For example, over the past decade, Sun-Maid has significantly increased the mechanization of the production process due to a shortage of farm labor.  They now produce more raisins on less land than ever before.  If you get a chance read up on the history of the Central Valley.  If you just want the recipes, you can download this book for free from the Sun-Maid website.

These 11 inch plastic parts organizers come in a set of three.  They are made in China and distributed by Home Depot under the Husky Tools brand (www dot huskytools dot com).  They have a "two year limited warranty" on failures due to a defect in materials or workmanship which really means, if you break it, you keep it.  I don't know why they are advertised as 11 inches.  The actual length of the box is approximately 10 5/8 inches and the storage length is about 10 1/8 inches.  The box width is about 7 inches with a storage depth of a little over 1 1/2 inches.  As can be seen in the product image, the storage area is divided into four fixed rows.  The back three rows are a little over 1 1/2 inches wide with removable dividers spaced about every 2 inches.  The front row is designed differently than the back rows with three fixed length compartments that are roughly 3 1/4 inches long.  The two side compartments vary between 1 and 1 1/4 inches wide to allow room for the box latches.  The middle compartment is approximately 1 1/4 inches wide with a shallower depth of about 3/4 of an inch to allow for a hand grip.These seem to be reasonably high quality storage boxes made from fairly thick plastic.  Flexing is minimal when you pick the loaded box up by one corner.  Even though made of plastic, the latches and hinges are two piece mechanisms (i.e., separate hinge pin and leaf) which are more durable than the one piece thin seam hinge that you usually find on small plastic box hinges and latches.  The latch snaps on the three bins I received were solid and snapped securely.  When fully inserted, the dividers fit flush with the compartment bottom and appear to be flush with the lid.  If you are storing hardware such as nuts, bolts, and washers, they will not mix when the box is turned over.  Overall, they are a nice set of storage bins.  But keep in mind, they are designed for small quantities of small parts and are not the best solution for larger parts or larger quantities.

In the first year of the Civil War, 1861, Northern troops under questionable leadership had suffered several setbacks and the Confederacy was on the offensive.  So, when Federal troops investigating an Indian attack on the Humboldt River in Nevada find stolen munitions in the burned wagons, the alarm is raised in Washington.  The possibility of secessionist insurrection in the Western states was a very real threat.  Northern leadership needed to find out just how much of a threat the stolen arms posed and ordered a covert operation to expose any such plans.  Our protagonist, Lt. Tracy Dalton, is selected as the undercover agent and is sent West to pose as a free-wheeling mining investor...and so the story begins.  Can Lt. Dalton uncover the truth behind the stolen guns and ammunition without compromising his cover?  Can he thwart plans by Confederate sympathizers to capture the Western states?  Can he stay alive long enough to complete such a dangerous mission?  The author, Chad Merriman, has structured this fictional tale around a true real world event.  In 1861, Brig. Gen. Henry H. Sibley began preparing a plan to capture the mineral rich Western states of New Mexico, Arizona, and Nevada for the Confederacy.  The campaign was launched from the, at the time abandoned, Federal Fort Bliss, located near El Paso, Texas.  Ultimately the plan failed for a variety of tactical and logistical reasons and, in April of 1862, Sibley was forced to retreat back to Fort Bliss, thus ending any Confederate hopes for capturing lands in the West.NO SPOILERS, BUT STOP HERE IF YOU WANT TO READ THE STORY WITHOUT ANY PRECONCEPTIONS.  I am only giving this novel three stars because, in my opinion, it is simply a boring narrative.  You would think with a title, "Ride West For War", this book would be filled with non-stop action.  Unfortunately, the first 15 chapters consist of Lt. Dalton talking to someone, searching for the hidden weapons, talking to some more people, again searching for the hidden weapons, and so on and so on.  The only action is a brutal beating and a short fist fight...that's it.  Even the romantic subplot is half-hearted and never really developed.  Ironically, this is probably a realistic depiction of an undercover investigation...you just talk to people until you find out what is going on.  But, it doesn't make good storytelling.  On the other hand, the climax in the last two chapters is very exciting.  If only the first fifteen chapters had been that interesting, it would have been a very enjoyable read.

(Just an FYI, I wrote a similar review of National's UltraSofts Women's Holiday sleep tee.)  The National Novelty sleep tee is simply a long teeshirt with no pockets that can be worn as a nightgown.  It is sold by the National Wholesale Company (www dot shopnational dot com) under the National label as a "Novelty" sleep tee.  The tee is made in China and was shipped to me from the National warehouse in Lexington, North Carolina. The material is a 60% cotton/40% polyester blend that, as one would expect from a knit, has a soft, stretchy feel. The seams were consistent with no fraying.  It is a very comfortable tee that is stretchy enough to ease binding and bunching as you move around in your sleep.  The tee is thin enough to be worn during the warmer Summer nights.  National also sells a line of cotton/polyester sleep tees under the UltraSofts by National label, which seem to me to be somewhat thicker and more suited for cooler Winter nights.  However, the UltraSofts tees are narrower across the shoulders than the Novelty tees.I ordered a carnation color Novelty tee which is a creamy pink hue.  As can be seen in the product image, the carnation tee has a nice "three stacked coffee cups" design on the front.  The Novelty sleep tees come in two sizes; Misses (One size fits 6-16) and Womens (One size fits 18-26). I ordered the Womens one size. The product description states that the tee is 39 inches long.  Before the first washing, I measured approximately 37 inches from the back of the neck to the hemline and approximately 29 inches across the shoulders. After several washings, I measured again and the length was approximately 34 1/2 inches, while the width across the shoulders remained approximately 29 inches. So, you can expect several inches of shrinkage in length, but the tee appears to hold its width.  Also, as I mentioned earlier, the UltraSofts tees are four to five inches narrower across the shoulders than the Novelty tees and may be snug across the chest for some. If you are full figured, you may find the Novelty tees to be more comfortable than the UltraSofts tees. Overall, the Novelty tees are good quality, comfortable night sleep tees so five stars.

This Holiday Print Sleep Tee is simply a long teeshirt with no pockets that can be worn as a nightgown.  It is sold by the National Wholesale Company (www dot shopnational dot com) under the UltraSofts by National label.  UltraSofts by National is their premiere knit separates brand that includes a range of knit clothing including shirts, pants, skirts, etc.  The tee is made in Taiwan and was shipped to me from the National warehouse in Lexington, North Carolina.  The material is a 60% cotton/40% polyester blend that, as one would expect from a knit, has a fairly thick, soft, stretchy feel.  The seams were consistent with no fraying.  It is a very comfortable tee that is thick enough to provide some warmth in a cool room.  As an aside, National also sells a line of cotton/polyester tees under the Novelty Sleep Tee label, which seem to me to be somewhat thinner than the UltraSofts.  The Novelty Sleep Tees are more suited for warmer Summer nights and are wider across the shoulders for fuller figures.Anyway, I ordered a Navy color UltraSofts tee which, as can be seen in the product image, has a "snowflakes over boxes" holiday design on the front.  The snowflakes are pretty and I guess the boxes are supposed to represent Christmas presents, but the middle box looks to me like a window with bars.  Overall, the design really needs some work.  Hopefully, National will review it and come up with better snowflake artwork.  The UltraSofts sleep tees come in two sizes; Misses (One size fits 6-16) and Womens (One size fits 18-26).  I ordered the Womens one size.  The product description states that the tee is 39 inches long.  Before the first washing, I measured approximately 38 inches from the back of the neck to the hemline and approximately 24 1/2 inches across the shoulders.  After several washings, I measured again and the length was approximately 35 1/2 inches, while the width across the shoulders remained approximately 24 1/2 inches.  So, you can expect several inches of shrinkage in length, but the tee appears to hold its width.  One thing to note, the UltraSofts tees are four to five inches narrower across the shoulders than the Novelty tees and may be snug across the chest for some.  If you are full figured, you may find the Novelty tees to be more comfortable than the UltraSofts tees.  In any case, the UltraSofts are good quality and comfortable night tees so five stars...but National really needs to work on their snowflakes design.

In Trail Blazers by E. C. Tubb, the protagonist, Gregg Halmar, is a hardened veteran of the Civil War.  Having fought as a Captain for the Confederacy, he has lost everything except the clothes on his back, and even those have become threadbare.  He realizes there is a substantial financial opportunity in post-Civil War Texas where large herds of cattle are bottled up by blocked trails to the East.  Gregg figures that instead of East, he can drive a herd North to the meat-starved mining camps of Wyoming and Montana.  But to push 5,000 head North, he must blaze a new cattle trail and, in the process, face outlaw Jayhawks, marauding Indians, and the ravages of Nature.  Can he stay alive long enough to make his fortune or will he lose his herd and his life?  Trail Blazers is a short novel and therefore a fairly quick read.  It is a classic Western in the sense that all the traditional elements are there; fistfights, gunfights, a cattle drive, Indian attacks, etc.  Recently, I have been reading some of E. C. Tubb's Western stories and, although he is better known for his science fiction and fantasy novels, his Western tales such as Trail Blazers are pretty good.As an aside, about halfway through Trail Blazers the protagonist argues that the Indians should be left alone and allowed to stay on their lands.  In Tubb's Wagon Trail (aka, Cauldron of Violence) novel, published one year later in 1957, it is clear the Indians are the bad guys, savages bent on murdering innocent white settlers.  I wonder if these views were written as purely character motivation or if is was a reflection of the author's changing view of Westward Expansion and the "Indian Wars".  Anyway, getting back to my review of Trail Blazers.  Even though the story is pretty good, I am giving it three stars based on my personal preferences.  About halfway through the book, the protagonist acts in a very distasteful, disturbing manner and I developed a sudden dislike for Gregg Halmar.  I really don't want the protagonist to be "super" human.  Human weaknesses add realism to the character.  But, I do want him or her to have a fairly strong sense of moral right and wrong...and to choose the right path.  Personally, if I don't like the protagonist, I don't enjoy the story.  Of course I finished reading the book, but I really didn't connect with Gregg Halmar in the second half of the story.

I like to hang out a wind streamer (windsock) so I can just glance out the window to see how windy it is outside.  I have been using a rainbow colored streamer that is generic enough to be used year round.  For a change I decided to buy this series of windsocks to add some seasonal color to the yard.  The windsocks are made in China and were shipped directly from the Miles Kimball Company in Oshkosh, Wisconsin.  They arrived in a clear plastic bag which itself contained six plastic bags each containing one of the six windsocks in the set.  The socks are as pictured in the product image; a snowman for Christmas, flowers/bee for Spring, a bunny rabbit for Easter, USA stars and stripes for the Fourth of July, autumn leaves for Fall, and a pumpkin/ghosts for Halloween.  The patterns are on only one side of the windsock with just the background color on the other side (e.g., The Fall sock has leaves on one side and just the brown background color on the other side.).As you can see in the image, the streamers are crinkled when unpacked.  Even though advertised as being 62" long, I measured the length at about 59"; however, if I pull the streamers tight, I can get just about 62".  They may straighten out with use, but that isn't really an issue for me.  I sorta like the crinkled look.  The sock material is made from very thin, very lightweight, polyester.  The three (double strand) hangar strings appear to be made from braided nylon and the hook is metal.  Being so thin and lightweight, It is hard to judge the durability of the materials and construction.  On the other hand, the sock needs to be lightweight so it will flutter in a light breeze.  So far, I am happy with my purchase.  It seems to be a good value for six seasonal windsocks.

By sheer luck, Colin Bowman manages to escape an Indian attack that kills his parents and instills in him a hatred and fear of Indians.  Still a young boy, he was suddenly thrown into an adult world.  As he grows older, the horrors of the Civil War transform him into a hardened, dangerous, man.  Surviving the War, Colin is once again drawn west to the land that he loves, but he will need to face his fears and heal his hatred before he can find love and peace in his life.In my opinion, E.C. Tubb is an inconsistent writer.  Some of his work is excellent and some is below average.  I liked Cauldron of Violence.  It is not his best work, but it is an enjoyable read.  It is a classic Western where the Indians are clearly the "bad guys"; ferocious savages bent on murder.  If you like your Westerns to be more sympathetic to the Indian plight, then this is probably not the book for you.  The narrative is a fairly quick read and is essentially three main episodes connected by a some transitional paragraphs.  I got the feeling that the author had three short stories that he decided to string together to create this short novel.

This folding "camp" table sold by Outsunny is made in China and has, by my measurements, a 23 3/4" wide by 17 3/4" long top with legs that can be locked at either of two heights; 19" from the ground or a maximum height of 25 1/2" from the ground.  The legs fold up into a 2 3/4" thickness.  The top does not fold.  My scales are not very accurate but it does appear to weigh the advertised 6 pounds.  The table has an advertised maximum weight loading of 60 pounds.  The frame is aluminum.  The top appears to be made from some type of plastic(?).  My guess is that most of the 6 pound weight is in the top.  It has a nice flexible plastic (rubber?) hand carry strap on the side.  The strap feels secure but I don't know how durable the plastic is.  Even though the advertising states that you can carry it for long distances, with a weight of 6 pounds and a solid top, the table is not well suited for hiking or backwoods camping.  For hiking and remote camping, you really need a slated or cloth table top that you can cinch into a tight roll.  On the other hand, if you can drive to the campsite, or just need to walk a short distance to a picnic area, or maybe need some extra spread space for a tailgate party, this table is a good choice.The product description states, and I agree, that the top is easy to clean.  However, keep in mind that since an aluminum flange runs completely around the edge of the plastic top, large liquid spills will undoubtedly seep between the top and the flange where you won't be able to clean it up.  So, if you aren't careful the edges can get very dirty.  In conclusion, I had two issues with this table.  First, you really need three hands to adjust the legs;  two to push in the spring-loaded ball bearing catches on each leg pair and one to push in or pull out the leg pair.  It was a bit awkward but I had to push in on one ball bearing and force one leg down just far enough to release it from the catch hole and then release the other leg the same way.  Once both legs are released then you push or pull the leg pair in or out.  The second issue is that you can't fold the table with the legs fully extended.  I had wanted to extend the legs and then hang up the table for later use, but, the design of the folding legs forces me to extend the legs every time I use the table.  I am going to give this four stars for these two issues, but for the right application, you may find it a five star buy.

This is a rectangular shoulder shawl sold by Maxi-Aids.  The shawl I received is made in the USA by Care Apparel Industries.  Even though it is called "polar fleece", the material is 100 percent polyester.  There is no organic material or wool in the shawl.  The synthetic fibers are woven into a soft nap that provides a moderate level of insulation.  The shawl is sold as "one size fits all" and is a single rectangular piece of material that is 19 3/4 inches wide by 62 inches long.  A pocket is sewn on each end of the material.  The two pockets are 6 1/2 inches square with the bottom of each pocket sewn into the edge hem of the material.The seller describes the shawl as a "extra thick and luxurious".  In my opinion, this is a bit of an exaggeration.  The material is fairly thin.  It is not stretchable and has a soft feel that is just slightly harsh but still comfortable.  You can tell it is made of polyester fibers.  In any case, the material is thick enough to feel good in a cool room, but it won't keep you warm if the temperature is lowered.  I know these are vague words, but a "comfortable" temperature can vary quite a bit between individuals.  Let me put it this way...my mother likes this shawl in an air conditioned room in the Summer, but finds it too thin to keep her warm during the Winter months.  There are no wrinkles after washing and the material is durable.  Even though the product description indicates light blue, I don't think the seller can guarantee the color.  The shawl I received turned out to be black.  I don't know if there is any variation in size.  I am giving it five stars with a caveat.  This is a nice simple rectangular shawl with two pockets.  It is comfortable for a cool room but is too thin for anything colder.  If this is what you need, then it is a good buy.  If you are handy with a sewing machine, then you can make your own and save some money if you want.

This gap hole taper gauge sold by Amico provides a quick low cost way of measuring hole diameter with some limitations.  The tool itself is about 6 inches long by about 3/4 inches wide and a little over 1/32 of an inch thick.  The stated measurement range is between 1 mm and 15 mm.  However, if you look closely at the product image you will see that you lose the multiple length gradations at below 4 mm.  So, if the hole is smaller than 4 mm, you will have to start counting lines which can be a pain without a magnifying glass.  In fact  you will need to count lines from 4 mm on down to 1 mm just to figure out which lines are the 3, 2, and 1 mm marks.  In my opinion, the useful measurement range of the gauge is between 4 mm and 15 mm.  As another reviewer has noted, the design of the gauge means that it can only be used on "through" holes or holes that are deeper than the length of the gauge below the hole size mark.  I mic'ed out a couple of the marks and they appear to be accurate.  I can certainly work with millimeters, but I wish they made these in SAE also.Anyway, the gauge is made in China and appears to be targeted for the Chinese market since the packaging is all in Chinese.  The seller?? has taped a UPC bar code and product name in English to the outside of the package.  The gauge was slightly bent (bowed) but not enough to be a problem.  The labeling stamped on the tool that I received is "KC0-15mm".  This is different from the product description image which shows a labeling of "JOA No. 700A Stainless Hardened" so I don't know if my gauge is actually made from hardened stainless steel.  I am not sure why there is a small "01" dimension mark stamped on the tool next to the labeling.  Overall, the gauge is a good solution for measuring the top edge diameter of 4 mm to 15 mm holes.

These 6 mm nylon wing bolts are sold in two pair packs (two bolts and two nuts).  They are made in Vietnam out of what I am guessing to be Nylon 6/6.  The type of material isn't given in the product description, but Nylon 6/6 thermoplastic is pretty much the industry standard for "plastic" bolts and nuts.  In addition, the bolts/nuts I received are off-white which is the untreated color of Nylon 6/6.  It should be noted that the product image shows black bolts/nuts.  However, my project (electrically insulated wire posts) doesn't require a specific bolt color so the off-white is not an issue for me.  They are called wing bolts because they are usually used by radio control airplane hobbyists to mount the wing on the body of the aircraft.  If the airplane crashes, the bolts will shear, releasing the wing from the body, and reducing the amount of damage to the aircraft.  I mic'ed out one of the bolts and nuts.  The diameter of the threaded length is 6 mm or just under a quarter inch.  The bolt length from the pointed tip to the base of the bolt head is 13/16 of an inch.  This includes an un-threaded 5/16" shoulder between the bolt threads and the base of the bolt head.  So, keep in mind that you can't run the nut all the way against the bottom of the bolt head.  The bolt head is a 5/8" diameter circle that is just under 1/8" thick with a protruding 1/8" flange.  The nut is T-shaped with a circular threaded tube (O.D. just under 3/8") and a flat 17/32" x 1 1/16" base that is 1/8" thick.  Note that you can't use a screwdriver to tighten the bolt head and you can't use a wrench to tighten the nut.  There is some mold flashing left on the length of the bolt but I was able to run a nut all the way up the bolt without a problem.  Overall, except for the color, the bolts seem to be as advertised, so five stars. Oh, and just an FYI, depending on your application, if you need stronger plastic bolts, you should consider buying glass-filled Nylon 6/6 which has double the strength of the unfilled bolts.

Nylon 6/6 thermoplastic is pretty much the industry standard for "plastic" bolts and nuts.  It is fairly tough and and has good tensile strength at temperatures up to about 185F.  I received a package of 100 off-white bolts which is the untreated color of Nylon 6/6.  I mic'ed out one of the bolts and the measurements didn't quite match the drawing provided in the product description.  (It could be my micrometer is off zero.)  Anyway, the threaded bolt length is slightly under a half inch with just under a quarter inch diameter.  The bolts I received don't have the shoulder between the threaded shaft and the bolt head that is shown in the drawing.  Instead, the threads on the bolts I received run all the way up against the bolt head.  The bolt head is 3/16 of an inch thick and 3/8 inch wide across the flats.  I am using these bolts for insulated wiring posts on a project so I needed matching nylon nuts.  I ordered a pack of 100 nuts from Amazon (Nylon 6/6 Hex Nut, Off-White, 1/4"-20 Thread Size, 7/16" Width Across Flats, 15/64" Thick).  Note that the nuts are slightly wider and thicker than the bolt heads.  The nuts went on smoothly.  The bolt threads look clean under a magnifying glass.  Overall, the bolts seem to be as advertised, so five stars.  Oh, and just an FYI, if you need stronger bolts, you should consider buying glass-filled Nylon 6/6 which has double the strength of the unfilled bolts.

Buckskin Man by Wayne D. OverholserRafe Dolan grew up as a buckskin-wearing, mountain man and he wanted to continue that way of life until he died.  Unfortunately, he was born too late.  The progression of cattlemen and farmers were slowly settling the last remaining wildernesses of the West.  Rafe didn't like farming and he certainly didn't like cattlemen, so he constantly drifted, looking for a place far away from the relentless spread of civilization.  Whether he wanted it or not, a chance meeting with a cattleman and later with an old friend from the past was about to pull Rafe violently into this new way of life.  There was a good chance he wouldn't survive.  The odds certainly were against him.  But Rafe knew that he had to fight for what was good and right and to protect those who were depending on him.== Musings ==As I have written in another review, my favorite author of Western novels is Louis L'Amour.  Louis' protagonists are quintessential Western heroes.  But Wayne D. Overholser and his son Stephen Overholser are a close second.  They are master storytellers in their own right.  Usually, Overholser stories have a sub-theme in the narrative that gives the story a "realistic" feel.  Buckskin Man is no exception, as Rafe has to face the end of a way of life and adapt to a new modern reality.  In fact, one character in the story, upon first meeting Rafe, calls him an anachronism...a man living in the past.  And finally, I have no idea why the dust jacket blurb refers to Rafe as a "legend".  Being a legend isn't even an element of the narrative.  Did the blurb writer even read the story?  Anyway, this is an excellent Western tale.  You should read it.

As a caregiver, I have bought several different brands of adult pull-ups (i.e., Depend, Tranquility, Prevail, Tena, and Surecare) and have written a few reviews on the their attributes.  I recently decided to try these Prevail bladder control pads as "booster" pads for adult pull-up diapers.  Booster pads are placed in the crotch of the pull-ups for at least two reasons; first, to increase the amount of liquid that can be adsorbed if there is a heavy flow or the pull-ups must be worn for an extended period or, second, to reduce the number of pull-ups used either for financial or convenience reasons.  As an aside, if you are having an issue with overnight containment, then I would suggest trying the Tranquility Overnight pull-ups first before resorting to booster pads.Anyway, back to the Prevail pads...the pads are individually wrapped in a soft, "faux cloth" overwrap with a flowery imprint that is seamed and easily torn open.  The pad unfolds into a 13 inch long strip that is about 3 inches wide and about a half inch thick.  (This is their maximum absorbency pad, previously known as Ultra-Plus.)  The pad is advertised as body shaped and designed for women.  There is only a barely discernible hour glass shape to it with an elastic edge on each side of the middle.  I'm not sure why, but the inside of the pad is imprinted with a flowery design.  The back side of the pad (away from the skin) has a full length adhesive strip (covered with paper) for securing the pad to the crotch of the pull-up.  I didn't realize that the quietness of the wrapping was an issue, but Prevail advertises the fact that the wrapping is soft and quiet for discretion.  But you should note that even though the overwrap may be quiet, taking the paper off the adhesive strip can be somewhat noisy.  Although I can't see the difference in the symmetrical design, the paper covering the adhesive strip indicates a front direction.The 13 inch length provides very good coverage and the pad adsorbs well.  However, unlike pads designed specifically as boosters with "flow through" control, these pads limit the amount of fluid flow through the backside material when the pad is full.  Accordingly, these are not a good solution for increasing the fluid capacity of the pull-up.  When the Prevail pad gets full, they tend to leak around the sides rather than flowing through to the absorbent layer of the pull-up crotch.  (See the comments below for further discussion on this issue.)  On the other hand, if you can change the pad when it gets full, then you can greatly reduce the number of pull-ups you use and, in turn, reduce your overall cost for incontinence protection.  Also, for extended wear, changing out the pad is much more convenient than replacing your pull-up each time you get wet.  So I am giving a mixed review and four stars for use in booster pad applications.

I had a bottom rack wheel assembly break on my Sears Kenmore dishwasher.  I looked up the part number on the Sears website.  It turned out to be fairly expensive when I included shipping, so I searched the same part number (8268645) on Amazon.  The result came back as a Whirlpool wheel.  The product image appeared to be the same as the Sears wheel assembly and it was significantly lower in cost (with free shipping) so I ordered it from Amazon.  It is an exact replacement for the Sears wheel assembly.  Whirlpool must make some of the Kenmore models.

This CD entitled "Dream Sleep: Music for Relaxation" is produced, composed, and performed by Rutman Bowmore and printed and manufactured in Canada.  It is from the Reflections of Nature series of CD's (reflectionsmusic dot com).  The CD is just over 45 minutes long and is structured into eight tracks ranging from about four to seven minutes each.  All the tracks are similar and integrate ocean waves with the music.  The waves stay in the foreground throughout with the instruments serving as filler between wave crashes.  Most of the time, a piano and flute are leads backed by strings and winds.  Occasionally, a violin and guitar will move to the front to carry the score.  On some of the tracks, the flute gives a Celtic vibe to the score.  I don't know whether this is an ensemble performance or multiple synthesized keyboard overlays.  The compositions are all fairly slow nondescript scores with no vocals.  The music smooths out the amplitude by filling the low volume transitions between wave crashes.  Accordingly, none of the tunes and transitions stick in your mind and there are no surprises as you are trying to drift off to sleep.  This is a nice hybrid of nature (ocean waves) and relaxing music.  I do wish it were about 15 minutes longer to round out to an hour.  If you are looking for nature/music hybrids, then this a good one to add to your collection...five stars.

This CD entitled "Evening Symphony" is produced by Santec Music (santec-music dot com) in Germany and is performed by the in-house Santec Music Orchestra.  It is 54 minutes long and is structured into 12 tracks ranging from about four to seven minutes each.  There are no nature sounds.  All the tracks are pretty much the same with either piano or guitar leads supported by a small orchestra of strings and winds.  The compositions are all fairly slow nondescript scores with no vocals.  Of course, this is a plus since you really don't want vocals or catchy tunes when you are trying to fall asleep.  The volume is consistently even throughout with no high amplitude surprises.  It is apparent the CD is designed to be background music and it succeeds in the sense that none of the tunes and transitions stick in your mind and, in fact, quickly fade from your consciousness as you thoughts drift elsewhere.  Even so, I would have preferred if the conductor had pushed the strings even further into the background.  Using this kind of music for sleeping really depends on your mood when you go to bed.  Sometimes I feel like immersing myself in nature (e.g., storms, oceans, etc.) and sometimes I want relaxing music.  Evening Symphony is not a nature CD and it really doesn't fall into the latter category either because it is so homogenized.  Usually music to promote sleep is structured to gradually ease the listener into sleepiness.  The music on this CD is targeted more for meditation than sleeping.  Nonetheless, I am going to give it five stars because I think it is good for those nights when you are already relaxed.  Since you don't need to "de-stress", quiet background music is really all you need at bedtime.

I actually got these bulbs intending to put them in our ceiling fan/chandelier combo, but didn't realize that the "A15" wasn't describing the socket, but the length and shape of the neck (I know now, though :/), so I had to order some candelabra socket bulbs after these. I ended up re-purposing these bulbs into the nightside tables of my girl's rooms. They worked very well in there, as they are quite low profile, and their lamps are also low profile. The bulbs do indeed put out a nice 5000K color temperature, and at last ~300-350 lumens. So, overall, it worked out well.

This is a fantastic LED bulb. I put it up in a recessed flood light socket in our high ceiling (had to use a special tool to get it up there (ASIN: B001AH7CU8 if you want to get the same tool)), and it casts great light from up there. I am very pleased with the light it is putting out. It is dimmable, and works very well on the dimmer control we have it in. And the light is indeed a pleasing 5000K color temperature, and it is easily putting out 950 lumens. I am very happy with this bulb. See attached pictures to see it in action. The first picture is with the dimmer at the lowest setting. The second is with the dimmer at max. The STAR Tech is the light source in the upper right of the picture. The other bulb is a 3500K bulb we will be replacing soon.

I think this is a cool little lamp. It has a fully powered USB port which makes charging a phone or tablet a snap, and I think it was genius to include different types and intensities of LEDs in the lamp that you can toggle depending on your mood. I pretty much always have it in Reading or Study mode, because I prefer the 5000K+ color temperature of light, but it is nice that they include "softer" light modes for people who prefer yellower light. Also including a light intensity +/- control was also a nice touch. The lamp also swivels, and articulates at the base and the top of the neck. However, the whole thing is plastic, and the cord is a little short. Additionally, it only angles on the plane of the neck of the joints it has, no side to side rotation, which would have been nice. Overall, it is a very nice desk/side table lamp, I am using my next to my favorite chair, see the picture I am attaching to see it in use.4.5 stars

I like this little set. It snaps together quickly with no tools needed. It comes with the two little buckets you see in the picture, and the unit can support a decent amount of weight. It is a great, quick, way to help organize your closet.4 stars

This has been working very well for us. We got a new house recently that had some musty smells in the closet built off the master bedroom's attached bathroom. The prior owner's had obviously not done a good job ventilating or keeping moisture controlled. I put one of these in there, and have been keeping the door closed except when going in or out. After a week, the air has changed dramatically, and you can even feel the dryness of the air when you open the door. I would heed the warnings here, and put a pan under the bucket though, jut in case the plastic does break, but I think that is more likely if it is exposed to direct sunlight in a high heat situation, like in a car sitting out in the sun. But still, better safe than sorry.4 stars.

This is a solid, workhorse tablespoon. It will last a long time in your kitchen. The stem isn't very thin, so it won't bend easily when scooping out stubborn hard sugar, or heavy molasses. It has a nice shape for the bowl of the spoon itself, not too wide, and not too deep. My only gripe about these spoons is the end of the stem has corners which are actually fairly sharp -- which seems like a ridiculous thing to overlook -- HOW could they miss that? If you are pressing on the end of the stem hard enough, or aren't careful with it around soft skin, it could scratch you, maybe even cut you, depending on how soft your skin is. So far, all I have done is poke myself it, which is annoying, but it is just baffling that something like that could be missed on an otherwise quality product, so I had to ding them a star for that.4 stars.

I love these. They produce bright, clean, white light in the 5000K spectrum at about ~300 lumens per bulb. So, a nice approximate cumulative ~900 lumens with three of them together in our ceiling fan/chandelier combo. I looked long and hard for bulbs with candelabra bases, in the 5000K color temperature, with at least 300 lumens per bulb. It is harder to find bulbs with those specifications than it should be. I think I am going to stock up on these things, in case they stop making them o_ONote for people with exposed bulbs in their fixtures, there is text printed all around the white base of the bulb, below the clear section where the light is generated. If you care about that sort of thing, that might bother you. It doesn't bother me.5 stars, I love these

This is a good little juicer. I have used this for several weeks now, and prepared a few meals with it. It has performed well each time with no bending, breaking, rusting, or other issues. The cups for juicing are only large enough to hold limes and small to medium sized lemons, so you will need a full sized juicer for oranges and large lemons. I am not 100% pleased with the quality of the juice from it, though, you get a bit of the rind juiced as well if the fruit rind is near the expression point for the juice. I am also not thrilled about the metal prongs that stick out of the top of it. But, overall, this is a good juicer, especially for adding juice to prepared dishes, adding juice to barbequing items, or to a drink.4.5 stars.Full disclosure: a free sample of this product was provided to me in exchange for my honest review.

These are very nice. I use them when outside the paintball field, refilling, and checking equipment, so I still have some eye protection, without having to wear my full mask. I also use these when I am out rollerblading, or when I am walking/jogging, and I don't need to read street signs with my prescription sunglasses. These are RX ready, though, which, according to Under Armour, means you can wear your regular lenses under these, and the sunglasses shouldn't interfere with your RX vision. I have tried that, and in practice, it works OK, however, unless you have fairly thin and small frames (which I happen to have), then that is going to be fairly impractical, and uncomfortable.Additionally, I like the hinge/flexibility of these glasses. They are very sporty, and I appreciate that while they hug my face pretty well, they are also flexible enough to not be gripping so hard that they cause headaches. These aren't perfect, I am not wild about the lens color, and they are mostly plastic, which is a bummer for me. But, overall, these are solid sports sunglasses that you would be hard-pressed to find something better than what you get with these.4.5 stars (4 on Amazon, because they make me)

I have some insulated casserole carrying cases for my Anchor Hocking dishes. But, I have more dishes than I do insulated carrying cases. I have used the bag with one of my Anchor Hocking casserole dishes, with the lid on, to bring to a party 40 minutes away. When I took the dish out when I got there, it was still warm enough to serve without reheating.I am not wild about the color of the bag, the way the handle works, or the design of it. But, functionally, it works very well.4 stars.

Unlike some other Xbox One headsets I have tested recently, these I had very few problems with. I was able to get chat working fine. The sound quality was excellent, and the materials are pretty good.PROS:-Good sound quality. I am not an audio expert, but the audio quality seemed very good to me.-Retractable boom mic. I like this idea a LOT better than the removable mics most headsets have. Now you can get it out of the way without danger of losing it.-Chat worked fine with Xbox One.-Comes with everything you need, IN THE BOX, to use the headset, and to chat (which I just flat-out expect these days)-Has mic monitoring, you can hear your own mic level in your headset (they call this chat loop), this is important for a LOT of people-Headset cups are over-ear style, which helps shut out external sounds, and also helps to keep your sounds to yourselfNEUTRAL:-Not 100% wireless, you still have to run a wire from the headset to your controller, no big deal, though.-No batteries (rechargeable, or otherwise), draws power from the Xbox controller-Fairly comfortableCONS:-Mostly plastic, not a deal breaker for me, but I know this is a bummer for a lot of people-Sound seemed a little strained at high levelsOverall, very good headset.4.5 Stars

I think the idea behind this is fairly solid. In my tests, it worked as advertised. I put berries into the container, and then into a glass control container, and left them in the fridge for a few days. The berries in the OXO GreenSaver container lasted longer without rotting, that the berries in the glass container.  I also tried putting cilantro into the OXO GreenSaver, and again in a glass control container, and again the herbs in the GreenSaver lasted longer than the same herbs in the glass container.My only problems with the OXO GreenSaver container are:a.) you have to buy replacement filters for it, that is a bummer, and offsets the savings from not having food rot as fastb.) it is made out of plastic. Kind of ironic that the "Green"Saver, is made from plastic, which is well known to be detrimental to the environment.Overall, it delivers what it promises. If you are willing to invest in getting new filters, and you don't mind that this is made of plastic, then you will enjoy this.4 stars.

I wasn't wild about this frame. We installed it for a full-sized bed, and I think that is as large a bed as I would want to put on it, despite it being able to resize. Without a cross-bar brace, I would just be nervous about structural integrity. I am also not wild about the wheel posts, they seem flimsy and prone to breaking.  The steel frame itself goes together fairly easily, and locks in place well, and the wheel locks work well too. Over all, this is a 3-4 star frame. Not quite 4 stars, and not fully 3 stars. Depending on how much the things I listed bother you, slide your expectations closer to 3 or 4 accordingly. I may post a video later to show what I mean. Since Amazon won't let me give partial stars, and I don't think this is worthy of 4 stars, I have to give it 3.3 Stars.

5:38 Mins The video shows me using a decibel meter to measure the loudness of the alarm. I also compare it to another alarm from another company, and go over the various features of it. Overall, I think it does its job fine, but for a home security device, it just isn't loud enough. With a product like this, the value is in it being able to wake you up or get your attention from several rooms over. This product isn't being monitored by a security company, it won't summon the police, so, the value it provides is the alarm it can raise. And for the 100 decibels it can produce, I just don't think that is enough.

8:17 Mins In the video, I walk you through the differences between the various Cherry MX switches I have from my sampler kit, and then I walk you through the main features of the keyboard. Overall, I think the keyboard is solid, and I like it. I have been using it for about a month now at work, typing on it daily as a programmer (so, you know, heavy usage), and overall it is just solid. I like everything about it. This kind of thing is going to be very personal for every person, though -- everyone is going to have different opinions on what type of switch is the best. So, I STRONGLY recommend you get a switch sampler kit, and TRY THE SWITCHES YOURSELF. I try to help you make the decision by walking you through the various switches I can show you, but really, NOTHING can substitute better for you just feeling the switches for yourself.Overall, this is just a rock solid keyboard, with very nice performance. I liked it so much, I got another one for home, and I just ordered a third for my daughter.5 stars :)

9:49 MinsThe video shows me doing a sound test of the main unit that you can program with an arm/disarm code, and with the door & window models as well. The main unit is LOUD, it actually hurt my ears. The door and window units aren't quite as loud, but they work well enough. You can put everything into alarm or chime mode, which I like. You can install them easily, and I think they work well, and since they are white, they will blend into the walls of most home paint jobs. These will work very well for renters too, as they install with double-sided tape which allows for easy removal that doesn't damage the walls. I wasn't 100% wild about the kit, though. I think the door & window models should be louder, and I think the main unit should be smaller. I also wish that the main unit didn't have a screw required to get into the battery compartment. Yes, I know that keeps kids and possibly a criminal out of it, but frankly, the criminal could just smash it, and if it is mounted on the wall with screws, a kid shouldn't be able to get to it, and the criminal would have a semi-difficult time getting it off the wall to get at it. So, yeah, anyway, not a fan of the screws to get to battery compartments.Overall, I personally rate this 4.5 stars. Since Amazon won't let me do that though, and this kit wasn't quite perfect enough to get a perfect score, I am going to have to give it a 4 star rating on Amazon. So, 4 stars on Amazon, 4.5 stars from me personally :)

I have reviewed a lot of headphones for gaming (check my reviews). These ones were decent, but could be better.PROS:-Nice design-Uses fabric on the ear cups instead of (p)leather-Solidly built-In my (amateur) opinion, the sound was fine -- bass was OK, highs seemed to be OK. I am not an audiophile, though, so take their word for the sound quality over mine :)NEUTRAL:-The microphone is a little tricky to plug in at first-swapping between modes on the base unit to get chat to work can be tricky/time consuming-switching between volume modes on the headset, so that you are adjusting either the game volume, or the chat volume, can be tricky -- and hard to do by touch alone-uses batteries instead of a built-in rechargeable batteryCONS:-I was never able to get chat to work on the Xbox One. The cable that comes with the unit has a 3.5mm plug for the end that connects to the headset, but a 2.5mm plug on the other end that connects to the controller (intended for use with the Xbox 360). In the manual it flat out tells you that you will need a 2.5mm to 3.5mm adapter to get it to work with the Xbox One (REALLY, Klipsch?!) -- so, OK, I went ahead and ordered an adapter (you can find them for only a couple of bucks on Amazon) to use with the Xbox One Stereo Headset Adapter you need for chat for the Xbox One (if you don't already have one, you will need to order one from Microsoft as well, as the Klipsch headset doesn't come with that, either). And, after all of that, I couldn't get it to work. I re-synched, but that didn't work. I re-initialized the mode and made sure it was in the correct (green) mode. I swapped out the headset for another one which I knew was working (my Turtle Beach Ear Force XO One Gaming Headset), just to make sure the line wasn't dead. When I used the other headset, my friends could hear me on the Xbox Party chat I started to test the headset, just fine. But when I had the Klipsch plugged in, I could sometimes hear them (it would bring their audio in every few seconds or so), but they couldn't ever hear me. So, yeah, this is a deal breaker for me.  Note, I was able to get the chat working on the PS4 just fine. But, for a premium headset well north of a couple hundred dollars at retail price, I expect more than this. First of all, why not just either include the 2.5mm to 3.5mm adapter, or include another cable for Xbox One chat. Would that have been so hard? Also, if the (fairly cheap compared to these) Turtle Beach Ear Force XO One Gaming Headset can come with the chat adapter that you need to plug into the controller, then these should have come with that as well. It is just inexcusable to not include it, when you are marketing your headset as a premium headset that supports the Xbox One & 360, and the PS4 & PS3. That support should be there OUT OF THE BOX. This problem by itself is a deal breaker for me. I will be giving these headphones to my daughter to listen to her TV/Music on.BOTTOM LINE:Sadly, the chat problems are a deal breaker for me. Otherwise, I think these would be perfectly serviceable headphones for gaming or listening to TV or music. In the end, though, I am going to be gaming with my Turtle Beach Ear Force XO One Gaming Headset I picked up at the same time I got these. They are smaller, and less fancy, but they worked 100% right out of the box, with nothing complicated about them at all, and chat worked beautifully on the first try.So, for the Klipsch KG-300, I have to give it: 3 stars.

3:19 Mins The video shows me doing a sound test with the device and a decibel meter, and it shows me testing it with it armed and a door opening. Overall, this is a high quality device that passed all of my tests with flying colors. I really like it.5 stars.

This is a decent little voice recorder. My only complaints about it, are that the status lights are WAY too faint and small. I didn't think it even had status lights at first, until I read the manual, and then knew where to look for them. Other than that, though, this unit is fairly solid. I did several sample recordings of myself talking, from various distances away, and it all played back fine. I was originally concerned that the device would fill up FAST since raw audio can be HUGE, but it is compressing it to a smaller format, and a 1 minute recording only took up a couple of Megabytes of space, so you should be able to use this sucker to record around 20-30 hours of voice (assuming the compression rate holds, and the charge holds -- you will most likely need to recharge it before you would be able to fill it up).Over all, this is a decent little unit that gets the job done. The controls could be a bit easier to use, and the status lights could be MUCH bigger and brighter, but either way, this will get the job done.4 stars.Disclosure: I was given a free copy of this item in exchange for a fair and honest review.
