I got this for my 6 year old nephew, and he loves it. It is a very fun toy. It shoots, makes noises, moves and all with the remote control. He loves it, and has spent a lot of time playing with it. I think he would play with it, even without the Star Wars theme. We haven't had any problems with it.5 stars

8:06 MinsThe video shows me doing a test-cook of some scrabbled eggs (and it not going well). Overall, the griddle feels cheap and not well made. I had trouble with the surface temperature of the unit, and I don't care for the design of it.2.5 stars.

This is a very nice neck pillow. I have been testing it out for weeks now at home on the couch (because why not?) and it does a very good job of resting the head and neck, while not being too hot. It is also soft and comfortable, has a removable cover for washing, and includes a generous amount of memory foam. My only caveat would be that the pillow is rather thick, so if you are smaller in stature, you may want to try before you buy, as the pillow might end up pushing you head into an uncomfortable position, especially if you are trying to sleep with it on a plane.

I can't really say a lot about these headphones that is nice. Among the traits of these headphones which I don't find objectionable:1.) I can say that the ear cups have a nice fabric-y covering (better than leather or fake leather, absorbs less heat)2.) The removable microphone works well3.) The status notices from the unit are spoken words (powering up, powering down, etc.) instead of just beep codes.On to the objectionable traits.1.) The pairing process is RIDICULOUSLY complicated (you have to use a paperclip to press a recessed button!) and DOES NOT WORK WELL! I had to FIGHT with this stupid thing to get it to pair AT ALL. The instructions SAY that it will arrive pre-paired, but mine didn't. Just the overly long and obnoxious pairing process alone makes me not want to use these things. Seriously, headphone industry, you NEED to find a BETTER way to do this. It should be a one-button press thing that happens automatically. The Playstation and the Xbox have figured it out, why haven't you?2.) The digital audio cable they include with the unit is VERY short (just a little bit shorter than 2 feet long, tip to tip). I don't know about you, but NONE of my game systems sit within 2 feet of my TV. Conversely, the digital audio cable that has come with all of the other Turtle Beach headsets I have, were all around 4-6 feet in length -- much more practical to use. With this cable, your choices are to go out and get another one that is longer, or to move your game system to sit right under/next to your TV.3.) The whole unit is a light-weight plastic, and feels cheap.4.) The sound from the unit is spotty at best, and seems to suffer for poor signal quality.5.) The controls on the unit are too close together, and seem to be cross-wired or at least so close together that it is VERY easy to hit the wrong control when you are trying to find one by feel alone.In short, while there are some positives for this headset, I CANNOT recommend it. Turtle Beach normally puts out fine quality products -- but this is NOT one of them.2 stars.

Works just fine. I tested this to connect my PS4 to my TV, my laptop to my TV, and my 360 to a different TV. Connection worked fine every time. Not much else to say about a utility item like this :)4 stars

Not bad, not bad at all. This table cloth has a nice weight and grain to the fabric. It drapes well, and it looks good on our table. Probably it's biggest feature is its claim of being stain resistant, however, I am unwilling to possibly ruin a perfectly serviceable table cloth simply to test that claim. However, if we ever do make a major spill on it, and the stain resistance proves to be not up to their claims, I will update this review. We have used it for a normal dining experience, and it handled fine the usual small amounts of food, etc. that can end up on a table. It washed up fine afterwards, as well.This isn't a jaw-dropping, perfect table cloth, but it certainly gets the job done.4 stars.

Not bad at all. This s a good little utility item to have in the car for day to day use, and especially for road-trips. I tested it with 2 Samsung Galaxy S5's, and an LG Optimus F6. All 3 of the devices charged fairly quickly, and I didn't observe any major problems. Of course, with a 3-port USB charger, that means keeping 3 USB charging cables in the car, which I would rather not do. Also, I did notice that the cables don't fit super-snug into the charging ports, so you have to do a bit of fiddling with the cables to get them all seated and charging. If you plug in 3 high power demand devices, then you are going to get a slower charge rate, there is no getting around that.Overall, though, this is a handy little device to have.4 stars.Notice: The manufacturer of this item gave me a free copy of the item for review purposes.

8:06 MinsThe video shows me doing a test-cook of some scrabbled eggs (and it not going well). Overall, the griddle feels cheap and not well made. I had trouble with the surface temperature of the unit, and I don't care for the design of it.2.5 stars.

7:06 MinsThis is not a bad little device. The video walks you through setting it up and connecting to it with an iPad (although any mobile device's steps would be similar). The video then shows photos, documents, videos and music running on the tablet, streaming from the device. Overall, not bad at all.4.5 stars.

Very nice cloth napkins. There isn't much to say about things like sheets, hats, forks, etc. They are soft enough for my usage, they launder well, the colors don't fade after washing, and they are absorbent. I even like the color :)4 stars

This Wahl trimmer is all right, but it isn't salon-grade, for sure.It feels cheap and plasticy, and the heads they include with it don't really impress me all that much. That being said, it is quite functional, and your average user will probably like this unit just fine. I have reviewed quite a few shavers over time, and I have come to have a pretty fine eye for these things. Nothing about this unit jumps out at me. I do like that they aren't using touch-controls for the unit. I also like the quick-charging battery, and the lithium-ion capacity and performance of the battery.Overall, this is a decent beard trimmer and shaver, but in my experience, these kinds of units can either be great shavers, or great beard trimmers, but never both. This one tries to be both, and like all the rest who have tried, I think it fails at it. There aren't a large variety of trimming tools available, and the shaving options are foil-based, which I don't really care for, and they are set in that dual rotary-drum layout which I REALLY don't care for.There isn't anything really WRONG with this unit, it just isn't stellar. So, I am giving it 4 stars, because Amazon won't let me do partial stars, but my actual rating is 3.5 stars. I am rounding it up to 4, because I don't think it is fair to rate it as 3 stars.3.5 stars

These will be used for nicer dinners, only.I like the look and feel of them, and they will pair well with the blue napkins we have, but since the mat is joined bamboo sticks via cloth, and with a large ribbon of cloth down the middle of them, there isn't any way to expect these to be long-life placemats. Once the cloth ribbon in the center gets severely dirty, that will pretty much be it for these mats. They are nice looking, but they are going to be a pain-in-the-neck to clean. Can't just throw them in the washing machine and call it a day.So, like I said, these will be reserved for nicer dinners only, knowing full well that they won't be long for this Earth. That's ok, though, sometimes it is worth it to have a nice layout a few times, than never :)4 stars

This is just a cool little device. In addition to being a label printer which you can hook up to your computer, you can also use this wirelessly on the go after pairing it with your bluetooth-capable phone. I didn't really do much with that functionality of it though, as I have no need for a wireless label printer to be paired with my phone. But I am sure some people do, and they will love this.-----------------------------------------------------EXECUTIVE SUMMARY:PROS:-you can use it wirelessly on the go with your phone paired to it with bluetooth, and batteries in the label unit-labels stick very well-label adhesive backing is easy to remove-label maker software included with the unit is very nice, and very easy to use, and includes a TON of pre-done labels to use-label ribbons aren't as expensive per inch that you get in each package, as other brands I have used-labels come in neat versions like glow-in-the-dark, and fancy designs, they also come in super-sized formatCONS:-not much, at best I can say that if you have no need or desire for the mobile phone integration, you'll be paying for it anyway-----------------------------------------------------As for the core functionality of the device, after you install the software for it, and hook it up to your computer, it basically acts just like any other printer would. The labels you can make with it, though, are pretty impressive. The software you download to the computer includes a TON of pre-made labels in various categories (school, hospital, office, home, travel, etc.) with nice graphics and standard messages. And, then on top of that, they give you access to a BUNCH of clip-art, borders, and other cool things, in addition to fonts to craft custom labels. You can then save those labels, use them like templates, etc. etc. It is all very slick, and works very well.Additionally, the label ribbons themselves aren't as expensive as labels I have used in the past for an older Casio model, and they stick VERY well, AND the backs of the labels are split down the back making peeling off the backing to expose the adhesive MUCH easier. Also, the labels come in neat varieties like glow in the dark, and fancy/elegant as well as large-print sizes.5 stars

0:55 MinsThe video shows me doing a distance test with the bow for 100ft (which it passes), and shooting the suction-dart at a glass surface, and seeing it stick. The bow works very well, it is very accurate, and it can rocket those arrows out at a pretty impressive speed. I think most kids that would be in to shooting targets, or having "nerf" wars with their friends, would love this thing. Only caveat is, the heads on the arrows aren't that soft, and the bow really CAN fire at impressive speeds and power, so they should be LONG-DISTANCE "wars" and protective clothing should be used (of course, the manufacturer is going to say not to shoot it at people at all, but we all know the kids are going to shoot it at each other anyway).Anyway, the thing is fun, it works very well, and as advertised.5 stars!

Meh.I am a long-time software engineer who has also been doing web stuff since the 1990's. I have been largely avoiding JavaScript and jQuery where I could, and only using it as built-into the .NET framework with update panels, and similar constructs -- or just using snippets of JavaScript I have built up into a handy library over the years to show/hide things, change fonts, etc. I have been using HTML5 since it came out, though, that and CSS3 are pretty much unavoidable.But, I figured, since jQuery doesn't seem to be going away, I might as well sit down and fiddle with it until I could bend it to my will :)This book starts out strong (although I skipped right to chapter 4, and the first 3 chapters are just intros, "about the book" and a history of web applications (which I already knew). Chapters 4 & 5 went along swimmingly, then chapter 6 (jQuery) arrived.Listen, I am a developer with almost 2 solid decades of programming experience across a wide swath of languages, and I am telling you that the structure of chapter 6 leaves much to be desired. Instead of breaking the chapter into smaller parts, and including intros for each concept, etc. the author just kind of dumps everything out in one long string. Yes, there are examples, and section headers, but it seems like the author just wanted to get that info dump out there as fast as possible, so they could move on to playing with the jQuery.Now, I am no stranger to jQuery, like I said, I have been avoiding it, not ignoring it. I have jQuery deployed in quite a few production apps at this very moment. But, I hadn't ever sat down to study and understand it. I would just google for whatever it was I needed to do, find a code sample on stack-overflow, or similar, and then away I would go. My purpose behind getting this book was to get a solid understanding of jQuery-speak. And, while I can certainly do that with this book (because the information IS there), I cannot do it easily. The author quickly jumps into selectors, and then immediately springboards into DOM manipulation from there, expanding rapidly on the vocabulary and keyword usage, without every really stopping to catch one's breath.If you can make it through chapter 6, and get your head around everything, then the rest of the book will be downhill for you. But, as for myself, I didn't care for the author's layout and information presentation style in the book. Too rushed, and too much of an information dump, in my opinion.  I would have broken it down into sections, with each section having a clear purpose, and goal, with explanations along the way. You do get that information from the author, but it comes out as one long string of data, so, brace yourself.3 stars.

I am, by no means, an audio expert. I can just tell you what I have experienced. The sound output from these headphones seems really good to me. The bass is very deep, and very satisfying. High vocal ranges come through clear, and everything in the middle sounds good to my non-expert ears.Additionally, I am a fan of quality materials used in the construction of things like this. These are made out of metal and leather, and some plastic and some synthetic fabric, but the majority materials are metal and leather. (Note, the leather earpieces can get warmer faster than fabric covered ear-pieces).I also like the extra-long cords that come with the headphones (with a nice braided cover as well), and the hard-case for storing them in. You can also order custom face-plate "shields" with stock graphics, or your own graphics -- which I thought was pretty cool (you have to do that directly with V-Moda, though, you can't do it through Amazon).My biggest complaint about these headphones, is that stock/out-of-the-box, they were TIGHT on my head, which would have given me headaches. Luckily, this isn't my first time to the new headphones rodeo, so I knew to stretch them out by putting a few books together and putting the headphones on the books to stretch them out for about a week. After that, they were golden.5 stars!

Works just fine. There are plenty of USB devices (such as keyboards that have to run through a keyboard tray, and up or down through a desk to a PC tower) that don't have long enough cords to reach where you want to put them. These extension cables also make it easy to access USB ports on a computer in non-ideal spot to reach, or USB ports on the back of a computer, etc -- making plugging in flash drives and the like easy. I constantly find uses for things like this.4 stars :)

Got this for my girl's bed. Let it air out for a day like they say to do in the instructions, then put a mattress protector over it, and then sheets, etc. The bed is much more comfortable with the memory foam topper on it. We have toppers on all of our beds (from various manufacturers), and they all work just fine. They DO retain body heat a bit better than a basic mattress would, but not drastically. And, if you have the topper under a mattress cover, and sheets, then the body heat retention shouldn't be that severe. Overall, it does exactly what it is supposed to do.The only thing I DIDN'T like about this one, is for some reason they decided to punch a bunch of holes all throughout the thing. I don't know WHY they did that, but I don't like that. You can't feel the holes when you lay on it, but it still bugs me that they did that. Like I said, we own a lot of mattress toppers, and this is the first time I have ever seen one with holes in it. It kind of screams "cost savings" to me, and if that is the case, it should be advertised as such.

Works well enough. I bought this for one reason, and that was to sit in a windowsill and pull in cool air from an open window to cool the house off at night. It works OK at that, but the air displacement from this unit isn't very good (which isn't surprising, it is small). It is also louder than you might expect, on the highest setting.  But overall, it does its job well enough.4 stars

Works quite well. We are using one of these in the master bedroom, and I put one in the girls' room as well. They sit on a desk or dresser, so they don't take up floor space like a stand-fan would, and the air output from them is quite nice. I generally like Lasko fans, and this one is no exception.4 stars :)

I am using this bad-boy in my ASUS Republic of Gamers laptop right now. I tried several SSDs and after much research and trial and error, I settled on this one. It comes with data transfer and porting tools, but I just did a fresh install of the OS on it, so I can't report how well the tools work. I trust Samsung, and this drive was universally well-rated and reviewed. I have been using it for over a month now, and the speeds are excellent both up and down. I am so used to running on a SSD now, that when I use the computers at work, they seem like they are running in slow motion to me >_<The drive has been rock solid so far, and I really like it. Installation was a breeze. They include drive-cloning and data-porting software for free with the purchase of the drive, and the drive is big enough to use as a main OS/"C" drive, and still have enough room to install your core software to run as SSD speeds (games, and general data I am keeping on a separate "data-only" drive in the second HDD port on the laptop).5 stars!

Works very well. I use one of these at work, and another at home. Printed books aren't dead yet! They still have their uses over their digital counter parts, and when you are trying to work from a book, having a stand like this to hold it open is VERY NICE to have.4 stars ;)

Very very nice set. The blu-ray transfers are beautifully cleaned up, with enhanced colors, and good audio. There are multiple subtitling options to cater to all tastes, and everything is as I remember it. The sets also include a nice book that lists the episodes and gives a summary for each, and includes some samples of the manga. This is the first volume of a planned 7 volume run. The first volume will give you a good idea about whether or not the series is for you or not ;)Also note, with this set, Viz has FINALLY fixed the order of the episodes so they run in the correct order, and are not out of sequence any more (the most glaringly annoying example of which was that in the old sets they use to run the episodes: "The Abduction of P-Chan" and "Close Call! The Dance of Death... On Ice!" (the ice skating episodes) AFTER they ran "Enter Shampoo, the Gung-Ho Girl! I Put My Life in Your Hands" -- which made NO SENSE, because Akane has a flashback in the Shampoo intro-episodes where she remembers events from the ice skating episodes, that HAVEN'T HAPPENED YET, when they were presented in the wrong order.)Parental Warning: For those in the United States (and elsewhere) still fiercely clinging to ancient Puritanical vices on nudity (but for some reason are perfectly OK with wanton/graphic violence o_O), you should note that there is a fair amount of female non-sexual nudity in this series, especially in the first season. There is a little bit of sexual nudity in the series as well, but usually just in the form of females trying to entice the main character, and not "bedroom" scenes.5 stars for one of the best animes of all time getting the red carpet blu-ray treatment!

These things work really well! I have been using these things for about a month now (I was originally just going to use grease pencils, until I saw someone else recommending these on Amazon), and I have to say I am impressed! The stickers go on easily, and they stay on quite nicely. I have run MANY of the stickers attached to the lids of our glassware, through the dishwasher (top shelf), and they have all stayed firmly affixed to the lids. The pen that comes with the set works just fine (but any permanent marker will work as well), and the eraser also works just fine (and again, as I understand it, any eraser will work as well). This is such a novel and handy idea to have working in the kitchen, I really do like it. It makes putting the date on leftovers a snap, and eliminates the need to do the dreaded "smell test" to decide if something is safe to eat or not.5 stars!
Fits the advertised photo print size just fine. Very simple/basic monochrome color with the matte black finish. Stands up well. Not much more to say about a picture frame.4 stars

This frame turned out to be prettier than expected. It fits the photo size perfectly, and it stands up well. I really do like the glossed wood look. Very nice, I plan to pick up a few more in the near future.

Very nice. It drives me crazy that a lot of headphones you can buy today, don't come with a clip for the wire! This is a pack of 5 clips, at a very reasonable price. They work well, and I would not be able to tell them apart from one that came included with a headphone set.4 stars :)

Works just fine. I am using it right now to extend the range of my headphones. Not much to say about little single function devices like this. They either work or they don't work. This works. Nothing exceptional about it, though (which would be hard to do). I will say that I have tried other 3.5mm audio cable extenders and couplers in the past, and have gotten static/buzzing and other problems on the line because of them -- THIS coupler, has no such issues, sound comes from the first cable plugged into the coupler, and transmits to the second cable, and comes through to my headphones very clear.4 stars :)

Pretty darn good. I like it! I had zero problems getting this to connect to my ipad. I had no problem getting my ipad into the case. And the keyboard itself works very well. And, the kickstand mode for this case works a LOT better than the standard ipad case. I was also impressed that the case is designed so that the keyboard isn't active, unless you have it in kickstand mode, it can detect when it it in that mode, and only enables the keyboard then. You should know, though, that this case is QUITE heavier than the standard ipad case Apple sells. If you hold your ipad in your hand a lot, you should expect an additional amount of wrist strain because of that.PROS:-works very well-keyboard is responsive and pairs easily with the ipad-gives your ipad a kickstand easy way to prop up-keyboard turns itself on and off depending on how you are using the caseCONS:-it is HEAVY4 stars! :)

I have bought, literally, 5 ASUS laptops and counting. And, you know what, I am done with brand loyalty. Brand loyalty is for suckers. I am also done with cheap laptops with cheap components.I bought this laptop, and not only did the Seagate Hard Disc Drive (HDD) die, but this model also had the fun problem of the socket to plug the AC power into, came loose from the sidewall of the laptop, making it impossible to charge it after that (unless I wanted to break it open and resolder the connections). I didn't cheap out on this model, either. I paid $600 for it when I bought it. I was expecting FAR BETTER quality than I got.ASUS *CAN* make a VERY GOOD laptop. However, you have to be willing to shell out the premium bucks if you want their quality stuff. Their Republic of Gamers (RoG) line is actually quite good. Their stock/discount lines (which is what you are looking at now) are where ASUS cuts corners to make up profits for the slimmer margins they must have on their decent lines such as the RoG line.Most of their "bargain" models come with Seagate hard disk drives (HDD) -- and, I am not kidding, almost every single Seagate drive I have ever owned, has died a horrible death within 1-2 years of normal usage. I have had 2 full-sized HDDs die on me, 1 external HDD die, and 3 laptop HDDs, in three SEPARATE ASUS laptops, die. ALL of them were Seagate drives. In contrast, the RoG ASUS that I have, shipped with a Hitachi HDD, which are widely regarded as one of the best on the market, and I have owned several, and NONE of my Hitachi drives have died, and they are still alive and kicking to this day.In short, you get what you pay for. If you are looking for a CHEAP laptop that you ONLY expect to be used for business/school needs, and it will be kept CAREFULLY on a desk, and HARDLY EVER MOVED, and you only expect to get 2-3 years out of that laptop (TOPS) before it dies, then go ahead and get one of the cheap ASUS models.If you want to be able to take the laptop around with you, also use if for gaming (or graphics work, or video work, or anything else RAM/Processor intensive) AND you want it to last AT LEAST 4-6 years (treated decently), then shell out for a top-line ASUS (like their RoG line), or get an Alienware, or a Samsung laptop.My experience with this laptop, and 3 others like it, all from the bargain line of laptops from ASUS, has been to teach me that you get what you pay for, and cheap up-front isn't as good a deal as quality and pricier up-front. My Republic of Gamers laptop from ASUS has been working very, very well. It came with quality parts, and runs very nicely with no problems. The "cheap" laptops I bought from ASUS have all died on me within 2-3 years, and I regret purchasing all of them. I am on my last "cheap" laptop (the A53U-AS21), and once it dies, that's it, I am not buying any more "cheap" laptops.1 star for cheap components and shoddy workmanship.

I got this model of ASUS laptop 3 years ago. I still have it, and it is still running fine.  I have owned 5 ASUS laptops over the years. This one isn't the best one I've owned, but it isn't bad. Most of the rest of them were the "cheap" models ASUS has, that I bought for my girls. Get the better/more expensive models, it makes a HUGE difference.I bought the A73E-XE1 to work on, and to game. It ended up being a bit under-powered for both gaming and video editing. For programming and database work it excelled, though. It seems that ASUS used some decent components in it, though, as it is 3 years later, and it is still running fine.The A73E-XE1 is a 64-bit machine running under a GeForce GTX 660M GPU. It ships (at least mine did) with a 650GB, 5400RPM HDD, has a full-sized keyboard, and number pad, and a 17" screen. Unfortunately, it only had an on-board Intel graphics setup, and an i3 Intel processor. Just not enough power under the hood to do everything I needed it to do on a daily basis. So, I upgraded to a Republic of Gamers model.If you are going to go ASUS, go premium, because their bargain/cheap models, leave MUCH to be desired. I will never buy another of their cheap/flimsy component models again.4 stars.

I have owned 5 ASUS laptops over the years, and I am by far the happiest with this one. Most of the rest of them were the "cheap" models ASUS has, that I bought for my girls, and holy cow, IT MAKES A DIFFERENCE!I bought the G75VW-AS71 new right about when it came out, and paid a pretty price for it (>$1250), but you know what? It was worth it.  It is a heavy, mean, gaming machine. It also kicks booty at video editing and other processor intensive stuff (like database work, programming tasks, etc.). It comes with QUALITY components, and it has NICE extras included for the price.The G75VW-AS71 is a 64-bit machine running under a GeForce GTX 660M GPU. It ships (at least mine did) with a 750GB, 7200RPM Hitachi HDD, has a full-sized keyboard, and number pad, a 17" LED screen, backlit keys, an extra HDD bay which makes upgrading your storage space a SNAP (didn't know about the extra drive until I popped mine open, originally planning to do a HDD swap). But, most importantly, it hasn't died on me, or even stuttered or lagged on me 1.5 years on and counting. I am writing this review on it.If you are going to go ASUS, go premium, because their bargain/cheap models, leave MUCH to be desired. I will never buy another of their cheap/flimsy component models again.My only complaint about my RoG model is the little rubber feet on the bottom were put on with some extremely cheap/bad glue, and fall out easily. I lost one of the feet entirely before I realized that. After that, I yanked them all out and re-glued them with a good glue. Do that, and you're golden.4.5 stars.

I have bought, literally, 5 ASUS laptops and counting. And, you know what, I am done with brand loyalty. Brand loyalty is for suckers. I am also done with cheap laptops with cheap components.Here's the thing. ASUS *CAN* make a VERY GOOD laptop. However, you have to be willing to shell out the premium bucks if you want their quality stuff. Their Republic of Gamers (RoG) line is actually quite good.  Their stock/discount lines (which is what you are looking at now) are where ASUS cuts corners to make up profits for the slimmer margins they must have on their decent lines such as the RoG line.Most of their "bargain" models come with Seagate hard disk drives (HDD) -- and, I am not kidding, almost every single Seagate drive I have ever owned, has died a horrible death within 1-2 years of normal usage. I have had 2 full-sized HDDs die on me, 1 external HDD die, and 3 laptop HDDs, in three SEPARATE ASUS laptops, die. ALL of them were Seagate drives.  In contrast, the RoG ASUS that I have, shipped with a Hitachi HDD, which are widely regarded as one of the best on the market, and I have owned several, and NONE of my Hitachi drives have died, and they are still alive and kicking to this day.Additionally, the stock/"bargain" ASUS laptops tend to come with off-market/no-name RAM, and other components. As for video cards, count yourself lucky if you get a name-brand. Most likely you will be getting an Intel baked-in, on-motherboard video setup to handle your graphics. Including this one, the A53U-AS21 comes with Intel graphics. What that means is, no modern video games at decent settings, and games yet to be released may not run well (or at all) on that laptop -- which is all well and good if you don't play games on your laptop.Additional problems I have had with ASUS laptops in their bargain tier have been:-the little rubber feet on the bottom of the device which are supposed to balance the unit and provide shock absorption, fall off.-one of my ASUS laptops had a faulty connector where the AC power plug-in point was, and came detached from the side-wall of the laptop, making it impossible to charge the laptop anymore without ripping it open and soldering that connection point back into place (for the record, that model that happened to was the K53E-C1)-I have had frequent memory problems with many of my ASUS laptops until I ripped out their cheap RAM from no-name companies, and replaced it with top-of-the-line Corsair RAM or similar.-the amount of bloatware and shovelware that comes pre-installed on ASUS laptops is getting worse and more numerous each year.In short, you get what you pay for. If you are looking for a CHEAP laptop that you ONLY expect to be used for business/school needs, and it will be kept CAREFULLY on a desk, and HARDLY EVER MOVED, and you only expect to get 2-3 years out of that laptop (TOPS) before it dies, then go ahead and get one of the cheap ASUS models.If you want to be able to take the laptop around with you, also use if for gaming (or graphics work, or video work, or anything else RAM/Processor intensive) AND you want it to last AT LEAST 4-6 years (treated decently), then shell out for a top-line ASUS (like their RoG line), or get an Alienware, or a Samsung laptop.All of the top-line models are going to cost you more, but if you do the math, it works out as a better deal in the long-run. The "bargain" laptops tend to run $300-$500, and you will get 2-3 years out of them (less if they aren't treated VERY well). To get decent memory use out of them, you may then spend another $50-$150 upgrading the RAM (which is easy to do, even for non-technical people) and another $50-200 upgrading the HDD (unlikely unless you are a tech-type person). Multiply the base amount by 2, and you get a cost of $600-$1000 for 4-6 years of computing, having to buy a new "cheap one" half way through. And, if you DO upgrade the RAM each time you get one, then it will actually be more like $700-1300. If you also upgrade the HDD, then it will be more like $800-1700. So, at the most optimistic, you get a cost/year of $100-167 up to $150-$250, and a cost per year of $133-283 up to $200-$425 at the higher end of the scale, if you are an upgrader.But, if you get one of the more premium models to start with, at a cost of anywhere from $500-$900 (or even more if you really want to shell out for a power machine), then your cost per year goes down dramatically to $83-$125 on the cheaper end of the scale up to $150-$225 on the higher end. For 4-6 years of decent, hassle-free, computing (if you treat and handle the laptop well).My experience with this laptop, and 3 others like it, all from the bargain line of laptops from ASUS, has been to teach me that you get what you pay for, and cheap up-front isn't as good a deal as quality and pricier up-front. My Republic of Gamers laptop from ASUS has been working very, very well. It came with quality parts, and runs very nicely with no problems. The "cheap" laptops I bought from ASUS have all died on me within 2-3 years, and I regret purchasing all of them. I am on my last "cheap" laptop (this one, the A53U-AS21), and once it dies, that's it, I am not buying any more "cheap" laptops.

I have an iPad (current gen) I like to carry around with me sometimes, and having the ability to charge it while on the go, without having to carry around the full charging setup, can be quite handy. This little device fits that need quite nicely. I have tested it, and it worked fine to charge my iPad via the USB to Lighting adapter. It also fits on my keychain ring (although it is VERY thick, and you will need to use another key, or something, to get the ring open wide enough to start threading it on the ring). Once that is done, though, carrying it around with you makes being able to charge your Lighting powered devices on the go, much more likely.Caveats: the cord is VERY short, so you will need to plug this in someplace where you can lay your device down as well. Also note, the power the device receives is dependent on the type of USB source you plug it into. A LOT of USB ports on computers DO NOT output enough AMPS to power charging an iPad -- that IS NOT the fault of this device. You have to plug it into a USB source that is outputting enough AMPS, to charge the device. Some USB hubs do that, and any USB to AC adapter (like the one that comes with your iPhone/iPad) will do that.Overall, this is a good product. They need to make it slimmer, and they should figure out a way to have a retractable cord, or a cord that wraps around a few times, so that WHERE you plug it in doesn't matter as much.Full disclosure, the manufacturer of this device gave me a review copy of this item for free, in exchange for an honest review.4 stars.

This is the sequel to Hard Luck Hank: Screw the Galaxy, which I read and reviewed as a 5-star book -- you should read it too! :)This followup book continues the story from the first book, and it keeps many of the same characters (including the titular Hank, naturally) from the first book. Not a whole lot of the stuff explained in the first book are recapped again for the sequel. So, while reading the first book isn't necessary to reading and understanding this book, I highly recommend it (besides, Campbell is an independent author, and I am sure he could use the support!)Hard Luck Hank: Basketful of Crap is difficult to categorize as was the first book. It is set in a Star Wars-y/Halo-y/Mass Effect-y universe (dirty/well lived in/high tech/military & super-humans). The book also has humor in it -- it is a dry/dark sense of humor, but it is still humor ;)The story is basically a continuation of the first book, but set after a 7 year period of time has lapsed. Events from the first book are commented on, but not generally explained. The story is basically an ongoing narrative from Hank as he deals with an ever-escalating series of issues and events as things spin out of control on his space station. There are quite a few fire fights, and there are lots of instances of random/weird stuff happening that Hank has to deal with.The story in the sequel again moves along at a fast pace, like the first book. And you will get hooked pretty quickly wanting to know what happens next, and also wanting to know what the answer is behind the big mysteries in the story. The story is well written, polished, and well edited (better edited in fact, than a LOT of major-publisher written stuff I have read).Overall, I liked the book, hence my 4.5 star rating. However, I did dock it half a star this time around, because frankly the story got a little less fun for me. The first book was lighter, and sillier; it had goofy alien girls in love with Hank and not realizing the situation they were in. It had crazy-powerful mutants messing up everything; it had robots running amuck; it had Hank yelling his trademark line (before attacking someone), "eat suck, suckface!" and it coming off as comedy; it had mad scientists, galaxy-destroying ships and insane street-gang politics in it. It was just a fun read.In contrast, the sequel gets a bit heavier. Gone are the goofy girls in love with Hank -- in their place are random people being shot to death outside Hank's door. Gone are the crazy-powerful mutants, Hank is pretty much the last remaining powerful mutant on the space station. There are no robots running amuck, but there are powerful assassin women running amuck -- but they keep stabbing Hank. There is a weirdly cheerful guy who befriends Hank, and seems to have a weird power over females, and the story rarely leaves the space station this time.  Everything just feels more closed in, and restricted in this book, even in situations where Hank yells his "eat suck, suckface," line, Hank is in danger, and even he is worried about whether he should say it or not given the situation he is in. Finally, the biggest bummer for me, was that Hank was made more vulnerable in this book. In the first book, Hank is basically indestructible. That made the fire fights more or less fun, because we weren't worried about the viewpoint character, so we could appreciate the situations in a macabre way as the action and dark comedy unfolded. In this book, Hank keeps getting hurt (which happened in the first book) -- but now for some reason, it is affecting him in ways which is making it very hard for Hank to move or even feel things -- and it is freaking Hank out. That isn't fun. Hank spends a LARGE portion of the last 1/4 of the book being very worried about himself and his mutation -- and that just bummed me out.I STRONGLY hope that the 3rd book will "fix" Hank, at least enough so that he is more or less at the same point he was at in the first book. Because, 2nd book Hank wasn't nearly as fun to read about -- and with his limitations given to him in the book, if things keep progressing as they have been, I am not sure what Hank is really going to be able to do in the 3rd book.Overall, though, this is a quality sci-fi story. If you like sci-fi, you should like this book. It is better than a LOT of the stuff out there now. Read it! :)4.5 stars![Full disclosure: the author gave me a copy of the book in exchange for an honest review]---------------------------------Book Content Guide For Parents:---------------------------------Sex & Nudity: [1/5] sex is mentioned, but only in passing. There were no nudity or actual sex scenes. There are a couple of kissing scenes, and women's bodies are commented on appreciatively -- but in very generic terms ( like, "and she was muscular and had an amazing figure" sort of terms).Violence & Gore: [2/5] minimal, mostly PG/PG-13 action-movie types of stuff. There are fire fights in the book where people die via gunshot and explosion, but none of it is described. That's about it. No torture, no crimes against women, no graphic details of much of anything. Even in a fight scene where Hank is involved, when he gets stabbed or whatever, we aren't worried about it, because he is basically invulnerable. Hank DOES crush someone in a bear-hug kind of attack in one fight (and the crush is told about, but not described in detail), and hurts that person, but to be fair, that person was trying to kill him.Profanity: [1/5] the occasional crass language is used (not profane, just crass), women's bodies are described in a couple of scenes (but not graphically, just appreciatively). I don't recall much in the way of profanity.Alcohol/Drugs/Smoking: [2/5] there are scenes in bars. Drug addicts are talked about, but are never "on camera." Characters drink in a few scenes, but no attention is called to it.Frightening/Intense Scenes: [3.5/5] The last 1/4 of the book is fairly intense. There are some major battles, and lots of people die, and Hank has to run for his life. There are fights where people close to Hank are in serious danger. The main villain in the book is crazy powerful and insane, and creepy. There are at least 2 fight scenes I recall where Hank is in genuine danger during the fight.

I had this game on pre-order ever since it was available for order. It is brimming with inside jokes and references for fans of the show. Even if you aren't a fan of the show, the game is a good RPG all by itself. It is a turn-based RPG in the grand tradition of old-school RPGs like the Final Fantasy & Dragon Quest series.  Standard RPG tropes are featured like upgradeable: weapons, armor and trinkets that boost various stats. You can also tinker with the items a bit with a limited crafting system that allows you to add your favorite types of boosts, stats and/or powers to items you gain, or want to make more powerful.The story is PURE South Park. If you are a fan of the show, you will LOVE it.  If you AREN'T a fan of the show ... you may like it, if you don't mind graphic stuff (expect graphic violence, graphic sexual content, and some pretty gross stuff as well overall, NC-17 stuff) -- then there is plenty of humor and plenty of entertainment to be had.Overall, the game-play is solid, the jokes are funny, the production values are stellar.5 stars!

I got this for my niece, she is solidly in the 6-12 age range for the toy. It has some great features:-a voice password-invisible ink & black light-a hidden compartment for super-secrets!For a kid, especially a young girl who wants to keep a diary, this thing is pretty darn cool. The invisible ink and black light by themselves are pretty neat. The voice password makes it that much cooler, and the hidden compartment makes it super-cool!My niece likes the toy, and uses it, and that is pretty much all that needs to be said about it.5 stars

I got this for my niece (solidly in the 6-12 age range for the product). She is super into the Monster High stuff. She has added this to her collection, and I have watched her playing with it, and enjoying it. The toy is made of decent materials, and hasn't broken while she has played with it.4 stars :)

Dreadnaught (Book #7 of the "Black Jack" Geary series, is also book #1 of the "Beyond the Frontier" series, which succeeded the "Lost Fleet" series) picks up right where Victorious (Book #6) leaves off in the Lost Fleet series by Jack Campbell. The only real difference, is the fleet is no longer lost, so the series from this point on is called the "Beyond the Frontier" series. The fleet is still under the command of John "Black Jack" Geary (now an Admiral), but they are no longer trying to head for home. [minor spoiler alert] If you want to read this book, then you should already know that Geary got the fleet back to Alliance territory, and then was able to turn around with that same fleet after repairing and resupplying, and was able to force an end to the war. [/end: minor spoiler alert]In this book, now with the war between the Alliance and the Syndics ended, humanity can turn its beleaguered gaze to the apparent cause of the war in the first place, the aliens on the other side of Syndic space.  [minor spoiler alert] Aliens, who quickly went from suspected, to outright seen and fought against, at the end of book #6, Victorious. [/end: minor spoiler alert] Now, after Geary & Desjani (whom I love) has managed to take care of some personal business, they are back with the fleet -- Geary is still an Admiral, and they have been ordered to head into the unknown region of space where these aliens reside, and to try to establish peaceful contact with them -- but, failing that, at least get the aliens to understand that any further aggression from them will be met with strong resistance from humanity.What follows is an interesting tale with more issues from cranky officers who think they should be running things, romance gone wrong, and an alien culture which completely baffles Geary and his trusted officers, forcing them into fights they don't want.  The ending was kind of abrupt though, I am fairly certain the author was told he was running long, and he just had to pick a place to end it, instead of planning the ending. But, regardless, it is an enjoyable read, and the next book is already out, so it is no big deal to get the next one and keep reading.The Lost Fleet/Beyond the Frontier -- "Black Jack" Geary series are some of my favorite Military Science Fiction series, and frankly, they are some of my favorite series, period. It is a story told in the grand tradition of Star Trek/Star Wars and epic space operas in general. The "Black Jack" Geary series (although sometimes very corny) are what got me majorly hooked on Military Science Fiction, which lead to me discovering other excellent series after that, such as the Man of War by Honsinger, and the Frontlines series by Kloos, and the Shadowstorm series by Almasi. Read it, you won't be disappointed.5 stars.---------------------------------Book Content Guide For Parents:---------------------------------Sex & Nudity: [1/5] sex is discussed in the book but not described, and it is all past-tense.Violence & Gore: [1/5] fairly minimal-- almost all of the story takes place aboard the space ships, so any violence is via naval space battles, which do result in the deaths of people, but they are never described, so feel very abstract.Profanity: [1/5] minimal, not nearly as much or as often as you might expect from a military science fiction story.Alcohol/Drugs/Smoking: [1/5] minimal. No smoking or drug use, and only minor alcohol use.Frightening/Intense Scenes: [2/5] the ships and crew are in mortal danger pretty much all of the time while behind enemy lines but nothing like a character being chased down a dark hallway followed by a homicidal maniac.

Victorious (Book #6 (and the last book in the original Lost Fleet series)) picks up right where Relentless (Book #5) leaves off in the Lost Fleet series by Jack Campbell.[spoiler alert!]......Geary has managed to get the fleet all the way back into Alliance territory, and he has managed to make use of the technology that the brilliant Captain Cresida invented, to stave off disaster with the hypernet gates. Now, safe for the moment, a lot of things happen very quickly, many of which were predicted by Geary's officers. But, once the initial political issues are dealt with (I won't say how ^_^), there are more immediate concerns....[/end: spoiler alert]Geary is tasked with leading the fleet back into Syndic space, this time with the aim of ending the war, for good. The fleet is given minimal time to repair the worst damage, resupply, and lick their wounds, and then sent out again. The Syndics are reeling, their fleets have been (mostly) destroyed, and the alien threat is looming large. Many of the Syndic star systems are in open revolt/civil war and everyone is looking to Geary for leadership and answers (poor Geary must be popping antacids like skittles at this point).The story ramps up to a major confrontation and satisfying conclusion, then it takes a turn and provides a nice setup for the next series that continues where the Lost Fleet leaves off, the Beyond The Frontier series (see, because, they aren't lost any more). The ending of the book is especially nice, and long awaited. I highlighted like the last 10 pages of the book. Very sweet, and very satisfying payoff to a long-running story thread.The Lost Fleet series is one of my favorite Military Science Fiction series, and frankly, it is one of my favorite series, period. It is a story told in the grand tradition of Star Trek/Star Wars and epic space operas in general. The Lost Fleet series is what got me majorly hooked on Military Science Fiction, which lead to me discovering other excellent series after that, such as the Man of War series by Honsinger, and the Frontlines series by Kloos, and the Shadowstorm series by Almasi. Read it, you won't be disappointed.5 stars.---------------------------------Book Content Guide For Parents:---------------------------------Sex & Nudity: [1/5] sex is discussed in the book but not described, and it is all past-tense. There are minor romantic interactions, such as kissing.Violence & Gore: [1/5] fairly minimal-- almost all of the story takes place aboard the space ships, so any violence is via naval space battles, which do result in the deaths of people, but they are never described, so feel very abstract.Profanity: [1/5] minimal, not nearly as much or as often as you might expect from a military science fiction story.Alcohol/Drugs/Smoking: [1/5] minimal. No smoking or drug use, and only minor alcohol use.Frightening/Intense Scenes: [2/5] the ships and crew are in mortal danger pretty much all of the time while behind enemy lines but nothing like a character being chased down a dark hallway followed by a homicidal maniac.

Relentless (Book #5) picks up right where Valiant (Book #4) leaves off in the Lost Fleet series by Jack Campbell. The fleet is still under the command of Captain John "Black Jack" Geary, and they are still trying to head for home. The Fleet is also still under attack from internal sources trying to assassinate Geary to force a return to the way things used to be, before he took command. The assassination and betrayal-from-within subplot comes to a major peak in this book.In this book, we get a lot more up-close and personal interaction with the Marines, who we follow for decent lengths of time as they liberate a POW camp. We also see the culmination of the fears Geary has had about the gates, and the suspected aliens, leading to an intense finale and ultimate showdown as the alliance approaches the borders of their home territory.The Lost Fleet series is one of my favorite Military Science Fiction series, and frankly, it is one of my favorite series, period. It is a story told in the grand tradition of Star Trek/Star Wars and epic space operas in general. The Lost Fleet series is what got me majorly hooked on Military Science Fiction, which lead to me discovering other excellent series after that, such as the Man of War by Honsinger, and the Frontlines series by Kloos, and the Shadowstorm series by Almasi. Read it, you won't be disappointed.5 stars.---------------------------------Book Content Guide For Parents:---------------------------------Sex & Nudity: [1/5] sex is discussed in the book but not described, and it is all past-tense.Violence & Gore: [2.5/5] fairly minimal-- almost all of the story takes place aboard the space ships, so any violence is via naval space battles, which do result in the deaths of people, but they are never described, so feel very abstract. However, we stay with the Marines a lot more in this one, and some of the battle field wounds, and fighting is covered when that happens, so the violence bumps up a bit in this one.Profanity: [1/5] minimal, not nearly as much or as often as you might expect from a military science fiction story.Alcohol/Drugs/Smoking: [1/5] minimal. No smoking or drug use, and only minor alcohol use.Frightening/Intense Scenes: [2/5] the ships and crew are in mortal danger pretty much all of the time while behind enemy lines but nothing like a character being chased down a dark hallway followed by a homicidal maniac. There is a scene where a character commits suicide, but it is describe in abstract terms, and is bloodless to the reader.

Valiant (Book #4) picks up right where Courageous (Book #3) leaves off in the Lost Fleet series by Jack Campbell. The fleet is still under the command of Captain John "Black Jack" Geary, and they are still trying to head for home. Things are getting serious now. Geary has decided to jump right back to Lakota, the location of their last fatal encounter with the Syndics where they were ambushed by Syndics who were just as surprised to see them as Geary's fleet was. The return to Lakota strategy is basically to go on a surprise offensive, while also giving his ships more time in jump space for repairs.From this point on for the rest of the series, the actions Geary has been taking in the series start to pay off. Syndics are listening to him, and even reluctant officers under his command begin to believe in what Geary has to say. Of course, there are still some die-hards who will stop at literally NOTHING to stop Geary from ruining the way they think the war should be governed.The Lost Fleet series is very entertaining, very realistic Military Science Fiction told in an epic space navy/space opera sort of way. There are huge space battles, Marine actions, love and hate, revenge and loyalty, duty and valor. The books ring with the power of those words, and even though the writing can get corny at times (sometimes SUPER corny) I never want to stop reading.5 stars.---------------------------------Book Content Guide For Parents:---------------------------------Sex & Nudity: [1/5] sex is discussed in the book but not described, and it is all past-tense.Violence & Gore: [1/5] fairly minimal-- almost all of the story takes place aboard the space ships, so any violence is via naval space battles, which do result in the deaths of people, but they are never described, so feel very abstract.Profanity: [1/5] minimal, not nearly as much or as often as you might expect from a military science fiction story.Alcohol/Drugs/Smoking: [1/5] minimal. No smoking or drug use, and only minor alcohol use.Frightening/Intense Scenes: [2/5] the ships and crew are in mortal danger pretty much all of the time while behind enemy lines but nothing like a character being chased down a dark hallway followed by a homicidal maniac.

Courageous (Book #3) picks up right where Fearless (Book #2) leaves off in the Lost Fleet series by Jack Campbell. The fleet is still under the command of Captain John "Black Jack" Geary, and they are still trying to head for home. The disasterous results of the mutiny are fully felt in this book, and the author's long game plan is slowly revealed in this book, with hints of a hidden alien species playing both sides of the war for their own interests.Geary's old fashioned and non-insane ways of doing things continue to be proven right, and amidst the personnel struggles he has to deal with, a new threat starts to make itself known to him, and with it, suspicions of dangerous powers that could change the face of galaxy for both sides of the war.The book is a fast paced, nail-biting thriller that includes plenty of the best the military tradition has to offer in the way of: duty, honor, valor and brotherhood. The book features space battles, revenge, some romance, and diplomacy done the Marine-way. The story is told in the best traditions of Star Trek and Star Wars, and fans of those series should feel right at home here. The story has no graphic violence, and very little regular violence. I can only start reading one of these books on a Friday night or Saturday, because I WILL sit there and read the whole thing cover to cover, until I am done -- regardless of if I have to go into work tomorrow or not. Not many authors can cause me to show up for work on 2 hours of sleep, but Jack Campbell can.5 stars.---------------------------------Book Content Guide For Parents:---------------------------------Sex & Nudity: [2/5] there are brief sex/nudity scenes in the book with minimal detail -- "and she shared his bed" sort of stuff. Characters also discuss sexual relationships in the book from time to time, but not in detail.Violence & Gore: [1/5] fairly minimal, sometimes the marines are sent out, and we get some general descriptions, but almost all of the story takes place aboard the space ships, so any violence is via naval space battles, which do result in the deaths of people, but they are never described, so feel very abstract.Profanity: [1/5] minimal, not nearly as much or as often as you might expect from a military science fiction story.Alcohol/Drugs/Smoking: [1/5] minimal. I don't recall and smoking or drug use, and alcohol use is mainly limited to occasional drinks or reference to drinks, never characters getting drunk or glorifying it.Frightening/Intense Scenes: [2/5] the ships and crew are in mortal danger pretty much all of the time while behind enemy lines, and all of the space battles involve the threat of destruction for everyone in the battle.

Fearless (Book #2) picks up right where Dauntless (Book #1) leaves off in the Lost Fleet series by Jack Campbell. The fleet is still under the command of Captain John "Black Jack" Geary, and they are still trying to head for home. However, things have gotten more complicated for Geary, because even while he tries to plan logistics and tactics against an entrenched enemy on their home field, he is also facing mutinous dissension in his own ranks.Geary's fleet has rescued some prisoners of war, and some of them were fairly high ranking, and none of the high ranking officers understand Geary's old fashioned (and sane) way of doing things, and they have no interest in learning about it. Cue fighting.The space battles in the book are interesting and exciting, and the romances and personal struggles are very interesting. The series feels like Star Trek, with a little bit of Star Wars sprinkled in for good measure. It is brimming with: military details, honor, loyalty, revenge, duty and action. It has no graphic violence, and very little regular violence. The story is riveting, and keeps me turning pages far later into the night than I really should. I love the Lost Fleet series, and you will as well.5 stars.---------------------------------Book Content Guide For Parents:---------------------------------Sex & Nudity: [3/5] there are brief sex/nudity scenes in the book that are briefly described, but not in full detail. Characters also discuss sexual relationships in the book from time to time, but not in detail.Violence & Gore: [1/5] fairly minimal, sometimes the marines are sent out, and we get some general descriptions, but almost all of the story takes place aboard the space ships, so any violence is via naval space battles, which do result in the deaths of people, but they are never described, so feel very abstract.Profanity: [1/5] minimal, not nearly as much or as often as you might expect from a military science fiction story.Alcohol/Drugs/Smoking: [1/5] minimal. I don't recall and smoking or drug use, and alcohol use is mainly limited to occasional drinks or reference to drinks, never characters getting drunk or glorifying it.Frightening/Intense Scenes: [2/5] the ships and crew are in mortal danger pretty much all of the time while behind enemy lines, additionally, there are a couple of major battles where things gets hairy, and another scene where a lot of bad decisions are made that negatively affect the fleet, but for the most part, nothing majorly intense.

I loved To Honor You Call Us (Man of War, Book 1) and the sequel did not disappoint me. It started off a little rocky (the somewhat pedantic method used by the author to explain tactics to the reader by having the captain "teach" the doctor gets a little old, fairly quickly -- luckily, the author stops doing that after a few chapters) but then it settled in and more than made up for the rocky start with an excellent amount of interesting and exciting military science fiction.The story takes place mostly in space, aboard space navy vessels -- in particular the Destroyer-class ship captained by Max Robichaux (the protagonist and viewpoint character for the story). Humanity is still deeply involved in a war for survival for the human species. Max is still training his crew, and he and his crew are still forced to deal with insane situations. The battles are interesting and exciting, and the danger always feels real.The universe feels lived-in, but not dirty. Fans of Star Wars and Star Trek should like this series. There are lots of great details about military duty, and there are lots of aspects of the story that are full of honor and duty and brotherhood and camaraderie.There are still a SURPRISING amount of details/conversations/plot points that involve organized religion (specifically the Muslim and Christian ones) -- which still feels out of place to me in a science-fiction story. I can appreciate that the author is trying to teach some people things they may not know, and expose them to ideas of tolerance and inclusion in the best tradition of Gene Roddenberry and his philosophy for Star Trek (amongst other tributes to Star Trek found in the books) -- but it still feels out of place.Overall, if you are looking for a good, clean, entertaining military science fiction story brimming with honor and duty and military details and engagements -- WITHOUT any horrific violence, crimes against women, or other vulgarities that can be found in other stories, then you will like this series.5 stars---------------------------------Book Content Guide For Parents:---------------------------------Sex & Nudity: [0/5] I don't recall any sex of nudity in the book.Violence & Gore: [1/5] almost completely absent -- there is an execution scene in the book of a traitor, who is executed via expulsion from the airlock, and there is space combat where people die, but none of it is described.Profanity: [3.5/5] it is a military novel, OF COURSE it has language in it. It is fairly tame (although I would say a bit stronger than the first book in the series). All of the "big 4" make it in, and some fairly strong additional ones as well. Nothing too terribly graphic or offensive, though (no crude sexual remarks, racial epithets, or hate-speech).Alcohol/Drugs/Smoking: [2/5] I don't recall any smoking. There is a bit of drinking in the story, nothing graphic or glamorized, though -- mostly just sailors having beers occasionally.Frightening/Intense Scenes: [2/5] pretty standard PG/PG-13 action/war movie stuff. Also, the execution scene is pretty intense. There are some military battles, soldiers die, and the protagonist and his crew is in mortal danger more than once. But it is never horrifying or sadistic stuff. None of it bothered me. Much milder than the first book in the series

Listen, if you are not a fan of the Simpsons, then this is just another town building game, and most of the buildings and characters in it won't mean anything to you. This is a game for fans of the Simpsons, pure and simple.I would describe the game as a cross between a town building sim, and an RPG-lite. The game has actual stories and quests/missions, etc. to accomplish, all the while leveling up, which unlocks new characters, new buildings, and new stories!The game is also REGULARLY updated (at least every 2 to 3 weeks) with new content that is either:-a new level-a special event based around a real or Simpsons-universe holiday-a new episode tie-inMost of the special event updates for the major holidays, are HUGE, with TONS of stuff to do (Halloween and Christmas are the biggest).The game *IS* a freemium/free-to-play (f2p) game, which is kind of a bummer. BUT, of all of the f2p games I have played, THIS ONE does it right! You can play the WHOLE GAME, unrestricted, and have a GOOD TIME doing so, FOR FREE -- no strings attached.  Seriously.  I have been playing since they released the game to the Android platform in June of 2013, and I haven't stopped since. This was the first game to really hook me since the original Plants Vs. Zombies game hooked me, and it has managed to keep me hooked far longer than that game did.The way that Tapped Out makes money, is by generating unique content that costs the in-game premium currency that costs real world money, that are ACTUALLY WORTH THE COST (a shocking idea, I know). The content can range from fan-favorite characters that won't unlock unless you buy them (often times originally free during an event, to win, before becoming premium content), to special/cool buildings and decorations, and sometimes limited time characters or event tie-ins. You can also use the premium currency to rush the completion of tasks and building, but in my opinion that is a waste of money.I view the game like a standard MMORPG game, and budget according to the assumption of $15/month subscription fee. I don't buy nearly as much as some of the players do, but of all of the f2p games I have paid, THIS ONE (even if it wasn't a Simpsons game) makes me want to reward the developers for their efforts. (Listen, I am as shocked as you are that EA managed to not screw up a game so badly that I want nothing to do with it. I don't know what to tell you, it is a GOOD game)Yes, the game has bugs (constantly), but what MMORPG doesn't have bugs?I hope that Star Wars/Star Trek/Lord of the Rings and other fan-favorite properties follow the example The Simpsons: Tapped Out is setting, and create similar games, of similar quality.5 stars!

This game is a decent mobile MMORPG-lite game (you MUST be online to play, and you play against other players).Unlike Spartan Wars: Empire of Honor, which I hated, and which was no fun, because the other players tear new players apart pretty much immediately, THIS game gives new players a chance to breathe, and to get their feet under them.The Hobbit game AUTOMATICALLY protects all new player for 7 real-time days, and also allows players to build vaults in their towns to protect a certain minimum percent of their resources from other players, and The Hobbit game regularly lets players win items that will protect their towns for a certain period of time, all for free. That makes The Hobbit game playable enough for new players, that even if other players are picking on them, they can still soldier on and build up their town, and eventually even get even with those who picked on them, if they want -- ALL without having to spend any money to do so.In contrast, Spartan Wars throws you to the wolves, IMMEDIATELY. That means that the other players are free to attack you, and take ALL of your resources, relentlessly, while you, somehow, try to build up your city. It is impossible unless you pay, or join a powerful enough alliance that will protect you long enough so you can get your feet under you. So, unless you pay them for magical protections/etc. in the game, you pretty much have NO CHANCE of surviving the game.The Middle Earth tie-ins for this game provide a pleasant atmosphere for the game to take place. It is basically a real-time, card-type/power-type, strategy game. It is similar to an RTS, except you cannot control how your armies fight, or your base defenses fight.Make no mistake, though, this game IS a Player vs. Player (PvP) game, and you WILL be attacked. That, essentially, is the whole game, after all. In the early stages, it will be all about leveling up, and unlocking more powerful units and resource buildings. Then, in the later stages it will be about building up your armies, and getting even for what was done to you earlier ^_^You can join a guild/alliance if you want, but that is WAY too much work for me. I would rather just soldier on alone, and survive or fail on my own. I like this game enough, and have had enough fun with it, that I have bought their premium currency a couple of times, and used it to help speed myself down the path to revenge.4 stars

This game, like The Hobbit: Kingdoms of Middle-earth is an MMORPG-lite game. You MUST be online to play, and the gameplay is in a PvP world populated with other players.HOWEVER, unlike in The Hobbit game, this game throws you to the wolves, IMMEDIATELY. That means that the other players are free to attack you, and take ALL of your resources, relentlessly, while you, somehow, try to build up your city. It is impossible unless you pay, or join a powerful enough alliance that will protect you long enough so you can get your feet under you. So, unless you pay them for magical protections/etc. in the game, you pretty much have NO CHANCE of surviving the game. The WORST kind of PvP anarchy and brutality is on full display in this "game," and the trolls populating it are welcome to it.In contrast, The Hobbit game AUTOMATICALLY protects all new player for 7 real-time days, and also allows players to build vaults in their towns to protect a certain minimum percent of their resources of other players, and The Hobbit game regularly lets players win items that will protect their towns for a certain period of time, all for free. That makes The Hobbit game playable enough for new players, that even if other players are picking on them, they can still soldier on and build up their town, and eventually even get even with those who picked on them, if they want -- ALL without having to spend any money to do so.I played for 3 days, and during that time my little, puny town with barely any resources at all, was attacked at least hourly from every neighbor within a 2-screen radius of where my town was. It was almost hilarious how badly they picked on new players. I tried to soldier on and hoped that the game would provide SOME mechanic to alleviate the brutal player abuse in the game -- but there was nothing. So, I ended up using the various game pieces I had to destroy all of my resource generating building, and then I deleted the game. They can pick at the empty bones of my town until they realize I'm never coming back, and give up. I would have just deleted my town, but I couldn't find a way to do that.All of this is because of the insane business model this game, and many like it, are using. If they were charging a fee up-front, then their business would revolve around keeping paying customers happy. If that was the business model they were using, then I guarantee you that there would be game mechanics in place to allow new players to get their feet under them, before being thrown to the wolves. But, their game mechanic is to pretend that the game is free, but in order to get you to pay, they have hobbled the game to such a degree, that it is mostly unplayable unless you pay them, or you are willing to endure an INSANELY long wait time to build up resources, and your armies, while having everything constantly stolen from you by players oftentimes barely more powerful than you are, perpetuating a vicious cycle for those who stick it out long enough to become strong enough to attack other players.The game is zero fun, so I rate it 0 stars (but I gave it 1 star, because Amazon made me).

This game is for fans of the Muppets, ONLY.There isn't a lot to do in the game. Basically, you clear stages for Muppets to perform. The Muppets perform a rhythm/scat/beatbox/a Capella song on each stage, each Muppet adding their own part to the song, usually by just making some sort of noise, occasionally actually singing.You earn money automatically from each Muppet, and they earn more if they are happier, and of a higher level. You level them up by using the money to buy food.That's about it, that's the whole game.You can use in-game money to buy additional set pieces and decorations for the Muppets and the stages, and you can also use in-game money to buy some of the Muppets for each stage. For the rest of the Muppets, it is trivial to get them from "Harv-E" the robot that you can use to generate the Muppets by basically trying to "win" them in a gambling setup. For each stage, though, there are always a few Muppets that are very hard to get that way. The idea being that you will get impatient and spend diamonds to get them (the premium currency for this "free" app). However, it has been my experience that almost every Muppet is winnable if you are just patient enough to keep trying the free way. The exception is limited-time Muppets, who are almost impossible to win in the given time frame. But, meh, there isn't enough GAME in this game to justify me spending any money on it. There is ZERO story line, and ZERO to do, besides level up the Muppets, and buy stuff for their stage. That's it, that is all there is to do.Like I said, this is a decent time waster to have on your phone while waiting in line at a grocery store or something, but I wouldn't pay any money for this. If they want to get money out of me, first of all, just charge me up-front, and secondly, provide content WORTH money. Not costumes and characters, or eliminating arbitrary wait times. Provide story lines, and expansion packs with new lands/levels/etc. THEN I will be happy to shell out some $$$ for you.4 stars (for fans of the Muppets, 2 stars for everyone else).

This Bocce kit is fun. The idea of "glow in the dark" Bocce is great.However, there are a few things that really lessen the fun:1. One of the balls was almost out of light the moment we turned it on2. Maybe the blues were made in different batches, but they're a little different from each other.3. The light for the pallino is too bright. I shines through making a bright white spotThis could be a lot of fun if you're just trying to get your family introduced to Bocce for the first time.The balls actually feel heavier than I expected. Are you going to use them in a pro match? No (but that'd be cool).The lighting is great, they glow well except for as mentioned about the pallino. The white spot on it is so bright, we don't even want to look at it.It really is a shame that the balls aren't completely round. They bulge where the battery access is located. Rolling one of the balls, we can see it rolling unevenly. Seems like something that wouldn't be hard to have gotten right from the start if they had done testing, or maybe their process is off, and will hopefully fix it. I'd love to give it more stars because it is fun to play, the the quality problems mentioned drop it to three stars.

The problem with V-necks is that sometimes the neck is just too wide. This Oxford shirt fits great, and the V-neck isn't to wide/low.The yoke of the shirt (if that's what it's called along the back of the neck), is designed well, giving a great fit in the shoulder area.The material isn't a thick as I would have liked, but overall, it's pretty good.It's Oxford, but doesn't have the Oxford logo embroidered on it like the polo shirts do.

Looking at some of the manufacturer responses, this supplement uses the ubiquinone form. A little bit of research on the good ol' information super highway shows that your body can make use of both types of CoQ10 (ubiquinone and ubiquinol).Which one is faster absorbed? Hard to say. The Viva labs has the black pepper extract which is to help absorption.Noticeable results? I haven't noticed any increase in energy. Does that mean the supplement doesn't work? I don' think so, there are many factors that can affect energy levels, and isolating one can be hard. However, the benefits of CoQ10 have been shown to be multiple, and is a top recommended supplement to take.

We've tried other hand protection lotions, and they ended up being very greasy, almost like slathering vasaline all over your hands.The Excipial is non-greasy, absorbs easily into the skin and works great keeping hands smooth.This formula is designed for an evening application before bed. Apparently, there's a day version as well, but we've used it both day and night.The ingredients seem okay, didn't notice any of the standard harmful chemicals.Overall, a great hand cream for those with dry skin.

This is a great idea for a good snack or meal on the go. Who would have ever thought about making a salad as portable as granola bar (well, a big granola bar at least).The bottle is made from a hard plastic, and the top unscrews to reveal a compartment under the lid for housing dressing (or house dressing :).Make sure that underside lid is good and tight, but not too tight to hurt the rubber washing ring inside that helps in making a seal.The only thing about the product is that the jar is deep, so you'll need a long fork to get your salad out of there when on the go.

The supplement seems to be good.If you compare it to Krill Oil by MegaRed, the Kril has only 50mg of EPA, and 24mg of DHA.This supplement has 100mg of EPA, and 480mg of DHA.The funny thing is that in "Other ingredients", Vitamin E, and Vitamin D3 are listed, but it doesn't tell you in the nutritional facts how much.Is it 100% of Vitamin D3 or 2% the RDA?The Costco Wild Alaskan Fish Oil in addition to the oil has 18% RDA of Vitamin E as well as 8% of Vitamin D3.Perhaps these other vitamins are helpful for absorption, but I hope they update the label to tell us how much D3 and Vitamin E are included in the Viva Labs supplement.

It's a good fit, and a basic cotton polo shirt. I'm surprised that it's 40% polyester. It seemed to have the feel of a higher cotton content (polyester making it more smooth and silky), this shirt feels like it could be 100% cotton.I like more of a cotton/poly blend, but it works.It's oxford, so yes, there is a tiny ox logo embroidered over the left breast.All in all, a good polo shirt.

Love the features on this speaker: -- The port that can be used as a backup charger for a phone is very handy. -- The auto-shut-off when not in use to protect the battery life. -- The design and the built-in carrying handle -- The large buttonsSome things that need improvement -- It had, and still has some difficulty connecting to my macbook pro -- The power light is colored white, and when turned on, it glows a soft white. This can be confusing during the day to see if you've left it on or not -- The bluetooth indicator is a bright blue right within the speaker top. It's a little annoying. It would be better placed with the buttons -- The sound is good, but not great. Comparing to the Sony SRS-X7, I almost like the Sony better for it's sound. Standing further away from it, it's okay, but when up close, I notice a difference from the Sony, hard to explain, but the Sony seemed better balanced between the high, mid and low tones -- It's large (that's not a bad thing per se, just a surprise when I got it, so be prepared for it to take up some spaceWith that said, the plus outweigh the minuses. I've been very pleased with it, and have used it over the Sony speaker because the battery life is so great, and it's a lot easier to carry around. The included audio cable is nice as well.All in all, it's a great speaker.
