We've used Magnesium Oxide with Zinc in the past as a magnesium supplement. It did have a slight laxative effect if you took all three tablets.I've heard that different magnesium variations get absorbed to varying degrees by the body, so I was excited to test the Magnesium by Viva labs.The first thing of note is that the tablets are large and the serving size is two. The odd thing is that these are about four times as large as the tablets we currently had and the daily percent value is halved. These give you only 50% of the RDA. That could be because it's absorbed much more readily, but it's odd.It has been recommended by other sources online (I know, I know), but this type of Magnesium seems to be rated at really being absorbed better by the body.Didn't notice any side effects with with this, so it seems good. The only thing is the size of the tablets in relation to the 50% RDA they deliver.

I'm comparing this case against the Spiegen Capsule case which has a very similar appearance (a clear case for the iPhone 6s).-- Size ---The first thing I noticed about the Speck case is that it is bulky. Compared to the Spiegen, it's a couple milimeters thicker.This can be a good thing for drop protection, but a couple mm make a huge difference in how big the case feels. It's really noticeable how much the case extends up past the glass.This is one of their selling points as it's supposed to help protect the glass if the iPhone is dropped and lands glass side down on a flat surface.-- Tacky Buttons --The volume buttons on the Speck are tacky, not in a fashion or appearance sense, but in actual feel. The plastic is slightly sticky, and it does not feel good.The Spiegen case buttons are not as soft and are easier to push feeling more like a natural extension of the phone.-- The product branding --One thing about a clear case is that it's meant to disappear to the eye and showcase the beauty of an expensive phone.However, the Speck case has a logo mark and lettering that's a couple inches long right on the back of the case and actually over the Apple logo.That is tacky in the fashion sense of the word.The other element that just doesn't make sense is that the Speck website address is imprinted under the volume buttons and it's backwards.Yep. You need a mirror to read it. It's also tacky again as it's right on the volume buttons. We don't really need to see the huge Speck logo, and the Speck website to know that this is a Speck case.-- Overall Case Feel --The back of the case is a hard plastic which makes it slippery. It can slip in and out of pockets okay, but it can also slip in cars and on dashes.The Spiegen case I have has just a tiny amount of grip to it making it not slide as easy.-- Military Grade --I didn't know that there were military standards for drop a phone. I'd like to see more about those claims since the case marketing material really pushes it.-- Who is this case for? ---If you consistently drop your phone, you may want to look at this case. If you just want some good protection, the Spiegen is the winner at half the price, and no, I don't work for Spiegen, I've just found theirs is a better case.

So many factors go into your health, it can be hard to isolate something and say, this really helps.With this supplement, that's how it feels. It seems to help, but it's not a huge difference.Your mileage may very. We haven't experienced and adverse effects using the supplement, and that's good.As far as this supplement goes, it seems like it helps. That may be all in our heads (literally), but it does seem to help a little to reduce stress.

We discovered that our previous vitamin D3 supplement (Kirkland brand) contains Soybean oil, corn oil, and caramel (ooh yum) for coloring.The Viva labs contains extra-virgin olive oil as the oil base, so that's a big plus for the Viva Labs version.This supplement also has 5,000 IU of D3 whereas our previous D3 had only 2,000 IU.All in all, seems like a good supplement. Hard to tell if it makes any difference, but in the winter months, when we don't get as much vitamin D from the Sun, it's a great supplement to have.

The color matches the Rose Gold phone great.It fits the iPhone 6S just fine, just follow the instructions putting the soft plastic part first, then the harder side shell starting in the bottom then working the case around the top.It does add some bulk and weight to the iPhone.The buttons work really well.The only thing that's a little bit of a bother is that the silence button/switch is a little hard to get to because the case is thick.

We've used other body measurement scales, and we like this iHealth, but results may vary...literally.The body fat percentage shows about 5% higher than another scale we tested. Which one is right?The one that give the lower reading of course!Seriously though, the scale gave a higher percentage, and that may be more accurate, but the scale isn't consistent. The body fat percentage can vary 2% or more from day to day, and it varies throughout the day. From our other scales we've tried, it's clear that different times of day can produce different results based on the amount of water you've drunk, etc. However our other scale varies only about 1% and is much more consistent reading to reading.Even testing against another iHealth scale (different version), the iHealth is different by a pound than it's own sister scale (or brother scale, you choose).The thing that saves it is the Wifi connection. You con't have to have your phone on or paired to the scale. Just stand on it, and the results are uploaded to the iHealth website, and then back to your phone through the app.However, it's really annoying to have to download an app, and it makes you create an account where you have to give up birthdate information, especially with this app/website that tracks your weight, body fat %, lean muscle mass, bone weight, BMI, and body water %.iHealth hasn't done the best job with it's apps. It's current incarnation is a lot better than the past, but for some reason instead of updating their app, they created a version 2.0 that we had to download, then they had a popup saying not to use that app, but to go back to the main app which had then been updated.Doesn't instill the best of confidence for a company that is storing your personal health information on their servers.It would be nice to know how well the company is protecting our data (encryption of this data is a must).Anyway, I give it 4 stars (borderline 3.5) because of once it's all set up and working, it works.

These jeans are a great fit after being washed and broken in a bit.They weren't the most comfortable right out of the box, but after being worn about, they felt a lot better.They fit well and are built wrangler tough.For some reason, I always picture Wranglers with a big 'W' on the back of the pocket, but these don't have that. There's just a tag on the back belt line.Great jeans.

I'm moderately familiar with the research on Glucosamine, Chondroitin, and MSM.We've had one doctor recommend all three of these as supplements, so were were excited to try this.It may be benefiting, it really may, but I don't feel any improvement, and to earn a good rating, I should feel something.Of course, after taking it for some time, I looked at the directions and it states to take two, and I've only been taking one. Shame on me, I'm going to go for two and see how things go.These are rather large capsules, and when you take a number of supplements, it can get overwhelming, so I try not to overdo it.So, the jury is still out, and I'll continue to try it, perhaps with time and adding one more, things will get better.The thing is that they say Guaranteed in their product title (as of this writing). That's a little pretentious to put into the title.

Not being a huge watch connoisseur, it took some time to actually figure out how to actually get the thing on.1. The metal extender (fold-over clasp)The watch has a stainless steel extender that connects the two portions of the leather band. This feature allows the the metal clasp holding the pin through the pinhole on the leather strap to always stay in place.It makes for an easier mechanism for removing the watch from your wrist (with practice).TIP: You've really got to pull hard to get the fold-over clasp open. Once you've secured the pin clasp over the leather strap, you can just pull the two straps near where they come together and the fold-over clasp will open.2. The pin clasp (bracket with the pin to secure the band).We really tried to push the leather band through the pin clasp, but the band was way too thick (and so were we).The clasp with the pin also hinges. You'll see "axle" for the hinge on both sides of the clasp. Pull the clasp open, and you'll then be able to slide it over the leather and secure the pin through the adjustment hole on the leather strap that meets your comfort level.Once that is secured, you can use the fold over clasp to remove or secure the watch--just make sure that the leather strap is taken out of both of the leather holding loops.Overall, great watch. The watch casing is a little large, but it is still beautiful.

This is one powerful hair dryer. The force of the air surprised us. The old hair dryer we had was also a Conair.There are a couple of quirks though.1. It's a bit heavier.  Not a big deal, but if you're older or have shoulder/hand/wrist issues, this Conair is weightier and could affect that.2. Control sliders too close  The sliders for the controls are right next to each other. You have a left side and a right side, and it's easy to get mixed up which controls which when you're not looking at them.  When you are looking at them, make sure the hair dryer is off (you may get blasted in the face).Other than that, it's a good hair dryer. Powerful, sleek, and...very purple.

This is the second Norelco I've used, and boy have they come a long way.The shaver is whisper quiet compared to other shavers I've used, and the trimming action is fantastic leaving a much smoother shave than my previous electric shaver.The pivoting head really helps to shave around neck and under the jaw.Plus, the design is sleek and it has a great feel.But...The bulky docking station was a big red flag when I pulled it out of the box. I couldn't believe how huge the thing was.I placed the shaver in the dock and thought when it's time to clean, how is the connector head going to fit over the charging end of the shaver. I did an initial test, and it didn't fit.Great.When it was time to clean, I plugged in the docking base, and tried to get the docks connector to fit over the shavers, and it just wouldn't (and yes, the shaver was pointing the right way).You've got the blades positioned down inside the dock and don't want to hurt them, but I put way too much pressure than should be necessary to get the dock connector over the shaver.The cleaning cycle started, and a minute or so into it, the dock's connector popped up. The manual said that the shaver would charge during the cleaning, so that didn't seem normal.Overall, the shaver is great. The cleaning station is so big and bulky, and are the chemicals cleaning it really better than just a rinse under the sink after each use? Seems like a big waste and waste of space on the counter.I do like that the shaver comes with a traveling case, but my old norelco had a protective cap for the blades, seems like an oversight to miss that in this model.

This is our second Fluxx game. Our first was aimed more at kids, and the rules reflected that.We thought the Batman Fluxx would be the same, but we found the game a little harder than the children's Fluxx although both are based on cartoons.It took us a while to get used to some of the new rules, and the powers the Creepers had, and then it became more fun.We did run into a rule that just simply didn't make sense of it's implications. It just wasn't clear how it could be applied, and it was really frustrating. We all had different opinions on what it meant. I think if they had run the game by a few more people that error could have been caught, and it could have been worded clearly.All in all, it's a fun game. The Batman theme is fun. It's fun to have the creepers be the villains from the show, and their cards and the rules really give the villains some power.

The game had a lot of potential, and there are certainly enough kids interested in frozen to make this game a success, and that's the problem, it's just not that great of a game.Yes, the game is supposed to teach 4-7 year olds,  but to make it a great game, it should appeal to older kids as well.Overall, the game is simplistic, it's just not a lot of fun.This is comparing it to other LeapTV games that we've tried that are fun, that are much more engaging. That's why this one was kind of a let down.Sure the kids played it, but they didn't enjoy it as much as the other games out there that are more challenging and educational.Specifics:Let's get into some of the specifics.The game is made up of mini-games that the kids can select and then play. The games are prefaced by Elsa and Anna talking to each other (this gets repetitive real quick).The ice skating number game has you select the that 5 or 6 numbers should go: 101, 102, etc., the Elsa skates the path. Sorry, but it's embarrassing how dull that game was, and having 101, 102, etc be the numbers for a 4-year-old is not engaging, and it certainly isn't engaging for the older kids.The addition games. The older kids wanted some multiplication, they got bored with the simple addition, but the point is that the game wasn't fun. It's just an equation asking for the answer. Also, on one screen the equation was backwards it had: ? = 3 + 2 rather than 3 + 2 = ?The point being they could have made the math portions fun, it just feels like they took some basic math games and put a Frozen spin on it, when they could have been more creative, and more engaging in the math games.Not sure if it's the game or the LeapTV, but the first time we put in the game, the sound wouldn't work.The graphics were a bit of a disappointment too. The slide game with Olaf was a bit jittery and the game play was way to slow. They should have sped it up a bit, again to make it more fun.No, the kids didn't hate or dislike the game, but as a parent, it's a big disappointment and a big waste of potential.

Wrangler makes me think of jeans and cowboys, not cargo shorts, so I was interested to see these cargo pants by Wrangler wondering if they'd be  cowboy rugged.The shorts are very nice looking they don't look "cowboy" but they're also not thin and delicate. It's the right blend of toughness and style.The waste can be adjusted by an elastic sewn into the waste and can be tightened at the end by buttons on either side of the waste (interior side).The cargo pockets are velcro and one of the cargo pockets has a dark brown square patch with the Wrangler logo. The patch isn't 100% sewn in straight, but it's not a big deal.Very nice shorts that are durable and stylish.

The game has a lot of rules that make startup a bit of a chore.Once you get familiar, the game goes quick, but becomes a little monotonous. It's not as fun as Ticket to Ride. We thought it might be kind of similar to 7 Wonders, but it's not at all.The game play is pretty simple once you get going, play a card, pick a new card.It would be more fun if the lost cities were named in the game, but we didn't find that anywhere. There's not much reason to the researcher vs the adventurer other than the researcher gives double the points.Seems like the game had a lot of potential, but ended up being fairly simple. Not much strategy, and a little bit of luck.However, I give it four stars because the kids liked playing it. It's a good game for 8 years and older and a good introduction to board games allowing them to advance to more difficult games in a similar style later on.

Ramone's Body Paint shop is a good addition to the Cars playset.You can connect it with the other Cars playsets, but I'd be careful about using the water in it anywhere you're concerned about spills.Ramone's was not as easy to put together as the other sets we've tried. Some of the instructions are confusing. Just make sure when applying the hanging hood stickers that the pieces are right side up. It's hard to tell from the instructions. We also left out a piece after having already placed the roof on which was frustrating to get apart and fix.In terms of play, we had trouble getting the car to change. The water in the open container needs to be warm.We got gold water from the tap, and after that didn't work, from the fridge for the sprayer, but that didn't work either.You need to have ice in the water source. So finally getting the ice water, we tried it, and the color of the car is pretty amazing. It comes out bright red. I thought it'd be a little bit of a change, but it's pretty amazing.If you hold the car, it will start to turn yellow again where your fingers touch it. The warmth from your hand will change where you hold to yellow again, but then it fades back to red when you release it.You can dry the car, and it will stay red for about 5 minutes and slowly return to yellow.

I've used phones by BLU before, and this is by far the most elegant of their phones. The feel of the phone easily rivals anything that Samsung has put out there (although the power and volume placements should be positioned higher).The display is high-res, and the software responsive.However, that's where we get to the quirks. They really need more testing, it feels like the software is still in beta.Here are the examples:1. Encryption doesn't workI've tried using the encrypt function multiple times (yes, it's plugged in), and the popup window says it may take about an hour.When I've done this on other Android phones (Other BLU phones even), a notification appears showing the progress of the encryption.Here, it just does nothing. After waiting an hour or so, the "encrypt phone" button is still an option, and it just lets you press it again, but doesn't seem to do anything.2. App icons there, but not installed?This was really weird. After setting up the phone and tying a Google account to it, I tried launching a few of the apps. The icons are there, but the phone said the app wasn't installed. This happened with multiple apps.Really strange. Google play also didn't display any of the apps as being installed. After a short while, the Google play store said I needed to try again to log in. Pressing the retry button did nothing, and not other screen in the Google Play store would work.After restarting the phone, Google Play worked again, and apps finally started to appear as being installed. A glitch, yes, but it doesn't instill much confidence especially with a device that can store personal information.3. "I've Known"This one was funny. One of the confirmation windows appeared when either installing an app or changing a setting and instead of the button stating "I understand" or "Okay", the button text read: "I've Known"So those are some of the quirks, but what keeps it four stars are what it has going for it:1. PriceThe phone is a great deal.2. BatteryThe phone does have good battery life. Although, the reading in the battery stats will often seem out of whack.After a full charge the battery estimator said it only had 8 days left, but a while later, and another full charge, it said it had 30 days.The battery has performed well, and of course, brightness settings, usages, and apps will greatly affect your mileage here.3. Dual Sim cardCould be handy for international travelers with two sim cards.4. The designThe phone feels like a real phone compared to the other two BLU phones we've tried (one a phablet, and not very good, and one a regular phone but with a plastic backing), this phone feels great.5. AccessoriesThe phone comes with a silicone case and a screen protector.I'm not a fan of the screen protectors. I have noticed that the display glass seems to get dirtier easier than an iPhone. Not sure how that works, but I find specks stuck to the glass when I haven't seen that on an iPhone.Overall, it's a pretty good phone if you can get past the quirks.

Adventure Time Fluxx is a pretty good game that takes a little getting used to.This was our first ever Fluxx type game, so we weren't quite sure what to expect but were excited to try something new.The idea centers around that the rules can change as the game progresses.What that means is that instead of drawing one card at the beginning of each turn, a new rule card played could change that to drawing two or three. Likewise, a new rule card may mandate that players play all the cards in their hand each turn.Many more rule cards can change the play of the game.Goal cards determine the requirements for winning the game. So not only the rules can change, but the way a player can win the game.The game is fun, and our family enjoyed playing it. It took a little bit to get used to, and they weren't that much into the Adventure Time theme for the game, but ti was still fun.The description said that basic math is involved, but don't expect this to be a math-based game or instructional game.

These are fun labels that you can incorporate into crafts, gifts or shipping.The wire is a thin gauge and easy to twist. When the top is twisted, it creates a loop thats just big enough for my wrist to fit through (hey new fashion accessory).The tips of the wire are not super sharp, but they could snag on something, so adjust carefully.Wheather you need to mail something to Mordor or Madagascar, these labels add style that can't be ignored.

These post cards are pretty good, but there are few things to watch out for.1. The Print qualityThis isn't so much a problem with the paper, but with the printer/paper combo. If your printer doesn't print graphics well (horizontal lines appearing in solid color blocks), your post cards won't look as professional.Print a test card on some regular paper, or a test graphic before buying these, and you can see if your printer can print to the quality you'd like. Some printers also let you choose the quality (some like to save ink), so there may be a setting to put it on high quality to get a better image.2. The cards say feed one at a time (no mass printing)The cards say to feed one at a time. You'll probably be able to get away with putting them in the tray a few at a time depending on your printer.If you're printer bends the paper too much, you may need to use the front feeder area (on our printer it's one at a time), and this produces less bend.3. Perforated edgesThe cards have perforated edges, but instead of having just one edge all the way around, the bottom and top are perforated twice for some reason.4. QualityThese feel like a post card, but they seem just shy of the thickness of a real post card.Other than that, they're pretty good.

The essential day moisturizer is 0.51 fl ounces. That's a really small container...really small.Just be prepared for that when making your purchase.The lotion has many ingredients listed on the bottle. It's a lot more than just dead sea minerals. In fact, dead sea water is listed in the middle of the list of about 29 ingredients (Glyceryl Stearate, Cetyl Alcohol, Alanine & creatine & Glycerin & Glycine & Magnesium Aspartate & Saccharide Hydrolysate & Urea, Peg-40 Stearate, Parfum, etc. etc.The fragrance to my senses is not pleasant and gave me a headache, and was hard to get rid of.If you're looking for Dead Sea Minerals, just do a quick search on Amazon, and you can find plenty of other masks, lotions, and salts that are not as expensive.

I was very excited to get the smart plug. We'd tried a few wemo products and found them to be difficult to use, bulky and just plain not fun.The iHome smart plug is sleek, small (ish), and held lots of promise.Unfortunately, it's got some issues.First, the positives:1. Sleek design2. Covers only one plug (other devices are so bulky, the cover both plugs on an outlet)3. Sleek design (worth two points)4. Ability to use Siri to control the outletThe problems however are disappointing.First, you have to turn on Keychain (iOS). Maybe that's a HomeKit thing, but keychain had to be turned on, and even after turning on Keychain and checking the privacy settings, the app kept asking to "Continue" with the notice that Keychain had to be turned on and the privacy settings set.Another downside is that although the app shows "Usage" (when the devices have been turned on or off), that's it. It would be great to have the option to know how much power is being consumed. Other competing devices offer this feature.The app requires you to create an iHome account which I wish wasn't necessary, just one more step to getting started.There are no instructions that come with the device other than a quick start guide. It would be better if there were some instructions describing what rules are (maybe they should be called schedules).Siri can recognize commands and turn off the outlet, but there isn't a user guide that says what sort of things you can say.You can turn off an outlet or if you have it as part of a "room" in the app, you can turn off the smart outlets in the room.However, if you picked a name for the outlet that Siri has a hard time understanding, then you'll find yourself repeating the command. If you go to change the name of the device, you may get error after error like I did which was frustrating.By far the best feature is the ability to use Siri to turn off the outlet. Just make sure to pick a name for it that's easy for Siri to pick up exactly.Hopefully, in future versions of the app, these bugs will be cleared up. It works reliably with voice command, so if you can get past the other bugs, and are patient, it could work for you.

Blackout is an interesting read. What would happen if teens were infected by a virus that gave them powers. (Minor spoilers ahead) The wrinkle is that there are teens who have been trained as terrorists and using their power to wreck havoc.The book keeps you reading, and the chapters are short which helps with the pacing.I did have trouble with the believability of the military personnel. Some of the dialog they were given just didn't seem real. It also stretched believability that teens, all teens, would be rounded up to testing facilities hundreds of miles from their homes without a major fuss from the populous. It was a convenient way to get the characters together, but I had a tough time swallowing it.The other challenge to believability was how the roundup was handled by the military and how the teens were treated.The powers that the kids had were interesting. Some of them were random and fun such as the ability to not miss a basketball shot, or to wither plants, or count stuff really fast.So, if you can get past some of the believability issues of the roundup and the testing of the kids, it's a fun read, and definitely will keep you wanting to know what happens next.

The mouse is cool and sleek, but unfortunately, it's just not comfortable. If you have carpel tunnel issues, this mouse probably won't feel good.Otherwise, the mouse had a lot going for it. The click action is solid, and it twists to have a flatter form factor for traveling, and the construction feels solid, but when it's something that you'll use everyday and doesn't feel good on your palm and wrist, then that's a problem.Perhaps if you have larger hands, it would work better for you.The other drawback is that the scroll bar is inconsistent. A wheel works much better.

This is a great necklace, and the pendant is heavier than I expected. It's quite thick and not reversible.The square cut diamonds in the bottom right and top left are interesting. The square cuts don't have the silver division between the diamonds (Pave Setting), and so the beauty of those diamonds meshes together and isn't as defined as the round-cut.Still, it's a very beautiful pendant and necklace. The chain seems thin and small compared to the large pendant.All in all, it's a great necklace.

These headphones looked so strange, they had to be good right?Why go to the trouble of such a different design to have the quality not measure up?Well, that's what's happened with this headphones.The standard headphones that come with the iPhone provide 3x's better base, fit better, and don't look so goofy.The headphones come with different sizes for the plug cover, but even on the smallest size, the bulk of the headphone weighs it down making it fall out easily.The treble sounds somewhat tinny, and the base is almost nonexistent compared to the iPhone headphones.The name indicates that these are about "clarity." And yes, things are clear, but it's not "better sound." Better sound means better across the entire range.So, if you're looking to listen to music, these aren't the best choice.The cables are flat and a little unwieldy.It's also difficult to tell which is the right vs left ear bud.I really thought these would be fantastic because of the design supposedly making the sound better, but alas they come up lacking in many regards.

This was my first Shannara book. It seems like somewhere I read that you didn't have to read the other books to read this one.Well...the first chapter proved that wrong. There was quite a bit going on that seemed to have greater meaning if you had read the previous books.The first chapter also seemed slow to me, but then things picked up when we get to Reyn. I found Reyn's storyline to be the most interesting.There is quite a bit of point of view changes in the story and even many in different chapters, sometimes that made it hard to keep track who's POV we're in and ended up being a little jarring.The book kept me reading to the end, and was interesting, but I probably would have gotten much more out of it had I started with earlier Shannara novels.So if this is your first go at the Shannara books, give a thought to starting at the beginning of the series. I've heard that Mr. Brooks' Genesis Shannara books are a good place to start as well.

So, we have some smaller windows that this could cover, but our first attempt at applying the film was laughble.Here are some tips.Make sure you have a ruler to cut a straight line. There aren't guides on the film backing, and our cuts weren't straight.If the cut is not straight, it's quite easy to see when applied that something is off with the window.Our first application somehow had creases in it that would not come out, and the window looks like it has cracks in it.Every little seem and bubble has to be smoothed out, but if there's a crease/bend in the film before applying, you might not be able to get it out.Also, just FYI, there are instructions that come with this. They're hidden inside the tube. We didn't discover it until after we had applied it.

These are good gummy vitamins...like too good, but that's another story.They're prenatal, but are good as a regular vitamin as well. It's nice that the gummies have omega-3's in them.There's 8 grams of sugar per serving. That's something to think about. In fact after eating two together, it gave me a little bit of a sugar headache.The gummies are still good, just spread out the servings throughout the day. But that's another thing.6 gummies are one serving. That's a whole lot of gummies.Overall, they're good gummies, just be aware that it's 8 grams of sugar.

Three-ply definitely is in the "ultra" category of toilet paper.The paper is soft just like you would expect. If you've never used three-ply before, it's quite a change.The packaging is different compared to other bulk packaging of toilet paper we've seen. All the rolls are packaged in a single plastic wrapping (seen in the photo). Other bulk paper is usually packaged like this but also two-stacked rows are packaged together. The addition of the inner packs makes it easier to take to different bathrooms. That's really the only downside of this paper.

A hula hoop that can count? Now that's a good idea.Unfortunately, it doesn't work very well. In fact, we had a lot of trouble with it.The hoop has to be assembled, and when assembled, the hoop isn't firm. You can feel the bend in the joints. A real hoop is much easier to hula.It might be worth it if the counter works, but it's not accurate at all. It over counts, then under counts. It has a little button that hits against you when the hoop cycles and it changes the counter (which is a simple analog counter).The counter mechanism is huge and adds quit a bit of weight to the hoop. Each member in our family that tried it commented on how it didn't count right. Also the heavy counter hurts if it hits you on the ankle or foot when the hoop falls.If you want to count hoops, get a regular hoop and count in your head. We had hoped this would be fun, but unfortunately, it wasn't.
This is a great starter for someone wanting to get into Dr. Who.It's based loosely on Dicken's Christmas carol and has many delightful moments.You don't have to be a Dr. Who fan to enjoy it.

Good to know that they still make VGA cables. This cable feels high quality and has gold plated connectors. The cable is sturdy, but still bendable. The only thing about it that may make it hard to use for some connection needs is that that the connector heads are quite large. The actual VGA connector is standard sized, but the housing around it for gripping seems twice as long as a run-of-the-mill VGA cable. Some monitors have a tight space for the VGA cable head as it is, so that's the only downside as it could be difficult to use in those situations. The monitor we have is like that, but the cable still fits in the space, just not as easily as the shorter head cables.

This little adapter mount is great and not only works for GoPro models, but also other cameras (The Sony HDR-AS200VR/W, in it's case).The only reason it's 4 not 5 stars is that the adapter isn't gold colored, it's silver colored. Not a big deal, but it doesn't match the current picture (as of this review).The mount is sturdy enough, and works well on the GoPro stick.

We've used onlinelabels previously but have found that the label doesn't adhere to a box as well as these Avery labels. They stick very well. The corners of the label are also rounded which create less of an edge that can catch on things.The paper actually seems just a little thinner than the onlinelabels we've used, but it seems to adhere better. We had no issues printing on them.

This booster is big, a lot bigger than the previous Graco booster we were using.The problem with the Graco is that it didn't offer much back support. It looked like our child was sitting straight up against a wall. Not comfortable at all.This booster seems much more comfortable for our child. He likes it, and it offers a better sitting position.The head guards/rests on this are huge but offer better support for napping. The head rest extends vertically to an almost ridiculous amount. If your child is close to NBA height, the booster will extend to meet his/her height. It's crazy.The sides (wing tips) expand out as well. This is a little more confusing. If a child has extremely broad shoulders, then you might want to expand the wing tips, but it seems like if that's necessary (or to fully raise the head rest), a child would be big enough to not need the backing of the booster.The backing can be removed and the base used only.The one confusing thing was finding the seatbelt guide. It's hidden on the headrest and obscured by the wing tips.Great booster. Our little tyke loves it, and was able to fall asleep in it looking much more comfortable than the Graco.

The premise of the game is fun, helping to make guests (various people on the guest cards) happy by serving them desserts that they like.At first, I was skeptical, I thought it would be hokey, but it wasn't.We played with the max number of people, and each thought it was a fun game (for adults and kids). The fun thing is that the game is about helping the guests get what they want instead of a game where you get only what you want. It's a fun spin and a good undertone to the game, but again, it's not all kittens and rainbows, you're definitely motivated to win, it's just that win comes by helping people. Fun idea.The game isn't overly complicated. The one thing is that playing with 5 people, we ran out of new guests before the game was up. There were still some in the to-be-served area. It might have been possible for the cards to be all used up without a winner, although the chances would be slim at that, it seemed like a possibility.I do like that there is an advanced way to play the game to keep it interested.All in all, fun game.

The pendant is a silver heart with a smaller heart (the one with the decoration) inside.The inner heart rotates and the opposite side has the word "MOM" inscribed in a non cursive script (looks like the Arial font, plain, just like: MOM). As of this review only one picture is listed for the item. Hopefully, they'll post another so you can see the reverse side of the inner pendant.For an idea for the size:The pendant looks great with a great luster to it. The heart itself is about .75 inches tall and about an inch if you add the clasp at the top.This would make a great gift from a child to his or her mom.It comes in a nice pull-away top box. The only issue was that after opening the box, we discovered the necklace and pendant bunched up at the bottom of the box. There's the inner display holder, but they should do a better job at getting the pendant to display correctly after it's been tossed about in the shipping process. Presentation can be everything with jewelry, so make sure to open before gifting it and making the pendant presentable in it's box. I've seen other boxes that do a much better job at keeping the necklace and pendant in place. Maybe that's something they can work on.Overall, great pendant and necklace.

There's some things to love about this camera pack, and there's a number of things that are in a word: goofy.I'm rounding a 3.5 star review up to 4. If you're wondering between this and a GoPro, there are a few things to consider as well.----------- Form Factor -------------The Sony looks like a miniature video camera device compared to the GoPro which looks like a little cube.The problem is that the cube approach is so much more practical for an outdoor adventure camera.  -- Head Mounting --A GoPro can be mounted with straps to your head. Yes, it looks goofy, but it works. The Sony however has to be strapped ***to the side of your head.***I'm not sure they thought this through. The lens can achieve 170 degree viewing. You're getting the side of your head in the picture, and the head strap is extremely uncomfortable, not to mention the camera feels like it's going to flop off the side of your head.Where can the head mount work? If it's attached to a helmet, you avoid the uncomfortable feel of the head band. -- Hand Held --Because the design is long, it offers a good area for you to grip when hand holding, however, it's harder to keep level than a cube design (GoPro). Just imagine holding your phone like you normally would for a video, the rectangular shape make it easy to line up almost subconsciously to produce a level video. The way you hold it with your palm facing away from you also helps.Now imagine turning your phone so the longest edge points away from you. All of a sudden, it's much harder to keep it level. You're wrist also feels much more unnatural.That's what it's like holding this camera because of the long form factor, it's harder to keep the video level and it doesn't feel good on the wrist compared with a handheld filming from a phone or a GoPro. -- Mounted --The above problem goes away if you purchase the separate video pole/mount, but there's a little issue with the mount built into the camera. It's not the standard size tripod/camera mount. It's smaller. You have to use an adapter (included) to mount on a standard sized mount. This is definitely one of those goofy things that should have been fixed. The waterproof case (included) does have the larger mount size. Why not just make both the same instead of requiring a goofy (there it is again) adapter? -- Buttons and Access --The form factor makes the hdmi and usb ports accessible on the bottom of the device, they're really hard to get open if you've just cut your fingernails. Just FYI.It comes with the mini/micro USB cable, but it would have been more handy to have it come with the mini HDMI cord as those aren't as common to have around.The micro SD card is accessed through the back, and it's not clear which way the micro SD card should enter. I have a hard time remembering.----------- Accessories ------------- The Water Proof Case --The included Water Proof case is great. Except around the controls, there's lots of nooks that take a long time to dry out. Even after a day of drying out, we're still getting water drops out of the nooks.The side buttons on the case are not easy to press. They should have been made bigger.The case lets through audio okay. It's a little muffled, but audio in underwater recording we did came out very well, and the sound is dampened a bit when recording out of the water with the case on. -- Live View Wrist Band --Wow. Get ready to strap a TV to your wrist. This think is bulky.You can use the app on your phone to achieve pretty much the same thing, and we've used that much more than the live view wrist band.If this were sleek, it would make the whole package worth it, but unfortunately, it's not. It's giant and awkward.-- The clips --The clips are difficult to work. Because of the form factor, you have to use these funny clips to side mount the camera. It's a ton of extra bulk that could have been fixed if the camera were just a cube, and you could front mount it easier.----------- Software -----------They really needed to work on the menus for this puppy. Just figuring out how to turn it off was a problem the first time we used it. It's not intuitive, and that counts for a lot. The options between the video types and slow motion are also not very clear.Along with the software is the app that you can download. The app worked fine, and you can transfer videos straight to your phone. That's really handy and big plus. The app still has some quirks, but it's better than the wrist viewer.-------So far, things aren't looking so good for the Sony. Its shape is not a good choice. GoPro wins there. The case, clips, and that bulky wrist weight, leave much to be desired.So why 4 stars????----------- The Quality of the Video -----------This is where the camera shines. Perhaps, let's hope anyway this is the reason, the form factor allowed for better video, a better lens and digital sensor.The 170 wide angle view is fantastic, and the picture is clear, clean, and crisp.I've seen too many low quality GoPro videos (older/less expensive models, the new/higher end ones will rival this for sure). It's nice to seem some high quality video out of this device.If you enable the image stabilization (recommended if you're walking with it without a steady cam), you lose the full 170 degrees as it uses the constricted space for the stabilization. It goes down to 120 degrees. The stabilized video is good. On other cameras with similar stabilization, it comes through a little too obvious and almost like you're walking on a ship that's moving up and down with the waves. The stabilization here feels much more natural.The Slow Motion video is really good as well, however, those menus make it harder than it should be. Note to the programers, do more user testing, and make the menu and terminology clear.So, if you're okay with all the goofy things with this camera and its accessories, you'll enjoy the quality of the finished video. I'd recommend getting the--- Update 6/15/2015  ---One thing that we've noticed that has been a drawback is that when you take pictures after getting the camera wet, there can be a water drop on the bulbous lens. The drop distorts the picture.It's unfortunate. Maybe it's because the lens area of the case is so big that it just offers a larger area for drops to appear.So just be warned that when talking pictures after the camera has gotten wet to make sure there's not a big drop on the lens.You'd think the drop would go away quick, but it doesn't you need to wipe it off.Sometimes the drops are there after getting it wet, and sometimes they're not, but since you can't review the pictures until you've connected to your computer/phone, or remove viewing device, it really is disappointing to see picture after picture was distorted due to water drops on the case.Because the GoPros generally have a smaller lens bulb area, they may not be as prone to this problem. Something to consider when making your purchase.

This is a good Pack N' Play with a few things needing improvements:-- Portability --One of the main selling points of this Pack N' Play is that it is portable. It's made smaller than other playards which makes it easier to haul around. The bag has shoulder straps so you can carry it if you're going to head outside with it.The main pad is well cushioned and feels like it may be made of memory foam or at least a high quality foam.-- The Shade --The portability of the playard will make it more likely that you'll end up taking it with you places because it's easier to carry, so compared to other playards, you may actually use it outside a lot, and thus need to use the shade.We had a few issues with the shade. The snaps on the shade cover are hard to attach. It seems like any snaps that size are always hard. Maybe it's just us, and if they could come off easily, that would be bad, but nevertheless, they're tougher to snap than they should be.The cover is great for creating shade, but it does obstruct your view. The playard is ventilated on the sides, but use common sense if it's in full sun, it's going to get hot in there for your infant so be careful.Also, the way our's came packaged, the shade was formed in a U shape over the Pack N' Play, but the U shape was backwards. It made it seem like it was pre-bent or molded into the U shape, but when we went to assemble, we thought was it made backwards? We just had it bend it the other way and the latches fit like they were supposed to.-- The size --The playard is smaller than your normal sized Pack N' Play, so a standard pad cover isn't going to work very well.The smaller size is a much tighter fit for older toddlers.-- Changing Pad --The changing pad that attaches is a nice addition and very handy.-- The Bassinet --It's easy to zipper-in the bassinet. That's a plus for sure. You use the same pad on the bottom and insert the sides into sleeves hooked on the bassinet. The instructions weren't clear because they show if you see the warning imprint, the bassinet hasn't been set up right.Problem: There are warning signs all over it. If you squint you can see in the instructions which warning sign they're talking about and it's not the warning sign on the sleeves which are not covered up.It was confusing, so just be aware of that.-- Overall ---Overall, a good playard. You'll find it very handy for trips. The lighter weight and shoulder straps make it very handy.

It's surprising how will the Powerline 1200 works. There are a few things that could be improved, but setup was fairly easy, and we tested it in a number of locations and setups, and it worked with good speed each time.First thing to remember is that if your internet provider gives you slow speeds, or your main router is slow, this won't make your internet faster. However, there are lots of good reasons to use the powerline1. Avoiding Wifi InterferenceIf your neighbors have all set up wifi, there's the chance they're using the same frequency an channel setup which can interfere with your wifi router's signal. The Powerline can come in really handy in this case as you can connect your device anywhere in your home that has a plug and bypass the wireless interference.2. For better in-network streamingIf you have a media server and want higher speeds than your wifi can deliver, you can connect this to your television for faster streaming from your server. Also if you use NAS or network storage, you can get faster transfer speeds than many wifi routers provide. Again, it all depends on where the bottlenecks in your network are. Having a large distribution pipe on one end won't increase the speed if there's a bottle neck somewhere in the line (slow router, slow hard-drive/sever speeds).3. Extending coverageYes, you can buy wifi extenders for your network, but if you really don't need wifi in a particular area and just need a wired connection, this can work great.Probably many more use cases (presentations where the wifi isn't reliable, etc), but on to how well it actually works.--- Connection ----We tested it in multiple outlets in our home, and the signal was always strong. The connection lit up green each time indicating a good signal, and the speed seemed just as good as the wifi connection when we disabled the one and switched back and forth to see if there was a noticeable difference.--- Surge Protectors ---The documentation says to plug it straight into the wall, but we tested both that way, and having one of them plugged into a surge protector. It took just a little longer it seems like to make the connection in that case, but after that, the connection was fine.--- Setup ----The instructions are pretty simple, but it would be great if there were a different color indicator, or an additional LED to show that the connection is encrypted. At first, we plugged in the devices to the wall (but not the network yet), and pressed the security button, and nothing happened. Was it secure? Who knew?Looking back at the instructions, it says that the power button will blink for a few seconds when establishing the secure connection.We did a reset on both incase we messed something up, plugged in the network cables to both devices and waiting for a link to establish. Once we saw the internet working, then we pressed the security button (tip it says hold for two seconds, that's all it really needs).When trying to do the reset, you really only need to press the reset button for one second. Holding it for longer didn't do the trick. Weird.The power light did start to blink, and then we pressed the security button on the second unit. The link was re-established and we assume it is secure, but it'd be nice to see a "secure" indicator or something. Seems like a big oversight given how we would like the assurance of knowing our networks are secure.--- Security ----The documentation merely states that the devices are secure and that they share an encryption key when setting up security. However, it would be nice to know what strength and what type of security. Another oversight for something as important as the security of your home network.*** Update: A Frequently Asked Questions page on the Netgear site states: "Earlier versions based on HomePlug 1.0 support 56-bit DES encryption. Later versions based on HomePlug AV support 128-bit AES encryption." Also, the company stated that the signal cannot cross an electrical panel or circuit, so your neighbors may not be able to jump on, but in an apartment if you're on the same circuit, it's possible. ***This is the newer version and should support 128 AES as it uses HomePlug AV.Also, the documentation online states that this can cover an area bout 5,000 square feet. So if you live in an apartment, and a nosy neighbor discovers you're using one of these, they could potentially hop on your network just like having an extra plug into your router sent into their apartment, unless you have the security enabled.--- Overall ----This is a great device. I'm glad they have the security option there, but it would be nice to know more about it, and to see a continuing visual when it is enabled. All someone needs to do is a reset on the devices (which takes one second), then they link back up and you wouldn't be able to tell that the security had just been turned off. Hope they fix that in future versions.

Our previous wagon was one of the "red tubs" big, plastic, and hard to store.The advantage to this wagon is that it folds up more compact than our stroller does!We'll be taking this with us on lots of walks.The ability to fold is its greatest feature, and there are a few other things we like about it and a couple things that could be improved.Pros:1. Ability to foldThis makes it great to store, or fit nicely in a car trunk if your traveling somewhere. It's very easy to fold. Again, compared to our stroller, it's more compact when folded and easier to fold.2. Sturdy CanopyThe canopy supports on our old wagon were plastic, these are metal, and the canopy itself seems thicker and higher quality. The canopy folds up (just like a windshield sun guard for your car).Could use some slight improvements:1. AssemblyThe instructions show that there is a right and left front wheel and that it's important to get them in the right socket, but they are not clearly marked, and then you wonder, wait, my left or the wagon's left. Tip: feel up the black vertical wheel support and you'll be able to feel the L and the R imprinted. They are hard to see, and the instructions refer to them as the right and left of the wagon. It is important to get them on the correct side. You can tell by how the red dot in the center of the wheel lines up with the wagon when the wheels are straight. The instructions do show this, but you have to flip the page.Also, not quite sure why you have to attach the little underside bumper pieces when that could have been done before the wagon was shipped.2. CanopyThe canopy is great, sturdy, and tall, but it snaps onto the support struts, and it's not easy to get the thing to snap on. It shows it's tough and won't come off easily, but it is hard to snap.3. Knee/Foot SpaceThe bottom isn't as deep as the red tub version, so for older kids, it's a tighter squeeze.4. NoiseThe back wheels squeal. It's loud. Nothing that some WD-40 can't fix, but man, what a wail.5. Telescoping handleIt's great that the handle telescopes, but it doesn't feel as sturdy as it should be. Even though tightening at the base, there's still some give in the handle. Wish it were more sturdy.These points aren't major game changers, just things to be aware of.OverallThe best feature of the wagon is the ability to fold and easily be stored or carried. 5 Stars.

This planner is hard back. It has an elastic band to keep it closed. It has a single silk bookmark for keeping track of where you are in the month. Each month has a two page spread of traditional calendar boxes. Each week has a two page spread with each day having hours marked out for scheduling. There are a few pages in the back for other various notes. My only wish would be for two silk bookmarks to mark both the month and the week.

Well, imagine my disappointment to discover this doesn't work with an Amazon Fire phone. Despite having Bluetooth, Amazon's only UP app is for the UP or UP24. No app for the UP3.My husband kindly let me borrow his iPhone (starting to wonder why I got rid of mine) to play around with the UP3. It loaded easily on his iPhone. Download, sync, done. So simple.It doesn't track your heart rate all the time, just a resting heart rate on command when you wake up. Track your sleep. Track your steps. Set an alarm to wake you. Set reminders to remind you (via vibration). Use the app to track moods, meals, weight, and such. I think it is good motivation to get off your butt and move. Too bad I can't use it all the time since it won't work on my phone.

What did we do before Alexa entered our life? She answers all the kid's questions tirelessly. (Unlike me.) She tells them how to spell any word that they try to write. She tells them what words mean. Alexa keeps my husband company while he cooks, playing him talk radio shows. She keeps me company while I cook. Amazon is constantly adding new things Alexa can do. And I can monitor it all, including my shopping and to-do list from my phone and computer. I can play back all the requests, so I know what the kids are up to. Alexa is our time keeper, our shopping list sorter, and our entertainer. Love the echo!

This is really a good product for younger kids and indoor use. It really is. My only real issue is the quality. Foam kid products just always end up being a bad idea. They tear up so easily. For some reason, the handlebar is constantly being taken off of this and used as a weapon. The unicorn head is foam and is somewhat in the way when jumping. I just wish it were anything but foam. With a toddler in the house, we've already had a few bites taken out of this thing, despite my best efforts to make the kids put it up. It is fun. Hop on in anywhere. It squeaks when you hop. No weight limit. Even the toddler manages to hop a few times.  My kids (2, 4, 5, 7, and 9) all like hopping around on this jumper. (We actually have 3 of these Pogo Jumpers. 2 of the primary color ones and one unicorn.)

These are excellent. My kids love them, too. But be warned, chia makes you poop. So, you don't want to let your toddler eat three in one day! And they taste so awesome, they'll want to. I think they are best when cold. My kids will eat them however.

When you scan these into your iHealth glucometer, it automatically has them expire in 90 days. So, even if you have more test strips, which are not expired in the bottle, because they were opened 90+ days ago, you cannot use them. I am not diabetic and have a glucometer only for occasional use during pregnancy, so it can easily be 90 days since I last checked my blood sugar. And I have to open a brand new bottle for that check. Even though I have plenty of unexpired strips sitting in a bottle that has been opened twice 95 days ago. Very frustrating. There is also no way to override the system and just use it anyway. And if you scan the second bottle and use the first, the 90 day clock starts on the second, even though you didn't even open it. And heaven forbid you scan the wrong bottle. As soon as you scan it, it starts the 90 day clock, even if you didn't open the bottle or scanned the bottle on accident, not knowing the other bottle was the open bottle. It is just frustrating to me that I have to buy new strips, even though I have plenty of strips.

Great B-complex supplement. 1 capsule a day is the recommended dosage. The capsules are small and easy to swallow. Also contains folate, not folic acid. (Folate is now the recommendation over folic acid.) The bottle also claims it is suitable for vegans. Not being a vegan, I did not verify that claim.

I really like these Omega supplements. They are easy to swallow. The dosage is two capsules a day. My only real complaint is that they cause really awful fish burps. So, definitely take them at night and then be prepared for the fishy aftertaste to come hours later. Other than the aftertaste, they are really good supplements.

We bought this for my daughter's GoPro, as it said in the description of the item that it would work with a GoPro. It doesn't work. The screw top pushes the adhesive connector off every time we try to put it on. You'll need another adaptor to be able to use this with the GoPro. It will not work as is.

I love these little gummies. 1000 iu of D3 in each gummy. They taste great. I call them sunshine in a bottle. I had another brand of D3 before these and they just smelled terrible and though tiny, the smell made them a little difficult to swallow. Problem solved with these. They will melt in the bottle, so don't store them near the stove or your flat iron.

These look awesome. They fit well on my husband, who is an adult male with a normal sized head. They are just good, fun, reading glasses. This is the third pair of Peepers I have purchased. (The other two pairs bit the dust at the hands of a toddler, not because of poor workmanship or anything. They'd still be with us if the toddler didn't list breaking glasses as one of his skills on his resume.) They get complemented all the time. I'd say they're unisex. I think I could pull them off just as easily as my husband can. And they work really well for a great price. When our toddler decides to perform feats of strength using these as resistance, we'll buy another pair of Peepers.

I love Mrs. Meyer's products but I do not love these. This is the second time I bought the Mrs. Meyers dryer sheets, and honestly, I only bought them the second time because I forgot how much I disliked them the first time. The scent in the box is amazing, like all Mrs. Meyer's products. However, they don't leave your clothes smelling like anything at all. So that awesome in the box smell is just totally wasted. The actual sheets are like wax paper, which you tear in half. I don't like this at all. Apparently, it is more green. But let's be real, if I was trying to be green, I'd be using wool balls or oil laced wash clothes, not disposable dryer sheets. And I do understand that Mrs. Meyer's is all about being green and having good quality stuff that works. But these just don't really work. I'm mostly leaving this review as a reminder to myself to NOT make the mistake of buying these again.

While the price was right, the scent was way too strong. These are the most overpowering scented baby wipes I have ever used. The packages are easy to use and the same quality I get from more expensive brands. The wipes themselves are pretty durable, maybe a little on the fleecy side. But the smell is just so overpowering. Definitely not for sensitive bums or noses.

This soap is very nice. I am a soap conisseur and love trying all sorts of different bar soaps. This one comes in a fancy giftable box. It is packaged with some fancy raffia stuffing. Beautifully wrapped. You won't even want to throw the box away it is so pretty.The soap itself is a huge jellybean shaped bar. It smells like a high end boutique. Layers of scent that all together just smell nice and feminine. There is a distinct fruit scent, flower scent, creamy scent, and musk scent. If you smell it thinking fruit, you smell a little fruit. Smell it thinking floral and you smell flowers.It lathers well. It feels milky on your skin, not oily or thick. It does leave a slight floral scent on your skin, nothing overpowering.This soap is lovely.

This sunblock stick is decent. It is gentle on the skin. It provides adequate protection. It doesn't clog pores. I like it. My only complaint about the stick is that your skin has to be completely dry to get it to rub on. It is so thick that the slightest amount of sweat makes it incredibly difficult to rub on. You have to dry your kid's face completely. I also tried rubbing it on my hands and then rubbing it on the baby's face, and that didn't work out so well, either. You just couldn't get it thick enough in your hand to spread. You really need to use it directly from stick to dry skin. But really, those are the limitations of this particular application in general (sunblock sticks) and not the product itself.

My kids thought this book was great. At first, I thought it would be a good fun read for my 3rd grader, but it was really below her level. My.2nd grader gave it a shot and found it easy, as well. So, I'd say it is a 1st grade reader- but the older kids still found it fun, though easy. Pictures on each page and large print make this a good intro to the world of chapter books.

I am 5'4" and the petite is the perfect length. I find that many petite sizes are just too short on me, though regular are always too long. The fabric is stretchy and forgiving.My only real complaint is the rise. It.isn't really short enough to be considered petite to me. Like they shortened the legs but not the rise. It was just a little too long. But the trouser pocket style does help hide the rise issue a little.As far as size, I think it is right on, I really don't know. I just had a baby 8 weeks ago, so my size is a little up in the air. It seems right to me. Plus the stretch in the fabric helps them fit on a broader size spectrum.

These are great vitamins. A serving is 6 gummies, so 180 gummies is a one month supply of vitamins. These took the place of 4 supplements I was taking! (Prenatal vitamins, D3 supplement, B-complex, and Omega 3s) They are really tasty and don't leave me burping fish, like my other Omega supplements do. They do contain sugar- that is important to know! These are much easier on the tummy than other prenatal vitamins. My only real issue is that they are not whole food vitamins, which is fine if you can't stomach the whole food vitamins. But these are a great multivitamin for pregnant or breastfeeding (or both!) moms. The biggest plus for me was that they contain a full 1000 iu of vitamin D3. (And the whole no fish aftertaste with the Omegas.) They smell and taste great!
I always preferred the skip-its with the hard connecter- made it easier to swing. This works with or without the Twister Moves fitness tracker. It counts the skips even without the tracker.

Beautiful faucet. I wouldn't say it is easy for someone with no plumbing experience to install, but it isn't impossible- you can do it if you have some reasonable skills following directions. It looks beautiful. The finish is a perfect silver finish- not too polished, but polished enough. Good, sturdy faucet and handles.

I have been cloth diapering for about 9 years now (yes, straight), so I have had more than a few cloth diapers come and go around here. This newborn all in one is a really good diaper. The inside is a microfiber fleece. The insert is sewn into the front of the diaper, so it lifts in the wash and dry cycle, making it pretty fast drying for an all in one. You can also add a doubler under the insert, but for a newborn, it really isn't necessary. In snaps down to fit a tiny baby and then you can also use it for a bigger baby. That means the life on these is much longer than the average newborn diaper. My only real complaint, and the reason I'll stick with mostly fitteds and covers, is the lack of leg gussets. Newborn diapers tend to leak with the poopsplosions of those early days, even paper diapers do. So, I do find that my fitteds and covers result in zero diaper emergencies, where these can leak with the really bad poopsplosions. These are still infinitely better at containment than paper diapers, though. And the whale print is adorable!

I like this diaper. We've been cloth diapering for about 9 years now, so I have used many, many brands and types of cloth diaper. These are a microfiber fleece on the inside where it touches the baby, which makes getting solids off very easy. The microfiber insert is sewn into the front, so it lifts in the wash and dryer, making it dry pretty quickly for an all in one. Now, the size is a little on the small side. It fits my 21 month old pretty well, but he is on the small side. (25 lbs.) I cannot imagine it fitting up to the 40 lbs. it says it will. If you have other cloth diapers, the fit is almost the size of a BumGenius one size, it is a little shorter, though. You can also add a doubler under the insert if you need more absorbency. A really decent all in one diaper, and the fish pattern is super cute!

I found the grade level of this workbook to be right on. I was hoping to use it as an end of the year review for my second grader. And it it an okay book for that purpose. It just spanned way too many subjects and didn't stay on any of them very long. There is one page for syllables, one page for root words, one page for prefixes. It just wasn't a thorough enough look at anything.

My 8 year old daughter love the Nerf Rebelle products. This gun and holsters fits into her collection really well. Ours only came with 4 darts, not 8 as shown. It works by pulling the hammer on the back (which is much easier for smaller hands than the cocking mechanism of other Nerf guns). It only shoots one dart at a time, the darts do not rotate, they just fire one at a time from the four holes. A good addition to your Nerf arsenal.

My 8 year old daughter loves the Nerf Rebelle line! She loved this little sling shot. It required assembly, which was a little strange since most Nerf products come fully put together. It did take us a couple minutes of fiddling with the thing to realize where exactly the bullet needed to go. It comes with two bullets, or darts, whatever you call them. Pull the string back, shoot. Easy and fun.

I've been using this seat for my toddler in my Nissan NV. Rear-facing, it is much taller and hits the seat in front of it much more than the Combi seat he was using. He is 21 months old and weighs about 25 lbs, so he fits in this seat rear-facing extremely well. It fits very snug rear facing, which is a plus since I was having issues with our previous seat in this vehicle. The chest clip requires two hands to unclip. The bottom buckle can be buckled one side at a time. (It is not a puzzle clip.) I do wish it had come with strap covers over the shoulder area, but it didn't. The seat belt holders when the seat is not in use are great. They actually work, unlike so many other seats we have tried. Installation in the car was very easy using the LATCH. I also found the way the bottom of the seat was made was good for getting the seat at the proper recline for rear-facing without having to use a towel or pool noodle.Overall, a good seat for the price. Decent rear-facing weight limits. Easy install. Fits well.

My seven year old was moderately interested in this story. The story moves and has pictures for young readers. (My son is in second grade.) He seemed to loose interest a few chapters in and had to be encouraged to keep going. Once he got to the end, he said he really liked it, but I did have to prod him a bit to get him there. The story is high action and adventure where the main character, a boy named Max, finds himself in the middle of a war between bugs and lizards. This book was deemed "boring" by my 8 year old (third grader). I'd say this falls into the category for kids who like The Magic Treehouse type stories.

Six tabs to organize your life. I keep a binder for both my schedule and my homeschooling schedule. These useful tabs help keep my week in order. They are easy to use and decently durable. They are certainly an upgrade from the makeshift tabs I had been using. I would have liked a full seven tab system, since Saturdays and Sundays are pretty busy around here.

This is a really good size bulletin board. I also like that it isn't cork, so it doesn't fall apart. It was very easy to hang, and large enough that stuff on it isn't cramped. However, the board is dense and a little difficult to get push pins into. Not exactly a problem, since I'd rather have that than have the pins falling out. My other issue is that it looks very commercial. It looks like it belongs on the wall of a cubicle, not on the wall of my homeschool room. So, aesthetically, it is a little lacking. But functionally, it works really well, so I am happy.

This hand-held seed spreader is very easy to use and very light weight, though durable enough that I am not concerned it won't last until next season. The seed is scattered from the bottom front of the spreader. You pull the trigger with one hand and spin the handle with the other. Even my 8 year old can operate this.
Good set, especially for those just getting started collecting. There were a few duplicates, but I would expect that in a bulk batch.

My 3 year old purchased this as a gift for my husband. The suction on it is really strong, yet also easy to move when you need it elsewhere. They've even stuck it to the wall and had it stay really well. It is very springy and bounces back quickly. I was actually pretty impressed with the quality. I've got 4 boys, 1 girl,  and a man punching this thing and it is holding up perfectly. It comes deflated, so you have to inflate it.

My 8 year old daughter suddenly decided she wanted to collect Pokemon cards. We got her this small book to hold them, so it wouldn't look completely empty. (She has 50 cards.) The description says it will hold 40 cards, but it will actually hold 80. (2 cards per pocket, one facing each direction.) She loves it. It is small enough to carry around in her bag, but big enough that she feels like she has plenty of cards. And she still has room for some more cards. The pages are made into the book, so you cannot add more pages. We'll likely repurchase this when she fills the first one up, because the size is so much more usable for a kid than the large 3 ring binder style. My 5 and 7 year olds now want their own, as well.

This toy is absolutely wonderful. My three year old LOVES robots. We have a few of the Janod sets, and while I like them, they are pretty small. The pieces of these robot magnets are not small, though. They are appropriate for a younger child. These are easy enough for my 19 month old to put together and play with. We also love that the box is durable enough to keep and store the pieces in when not in use. My 3 year old and 19 month old LOVE these. My 5 year old even loves playing with them. They are a little simple/childish for my 7 and 8 year olds.

This is the second keychain in this style I have owned. I really prefer this one to my other. This one is made of neoprene type fabric, so it stretches better than the canvas type and puts less stress on the zipper. It comes with 8 5/8 dram amber vials with orifice reducers and lids, so you can fill them with your essential oils. About 30 drops of oil fit into each bottle. You can use smaller vials, as well. And I have found you can it a few even larger vials. (I have a few 0.12 oz amber bottles that fit in the four center slots.) You'll want label stickers, so you remember what you put in each bottle and those DO NOT come with the keychain. The pouch keeps the glass bottles safe and well protected. I definitely recommend this keychain for having oils on the go.

These are good, basic file folders. They have three tab locations per box. (Left, middle, right) They are thick and durable. I have also used them for lap books (homeschool) and they work well for that, as well. Good folders. My only real complaint is the box they come in cannot hold the folders once you open it. It folds itself apart and goes flat. Which is great for breaking it down for recycling. But not great if you planned to store the folders in the box until you used them all. ----------

I use this in my playroom, not for my baby. (My baby sleeps in my room, so a monitor would be overkill there.) So, for my purposes, I love that I can talk to the kids through the monitor. ("Hey guys. Time to clean up and come upstairs." Awesome. No yelling down the stairs at them.) I keep the "parent unit" in the room directly above the playroom, so I can't say I have ever had it go out of range. The advertised 520 ft. range is with no obstructions. The asterisk by that says that indoors with obstructions, the typical range is 100 ft. So, you may want to be aware of that. The screen on the parent unit is tiny, but I can see what I need to see on it and more importantly, I can hear what is going on with it. I also don't use the night vision capabilities, but they are there. And there is a room temperature display which is useless for my purposes, but you may like it if you're actually using this to watch a baby's room.

We live in a world where our milk isn't just milk anymore. Our coffee is rarely just coffee. Our bread is more than flour, yeast, and water. So what is in the food? Food labels tell you what is in the product, but do you even know what half the things on food labels even are? This book breaks it down. Whether the substance is a chemical additive or just a part of coffee itself- this book tells you what is in your food and what that means. Chapters are broken down into 3-5 pages about each food. This isn't an encyclopedia of all foods. Just enough to get you thinking about what you put in your mouth. Part two is about things we don't eat, but use on a regular basis. What is in your shampoo, cigarettes, Febreze, etc.

**Changing my review from 5 to 2 stars after several months of us. Original Review below the updated review.**So, after several months with this glucometer, that I only use occasionally during pregnancy as I do not have a medical condition requiring daily us, I'm unhappy with this. First, I got rid of my iPhone. I didn't even think about the glucometer when I did it. It only occurred to me when I needed the glucometer and got it out, only to realize I couldn't use it. So, I waited for my husband to get home and borrowed his iPhone.Then I go to use my glucose strips and the bottle I had opened wouldn't work. Though they were unexpired, the machine automatically expires them 90 days after they were opened. So I have to scan and open a brand new bottle, as there was no way to override the smart glucometer who just knew my strips had been opened too long. Super annoying. I really wish they'd package the strips individually or in smaller groups so people like me don't waste 20 strips.**Original Review**This glucometer system was easy to use and stores results in an easy to access way. Using your iPhone has its advantages, mainly the storage of results and notes and such. It also comes with disadvantages, it takes a little longer to set up, won't work without your iPhone, and takes a little longer to do.The system comes with lancets, the reader that goes in your headphone port, 4 covers for the reader (which seems like overkill, but I guess they wanted you to have color options- blue, pink, orange, white), a carrying case, batteries (one extra), and plastic bags to cover your phone while you use the device. It does not come with the testing strips. Not a single one. You have to buy those separately. They are cheaper than your average box of strips, though.Prior to use, you'll have to install the battery (which actually proved difficult for me). Download and set up the app on your phone. Set up your lancet. And scan your bottle of testing strips (that ARE NOT INCLUDED). Once you do all of that, which takes about 15 minutes including the time I spent fighting the button battery, you'll be ready to test.Results appear quickly (about 10-15 seconds), they are large and have a color gauge to tell you if it is "good" or "bad". It marks the date and time automatically and allows you to select details (before eating, after eating, etc.) and has a place to put notes. Results can then be pulled up as needed.

My kids insist on Annie's Mac and Cheese. My only real issue with this particular pack is that the bottom of the boxes are glued to a piece of cardboard. So, when you are taking apart the packaging to store them in the pantry, even when you're super careful, you'll inevitably rip the bottom off of at least one box. Which I then have to tape up with duct tape if I'm not making mac and cheese right that second.

I had heard a lot of good things about the SodaStream, so I decided it was time to get one. This kit came with the soda stream, a tiny CO2 cartridge, and a sample of soda syrups. I was pretty irritated that half the syrups were diet. We don't use artificial sweeteners, so these were a complete waste to us. However, the Soda Stream itself is great. Easy to use. It also came with a rebate of some sort for upgrading the tiny CO2 canister once empty for a full size canister.Since we purchased the SodaStream and several of the SodaStream syrups, we have come to realize that we don't like their syrups.
