And who is this previously unknown Uncle that enters her life ?The book also depicts Dot's first exploration into the world of dating plus the formation of a roller derby team.I find it amazing that Joe Lansdale,  writer of ultra violent Men's Adventures can write such a quiet and touching Novel.I read this Novel over the weekend amid reports of Terrorists attacks in Paris, and it was the perfect remedy to brighten my troubled mind in these scary times.  I really hope more people discover this hidden little gem.My Highest Recommendation.

It was exactly twenty years this month that the first Birds Of Prey special was released in November 1995.  DC Comics seemed unwilling to commit to full fledged series so between 1995 and 1998 a whole slew of one shots , one mini-series and an appearance in the anthology series Showcase 96 all came out.  These all appeared one after another.This 288 page collection is the start of DC's attempt to collect all the Birds appearances in chronological order. The paper is slick and glossy with a card stock cover.Birds Of Prey was created by Chuck Dixon , a top notch Action writer who started by writing the adventures of Airboy for Eclipse Comics.  Gary Frank, current British superstar did the first special and remained on the project by doing all the covers in this collection.  Editor Jordan B. Gorfinkel was the third creator.  He would go on to write their 2nd adventure for Showcase 96.The original team is only the crippled Barbara Gordon former Batgirl now called Oracle.  Plus Dinah Lance , Black Canary.  She is a down on her luck, and recovering from the death of Oliver Queen.The first special was a massive 56 pager from Dixon and Frank.  Gary Frank early art here resembles Steranko and Paul Gulacy.  This excellent start gives us the first globe hopping adventure and brings back Dixon's villainess Lynx.Next is the Showcase adventure which is by Gorfinkel and new artist Jennifer Graves.  The art is rather pedestrian compared to the others in this collection.  It teams Black Canary with Lois Lane.Next up is the Birds Of Prey four issue series called Manhunt.  Chuck Dixon returns and Matt Haley takes over the art.  Haley is another excellent artist. This time Black Canary teams up with The Huntress and Catwoman much to dismay of Oracle.  Lady Shiva also makes an appearance working for the bad guys.The next one shot is called Revolution and it ends in a rift between Oracle and Black Canary.  Dixon teams with Italian artist Stefano Raffaele.The next one shot called Wolves picks up on the continuity from the last book with gals not working together.  This is my favorite story from the collection as Oracle and Black Canary have parallel solo adventures and bad romances.  It nice to see more of Barbara , and especially Barbara in action. The late Dick Giordano penciled the Dixon story.We conclude with the final one shot titled Batgirl.  Since at the time no Batgirl existed in the DC Universe this one will leave you confused until close to the end when an explanation is made.  This story is by Dixon and Greg Land.  Land would be involved with the characters when they finally get their own book in 1999.The second collection is all ready solicited and should be as much fun as this inexpensive volume.Highly Recommended.

This almost 300 page Trade Paperback collects the seven comics directly leading up to Tim Drake's emergence as Robin. Plus the five issue Robin comic.The character of Tim Drake was created by Marv Wolfman and Pat Broderick in Batman #436 ( 1989).  He was named after Batman director Tim Burton.Unlike most origins, Tim's was plotted very slowly over a period of over a year.  He is mostly just a background character in Dectective and Batman until the four issue run ( collected here) Detective #618 through #621.  This 1990 story "Rite of Passage" features Tim's bickering Rich Parents being abducted in Haiti.  Batman sets out to rescue the parents, while Tim longingly looks at the Robin costume in glass case and works unraveling a different domestic crime case with his computer skills. Batman comes back unsuccessful after rescuing them they quickly drink some poisoned water.  Janet Drake dies and Jack Drake is paralyzed.This very dark tale is brought to you by Scottish Writer Alan Grant and Norm Breyfogle.  As it turns out Grant and Breyfogle successful run on Detective ended with this saga and they quickly jumped over to the better selling Batman comic.Then the story of Tim is continued in Batman #455 to #457 which is collected next.  This Grant and Breyfogle three issue arc is called "Identity Crisis". Clever title.  This story line features Vicky Vale as a reporter in trouble and the villain is The Scarecrow.  Defying Bruce's orders Tim rescues The Batman and is finally rewarded by getting the Robin costume in the final panel.Speaking of the Robin costume this book has a nice bonus in the back of it , eight pages of possible costume designs for Robin.  The winning design was created by Neal Adams.Next comes the five part Main Course the Robin mini-series that debuted a month later from Chuck Dixon and Tom Lyle.  With beautiful covers by England's Brian Bolland.This globe hopping saga starts with Tim in France and ends in Hong Kong.  The main bad guy looks a little dated today with Snake Tattoo on his bare chest and his mullet hair cut.  We also are re-introduced to Lady Shiva , a character who goes back to Richard Dragon, Kung Fu Fighter #5 in 1975.  We are also introduced to morally ambiguous Lynx.This is a great collection and I look forward to the follow up collections announced.My Highest Recommendation.

Several years ago Dynamite Entertainment realizing the early John Carter books are in public domain started publishing Warlord Of Mars comics not using the name John Carter , but just calling it Warlord Of Mars .  The estate of Edgar Rice Burroughs sued Dynamite.  While the legal results have not been made public,  it has been announced that they are now working with the full cooperation of Edgar Rice Burroughs Inc. This book is the results of that newly made agreement.The book was rebooted bringing in long time comic writer Ron Marz.  Marz has a love for the Burroughs characters and was prior to this assignment already writing both The Mucker and Korak for Edgar RIce Burroughs Inc. Online Comic Strips.This Trade Paperback collects the first six issues from the Ongoing John Carter series.  The storyline is called Invaders Of Mars. It involves a nemesis  who John Carter battled during the Civil War.  A Union Officer named Captain Joshua Clark.  Clark through a parallel storyline has now become his own Warlord for a different alien race who want to invade Barsoom (Mars).The art for the book is very good and features a very multi-national flavour as is common with many of Dynamite books.  The excellent interiors (for the first five chapters ) are by Abhishek Malsuni from New Dehli , India.  Chapter Six is from Mexican artist Roberto Castro .  Castro's art is a little bit sketchier but not jaringly different.The cover for this trade is from American Superstar J. Scott Campbell.  With issue #2 Brazilian artist Ed Benes takes over as the main cover artist.  Since this is Dynamite you have an entire slew of variant covers and those are collected in a gallery in the back of this book. Trying to collect all these variants can be pricey and a good incentive to just wait for the trade.This is a very handsome volume and Dynamite's best Warlord Of Mars book yet.  It gets my Highest Recommendation.It has been a very good year for Edgar Rice Burroughs in comics.  I am also recommending the Tarzan newspaper strip collections by Manning , Foster and Hogarth, The excellent adaptations from Sequential Pulp and of course the online comic strips .

Last year's first Epic Collection of Moon Knight was a surprise hit for the Epic line.  So now one year later we get a direct sequel.  This collection is again over 500 pages but this time it is all from a two year period 1981 and 1982 when Moon Knight got his own monthly comic.  Collected are Moon Knight #5 through #23 plus the back up stories and related text pieces contained in those issues. The reproduction is equally as good as the first volume and you get a heavy card stock cover once again.  My one complaint about the format is I think the re-coloring done for the cover is too dark and obscures the art.This volume is largely a success because of the skills of two men who do over 90% of this volume.  Doug Moench and Bill Sienkiewicz.Doug Moench is Moon Knight's co-creator who brought him to life in Werewolf by Night #32 as a foe for the Werewolf.  While some of his early 1970's writing was a little pretentious and over written by the time Moon Knight got his own book he was really at the top of his game doing some excellent work.  His storylines are very diverse and non-repetitive.Young Bill Sienkiewicz was actually brought to Marvel by his mentor Neal Adams who recommended him to the Editor Archie Goodwin.  Sienkiewicz worked on the Moon Knight backups in the Rampaging Hulk Magazine. They served as just the right forum to get him noticed.  He quickly emerged as a fan favorite artist.Sienkiewicz inks about half of his stories and they are beautiful and my preference.  Frank Giacoia inks one issue and is a poor fit destroying the intricate line work. Steve Mitchell is very good and Klaus Janson is excellent.Moon Knight for those unfamiliar with the character had four separate and distinct personalities.  Marc Spector the Mercenary who started it all.  Marc Spector gets his own back up stories in this volume.  They read like a cross between paperback novels featuring the Destroyer and Indiana Jones.Steven Grant the suave, rich Playboy from the Bruce Wayne mold. Jake Lockely the gritty Taxi Driver and Moon Knight himself.  The personalities are so different it is a borderline personality disorder.Moench develops an excellent supporting cast also.  Marlene Alraune is his girl Friday who keeps it all together.  Jean-Paul DuChamp called "Frenchy" is a skilled Helicopter Pilot.  Plus the civilian friends of Jake Lockely like Betrand Crowley .  Crowley is a highly intelligent homeless man.  Gena Landers is greasy spoon waitress who also aides on occasion with or without her sons.With issue #15 the comic became a Direct Sales only comic. These comics where not sold in other sources then comic book shops and were not returnable.  Moon Knight was a very successful Direct Sales Comic.  This meant generally several things.  First stories aimed for an older adult audience.  While Moench's Moon Knight stories seemed aimed at adults since the Black and White magazines, now he no longer had the Comics Code to contend with.  The price was increased from 50 cents to 75 cents and the kid aimed advertising disappeared.  That meant the story pages went from 22 pages an issue to 28 pages.  Moon Knight #20 and #23 featured extra long stories but the other seven issues included here either had text back up features or related back up stories.This book is actually even better then the first volume and comes highly recommended.

The creator's of this book say it was inspired by Buffy The Vampire Slayer but the book seems more like a young Japanese Supernatural version of the X-Men.Written by Jim Zubkavich know as Jim Zub.  He is the Canadian writer of Skull Kickers . The art is by American artist Steven Cummings.  Cummings beautiful Anime inspired art is what turns this project into a 5 Star ratings for me.This beautiful Hard Cover is oversized and comes loaded with so many extras you might want to double dip even if he have all the issues or both trades.  This collection is 300 pages long.  It includes the first 10 issues of the Wayward comic plus all the multiple covers and variant covers.  Also you get a ton of Character sketches and pre-production art work. Plus a 34 page lavishly illustrated text article on the back ground of the characters and Japanese Myths that this book uses.  And then finally a giant five page fold out poster which came tipped in the book.  This is a ton of value added bonus material.The story for for you total newbies is about Rori Lane a girl of mixed descent.  She has been staying with her father in Ireland but when the book opens she is returning to Toyko to be with her mother.The first five issues form a small arc about Rory discovering her own powers and meeting other youths with similar supernatural powers.  At the end of the first five issues a big battle takes place with results in Rori as well as another of her friends disappearing from Toyko.The second five issues opens three months later with entirely new character named Ohara Emi a perfect Japanese School Girl .  She of course also has powers. Eventually she meets some of Rori's friends.  Meanwhile we find out what happened with Rori and by the end of issue ten all our Heroes have met and come together with a mission statement.Highly Recommended.

Richard Corben is one of those working masters of American Comics who doesn't get neatly the recognition he deserves.  For almost 50 years Richard Corben has been doing some of the best of Science Fiction , Fantasy and Horror Comics in the Industry.Now Dark Horse collects his newest work a five issue mini-series released early in 2015 now collected in this inexpensive (under $20) Beautiful Hard Cover collection which features all the covers plus pre-production sketches and other material.  Corben is assisted by his daughter Beth Corben Reed who did much of the air brush coloring.While the date of the story is never given it appears to be set in the 1920's. It is set in the winter in Massachusetts.  The lead protagonist is named Clark Elwood , a racist and self-absorbed college student.  Clark falls for a odd looking but voluptuous young woman at the college.  When Clark finds her doing nude modeling she flees back to her back woods home town named Lame Dog.  Once Clark reaches the town things turn horrifically gruesome.The stories features all the Corben Standards with Nudity, Sex , Violence and Horror.  The story successfully mixes the Native American legends and mythos with that of H P Lovecraft.  This book is definitely not recommend for children.I hope some day Richard Corben returns to his ground breaking legendary series DEN and we get a comprehensive Hard Cover Collection, but in the meantime enjoy his latest creation.Highly Recommended.

While I originally thought Jet Powers was a Flash Gordon or Buck Rogers clone he is actually more of Doc Savage character since he lives in the present day ( the 1950's) rather then in the future. His subtitle is "Man Of Science". He is a scientist, an inventor as well as an explorer and adventurer.  He lives in a underground laboratory cavern in the American South West desert Mesa.  He has a distinctive white crew cut hair and a chiseled face.  He resembled actor Jeff Chandler.Jet Powers appeared in a mere four issues of his own comic which was simply entitled Jet.  Each issue had three separate stories.  After the end of that book Jet Powers was simply repurposed as an Air Force pilot in the Korean War.  This Comic was called The American Air Forces and was published in 1951 to 1953.  Jet had a story in six of eight issues published and these war stories are also included.This is companion book to the Cave Girl volume published in 2014.  It was published by Dark Horse and put together by their Kitchen Sink Imprint.  It is a quality Hard Cover but slightly over priced for only 168 pages.  It has excellent introduction and afterwards by John Wooley and James Vance. The other introduction by Steve Rude is rather pointless since he had never even heard of the character before being asked to write an Introduction.The publishers have once more decided to use the tan paper to give it the realistic look of a comic of that era.  I would have preferred white paper like a Marvel Masterwork.  The color restoration is slightly better then the Cave Girl volume where the quality for a couple stories were inferior to the rest.  The restoration is much better then the color Xerox's of say PS Artbooks,  but no where as good as a Marvel Masterwork. All the dot matrix coloring has been converted to solid colors and the bleeding over the line blotches have been removed.Bob Powell art is excellent here and he really excels at the Science Fiction settings. This art is comparable to the excellent EC comics work done by Wally Wood and Al Williamson. His knowledge of then current Air Craft and Military equipment saves the rather generic later done War Stories from being a disappointment.The writing is thought to be the work of then M.E. Comics workhorse Gardner Fox. Fox also did most the other recent collections of M.E. Comics like Thunda, Ghost Rider and Cave Girl.There is some speculation that Powell have written, co-written or plotted some of these stories.  Regardless they are superior to the above listed efforts.  While these stories are totally zanny and unbelievable they are intricately plotted with a lot happening in each story.  The stories all run a mere seven to ten pages each.In the very first episode we meet the evil Mr. Sinn who is unfortunately a racist Yellow Peril stereotype.  Dr. Sinn has created a machine which is causing worldwide Earthquakes and massive destruction. It is up to Jet Powers and his Graviton Gun to save the day.The stories run the gamut from Alien Invasion, Time Travel , Giant Grasshoppers, Robot's gone wild and Animals on the loose.  Jet also gets involved in war between the friendly Martians and The Evil Venusians. In one of the most startling stories a Radioactive Death Dust settles on the earth killing most of the population before Jet Powers can invent a remedy for the survivors.The book has a tighter continuity then you would expect for a book published in 1951 .  Not only do villains reappear but some stories are direct sequels to others.  The Martian War and The Death Dust stories both get a follow up story.The only other major re-occuring character is the beautiful Su Shan.  She is of Asian decent and modeled after Milton Caniff's Dragon Lady. Su Shan and Jet Powers have a very bizarre relationship. She appears in the very first episode as Dr. Sinn's assistant. When Dr. Sinn throws her out of his plane, Jet rescues her.  In the next couple episodes she appears to be being held in Jet's underground laboratory against her will. Twice she tries to leave and return to Dr. Sinn.  When Jet rescues her the for a third time she starts kissing him and now they are boyfriend and girlfriend.Recommended.

Your enjoyment of this book will depend on your love of Jack Kirby and your expectations of this book.What you won't get is any complete Kirby Comic stories, any never seen or never published art.  Or even any real information on the life of man besides superficial information that most of us are already aware of.What you do get is a beautiful art book crammed with covers, splash pages and pin-ups done by Jack "The King " Kirby done for Marvel Comics during his three stays at Marvel.The book is done on High Quality glossy paper stock .  It is a beautiful Hard Cover done in the Landscape ( wider then tall ) 240 pages that all fit in a classy Heavy Duty slip case.In preparation for this review I did something that I expect few will do with this type of book.  I read it cover to cover.  The writing is by John Rhett Thomas who really does little except introduce each chapter and provide complete credits for every cover and splash page .  Sometimes he also provides a sentence or two talking about the art or the importance of a story.The book is set up chronologically into six chapters.  Chapter One is Jack Kirby and Joe Simon: Timely's Golden Age.  This focuses on Captain America and The Vision,  but does include many of the other great covers he did during this era.Chapter Two Monsters And Cowboys: Jack Kirby And The Atlas Era focuses on the time he became Stan Lee's main muse after the death of Joe Manleey in 1959.  He did a few stories starting in 1956, but starting in 1959 through his departure in 1970 his production was phenomenal.This is the subject on my favorite chapter November 1961: The Month That Changed Marvel.  This of course is the month that Jack illustrated the 25 page Fantastic Four #1 and it's cover.  But here the focus is on that book and the twelve other stories and nine other covers he also did that month.  Monsters, Superheroes, Westerns and Romances,  all total 119 pages for that month alone.The next chapter is massive since it covers The Marvel Age: King Kirby. This is his superhero work from 1961 to 1970. Since it runs 150 pages each character gets his own sub-chapter.  The Fantastic Four, Ant-Man /Giant-Man and The wasp, The Hulk,  Spider-Man,  Iron-Man, Thor, The Avengers, Captain America, X-Men, Sgt. Fury, Nick Fury, Sub-Mariner, Silver Surfer, Ka-Zar, Inhumans and even Not Brand Echh.Chapter Six is The Return Of The King and deals with the three years when Jack returned after his DC Comics stay.  Again we get sub-chapters with Captain America, The Eternals, Black Panther, Machine Man and Devil Dinosaur.  I assume no copyright agreement could be reached so we are sadly missing any art for 2001.The final chapter is a very short reminiscence by Neal Kirby, his son.  While this is entertaining it is very brief (four pages with illustrations) and might have just been included as an afterward rather then an entire chapter.We also get an Introduction by Joe Quesada.  Plus sprinkled in through the volume are small sidebar stories from a multitude of Comic Creators. These include John Cassaday, Mark Bagley, Alan Weiss, Ryan Stegman, Michael Allred, Ramon K. Perez, Steve Rude, Dan Jurgens, Karl Kessel, Keith Giffen, Sal Buscema, Terry Austin, Nick Bradshaw, Klaus Janson,  Rick Remember, Tom Scoli, Rich Buckler and Andy Lanning.  These are very brief and talk about the time they met Kirby or what Kirby meant to them.  The name quite obviously missing from the list above is one Stan Lee.If you want deep insight into the man this is not your book. But if you just want to look at a collection of beautiful art work then this comes Highly Recommended.

With very little fanfare the American Comics Library has brought out this sequel to the excellent Five Volume set of the much adored run of Archie Goodwin and Al Williamson.In 1980 the strip was offered to George Evans , a life time comic illustrator who had helped Al Williamson on occasions Ghost Illustrate some of the previous run. Evans would pick up the baton and write and illustrate the strip for sixteen additional years until his retirement in 1996. It was then decided to cancel the strip rather then look for a successor.George Evans started in comic books in 1947 working for the publisher Fiction House.  When working for DC he frequently turned down chances to work on superhero comics believing it not to be a good fit for his realistic style.His most famous comic work was in the 1950's working for EC Comics.  His work on their Aces High Comic is brilliant and reflects his life long love of airplanes.  In the 60's he spent a decade ghosting for George Wunder's Terry & The Pirates.Since this work was done at both the twilight of George's career and the death of daily Adventure Comic Strips it has been seen by very few and ran in a only select few newspapers.Both George Evans and this last hurrah for Secret Agent Phil Corrigan deserve a much wider audience and appreciation.As of right now there has been no announcement of a follow-up offering.  I suspect like the similar John Prentice volumes of Rip Kirby as long as they sell enough another will follow.  Sadly some of these experiments do not have as much such success like the Dick Moore run on Gasoline Alley.  So it is important for comic strip fans to support this volume now.This comic strip started in 1934 as follow up to the success of Dick Tracy.  The inaugural creators selected for this project are Flash Gordon artist Alex Raymond and the father of Hard Boiled Detective Fiction , Dashiell Hammett. IDW has just released that volume this past May and you can read my overly kind review for it also on Amazon.  Beautiful art , but poor writing.This collection features two and a half years of large daily strips reproduced in crisp black and white on heavy stock paper.  Three strips to the page on large landscape size.The strips in this collection are a blend of action, adventure spy stories with two outright Science Fiction tales throw in to my surprise and delight. Most of the storylines run a compact fifteen or so weeks. I know most of the Comic Syndicates at the time much preferred this.While decades earlier Phil Corrigan was married off. His wife  Wilda was rarely used in the Goodwin/ Williamson era and now is gone entirely.  She seems to be entirely written out of the strip  and Corrigan has numerous female companions. Anna Kreemar is the Chief's niece introduced in George Evans's second storyline.  She is beautiful but spoiled. They have a love/hate relationship.  Anna appears in about half of the storylines collected here and is the only other re-occuring character besides the now nameless Chief who dishes out his assignments. Phil Corrigan started his career working for the U.S. Government but in the 60's and 70's it became an unknown organization.  Now it is the 80's and George Evans decides it is OK for Corrigan's employers to be the government again.The adventures criss cross the globe and George Evans likes to use made up countries with obvious real world analogs rather then offend anyone.In Evan's very first story we get a story about a man who holds an entire town hostage with the claim he can set fire to all the water in the town.  Especially chilling is the tale about a group of young cult like members in Hawaii and the deadly weapon they invent called the Nothing Bomb.The two Science Fiction stories mentioned earlier involve a young boy who discovers an alien in a rural town in first story. And then a story about a artificial life called the Emperor taking over Phil's agency and gaining control over the agents.In all the stories are very diverse and entertaining.  The story about an avant garde troupe of entertainers and Anna's desire to sing brings lots of humour to the mix.Highly Recommended.

This Adventure novel was first serialized in six issues of the great Argosy Pulp Magazine in 1930 and 1931 and has never been reprinted before.  That is too bad , because it is rip-roaring good story.The novel was written by Fred MacIsaac who was a favorite of Argosy readers and would go on to create the character of The Rambler who regularly appear in Dime Detective.The Novel is printed in large easy to read print in and features a cover painting by Paul Stahr and all the orginal six illustrations from the Pulp Magazine.  This is part of the Altus Press first ten books in their new Argosy Library.It is my third book read in this series and like the previous two I devoured they are excellent. They have been doing a great job of selecting neglected classics.Balata the novel's title referrers to a kind of very durable rubber discovered in South America.  Today Balata is still used and is they key ingredient in quality golf balls.  In 1930 the Rubber trade had moved from South America to the cheaper Asian countries, but then the discovery of Balata started a get rich boom similar to the Gold Rush.Young Pete Holcomb's career was not working out the way he planned so Pete agrees to follow his rich college buddy Les Gorman down to explore his Balata claim in the Amazon Jungles.  Gorman's beautiful but rugged sister Louise insisted on going. Also hired is World renowned explorer Felix Dexter. These four form the core of the party and a love triangle also develops.They must build boats and hire crew and porters,  meanwhile a very greedy rubber Plantation owner will stop at nothing to stop their deadly trip.They also must face danger with the Jungle's nasty creatures and Cannibal Natives.  At one point our hero finds himself separated from the party and forced to live among the cannibals.This is a non-stop fun action, adventure romp with a little politics and romance thrown in to flavour it.My Highest Recommendation.

I have been waiting decades for The Burroughs Estate to authorize a new Tarzan Novel.  It is my belief that they have selected the perfect author.  Will Murray's continuation of Doc Savage has been a ton of fun.This new novel brings us back to one of my favorite Lost World Civilizations Pal-ul-don.  We meet both old friends and new ones in this delightful romp.The creation of the Turtle People is great addition to the Burroughs Universe.  The same with the majestic elephant Torn Ear.I was both upset and discouraged to see a couple "haters" who gave this book a bad review then appear to be then give reviewers "unhelpful " votes.  Don't listen to these few negative individuals and spend some time immersed in world of your favorite jungle Lord.Just a reminder the Hardcover can be ordered from LuLu and I will be ordering a second copy because the Hardcover contains the expanded wrap around cover from Joe Devito and an additional short story.Highly Recommended

This novel was serialized in the Pulp magazine Argosy in 1937.  It is not a bad Lost World novel.  The story follows Hugh Lambert who is heading a Boy's Camp.  Soon he discovers the mystery of the little people who live under the lake Wanooka.You get a bit of a love triangle , as well as meeting two different competing Aquatic cultures.The book is put together using various different story telling tools like Medical Reports , News Articles as well as the Journal of Hugh Lambert.  This is an attempt to make it seem factual.This review is of the physical audio CD set rather then the digital download.I have enjoyed quite a few of these Radio Archives Audio Books and they suffer from a couple problems.  First off it would be nice if they either had a very large pause or the narrator would  simply tell you when the C.D. is over, as they are they would immediately start the CD over before I realized it.Second while narrator Milton Bagby has a decent voice it is very limited.  He has a voice that makes you think both Rural and Ancient.  So listening I kept imagining every character as the same type of person,  all Old Farmers, which is not what they are.I am sure I would have enjoyed the book more by simply reading it.Still worth a listen.

This thick tome collects most of the earliest adventures of Marvel's second Kung-Fu series starting in 1974 with eleven issues in Marvel Premiere continuing with his fifteen issue solo series from 1975 to 1977 and winding up with two issues of Marvel Team-Up from 1977 Marvel Team-Up #63 and #64.  All total 28 comics are included making it a whopping 528 pages.The cover is a durable cardboard stock and the printing is crisp with bright vibrant colors.Now comes my real only complaint and if anyone knows Marvel's explanation please leave a comment here.  This volume does not include any of Iron-Fist's black and white appearances from Deadly Hands Of Kung-Fu magazine done during this time period.  The Moon Knight volume does include them but maybe only because they where later colored and released in a comic format.  Regardless I can understand that decision, but not the decision to totally exclude the two crossovers books Marvel Team-Up #31 (1975) and Marvel Two-In-One #25 (from 1977 ). Both of these feature Iron Fist in a lead role. Granted these are both rather weak stories and are not needed to enjoy this volume. I just thought these volumes would be comprehensive including all major appearances.Iron Fist was the brain child of then current Editor-in-chief Roy Thomas and his friend Gil Kane.  His origin story takes place in Marvel Premiere #15 and #16. The text page from Marvel Premiere # 15 should have probably been included since it explains how they were inspired by Bill Everett's creation of Amazing Man.  Roy explained in an interview that he was already a fan of Kung-Fu movies even prior to Bruce Lee and thought the name Iron Fist would make a great hero.  With Stan Lee's O.K. they proceeded.  Gil Kane's  Iron Fist costume is a knock out and has varied very little over the years.Gil Kane who had divorce related money problems and never stayed on a book long and preferred to just do covers where the page rate was higher.  That is why Gil departed after just one issue but did the majority of the covers included in this collection.  Rounding out the debut was Dick Giordano one of the best inkers in the business.  Giordano would ink the first five issues.But Roy didn't stick around long himself as Marvel Premiere #16  was only plotted by Roy and then scripted by Len Wein.  That same issue featured the debut of new penciler Larry Hama.  G.I. Joe main writer Hama actually started as a penciler.  Hama was actually either a very good penciler or Dick Giordano just did magic on the next four issues because they look pretty good.The Origin story had always puzzled me because they seem to be setting up a great nemesis in the form of Harold Meachum.  He is responsible for the deaths of both Danny Rand's parents.  So I naturally thought he would become the ultimate bad guy and they would spend their days battling. In Marvel Premiere #17 and # 18 new writer Doug Moench takes over and decides to flip the script so instead when Danny seeks revenge he finds Harold had lost his legs and is confined to a wheelchair.  Next Harold is quickly murdered by an unknown assailant.In Moench's last issue Marvel Premiere #19 we get the introduction of Colleen Wing and her archaeologist father Professor Wing.Marvel Premiere #20 to #23 introduces a whole new creative team who last for three issues.  Tony Isabella as writer and Arvell Jones on pencils.  While Mr. Jones' early pencils here are rather we weak  , one neat thing this team tried to incorporate is showing us real Kung-fu moves in the stories. This of course only lasted the three issues.  In Marvel Premiere #20 Isabella has Iron Fist face his first regular Marvel villain as Batroc The Leaper made a great foil for Iron Fist.  Isabella also introduces Danny's love interest and lady with a bionic arm , Misty Knight.Finally in Marvel Premiere #23 we get some consistency.  This is Iron Fist's ninth issue and fifth new writer.  Chris Claremont would stay on the book for the remaining 20 issues. Claremont's writing seems to evolve and get better and better as it continues.Marvel Premiere # 23 and #24 featured art by new artist Pat Broderick. MP #23 introduces a new villain Warhawk while MP #24 brings back Monstroid, a lame villain from Marvel Team-Up #5.  Broderick's art is actually quite nice but according to reports he missed his deadline and was fired off the book by John Verpoorten production manager.  Broderick went on to become a mainstay on such books as Micronauts and Firestorm.In Marvel Premiere #24 we are introduced to a Chris Claremont tradition, heroes relaxing by playing softball.  The little bearded fellow on page 184 is Claremont himself.  Can anyone name the entire Bullpen staff on the top of page 185 ?  The only one I am sure of is Roy Thomas on the far right.John Verpooten then hired John Byrne for his very first regular Marvel assignment.  John Byrne started with Iron Fist's final appearance in Marvel Premiere which was #25 and continued for the next 18 issues.Claremont and Bryne together and separately would become the key components of the success of Marvel for an era starting in the late 1970's and extending until the mid 1980's.  And Iron Fist is the book where they really started to put it all together.One interesting footnote here is in both the Iron Fist's Marvel Premiere run and his solo book's runs both books seem to yo-yo back in forth in frequency from Monthly to Bi-Monthly switching up every couple months.Marvel Premiere #25 features the villain Angar the Screamer and leads directly into Iron Fist #1.  This also starts a long storyline about the abduction of Colleen Wing.  An appearance by Iron-Man kicks of Iron Fist #1.The quest to rescue Colleen continues til issue #7 and includes the new nemesis Master Khan.In Iron Fist #8 to #10 meets Chaka Crime Lord of New York and gets framed for a crime. The artist pictured on page 343 is John Byrne himself.John Byrne is partially color blind.  He said he had been doing the book for over a year before some one told him Iron Fist's  costume was actually Green and Yellow.  He saw it as Brown and Yellow.In Iron Fist #11 and #12 the Wrecking Crew are loose and Iron Fist needs the help of Captain America to put them away again. This one has yet another cameo next to Matt Murdoch on page 398 are editors Jim Shooter and Roger Stern.Then in Iron Fist #13 and #14 we get a glance of things to come with an X-Men crossover.  I love the fact that Misty Knight and Jean Grey are roommates.Iron Fist  #15 starts a story about the Steel Dragon , the son of the man who trained Danny Rand.  When the book was canceled the storyline picked up two months later in the pages of Marvel Team-Up #63 and #64.Marvel Team-Up #64 actually is labelled a Spider-Man and Daughters Of The Dragon crossover.  It was covered dated December 1977 the same month that John Byrne became the new regular penciler on X-Men.This is a super fun collection especially when Claremont and Bryne take over.My Highest Recommendation.

Canton Street Press is a new small publisher of archival comic book material.  They are the former owners of the online comic retailer Tales Of Wonder.  I own both of their previous two collections and was quite an advocate for them.This collection reprints the now public domain comic material from the Magazine Enterprises Ghost Rider comics #1 to #5 in their entirety.  Plus you get the first four appearances of Ghost Rider from Tim Holt #11 to #14.  All of these originally dated from 1949 to 1951.The book was produced in a quality format with good quality paper and a sewn binding. While some restoration has been done, it quite frankly is not up to even the quality of the first two books Canton Street Press has produced.  My overall feeling is it is that it is all too dark and could have been greatly improved with just lightening it up some more.  If you don't have a problem with quality of the PSArtbooks editions you shouldn't be too disappointed.  Because it is of a similar calibre.  One clue I can find for this decline in restoration quality is the publishers said in an a recent interview that this had been done for a couple years and had just been put on hold.  Perhaps it even pre-dates the earlier work.My other complaint about the book is the giant leap in price point.  The Airboy was $24.99 then Canteen Kate was $28.99 now this is $49.99.  That is quite a price jump.Tony Isabella gives a fun and informative introduction. That introduction is dated April 2013.  More proof that this material was put together much earlier.Even though the Tim Holt comics are older then the Ghost Rider comics they are in the back of the book.  The only reason I can think for this is both Tim Holt #11 and the first story in Ghost Rider #1 tell the same origin story.  This way you read the better, more defining origin first.US Marshal Rex Fury was secretly Calico Kid appearing in earlier issues of Tim Holt Comics , but suddenly with Tim Holt  #11 Rex stopped being the Calico Kid and adopted an entirely new identity as the Ghost Rider.  None of the earlier Calico Kid adventures are included , nor are all the Ghost Rider stories from Tim Holt Comics included.  In fact we have material enough for three or four more like sized volumes.  Since this is only volume one , we can hope for more.Sing-Song the racist Asian stereotype is his faithful sidekick.  He also had the same role for the Calico Kid.  Sing-Song  is actually there for more then just comedy relief as he becomes more of a full partner and helps save the day in some stories.Ray Krank is credited with writing the first Ghost Rider story but most of the others have all been credited to Gardner Fox . Gardner Fox's importance in comics history is closely identified with his work done during the Silver Age of DC Comics.The stories themselves all vary in writing quality but all run a compact six to eight pages.  More story often happens in six pages of these, then in six issues of a current comic.Another thing to remember are these stories are pre-code comics.  For example in the story from Tim Holt #11 it opens with Rex being worked over by some evil American Indians. Our Hero's face is depicted with numerous cuts and blood streaming down his face.  That same story closes with evil Indian being impaled with a jagged wagon wheel spoke.The non-cover artwork is all the work of Dick Ayers.  Ayers of course is remembered for his Sgt. Fury and his other early Marvel work.  In 1967 Marvel brought back the western Ghost Rider but changed his alias to Carter Slade.  Dick Ayers also illustrated that version of Ghost Rider drawing him exactly the same.  While Magazine Enterprises was long dead, I am not sure wether Marvel was in their legal rights to do that.Frank Frazetta is one of the main reasons collectors first sought out this material . The Frazetta covers for Ghost Rider #2 to #5 are all included and a big selling point.I am really hoping we get another volume and really hoping the restoration improves.  Because this is really fun material.

This recent trade paperback includes all the first appearances of Scott Lang as Ant Man in his first three years in comics.  From the years 1979 to 1982.  In total eleven full comics and two small snippets of a story in which Lang makes a mere cameo. The eleven full comics consist of the two issues of the Marvel Premiere debut, four issues of Iron-Man ,three issues of The Avengers and an issue each of Marvel Team-Up and Marvel Two-In-One.If you want to know more about Hank Pym pick up the Ant Man / Giant Man Epic Collection.  But for your Scott Lang fix you need to start here.David Michelinie wrote every single appearance here of Scott Lang except one and deserves all the credit here for molding that character into the form everyone recognizes today.  Most early superheroes where all pretty cookie cutter similar.  But Scott Lang was certainly different , being an ex-convict and a single father of a nine year old daughter.The collection starts out with a four page snippet from Avengers #181 which appeared one month before his costumed debut.  Basically Tony Stark hires Scott Lang to put in a new security system in the Avengers Mansion.Marvel Premiere #47 and #48 is Scott Lang's debut and origin as Ant-Man.  David Michelinie and the great John Byrne on pencils. Scott is released from a three year stint in Prison.  Unlike the movie no attempt is made to "soft sell " his crimes.  He was a burglar and now he is going straight.  The Handbook entry in the back of the book says Scott is divorced but no mentions anex-wife. But she is not seen or mentioned in this story.  Cassie is 9 years old and has been staying with Scott's sister until he is released from Jail.While he intends to follow the straight and narrow path he soon discovers Cassie has some serious Heart conditions.  The one specialist who has a chance of fixing Cassie, Dr. Sondheim is abducted by Cross Technologies.Scott steals the Ant-Man suit from Hank Pym and breaks into Cross Technologies to rescue the doctor.  CEO Darren Cross also has heart conditions but his treatment had transformed him into a pink brutish Hulk.  After everything is resolved Hank Pym (now Yellowjacket ) gives Scott his blessings to continue.Next we get another snippet cameo from Iron-Man #125 .  Scott Lang now working for Stark Industries breaks back into Ryker's Island prison to get something for his boss.In Iron-Man #131 to #134 we get a three part story.  Michelinie and Jerry Bingham on pencils.  Dr. Sondheim and Tony Stark are trying to capture and cure The Hulk in the first two parts.  After the Hulk battle fries Tony's armored suit Ant-Man spends all of #134 inside the suit making repairs.Next is Avengers #195 and #196 a two part story by Michelinie and  legend George Perez.  The story teams up Ant-Man with Yellowjacket and the Wasp. This story introduces the Taskmaster who would become Scott Lang's Arch-nemisis and appear in four issues in this collection. The Taskmaster had the ability to mimic any skill or agility he merely witnessed.  He also heads a school for henchmen in training.In Marvel Team-Up #103 by Michelinie and Jerry Bingham (again) the Taskmaster returns and demonstrates to his Henchmen Class how is it is easy to take down Spider-Man.  But Scott must save the day.In Iron-Man #152 by Michelinie and Luke McDonnell Stark Industries comes under attack.  This is almost an Ant-Man solo story since Iron-Man only appears on a page and a half.Marvel Two-In-One #87 ( the only non Michelinie story ) is by Tom DeFalco and Ron Wilson.  When the The Thing goes to a sub-atomic world Ant-Man is called in for a rescue.Avengers #223 is the final story it is by Michelinie and Greg Larocque.  Hawkeye and Ant-Man team up when it is discovered a carnival had been taken over by a secret villain.  Could it be the Taskmaster yet again ?While I believe the list price is a little steep for a 232 page collection. I can't deny this is some great writing and art and a great way to discover or rediscover this material.So, buy this book , then go see the movie again.  It will make it all the more fun.Highly Recommended.

This handsome oversized trade paperback reprints the almost lost novel of Lester Dent.  Lester Dent was the co-creator and main writer of Doc Savage who's adventures were attributed to Kenneth Robeson , a house name.This long novel was serialized in six parts in the high class pulp magazine Argosy from November 1937 to January 1938.  This novel has sadly never been reprinted since it's inaugural appearance.  Also restored for the first time is a chapter and a half of material accidentally not printed by the publisher.This edition is volume one in Altus Press exciting new Argosy Library reprinting the best of Argosy.  So far ten books have been printed all of equal quality.  This edition features the original Rudolph Belarski cover painting and all the original illustrations done for the pulp version.It also features an excellent introduction by Pulp Historian and Doc Savage current writer Will Murray.  Plus in the back we get Dent's outline for the second never written Genius Jones novel.According to Will Murray in the summer of 1936 the publishers of Doc Savage Street & Smith were planning on the magazine going to a twice a month frequency.  When those plans were put on hold they then had two years worth of stories and Dent was given a reprieve.  So Dent set out to break into the high paying Argosy marketplace.  Which he did with a couple smaller stories and this lone novel.  After six months Street & Smith once more came knocking, and more Doc Savage meant Dent would never return to this equally deserving creation.Genius Jones is the story of a stoic pulp hero raised in the arctic wilderness to superhuman ability who enters the world of 1930's New York with screwball comedic results.Polar Jones and his young son are part of an arctic expedition. When World War I breaks out the German member of the expedition poisons everyone including himself but not young Jones.  Raised by one half crazed member who survived for awhile,  Jones grows up living on seal meat and reading encyclopedias.When they first try to rescue the muscular giant off an iceberg he shoots the rescuer because the man is a German and Jones doesn't know the war has ended.The second attempt is made by Polyphemus Ward one of the ugliest and richest men in the world.  Ward is looking for a successor to give a way his Millions after he is gone.  He has a test for Genius Jones first.  Jones must give away $100,000 to one thousand deserving impoverished individuals.The cast of regulars for this adventure includes Genius Jones new best friend Funny Pegger, a portly comedy writer and Vix, a ravishing red headed girl Friday.For antagonists we have the evil Lyman Lee , Ward's second in command who thinks Ward's fortunes should be his.  Plus Glacia the knockout, voluptuous blonde who is a first rate Gold Digger.  Since Jones has never even met a female trouble ensues.We get a lot of "fish out of water" style comedy , but often Dent sneaks in some sly social commentary.  Dent really is a quite skilled writer and this whole story moves quickly and makes you eager for more.It's too bad Hollywood never encountered this material it would have made a great Scewball Comedy under the direction of Frank Capra or one of his peers.Highly Recommended.

This is a combination of a European high art graphic novel and an American Superhero book.  I believe this book was first printed in France for the European market in 2014, now it has been translated and printed in a style resembling the European Album format by Image Comics.The book itself is gorgeous Hard Cover with a sewn binding and large oversized pages. The European style uses much larger original art and is reproduced much larger.  Most pages therefore contain many more panels and story then an American comic.  So if you reduce it you do the album's art a great disservice.  Thankfully we get the large size here.French writer Xavier Dorison is well known in the Franco-Belgian comic art scene.  His Long John Silver series has drawn raves and he was recently selected as new writer for the legendary barbarian series Thorgal.  Dorison has also done screen writing and film work.Terry and Rachel Dodson are renowned American artists.  They have been all over the Industry working on the top books.  Along with Adam Hughes and Frank Cho, they are considered the best artists in business who can draw beautiful woman.  Terry Dodson pencils and colors, while wife Rachel inks with her very smooth ink brush technique .  Their current Marvel contract allows them to also work in the European market.  Their first effort was for Les Humanoids Muse.It is 1977 and Soviet Superspy Vera Yelnikov has a secret mission, go to the USA and become a Superhero.  She goes to Hollywood and becomes a driver and assistant to a sleazy American Director.  She even has an American secret identity as Alabama Jones.  Because really, who could tell the difference between a southern red neck and a soviet agent .On her first mission she must defeat a right wing moral zealot called The Carpenter.  The Carpenter fights the moral decay by murdering those more liberal then him and literally nailing the offenders down.Although that description sounds pretty brutal , this book is mostly light hearted and PG-13 rated.  Vera appears to have a high sex drive but that action all happens off screen.The Red One's costume is a skin tight red leather outfit which was deliberately created too small so that we see ample cleavage.  For weapons she brandishes a matching Hammer and Sickle made from special alloys.The back pages give us pre-production illustrations and ideas.  In early  incarnations she was known as both The Red Widow and Red Skin.Now for my very minor complaint.  The story is continued.  So please, please purchase this beautiful book so that we get more.  It is priced at a mere $16.99 and you can find it for much cheaper.Highly Recommended.

Donald Westlake became an iconic writer as Richard Stark the writer of the Parker Novels.  Now here back in print,  is the building blocks on which the entire series is built.Clay is a Mob Fixer and right hand man to the boss.  He is a morally ambiguous man in love with a good woman when a heroin addict stumbles in to his apartment in the middle of night. He has been framed for a murder.It is up to Clay to play detective and find out who is the actual killer. He is also at a crossroads in his life because his lifestyle and romance don't mix.Very well written with a break neck pace , this book is Highly Recommended.

I write this on the eve of the multi million dollar big screen debut of Ant Man. This Epic Collection of course is timed to hit right before the movie.  It is a lavish 448 pages of fun reprinting the very earliest adventures of Hank Pym as both Ant Man and then as Gaint Man. All of these stories are from the pages are from Tales To Astonish and first appeared in 1962 to 1964.  In all you get 26 Hank Pym stories , 8 of the Tales Told By the Wasp stories and the behind the scenes Let's Learn About Hank and Jan Back Up.  All under a durable cardboard cover.I read a recent interview with Evangeline Lilly star of the above mentioned Ant Man movie and she says she asked for some Ant Man comics and said that they where awful.  She says she hoped to get her hands on the original material because she knew that it must be better.Well here is a secret Ms. Lilly, while no true fan of Stan Lee or Jack Kirby could ever call this material "awful " it surely does not stand up as fine literature and was a actually one of Marvel's first superhero flops.But I, like most of superhero fandom have come to love the little guy (sometimes big guy) and had a blast reading these clunky but charming 53 year old stories.The very first story was a one off which appeared in January 1962 issue of Tales To Astonish #27.  This comic at the time featured a selection of Weird Monster and Science Fiction stories.  The Man In The Ant Hill was a seven page story which features scientist Henry Pym who invents a solution that when poured on anything makes it smaller.  At no time does Hank become a superhero.  This story owes a lot to the Richard Matheson's novel and subsequent movie The Incredible Shrinking Man from 1956 and 1957 respectively.  The plot is by Stan Lee, script by his little brother Larry Leiber and art by Jack "King" Kirby. This story first appeared the same month as Fantastic Four #2 , so depending on your prospective Ant Man might be considered Marvel's second silver age superhero series. Marvel Comic's Fantastic Four was selling quite well and it was decided more superhero books would sell better.  So ten months after his first appearance in the September 1962 issue of Tales Of Astonish ( #35 ) Henry Pym gets a costume and becomes Ant Man.Ant Man's powers are he can shrink to ant size but remain as powerful as a normal human. He can also talk to ants with use of a special helmet. His formula quickly evolves as the stories go along in the earliest ones he pours a liquid on himself to shrink or grow. In Tales To Astonish #39 it becomes a reducing gas and finally in Tales To Astonish #49 it becomes a capsule they have contained on their belts.In Tales to Astonish #36 Henry Pym's third adventure we are introduced to his most wonky invention and new means of transportation.  A remote controlled giant catapult.  He gets inside and then shoots himself across town to where ever a crime may be happening.  Then it is the job of thousands of ants to form a soft cushion with their bodies for his landing.  I can't help but believe numerous ants would have been killed and maimed in this reckless action.  I expect the movie to leave out "The Ant Catapult ".The first seven stories are all scripted by Larry Lieber from a Stan Lee plot. Jack Kirby on art.  The first stories feature some very lame villains that are either Aliens or Scooby Do styled villains who's identity is revealed at the end of the story.They say you can judge a Superhero by how good his Rogues Gallery of Villains are , well that may be the reason why Henry Pym eventually lost his book.  His are terrible.  Egghead is his arch nemesis and appears in three stories.  In his second appearance Egghead becomes a Zoologist so he can unleash an Ant-Eater on Ant Man. The Human Top also appears in three issues.  The Magican is in two stories and my favorite lame villain the Porcupine is also in two stories.With issue #41 Don Heck would become the regular artist as Kirby was needed elsewhere. I like Don's art quite a bit here , especially when he inks himself.  He displays a fine line style with much more intricate details then his later work.Tales Of Astonish #44 was an important issue for several reasons. First because it introduced Janet Van Dyne and The Wasp.  Strangely the strip up to this point did not have a single reoccurring character except for Henry Pym. She is mere teen ager. While her age is never revealed Hank mentions repeatedly how young she is in these early stories.  In this story it is revealed that Pym had a Russian wife who was killed defecting.  Janet is a very young spitting image of the late Maria Pym . Dr. Vernon Van Dyne comes to visit Hank.  He is Janet's father and a fellow scientist.  Janet's father is then killed by an alien , so on their second meeting Hank asks Janet to become a superhero and avenge his death.Tales To Astonish #44 also marks the debut of a new scripter as H.E. Huntley replaces Larry Leiber for a five issue run.  H.E. Huntley was actually Golden Age Timely Comics writer and artist Ernie Huntley Hart.  Ernie Hart was most famous for his 1943 creation of Timely's funny animal character Super Rabbit.  Hart's stories are more wordy then Lieber's but still followed Stan Lee's wonky plots.Tales Of Astonish #49 is the next important issue.  Stan Lee takes over full writing duties for the first time , Jack Kirby returns to the book for three issues and Hank first becomes Gaint Man.  You can't help but wonder if this wasn't all part of one big push to make the book more successful.Jack Kirby would be inked by the departing Don Heck on Tales Of Astonish#49, then legend Steve Ditko on #50 and finally Dick Ayers on #51.  Dick Ayers then would become the regular penciler for the duration of this volume starting with Tales To.Astonish #52.Lee and Ayers would remain as the creative team for the duration of this collection but Larry Lieber would return as the penciler and scripter of the eight Tales Told By The Wasp series.  Only one of these feature an actual Wasp story ,for the rest the Wasp merely introduces some small sci-fi story.  These are strange stories and we are never told wether we are supposed to believe these stories or wether the Wasp is just fabricating all of them.  They closely resemble the Tales Of The Watcher stories which Larry Lieber also did many of.  The Watcher ones  at least makes a lot more sense with him as a host then the Wasp ones. One wonders if Stan Lee, perhaps had a shoe box full of unused stories from the previous science fiction era and he just gave them to his little brother with the instructions to make this into Wasp and Watcher stories.Tales Of Astonish #57 featured a crossover with Spider-Man and the final story ( #59 ) featured in this collection is the return of The Hulk .  The Hulk would get his own regular feature with the very next issue.  That event would eventually spell the demise of the Giant Man and the Wasp feature.  The Hulk strip would always be the more popular strip and soon Giant Man was replaced with the Sub-Mariner.But for now let us go back in time and revisit these wacky tales from the dawn of the Marvel Age.  Who would have ever have guessed Ant Man would ever get his own movie.Highly Recommended. Fun Awaits.

This is a great pulp hero very much in the style of Edgar Rice Burroughs' John Carter on Mars.  These early pulp adventures are being reprinted once more from the pages of Argosy Magazine complete with an original pulp painting and all the other original pulp line drawings.  It is in a large trade paperback size with easy to read print. So while you can get the material from many sources this is the definitive edition you want to own.Things are not going well for Harry Thorne of Earth.  He is broke and is dumped by girlfriend.  Fortunately he has a chance to exchange bodies with a Martian Prince.  Some day I would like to read a book about the Martian trapped in Harry's body but that may never happened.Harry who happens to be a master fencer,  gets many chances to defend his honor and slay strange creatures in this rousing adventure.  There is also a civil war brewing.  He rides winged Dragon like creatures years before Anne McCaffrey's books.He also meets two beautiful princess and he most choose from them.  Personally I think he made the wrong choice, but I saw the writing on the wall.I am a huge Edgar Rice Burroughs lover so I want to weigh in on the debate about whether Kline was a pale imitation or a worthy successor.  Well this Kline novel is not as good as the best Burroughs, but it certainly is better then some of his later work.I enjoyed the heck out of it .  And remember to buy the Altus Press version.Highly Recommended

Well EuroComics and IDW brought us their excellent first edition of this European Masterpiece in January, now six short months later we get another volume. I hope this means can look forward to another volume around the beginning of the year.  In total this series will be 12 volumes.  EuroComics started with volume 3 , since the earlier material was released recently by another publisher.  That publisher did an inferior production and that material will be correctly done at some future point by EuroComics.Anyways, that makes this volume four.  While you can start with this volume , and it makes perfect sense, I recommend starting with the the third volume since it introduces a few characters you will meet again here.For those of you unfamiliar with Corto Maltese, he is a legend in European Graphic Novels.  Think Tintin , but for adults.  Created by Italian artist Hugo Pratt with a style that influenced many of the American greats.  It is one beautifully composed panel after another of stark black and whites. EuroComics has done a new translation and released it in an oversized edition of that matches the original size.Corto Maltese was a Captain and an explorer who sailed the Islands of the Caribbean and the continent of South America in these early adventures all set in 1917.When last we left our hero he was suffering from Amnesia after being shot in the head. In the first story Mushroom Head Professor Steiner ( Corto's elderly alcoholic companion) seeks to restore his mind.  We meet Levi Colombia a reoccurring character who is a  wealthy Treasure Hunter.  The story concerns a shrunken head of a white man and how it came to be.In the second story Banana Congo, Corto gets caught up in a local revolution and we meet for the first time the beautiful mercenary Venexiana Stevenson.In Voodoo For President we meet back up with the girl who accidentally shot Corto in the head.  She has come to a small island and bought a sugar plantation.  But now she is accused of using Zombies for workers.In the next story Sweet Dream Lagoon , a British deserter is hiding in a South American jungle.  He is deliriously sick and his life is cleverly revealed through a series of fever dreams.In the final story in this volume A Tale Of Two Grandfathers Corto is recruited by Levi Colombia to find a white man's grandson who is half native .  His parents have been killed and It is discovered he is being raised by his other Grandfather, a primitive native.All five of these stories are excellent and each has its own distinct tone.Highly Recommended

This volume collects material from the 1995 to 1998 Dark Horse run of Tarzan.  Tarzan #1 to #20 plus the one shot special A Tale Of Mugambi.  These are some great Tarzan stories done with an All Star cast of creators and priced at under $25 for over 500 pages which makes it is also a great deal.  The production values and the reproduction are top notch and reproduced on slick glossy paper.  Comparing them to Marvel's Epic Collection which also run about 500 pages a volume. But thid is on better paper and can be found for about $10 to $15 cheaper.Now for my two complaints.  First these are reproduced slightly smaller then standard comic size . Not as small as a digest but some where in between digest and standard comic size.  They are completely readable even by me with my ancient eyes,  but I still would have preferred the bigger size even if it warranted a price increase.My second complaint is that includes the covers of only 13 issues out of the 21 possiable covers are reproduced here.  I sure wish the other 8 could have been included here since the covers are a thing of beauty, done by some greats.  You get Arthur Suydam, Igor Kordey, Christopher Schenck, Bernie Wrightson, Mike Kaluta,  Mark Schultz and John Totleben who paints some beautiful pieces for the final story.The book opens with the Mugambi one shot. Mugambi is Tarzan's African friend who plays a large role in Burroughs The Beasts Of Tarzan novel. The story has the feel of Mythology or Legend.  The story comes from a talented pair of Croatians. Darco Macan the writer went on to do much for Dark Horse's Star Wars run.  Artist Igor Kordey you might remember from his work on Grant Morrison's X-Men run.  Kordey's art reminds of a cross between Richard Corben and Frank Quitely.Next comes the longest story of this volume which is Tarzan's Jungle Fury.  It ran six issues of the ongoing Tarzan comic. Written by Bruce Jones one of the greats who emerged from the independent explosion and Pacific Comics.  It was penciled by then newcomer Christopher Schenck and inked by current Prince Valiant artist Thomas Yeates.  Tarzan is accompanied by his French friend Paul D'Arnot on this adventure along with two beautiful woman . A white female doctor and a native princess. The story is about a parasitic plant life which grows wildly inside the human body.  Tarzan has brought this plague back to the jungle after his recent visit to Barsoom.  Jane is one of the first infected and Tarzan most find a cure.The next story Legion Of Hate is four part story written by Allen Gross of Insight Studios.  Schenck stays on for pencils but George Freeman takes over the inking.  Canadian Freeman burst on the scene with Captain Canuck.  His inking is just as good as Yeates, which may be hard to believe.  The story is about Nazi's and the two tribes of Amazon woman Tarzan first encountered in the novel Tarzan The Magnificent.  The Amazons possess a emerald which gives them control over anyone, soon the Nazis  have taken it and are using it for their own diabolical means. These first two stories are very entertaining and faithful to Edgar Rice Burroughs.Next we get three small two part stories written by Canadian colorist Lovern Kindzierski and illustrated by a team of French artists Stan Manoukian and Vince Roucher . All three of these stories take place in 1909.  Since the first Tarzan novel was first published in 1912, I first assumed these to be an error.  But according to Win Scott Eckert's timeline these could be correct.Anyways the stories appear to have happened right after the first Tarzan novel and before the Return Of Tarzan.In the first one Le Monstre, Tarzan and Paul D'Arnot have returned to Paul's native France they briefly encounter Pablo Picasso before the main story which is a retelling of The Phantom Of The Opera with Tarzan.In the second one  The Modern Prometheus, Lord Greystroke arrives in New York and promptly meets Sir Arthur Conan Doyle and Nicholas Tesla.  Then they encounter Thomas Edison who is cast in the Victor Frankenstein role for a retelling of Frankenstein.  While I found the first one to be a clever change of pace , starting with this story I wished they would return to the jungles and lost worlds of Africa.But in the third one Tooth And Nail we get a retelling of Dr Jeckyll and Mr Hyde.  Much to my dismay Tarzan has now become a full fledged Detective, it appears, and he must solve this case.Finally things turn back to status quo in Tarzan Vs. The Moon Men , a four part story which crosses Tarzan over with another world created by Edgar Rice Burroughs.  The world of The Moon Maid and The Moon Men.  This was a very fun treat for me and included an appearance by Korak who falls for a Moon princess.Working on this last story we have an all star cast including Tim Truman scripting,  Thomas Yeates now on pencils and the great Al Williamson inking.All in all this collection includes fantastic art , some great stories and over 500 pages of Tarzan art.  It deserves a place on the shelf of every Edgar Rice Burroughs fan.Highly Recommended.

Well I have been making my way through all the Black Mask Audio series and this is the best yet (at least so far ). Under this great Rafael DeSota pulp cover are one of the first great hard boiled characters beginnings,  a six part collection of interconnected short stories about the first great Asian detective plus a fantastic stand alone story by an almost unknown author.Carroll John Daly is the lost father of hard boiled Detective Fiction.  The man single handedly evented a new genre of fiction. Long before Chandler or Hammett came Daly and his most famous creation Race Williams.  Knights Of The Open Palm is the very first Race Williams story. It is an anti Klu Klux Klan story published in 1923.Next we get six part the Jo Gar story about the thief of nine diamonds.  Written by Raoul Whitfield under the Ramon Decolta alias.  Jo Gar is Spanish Filipino Detective who solved murders and mysteries in 1930's Philippines.  In this one the mystery goes from his native island , to a cruise ship , to Hawaii and San Francisco.  I highly recommend the Atlus Press very thick collection of all the Jo Gar stories.  See my review also on Amazon.The title story The Ring On The Hand Of Death is not part of any series but is really the show stopper of the collection.  It is about a sixteen year old Depression Youth who witnessed a murder. The author William Rollins Jr. was a Marxist and an early out of the closet Homosexual.  Don't let any of that dissuade you this is a great story and not to be missed.Buy this collection, you will not regret it.

The late Mark Gruenwald wrote Captain America for 10 years .  From 1985 to 1995. In Epic Captain America Collection volume 12 we saw the very beginning of Greenwald's run , now in this volume 16 we pick up with Gruenwald's run at the half way point in 1990 and 1991.  Included are Captain America # 372 to #386 (15 issues ) plus Captain America Annuals #9 and #10.Nobody will ever confuse Gruenwald with Alan Moore or this with Watchmen but it is a very fun read.  Gruenwald loved this book and these characters and it is obvious in every story he writes. Gruenwald loved back up stories starring his supporting characters and almost every issue has at least one five page back up.  The Annuals and the triple sized Captain America # 383 have multiple back ups. All of these quirky little stories are included and make this so much more fun.The lead feature is mostly penciled by Ron Lim .  Lim is a prolific artist who made a name for him self during the Indy Boom illustrating Malibu Comics Ex-Mutants.  Inking Ron is Philippine artist Danny Bulanadi who gives it a nice polish.  The back ups are mostly the work of Mark Bagley who is active today.When I remembered that Marvel Annuals at the time mostly featured continued story crossovers that ran in three or more Annuals I was worried we would be treated to incomprehensible story fragments, but that doesn't seem to be too much of a problem. The lead story in Captain America Annual #9 is the very first part of The Terminus Factor.  Written by Roy and Dann Thomas the story is written well enough so that is has an ending , even though it goes on.  We also get a full page text wrap up explaining what happens in the rest of the story.  This is a vast improvement over some of the other Epic Collections from the 90's which have one sentence wrap ups that are worthless.  Art is provided by Jim Valentino done just before he left Marvel to help form Image Comics.  Mark Bagley illustrates a large flashback story with Cap and Bucky meeting the Howling Commandos in WW2. Nomad is the final back up.Comics used to be written for kids.  In the 90's it was still believed that kids formed the majority of readers.  Kids are off school for the summer ,so Marvel had many of their books go bi-weekly during the summer.  Streets Of Poison is the bi-weekly Captain America story for 1990. It actually goes over by one month and runs seven issues Captain America #372 to #378.  The story involves Red Skull and his lieutenant Crossbones distributing the drug Ice. He is opposed by rival drug lord the Kingpin and his lieutenants Bullseye and Typhoid Mary.Since for a large portion of the story Cap is under the influence of the Drug Ice he ends up battling some heroes also including his girlfriend Diamondback plus the Black Widow and Daredevil.The back up story for these same 7 issues is the patriotic garbed superhero Battlestar.  Battlestar meets USAgent and gets captured by the Power Broker who first gave both of them their powers.  Gosh, I love Gruenwald's quirky superhero creations.  My favorite is portly hero dressed in scarlet spandex.  The Red Zeppelin.Captain America #379 is by Guest penciler Chris Marinnan. It teams Cap with Quasar,  Gruenwald's other long term series.  They battle Nefarius who has kidnapped Moonstone. The back up switches to Diamonback and sets up the next three part arc.Captain America #380 to #382 is Serpent Society three parter about Diamondback being put on trail by the Society. Diamondback is unsure of Cap's loyalty and so she recruits Paladin.USAgent takes over the back up for Captain America #380 to #383 It starts out as just an origin story but turns disturbingly dark as you realize Johnny Walker (USAgent ) is mentally unstable and tortured his fellow heroes.Besides the final USAgent story,  Captain America #383 is triple sized 50th Anniversary issue.  The lead story I think was Gruenwald's attempt to do something like Jack Kirby's Bicentennial Battles issue. In the story Cap meets imaginary heroes of American Folk Lore. This is pretty stupid story who's explanation and Hawkeye reveal makes no sense.  My favorite story in this issue is the Red Skull story which explains how Skull and Crossbones first met.Captain America #384 is the only issue without a back up and a done in one issue.  Captain America finds out a fellow hero is trapped in ice so he goes to explore thinking it is his former side kick D-Man.  Well it turns out to be Golden Age Hero Jack Frost.Captain America #385 and #386 features two returning characters from the Stern /Bryne run on Cap. Bernie Rosenthal re-enters Cap's life and has changed her mind about a life with Steve Rogers.  Mike the Fireman some how gets involved in a some militant group called The Watchdogs.In the back up Diamondback returns in a back up story designed to prepare us for the next six week bi-weekly summer storyline which sadly is not included.Instead we finish with Captain America Annual #10.  It starts with part three of the Von Strucker Gambit.  While the story was not to my liking it does have some nice Mike Manley art.Next we get two solo stories for two members of Gruenwald's Serpent Society. Bushmaster and Sidewinder get their own tale.The Bushmaster one is excellent and features some of the last art done by Marvel Legend Don Heck.The final annual tale is by Fabian Nicieza and is warm up for his Nomad ongoing series.The back matter consists of stuff done for Marvel Year In Review, some copies of original art and the Marvel Age interviews with Jack Kirby and Joe Simon.The cover of this book by Ron Lim and Jim Lee and is great.Mark Gruenwald who died in 1996 at the age of 43 left us with a legacy of ten years of Cap books and you can feel his love of Cap and all his wacky, goofy characters on every page.  I look forward to the next Gruenwald Epic Collection.Highly Recommended.

Well like clockwork the Prince Valiant oversized strip collections have been appearing twice a year around June and December and each is a cause of celebration.  Volume 11 lovingly reproduces another two year's worth of strips.  This volume from 1957 and 1958.Even though I bought all the paperback editions Fantagraphics did years ago, these Hard Covers are an improvement in both reproduction and value being twice as large.The accompanying text pieces this volume feature the advertising art of Hal Foster and the firm he first worked for.  Brian M Kane does an article about the advertising executive Reinhold Palenske , a brilliant artist in his own rite.  While the afterward focuses on Hal Foster's advertising art he did for Palenske-Young.When we join this volume Hal Foster had been doing the strip for twenty years (1937) and Valiant was married with three kids. Arn,  a pre-teen youth and the twin girls Karen and Valeta just emerging from the toddler age.The book bookends with Prince Valiant going in disguise.  In the opening storyline as a Palmer.  A Palmer is a medieval  crusader who had been to the Holy Lands.  Then as we wind up the volume Val is disguised as a Minstrel in a quest to find the missing Sir Gawain.In between we get a bunch of great stories including the story of how Prince Valiant first discovers his great red stallion , the war horse Arvak.  Prince Valiant's crest has always featured a red steed now he has a living totem.Young Arn is also fostered off to another kingdom.  Arn experiences loneliness and meets his foster sister Frytha.  While Arn finds Frytha  quite lovely she is nicknamed The Monster for  the evil pranks the spoiled girl pulls.Meanwhile Aleta and the twins make their first arrival at Camelot. The Beautiful Aleta encounters jealously from Queen Guinevere and needs to resolve that problem.In one of the most touching and heart breaking stories Valiant acquires two teen age squires. One of them a reckless, brave youth meets a very grisly demise. Wracked with grief Prince Valiant goes on a rampage.As always Hal Foster demonstrates a wide diversity in stories.  While the majority of it is rousing adventure we do get moments of quiet family life , romance and even mysticism as Merlin makes an appearance.This beautiful volumes deserve to sit on the shelf of every true comic fan.  The illustrations of Hal Foster need to be savoured by all for years to come.My Highest Recommendation.

This version of the Maltese Falcon is the exact version that was serialized in Black Mask magazine in 1929.  It seems with each version Dasheil Hammett changed it and polished it up some.  Since it was serialized over a period of months each new installment featured a what has gone on before recap.  In the trade paperback version you have the luxury of skipping over these recaps and it might become monotonous.  I listened to it in my car while driving locally over a period of a week so I didn't mind the constant recaps.By the way if you are a big fan of the 1941 Humphrey Bogart classic give the the first version a try.  It has Richardo Cortez as Sam Spade.  Since it came out in 1931 before they movie code went into effect it is quite racy for it's time.  Satan Was A Lady is the second (1936) version and not as good with a more comedic take. But it does have Betty Davis in it.The narration is very good.  This is a six disc set . The Maltese Falcon is 5 and a half discs then you have two very small short stories. The better of them was written by Frederick Brown . Brown was mostly know for his science fiction but he was a master of the short, short.Recommended

This collection contains Fantastic Four #176 to #191.  Cover dated November 1976 to February 1978.  If you do your math you would think you are getting Sixteen issues.
