But sadly you only get Fourteen full issues because two of them are total reprints with only the new covers included in this collection.  Story wise the first half of the book was mostly Roy Thomas while the back half was mostly Len Wein.  But since both of them seemed to be having trouble making deadlines we had many other writers helping out.  The penciling features Nine stories by George Perez, Three by Sal Buscema and Two from Ron Wilson.  Inking was Joe Sinnott for twelve  issues with Dave Hunt and Tony DeZungia each inking one issue a piece.This is the first time ( I believe ) Marvel has gone with the split introductions.  Roy Thomas talks about his involvement with the first half of the book then hands it off to Len Wein.  But instead of following suite Len just tells a story of discovering FF #1 on the newsstands as a boy.Roy kicks off things in a big way with FF #176 which was the re-introduction of Impossible Man. This was a wacky fun ride with the FF meeting the Marvel Bullpen.  Featured in the Bullpen is Stan Lee, Jack Kirby, Roy Thomas, George Perez, Joe Sinnott,  John Verpooten, Marv Wolfman, Gerry Conway,  Marie Severin and Archie Goodwin.  Jack Kirby penciled this cover (one of four in this collection) and probably deserves a plotting assist credit.  Jack drew the Impossible Man with his two hands looking like Iron-Man and Thor,  when Roy and George saw this they changed the story to include this scene.  The Impossible Man was created way back in FF #11 , at the time of his appearance he was dismissed by fans who hated this cartoony green alien.  Stan had forbidden his return.  But Roy not only brought him back but he made him a regular character of the FF's supporting cast.  Fortunately for Roy fandom had changed over the years and they now loved the little green imp.Fantastic Four #177 was an equally fun and zanny romp.  The Frightful Four ( currently three ) were holding try-outs for their fourth member.  Not since The Legion Of Substitute Superheroes have we seen such wacky doings.Now here is a mystery and an error I discovered and hope to set straight.  If you look at the writers credits in the front of the book you will see Mike Friedrich listed as a writer for FF #178.  Wow I couldn't find anything to back this up.  After burning up the internet and not finding anything , I decided to unbag my original copy of FF #178 .  There on the letters page was my answer.  Mike Friedrich had nothing to do with FF#178 , but he in  fact co-plotted FF #177 with Roy.  And in fact Mike Friedrich created the best of the try-out heroes, Captain Ultra and The Texas Twister according to an acknowledgement from Roy.  This fact is not mentioned by Roy in the introduction,  but he did write thousands of pages of comics, so I am sure he can not recollect every detail.  His memory is still much better the Stan's.FF #177 also introduces Tigra and the returning Thundra as regular supporting characters along side The Impossible Man .  At least until Len Wein comes on board.  Both of these girls experience unrequited love for Ben Grim , a funny change of pace.FF #178 is where things starting go bad for Reed , he previously lost his stretching ability.  Now the Reed Richards from counter earth ( he is also a purple monster called the Brute) takes his place on the team and the original is tossed into the Negative Zone.In the continuation of this story in FF #179 Gerry Conway comes on board to plot the story and script the first three pages for Roy.  Ron Wilson also comes on board to illustrate two issues.  As inked by Joe Sinnott the art still looks pretty good.Issue #180 is a reprint of Bedlam At The Baxter Building from FF #101.  Here is where things get wonky.  The cover for #180 was clearly meant for FF #179 since it depicts events from that issue.  My guess is that since it was a Jack Kirby piece it didn't come in from the west coast in time for FF #179 , so they had Al Milgrom whip a different version.But in the meantime what to do with cover John Romita had done for the reprint issue.  Well they used it for FF #181 which would sadly be the last we would see of Roy for awhile.  Clearly he was having deadline problems and his commitment to Conan and Savage Sword Of Conan won out.  Reed is still stuck in the Negative Zone but now he must team up with Annihilus.Sal Buscema does the art for the next two issues  FF # 182 and #183,  which finishes up the counter earth Reed Vs. Reed in the Negative Zone saga.  The first part is cobbled together by committee.  Len Wein, Jim  Shooter and Archie Goodwin plot it with Bill Mantlo scripting it.  Mantlo gets solo credit for the second part.In Fantastic Four #184  Len Wein starts his run with the missing George Perez he hasn't done the book for five months.  This is the start of a good three part story FF #184 through FF #186 dealing with Witches and New Salem.It starts when Nanny, Agatha Harkness disappears with young Franklin Richards in tow.  First we meet the Elminator , then Agatha's power mad son Nicholas Scratch finally an entire team of witchcraft powered superheroes called Salem's Seven.FF  #187 and FF #188 is a good two parter with two classic villains teaming up. Klaw and The Molecule Man. Of course as is the theme of this volume things go badly for Reed as he is transformed into The Molecule Man.  The Watcher and the returning Impossible Man guest star.  At the end of this story a depressed Reed announces he is leaving the team.  Sue follows him.Well during the introduction Len admits he was currently writing Spider-Man, The Hulk and Thor at the time this was assigned to him and a week behind on all of them .  So I imagine the deadline got to him for FF #189 was yet another reprint issue, the 2nd in 9 Months.Apparently that wasn't enough time for Len and George because FF  # 190 appears to be a quickie fill in issue.  The only really good thing about this issue is the Jack Kirby cover. The story is by Marv Wolfman with very rushed looking art from Sal Buscema and Tony DeZungia. I got the feeling this whole thing was put together in under a week.  It is now revealed the whole team is breaking up . We see Ben with Alicia Masters reminiscing about a dozen random past battles.  This is low point for the volume .We end on a better story in FF #191 .  Wein and Perez reunite for the final story of the team breaking up.  The Plunderer pops up towards the end just so the FF can get together and fight someone.The extras are very slim this volume with only the editorial page from FF #176 reprinted.In Summation despite the lack of consistency from the creators I found this volume to be ,with one exception ,a lot of fun and the art of Perez and Sinnott is simply fantastic.My Highest Recommendation.

Thank you Library Of American Comics for this volume.  While I have the early Sunday strips in collections from three different publishers , I have yet to find a collection of the dailies.This is a fantastic collection of the very first adventure newspaper comic strip.  These strips first appeared over 85 years ago in 1929 and 1930.  The original plan was for them to adapt each Tarzan novel separately and sell them each as unique series.  The plan included each novel would be adapted over a period of 10 weeks or 60 individual strips.  Later in fear of exhausting source material it was decided that they might stretch out continuities past the ten week limit.This volume features the first four novels of Tarzan collected or about a years worth of material.While the Library Of American Comics Essentials was launched with much bravado , I wonder about it's continued success.  The wait time between volumes has increased and no future volumes past this seventh have been announced.  Also we have gotten two price increases.  The list on first volumes was $19.99 , then it was $24.99 , now they are $29.99.Well even at that price I still think they are a perfect format to display an older strip which needs the space.  One daily strip to a page is like reading a Hard Cover Collection in which some collector has found pristine original strips and cut out each one and carefully bound them together.The nine page illustrated introduction by Burroughs expert Henry G. Franke III is worth the price of the book alone.  He is very insightful and I learned a lot.If I have one complaint with this volume is that it could have been enlarged even more.  Each daily was composed of five individual panels each with a paragraph of text under each one.  The text is really small by current standards.  Just to clarify these early strips  just like the Tarzan Sunday's and the Prince Valiant Sunday's feature no word balloons, just text beneath illustrations.  Starting with the second novel only 4 panels were used, this made it easier to read.The first adaptation of Tarzan Of The Apes is adapted by Ralph W. Palmer . Palmer in fact adapted all the stories included here. The art was by Hal Foster, who was at the time just another advertisement artist and this was just another assignment.  Foster had no realization he would later become the premiere action adventure comic strip artist in the field and it would bring him fame, money and recognition.The 300 panels Hal Foster contributed to the first novel's adaptation are brilliant and rich in details. But since Foster had other advertising work to do another artist was chosen for the second story.The Return Of Tarzan followed after a three month gap.  Like the first  story it is 60 strips but now a reasonable 4 panels a page.  Rex Maxon was the artist selected.If you are familiar with Rex Maxon you have probably have heard stories vilifying him.  Poor Rex Maxon was actually a pretty good artist and this volume should rectify that impression.  First off he had to follow in the shoes of now legendary Hal Foster and then second because Maxon was not immediately available an artist named Hugh Hutton ghosted the first strips.  Burroughs and his artistic son Jack hated these first strips and would spend a lot of time trying to get Maxon removed from both this and the later Sunday Tarzan strips.  Neither realizing that their initial impression was based on art that was not even Maxon.  The introduction says Maxon tried to correct Hutton's art.  The first daily to carry Maxon name was episodes six.Maxon art continued to improve on the third and fourth novels adapted here.  It should be noted that from Maxon's start there would be no more three month wait between adaptations.  One would finish on a Saturday and come Monday a new adventure would start.With Burroughs permission The Beasts Of Tarzan was 84 dailies while The Son of Tarzan ran 96 dailies.With this volume finished we still have decades full of Tarzan dailies that deserve to be reprinted.  I have high hopes for the success of both the LOAC Essentials format and the continuation of Tarzan.My Highest Recommendation.

I first heard about this book at the Windy City Pulp Convention where author Ron Fortier who had read an advance copy was extolling it's virtues. The idea of the late Mickey Spillane and Max Allen Collins writing a western got me very interested and I pre-ordered it upon returning home.The origin of the novel has been covered in other reviews ,but more importantly in Collins own introduction.  So here is the short version.  Mickey Spilliane was friends with John Wayne . Wayne asked Spilliane to write a screenplay for him. For various reasons It was never produced.  Max Allen Collins took the screenplay and converted it to novel form.I am a very late convert to the virtues of the western . Like Collins himself I have read very few Westerns. Also like Collins I enjoy the movie cowboys such as the movies of Anthony Mann and Sergio Leone.I mention those two directors for a reason.  This novel reminds me of both. The story structure reminds me of one of those good old fifties Westerns (Which is when this was first crafted ).  But then we get some of modern ultraviolence like in a spaghetti western.  I think the violence is more of the tough , hard boiled style of Spilliane and Collins brought over from their crime books rather then any spaghetti western influence which didn't even exist when the screenplay was written.The story hits a lot of classic Western troupes. A town held hostage by the evil sheriff, the misguided harlot , the beautiful but spunky ranchers daughter and the town drunk who proves himself in the end.And of course the stranger . The loner with the mysterious past who rides into town just as things have escalated to a breaking point.This book will not change your life but it is good old fashioned fun.Max Allen Collins has a contract to write at least two more novels. He has recently completed his second Caleb York novel, The Big Showdown. It is more to form , a murder mystery story.Sales of this introductory novel have been rather slow , so I encourage any fence sitters to purchase this book now so we can continue to enjoy the adventures of Caleb York.Highly Recommended.

This handsome hardcover collects the Rip Kirby strips from October 1964 through July 1967.  We get over  two and half years reproduced in crisp black and white on heavy white paper.Labeled the first modern detective the strip started in 1946 by master illustrator Alex Raymond. After his tragic death in 1956, John Prentice was selected to continue the strip. And continue it, he did . It ran till 1999.John Prentice it turned out was also an excellent artist in his own right . His fine line art was three times the recipient of  National Cartoonist Society award for Story Comic Strip. The first two years he won 1966 and 1967 are featured in this very volume.It's no secret that most adventure strips relied heavily on ghosts, assistants or background artists.  In volume seven Al Williamson contributed a lot. In this volume the talented Alden McWilliams helped out some in 1964 and 1965.  Then in 1966 following his firing at DC comics Superman artist Wayne Boring was hired by Prentice to help.Fred Dickenson writes the stories featuring a variety of different genres.  We get straight detective, action adventure, soap opera, romance and even a wild science fiction romp.Comic historian and fellow comic creator Brian Walker continues his series of Introductions with more information about Prentice accompanied by some early Prentice work from the Romance Comics genre.The stories featured in this volume are :1) The Planted Butler.  This is an adventure which draws heavily on Desmond.  Desmond is former safe cracker reformed by Rip who becomes his butler and loyal companion.  Desmond is featured in all of the included stories.2) In The Hands Of The Avenger.  This is a story set in the middle east about a Sheik friend of Kirby who asks for help with his arrogant son.3) The Gibson Girl.  In this story Prentice is able to take Rip back to the early 1900's without using time travel.  It is a story about an actress filming a movie about a turn of the century murder. She insists everyone must stay in character so we get Rip in old fashioned clothes driving a horse and buggy.  Rip must find out who is threatening the actress as well as solve the original case.4)  A Hundred Fathoms Dead.  This is my second favorite story which features great art and an action adventure reminiscent of Thunderball. You get panels with beautiful underwater scenes, lost sunken treasures, beautiful girls in swimsuits and a maniacal villain.5) The Chameleon Strikes. In this story we meet a character from Rip's past who is a master of disguise.6) Is There, In Truth, No Beauty ?  This was my least favorite of the volume simply because it is based on a very wobbly foundation. It assumes that a beautiful woman who puts up her hair up and wears glasses becomes an ugly duckling. The story does introduce a new cast member though as Rip adopts Lucky a beagle.7)  An Old Detective In New Atlantis .  While this story may have upset many Detective purist it is my favorite.  This story is pure Sci--Fi schlock with it's spaceships and time travel and a futuristic princess who needs Rip's help. The art has many fans wondering whether Al Williamson or Alden McWilliams were involved, but instead my research indicates it is from the time when Wayne Boring first became involved.8) The Wheeler Dealer . This is a story set on a cruise ship about a pretty gal involved in a plan to swindle millionaires out of money.9) Mission: Find That Girl.  In this story Rip meets yet another gal with questionable morals.  She starts out as a fake gypsy and ends up being sought by a murderer.10)  The Hairpin Escapade.  While I was disappointed by the lack of an appearance by either of Rip Kirby's main two love interests Honey Dorian and Pagan Lee, I was delighted by the return of the Amour Sisters who appeared in a volume six story  competing for Rip's affections. They are rich,  but spoiled siblings.  The lovely brunette Mumu and here equally enticing blonde sister Tutu. This is mostly a comedic story about a stolen crown.  Desmond and his fellow butler Wiggins play a large role.11)  The Troubles Of Nelson Chatfield.  I found this story very unique in its very extended set-up.  You don't even see Rip until almost four weeks into the story.  The story itself is about an owner of a luxury Island resort who starts experiencing a series of negative incidents.The Library Of American Comics and IDW released the Alex Raymond four volumes in rapid order. Then as an experiment they released a John Prentice volume, to see if the market would support it.  These books, I understand,  barely break even  But it is labor of love for LOAC head honcho Dean Mullaney and he has said as long as they don't loose money, he will keep publishing them.  So once a year for the last four years we have now been treated to an annual new edition.Please support these handsome collections so that they will keep producing them.  This is worthwhile addition to the library of every true fan of classic comic strips.  I urge your purchase, so that we may keep enjoying this wonderful series.My Highest Recommendation.

Shortly after the announcement of A Guardians Of The Galaxy movie marvel decided to reboot the comic in 2013 putting their A-listers on the book Brain Michael Bendis and Steve McNiven in 2013. This oversized collection reprints the contents of the first two trades or 12 comics.  Over 300 pages of mostly beautiful comic art.  Plus all the covers and numerous alternate covers are reproduced.The lead story from GOTG #0.1 tells the origin of Star Lord. It is brilliant and starts things off with a bang.For some reason Bendis puts Iron Man on the team. The rest of the team includes all the favourites we would get to know from the movie Star Lord, Gamora, Drax, Groot and Rocket Raccoon.  There has been lots of discussion about whether Tony Stark belongs on the team or not.  Personally I am rather neutral on the matter . I don't think he adds much but I am not upset about his presence here.Star Lord argues with his father and then the gang intercepts Angela, who they think may be attacking Earth.  Angela is Neil Gaiman's Valkyrie like fallen Angel created for Image Comics in Spawn #9 in 1993.  So after a lawsuit and Two Decades she is back .  This is a mildly entertaining story certainly not worth all the build up.In issue #2 Sara Pichelli joins McNiven on art . She is an equally talented artist who also produces beautiful art. But in issue #8 and #9 fellow Italian artist Francesco Francavilla takes over. I love Francavilla's art on his prior assignments which are mostly gritty pulp characters and the heavy blacks adds lots of mood.  In this book it is jarring contrast to polished detailed art of McNiven and Pichelli. It just doesn't work.Issue #10 brings Kevin Maguire on for the issue.  Maguire is a much better fit .Unfortunately the second half of the book plays off the one of Marvel's big events "Infinity".  Having not read that book I have no idea what is going on and quickly found myself losing interest.  Why Marvel finds the need to force these events on their readers is a matter too big for this review.The book closes out with four short solo stories of mixed quality. I enjoyed the Groot and Rocket Raccoon stories but was bored by the Drax and Gamora stories.In summary I loved much of the art. I was very excited by the inaugural story and was having a good time till the crossover hit and then I became confused and frustrated.

This is one of Robert Heinlein Juvenile Science Fiction novels written in 1957.  The fact that is 58 years old and the fact that it was written for young boys are two facts I had a hard time believing as I read this complex, but highly entertaining story of one boys journey from slave to one of the most important men in the universe.Thorby the lead protagonist boyhood is told as he lives among four completely different cultures.  When the book opens he is slave . He is sold to a crippled beggar who is secretly much more.  Next he boards a spaceship  and becomes a part of a trader society.  Then he becomes part of military organization.  Finally he returns to Earth to find out that he is an important member of a powerful giant corporation.The book deals with Economics, Poltics, Morality, Freedom and many complex issues that might not be easily digested by adults let alone minors.I listened to Blackstone Audio version which is excellently narrated by Grover Gardner . The only jarring problem I found is he uses many multinational accents to represent different alien races.  So you might here an alien with a middle eastern accent or an extraterrestrial with a southern drawl.Highly Recommended

This will be a short review because there are 66 other reviews and in all likelihood no one will ever read it.This is one of the very earliest Hard Case Crime Books written under an alias by publisher Charles Ardai.  It was nominated for both an Edgar and a Shamus award. It is every bit as good as the classic Hard Boiled fiction from people like Lawrence Block,  Donald Westlake and Earl Stanley Gardner.The cover is by the master of Femme Fatale paperback covers Robert McGinnis and I love his work but something about the anatomy of this woman looks all wrong. The leg is way too long and in an impossible position.I solved the surprise twist ending about 2/3 of the way through the book which made me wonder about the intelligence of the protagonist, but still I had enough fun that it has made me eager to read it's sequel.Recommended.

Thank You Titan Publishing for continuing to publish one of the greatest adventure comic strips of all time.  We are in the home stretch to completion which will run either 30 or 31 volumes. It seems Titan has settled in to a schedule with a new volume arriving every six months.This volume once again features the excellent writing of the late Peter O'Donnell and the skillful fine line work of Enric Badia Romero.  Once again we get three complete stories which ran over sixteen months from February 1994 till May 1995.New for this volume is Rick Norwood who takes over the introductions from Lawrence Blackmore.  Mr. Norwood is the publisher of Comics Revue and the editor many fine classic comic strip collections. He is a wise choice and provides three delightful introductions for the three stories.Guido The Jinx is the first story and my favorite of this collection, and not just because it features Modesty in a Cave Girl bikini for the duration.  Modesty and faithful sidekick Willie Garvin decide to travel the historic Silk Road which runs between China and the Mediterranean just for kicks. They meet a movie production company and get talked into being stunt actors.  Will there they encounter a few characters from their past and we get a highly entertaining story.In The Killing Distance things get much more serious when Modesty discovers a contract has been taken out for the death of their boss Sir Gerald Tarant.  Modesty and Willie must discover who it is and find a means to stop "the hit".In the final story The Aristo ,our heroes encounter modern pirates and a young hostage about to give birth.What I always love about O'Donnell's writing is the variety of stories he can tell and this volume is no exception. For those new to Modesty you can really start with any volume.  My Highest Recommendation.

This Epic Collection features some wonderful stories from the Roy Thomas's very fertile imagination . 450 pages of some of the best Avengers tales ever told . In crisp white paper with vibrant colors this book lovingly reproduces Avengers #57 to Avengers #76 , plus the Black Knight solo story from Marvel Superheroes #17.  Twenty one comics from the years 1968 to 1970.The writing is all Roy Thomas .  Stan's right hand man had broke out of his shell and was producing better work then his creative boss. Art wise we have some very polished work by John Buscema and Gene Colan.  Two veterans at the top of their game. Also included is some very early work from Barry Smith and Sal Buscema. Plus a one shot story from two Golden Age artists Frank Giacoia and Howard Purcell.This Epic Collection was timed to coincide with the Avengers second movie, and in fact the day I came home from the movie the box containing this volume was on my door step. I was very excited to re-read this introduction to the Vision.Avengers #57 and Avengers #58 break down as single stories each with having their own endings but combined they give you a fuller introduction to the Vision. In the first book Ultron creates the Vision , and the Avengers defeat Utron. In the second story the Avengers consider the ramifications of accepting The Vision as a member.For these two stories and the next one John Buscema is beautifully inked by George Klein.  Klein was a Golden Age artist who did much early Timely Comic work before heading to DC in 1955. He became one of DC's mainstays inking a lot of Curt Swan and Superman Family books.  In 1968 not yet Editor-in-chief Carmine Infantino was instructed to fire some of old dead wood and bring in fresh talent.  Klein was fired with six others including Superman co-creator Jerry Siegel.  Stan gave Klein work for the remainder of his career.The next story in Avengers #59 and #60 is almost as famous as the first one . It introduces Yellowjacket and the wedding of Janet and Hank. Mickey Demeo who inked the second part was Mike Esposito under an alias.Avengers #61 is a single issue story which not only brings back inker George Klein but The Black Knight and guest star Doctor Strange in his full face mask costume.Avengers #62 is another classic story which focus on The Black Panther and introduces his new nemesis The Man-Ape.Avengers#63 and #64 is yet another famous yarn in which Clint Barton becomes the focus of the story when Clint uses Hank Pym's growth serum and  becomes Goliath. Old Ant-Man foe Egghead shows up and we meet Clint's brother.  Gene Colan starts his brief three issue run.In Avengers #65 the man who trained Hawkeye , The Swordsman returns. More great Gene Colan art.In Avengers #66 through #68 Ultron returns becoming an even a bigger and badder menace.  The first two issues are done by a very young Barry Smith who's early art very much emulates Jack Kirby style with a touch of Steranko thrown in.  Avengers #67 was one of  George Klein's final jobs as he died shortly after.  In #68 Sal Buscema makes his Avengers  penciling debut.  At this point Sal had only done one other penciling job for Marvel a Gunhawks story for Marvel's Western anthology.  Despite this, his work here looks very polished. I don't know if John Buscema actually pitched in or if Sal who was inking his big brother on Silver Surfer just absorbed all his style.Avengers #69 through #71 is a three parter which brings back Kang and ads an important new villain called The Grandmaster.  The two engage in a battle of cosmic chess when in the first two issues the Avengers battle the Squadron Sinister.  The Sinister Squadron are analogs for DC's Justice League.  The Squadron Sinister then begot The Squadron Supreme , which became lasting heroes in the Marvel Mythology.  In the final part of the story The Avengers must then fight an early version of the Invaders.In Avengers #71 and #72 they battle Scorpio and His Zodiac Crew, who have been threatening Nick Fury.  Nick , Rick Jones and Captain Marvel quest star.  #72 concludes Sal's first Avengers assignment.Avengers #73 and #74 focuses on The Black Panther and The Sons the Serpent return in a story about race relations.  Frank Giacoia draws the first part and John Buscema returns as regular artist for second part.  The story features some heavy handed politics.Starting with Issue #74 John Buscema is paired with his perfect partner Tom Palmer. Palmer's fine line and cross hatching just made the art "pop".The final two part story Avengers #75 and #76 introduces Arkon , a Sword and Sorcery Hero who serves as a test run for Roy's run on Conan a half a year later.  The Scarlet Witch and Quicksilver also return in this very entertaining story. I kind of like the romance between Wanda and Arkon.The book closes with the Black Knight story from Marvel Superheroes #17. The reprint book at the time featured a new lead story every issue  in a pilot type way like DC's Showcase. Howard Purcell produces some rather bland art for Roy's uninspired tale.Extras for this volume are a pair of unused covers and some original art.With the possible exception of Black Knight tale , this is some of Roy's best and most creative work.  I had read many of these stories as an 11 and 12 year old boy and I am happy to say I found them just as entertaining today.My Highest Recommendation.

Written in 1961 by Lawrence Block under a pseudonym this gritty novel is dripping in plulpy noir.I double dipped on this one.  I bought the paperback when it came out but decided to purchase the AudioGo unabridged CD , when I saw it being remaindered at Half Price Book.It is a very fun read and follows five different men who are hired to assassinate Fidel Castro shortly after he comes into power.  The story takes turns following the five would be murders with a factual history of Castro's rise to power mingled in.  But Block decides not to totally follow history, so this becomes an alternate history. I am not going to reveal when this happens because it will totally ruin a surprise.I have been making my way through both the Hard Case Crime books and the novels of Lawerence Block with a goal of reading them all. So far I have yet to be disappointed by either.Recommend.

While every adventutre comic strip fan knows about Alex Raymond's legendary run on Flash Gordon and Jungle Jim , not everyone is aware of run on this daily strip which he started mere weeks after Flash Gordon in 1934.  This collection features not only the entire Raymond run but 11 months of Charles Flanders rarely seen strips . More then 800 daily strips or almost 3 years  (34 months) of strips.The writing is by two of Mystery Fiction's biggest names.  Dashiell Hammett the founder of Hard Boiled and author of the Maltese Falcon and The Thin Man.  And later Leslie Charteris author of the Simon Templar, The Saint stories.The series was started by King Features to compete with Dick Tracy which started in 1931 and was having phenomenal success.  The comic syndicate spent a lot of time putting together what they thought would be the perfect team.  Hammett was a literary giant at the top of his success and Raymond a virtually new and untested talent.  Although the series never delivered the quantity of readers they had hoped for, it ran until 1996.  American Comics Library has previously released the 13 year run written by Archie Goodwin and beautifully illustrated by Al Williamson. These later strips ran under the revised title as Secret Agent Corrigan.  Also just recently announced is the continuation of Archie Goodwin's run starting in 1980 with artist George Evans.Reading these early strips you can see for yourself  their origins.  Dasheill Hammett did four storylines for Secret Agent X-9.  The first story ran a rambling 9 months.  Every succeeding story was shorter.  The second story was a compact three months, the third was even shorter while the final one ran a mere 5 weeks.If there is a problem with these early stories , it is the fault of writer Hammett and not artist Raymond who produced panel after panel of beautiful art.To be fair to Hammett had had no experience in this field.  He also was battling Alcoholism and found a much better source of income that came pouring in from Hollywood after he had already committed to this project.The introduction suggests Hammett based his writing here on the early hero pulp novels of such characters as The Shadow and Doc Savage.  But to my knowledge they more resemble the more disjointed writing of a Movie Serial or Chapter Play.In the first story they jump back and forth from a simple murder, to a pirate episode, then back to a state side drama involving a secret mob boss called The Top.  As X-9  encounters pirates who plan to steal two million dollars in gold bullion from a Luxury Cruise Ship.  What the gold is doing on this type of  boat is not explained.  After the gold is moved to the pirate ship it is bombed by X-9.  Everyone congratulates him completely forgetting about the gold.  When this story finally ends the big reveal of The Top is anti-climatic.The second storyline once again features a secret bad guy named the Mask.  The story ramps up the action as we travel to a ranch in Wyoming.Finally in the third story we get two panels in which Secret Agent X-9 talks about his past . Until then the reader knows nothing about him not even his real name.  He goes by the name Mr. Dexter but we are told that is not his name.After the short fourth Hammett story Don Moore ( the scripter of Flash Gordon and Jungle Jim ) comes in to help Raymond for two stories.  But it seems the syndicate was not happy and hired yet another big name writer.  King Features next hired British Mystery writer Leslie Charteris who had moved to the USA in 1932 to start a career in screen writing.Charteris wrote four Agent X-9 with only the first one being illustrated by Alex Raymond.  The other three included here are by the above mentioned Charles Flanders.  These three stories are new to me and rarely seen.  While Charteris would only spend a little over a year on the strip ,this experience would help him out when The Saint would get his own comic strip in 1948.  That strip would last for 13 years.The failure for this strip to become the success it seemed destined for is often attributed to duo nature of the character sometimes being just a straight detective story then becoming a wild secret agent at times.  The organization X-9 reported to was initially just a secret government agency, but then became the FBI during the years in which the FBI was highly respected. In later years when the FBI fell out favor , X-9 once again just reported to a Secret Government Agency.Re-Reading the strips , I think the biggest problem with the strip is the total lack of any personality for Mr. Dexter and the total lack of any other reocurring supporting characters or villains.I think the first story should have had a flash back to his very tragic origin giving the reader some emotional resonance instead of him being just a generic action hero. This would have helped greatly.  Also a cast of reoccurring supporting characters , a regular love interest and better villains would cemented faithful readers.Presentation wise The American Comics Library hits yet another home run with excellent reproduction, quality paper, and an entertaining introduction. If I have one complaint , and its not really a complaint, it is that the book is too large. The book is a couple inches taller then their standard size used by Steve Canyon and Little Orphan Annie.  It just made it less portable then the others and I found I needed to read from one stationary spot instead of lugging it around with me.  Still I would never advocate for this beautiful art to be printed in a reduced size.  Still this books contains over 300 pages.My Highest Recommendation.

I have always thought this was a great concept that never quite lived up to its potential.  It was based on an idea Marv Wolfman had in 1970 about an Manhattan office building being  transported to a primeval world.After DC comics vetoed the idea Marv brought the concept to Marvel.  Marv and then editor-in-chief Roy Thomas hammered that concept to a bi-monthly series in 1975. Instead of an office building, we got a lead character Jim Scully and three supporting characters all who are transported through the Bermuda Triangle to a Prehistoric world.Collected in this trade are all eight issues of the Skull The Slayer comic and the two issues of  Marvel Two In One  which concluded the series.The four characters all have some form of chip on their shoulders and have trouble gelling as a group. Jim Scully, who becomes Skull the Slayer , is a former Vietnam War P.O.W. who comes home from the war to find his wife has divorced him and is with another man, his parents are dead and his brother is a drug addict who tries to kill him.  Scully then kills his own brother in self-defense but is charged with murder.The other three survivors of the crashed airplane are Jeff Walker a teen aged youth who's father is an overbearing US Senator. Dr. Corey the angry oppressed black man and Ann Reynolds , Corey's assistant, the angry oppressed woman's libber.Steve Gan did the art for the first three issues. Gan is a Filipino artist , not as well known as many of his many of his Filipino colleagues. He was the co-creator of Star Lord.  His art especially for the first two issues is beautiful and perfectly suites this concept. Gan has a fine line style that reminds me of Al Williamson.In issue one we get the introduction with the airplane crash and the characters meeting in this Prehistoric world.Issue two continues with the protagonists bickering and discovering ancient (now dead) astronauts. Scully removes a belt from an alien carcass and gains enhanced strength when wearing it.I love the first two issues but with number three Marv seems to loose his focus as  they suddenly encounter a time tower and robotic dinosaurs.Around this time Marv Wolfman is promoted to Editor-In-Chief and dumps several of his writing assignments.  Issue #4 introduces an entirely new creative team . "Together again for the fourth time " proclaims the splash page are the team of Steve Englehart, Sal Buscema and Mike Esposito.  They had all previously worked on Avengers, Defenders and Captain America.Steve Englehart is my favorite 1970's writer but what he does to this book in one issue totally torpedoes the concept. He turns the already hard to identify with Jim Scully into a total A-hole , then kills off the three supporting cast members as Scully shows no concern.  The plot also stinks with robotic versions of Merlin and the Black Knight.Then in issue #5 Bill Mantlo takes over and tries to finish this train wreck of a story and return things to status quo.  Mantlo even resurrects the slain trio.Sal Buscema remains on the book to it's conclusion but is now inked by Sony Trinidad, another Filipino artist and in issue #6 Steve Gan.  In the end of issue #5 Scully saves the life of Dr. Corey and the four start gelling as a team .Issues #6 through #8 are much better and the return of the dinosaur and lost world concept. Mantlo has Scully experience Vietnam flashbacks which relate to the story. He also plants some future issue teasers which never come to fruition as Issue #8 ends on a cliff hanger.A little over a year later Marv Wolfman would return to the world of Skull The Slayer and put a closure to the concept in Marvel Two In One #35 and #36.  Ernie Chan , yet a third Filipino artist illustrates the two issues which has Ben Grimm , The Thing , pilot a plane and rescue our four characters.  Since the concept of Two In One is The Thing plus a different quest star every month Reed Richards, Mr. Fantastic joins them for #36.  Actually Reed is only in the final eight pages but it qualifies him for cover billing.While this would wrap up Jim Scully's savage world adventures , the man would reappear later as the costumed character the Blazing Skull.In conclusion this is , for the most part , a fun read , which had some problems along the way and could have been great . Mike Grell's Warlord  was a similar concept which was also started later in that same year 1975 , but would go onto to greater fame because of it's creator stability .  Skull The Slayer just never quite lived up to it's potential.

The addition of George Perez to Steve Englehart's very imaginative run makes this volume an instant classic and a delight to re-read.  Collected in this edition are thirteen issues of the Avengers from 1975 and 1976. Avengers #136 to #149.The art for this collection is divided up with George Tuska penciling four issues, George Perez doing seven and Don Heck doing a two issue fill in written by Tony Isabella.Avengers #136 is listed on the Masterwork cover but all you really get is the new Gil Kane cover since it was a reprint of the recently collected Beast solo story from Amazing Adventures #12.Avengers #137 and #138 is the two part story that kicks off the volume. George Tuska and inker Vince Colletta are the art team. While some argue about their artistic merits , I find their art to be so Iconic that it delights me.  The over all theme of the entire volume would be the "Building Of The Team " with many Avengers entering and exiting the team.  This volume features the return of Janet and Hank Pym as the Wasp and the Yellowjacket.  Plus Moondragon takes a more active role and The Beast debuts in his new furry form . The villain for this pair of issues appears to be the Stranger , but in reality turns out to be someone else.  According to Englehart's excellent introduction he was disappointed with George Tuska's initial depiction of the Beast so he recruited Jim Starlin to redraw his first head shot .Some of the other touches I enjoyed from this story was seeing the Vision and the Scarlet Witch on Honeymoon vacation and Hank McCoy disguising himself as Edward G. Robinson.In Avengers # 139 Hank Pym's nemesis Whirlwind returns to battle him while his wife lays helpless in the Hospital.Hank Pym is injured in that battle also and can not stop growing , so in Avengers #140 the returning Vision must go inside the body of Hank  Pym. This is entire flip of Roy Thomas classic story (Avengers #93 ) where Hank Pym entered the body of the Vision .George Perez makes his debut as regular penciler in Avengers #141 in a story which brings Marvel's teen romance character Patsy Walker in to the Avengers world. Engelhart had previously used her in his Beast solo stories and now continues her storyline here.  This issue also reintroduces the Squadron Supreme who are all clever analogs of DC's Justice League of America.  My favorite inside joke is that the Green Arrow analog the Golden Archer has a secret identity as a man named McDonald.  Get it. Kang is the villain.Englehart has a simultaneous story going on that started with Avengers #142  and #143 which follows Thor and Moondragon as they go back in time and discover that Hawkeye has joined all Marvel's Western Heroes on a team. So the Avengers meet Two Gun Kid, Ringo Kid, Rawhide Kid and Night Rider (formerly Ghost Rider ). This is a great adventure and my favorite of the collection.  We do get a few pages of the present day storyline with the Squadron Supreme, but that is the "B" story.Avengers #144 returns our focus back to the Squadron Supreme as Patsy Walker becomes an actual Super Hero, the Hellcat.When the Western time travel story ends Two Gun Kid accompanies Hawkeye back to the future and they ride off together. Steve Englehart urges readers to follow their future adventures in the pages of Marvel Spotlight.  Sadly this was never to have happened.Next we get two fill in issues Avengers #145 and #146 which breaks the continuity of Englehart's story.  Apparently Englehart is still ticked off about it because 40 years later in his introduction he refuses to comment on it other then to indicate their was a war raging for editorial control since Stan Lee left the position.  That much is true when this volume started Len Wien was Editor In Chief , then Marv Wolfman and by Avengers #150 Gerry Conway would have the position and upset Englehart enough so that he leave both the Avengers and Marvel.Anyways the two parter appears to be have done for the just canceled Giant Size Avengers. Tony Isabella writes this strange story from an idea by Scott Edelman.  Don Heck does the art and Keith Pollard ads three additional pages at the beginning of Avengers # 146 to stretch it out two issues. The one shot villain or villainess The Assassin is seen at the beginning of the story with a costume which appears to be a set of chain mail with a hood that goes down past his knees golfing. This page cracked me up as imagined actually golfing in an outfit like this.The plot has a lot of holes in it and the characters actions all seem pretty strange.Avengers #147 to #149 returns Englehart and Perez to the book and finishes up the Squadron Supreme storyline which now highlights the Serpent Crown introduced in the Sub-Mariner book.  Just a point of clarification when Roy Thomas first introduced this concept the Squadron Sinister was a group of four villains including NightHawk who went good.  Later Roy introduces the Squadron Supreme as good guys , some of who have the same costumes even, but they had different identities.  This apparently confused for many including the editorial staff who twice in this volume call the Squadron Supreme the Squadron Sinister on the covers of Avengers #141 and #147.  Then even Englehart gets confused as he had Iron Man referring to his recent battle with Doctor Spectrum not realizing it was the other Doctor Spectrum from the Squadron Sinister.The back matter consists of art used for Avengers Marvel Treasury edition,  promotional Avengers ads, and original art reproductions. The art and color restoration are excellent and Steve Englehart's excellent introduction runs three pages so he can cover his final couple of stories from the next volume.For 40 year old stories , I found this volume to be highly entertaining and I give it my strongest recommendation.

I love the Epic Collection format with phone book size and great full color reproduction on quality paper.  But this is the first one that kind of became a chore to finish.  I debated giving it only three stars but I decided to be generous and round this 3.5 star book up.Collected from the cover dated years of 1991 and 1992 we get three connected Annuals, ten issues of Amazing Spider-Man and a stand alone graphic novel.The volume starts with three connected Annuals, Amazing Spider-Man Annual #25, Spectacular Spider-Man Annual #11 and Web of Spider-Man Annual #7.  During this time Marvel had decided to make the Annuals 64 pages long so you get over 50 pages of new content.  Each had a lead story of around 25 pages then a bunch of smaller stories featuring Spider-Man related characters.  These are also included.The lead connected storyline is written by David Michelinie and spins out of characters and concepts from his then current Iron Man run.  The art is by Guang Yap for the first and last part and Marvel Legend Marie Severin for the middle section.  The story is about Roxxon Industries creation of a synthetic Vibranium . Spider-Man teams with Iron Man and the Black Panther to take on Sunturian, The Ghost, The Kingpin and Ultron.The backups are a good idea in concept , but turn out to be mostly a waste of space.  We get four different three page "the origin of...." stories with Spider-Man, Green Goblin, Hobgoblin and Venom.  Venom gets another story "The Truck Stop Of Doom " which is just as good as the title suggests.  Fred Hembeck does a story of young Peter Parker story which is fun. My favorite is The Outlaws three part story. The Outlaws are a bunch of quasi heroes and reformed villains from the pages of Spider-Man.  They are Silver Sable, The Prowler, Will-o-wisp , Sand Man and Rocket Racer.  Rocket Racer also gets his own solo story battling Speed Demon.  Steve Ditko does a Chance story.  And even The Rhino gets his own story which is really just a Spider-Man story, since Spider-Man appears on page two defeats Rhino and it over.When Erik Larsen left Amazing Spider-Man it was decided to bring Mark Bagley over to the book following his 25 issue run on New Warriors.  Amazing Spider-Man#351 and #352 starts Bagley's run as regular artist for the book with Michelinie as writer. In the story Nova teams up with Spider-Man to battle a three headed Sentinel.Nova returns for guest writer All Milgrom's six part "Round Robin" story (Amazing Spider-Man #353 to #358 )which ran all summer as the book came out every two weeks.  This story featured a bloated All Action adventure against The Secret Empire and Midnight who died in the pages of Moon Knight and is brought back here as an evil cyborg.Also guest starring are a bunch more of the 90's Who's Who with Nova, The Punisher, Darkhawk and the hero who's name sounds like a Porno Movie title Night Thrasher.At this point Mark Bagley had now done eight issues in five months so Chris Marrinan comes in for Amazing Spider-Man #359 and #360 . This two part story welcomes back David Michelinie and Cardiac. My favorite part of this story was the use of Peter Parker's supporting cast of friends and Daily Bugle work mates. Up until this story only Mary Jane and Aunt May had been used.Finally we close with the strange graphic novel "Fear Itself " which should not be confused with the recent 100 part Mega Event.  The story is plotted by Gerry Conway and scripted by Conway and Stan Lee. If anyone knows the back story of Stan's involvement, I would love to hear it. I can't imagine in 1992 Conway got behind and Stan just came in to help out.  Anyways the plot reads like something out of an Alistair MacLean adventure novel.  Spider-Man and Silver Sable explore an old castle in Germany and battle Nazi's and Ninjas.  The art by Bronze Age Spider-Man legend Ross Andru is some of his best and the last time he would draw Spider-Man before dying in 1993.One of the problems that all these stories share is a carefree and happy Peter Parker.  This is not the character I know and love.  I think his biggest worry is Aunt May's new infatuation with Pro Wrestling.For supplemental material you get information and samples of Mark Bagley's try out book entry,  covers done for collected editions and Spider-Man related trading cards.Recommend for fans of Mark Bagley or "Die Hard " Epic Collection collectors.

Travel back in time to 1972 and 1973 when these stories first appeared in Iron Man issues #54 to #67. Fourteen comics have been reprinted and remastered so that they look outstanding on glossy paper with laser sharp reproductions.The lions share of the creative work here is from young writer Mike Friedrich who had just jumped on the book with #48 but would have a lengthy run. He was only 22 years old but had already had spent 5 years working at DC comics.George Tuska started comics in 1939. He worked on Fawcett's Captain Marvel in the 40's and the Buck Rogers newspaper strip in the 60's. His Iron Man run lasted almost 10 years.Iron Man #54 opens the collection with an Iron Man and Sub-Mariner battle. Sub-Mariner legend Bill Everett gives Tuska a hand penciling his creation. Madame McEvil the hot looking villainess with the bald head would later become a part of both the Thanos legacy and Avengers team as Moondragon.Next we get the big one as Jim Starlin takes over Iron Man #55 with his creations of Thanos and cast.  Including first appearances of not just Thanos but Dax the Destroyer, the Blood Brothers, Mentor and Starfox.  Starlin would create the characters, plot the story and pencil the works.  Friedrich does scripting.  This is a great story.Starlin would stay on the book for a second issue but now just as a penciler in issue #56. It is nice art but  Steve Gerber writes a rather lame issue with one shot villains Rasputin and Fangor. Even the cameo from Dr. Strange does not save this bizarre story.George Tuska returns for the two part battle with the Mandarin and the Unicorn in Iron Man #57 and #58. Steve Gerber plots the two issues and scripts the first part.  Friedrich scripts the second part and returns as writer for the remainder of the book.  The Mandarin is undercover as Gene Kahn .  This is a fun story which brings back Happy Hogan and Pepper back into the supporting cast.Iron Man #59 is a good single story in which Stark goes to Detroit where he spends most of the rest of this book. He battles returning villain Firebrand and gets a new love interest in the form of Roxie Gilbert (Firebrand's sister ).In Iron Man #60 and #61 we get shellhead fighting Daredevil's old foe the Masked Marauder.Next we get a single story (Iron Man #62 ) with another old villain Whiplash. Young  P. Craig Russell does a fill in issue early in his career.  John Romita Sr. is called in to do so many art corrections he actually gets a credit on the title page.  It mostly looks like he had to fix faces that might have looked too different.Next we get what someone on the title page of Iron Man #66 calls "perhaps the greatest Iron Man saga ever told".  I disagree and found this four part story to be my least favorite of the entire volume. I found it be a convoluted mess in which Friedrich is so eager to surprise us that the story stops making sense. Dr Spectrum is a cool villain . He was created to be an alternate earth version of the Green Lantern in the Squadron Sinster.  Now he needlessly becomes a Skrull who can hop to different bodies.  Iron Man spends an entire issue battling the villain Rokk only to find out he is a creation of Dr Spectrum's prism gem. Then in the final part Thor appears to battle an Iron Man possessed by the entity that was formerly in Dr Spectrum body. But who is in Iron Man costume that gets possessed ? We see Tony Stark, Happy Hogan and former sparring partner Eddie March all in the Iron Man suit.It is Eddie March who gets his clock cleaned by Thor.  Poor Eddie is forever taking abuse. In the final story from Iron Man #67 to save Eddie's life Tony subjects Eddie to the same experiment that turned Happy Hogun into the villain called the Freak.  It of course also changes Eddie in to the Freak. The Freak is eventually restored to Eddie March after a big fight but it is revealed that Eddie sustains enough injuries in the battle that he will be in a wheelchair for life.  Poor Eddie.This a fun collection of Iron Man stories which takes me back to my boyhood.

Six months ago I bought the first Ms. Marvel trade and was delighted by how fresh, original and charming the first volume was.  Now I am very happy to report that the second collection is just as great.G. Willow Wilson takes on a new journey of exploration for our heroine Kamala Khan.  Kamala is a Pakistani American and "fan girl" attending  High school in New Jersey.  The six issues collected here are from single issues #6 to #11 published in 2014.The first two issues in this volume form a single story which serves as a prequel the main saga. In th his arc Ms. Marvel has her first official team up as she battles along side of Wolverine who has lost his healing factor.  As has been proven in the past Logan (Wolverine) has pretty good chemistry with teen aged girls . Kitty Pryde and Jubilee come to mind.  The action takes place in the sewers with giant alligators.  Kamala initially thought she was a mutant but Logan figures out her secret.While regular artist Adrian Alphona takes a break Jacob Wyatt steps in for the two issue series. His art is similar enough to the previous art that it is not jarring. Wyatt style resembles Mike Allred but done with a finer line . His Wolverine looks a little fat in some panels, other then that I have no complaints.At the end of this of this arc Wolverine speaks to Medusa of the Inhumans and she takes an interest in Kamala and sends Lockjaw to locate her.Then for the remainder of the four issues Lockjaw becomes Ms. Marvel's sidekick as they battle the evil Inventor.  The villain who's head looks like a cockatiel. Along the way  Kamala's High School comes under attack by a giant robot.For these final four issues regular artist Adrian Alphona returns.  His charming style looks like a cross between Anime and Mad Magazine.  It is the perfect accompaniment to G. Willow Wilson's delightful storytelling.This book is very highly recommend.

The third volume features another nine issues of Eclipse Comics Airboy ( Airboy #26 through #34) plus an Airboy spin off The Air Maidens plus two crossovers.  One with Mr. Monster and one with The Prowler. Over 300 pages of fun 1980's comics.These volumes are big and thick like an Marvel Epic Collection done on thicker paper then an Epic book.  Unfortunately IDW is still using that tan pseudo aged paper stock which mutes the vibrant colors and makes them look dull.The book features a great new cover from Tim Truman and another informative introduction by original writer Chuck Dixon.  The book opens with the Air Maidens special. The team consists of Valkyrie , the new Black Angel whom we met in the Valkyrie mini-series plus the new creation of La Lupina a female Hispanic version of Sky Wolf.  The story showcases some nice "good girl art" from Larry Elmore a great from the TSR school of gaming books and magazines.The lead Airboy story for issues #26 to #30 is a great five part battle royale with all of Airboy's villains teaming up to combat all of his allies. Lots of fun. We get eight Sky Wolf backs set in the 1950's plus a lead in story to the Mr. Monster crossover.  The two Sky Wolf back ups done by Dan Spiegle are things of beauty. The first of these stories which featured Sky Wolf and Riot talking is a touching tale and my favorite of the entire volume.In the Mr. Monster story, The Heap also is featured. This is another touching tale of a washed up alcoholic comic artist named Everett W. Coleman.  This character I believe is inspired by Sub-Mariner creator Bill Everett who's battle with the bottle prevented him from ever getting the acclaim he deserved.  Plastic Man's creator Bill Cole who committed suicide at an early age may also be the other inspiration.The book ends with The Prowler crossover which who was a Tim Truman and John K Snyder creation.  By my calculations we have two more archives to go and I eagerly await them.

This hardcover book collects Brian Michael Bendis and Michael Avon Oeming new creator owned comic.  Fifteen years earlier the same two creators  broke new ground with the award winning series Powers.  Can the two catch lighting in a bottle twice is what I set  to find out.Bendis started his comic career as a writer and artist of crime fiction and is now returning to it so it seems a very natural fit.  I find Bendis to be Marvel's consistently best scripter who rarely disappoints.Omeing conversely does not fair as well in my opinion. It all depends on who is paired with. Of course I loved his Powers work at the time and thought he was Artistic Genius, while other times I find his work to be too stiff and primitive for my liking.I know Bendis , a one time artist himself, spends a lot of thought pairing the correct artist to the correct project.  By the end of the volume Oeming had won me over on this project and I could not imagine a different artist.One problem I had , especially early in the volume, was several times I was confused on panel layout in not knowing if the panels flowed across a two page spread or if each page was made to read separately.  I found this distracting and could have been fixed with either better page layout or by the colorist using different color palettes on each page so that you knew when the pages were a separate entity.Colorist Taka Soma uses mostly dark monochromatic color schemes.  This coupled with Omeing's heavy use of black and black space makes the results look a little too dark for my taste.  I would have preferred either more pastels colors or perhaps skipping the coloring entirely and just going black and white for a very noir feel.As for the story itself it is an excellent tale of a parallel reality in which the Crime families have been the dominant way of life.  Society in America is controlled by five crime families each with its own territory.The story opens with Valentine Gallo becoming a "made man" and sent on a mission which should have been a cake walk.  He was to give a senator a suitcase.  It ends up killing the senator and he finds himself in trouble with both the CIA and all the families.His only ally a sexy ginger hit-woman named Jagger Rose. Even Valentine's own mother tells him a dangerous secret which shocks him to his core.Along the way Bendis breaks the Valentine narrative to give us key glimpses into the alternate history in which the Crime Families made a major difference in how things turned out.The books contains the first six issues including a double sized first issue published by Marvel's Icon line in 2014.  Also included is the covers and alternate covers plus the Bendis script for the first issue . Plus you get the original sketches and character designs done by both Bendis and Oeming.This is just the start of a rich and powerful epic and the more I read the more I got drawn into this world.  I highly recommend this volume.

I sometimes don't see the point in reviewing something like this book which already has 24 other reviews. Does anyone really need to read 25 reviews before deciding to spend their $8 on a paperback.So here goes anyway. I love Max Allen Collins Quarry and can not wait for the Cinemax TV series.  Quarry is a stone cold killer. At the time of this writing there are 11 Quarry novels and a short story collection.The first novel originally called the Broker is now titled Quarry.  I recommend you read it first.  After that read them in any order. They jump around in the years that they are set in so it doesn't really matter.  Collins will bring you up to speed.  This is my 7th.The plot this time revolves around Quarry getting caught in between two warring illegal gambling operations. Hence the title.Quarry is no longer just a killer, now he kills the killers before they can kill you for a price.  I think this makes him a quasi good guy, but that is a fine line.In this story he kills people, gets beaten up a lot, beats up people and has a lot of sex.  If this is the kind of thing you enjoy you will love this book.  Nobody does it better then Max Allen Collins. Also Ron Lesner does an excellent cover.And if by any chance you really did read this review please either click on the "helpful" button or leave a comment saying yes I actually read your review, which will impress the heck out of me. In the meantime I will hold my breath and check in every few years.

Dark Horse has taken this rare European graphic novel and given it a very fitting classy new edition it so rightly deserves.  The one thing this volume could use is some background information so I will attempt to provide that in the course of this review.Joe Kubert's contributions to the field of comics art are legendary. First as artist himself with beautiful art starting in Golden Age of comics with illustrations for early DC superheroes like the Flash and Hawkman spanning to his award-winning graphic novels done in the last couple decades of his life.  Second as the father of Adam and Andy Kubert his equally talented sons.  And third as the creator of The Joe Kubert School of Cartoon and Graphic Art where he has mentored hundreds of people working today in comics, animation and related fields.This 230 page graphic novel was originally printed in Italian in 2001. There was an obscure English-language version printed in 2005 by a company called SAF comics.  I also own that version, it is printed in black and white and is a softcover.  This is printed on glossy high quality paper in full color in Hard Cover with a dust jacket. If you own or have seen the Kubert Tarzan Archives also done by Dark Horse this is done in the exact same format with equally good production values.Tex Willer is the longest running Italian comic book.  First created in 1948 and continuing today.  Over 1,100 regular Tex Willer comics have been published plus large 230 page TexOne specials of which this is one of. Tex has worldwide appeal, in the Nordic countries his adventures rate almost as much admiration as those of the Donald Duck family of books.Tex Willer has a long history and continuity with three regular traveling companions and a large cast of continuing characters and villains. For this story it was decided that Tex would ride alone hence the subtitle The Lonesome Rider.As a favor to the Italian publishers of his Graphic Novels , Joe agreed to do this story for them provided he had unlimited time to complete it. According to an interview he says he worked on it on and off for seven years while teaching full time and taking other side work.The story itself written by current Tex Willer writer Claudio Nizzi is a good one but a little bit of a cliche.  On his way to visit a farm couple and their teen daughter who he has not seen in around fifteen years Tex discovers all three have been recently murdered by three whites and an Indian.  They discover Tex in pursuit and dump him and his horse over a cliff.  Recovering from the fall the story splinters in to four separate storylines as he pursues each killer alone.The art by Joe Kubert is kinetic and powerful with lush swatches of black inking. Every brush stroke is purposely placed.  The coloring I am guessing was done in house by Dark Horse and strangely not credited.  The coloring is done in a traditional flat style with subdued tones which do not distract from the art. I would not like to see this done with current overrendered style with the dark palate which is in current vogue.One minor disappointment is on pages 9 through pages 13 Joe Kubert originally drew the young lady bathing nude . Even though the front side naughty bits are totally covered the Italian publisher who is described as very Catholic forced Joe to make her bathing in a full length petty coat, which seems strange. Even stranger after she is murdered she is clearly depicted as nude.  I have seen scans of a limited edition of the original art published in an earlier promotional version done for the Nordic countries.  Also in that Graphic Novel it had depictions of Tex Willer's supporting cast who do not appear in story.  Those would have made great extras.But what we do get is excellent and a welcome addition to any lover of Joe Kubert's art and a classic Western story which is a fun read.

This is a review of the AudioGo audio book which came out in 2012.  First any book written by Donald Westlake is well worth reading or listening to.The book is the final in the John Dortmunder series because Mr. Westlake would die shortly after writing it.  The Dortmunder books are the polar opposite of the Parker books he would write under his Richard Stark alias.  The Parker books about are also about a thief but they are cold, calculating and hard boiled. The Dortmunder books are about a gang of crooks we are bumbling misfits. The books are loaded with humor. This one especially had me laughing out loud.The premise is a reality show company wants to make a TV show out of Dortmunder's crew robbing something, meanwhile the crew wants to pull a job ripping off the TV shows parent company.  Westlake shares some hilarious insights into the nature of Reality TV.While this is the last book in the series, newcomers will have no problems getting into the story.  The first book in the series has been made into the movie "The Hot Rock". The narrator does an excellent job of creating different voices for all of Dortmunder's motley crew.Very entertaining and Highly Recommended

This is volume seventeen of what was meant to be the definitive Conan run. The series started so wonderfully with the team of Kurt Busiek and Cary Nord. It has maintained a pretty high quality run up until the recent two year series by Brian Wood which many fans (myself included) found to be lacking in both the writer's and artist's portrayal of Robert E Howard's barbarian.So how does the new team do ?  The writing by new writer Fred Van Lente is quite good but suffers a little from a slow start where Conan seems to wandering around for awhile and numbing himself with alcohol from the loss of Belit. By the third issue (this was originally published as six comics ) the main plot was starting to really come to together and from then on I greatly enjoyed the book. This is the point in the story when Conan takes a position as Captain of the guards. I really enjoyed Fred's run on Marvel's Hercules and expect even greater things for him in the future as he settles into the book.Brian Ching was announced as the regular artist but unfortunately was able to complete only the first half of the book, but will return in future volumes. Brian Ching is a Californian artist who has been making a name for himself on Dark Horse's Star Wars books. I found the art initially to be a bit too cartoony for my taste. His depiction of Conan is a little too much like that of during Brian Wood's run where he looked like a scrawny "emo " teen.  While not quite that bad I would like to see him a little more muscular.By the third issue either Brian's art improved or I just started to enjoy his style a lot more I am not sure which.  But I saw John Buscema like characteristics to Brian's art start to emerge.  Then he was gone.Replacing him for the second half of the book is Brazilian artist Eduardo Francisco.  Mr Francisco reminds me a little of Mike Deodota , but not quite as polished. The styles are similar so it isn't too jarring.The colors by Michael Atiyeh are excellent and helps unify the art.So bottom line is the book been restored to the level of greatness it once held in my heart ?  Well to be honest, no.  But I think it is well on the road to recovery and I expect bigger and better things in the future. I encourage you to sample this volume.

While I own both the paperback and the audio book, this review is of the BBC audio book 5 disc CD set.The story is about a con man who gets conned himself when he falls in love with a rich young housewife.  The action is intense as Block serves up a lost early jewel from his early works.The narration on the book is excellent.  Outstanding production values.  Highly recommended .

One of the problems inherit in Doc Savage seems to be the need to re-imagine the character for a new generation. DC comics did this poorly twice. Now rising comics writer Chris Roberson takes a stab at it with six single issues and one two part story all loosely connected. Also collected is the 2014 Annual by an entirely different team. All nine of these comics where published by Dynamite Comics in 2014.I so badly wanted to love this book and give it five stars but it just falls short. Roberson concept for the series is to start with issue #1 set in 1933 then advance the story a decade or so every issue until the final two set in 2014. For those interested #2 is set in 1949, #3 in 1961, #4 in 1979, #5 in 1988 and issue #6 in 2000.Due to events in the story Doc ages very little, his cousin Pat does age but at a reduced rate , but the famous five sidekicks all age normally so that they are only featured in the first couple stories. So Chris Roberson spends a lot of time introducing new sidekicks who last a couple issues then are replaced by new ones. Yes this is more politicaly correct as we get more females and nationalities on to the team. But I think Roberson has bitten off more then he can chew as there just is not enough space to flesh out all these characters and most of them seem rather bland. The other major idea Roberson seems fascinated with is Doc's manipulation of the criminal Brain as a means to reform them. This an idea that really doesn't work today and by dwelling on it makes Doc look less heroic which may or may not be Roberson's point. But just wished he would not have gone there.Part of the fun of a Doc Savage novel is crazy and outlandish villains. This story would have benefited from maybe one also Immortal villain to tie the stories together or at least more colorful ones.The art from female Brazilian artist Bilquis Evely is technically drafted quite well with very solid intricate panels.  The only fault I find in her work is the characters look quite stiff and posed. She also draws uniformly neutral faces with very little emotion.The eight covers painted by Alex Ross are things of beauty and worth the price of the book alone.  John Cassidy provides eight alternative covers, each a tribute to an earlier incarnation of Doc. These are also excellent.  Roberto Castro provides the art for Doc Savage Annual. His art while not as detailed as Evely's is much more kinetic and dynamic. I preferred it to the main story's.The Annual is written by Shannon Eric Denton . It starts early in Doc's career in 1930 then goes back earlier to World War One with Doc and his aides battling side by side.  Overall I think I enjoyed this story more then the series.  Two things bothered about the story. First seeing two Colonels and a General all in the trenches fighting together with enlisted men and lesser officers. Secondly the portrayal of Doc Savage as a womanizer.Overall as a Doc Savage fan I am recommending this omnibus.  It was a lot of fun seeing The Man Of Bronze back in any incarnation.

As I have been reading all the Masterworks I have found that Sub-Mariner run to be the most consistently excellent of all the Marvel Silver Age Masterworks. Well this volume takes a little dip in quality as teen aged Gerry Conway takes over for Roy Thomas .This volume collects Sub-Mariner 39 to 49 with Daredevil 77 as an added bonus. These books all originally published in 1971 and 1972 have been loving restored so they look perfect.The first story from Sub-Mariner 39 is Roy Thomas's swan song as he departs the book.  As the story opens Lady Dorma has been killed and Namor has returned to New York and the abandoned Prison Island as his new "Fortress of Solitude". In this story he demonstrates a new super power, the ability to punch stone walls and sculpt aquatic statutes. Why he won't prefer a palace under water is not explained. Besides that question this is a tight little story that sets up Namor's quest for his father and a whirlwind tour of the USA and other dimensions. The art for this issue is by Ross Andru and Jim Mooney and is very solid.Next we get Daredevil 77 . While this does features the best art in the book, Gene Colan and Tom Palmer, it does not really need to be included.  It was just recently printed in a Daredevil Masterworks.  Sub-Mariner does not show up till the story is half through. Not a bad story but I skimmed it since I just read it. The coloring error from original is carried over for the third time as Mary Jane Watson becomes a blonde.The second part of this story in Sub-Mariner 40 is not as successful. At the end DD 77 Namor and Spiderman where brought to another dimension so that they can fight a lame bad guy named Turalla.  This story is way over written and kind of confusing. SpiderMan just kind of hangs around and has no purpose in the story. Nice art by Colan but Sam Grainger is not a good fit inking.OK let me make a few things clear before I rip on Gerry Conway a little. First he was just breaking into comics with only a dozen or so scripts written.  Second he was a mere teen aged boy just learning his craft. Third he learned very quickly and became one of my favorites. I found his first five issues to be problematic, but the last five issues in this collection are quite enjoyable.Now on to Sub-Mariner 41 and 42 this two parter was either inspired by the TV show Dark Shadows or the writings of HP Lovecraft or both. The story starts off clear enough with Namor being knocked out the sky by some nameless force. But then we meet one lame monster after another and by the second issue things have become so muddled I don't what is going on. Just as try to stop my head from spinning up pops up two robotic characters who work for Mr. Kline. They fight for two pages then disappear forever. Mr. Conway just loads every page with word balloons but it serves no purpose. It is like Gerry is just trying to impress the readers with his large vocabulary and has given up on this train wreck up a plot. The art for both of these issues is not helped by George Tuska who delivers some lackluster pencils.The Sub-Mariner world tour continues as Namor goes to Boston and we meet another lame-o from another the people of the Black Sea. This one is named Tuval  instead of Turalla . Sub-Mariner 43 is the issue in which Marvel for one month tried to emulate DC's attempt to go double size for a quarter. It would be interesting to find out how much notice the creators got but this one seems very padded. Much better scripting by Gerry even if I did like the basic plot. Very nice art from Gene Colan and Mike Esposito helps.Sub-Mariner 44 and 45 is a two parter that was created to be a single issue but then cut in half when Marvel quickly went back to 32 page comics. I believe Golden Age reprint stories appeared as back ups but are not included in this collection. This story I enjoyed and brings back the classic pairing of Namor and The Human Torch.  Conway cranks up the soap opera elements of his writing which would become a his trademark. Marie Severin does the art for both parts.Gene Colan returns in Sub-Mariner 46 as Namor finally gets to meet and then lose his Dad.  A good story but I wish Gerry had kept Captain McKenzie around longer. Also Namor gets Amnesia once again.This Masterworks volume closes on a high note as we get Conway's best yarn a three parter all illustrated by Colan in Sub-Mariner 47, 48 and 49. Still in tour mode we start in Chicago for the first issue before we head to New Orleans for the final two parts.  We meet Cindy Jones who looks to be a love interest for Namor. She would leave the book in issue 50  right after Conway departed. The plot involves Doctor Doom, Modok and the Cosmic Cube.All together this is mixed bag with a good first story , then some dip in the quality of the writing . Finally it finishes quite strong.The next volume brings back Sub-Mariner creator Bill Everett for a nice run as writer or co-writer and penciler.

When a life long comics fan makes a new discovery it is a happy day. Such was a day was in late 2011 when the first volume Classic Comics Press  Cisco Kid comic strips collection arrived.  I had long ago learned to respect the taste of publisher Charles Pelto and I pre-ordered the book blind.  Of course I had heard of Cisco Kid, but as a youth I avoided anything in the War or Western genre.But the first volume totally blew me away.  Good stories and the art of Jose Luis Salinas was just fantastic. Clearly in the school of Alex Raymond and Al Williamson came master illustrator Jose Luis Salinas. This Argentine artist did beautiful fine line as good as the best of them.  Excited for more I waited and waited. Now after over three years comes the second volume and it is every bit as good, if not better then that first volume.Cisco Kid was created by famous writer O.Henry in 1907 in the early pulps.
