He went on to star in 28 feature films and 156 episodes of one TV's first color TV shows.  I have been exploring some of these and all though they may be a little juvenile they are not bad. But I like my Cisco in Black and White. The Black and White of Salinas daily comic strip. Sadly a Sunday section was never created.This book features an excellent introduction by Marvel Comics ground breaker Don McGregor and another article about Salinas life featuring many illustrations by Salinas in color. And the Main Course 25 months worth of daily strips from February 1953 to March 1955. Eight complete stories and 248 pages.The second story "The Artist" was shot from Production Proofs and looks perfect. But the rest of it was shot from sixty year old newspaper clippings. Considering this, they look amazing and I would not want to guess how many countless man hours went into this restoration process. This was especially difficult when seeing the intricate fine line work produced by Salinas. The artist I think Salinas mostly closely resembles would be EC Comics Legend Reed Crandall.  We have beautiful Iconic full length panels of Bar Room Brawls and Scenic Outdoor Panoramas. I often found myself pulled out of the story as I became lost just studying the art.I was planning to go over each story individually since I have read it cover to cover but I would like to keep this review short enough to keep your interest and still let you have the fun of watching the stories unravel.  The stories are the work of writer Rod Reed. Since the comic strip was created shortly after the TV series they ran simultaneously at this time.  So the strip had to appeal to both the younger crowd who adored the TV show and the adults who still avidly read the Comic Strips section in the 1950's.The stories are mostly self contained but we do see some overlap a few tomes like when Pancho disappears after one story or Cisco is still still romancing a young lady.  Rod Reed does a pretty good job at mixing up the stories. So we get a pulse pounding action romp, then a more humor filled story followed by one with lots of Romance.  And make no mistake about it Cisco was "a ladies man" unlike most do-gooders of this era. Pancho his portly side kick was both comedy relief and a deadly sharp shooter himself."Probation For Waco"" was my favorite story of this volume,  An aged ex-con Cisco Kid put in jail comes looking for Cisco. Life is rough for him, nobody will hire him and he can't force himself to "rat" out another criminal so that Cisco will trust him.  This is a poignant little story.This volume comes with my Highest Recommendation.  The publisher has promised a shorter time between volumes which is great because I am already eager for more of this almost lost Classic.  This is a book that deserves shelf space in the library of every serious connoisseur of classic comic art.

I have never seen a book listed on Amazon that more badly needed a review then this one. Neither the cover or the very cryptic description gives you any idea of what this book is even about.I assumed from the cover it was a novel about the sea-faring adventures of one Abel Smith.  What this is a collection of six inter-connceted short stories featuring a youth from Nantucket who after a time on a whaler ship settles in the town of Yerba Buena, California.  It starts in the year 1846.  I had to goggle Yerba Buena after the first story to discover that this is the city that will become San Francisco.  This fact is explained in later stories but an introduction might have served to set it up better.These stories all appeared in different issues of the pulp magazine Short Stories in 1945 and 1946. Short Stories for those unfamiliar, was one of the upper tier of pulps publishing some up the best fiction to be found.Yerba Buena was a small,just emerging town which had just come under the USA flag.  Being on the San Francisco Bay it was becoming a major west coast harbor and a stopping point for many ships.  The stories themselves are all about doing commerce in this frontier town. If this sounds a little boring you have not read much H. Bedford Jones. The man could write a phone book and make it interesting. I can not imagine an author today writing about Economics in a frontier town and giving us six such enchanting stories. Now days it all about action and explosions. This is about one man using his brain to resolve problems and outwit his competition.The very first story deals with 22 year old Abel Smith's first day in Yerba Buena and how he arrives with two dollars in his pocket and by the end of the day he is a partner in a General Store.  The stories progress over a period of time with many re-occrring characters we meet.  In each story Smith has a different problem and each story has it's own resolution which involves Smith being just a little bit more clever then his opponents and out thinking them.In one story he helps start a flour mill, in another he goes on a salvage mission for the cargo of a ship wreck , in yet another his business partner is upset with him for what he thinks are foolish purchases,The sixth stories introduces a love interest for Abel Smith and definitely ties up all the sub-plots into a neat little finale. The fantastic but misleading cover by Rudolph Belarski is from an 1939 issue of Argosy.  The six issues of Short Stories covers which featured Alex Smith stories in their contents are shown on the back cover. Unfortunately they are all smaller then postage stamp size so it hard to know if any of them even featured Alex Smith, my guess is no. We also get all seven of the original illustrations by Fred Humiston.All together a beautiful package with clear large print on quality white paper. Just to nitpick a small issue , I did find a couple typos. This is a first for any Altus Book I have read.H. Bedford Jones is known as "The King Of The Pulps" not only because quantity (200 novels, 400 novelettes and 800 short stories) but for his quality. This is one of 10 matched editions Altus Press has released so far with new ones just recently announced.  I plan to read them all and I think you should too.Highly Recommended

Stark House Press brings us the first three novels (of six) written about former Mob Man Daniel Port.  Written in 1956 and 1957 for the emerging Men's Action Market taking place in the new 'Paperback" format for the leader in this genre Gold Medal Books.Peter Rabe (real name Rabinowitsch) who had only moderate success at the time is now being placed in much higher regard for his Hard Boiled Prose thanks in no small part to Stark House Press who has previously reprinted 14 of Rabe novels in seven deluxe double collections.The titles of the three novels are quite generic and just different ways of saying "I think I might Die Soon". My single complaint with this volume is the cover. It is terrible. I know it was done by Stark House Press publisher Mark Sheppard, but please , part of the appeal of these books at the time was the lurid eye catching paintings. I know Stark House might not have the deep pockets to commission new art like Hard Case Crime does, but I find nothing wrong this using the original or re-purposing a great painting.The first novel Dig My Grave Deep is the introduction to the character and explains how Daniel Port is able to leave mobster gang job. Like in a real Mafia organization a lot of the criminal activity deals with real estate and politics. This is only a small portion of the novel but it is an area in which it seemed to slow down the action and pace of the story and made it the weakest of three. Still it is an excellent novel and a necessary set up to the series. The parts involving the want-to-be made man Ramon and his beautiful sister I found to be very realistic and the high light of the book. Rabe writes great three dimensional characters.In the second novel Port is now out of the outfit and moved on. A dying ex-criminal is released from prison.  He just wants to die free but a young punk gangster has other plans for him. With no place to turn he seeks out Daniel Port. This is a dark and tragic Noir in the classic sense and most of the characters have a sense of impending doom hanging over them. Letty the Gun Moll who just wants to dance is an especially tragic figue. She is used by every body in the story including Daniel Port.  For my money this novel packs a gut wrenching impact and was my clear favorite of three. As Rick Ollermann points out in his excellent introduction Peter Rabe follows no formula and these three books are all quite different in tone and style.In the final novel It's My Funeral we encounter a Daniel Port who seems happier and more well adjusted to his new life style. He has moved out to Hollywood and is pursuing a pretty night club singer. His past once more invades his happiness as he encounters an old enemy who wants to use him.  Meanwhile Daniel is trying to help a movie actress who is being black mailed with some pornographic film.  This one packs lots of twists and turns as we try to unravel this intricate plot. During the story we get Peter Rabe's not too subtle take on fame and happiness is on display.  Again this is different type of story and one that we might see in today's era of recent books and media.This is a nice package in over-sized Trade format with typo free easy to read print. I eagerly await the final three novels in a matching omnibus. My Highest Recommendation.

First off there seems to be a debate rising about the format and the amount of white space on the pages. As publisher Daniel Herman explains in an text piece good source material for these rare 1946 and 1947 strips was hard to come by forcing Hermes Press to use both dailies from the the full size strips and the truncated strips some papers ran because of the War caused paper shortage.  If you look on page 258 and 259 for example you can see the two different sizes in comparison.  Short of waiting and locating only full size strips I don't see how this white space problem could have been avoided.  Another complaint is about the shiny glossy paper used by Hermes Press. Personally I have zero complaints about that, I think that is personnel choice . I know I dislike it when publishers use off-white or tan colored paper to make the strips look aged or closer to their pulpy originals.In summation "No" these are not quite matching the quality of those put out by The American Library Of Comics .But "Yes" they have done a good job at restoration and I will treasure having this volume in my library. The Phantom is America's first costumed super-hero and these stories are a ton of fun.The first story about a brave little girl is called PRINCESS VALERIE. She is abducted by conspirators to her grandfathers throne. This is a charming story. When Valerie is put in a cannibals pot to simmer she complains that they don't know how to give a little girl a bath correctly. This is the last daily strip continuity that Ray Moore (the Phantom's first artist ) would work on because of the nerve damaged he received in World War 2.Starting with QUEEN ASTRA OF TRONDELAY Wilson McCoy would work solo on the strip. This is another jungle adventure with a spoiled and cruel queen who abducts a young man on the eve of his wedding.  Later she develops a crush on The Phantom himself.In the story MISTER HOG the ghost who walks returns to the USA to pursue his love interest in Diane Palmer . But Diane has been tricked into working for Mister Hog, a hideous Crime Boss.  While this is am entertaining story the quality of the reproductions for this story varies greatly with some of the strips look quite poor and some feature fuzzy line work.ROMANCE AND THE VESTAL PIRATES is the final story of the volume and the longest, It covers over a hundred pages and ran for eight months. It is also my favorite of the volume. It starts with a romantic soap opera story and then finishes with another romantic soapy ending. In the middle there is an exciting adventure story involving modern day pirates on a yacht.  The story demonstrates the wide range of Lee Falk's writing skills jumping from humor to romance to action and adventure.As a long time collector of The Phantom I have quite the collection of The Frew Comic Books which reprint the classic strips.  Unlike the earlier volumes  in which I had read most of those stories I found all of these quite new to me.  I am delighted that this series is being reprinted comprehensively in a deluxe Hard Cover format.  Publisher  Daniel Herman promises they have excellent source material for the remaining decades of strips.  I know I will be on board and excited for each release.

While I have never considered myself a Digest collector, I had been a subscriber of the Science Fiction Digests for decades. This digest sized fanzine completely sucked me in and I ended up reading it cover to cover.  The production is flawless and I found no typos. It was filled with tons of cover reproductions and the the two new prose stories had numerous illustrations. The Joe Wehrle Jr. cover was excellent and convinced me to buy this book.My favorite articles of course are related to the SF digests the article about H.L.Gold's run at Galaxy and the interview with current Fantasy & Science Fiction editor Gordon Van Gelder.  That article had the only one error I noticed when the interviewer stated TV Guide was no longer published. I have been a four decade long subscriber. True, it is no longer a digest  (now the size of Time or People) and no longer weekly. It comes out about 30 times a year with numerous double issues covering two weeks.The Archie digests were a gateway to bring my pre-teen daughters into the world of reading, They loved them and I subscribed to a ton of them for them.  I found that article very informative.Even the articles about magazines I never cared about like FATE and CORNET, I found interesting and has tempted me to look for back issues.And WOW the price is a steal . If you are a reader of any kind I recommend this wonderful new book for you. It is great I can't wait for the next issue.

Volume 5 of Steve Canyon brings us another two years of Steve Canyon from 1955 and 1956. The Dailies are printed in crisp black and white and the Sundays in lush full color. Truly the strip has never looked better.Milton Caniff a master from the chiaroscuro school of art is at the top of his game here.  After eight years of doing Steve Canyon, it was a bonafide success and Caniff felt confident enough to tell some very experimental and unique stories here.The first story winds up a stoy-line introduced in the last volume with General Index and his wife with a shaddy past Delta. Pipper the Piper readers should be aware was based on John F. Kennedy.The next story-line reintroduces Doe Redwood while Reed Kimberly who resembles Terry Lee (from Terry and the Pirates) enjoys a romance with a young lady.  Things end very darkly for Doe.  But this story is not nearly as dark as the next one.The next story is my absolute favorite of the volume and a total gut-wrencher. It follows Summer Smith now Summer Olsen as she is trying to escape the evil clutches of the Villainess Copper Calhoon. Copper has her under watch and seems determined to wreck her life and bring her back under her control. Summer experiences a brief taste of happiness in the form of a budding romance. In the meantime Steve plays almost a cameo role in the storyline. We know Canyon is on a path to see Summer.  When he finally meets Summer he completely destroys her life. This by far is one Caniff's best.Caniff must of realized how dark this story was because next he does a 180 and the strip reintroduces Happy Easter and his troop of Hooligans. This starts out as a series of gag and humor strips mostly until "the Scarlet Princess" story-line emerges. This story is about actress Savannah Gay getting Happy to finance her next movie.  Besides being beautiful Savannah really has no redeeming qualities, so I found Steve and her romance kind of strange.Next we go very dark place once again for the story involving young General Shanty Town. This is a very realistic and heart breaking story which packs an wallop. The unrequited love story is also very well told.Finally we close out the volume with the Introduction of Steve's cousin Poteet Canyon. Poteet would become a very integral part of the strip for the next three decades so it is fascinating to see her origins.Bruce Canwell does an excellent job once again with his Introduction.He not only sets the stage letting you know what was going on during these years but gives you insights to the makings of the stories featured here.I can not praise high enough the quality of this book from Dean Mullaney and The Library Of American Comics.  It is a delight and made to be treasured and read over and over.My Highest Recommendation.

This Masterworks collection reprints 12 issues of Thor from 1973 and 1974. Thor #217 to Thor #228. the writing is by a young Gerry Conway and the art is by Big John Busema for the first ten issues then Rich Buckler steps in for a very capable two issue fill in.  As Gerry points out in his introduction the writing is an improvement from last volume and much more cohesive.  The art is very good.  I remember reading these as High School student and being a bit disappointed in the book at the time. As teenager still desperately clinging to art form my peers found juvenile I found their flying ship "The Starjammer" too stupid and very unrealistic.My favorite Thor stories  and the ones I think work best are the ones soaked deeply in Mythology and Legends or the ones with Thor on Earth doing the "Fish Out Of Water" type story. Gerry don't do a whole lot of that and mostly uses the book as his venue to do big sprawling Science Fiction stories.The book opens with Thor #217 with Thor and his band of Heroes returning on the StarJammer to find evil duplicates in all their positions in Asgard.Our heroes don't stay is Asgard long as The Starjammmer is refitted and a three issue Space Opera tale  is launcfhed. Thor #218 to Thor #220 Gerry reveals were based on John W. Campbell's "The Black Star Passes".Next Greek God Pluto has abducted the lovely young Norse Goddess Krista. So in Thor #221 to #223 Thor goes to Olympus and then to Earth to gain Krista back.  Thor acts like a knuckle head in this story, first believing Hercules is involved in the abduction, then taking time to arm wrestle Hercules to see who should rescue Krista.  This is the start of twenty issues of Hercules hanging around as Thor's side kick. He stayed in the book until Gerry Conway left.  While I love Hercules it did take the attention away from Thor. Herc is an impulsive, lovable rogue and next to him Thor seemed pretty boring.Finally we get an even bigger five part Space Opera tale in Thor #224 through #228 with The Destroyer, the newly introduced Firelord, Ego the Living Planet and Galactus. My favorite parts of the opus was the early parts set on Earth. Thor is forced to become Dr. Don Blake after a year of him being gone.  Some interesting material is explored by Conway when Don Blake tosses the cane that facilitates their body switch out the window and then wonders if he did it on purpose.As Galactus' new herald it appears Conway had bigger plans for Firelord and he did appear in many Conway written books afterwards but never attained the level of success of the Silver Surfer.While I still hate the Starjammer I had a fun time rediscovering these stories and the Buscema and Buckler art is quite nice. The extras are a bit slim in the back of the book with a single pin-up, a couple pages of original art and art done for Thor's Treasury Edition. The reproduction and color restoration is the same fantastic quality we have come to expect from these volumes.Recommended.

0:44 Mins I have a large kitchen with laminate floors and small children so I've always found cordless vacs convenient and almost a necessity in my household. My first generation Shark sweeper served me well but I always had problems with the battery life. This Electrolux so far has demonstrated an excellent battery life with its lithium battery, which charges from a port on the base. It picks up even the smallest of crumbs but it has a little problem with larger items the size of a Cheerio. What makes this most convenient is that it has a quick release button to take the vacuum off and pick up items the base misses. One thing I do not like about this vacuum is that the base is very wobbly and topples over easily.

This At-A-Glance weekly calendar measures approximately 8"x5" and is a convenient and portable size. It is large enough that you can write normally without using micro-small handwriting.The flexible cover is a soft faux leather in neutral tan color with orange accents.This planner is organized by 2 pages dedicated to each month followed by 2 pages per week. There are pages for contacts, notes, special events, a zip code/time zone, and 1 clear pocket page. There is an opening to which you can add or remove to this planner.

I still use a paper planner to keep my schedule and that of my kids, organized and available for all of us to reference. This planner is a convenient size (imagine a 5x7 photograph) to carry with me in my purse yet large enough to write in without using extra small lettering.  It covers a school year from July 2015 to July 2016 and has both week to week and monthly formats. The cover is flexible, the spiral has an opening that makes this planner customizable and refillable. The color scheme and pages of this planner is so pretty with its grey color scheme and pink accents.

I have always liked the look and versatility of sheer curtains. These offer my window a little style and the sheer allows me to let some sun in, see outside but peeping eyes cannot see inside during the day. At night with lights on, you can see inside the house. These are a lot more scratchy than I expected them to be. If I saw them in person, I would have probably passed on them because fabric texture and feel is an important quality for me. That said, you also have to consider the price and they are beautiful to look at from a few feet away. My favorite thing about this window treatment is the lattice print. It's very modern, low key and not the dated traditional lace print that I'm not too fond of for my windows. I don't dislike them or love them. I am satisfied for the cost and do feel it is a good value. I'll order a second set to complete the other windows in the room that they are in. I would recommend washing them first to remove the wrinkles and soften them up.

These sterling silver halo blue topaz earrings would compliment any woman. They are small enough that you can wear them in the day and large enough to see them sparkle at a distance. They are about the size of a #2 pencil eraser. They arrived in a pretty blue box which makes for a nice gift presentation. The only issue I had with mine was that one of the backs would not stay on and I had to pinch it with my teeth (not recommended, use a tool) to tighten them. I haven't had the back slip off since doing that.

This was a great read for me. This author will give it to you straight, but thar is in a style that I found refreshing and easy to relate to compared to other relationship books available. There were so many topics thar I found myself nodding my head and saying, "Yep!!"  Most chapters are brief and I wish they were longer. It is a quick read and I wasn't able to put down until I finished it. I think it would make a nice gift for a friend who might be involved in a troubled relationship and looks to you for advice.

I have long straight hair and I used the Fekkai Soleil Beach Waves on my towel dried hair and scrunched it up with my hands. I let it air dry and was left with some waves but it looked better after I twisted my hair into a bun and took it out after an hour. The spray smells nice, is sticky on my hands but not in my hair. It did leave my hair feeling noticeably heavy, filmy and not as soft as it usually is. I'll add some pics to this review. I think it's worth a try if you're looking for a carefree beach look. I like it.

I wanted to be able to track the distance and speed of my bike rides so that I can improve my fitness. I didn't want to spend a lot of money on this as I have found so many things I want with my new bike. I opted for this wireless computer based on the high ratings and lower price point. I've been using it for a month and here are my thoughts.Installation: difficult when it did not have to be!  If written instructions were included this would have taken much less effort. The instructions I received were so unclear with pictures and arrows pointing this way and that. I had to remove and reposition my sensor and transmitter 6 times. Luckily I had spare zip ties because they only give you enough for 1 install.Accuracy: excellent, based on all of the traffic Mph radars I have passed on my bike rides.Ease of use: excellent, despite the lack of directions, the device is very easy to program for what I like to use it for- distance and speedValue: excellent, compared to similar devices available. If you are going to bother using a computer, accuracy is key.  Wireless is a must have for something like this.

I don't have previous experience with bike racks as this is my first one. We recently purchased bikes for the entire family and needed this to transport them to the places we like to go. So far I am very pleased with the 4 bike version of the Vertex.Some of the things that I like about this rack are.1) Super easy to install and I'm not mechanically inclined.2) Lightweight - this is subjective but at approximately 40 pounds, this weighs less than many other things I haul in and out of the car on a daily basis (baby stroller)3) Stable and secure - When loaded with 1 or up to 4 bikes, they are securely held. This surprises me because 4 full size bikes is quite a load. In addition, I appreciate the cable lock so I can lock my large investment of bikes onto the rack when they are unattended.4) Design and style - I really like the sleek and clean look of this rack on the back of my car. I also love that I can swing the arm of bikes or sometimes, empty rack out of my way and access my cargo area via the hatchback. Very cool! I can fit my installed rack into my garage but I don't know if this is typical or if I am just lucky.Overall, I am thrilled with this Thule and would recommend it to those looking for a  bike rack.

This could not have come at a better time! As I type, I am laid up in bed nursing a knee injury. I can use this to control my music and volume. I also love the fact that you can set up a tripod and use it as a remote shutter. It has a hidden keyboard as well. When I first paired it to my iPhone 6, it took over my keyboard, assuming I would use the remote for that. There's a button you press to disable that. It uses two CR2025 batteries. The remote is slim, sleek, feels nice in my hand and has just enough weight to it that it doesn't feel like a cheap piece of plastic. I previously purchased and reviewed a piece of junk labeled as a remote. It was horrible. This Satechi is amazing. I am smitten!!!
Love this talisman. It's very unique and has a beautiful message. I will pass this along to my daughter one day. The pendent itself has a solid weight to it.

I've always been a fan of the Otterbox defender but I must warn other to stay away from this hot pink color. It absorbed the dye from my pants and jeans and would not clean off. I had to file a warranty claim to get a replacement (a darker color)  Protection is good. There is room for improvement. The opening for the charger is a bit large and I have scraped my phone on more than one occasion when I missed the charging jack.

I had these in my cart for months and when I saw them on sale, I had to try them as I am sick of wearing frumpy sweats and yoga pants. Now I want more. I love them! They are so comfy with the stretch but it's not so much that they are sagging at the end of the day.  I don't have to worry about any unmentionables showing when I bend over.

As a person who dislikes clutter in a very bad way, I love the small footprint of this Kenwood Compact Processor and blender. I keep the appliances that I do not use very often stored in the cabinet. Due to this units' compact size, attractive and sleek body, I opt to let this reside on the counter. I often make protein shakes when I come home from the gym and having this out on the counter enables me to start on that as soon as I walk in the door. The motor is not as loud and obnoxious as my old blender and mixes the ingredients to perfection. The reservoir itself is also smaller in size and does not hold as much liquid but for a couple shakes, it's perfect for me.  I do not use a food processor as often so that reservoir stays stored in the cabinet until needed. It chops my veggies to my desired consistency and saves me a ton of trouble when preparing meals. I found clean up pretty easy. There are just a few pieces to clean and reassembling them is a breeze. This unit has 2 speeds. I tend to use the high speed the most for the blender and the low for chopping.  Grating my own blocks of cheese saves me a ton of money on the prestressed variety and it tastes better freshly grated. The feet have suction cups and keep this powerful little gadget from bouncing around.

This whimsical flower fan adds a splash of fun color to my daughter's room. The fan comes comes fully assembled except for the blades. The blades are rubber and easy to install by just unsnapping them off and on. The blades being softer than a traditional fan make it a safe option for a mature child's room. I would not put this within reach of a toddler or curious child as they can still get their hair caught up in the blades if they get to close to it.  It is lightweight, produces a good amount of air to small bedroom with its 2 speeds. It is very quiet, so if you're looking for a fan for white noise, this is not the fan for you. It does not rotate.

Cooking healthy has never been so easy. I like using this to steam fish, chicken, shellfish and veggies. It is easy to use and I can have dinner on the table in 30 min or less. Prep work is eliminated and I don't have to babysit the food. I set it and let it do its thing. Cleaning it does take a little more time than a crockpot but using it takes no pre planning. I can throw frozen items in there without having to thaw them out ahead of time. I really like the separate compartments and my kids appreciate that, too, as one of them strongly dislikes anything from the sea (unless it come in a can: tuna lol)This is a great appliance to have to easy and healthy cooking.

I have a large yard and many stray cats roam the neighborhood so there's fleas galore. This works very well to keep the fleas away.  The applicator is easy to use with no mess. The formula stays greasy looking on his fur for a few days but absorbs well in the end. We like it.

A large cystic pimple graced me with its presence the very day this was delivered to my house and I was excited to test it out. The scent has a slight minty-eucalyptus smell but is in not overpowering or chemically smelling at all. It comes out white and dried clear on my skin. As per the directions, I rinsed it off after 10 minutes and the salt seems to have dried the area out and sucked out all the oil. This left my treated area very itchy but I did see a noticeable difference after a couple of days. Be sure to moisturize the treated area or you may experience that as well.

I have dry skin and it is especially bad in the winter.  The skin on my fingers crack and bleed and because wash my hands so often, it is a constant battle.  The Eucerin diabetic formula goes on smooth and absorbs fast. It feels a little thin (watery) and I expected it to be thick since it is marketed for diabetics.  My skin is silky soft all day long with the exception of my hands but I need to find a heavy duty cream for them. There was no scent in the version I received.

The delivery of this mattress was a very funny event. It showed up on my doorstep in a 3'x4' box and when opened, it presented itself as a large duffle bag (see pics next to my 5'4" frame). It was a beast to get out of the packaging. I resorted to cutting the duffel as there was NO WAY this mattress would ever be able to fit back inside.The mattress had to regain its shape and size and this process took about 2 days but I could not resist plopping myself on it immediately. Even at its newly uncompressed state, I was infatuated.After letting it sit for 2 days, I decided to give it a whirl overnight and it was amazingly comfortable. The innersrings do not make any noise when shifting. My back feels supported and I woke up feeling refreshed and well rested. This mattress will be used in my child's bedroom and so far she likes it very much. I have no complaints. I am very happy with the speedy delivery and ease of which it was to move this through my house and to the second floor on my own.

Agata is in Norway on business, she's of Scandinavian descent herself. So when her business is completed she goes sightseeing. At a village fair she's given a herb drink by an old woman. When Agata wakes she finds herself in a strange place and she's been captured by a viking named Stian. Neither speak the others language, so communicating is impossible. But Agata understands one thing Stian desires her.I found this story more romantic than I had expected. I liked both characters, they were well matched even though they're from different worlds. The sex is well written as usual. A very enjoyable short story.

Pro football player Mal Hughes is driving home after attending his twin brothers funeral when the strangest sight he's ever seen is up ahead on the road a runaway bride, complete with wedding dress. Sabrina had run away from her beach wedding when her grooms wife and child turned up to the ceremony. Not really knowing where she would go she had run. Now there's this large handsome man offering her some help. Mal has his grief and Sabrina has her anger, together they find hope for the future.I loved this short story. It's got everything it's sweet, romantic and hot. I loved Mal and Sabrina together they were a perfect match. My only complaint I wanted more.ARC courtesy of the author via her assistant.

I've read every single book in this series. This story about Drevin who is the last of the original 6 Grizzly members without an old lady, is one of the best IMO. I loved Drevin and Allie together their story ticked all the right boxes for me. As usual the sex scenes were hot, Drevin envied his club brothers who had found happiness, but he thought he had reached the age where finding a woman to be his had passed him by. But when Allie moves to town he can't stop thinking about her. She has had a rough time and is trying to make a new start.Loved this story, Drevin is a big bad dirty talking bear shifter, Allie never stood a chance at resisting him. She asked Drevin to do something I dont think any of the women have asked in the previous stories, I've always wanted them to so I was pleased that Allie did. I love this series and can't wait for whoever is next to get their story.

The sixth book in The Last Riders series covers the previous five books and then gives more. I wasn't sure I was going to enjoy this one, I had the notion that a rehash of what's gone before would not be worth the read. I've read all the previous books, some I've loved others not quite so much. The same could be said for the characters. But what I hadn't bargained for was how very quickly I became engrossed, yes there are lots from the previous stories, but there are plenty of scenes that readers didn't get to read because they happened in the background,as each book mostly stuck with the scenes the heroine's were in. With it being written from Shade's POV we were we privy to these, it was interesting being inside Shade's head, sometimes during Shade's Fall I didn't always like how he treated Lily, but being able to see his reasoning behind his actions pulled things into focus. I have to say some of the characters whom I previously disliked have changed my mind how I think about them. Except for Bliss if anything I dislike her even more. I wasn't too keen on Lucky either, I had liked him a lot before this book. We'll have to see how his story pans out. The brand new part of the story was dramatic and emotional. The ending was even more so. The author has outdone herself IMO.

This is the second book in the Grizzlies MC series, Rabid and Christa were featured in the first book. After what happened to Christa, Rabid has been keeping an eye on her. But it's become more than that, he's obsessed with her, but she's determined to keep him at arms length. Rabid is sure that Christa is hiding something from him and he knows that sooner or later he will find out what it is. Christa thinks she knows what sort of man Rabid is, little does she know how far he will go to get what he wants and keep her safe. When everything comes to light it not only affects Christa, the Grizzlies are involved as well. Rabid will fight to his last breath to do what's right.This is another hard hitting story from this author. I loved the characters, the story was action packed, yes there's violence, but this club has to fight to survive. Rabid and Christa are great together, the sex was hot and explosive. This is a real page turner. I can't wait to see who's story is next.ARC courtesy of the author.

Three short stories about bad boys, I really enjoyed this, if you're looking for a lighthearted sexy read this fits the bill. All three tales have engaging characters as well as cute plots. If I have to pick out a favourite it has to be Erin McCarthy's story. It was such a sweet read. This is the sort of book that I think is ideal to read on holiday.

Will Tucker needs a housekeeper on his ranch he asks his sister to advertise and find him a suitable candidate. When Linnea arrives she's not what Will was expecting at all, instead of the sturdy middle aged widow he thought would arrive, instead is this diminutive woman who looks like she hadn't eaten in a month, her clothes were worn and dowdy. Not one to hold back his feelings Will's tirade almosts blasts poor Linnea right off her feet. But having to look after a ranch, his aged stepmother and do all the household chores as well he agrees to give Linnea a months trial.I really liked this story it's one where the characters show real growth, I might have given this five stars. But during the early part of this I felt that Will wasn't just outspoken, he was rude and at times his remarks were cruel. As for Linnea to start with she was just a bit too downtrodden and scared. I'm pleased to say that does change. Linnea is keeping a secret from Will and of course he's furious when he finds out. She's had a rough life so far, but is trying to put all that behind her. I liked reading about life on the ranch, and all the other characters who made this an enjoyable read.

When Meg Telford's husband Joe is killed in the war, she's struggling to keep their ranch going. Joe's family are pressuring her to sell. But Meg has no intention of spending the rest of her days living with Joe's mother. She has to find a solution, then she meets in town returning bad boy Tye Hatcher he's home from the war, but he's not welcomed by the town, he's the son of a prostitute and has been despised for that his whole life. When Meg puts a proposition to him that he marry her to save her ranch he's taken aback. He'd always liked Meg, she had never treated him badly, but he knows he's not good enough for her.A lovely story between two people that at first look are poles apart in their outlook. But Tye is keen to prove to Meg that he can be the man she needs. But there's always the fact that Meg was married to Joe, it was Joe that Meg loved, it was Joe's dream to build up the ranch. Tye wonders if Meg will ever feel anything for him. He's got a surprise in store for Meg as well, one that might drive them apart forever.This is a sweet romance that draws you in from the first page.

This is the second book I've read by this author, this story is set in 1850, Maeve Murphy and her two sisters have just buried their father having lost their mother some time before. The landowner wants them off the land and the cottage where they live. Set at a time in history during the Irish famine the three girls decide to sell whatever possessions they have and buy passage to America, they had found a letter and deeds to a cottage just outside Boston, that a past love interest had left their mother, after he had moved to America many years previouslyWhile waiting to board the ship a small boy is badly injured, Maeve immediately comes forward to help the child, back home she was the villager's go to person if you were ill or hurt. When the ships doctor arrives he's so impressed with her treatment of the boy, he offers her a job as his assistant on the voyage. Dr. Flynn Gallagher is a widower and unlike Maeve and her sisters he's from a very wealthy family. He offers to find jobs onboard ship for Maeve's sisters as well. It very soon becomes apparent that the single women on the ship soon see Flynn as husband material. Maeve feels positively dowdy next to the other women, but Flynn seems more drawn towards her, than the others vying for his attention.The whole story is set onboard a ship travelling from Ireland to America. While the author had obviously done her research as to what life onboard a ship in 1850 was like, it did seem like an idealistic view, I'm sure conditions were much worse than are portrayed here. The characters are very engaging and easy to relate to as well. I would have like a bit more chemistry between Maeve and Flynn. There is a slight religious tone to the story but it fitted in with the characters personalities and backgrounds. Overall this story was charming.

I've not read this author before but I was drawn to read this by the blurb. I can honestly say that for me this was a great read. It has all the essential elements that make a romantic read IMO. A down on her luck heroine, a hero who is badly scarred and closed off to everyone.Katherine had married Levi Cutter after a whirlwind romance, she fell pregnant very quickly. Levi left Katherine in town while he went off with a promise to return for her once he'd estsblished a home for her and their child. But 5 months go by and no word from Levi. When a stranger turns up claiming to be Levi's brother, informing Katherine that Levi is dead, she's left with little choice except to leave with Noah and return home with him to his ranch.I loved the story and the characters in this, it's one of those books you don't want to end. Noah was a conflicted character having been badly scarred at a very young age, he'd always been in the shadow of his younger brother Levi who was handsome and charming. What I loved most was how having Katherine come into his life gradually turned his whole perception on how others viewed him. It was lovely reading how Katherine broke through all Noah's barriers.

Lily Brooks a spoiled socialite from Conneticut inherits a large piece of land from her uncle. Lily intends to travel to Caldwell Kanas and experience living in the Wild West for herself. Her family are horrified, but Lily has a wild streak and longs for adventure. She manages to secure a position as the towns school teacher. So Lily sets out on the biggest adventure of her life.Upon arrival in Cladwell Lily excitedly decides to explore the town. Unaware that she has wandered into a less than salubrious part she's accosted by a group of men, but a stranger steps in to save her, Paul McGregor is a local rancher, tall and handsome he takes Lily's breath away till he opens his mouth and mistakes her for a whore from the local saloon.I won't say any more about the story, except that it is filled with a rich tapestry of characters that come alive on the page. There are many twists and turns to the plot, but at the centre of the story is the romance between Lily and Paul. I really liked this story loved the connection and the chemistry between the two leads.

I've enjoyed every book in the Chaos Bleeds series so far. This one with Shane "Pussy" not so much. Reasons? I wasn't convinced of the connection between him and Sasha. Pussy still seemed too hung up on Ashley who had recently been murdered. She had been one of the club whores, and despite Pussy's protestations that they were just friends I wasn't convinced. I liked Sasha she was bowled over by Pussy even though she was blind and didn't know what he looked like, she didn't know him well either, she instinctively trusted him.The drama with Frederick a dangerous and powerful criminal continues there was a confrontation in this, that when it ended I was left thinking is that it! Devil the Chaoes Bleeds president didn't end everything then and there. I didn't get that. So I'm waiting for the book where all the drama the the Chaos Bleeds and the Skulls have been having with Frederick comes to it's final climax.

Kael is one of a number of vampire kings who rule different areas of the world. Three hundred years ago his mate and queen was killed by the enemy the soul eaters. Since that time he has vowed never to be mated again. But he needs blood to survive, and this is provided by the "proffered" human women who are virgins, but Kael refuses to drink directly from them instead he hypnotises them and drains their blood into a goblet with a blade. He never hurts them, that is until the beautiful Shayla is the proffered who is next to serve him.This had all the makings of a good story but it was too short. What there was is very well written. But it is just a story about Kael and Shayla's mating. The sex is really hot and the characters are interesting. But I was left wanting more.

Loretta has been divorced from her husband for seventeen years, she left him after she caught him kissing another woman. Young and hotheaded she ran taking her three year old daughter Nona with her.Present day and Nona is is one year away from graduating from college, but she's decided she's not finishing school instead she's staying on her fathers ranch to live the life she loves. Loretta hasn't seen her ex-husband in years but is on her way to his ranch she's determined that Nona is going to go back to school come hell or high water, even if it means that Loretta has to put up with being near Jackson her ex for the summer.First read for me by this author. I really liked her writing style it flows drawing you into the story. Loretta is a fiery redhead with a take no prisoners attitude. Jackson is rather more laid back, he and Loretta had always been a hot mess together, they married young after Loretta became pregnant. What was nice was that although their characters have not altered with age, they have learnt to deal better with their pasts and the present.This is a traditional romance, it's not erotic nor is it filled with loads of sex scenes, so some might find it rather tame. What it does show is a couple reconnecting and finding their way through all the drama, secrets and lies that have affected their lives.

Many other reviewers have laid out the plot, so I would just like to add that this story is very well written the author certainly knows how to pull a tale together. Her characters are very well drawn and utterly believeable. It's one of those books where you can hardly wait to turn the pages to find out what happens next. If you like a romance that's got drama, angst and bags of emotion and chemistry. I suggest you try this, this is a first read for me by this author, I will certainly be reading more from her.

A quick read about a young woman who's been pampered and sheltered her whole life by her parents. Rosalie is engaged to be married to Winslow and is looking forward to their wedding when she hears a disturbing rumour. She decides the way to go is to ask Winslow outright if what she's heard is true. Winslow arrogantly confirms that not only does he have a mistress, but she's pregnant and he has no intention of giving her up.Rosalie determines to run away especially after her parents try to tell her that's the norm, that husbands have mistresses. Rosalie leaves and goes to visit her cousin Audra. This is where she meets Garrett the town marshal.This is a pleasant story that is simplistically written, I felt it might have benefitted from a little more depth. In particular there is a complete lack of description of the characters. The ending felt a little rushed as well.

The final part to Braxton and Emmi's story was a very satisfying read. This couple have had their ups and downs throughout this series, so it was nice to get an angst free conclusion. I've loved the characters and the story and can't wait to see what this author gives us next.

This is the second part of the mini series, the first book The Marriage Betrayal (Mills & Boon Modern) held much promise of a really great story, it was a shame that the second part was not as good, part two kicks off with Tally and Sandor are apart, during this period Tally has started her own business and is doing well although emotionally is another matter.she is asked to return to the house in France where she and Sandor made their home as it is being sold. She needs to retrieve any of her belongings, soon after she arrives Sandor arrives the passion and sexual tension between them is still strong and they end up in bed. But Tally has no intentions of staying with a man who does not love her, Sandor has made it clear to her that the only woman he ever loved when he was younger betrayed him, he does not do love! Tally returns home, only to be blackmailed by her Father to return to the marriage, which is possible as Sandor made it clear to her while they were in France that he wanted her back. Tally goes back to Sandor but keeps her secret! But Sandor has his own secrets! While they were parted he did something, and now the indisputable evidence of that is staring him in the face. He is then forced to tell Tally the truth of what happened during their split. This book was not an easy read too many issues to deal with in a book this length. Tally in this book is a bit of an emotional wreck and is easily manipulated by the people around her. As for Sandor what he did was a multi levelled betrayal in my opinion, it was not just what he did but who he did it with, and he only told Tally when he was forced to! So he was not honest himself!

I've read all the books from this authors previous "Until" series, Until November being my favourite. Kenton was a character that was introduced in those books here he gets his own story.When Autumn is the last surviving witness to murder in the club where she works as a stripper, one of the bouncers and friend to her Link, sends her out of state to stay with a friend of his Kenton. Autumn is beautiful, but she hates that as people judge her on her looks, which seeing she felt that way I was surprised she would strip for a living even if it was to help her pay her way through getting her nursing degree. Kenton naturally is attracted to Autumn, but has made assumptions about her, once he realises he's made a mistake he tries to put things right, but Autumn is having none of it.This is a romantic and sexy read that I really enjoyed. I liked Kenton a lot even if he was an idiot at the begining. But it was Autumn I liked the best, she's not one of those spineless heroines, she gave as good as she got. I also liked Kentons friend and sidekick Justin, I'd like to read more about him. I'm looking forward to more books in this series.

Prudence Bosworth is a lowly seamstress. While working at a ball repairing the ladies gowns she comes into contact with Rhys de Winter Duke of St. Cyres, Prudence is captivated by this tall blond green eyed man. When going home later that evening she witnesses him saving a female servant from the attentions of another man, Rhys becomes her hero. What Prudence doesn't see is Rhys bedding the maidservant himself later that night.Prudence is later shocked that day after returning to her lodgings to find a solicitor waiting for her. She then discovers her father, who abandoned her mother when she was pregnant and had fled to America, has died and left her a fortune. She's now an heiress worth a million pounds a year. Rhys the Duke of St.Cyres soon hears of prudence's changed circumstances and as he's stoney broke devises a plan to marry her. But he pretends that he has no idea that she has money, and Prudence who has already put him on a pedestal swallows every lie that falls from his lips.I liked this story Rhys was a really wicked Duke, and despite the state of his finances he lives a hedonistic lifestyle, the lies he tells Prudence were not nice. As for Prudence she's so enamoured of him she can't see the wood for the trees, she's a true romantic, and very innocent where men are concerned. When it all comes to light he gets his comeuppance. Despite all that I really liked him, I liked Prudence as well. This is a nice read.

Rose suspects her husband is cheating with his new attractive assistant, the hastily arranged business trip to china taking the assistant with him niggles away at her, so she insists on going along. But her husband arranges for her to travel on a separate flight, when she gets to the airport she discovers her ticket is for the next day, and without being able to meet up with her husband as arranged and as she doesn't have his itinery she has no way to find him. Then a man named Monty steps in to help her, he's an ex marine and at 50 he's still attractive, Rose with no experience of airports and foreign travel accepts his help.I had quite a few problems with this short story, in fact I've got a list! Rose has been married to her husband for a long time, they have two grown children so they are very familiar with one another so she certainly shouldn't be hesitant in speaking up, she had enough guts to insist on going. So when her husband suggests she travel alone, why didn't she tell him no way! Then once she realises his deliberate action in booking her a ticket on the wrong day, why didn't she at least try to phone him. In fact she didn't attempt to phone her husband at all! That was totally unrealistic surely she has his number. Then the ending, huh what was that! This story basically went nowhere IMO. Unless there's to be a followup which I cannot see that there is.

This is the second book I've read by this author, I really enjoyed the first book this one not so much. Set in the early years of the twentieth century in England. Lady Beatrix had been engaged to Will he's the son of a duke. But when he got offered the chance of a lifetime to go on a archeological dig in Egypt he jumped at it. He wanted Beatrix to go with him , when she refused he called the wedding off. That happened six years ago, Beatrix eventually got over Will and the resulting scandal, and is now engaged to Aiden. Then without a word of warning Will returns from Egypt. Having spent all his inheritance he's hoping to ask Beatrix's relative for a loan.This is a romance story about two people who claimed to love one another, but it always seemed to me that they loved their dream more. Will had always dreamed of going to Egypt to find King Tut's tomb. Beatrix dream was a bit more attainable, she wanted a husband and children and to share her life with the man she loved. Out of the two leads I preferred Beatrix, I found Will had no business expecting a young woman to follow him half way around the world while he blew all his inheritance, his father had died while he was away and he never even came back for the funeral, he had only returned home now when he needed to ask for a loan. He certainly hadn't returned to reclaim Beatrix, that was literally a byproduct of his trip home.I was never quite convinced of this couples love for one another, and this story lacked passion.

Caleb with his best friend and Partner Henry started out as fighters, the trust between them is strong. Moving on from fighting they now own a nightclub, but that's mostly a front for all their other activities. When Caleb enters a jewellery store to buy a goodbye gift for the woman he's currently having sex with he meets Donna one of the sales assistants. He's immediately attracted to Donna, she's nothing like the women he usually goes with, and she's not fawning all over him either. Donna is not stupid she can tell Caleb is dangerous, but as hard as she tries to get away from him there's no escape.First I'm guessing this is going to be a two part mini series, as I'm sure we're getting Henry's story as well. This is a grittier read from this author, to be honest I wasn't sure I liked Caleb to begin with, in fact I wasn't sure I liked him much better by the end. Nevertheless he is a larger than life character a true anti hero. He's a bit like Kristen Ashley's Knight on steroids! He steamrolls his way into Donna's life and bed, and as much as Donna knows she should stay away from him, Caleb refuses to take no for an answer. His blunt way of speaking including his dirty talk scares and excites her. Donna does come across as a little bit timid, but when pushed she certainly knows how to hold her own. With hot sex scenes this is a recommended read.If I have a complaint this needed to be longer, as I wanted more. I look forward to Henry's book.

Wow I was really disappointed with this story. Overall I've enjoyed this series the first couple of books not so much. But Cash has been an interesting character throughout and I was keen to read his and Rachel's romance.What I didn't expect was to read about Cash having sex with other women numerous times, and that's exactly what happens throughout the first 50% of the story! and he didn't restrict himself just to the club women either. And when he wasn't indulging himself with the female population of Treepoint he made sure he hurt Rachel emotionally by opening his big mouth. I don't want to read about the hero of any book not just this one, having sex with loads of women other than the heroine. So on that score this book lost on every count for me.Elsewhere in the story there's plenty happening but it wasn't enough to redeem this IMO.

I'm going to keep this review short, or I'm liable to ramble on about this book as it's one of the best books I've read so far this year, the plot is brilliant, the characters all of them are wonderful, but Marcos is the star for me he's now one of my all time favourite hero's. Katie has that air of innocence and is a good person. Marcos is in his own words is a bad person, a gangster and a thief, he's also a member of a gang with a dangerous reputation. Katie is a high school teacher, they're complete opposites but they just worked. The sex is hot but more than that it's passionate and you can really feel the connection between them.I really loved this book it's a real page turner, a note to the author please don't make us wait too long for more.

This is a quick and enjoyable story about Ava who has just lost her job and is worried how she will manage. Luckily she has an interview as a pa at a BDSM club. Roarke not only owns the club he's also a Dom his long time partner Sam is his sub. For a long time they have hoped to add a woman to their relationship, but have never found the right one, that is till Ava arrives for her interview. But Ava is new to the BDSM scene so they have to go slowly, it doesn't help that she initially thinks they are gay. Ava has a personal issue she's embarrassed about, she fears that once Roarke and Sam find out they will discard her.I really liked this story by an author who is new to me. Yes there are scenes of BDSM in this, but it's also sweetly romantic and emotional. The characters are likeable and sympathetically written.

I really liked Donovan and Mara's story, the chemistry and sexual tension jumped off the page. Donovan wants Mara but there are a couple of obstacles, his best friend Reece is her overprotective big brother, plus he's 25 to her 18. But Mara is a mature 18 year old and definitely knows what she wants, and whats she wants is Donovan.This contained all the right elements for me that made this a good romantic read, there's lots of sexual tension, and just the right amount of angst and drama. The characters are well drawn as well, Donovan who's had plenty of women in the past knows when he's met the right woman, Mara has always wanted Donovan. So to read how they get together was great. I liked this addition to this series, the authors writing has improved as this series has progressed IMO and I am looking forward to Ryder's story.

I'm loving this series about Braxton and Emmi, they've had some hiccups in their relationship, Emmi finds it hard to trust after her disastrous relationship with her ex Trent. Braxton's reputation as a player didn't help matters. It was nice to see the two of them totally on the same page as to where they're relationship is heading.I really loved Braxton in this book he's turned into a real romantic guy. There's plenty of hot sex as well. It was great to see Emmi's best friend Zoe more toned down and being more supportive. Loved the ending. Plus this time I'm so pleased the author gave the readers a date for the next book, which is out at the end of August.

This is probably my least favourite of this series so far, I had been looking forward to Butch's story but I felt a little let down by it. Butch I'm afraid to say got on my nerves with his indicisive behaviour. He's left the Skulls for the woman he wants, Cheryl and her son Mathew. Cheryl is a single mother struggling to get by, Butch has seen the other club members old ladies get hurt and doesn't want to risk that with Cheryl. Mathew, Cheryl's son is not Butch's but he's willing to be the father figure in his life. The threat from Butch's past makes an unwelcome return. Dangerous times are ahead.I'd like to say that to get the full picture as to what is happening in the Skull's series you really need to read the Chaos Bleeds series as well as the series cross over into each other. There are a few shocking revelations in this story the biggest regarding The identity of Mathew's father, I didn't see that coming! Overall I think this is more of a transition story and a stepping stone to the big finale. I just wish I could have liked this more than I did.

This is part one of a new series. Alexa Hunt is a plus size model, she mostly models fetish clothes, she's on her way to an audition which could mean a big pay day if she's chosen. The audition is taking place at a BDSM club, house master Jake Morgan spots Alex straight away, he manoeuvres her into playing a public scene.This is a hot read that I have come to expect from this author. This basically introduces us to the two main players Alexa and Jake. We are given a little background about them both, I expect we will find out more as the series unfolds. The sex is hot and well written. I will definitely be reading more of this series.

"Organize Your Day" teaches the reader how to maximize his/her time with organizing, planning, and other techniques. The book is organized in steps, with each step focusing on a particular aspect of maximizing your time. Two of my favorite sections are on the value of the to-do list and using incentives to increase productivity. The writing is well-organized and concise, making it easy to digest. If you're looking for a book on getting the most out of your time, I'd recommend this book to you.

I've been experimenting with a gluten-free diet for a few months now, and bought this book for guidance on what to eat. The book is comprehensive, covering everything from what gluten is to other harmful food additives, such as BHT, and of course the recipes. One of my favorite sections is on eating gluten-free on a budget. The recipes are eclectic, yummy and fairly simple to eat. Out of the ones I've tried, my favorite so far is the apple pancake recipe. The kids love it too.

Matthew Barnes' "Investing 101" teaches the reader how to invest and money management to have a stress-free, successful retirement. The author's investing system is relatively simple and easy to understand even for people without investing experience, such as myself. The book covers a lot of topics in addition to how to invest, such as how much you need to retire. The writing is clear and concise, making the material easy to digest. My one critique is that I wish it were a bit longer, but I can see how a more lengthy version would be less approachable.

Caesar Lincoln's "How to Stop Lying" is a comprehensive yet concise guide to understanding pathological lying and overcoming it. The book starts with the basics, what is a compulsive/pathological liar and why we lie, before moving onto specific strategies and therapies use to address compulsive/pathological lying. I particularly liked the chapter on humanistic therapy and group therapy. What I like about this book is that the information is practical and written with the approach of someone who wants to give advice that can be implemented. Recommended for someone wants a deeper understanding of pathological/compulsive lying and how to treat it.

J. Armand’s “The Immortal Coil” is a sci-fi fantasy (with action and horror elements) that follows a young man as his life is turned upside down by the arrival of otherworldly intruders. The novel opens with Dorian, an aspiring model, at a casting call. His life seems normal – the hunt for work, relationship with his family, experiencing a new place – until he sees a CDC van in his neighborhood. Strange, right? Turns out, it was just a small sign of what is to come – an encounter with terrifying mutant creatures. Dorian finds himself on a life-or-death adventure, learning about the creatures and trying to figure out a solution. He meets some interesting characters along the way, such as Noah, a martial arts expert whose weapon of choice is a short version of the katana. Armand does an excellent job balancing scifi/fantasy world building with lots of action and adventure. I’m a huge fan of fight scenes, and was pleased to learn Armand writes gripping, vivid scenes that put you right in the thick of the action. If you’re a fan of sci-fi fantasy with lots of action, you’ll love “The Immortal Coil.”

Dame DJ's "Downsize to Freedom" is a comprehensive guide to downsizing your living space to improve your life. The book opens by explaining the issues facing people in large houses (financially, emotionally, and in terms of time) and how downsizing can improve quality of life in a variety of ways. The author, writing from personal experience, addresses how large house payments and expensive, time-consuming upkeep have trapped people, inhibiting mobility and the ability to enjoy our homes. The author then moves onto covering how to make the move and then how best to enjoy your new, smaller space. The writing is comprehensive yet concise, making this an informative, relatively quick read that'll give you all the information you need. What I love about the book is that it's very practical. The suggestions are all things you can do cheaply and efficiently to improve your quality of life. If you're considering downsizing, I'd highly recommend this book to you.

Caroline Angel's "Madman Across the Water" is a horror novel about an evil in the woods that is killing people... Whatever this thing is, it's not new. The locals have heard about it for generations, but its behavior is becoming more drastic...more brutal. People decide to take a stand, but the thing in the woods is merciless and powerful. Does anyone stand a chance? Angel writes with bone-chillingly descriptive narration that paints dark scenes filled with horror. As is required for horror writers, she has a knack for building tension, making your hair stand on end at all the right moments. She also writes an eclectic cast of characters, none of which are immune to what lurks in the woods, which is important for allowing me to get immersed in the story. Recommended if you want a fresh horror novel to read before your soon-to-be-delayed bedtime!

Dr. Sally Ernst's "Gotcha! The essential handbook on Cyber Security" is a must-read for anyone looking to address the growing threat of cyber security vulnerabilities in their business or organization. Before you can address the problem, you need to understand. "Gotcha!" does an excellent job breaking down the field of cyber security so that someone with minimal knowledge of the topic can understand it. There's a list of the different kinds of attacker profiles and their objectives that really sheds light on what your business/organization is up against. After granting the reader an understanding of the threats, Ernst goes on to the action items -- how to make your organization or business safe? The book is well-written and concise with visual aids, such as graphics and charts, that make the read easy to digest. Recommended if you want to get the low-down on how to keep your organization or business safe from cyber threats.

Robert Anthony Ariello's "Tommy's Choice" is a story about a talented athlete who is pulled away from his dreams by bad company and bad decisions. The protagonist, Tommy Bilotti, is someone who has always been talented at sports, particularly baseball and football, and attracted the attention of scouts early on. But when Tommy falls in with the wrong crowd, including the slick, dishonest Carmine Longo, he finds himself on a dark path that'll pull him away from his dreams. As he gets deeper into the gambling environment, he starts to realize the danger of the lifestyle, and is forced to make a decision between the gambling culture and his athletic aspirations. Ariello writes with descriptive narration that captures the settings and characters. For anyone who has been an athlete, you'll be able to relate to the challenges that Tommy faces. If you're looking for a sports novel with great characters and an engaging plot, you'll enjoy "Tommy's Choice."

Having lived in New Orleans up until recently, I was excited to check out a mystery set there. The main character, 73-year-old Imogene Deal McGregor, travels to New Orleans with her son, son's partner, and bulldog for a parade, only to find a dear friend murdered. What ensues is a humorous, frantic search for the murderer. The deeper they dig into the mystery, the more convoluted it becomes. The plot is paced well, allowing the quirky characters plenty of space to show their personalities, and author Hunter Murphy does a great job capturing the setting, New Orleans. If you're looking for a humorous whodunnit with eccentric characters in an authentic setting, you'll enjoy this read.

Truth Devour’s “Illuminarium,” book 1 in the Soliloquy Labyrinth Series, is a fantasy/paranormal novel with a thought-provoking philosophical theme. The reader follows a psychologist, Harper, as she journeys into a mysterious world, explores her past, and finds herself in the midst of a push-and-pull conflict between good and evil.With descriptive, philosophical writing, Devour manages to draw the reader into the main character’s mind as she navigates a variety of abstract concepts and ideas. The main character possesses a thirst for knowledge that is insatiable, despite struggling to see beauty in the world, at times. As readers, we are exposed to important ideas about introspection and moving forward while being entertained with a fascinating plot. A powerful, thought-provoking novel, I’d recommend “Illuminarium” to everyone who wants to read paranormal fiction that’ll make them think.

Jim West’s “Circulus de Potentia,” the second book in the Magicae Mathematica series, takes the reader on an adventure as our young hero races to find an enigmatic wizard to help her crack the secret of a mysterious symbol (the Circulus de Potentia). As in the first book, math and Latin play an important role in the plot. For those with a math/history background, you’ll recognize Pythagoras – for those unfamiliar with him, you’ll learn!Alex’s journey is every bit as eventful as the first book, with her contending with wolves, a mysterious forest, and a perplexing maze. Fans of the series will be delighted to know that the Guardians and Archimedes have returned. West does an incredible job seamlessly incorporating mathematical ideas into the story so that even someone who isn’t interested in math can get it excited about it. The cast of characters is diverse and interesting, further allowing young readers to engage. 5 out of 5 stars!

Mason Renee's "Evangeline: Sir Dred's Capture" is a novel about a young lady's journey to save those she loves from an evil king. The novel opens with the protagonist, Evangeline, on the run as evil beasts called crorochers attack her village. Her parents are killed, and she finds herself on a quest to find her brother. Her quest leads her to the evil king, Dredromous, who does the unexpected... Written in first-person, Renee does an excellent job writing a story that puts you in the head of the main character. With realistic dialogue and descriptive narration, you really get a feel for Evangeline's situation. The plot is paced well with plenty of twists and turns. Recommended for anyone who wants to read an engaging novel with a determined protagonist and a plot with a fantasy vibe!

Sherry Soule's "Smash Into You," book 1 in the Sorority Row series, is a steamy romance about a beautiful, young college student who must follow her heart when everyone else is telling her what to do. The protagonist is quirky 20-year-old Serena DuPont, a student at a fictional California university. She's through with romance, due to past experiences ... until she meets sexy frat boy Cole. The problem? The sorority she is pledging with forbids her to see him. Serena's life seems to intensify as pressure to dump Cole ramps up,  and she starts to worry about her relationship with sorority while trying to keep her grades up. Soule does an excellent job writing an engaging romance that captures the challenges and joys of college relationships. Definitely a must-read if you're looking for a fresh new adult romance.

"The Truth: Welcome to the Revelation" by AD Infinitum, the vehicle for its deep and eternal message, focuses on The Truth that is important for our children and the planet, in the hopes of igniting a transformative and unifying movement among peoples. "The Truth" is written by a master's qualified author.The end goal of "The Truth" is to achieve a new and peaceful world by dramatically changing our inner awareness and reviving our Essence towards peacefulness and fulfillment. The book is fundamentally a path towards a spiritual awakening by discovering The Truth with reflective text that asks readers to pause and think. We must wake up to what's happening around us, such as the common feelings of being lost in today's fast-paced society where we are "connected to soul-less pursuits" and the increasing prevalence of violence globally. We must break free from our Imposed and Foundational Connections and other limiting ways of thinking.I loved reading this eye-opening and heart-opening book by an author who sincerely wants to share this positive message with the world.  "The Truth" encourages us all to be compassionate with ourselves and others. The text is easy-to-read and is organized into three parts. The first part is about the revelation of Life Giving Energy and Source Energy.  The second part centers on the evolution that is knowing one's true self. And the final part provides encouragement and motivation to join the revolution to create a new world."The Truth: Welcome to the Revelation" is a book that will make you stop to think, search, connect, contemplate, and see yourself and the world around you in a whole new light with more freedom and more goodwill. Highly recommended!

Ludwig Lorrick's "Nigerian Dwarf Goats as Pets" is a well-organized book that covers all the important aspects of raising a lovable dwarf goat pet. The book starts with the basics, such as the property requirements for a goat owner, then moves onto more advanced topics, such as vaccinations. The writing is clear and simple, making it easy for a goat newbie like myself to understand. A good buy for someone interested in getting a Nigerian Dwarf Goat.

Victor Fox's "Dolce" is a gripping mystery novel filled with twists and turns. The plot kicks into gear when the young, intelligent Abrie Bachmann is mysteriously attacked. She awakes and learns from the determined detective Lukas Stein that her parents have been killed. The pair travels to California to get answers, and soon finds themselves unraveling a mystery that goes deeper than anyone could have imagined. Fox does an excellent job developing the back stories of each character and incorporating these details into the plot. One of the strengths of the book is the pacing; there is a perfect balance between tension, climax, and resolve. If you're looking for a fresh mystery with likable characters, you'll enjoy "Dolce."

"Deliciously Doable Small Plates from Around the World" is an eclectic combination of tasty, fun-to-make dishes. Author/chef Marisol Murano's book includes dozens of recipes from a variety of cuisines, from Japanese to American to South American. There are some classic dishes, such as sliders, as well as less common (yet equally delicious) recipes. The color design and beautiful photos look great on my Kindle Fire, which is handy for having next to me in the kitchen while cooking. I've made a dozen of the dishes so far and am more than happy. Recommended if you're looking for a new cooking book with lots of variety!

If you're a Christian looking to grow in your faith, this is the book for you. Author and pastor Rolando Gayo uses clear writing based on scripture to inform the reader about developing your relationship with the church and growing in your faith. Whether you're a new Christian or have studied the Bible for years, Gayo's thought provoking writing will get you thinking in new ways about your faith and how to strengthen it. Gayo touches upon a wide variety of topics from the nature of sin to the fulness of the Holy Spirit. 5 stars.

"Driving Grandpa" is a laugh-out-loud story about the adventures of a determined, high-spirited grandpa and his adult grandson. The narrator is the grandson of a WW2 vet who isn't supposed to drive anymore -- being the good grandson that he is, he decides to chauffeur his grandfather around. He ends up getting much more than he bargained for. The grandson takes his grandpa along on his work drives, creating endless opportunity for grandpa to interject his wisdom, humor, stories, and mayhem-inducing behavior. The pair is an unlikely duo that results in endless laughs. There's a story where Grandpa becomes obsessed with the idea of visiting Betty, a woman he knew four decades ago, that is hysterical. Although this is fiction, I could relate to a lot of the exchanges the characters had, and I finished the book with a nice reminder to appreciate all the different perspectives the different generations contribute. A great read if you want a light-hearted, humorous book.

"My Day in Heaven with My Lil' Sister," by Quest Delaney, is an incredibly powerful story about how one man's psychic abilities allow him to experience heaven.
