The author, Delaney, writes with affecting descriptive language about being able to move past the pearly gates into heaven after the tragic loss of his sister. The book delves not only into this journey, but into other aspects of his life as well. This book is really about understanding and appreciation. It made me really appreciative for the gifts that life gives us and gave me a deeper understanding of what lies beyond our senses. If you want to read a powerful book about the afterlife, love, and appreciation, you'll love this book.

"Surreal Photography and Effective Advertising” by Raqee S. Najmuldeen is a powerful, well-written book aimed at providing designers a means of coming up with ideas for successful advertisements using surreal photography. Najmuldeen writes about how to combine real-life images in a way that is unique and attention-grabbing while being effective for advertising. One of the things I like about the way Najmuldeen organizes the book is that he builds from the ground up. He opens by discussing the concept of surrealism (its origins, the different styles, its role in photography) before moving onto its usage in advertising in terms of the brand, message, etc. Najmuldeen makes a strong case for the value of surreal photography in successful advertising using well-thought out reasoning, and provides clear steps for implementing the approach in your own work. If you’re a designer who wants to take a fresh approach to advertising, I’d highly recommend this book to you.

If you're looking for a book that has all the info about Google Glass in one place, you've found the right book. The book opens with the predecessors to Google Glass, including an attempt at augmented reality in 1968 that I had never heard of before, then moves onto the Google Glass program, the design aspects, anatomy, etc. The book covers all the bases in an easy-to-understand manner (as a pure tech layperson, I had no problem understanding the concepts). There's a section on Google Glass in education that I particularly liked, although all the sections are informative. Recommended if you're fascinated by Google Glass and want to learn more!

R.P. James "My Stepbrother Romance" is an erotic romance (there are lots of adult scenes) about two step-siblings who have eyes for one another and experience the progression of sultry glances into much, much more. The protagonists are Heather and Foster. Heather is in lust with Foster the moment she sees him, but is put-off when she learns he will become her stepbrother by marriage. But she moves past that... R.P. James writes a story that is engaging, erotic, and fresh. The characters are dynamic and developed. If you're into this genre, I'd recommend this book to you.

The final book of the Whistleblower Trilogy brings the series to a close with a brilliant, gripping conclusion. In book 3, Candle now has more information about what is happening to him and who is threatening his family. It's just a matter of deciding what to do with that information. And  can he do what he needs to do before it's too late. Heskett deftly balances the need to answer questions generated in the first two books while entertaining the reader with lots of action, suspense, and mystery. I'm usually pretty good at being able to predict endings, but this novella was so packed with twists and turns I was completely caught off guard. 5 stars for the finale to an excellent trilogy.

If you liked book 1 of the Whistleblower series, you'll love "The Legend of Kareem." Just as Candle thought things were settling down, he receives a mysterious letter and finds himself on a mission to save someone he doesn't know ... or put his wife and unborn child at risk. Once again, Heskett writes with his trademark blend of action, humor, and wit. Candle is a protagonist that fans of the series will grow to love even more in this book. His determination in doing what it takes to keep his family safe is admirable while his no-holds-barred commentary on the humor of situations is more than welcome. I laughed out loud a number of times in between being gripped by the action and suspense. A must-read for series fans.

Jim Heskett's "Wounded Animals," book 1 of the Whistleblower trilogy, is a unique thriller/suspense novel that'll grab your attention with the author's unique, witty voice and hold it with an engaging plot. The protagonist is Tucker Candle, a businessman who is warned by a Jesus-like stranger not to go on a trip the next day. Tucker dismisses the warning, only to find his wife missing and a dead man in his bathroom. The plot kicks into gear and doesn't stop until the end. Expect plenty of adventure, action, and suspense. Heskett writes with punchy, witty prose that makes for a quick, fun-filled reading experience. Definitely worth a read if you like thrillers!

"Why Brand Risk Management Innovation is a Game Changer" by Yvette Dubel is a succinct guide for business professionals seeking to gain an understanding of brand risk management in order to bring positive change to their company. The book presents a new perspective on common business issues, from declines in shareholder confidence to brand value. The book emphasizes the importance of innovative thinking over technology and makes the case for diversity and a friendly company culture as keys to solving new problems in this Information Age. The solutions to problems lie in having new perspectives from a diverse group of people. One new pathway is through Art Based Solutions, a company the author founded.The author marries branding and risk management in a unique way, infusing lessons from relevant current events, and always centers on increasing the customer base and cultivating a positive brand. These two issues are certainly at the forefront of creating lasting companies and meaningful workplaces. I really enjoyed the simple style of the eBook with its cogent organization, fun images, and informative quotes. "Why Brand Risk Management Innovation is a Game Changer" is ideal for all types of business decision makers who are interested in staying current and are looking for an innovative approach to common pitfalls.

Osazee Will Omoregie's "In Life Unleashed" is an inspirational read about the power of faith and optimism. With uplifting, motivating writing, Omoregie outlines the importance of having positive values and planning in attaining success in life. Omoregie frames his strategy in twenty steps. The steps are practical, and Omoregie describes how to implement them in your life. Although hesitant about heavy planning before reading, Omoregie has really sold me on the value of a life plan and taking steps to make it happen. If you're looking for a book to help you take a more effective approach to life, then this book is worth checking out.

Stan I.S. Law's "In Search of Freedom" is a fresh, romantic story about a cloistered man who encounters a woman who changes him in ways he could never have imagined. The books opens with a background on the protagonist, Marvin Clark. After his parents were killed by a drunk driver, he is ushered off to an orphanage where he becomes the person he is for decades. A shy man, he retreats from everyday life to worlds and memories he has created for solace and warmth. But when a beautiful woman named Jocelyn enters his life, he begins a journey toward new horizons. Law writes with powerful narration that is emotional, descriptive, and humorous. Unlike any love story I've ever read, this is a book that is sure to make you think about romance and relationships in a different way. A recommended read for anyone wanting to read a fresh love story!

Bridget Renshaw's "Cornucopia" is a touching, humorous, and fun collection of poems about growing up. The collection is extensive and eclectic, although the theme of growing up runs throughout. There are also humorous illustrations to go along with each poem. The poems are very relatable to children (covering topics like riding a Ferris wheel, doing homework, and helping out the family) , and this would make a great collection to read to a child before bed. The writing is whimsical and fun; one of my favorite poems is the silly "Chug the Slug." If you're looking for an imaginative collection of poems that is sure to stimulate the imagination of kids, "Cornucopia" is worth checking out!

Kenan Hillard's "The Collective" is a dystopian novel set in a post-apocalyptic future where power lies completely in the hands of eight wealthy families. The wealthy have formed an all-powerful Collective that rules with a totalitarian approach. It seems untouchable...almost. The protagonist, Abel, is out for blood when his father is executed. On the other side, we have Xonox, a vicious tyrant with dreams of crawling to the top by any means necessary. Hillard has created a fascinating, dog-eat-dog world where only the tough survive. The characters are developed well, and I found myself rooting for Abel on his journey. There's a lot of action that was written in a way that keeps you on the edge of your seat. Overall, if you're looking for a post-apocalyptic novel with an interesting protagonist and lots of action, "The Collective" is a fantastic buy.

Pamela Hamilton and W.T. Hamilton's "How to Tame Your Ego and Fuel Your Ambition" is a powerful book about controlling your ego to unlock the power of your ambition. One thing I love about this book is it starts with the basics, for example, explaining what the egoic mind is and how it impacts ambition. As someone with minimal psychology background, I found this to be very helpful. Once the reader has an understanding of the ego, Hamilton moves onto how to tame the negative aspects of the mind and fuel the positive aspects to stoke the flames of ambition. This book outlines a lot of info and covers a lot of ground, but the writing is clear and concise, making it easy to digest. My favorite thing about the book is that it's practical. It's information you can implement into your life to help you reach your goals. A recommend read if you're looking to harness the power of your ambition!

I'm a big true crime fan, so I was excited to get my hands on a book that covers the big FBI cases. The book is well-written, outlining the criminal's trajectory of crime and including important details about their personal life. The information is thorough yet not too wordy, which makes it a fairly quick read. What I love about this book is the cases are eclectic. You have cases that are classic, famous cases then you have some lesser known ones. You also have a blend of older cases (John Dillinger) and new ones (DC Beltway Sniper). I learned a ton from this book, and would recommend it to anyone who enjoys true crime books.

"The Privateer Clause" is a gripping murder mystery/thriller that takes place on the Sea Empress, a cruise ship. Marsha and Danny Jones are retired law enforcement officers who have been hired as security consultants for a cruise ship company. This responsibility takes them head-to-head with a group of unsavory individuals looking to wreak havoc on the ship. If I were to describe this book in one word, it'd be FUN! There's a ton of action, some humor, and plenty of suspense to keep you wondering what happens next. The story reminds me a bit of the Hart to Hart TV detective show. The cruise ship setting adds an interesting aspect to the story, and the author has done enough research on the setting to make it reasonable. If you're looking for a fun story filled with action, this book is worth checking out!

Catherine Hunt's "Someone Out There" is the story of a life turned upside down by unimaginable circumstances. The protagonist is Laura Maxwell, a determined divorce lawyer who has given up the London rat race for a more peaceful life with her husband. A series of peculiar accidents seems to have been sinisterly plotted, and Laura becomes obsessed with the thought that someone is trying to kill her. Terrified, the thought dominates her life. Hunt does an excellent job of putting the reader in the mind of Laura as she is overcome with fear. The mysterious nature of the situation is built up with masterful plotting and powerful narration. Hunt has a knack for writing scenes that have an extremely eerie feeling well before any threats are overt. You can really feel the tension. If you're looking for a new suspense/thriller, "Someone Out There" is worth checking out.

Jeffrey Miller's "No Solid Ground" is a powerful read that provokes thoughts about the value of ancient wisdom and the danger of not thinking about the future. Part ancient mystery, part personal development, Miller references the Sixth Extinction Event, a rapid change that poses serious threats to humanity while also sharing how to realign the mind and body. Miller outlines a number of transformative exercises to help with the process of getting ourselves in sync with the universe. The author's training in psychotherapy is evident in the professional, scientific approach he takes with the topic. He uses concise yet thorough writing to show the power of the interconnectedness of the self, society, and the universe. What I really like about this book is that it's a "big picture" approach to self-improvement. Only by thinking outside oneself can we truly improve ourselves. If you're looking to find contentment and happiness with a spiritual approach based on ancient knowledge, then I'd highly recommend this thought-provoking book to you!

Linda Sands’ “3 Women Walk Into A Bar” is a murder-mystery that revolves around the peculiar deaths of three beautiful women…and the dead man with a gun beside them. The protagonist, Bill “Free Willly” Tedesco, is a PI with a very unique past (he was a stripper...). As Bill delves deeper into what happened that night, the situation grows more and more complex. Sands writes in first-person with a film-noir tone, really setting the stage for Bill’s witty, cynical, and often-funny voice. I’m a big mystery reader and was really caught off guard with the twists and turns of the plot. Excellent pacing. Sands has stormed into the mystery genre with this successful debut novel that is sure to delight mystery fans. Recommended!

I was looking for an SEO book that had all the info in one place and was worded so a non-techy could understand. This book met my requirements, and exceeded my expectations! With clear language and expert knowledge, R.L. Adams explains the theory behind SEO. Rather than use tech jargon and say "insert this code or that code", Adams explains the concepts behind boosting pagerank, such as the concept of trust, relevance, etc. I found I prefer this approach because it gives the reader an understanding that is applicable to a wide range of situations. I've gotten started on implementing the knowledge in the book, and am looking forward to the results!

I bought this book for my trip because it has all the info I was looking for (where to eat, visit, etc) all in one place. This travel guide includes well-known classic sites such as the Balloon Fiesta Park as well as lesser-known places such as The Grove Cafe & Market. The restaurant options are eclectic from BBQ to Japanese food to veg, such as my favorite Annapurna’s World Vegetarian Café. One of the things I like about the book is that is a quick read. You get all the necessary info, with none of the fluff. I also love that it's a very visual guide, so you get a feel for the place before you go there. As an avid web user, I also found the link to Google map location for each place very helpful.  If you're looking for a comprehensive book to use when planning a trip to Albuquerque, this is the book for you.

Chris Elliott's "Thought Shredder" is a powerful read about becoming who you want to be, rather than what your past says you should be. The "ThoughtShredder journey" is a quest to take control of your past and move forward. Elliott introduces the concept of the Bucker, someone who "bucks" his or her statistical future instead moving toward what they want. For instance, children of alcoholics are more likely to become alcoholics, but Elliott empowers the reader to "buck" the trend. What I love about this book is that Elliott shares his own life, using it for teaching the reader. I found his examples to be concrete and very helpful in terms of understanding the concepts. If you want to take control of your life and want a book with excellent examples to help you do it, look no further than this book.

Stan I.S. Law's "The JEWEL" is a collection of powerful stories that revolve around the theme of love. Each story starts off with slice-of-life narration. Law builds the reader's knowledge of the character then takes the reader in an unexpected direction that is thought-provoking, emotional, fascinating, or all of the above. Collectively, the stories make you reflect with dynamic, realistic characters and impactful ideas. My favorite two stories are "Lovers" and "A Wondrous Flute," but I enjoyed all of them. If you're looking for fresh stories that are sure to stimulate your mind and emotions, I'd recommend "The JEWEL" to you.

Judith James' "Libertines Kiss," a romantic historical with elements of other genres, is a powerful story with fascinating characters. The protagonist, based on Earl of Rochester John Wilmot (played by Johnny Depp in 'The Libertine') is a cynical poet haunted by his past. A complicated young woman wins his attention, but he must first overcome his past to move forward with the present. There are quotes from Wilmot's satirical poetry throughout the book, which helps set the tone of the story. James does an excellent job taking the reader to 17th century England, and she has a knack for pacing the story with the perfect balance of crescendo, tension, and climax. She also writes some very steamy yet tasteful sex scenes. If you like romantic historicals (especially those with steamy scenes), I would highly recommend this book to you.

I've done consulting work online for close to five years now, yet have been uninterested in LinkedIn until recently. I originally wrote it off as a resume site for people fresh out of college. "Maximum Success with LinkedIn" helped me capitalize on the opportunities in LinkedIn to grow my business. Well-written, thorough, and concise, the book helped me in getting the most out of LinkedIn, from creating a profile that gets more views to learning how to find and engage the best customers for my business. In fact, I've even got some new consulting clients from LinkedIn as a result of reading Dan's book.

"The Medical Librarian's Guide to Natural Mental Health" is a comprehensive, well-researched book about nutrition and other therapies for a wide range of mental health issues, from anxiety to bipolar disorder to depression. The author references a number of scientific sources with each topic, only relying about trustworthy references. One of the things I love about the book is that the author emphasizes the benefits of practices like yoga, meditation, and exercise. There is also a lot of info on how diet (omega 3s, vitamin D, etc) can help with many issues. For me, the most informative section was the one about digital addiction. Compulsive texting, addictive gaming, etc have become serious issues in modern society, and this book does an excellent job of getting to the root of of the problem and how digital addiction impacts the mind.

Elliot Sloyer’s “Bat in the Bunk” is a children’s picture book, based off the author’s experiences, that is sure to make readers think, laugh, and learn. This book, the second in the series, revolves around David and Elliot’s return to summer camp. They find a bat (the flying, mammalian variety, not the lifeless, wooden variety), which sets off an exciting series of events. The story is written so that beginning readers can handle it, yet the book is also great for adults to read to children. The plot is fun and unique and sure to keep youngsters engaged. I also like that the book touches upon a number of important themes, allowing children to explore these ideas and make decisions about them. The illustrations are well-done and complement the text well. A recommended read for anyone who wants a children’s book that is fun yet thought-provoking and sure to delight young readers.

Jean-Claude Carvill's "Empower Me # 1: In the Spotlight" is a steamy erotic novel that follows yoga instructor Freya Moreton as she navigates romance. She's someone who knows what she wants, yet when she finds a man who seems to have it all, she is torn because he's lacking in one area...sex. But his best friend more than makes up for his shortcomings. Carvill writes a story that is paced excellently with the perfect amount of tension to keep you reading. I found myself really understanding the characters and I really was rooting for Freya. Recommended if you're looking for a fresh erotic read!

"Pinkie and Blueboy" is an epic story of companionship, fate, and the power of memories. The story, inspired by two paintings in a public library, focuses on two characters who share a brief moment together in their pre-teens. The reader gets to follow the lives of Sarah and David as they grow up, ultimately reuniting through both being involved marijuana trade and subsequent being imprisoned in Mexico. The author, Holy Ghost Writer, does an excellent job capturing the power of memories in this beautiful story, using poignant writing and powerful characters. Recommended if you want a thought-provoking, soulful read!

Mia Perry's "Billionaire's Cinderella" is a racy romance novel about a steamy attraction (there are adult scenes) between a handsome billionaire and a beautiful pre-med student. One of the unique things about this book is it opens from the male perspective of handsome billionaire Grant Woodward. You get to see his first impression of Roxy Danvers, a beautiful young woman who is much, much more than what meets the eye. The reader then gets to read from Roxy's perspective, taking the reader on an unexpected journey. The writing is steamy, and the plot is filled with twists and turns. If you're looking for a sexy romance that will keep you guessing, you'll enjoy this read.

If you love infusing your own water, this bottle is a great way to do it. Prior to this bottle, I was infusing in a water pitcher and then straining through a strainer. This bottle makes infusing water with fruit quick, easy, and portable. Great for trips or exercise. The bottle is sturdy and durable, and is a good size that'll quench your thirst and also be portable. I've been infusing strawberries and blackberries everyday, and have been very happy.

I have used a variety of snorkels and masks and this product is as good as any of the big name brand stuff. Underwater, the seal is tight and the straps adjust easily. The view is very clear. It's easy and quick to disconnect the snorkel if you only need the mask.  It also comes with a nice storage bag. It also has a check valve, which is great for the kids and inexperienced snorklers.

This stuff is terrific.  I live in an area with lots of humidity and storms--- not to mention ice in the winter.  As a result, many of the outside locks on my house were difficult to use-- the key would just stick and I'd have to work to get it in and out.  One quick dose of this product and problem solved.  It's easy to use and worked on every lock I tried it on.  It's not greasy or runny and so far the "fix" is lasting.  Very handy and worth keeping around the house.

This is a nice quality bar of soap.  it leaves your skin feeling soft and it lathers up nicely in the shower.  It is a large (4"x2" x 1 1/4") bar of soap, as it should be for the price.  The smell is quite strong when you first open the wrapper, but it's a pleasant rose scent.  (If you're sensitive to scents you might want to pass on this.)  The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars is that it is cut with sharp edges and I would prefer a bar with rounded edges for easier gripping. Very nice quality.

As the advertising says, this is 8 books in one, and at a very reasonable price.  This book coaches a budding business owner (entrepreneur) through all the necessary steps beginning with a unit on going "From Idea to Reality."  In this unit you review your business idea, test the market for it, determine its "attractiveness" from several perspectives, and investigate franchises.  And that's just the opening. After that you will determine the best type of business to plan (sole proprietor, S Corp, etc.), write a business plan, and find the funding. (During this time you will determine if a home business or franchise is best for you.)  Then the book gets into the trenches of business management with helpful guidance on building a website, managing legal issues and finances (including an extensive section on profits/losses and working with cash flow), and then covers hiring processes (including how to delegate to get more work done)  and the basics of marketing and image management.As you can see, it's very comprehensive-- and what I like about it is it forces a potential business owner to carefully think through areas s/he might not have even realized were important.  For instance, the section on how to hire and manage people isn't just a guide to basic management-- it includes details like creating a career development plan for your employees.Most entrepreneurs and small business owners have their own areas of expertise and comfort-- one may be particularly good with finance, another with marketing.  What I like about this book is it gives you a working knowledge of all the elements of running your own business which can help you determine where you might need to hire someone else, or get outside consulting for areas which you recognize you are not your strengths.Very educational and well worth the investment-- before you sink money into a business venture only to realize you didn't know what you needed to know!

I have been using this for a few days and am very pleased.  I cannot use regular deodorants and antiperspirants due to allergy/sensitivity issues.  For several years I have been using Trader Joe's unscented deodorant with cotton, which I generally like, but it contains propylene glycol which is not supposed to be good for you.  This product does not contain any bad ingredients and is easy to use-- just put a tiny bit on your fingers and apply under your arms.  It goes on smoothly and dries quickly.  Despite being a liquid, it feels almost dry to the touch right away.  There is a slight smell (kind of minty) which goes away quickly.  So far it has kept me dry (even though it's NOT an antiperspirant) and odor-free.  With summer heat approaching, it will be put to the test and I will come back and revise this review if I encounter any problems.  I predict this tiny bottle will last all summer given the small amount you need to use.

I absolutely love this toy.  It's cuter in person than in the pictures. The body is about 10" high and 6" wide and the feet and hair (?) add another 2" each.  It's soft and cuddly and has a small pocket (6" zipper and the pocket is about 3" deep) which has just enough room for some small pieces of paper.It comes with a little booklet (translated into 7 languages) which explains that if you're afraid of the dark, worried about homework, having trouble with friends, etc., this little "Worry Eater" is here to help.  You just write down your worries, place them in the zipped pocket and he'll hold onto them so you don't have to.  The pouch can only hold a few worries, which I think is good-- rather than having lots of worries pile up each night, the parent/child can throw them away as needed, symbolically letting them go.The concept is wonderful and it's not just for children-- writing down their fears and anxieties is a great way, even for adults, to get them out of your head so you don't ruminate all night about them.  Excellent companion for anyone whose worries or fears keep them up at night.

This is a nice set which would make a great wedding or shower gift.  The pan is heavy-duty and coated with Xylar so it is nonstick which makes it easy to prepare typical stir-fry or other items with thick sauces which might otherwise stick to a pan.  Because of the nonstick coating, it's best to wash it by hand, which can be a little cumbersome if you don't have a large kitchen sink.  There are also warnings about not heating this type of pan to 500 degrees-- presumably most home cooks will not cook at this high heat level, but it is worth noting that the bottom of the pan does get very hot-- which is why it makes stir-fry dishes so efficiently.  The steamer is a typical bamboo steamer-- it's OK, but the key reason to purchase this would be for the stir-fry pan.

This throw is soft and plush and very comfortable.  It arrived neatly folded and tied like a package and does not have any odor. It would be a great throw for a sofa, bed, or extra blanket on a cold night.  I am keeping it in my car to use as a blanket or throw when I travel to outdoor concerts and festivals. Nicely made.

If you have sensitive gums this product is very mild and won't cause the irritation that a stronger mouthwash might.  It does not contain alcohol so you won't have the alcohol burn.  The ingredients are generally good, and it does not contain some of the irritating chemicals found in other mouthwashes.  It has a slightly thick texture (not as watery as other mouthwashes) and a pleasant, mild, slightly minty taste.I found the labeling confusing-- it's supposed to help with discomfort after teeth whitening and other procedures (it even says it's an "ideal rinse for after teeth-whitening procedures" and "use twice a day to reduce sensitivity")  and yet a separate notice on the product label also specifically says,"Does not relieve or treat sensitive teeth, oral pain or gum disease." That seems to contradict the advertising.  I also did not like the fact that it arrived with a tag imploring users to give it a 5-star rating on Amazon.Overall the mouthwash is mild, comfortable and non-irritating.  I usually use Biotene products and, frankly, I don't see a reason to switch to this.

The first thing I noticed about this flat iron was the smell.  It had a strange burned plastic type odor when I opened the box.  It was encased in a plastic bag (which also smelled) and I thought removing the bag would take care of it but it didn't.  I put it in my bathroom and could still smell it the next day, so out it went to the garage for a few days.  After a week or so, the smell is much less but still there.  When I plugged it in and heated it up, the smell was stronger.  (Please note: the product was fine and not burning-- it just smells.) I did a search to see if this is a typical problem with ceramic flatirons, but smell issues seemed to be related to too much hair product building up-- not an issue with this brand new item.I did use the flat iron-- it's well-made, heats quickly, and the macadamia conditioner provided with it keeps your hair soft.  I tried to look up the conditioner to see if more could be purchased-- at the moment the Remington website shows the product (and wants you to "pin" it or "like"it on social media) but there was no price and no way to add it to your shopping cart, so I'm not sure if this is something you can replace or not.  I'm sure there are similar products available.So...were I just reviewing the quality and performance of the flatiron I would have given it 5 stars-- but the funky smell drops it down to 3.

Let’s start with the obvious: at 120 decibels, this is an extremely loud alarm.  There is no chance that you or your nearby neighbors will sleep through it.  That’s one particular advantage if you choose to place it on a garage entry door, an outdoor shed or a patio/screen porch door that’s not directly connected to your house.It’s easy to set up and all the mounting pieces you need to install it are supplied.  You do have to purchase batteries for it (3-AAA).  You can set it up to simply chime every time the door is opened or you can set the alarm feature.  The alarm has a 30-second delay, which gives you time to type in your code, but, that also means that a potential intruder has 30 seconds to disarm it by pulling it off the door frame and removing the batteries.  (There’s a blinking red light that will draw attention to the device.) This assumes, of course, that the intruder is sophisticated enough to know to do this (and the truth is that truly sophisticated professional burglars can deactivate even professional home security systems.)So I view this more as an “extra” dose of security to be used in addition to whatever else you might have.  That’s why I put mine on my screen porch door where my home security system isn’t set up.  I think it will scare away any “mischievous” types who might just be on the property but not necessarily trying to break in.  I keep mine on the chime feature most of the time.  That’s loud enough to hear through most of my house and, again, I suspect that might scare away someone who’s just prowling.  I'm giving it 5 stars because it works as described and is good for its purpose-- just know the limitations of this type of system.

It's hard to know where to start in describing this wonderful block set.  It's well-constructed, with smooth solid-wood blocks, labels/stickers that stay put and don't peel off, and even includes a cute picture book.  But what I really love about this set is the imaginative potential it has for a young child.  So much of our children's time is spent "receiving" creativity: watching TV shows, videos, or playing games that other people have created.  This block set requires the child to create their own stories and set up their own magical land of knights and castles. (Made me want to watch "The Princess Bride again!)  Children over 3 could easily entertain themselves with this set, but it is also fun to watch the stories they create and help them build both their motor skills and their language/creativity skills.  Highly recommend.

This is a very nice gift set. It's packaged well (it was a little hard to get the eau de toilette out of the box), and would make a very nice gift for any man.  I really like the scent; it's sort of woodsy and also citrus-y, and very fresh and pleasant.  I don't like strong scents, and this one is definitely not overpowering.  There's probably no need to use both products at the same time; if you use the shower get, that's probably enough, which means this set will last for awhile.  The packaging is a heavy-duty cardboard with the famous Lacoste alligator on the box.You will want to shop around a little and compare prices.  Prices vary depending on the store-- the price tag on the box says that the "retail value" is $92.00 and the "suggested retail" is $68.00, but prices seem to vary so check around.  Also, check your local department store-- sometimes these products come with special bonus gift items for purchasing at the store.  Nice high-quality product.

I recently purchased a different model of this air purifier and I wasn't very happy with it-- it gave off a plastic smell that actually made the room smell worse rather than better.  So I was a little unsure about whether I would like this particular model.  But no worries.  This model was easy to set up and run, and it did not give off any plastic smell.  I placed it in a room that had some musty odors from camping gear and it did the work-- the air was much better within a day.  It's a fairly quiet machine and can run all night (at least on the lower settings) without disturbing your sleep.As several others have commented, it would be nice to have a filter that could be cleaned and reused, but the filters aren't that expensive and if you don't have a smoker or pets in your house, you can get a fair amount of use out of one filter.  I would recommend this for home or office.

First of all, the Amazon price for this product is very good.  The manufacturer's website sells this bottle for $33, so you save about half by buying from Amazon.  Doctor's Best products seem to be generally well-made, and, according to their website,  they test their ingredients for pesticides and other unwanted ingredients, as well as maintain high levels of sanitation and quality control. These pills are gluten-free and non-GMO.This product is recommended for individuals who desire an enhanced sense of well-being, a sense of calm and relaxation, better sleep, and possibly weight loss.  Most of these benefits would be a function of the 5-HTP which is a precursor of the neurotransmitter, serotonin, rather than the vitamins. In theory, it should raise your levels of serotonin, which will improve your mood and help you sleep better.  (For that reason, you should not take it with anti-depressant medication.)  I trust Dr. Andrew Weil on supplements, and he is more of a fan of exercise, St. John's Wort, or SAM-e to attain the same benefits rather than 5-HTP. Some websites also warn about not giving this to children without doctor's supervision.I have taken these pills for a week and I have noticed that my sleep is somewhat better, but I'm also experiencing some nausea which is a known side effect of 5-HTP. So I'm rating them as "OK" for the moment until I learn if the side effects disappear. I will continue to take them and revise my review as appropriate.

A few years ago a nutritionist had indicated that methylation issues might be at the root of some autoimmune issues I was having, as did a Ph.D. chemist friend of mine who had dealt with her own methylation issues for her Hashimoto's and Crohn's diseases.  I didn't get much support for this approach from my regular physicians for this, so I didn't think much about it, until I had a flare-up recently and really didn't want to go down the road of the increasingly powerful medications that were being prescribed.I purchased this product after reading a lot of information on the internet about treating methylation processing issues.  Vitamin deficiency can be a factor in auto-immune conditions, and to put it simply, this product is mostly vitamins (B6, B12, D, etc.) in more readily absorbed formulas designed for individuals whose genetic structure prevents them from absorbing the nutritional value of regular off-the-shelf vitamins.It's a cream, so it absorbs through your skin bypassing any gastrointestinal issues.  It's a bright red/coppery shade (which freaked me a little at first-- I guess I expected a white cream from a white bottle), but I'm sure that's a function of the B vitamins in it. You also need to pump it quite a few times at first to get the product out-- for a moment,  I thought I had a defective bottle, but it just takes a lot of pumps.I used it as directed-- a dime-sized spot of cream on my inner arm twice a day.  For the first 24-36 hours I felt great-- more focus, more energy, better mood, and just generally happier and content.  BUT-- the second night I couldn't sleep.  I was absolutely "up" and felt very tight inside-- like I was going to explode.  My heart rate was fine (not racing or anything) but it was clear that something was going on with my nervous system.I realized at that moment, that perhaps self-medicating in this area isn't the way to go, but I knew if I went to my regular doctor he would likely just tell me to throw it away.  Given that I had an initial good reaction (placebo effect? I don't know),  I contacted a doctor the next day who is experienced in functional medicine and knows about these issues.  He told me that it might work for me-- and it might be that I just needed to ease into it.  He knows the physician/lab behind its production and said it was an excellent product-- the trick is just to see if it's right for me.  So he ordered some blood tests and a genetic test to see if I have the 5MTHR mutation.So if you think you have the medical issues that might benefit from this type of product, I strongly recommend you seek a physician with functional medicine, environmental medicine, nutritional training, or other related experience/education to guide you with this product.  You need a physician who will listen like mine did.I will update this review when I get the test results back.

Brow Drama: What a great name for a useful product.  I'm sure the intent was to focus on making one's eyebrows dramatic.  For me, my brow hairs have a mind of their own growing in whatever way they like (aging is so much fun...) and this product stops that drama.  The unruly hairs are now in alignment and look smooth and, well, normal.  My thinning brows also look a little thicker now that they are lined up better.It has a slight chemical smell when you first pull the brush out of the bottle, but there is no lingering smell. It's transparent, so it tames your brows without adding color. If you choose, you can use a brow pencil to add color.  The gel goes on soft, not sticky or glue-like.  I had no sensitivity or reaction to the product.I also think men who would benefit from this product.  I get it that eyebrow grooming isn't necessarily something most men consider, but sometimes a man's unruly eyebrows can distract from his appearance.  I think this product would be a great way to surreptitiously bring some of those hairs under control. No one will know the secret.  Just make sure you buy transparent rather than any shades. I think Maybelline should consider repackaging the product and placing it in the men's grooming aisle of the pharmacy.Great product-- will continue to buy and use.

As advertised, my supply of pens consisted of 5 red, 4 blue, and 3 green markers.  (Technically although advertised as primary colors, green is not a primary color-- that would be yellow, which is not included in this color selection.) They arrive as loose items with no container or carrying case. They have medium size tips, which are smaller than typical whiteboard markers, so they are better for a smaller sized whiteboard or a board where you want to include a lot of information.  The colors are true, although a little light.  The green markers are a sea-green shade, not the teal-like shade that the plastic cover makes them appear to be.  They did not dry quickly when I wrote with them-- I'm left-handed and they smeared a little if I wasn't careful.  On the other hand, they erased easily and quickly. So far, they are working just fine.  I keep them in a plastic bag in my kitchen drawer so they don't get lost; I will revise this review if they dry up too quickly or otherwise disappoint.

I usually use more expensive powder eye shadows, so I tried this more on a whim than anything.  And I am so impressed-- it glides on, is a very attractive neutral taupe/brown shade, lasted all day, and is easy to remove.  I'm not sure what else you want in an eye shadow. I was really pleased with how it brightened my eyes (which are blue); the contrasting brown made the blue color stand out. I even took a gamble on trying the glittery right side of the combo-- I had always been told that glitter eye shadows are a no-no after 50, but it looked great.I was a little concerned about possible sensitivity or allergy issues because this makeup is so much less expensive than my usual choice of Clinique, but no worries. (And my skin hates everything.) I will definitely be getting more colors in this line of makeup.

This is a well-made, lightweight cork and magnetic board and is perfect for a home office, kitchen, laundry room, or wherever you like to post notices or leave notes for the family. The overall board measures 23" wide and 17" high when viewing it as it is shown in the pictures.  There is a frame around it, so the actual interior measurement of the cork part is 15 1/2" by 11" and the glossy side is the same.  The board comes with magnets and a black dry-erase pen which has a little plastic clip to attach it to the board.  You can easily attach it to a wall using the permanent self-stick pads which are included. I like the versatility of having both the magnetic and cork sides.  Practical and fun item for a busy home.

I have to admit I thought chia seeds were only good for growing on little clay animal-shaped things-- and a fun joke holiday gift.  Turns out they are actually good and pretty good for you.Healthy Joe’s Chia Seeds come packaged in a sturdy re-closable plastic vacuum-sealed package.  It's a generous amount of seeds-- a typical serving is one tablespoon, and the package contains over 35 servings.I tasted them out of the package, and they have a very mild flavor. They are a little chewy, and even get a little gelatinous after they are in your mouth for a few minutes.  Once I put them in my yogurt or on my oatmeal, I couldn't taste them. The only challenge I had is that they are little seeds, so keep some dental floss or toothpicks nearby.According to the package, a serving of these chia seeds contains as much ALA (Omega3) as walnuts, calcium as mozzarella cheese, fiber as bran flakes, and iron as spinach, although this statement isn’t verified by the FDA.There are a lot of claims on the internet about using chia seeds for dieting, as well as myriad health benefits.  While they do contain (healthy) omega-3 fatty acids, carbohydrates, protein, fiber, antioxidants, and calcium, I couldn’t find any credible studies that make chia seeds better than any other seed or nut.  That said, they are healthy for you and if you are looking for a way to get more nutrients in your diet, chia seeds might be a good source.Just pay attention to the medical warnings-- they do have some effects on blood clotting ability according to the package, and they also shouldn't be taken by anyone who is pregnant.

This is my first time using a George Foreman grill so I tried three different items on it: a hamburger, 8 oz boned chicken breast and a 6 oz piece of salmon.  Here's what I learned:1. The grill is very lightweight, but that also means that the lid doesn't really clamp down on the top of the item-- it lays there, so if your item (like chicken) isn't perfectly level, not all the surfaces will get cooked as well.2. The grill comes with simple instructions and no recipes or cooking suggestions other than a few basic times.  While the times were generally accurate (9 minutes for the chicken, 5 minutes for the salmon, etc.) it would have been helpful to have more creative ideas for using the grill.3. The grill steams a lot while cooking so don't place it under a kitchen cabinet or other location where the steam can't easily escape.4. This grill is small-- the 8-oz chicken breast was longer than the surface- I had to angle it, so it could only hold one 8-oz breast at a time.  You'll have to decide if that is two servings or not. Same with the burgers-- I was able to fit two on the grill but they were tight and relatively small.5. Cleanup isn't as easy as you might think.  I know the surface is nonstick, but the fat/liquid from the chicken browned quickly on it and took some scrubbing to remove.  It was not "wipe away" nonstick.All-in-all, it's OK--the food I cooked tasted fine.  Just be prepared to spend some time cleaning it.

Well-written and researched, this biography is a treasure chest for anyone who wants to learn about what it takes to become a great actor-- not a star.  At one point in the book, DeNiro expresses frustration with the publicity machine around movie-making, saying "Why do people want to know what I eat for breakfast?"  The author, Shawn Levy, has wisely chosen not to tell us what DeNiro had for breakfast or other distracting gossip and superficial information. Personal information is presented in a way that rounds out an understanding of his personality. Mostly we learn about DeNiro, the actor, who treats acting like work-- work which requires study, attention, and diligence.While presenting the circumstances of his solitary, possibly lonely, childhood with parents enmeshed in the artistic and literary worlds, the author doesn't venture personally into armchair psychological analysis-- he presents some opinions of DeNiro's friends and colleagues to provide insight or analysis of DeNiro's actions, but always in a professional manner.I have enjoyed DeNiro's performances over the years, starting with the first film I saw him in, "Bang the Drum Slowly" through "The Godfather", "Taxi Driver", "Once Upon a Time In America" and many, many others.  If you are a film buff like me, you will enjoy the details this book provides about the tremendous professionalism DeNiro brings to his roles.  The book describes, for example, the weeks DeNiro spent with a minor league baseball team in the South studying and learning from the players-- everything from how to play baseball to how to "look" like a baseball player, to how to speak with the correct Southern accent demanded by the role.His work to prepare for "Godfather II" is even more impressive with DeNiro studying Sicilian at a Berlitz program, and then traveling to Sicily to further enhance his language skills including learning hand gestures and the pacing of the language.  He then revises much of the script to include what he has learned, even removing his own lines when he determines they aren't necessary.  Finally, he studies Marlon Brando's work so that in addition to speaking Sicilian fluently, he can also sound like and capture the essence of Brando in his role as the young Vito Corleone.I was amused and pleasantly surprised by the almost whimsical way in which major aspects of certain films (or careers) came together-- and could just as easily never happened.  For example, Levy describes a party where DeNiro arrived in an unpleasant mood due to an altercation with his girlfriend, but despite this challenge, his friend Brian DePalma persevered and introduced DeNiro to "another guy" at the party-- Martin Scorsese.  Later in the book, Scorsese is working hard to get famous film composer Bernard Herrmann to write the score for "Taxi Driver."  Herrmann resists, but Scorsese gets him to at least look at the script.  Herrmann agrees to write the score because "I like when he poured peach brandy on the cornflakes."  It would be a monumentally great score, and unfortunately Herrmann's last.  This book is peppered with these types of anecdotes-- accidental meetings, unlikely coincidences which all lead to great film-making.Throughout the book, DeNiro comes across as a three-dimensional figure with good and bad traits, but with a constant theme of a man of few words who studies and observes, learns and absorbs, and then puts it all back on the screen for us to enjoy. And we are the grateful recipients of his talent.Great reading!

I bought these chairs about a year ago and they are terrific.  They have been on a screen porch through all four seasons and haven't suffered at all.  They work just great-- easily fold up and down and are very comfortable.  The fabric and stitching have held well and I've had no issues any of the joints.  Very comfortable.The only challenge I have had is that (I assume due to the exposure to 4 seasons) the little head support cushions have lost their elasticity in the back and they won't stay up, so they are now more lower-back cushions than head cushions.  But this was easily and quickly repaired with some duct tape pulling them tighter.  I like the fact that the cushions do slide up and down so you can use them where you most need them.Excellent value for the price.

Harney & Sons consistently produces great tea.  My favorite is Black Current, but this flavor runs a close second.  It has a nice bergamot flavoring without being overpowering.  I often use several bags in one mug and then add ice for a great-tasting iced tea.

My main piece of advice: have your computer or a pen and notebook nearby when you read this book. It is so much more powerful if you do the exercises and try writing while you're reading it.  In fact, I find it impossible not to write when I read it-- it's so inspiring and inventive.I have had this book for several years now and it is one that I consistently return to when I write memoir pieces.  The author outlines great exercises to get you started with your writing, and I really like her ideas for creating interesting memoirs.  I like it so much I've bought several copies to share with friends who want to write memoirs.  It's a dense book-- over 300 pages-- but don't let that scare you.

I really like the idea of these picks-- a thumbpick that looks and works like a flatpick.  And they work to a certain point-- they provide a crisp, clean sound and I would actually prefer them to a regular thumbpick.  BUT-- and this is the problem-- they don't stay tight on my thumb and go flying or slip off when I start to play with any speed or force.  The plastic wraparound part that goes over the thumb is just a little too loose for me and there's no way to tighten them.  Great idea-- just not quite perfected yet.

This is a very creative book which not only helps the reader design their career and their possible life path, but unlike many career books, also considers the "practical" nature of the dream: how to finance it.  I found it very helpful and interesting.

This book would be great to hand out to every high school and college student-- the advice is so helpful.  So many students think in "boxes"-- they don't stop to consider the connections between the diverse subjects they are studying.  This book helps them think in a new way and consider the connections and patterns between everything they are learning.

I read this book when it first came out and I remember feeling like I had finally found something that would help me in my personal life and in my career.  And it did-- I followed the system using the Franklin-Covey planners and became more productive and happy than I had been in years.  Many years have passed since that time, and I often "return to the well" and re-read this book.  Timeless advice, easy to read, and profound on many levels.  Highly recommend.

This is a very nice carry-on in some respects but it has a couple of significant problems.On the plus side the four wheels are top notch. They pivot well, they go over large obstacles well, they're precise and you'll have no trouble maneuvering on to an escalator in a busy airport. Inside the Tumi there are plenty of zippered compartments that will let you arrange your packing any way that you want. The TSA approved lock is a nice addition with a smooth action that is easy to set. (Note, the instructions to set the lock are not included with the case, you have to to to the Tumi website for that).However, the downsides are fairly significant. The thermoplastic composite material has what appears to be imperfections in it. I was looking down at the material expecting to see a nice crosshatch pattern across the entire surface but that isn't the case. There are places where it looks like the material wasn't set quite right. Also, the fit and finish falls short of what I'd expect in a carry-on in this price range. The details are small but the overall impact is large. For example, the bumper plastic on the edges is poorly done and you can see ridges from the injection molding process. As another example the wheels on the lock are made of plastic instead of steel.I'm frankly hard pressed to see how this carry-on is much better than the one I already had for which I paid 1 tenth the price.

I had initially went to a store to try and buy 7-8 oz highball glasses but they didn't have them. All they had were 11 oz highball glasses which look way too large for a mixed drink. I was looking for a size and shape appropriate for a gin and tonic.These glasses are the perfect size and shape I was looking for. They have a nice thick base that makes them stable without making them too heavy. The glass is nice quality and overall they look amazing. Considering this is a pack of a dozen glasses you're only paying like two dollars a glass which is very reasonable for glassware of this quality. I like the straight horizontal line of the side (other highball glasses I've looked at were either curved or in a sloped V shape). It makes the overall look classy without looking, for lack of a better word, girly.To help show the scale I added a pic of the glass in my hand.

Edit: I've found that it doesn't respect the boundary markers very well. I initially thought that was because the boundary was still slightly curved from being rolled up in ball. But now that it lays flat on the floor the Neato still just pushes it out of the way most of the time. I've found that i have to tape the strip to the hardwood to get it to work. That's rather inconvenient.The first thing I want to say up front is that the dust bin for this robot is directly connected to the filter. This means that the filter on the dust bin will clog very quickly. This is quite unlike other "bagless" vacuums that have a cyclone bin that removes most of the dirt/dust first. In the case of the Neeto the vacuumed air passes directly through the filter. Due to this fact they recommend a monthly schedule for replacing the filter (note, replace, not clean). I wanted to put that up front because frankly it seems like a design flaw though I suppose they did it that way to keep the unit small and compact.However, if that doesn't bother you how does the unit itself operate? In short it's a bit more clumsy than the company would have you believe. Yes, it does know where it is in the room. However, the laser guide only provides the unit with a rough estimate of what's in front of it. In my very first run of the Neeto it got stuck in two different places where it should not have gotten stuck if the laser was precisely measuring the height of a ledge. Not only that, it also does a lot of bouncing against objects when it's doing edge cleaning. It isn't nearly as precise as the ads when it comes to going around chair legs and other obstacles. It does a lot of bouncing off walls, chair legs, etc. However, having said that it does do a competent job of making it's way around table legs, chair legs, etc.I know that there is probably a fine line between making the robot too sensitive to lips/bumps in the floor and not sensitive enough. Both the Scooba and the Mint will be stopped by even the smallest ridge in the floor. They're too conservative and even a minor crack in the hardwood can confuse them. However, the Neeto is just a bit too aggressive and will jump over even an obstacle that is nearly 1/2 an inch high. This is a problem in the cases where I have chairs that have a sort of flat rounded rail as the base. The neeto will jump up on it and get stuck there. In most cases it manages to free itself but not always (and not without a lot of thrashing). The upside to this is that the Neeto will happily jump up on an area rug and back down to hardwood without missing a beat. The downside is that it will jump up on things that it probably should not attempt to hurdle.Overall for my use case (almost all hardwood that needs light sweeping) the Neeto does a fine job. However, do bear in mind you'll be emptying the dust bin a lot and replacing the filter frequently so make sure to factor that into your cost of ownership. If they could come up with a better dust bin setup this would be an easy 5 stars. As it is I have to take off one star for the dust bin issue.

I have been wanting a burr coffee grinder for quite some time but I never got around to it. I've done a lot of the coffee creation process myself from roasting green beans to grinding them in a bladed grinder to french press/drip/pour extraction. What I never did try, until now, is burr grinding and now I know how much it matters.The problem with a bladed grinder that has spinning blades is that it will inevitably produce a sort of coffee "dust" as part of the process. This coffee dust then gets over-extracted, when submerged in boiling water, and results in bitter flavors from your carefully roasted beans. This might not be much of a problem in french roasts where the roast character pretty much covers a lot of sins but it's much more evident in the lighter roasts.And that is where a burr grinder comes in. A burr grinder is designed to give you one consistent grind size (no coffee dust like bladed designs). The KitchenAid does a wonderful job giving a consistent grind across its 15 different grind settings. It works quickly and can grind an entire 12 oz bag of whole beans in just a couple of minutes. In my testing I've been pleasantly surprised how how much difference there is in the flavor of my roasted beans when ground by the KitchenAid vs. my bladed grinder. The burr grinder, yielding a more consistent grind, had helped me extract my coffee without the bitter overtones I was getting from my bladed grinder.Speaking to the design of the KitchenAid it's very smart. For starters they have used glass for the receptacles and this helps cut down on the "flying coffee" problem that plastic has. In fact, I tried using a plastic container under the grinder and I saw this problem first hand, coffee was literally flying out of the cup. Stick with the glass. Also, the top receptacle screws on to the grinder and is sealed with a silicon rim at the top and bottom so you can safely store beans in there between uses, very thoughtful. Lastly it's a solid well-made device that looks amazing on my counter and since most of it is vertical it's footprint is roughly only 9"x6".A couple of cautions. First, don't make the same mistake I made by unscrewing the top before taking all the beans out. Oops, that was messy. Second, do be prepared to unscrew the cover and clean it out fairly regularly as it will jam up before too long if you're using the more fine grinds. Aside from that it's a lot of fun to use, helps make a great cup of coffee and looks awesome.

I've been using this SSD for quite some time now and it is proven to be fast, reliable and a good value.A quality SSD is one of the single best upgrades you can do to refresh an aging laptop and make it feel like new again.

This is a good blower because it has a valve that prevents it from sucking air in from the front end. This is important when you're in a tight space and don't want to wind up sucking back in the dust you're trying to blow out.

Very nice replacement wiper and much cheaper than if I went any bough them at the local auto parts store. Easy to install and keeps the window nice and clear. Tip: clean the rubber part of the blade with Windex every now and then to keep the wipers operating at peak efficiency.

It's OK, it works but the part where it attaches to the computer has begun to break in 1/2. That's sad because I have not been using it long. However, it does appear to be a genuine Dell replacement and it is still working, so I only took off two stars.

Everything went fine this year. I installed the software no problem. I imported data from my brokerages no problem. I uploaded my returns electronically smoothly. The whole process went very well.I was also very happy with the 10% bonus offer that was available if I used my refund to get an Amazon gift card.

I've tried other tabs to keep the toilet clean and free of mold. However, they don't work as well or as long as the Clorox tabs. When I use these i can be assured of a month or two of a clean fresh toilet bowl. When I use other brand tabs the bowl doesn't stay as clean and sometimes mold forms. I'm sold on these tabs. Highly recommended.
The handle feels great in my hand. The action is smooth; the blades cut evenly and quickly.They're great for office use but they do not look durable enough for anything more challenging than that.

I use these filters on a box fan as a sort of makeshift room air filter. I had been using Honeywell FPR 13 filters previously. I just measured the airflow through this filter as compared to the Honeywell. My Dylos air quality monitor indicates that this filter is as effective at removing particles from the air. They both catch about 50% of the particles in the air on the first pass (I don't get full efficiency as it is just a box fan).The difference? I paid almost $20 EACH for the Honeywell filters at a local big box store. Buying 12 of these at a time may seem like a lot but at least for me it has meant getting about a 75% discount over buying them one at a time at the local store.Note, the actual measurement is 19.5 inches, not 20.
This enormous bath towel is a welcome addition to my bathroom.  I love to be draped in the thick long and wide luxurious fabric.  Recommended!
You get the best price, usually, by having the card mailed via snail mail. But either way Live is a great value for the price.

I have never owned a pair of headphones like this and i didn't know what i was missing.I watch most of my movies on a laptop. I had no idea how much of the texture of the sound I was missing. I rewatched Guardians of the Galaxy last night with these headphones on and I was like sitting in a movie theater. Instead of all the sounds being mushed together by my laptop speaker they were separated and clear. i could hear the dialog much more clearly and I felt much more immersed in the movie.In short, having these headphones on sort of recreates the experience of a large expensive surround sound system. If you watch most of your movies on a laptop or a tablet I highly recommend getting a quality set of headphones like these.

Like other reviewers I'm not using this on my pet because I don't have one. One of the big problems I have with battery powered clippers is that they tend to be underpowered.  They can also overheat because they run at such a high RPM but at low torque.This clipper doesn't have those problems. It can comfortably glide through my very thick beard hair. It isn't quite as powerful as a wired clipper and that's to be expected. Unlike the "human" versions of this model it doesn't come with a whole bunch of size attachments. But if you have the plastic guide combs from other Wahl clippers they'll fit this one just fine.

This is an OK vacuum but it has what I consider a fairly serious design flaw. The part of the dust canister that you open at the bottom has a kind of "lip" there that can catch the dust in there into a difficult to remove clump. It's hard to describe well in words...the opening narrows for some reason. I guess if you empty the cup frequently that won't be a big deal but who wants to do that? Also, the beater bar stays on all the time, even when the unit is fully upright, I find that irritating.On the plus side the suction is good, the HEPA media looks substantial (though I recommend looking at what the HEPA media replacements cost) and all the seals appear to be of decent quality. The hose, by my measure, is 8 feet long with the extender attached. There is also a spot on the unit for all the attachments which is appreciated and too often not the case on vacuums. In this price range this isn't a bad choice but bear in mind the issue I mentioned at the top of this review. If you have pets you're going to hate the way the dust cup empties (or doesn't empty).

I love this belt. At first I was a little bit concerned about how durable the pouch would be so I held off on this review. however, it has proven to be very durable, i wear it while running and when I go to the gym for weight training. The pouch that holds your stuff is very stretchy and you can easily fit keys into it as well as a license and some money. I think a small wallet could fit into it but that would probably be the upper limit. If someone wants to carry a wallet in this I'll give it a try and see if mine fits, drop a comment.

I'm a little bit disappointed they won't disclose the country of origin for all their raw materials. however, I'm rating them highly anyway because I want to encourage this market of organic supplements. Hopefully another USDA organic vendor will come along that is more transparent about the source of their raw materials. But until then GOL is the best bet i can find if you want to take a multi.

I love the hyperlock feature. It lets you very easily change out blades (using a built in lever) and locks them in place very securely.The little built in "headlights" are also surprisingly helpful when doing detail work (like grinding grout out of tile work when you want to be sure not to damage the tile) very helpful.I can't say I'd recommend this tool for big jobs unless you're going to keep a couple of spare batteries on hand. It's slightly less powerful than my plug-in Bosch but that's to be expected. I really wish they would have made a bypass plug in feature that would let you use the battery OR plug in to AC power.The tool feels good in the hand, it's well balanced and excellent for smaller jobs or detail work where you don't want a cord getting in the way.

I'm a big fan of sensors that extend our ability to evaluate our environment.One thing that I try to avoid is particulate pollution in the air but this is a very hard thing to measure without a tool like this.  For example, I have a $400 HEPA filter but I really have no idea if it actually works.  However, now i at least have some proof that in fact it does work.If you turn on the Dylos and let it run for a few minutes you'll get a good idea of what the baseline of your room is.  Then you can place the Dylos in front of the flow of air from your HEPA filter and see what happens. In my case my counts go from about 300 and 14 to 190 and 6.  This is evidence that my HEPA filter is doing quite a bit to clean the air (removing nearly 1/2 of the small particles on the first pass through the filter and removing more than 1/2 of the large particles).Once you can do this you can also critically evaluate whether one HEPA filter is actually better than another or not.  I'm not suggesting you can get definitive proof with just this one test but you at least get some decent evidence.A caution, this unit is probably affected by how much humidity there is in the air.  So if you're trying to compare apples to apples you may also want to buy a hygrometer so that you know if the humidity has changed significantly (it is a good thing to know the humidity in your living space anyway).  Also, you probably don't want to take any one measurement as the "truth".  This type of device is best used to compare two different things to try and find a difference over time.  For example:Maybe you want to test if leaving the windows to you home open increases or decreases ambient dust.You may want to test whether one vacuum is superior to another when it comes to how much dust it kicks up.If there is construction nearby you may want to test how much that has increased the baseline dust level over time.Overall its going to be important to get multiple readings and to make sure you've tried to establish a good baseline level of dust in your environment.  As far as the baseline the dylos makes this pretty easy because you can set it to monitor mode and it will only turn on once for a minute every hour.  If you write down the readings for a few days you'll be able to get a good sense of what your baseline dust level is.  From there you'll be able to test other things and how they impact the amount of ambient dust.

Actually I'm not very pleased but our cat is!  He loves it and waits for breakfast and dinner.I think he likes it better than the bigger brand name cat food we had been feeding him for a while.  The only thing that may be a drawback is that the chunks are on the larger side and may be difficult for older cats to handle.  Just something to bear in mind if you have a very old cat.

Major rewrite revision 4-27-14.When I wrote my initial review I had some concerns that have been addressed.  For starters I bought a Dylos DC1100 Pro air quality monitor and I have confirmed that the air coming from the AP260 is indeed 99.8% purified of particles down to .5 microns.The unit has some pretty cool features, listed in no particular order:1) 4 stage air filtration that includes a pre-filter, anti-bacterial, HEPA and activated carbon.  They are estimated to last 6-8 months even with continuous use.2) The activated carbon filter is very good.  It is much more substantial than what you find in other HEPA filers.  I find that it will clear my apartment of odors very quickly.3) It looks very cool, comes with a remote and is easy to assemble.4) It moves a lot of air for each given level of sound (low, med, high).  And at night it senses that the room is dark and it goes into an extra quiet mode where on low it is barely audible (it also dims the LCD lights which is a nice touch).The main drawback is that the built in air quality monitor simply doesn't work.  I trust my Dylos more than the monitor in the Friedrich and they often disagree (the Friedrich will show red even though the Dylos is showing very good air quality).  What I do is keep my Dylos air quality monitor nearby and adjust the fan speed as needed based on the actual count of particles in the air--this works well.  With my room door shut and the filter on medium I can go from about 600 and 70 on the Dylos (it measures .5 micron and above and 2.5 micron and above in two different numbers) to 50 and 3 by the morning.  That's considerably better than my old HEPA filter which was louder and could barely get the readings to 155 and 30.Will update with decibel readings when my decibel meter arrives.Silent room with the door shut: 34dBUnit on low: 35.2dBUnit on medium: 42.2dBUnit on high: 53.9dbOn low you're paying almost no "noise price" at all and it still moves a decent amount of air on low.For those of you that care it emits no EMF field unless you're literally an inch away from it.  Even just 1/2 foot away from the front and the EMF field drops to background.

I've been using Waterpik products for a lot of years.  I find they are a great way to keep my gums healthy.  In particular I like to use the Waterpik to shoot dilute solutions of saltwater or water + apple cider vinegar (every now and then) between my teeth where a toothbrush can't reach.But for daily use just plain water is good.  My favorite attachment is the bristle brush because I can shoot water between my tight teeth while brushing them at the same time.Combine traditional floss with this Waterpik and an Oral-B Professional Deep Sweep and you have a powerful dental care combo.

Some years I have problems installing or getting the updates to work.  But this year everything went just right.  Even my import from Quicken went without a hitch.  it is a beautiful thing when the import from Quicken matches the statement from my broker to the penny.Printing copies both on paper and to a .pdf file went very well.  Maybe part of all this ease of use was related to the fact that I did NOT import last year's data in.  I started basically with a fresh install and didn't import the TurboTax file from last year.  It all did seem a lot cleaner.Of course as others have noted do be prepared to spend an additional 19.95 to e-file with your home State.  Also, the 10% added to an Amazon gift card is a really nice bonus.  If you're going to spend money on Amazon anyway you might as well get a free 10% bonus for doing so.  I allocated $600 of my return for an amazon gift card which became $660 with the bonus.  I'll update this review if anything goes wrong with that process.

I'm not sure what it is but I've noticed that not every roll has great consistency in terms of how well the wrap sticks to itself.On my last roll maybe 1/4 of the roll hardly stuck to itself at all and would fall off right after I applied it.  The rest of the roll was amazing.  For the wrap that was good it would stay where I put it, even for days at a time.  Where the wrap touched itself it just about fused together to the point that it was like they melted together--very cool.So when it works there is really nothing like it.  When it doesn't work it's obviously useless.  I think they may have some issues with consistent production quality.

Just yesterday I dropped my Inspector and I was very glad i had this protective boot on it.It also helps to make sure that your pancake detector is safe from dust as it has a cover for the tube that opes and closes (most of the time you won't be testing for alpha radiation so it will be closed most of the time.

This is a major alteration of my initial positive review.  But sadly I have to take it down to one star because it eventually caused redness, itching and skin peeling of my underarm.This is clearly not something desirable for a skin care product.  I hope this deodorant works well for others but since this review is how it worked for me I have to reduce to a 1 star rating.  Also, looking at the other reviews i can see a lot of people reporting irritation.  maybe Tom's needs to look into their formula and find out why so many people are experiencing skin irritation.

One of the first things I do with any scanner is push it up to its maximum resolution, turn on duplex, and see how long it takes to scan a B/W page.  Even at 1200 DPI, on duplex, B/W this scanner runs through about 40 sheets per minute.  It's impressive.The text recognition is not supported at 1200 DPI which was a little bit disappointing.  The max resolution you can use with text recognition is 600 DPI.  This presents a problem, I think, because the software often gets the text recognition wrong.  It will get the wrong word even on a very clearly printed page.  Took off a star for that.The automatic upload to Google Docs is magical.  If you set it up properly the scanner will save a copy locally and simultaneously to your Google Docs account.  This is a very helpful feature if you need to have a backup of your scanned documents.  When setting this up remember you need to use what google calls an "Application Specific Password" if you use two-factor authentication.  It is different from your normal Google password, but you probably already know that if you use two-factor.Overall a nice scanner.  I wanted to give it 5 stars but I really can't because of how badly it does text recognition.  IF that feature isn't too important to you then make it 5 stars.

These sunglasses come with really nice quality lenses.  I can't say for sure if they are helping my migraines one way or the other.However, I can say that it is a real problem that the entire frame around the nose area is hard plastic.  If I'm walking while wearing these I have to keep pushing them up my nose or they'll eventually slide right off my head.  i know they want these to have a light touch but I think the touch is too light, at least for me.

We ABSOLUTELY LOVE our Amazon Fire TV!!! It has been THE Best streaming player we've owned bar none!The first thing I love about it is being able to "say" the name of the movie or TV show we're looking for, stead of typing it in - it's just so incredibly convenient! And there's never been an instance where it hasn't understood what we've said!The 2nd thing we love is ALL the content which is available - we LOVE having Prime! And having the Prime originals is really great - we've enjoyed every Prime original we've watched. We've enjoyed all the Netflix originals too, and can get them on Fire TV as well as our cable channels, games, picture, music, YouTube, etc...Frankly, I'm glad this wasn't around when I was a kid because I might have watched too much TV! (nah! I was a tomboy!)You can also get more information about the movie or TV show you're watching, or the actors, while you watch. Fire TV has X-ray available - which is great because, if you're like us, you're always wondering who someone is, or in what other movie/show they had a role.
