With x-ray, you just hit a button, and you're connected to the IMDB database, and can find out that quickly!Our family has had 5 Roku's, 1 Chromecast, and now the Fire TV, and without a doubt the Fire TV is our favorite!The kids might be upgrading to the Fire Sticks for Christmas!

The new Hoover Air Lift Deluxe has been a great tool in our arsenal of home cleaning items! I’ve been using the Air Lift over the past month, and have really put it through it’s paces. I’ve been vacuuming in every room of our home, and even took it to our daughter’s apartment, and had her do a thorough once over! I have to say, it performed very beautifully - better than any vacuum we’ve had to date!When the Air Lift first arrived there was very little assembly required. Our 12 year old son is very mechanically and technically minded, and asked if he could put it together. Last year he built his own gaming computer - so I knew he was very capable - all he needed was a Phillips head screwdriver, and he easily put the vacuum together in approximately 10 minutes. He laid out all of the pieces/tools on the floor, followed the directions - which were very clear, and put the vacuum together easily. (It wouldn’t have taken him as long as it did, but I questioned the way he put the handle on - which I’ll get to later.)One of the really nice features of the Air Lift is the “lift off” canister - which makes getting to those harder to clean areas so much easier - like stairs and above the head areas. When you want to use the lift off “canister” portion of the vacuum, you simply pull the hose out and attach the tool you want to use. Then you turn the Air Lift “ON”, and grip the handle of the canister - or lift off part of the vacuum, and pull the canister off the main vacuum. At 17 pounds the canister is heavy for me to carry around - that's where my husband comes in. I have to say though, despite it's weight, the canister made cleaning our stairs and tight spaces SO much easier! We have 3 levels in our home, the steps are all carpeted, and the Air Lift did an amazing job cleaning them. I was really impressed - things that our last vacuum missed because it was too heavy to lift and try to vacuum at the sane time, and where the dustbuster otherwise missed dirt or dust, came up quickly, on the first pass. I was also able to get to the tops of all of the ceiling fans, as well as giving all of the draperies a well needed going over without sucking them into the vacuum.The Air Lift also has great attachments - which fit neatly on-board the vacuum. If you have a pet who sheds, the pet hair tool lifts pet fur or hair easily - even from Berber carpeting. There’s also a crevice tool - which great for getting into tight spaces - like the area under the refrigerator and around the washer and dryer - which I normally hate trying to clean because it’s usually difficult to get all the dust bunnies that collect. There’s also a turbo tool, a 3 in 1 pivoting brush, and a wand - for those above the head, hard to reach areas - like ceilings, tops of curtains, and ceiling fans.Normally I have trouble vacuuming because of the weight of vacuums, but the power and steer-ability of the Air Lift make vacuuming pretty easy. Steering around objects is simple because the Air Lift is on a ball mechanism - by just maneuvering the handle the vacuum steers effortlessly around objects. There’s never a loss of suction even when maneuvering around furniture and other objects because of Hoover’s 3 channel “Wind Tunnel” Cyclonic Technology, and also edge cleaning - which pulls in any dirt from the area to the side of the vacuum - so you don’t have to worry about missing areas as you go around objects. This is a corded vac, but you have 30 feet of cord to work with - which was plenty of cord for my needs in all of our rooms.Another nice feature is how the Air lift automatically adjusts to different carpet heights, and with one touch of a button, goes easily from carpet to wood or vice versa. It does an excellent job of cleaning both. I loved the way it cleaned the wood floors in my kitchen - so I can quickly run the vac instead of dust mopping numerous times before wet mopping. I can easily get inside the cabinets and pull off the canister to do the upper cabinets, and above the cabinets as well. I have chronic back pain, so bending down to turn dials, push buttons, and lift vacuums really pains me. The Air Lift has made things much easier on me in that regard.Earlier I mentioned that when our son was putting the vac together it seemed the handle was on backwards. When you look at the vacuum it looks like the handle should be reversed, and this was one of the things I wasn't thrilled with about the vacuum - it just feels like it's on backwards. The only other thing about the vac that takes away from its appeal is its weight - at 25 pounds it's heavy, even though it's auto powered.The Air Lift also has a HEPA filtering system - with a washable filter plus a secondary filtering system - which is a definite improvement over all replaceable filters. The dirt cup is simple to empty, and nothing has to be touched when it needs to be emptied. However to keep things smelling fresh, like all vacs, you have to clean it periodically.This is one of the best vacuums we’ve had and one of the easiest to use. If you’re thinking of getting a new vacuum, and you don't mind a heavier vacuum, this is one you might want to consider!

I found this product didn't make any visible difference for my neck after using entire bottle. However, like they said, due to age differences, skin types, and condition of skin it's hard to meet the needs of every person. Since it's marketed specifically for the neck I thought I'd give it a try. Although the problem with my neck started after I lost weight - I got icky skin that I've been working to improve.  This wasn't an expensive cream, and I tried a $65 cream I got from a doctor, and didn't get better results - so I just have to keep working the muscles, moisturizing, and eating right.This company does have a 100% money back guarantee which they honor. I have used many, many products and have NEVER dealt with a company that actually reached out to me to try to RETURN my money!!! For that alone they get kudos! And BTW, I used the cream knowing it may, or may not help, I wouldn't expect a refund! But it was an AMAZING OFFER!!!  Thank you Body Mary! You'll definitely stay on my list of companies to use in the future!!!

I bought this for my husband to use as a bedside table. Obviously it's taller than a bedside table, but prefect for holding lots of different types of things. He had a standard bedside table with three drawers before, but there was too much clutter on the top. The for level Braxton table holds everything without looking ultra cluttered. He can have his clock and phone, his cell and charger, his speakers, and assorted reading, vitamins, snacks, and misc.The colour is dark brown - it's not real wood, but looks handsome and holds up well to all the daily wear and tear that we tend to put our bedroom furniture through with spills and lack of coasters. A good dusting, or a wipe with a damp cloth is all it takes to get it right back to its original condition.I would highly recommend this furniture for casual use, or a more modern casual room.

Clinical studies were done extensively on remineralization of teeth, and the only property which affected true remineralization of teeth consistently was the inclusion of the mineral  "Appetite" or nanohydroxyappetite.  Those who make jewelry, or gem enthusiasts, might recognize "Appetite" - a gemstone used in making jewelry - nanohydroxyappetite is derived from the mineral.When I was researching the clinical studies on tooth remineralization, the only place currently producing toothpaste with Appetite, was Japan. I was happy to find both children's and adult toothpaste on Amazon fromJapanese sellers. I ordered both. They arrived within a week, and we've been using the toothpaste ever since.All information is written in Japanese, but the seller's are very good about answering any questions you might have.I highly recommend this product to anyone who has concerns with their teeth or their children's teeth, especially before, or in the very early stages of a cavity.

However, unfortunately the Jabra Eclipse failed where it's really important - which is call quality.The pros for this device are many - it's small size means, for someone like me, it's almost unnoticeable because it's mostly covered by my hair. Although Jabra says this is a right ear only device, I didn't find that to be true - it actually fits better in my left ear, and I hear better with it in my left ear. I don't have any hearing problems in either ear, but after trying both the medium and large ear buds, the fit and noise cancellation was best in my left ear.  That being said, I found it disorienting to drive with the Eclipse in my ear - probably affecting my vestibular system in some way. (This might just be me, and didn't affect my scoring.)The set up of the Jabra Eclipse is incredibly easy. This was one of the plusses of the Eclipse! Once you turn on your phone's Bluetooth and NFC, you push the button on the bottom of the Eclipse' s charger (which I'll get to later),Swipe your phone across the bottom of the charger, and with the Eclipse in your ear, you'll be given instructions on how to pair the Eclipse with your phone.Go back into the Bluetooth menu and select device.Pairing will occur, and the Eclipse will give you a clear verbal okay if pairing has occurred.If there's a problem, the Eclipse will further instruct you on what to do.At this point you should be good to go!There were a few things that I found lacking:First and foremost is the lack of support on Jabra' s website. When looking at electronics I like to go to the brand site, and also checkthe user manual. When you go to Jabra's site there's a page where you can select your device by name or type. Oddly the Eclipse isn't availableto choose! I left messages in their feedback and support sections that adding the Eclipse might be a good idea.The manual which comes with the Eclipse lacks much explanation, so for people who aren't tech savvy, or who need written instruction, this was a definite minus. However, if you follow the instructions and add the Jabra app, set up should be a breeze. Except that there are many Jabra apps - stick with the one(s) recommended by Jabra for the Eclipse.Back to the Jabra website ... the manuals and firmware updates are all available online, so you don't have to hang onto papers and packaging.There's a place on the site to register your new device - a good idea, so you can be made aware of firmware updates.The FACS on the site are lacking. They could make use of user friendly links to real user questions, because when you ask a question you're often given irrelevant information.My biggest disappointment with the Jabra Eclipse is the sound quality leaves a lot to be desired, and as Jabra's top of the line Bluetooth headset, I was hoping for better results.  I tried the headset from various distances and situations, and 7 out of 10 times I had to call the person back on my Moto X cell phone. I found it odd that the sound quality in calls was so poor because the instructions given by the headset, in your ear are very clear.There didn't seem to be any reason why sound quality was good on one call, and not on the next few calls. I'm hopeful Jabra will work this out and make improvements.The Jabra charger is simply incredible, and one of the best features! Prior to using the headset, the charger is charged for 3 hours. Once that's done a green light indicates you have 60 - 100% battery life, a blue light indicates 30 - 60% battery life, and a red light indicates you have 30% or less. The Eclipse is held in the charger magnetically - which is genius because the charger can be unhooked from the USB cord, and taken with you to maintain its charge. When it needs to be charged, just reattach the micro USB cord and hook up to your computer or other USB charger. The Jabra instructions indicate you're to charge via computer, but that's not necessary, any USB charging outlet will do.All things considered, at this time I wouldn't recommend the Eclipse because of the call quality. All other minuses can be overlooked, but call quality is the primary reason for using a Bluetooth headset.

This case is VERY thin, and won't provide much protection if the phone is dropped. However, I've found the thicker cases we've tried on our Moto X phones tend to interfere with some of the keys when texting or searching. So it's a matter of what's more important. My phone gets lighter use - so I can use a thinner case. My husband, and especially our older son need a more heavy duty protective case.This case is good for those who are easy on their phones.

Relaxing for various anxieties without sedative action of anti-anxiety medications. Helps for calm focus. Our daughter uses for anxiety, our son uses before a test for focus. They both really feel it helps. They've both taken different brands, and you really need to find a brand that works best for you.I like this brand for daytime calm.

My husband and I have been researching PEMF for chronic pain, chronic fatigue, and cancer at a site put out by Dr William Pawluk - probably the foremost leading authority on pulsed electromagnetic frequency therapy. I was thrilled to find this inexpensive little unit through Amazon, Although I was concerned about how long it would take to receive the unit from the UK, I just had to order it, and as it turns out, there was no reason to worry at all! It was delivered very quickly and has been worth each and every penny!!!We have been trying to decide whether or not it would be worth an investment in a whole body unit. I have had chronic pain for over 30 years from two major car accidents, and then 8 yrs ago I fractured my spine wiping out on a patch of wet mud while on my daily bike ride, etc . . .  I've been to SO many doctors, tried different therapies and medications, but I'm allergic to most of the medications, or they leave me worse off than in pain. Not to mention the hoops one has to jump through with our "new and improved" healthcare system - it's such a mess!  I want to find and go to battle for anyone who has to deal with chronic pain, or chronic illness - so they won't have to deal with everything I've had to deal with over the years. I've felt the need to explore all the alternatives.This has been the most promising alternative I've found so far, I was SO pleased to find this inexpensive alternative to opioid pain medications. I do wish PEMF were more available in the U.S. - it's pretty standard in Europe, and has been for decades. In the U.S. it has been used very successfully in veterinary care for a long time, so why isn't it a standard in the treatment of humans? Pharmaceutical companies!  You can't have something like PEMF out there which has so many practical applications because it would seriously cut into profits. Incredibly shameful that we live in a time where money takes precedence over human life, comfort, and care.The only downside is that if you have widespread pain, you will have to move this little unit around, OR buy more than one unit. Or, like we did, buy one to see if it works for you, while seeing if it's worth investing in a larger unit, but it DOES work! This unit is about the size of a 50 cent piece.If you have chronic pain,  and want, or need, an alternative, I would VERY much encourage you to give this a try!One word of caution with regard to other units:this unit uses two 2025 lithium batteries - which it comes with, but some of the other units only last as long as the battery with which they come - so just be aware if you look at other units.

The Clorox Toilet Wand Disinfecting Refills, (30 Ct) is an incredible product! We bought the Clorox Wands several years ago when we wanted to get away from having a toilet brush, harboring who knows what kinds of bacteria, in our bathrooms. At the time we were thinking in terms of our kids and dogs, and health issues. Sure, I used hydrogen peroxide to disinfect, but never liked having a brush that had cleaned our toilets, sitting ... well, anywhere!Shortly after buying the wands/refill kit for one bathroom, we liked it so much we bought one for our 2nd bathroom, and now we have the whole shabang - there's a holder for the refills and the wand, and it really looks much better than the old brush - even though we had a decorative one.Using the wand and refill is SO incredibly simple, and I make it almost a no touch job, and have taught our kids the same - so they know how to clean a bathroom as they grow up and go off to college. The refill has a small protrusion on the top, which snaps into the wand, once it clicks in, it's secure, and you can clean. I start by getting the pad nice and wet by swirling the pad around the bowl, once that's clean, it's up and under the rim until it's clean. To make it a no touch job, press the pad against the part of the bowl that's pretty dry, and clean the underside of the seat, and around the top - above the rim, rinsing as needed in the bowl. Once that's clean, make sure to check the front of the toilet, and around the fasteners and behind the seat - again, rinsing as needed in the bowl, flush if necessary. Then wipe everything down and it will be nice and shiny and clean! Repeat as needed.This has been the best system we've ever used, and I can't see a change anytime in the future - unless they make a self cleaning toilet, or we win the lottery and someone else wants the job!I highly recommend the Clorox Toilet Wand and Disinfecting Refills to anyone who has to clean toilets, but doesn't really want to do the job. This makes it less of a hassle to do a job which must be done!

Our son absolutely LOVES this watch, and we were very impressed with it as well! I thought, from looking at the picture, the LED backlight was blue, but it's not ... it's blue, green, orange, red, purple, and can also be set to cycle through all the colors! It's SO cool! The LED lighting is every bit as bright as what's shown in each of the Fanmis S-Shock pictures - so you can see the various colors. It also has a timer, a stopwatch, an alarm, a calendar, and a compass - what's not to love?!I first ordered one for our son who's going off to college because I wanted him to be on time for classes - thus the alarm. He rides his bike a lot - this the LED backlight - which is more amazing than any watch I've ever seen!Anyway, once I ordered the watch for our older son, our younger son saw the picture, and expressed an interest - well he's the one who got this watch, and he just loves it! He had it set up in no time flat without any help - he's in middle school - so he's capable of reading the instructions as well as I, and probably more capable than I at setting the watch up. He said it was easy.Our older son hasn't gotten back to me on how he likes his watch, but once he does, I'll review that one as well.I highly recommend this watch to anyone who needs a great backlight, an alarm, a timer, stopwatch, and a calendar. I'm thinking of looking at the Fanmis Women's watches for myself because this one was so cool!

I LOVED this series! I knew it only had one season, and I didn't look ahead - so I was thrilled that it had 22 episodes!  I was surprised that there was only 1 season actually because this was a really great series, although it did move through the story line quite quickly after a certain point, and didn't end leaving you hanging. The way it ended, there was plenty of room for more seasons though.This was the story of "The Tomorrow People" who, at a certain point in their lives "break out" to their full potential - with the 3 T's  - Teleportation, Telepathy, and Telekinesis. It seems to happen in their late teens, and if a parent isn't around to let them know what's happening, they're telepathically contacted by either the "Tomorrow People" - if they're lucky, or their evil counterparts - who have been turned by this agency to track down the "break-outs" and either bring them in to be turned, have their powers removed, or killed.The way I'm describing it doesn't make it sound all that great, but I watched the whole season in 3 days on Netflicks - kind of a binge and it was really good.Now I'm on to a new series - Lost Girl - which thankfully has 4 seasons! And, so far, is also really, really good!!!  : )I highly recommend The Tomorrow People - especially if you can see if free!

I LOVE this shredder!  I’ve had 4 shredders since college, and this is my favorite!It’s the largest, with the biggest bin, and a smaller inside bin for discs and credit cards. The bin slides out from the front - so you don’t have to pull the top off, like you do with so many others - which is messy and time consuming. I put a trash bag inside the bin - so when it’s full, I just slide the bin out, pull the bag out, put a new bag in, and I’m ready to go!When I first set this shredder up, I have to admit I had a bit of a problem. Although it’s a no brainer, basically you just plug it in, I’m not big on reading instructions unless I have problems! ;) I kept hitting the power button - which is right on the front, and it wouldn’t turn on! Hmmm… Time to consult the very complete instructions! Oh! There’s a power button on the back! Great safety feature if there are any little ones in the house - or people who don’t read instructions! LOLAnyway, I like the feature that it is always on, ready to go when you need to shred. There’s forward and reverse - in case of a jam - which hasn’t happened to me yet. This shredder is really quiet - which is really nice compared to the ones I’ve used in the past. No shredder is whisper quiet, but this one is the best I’ve had. The manual says it will cut through staples as well as paper clips. I’ll put staples through my shredders, but not paper clips - I don’t want to wear the blades out by doing that, but it’s nice to know that if I forget, it’s not going to ruin the shredder!It’s 23” high by 15” wide by 9.5” deep, and weighs approximately 19 pounds. The bin hold 5 pounds of paper and there’s a full indicator when you need to empty the bin - which is really nice. There’s also an overheat indicator, so you can stop shredding before the shredder stops due to overheating. I also love that this shredder is on castors - it’s so easy to move, and since the top doesn’t come off, I don’t have to worry about pulling it apart every time I need to move it!The shredder opening is 9” wide, and placed in such a way that it would be very difficult for someone to get their fingers caught in the mechanism. There’s an indented area in which the paper is supposed to slide, and then the area goes down at a sharp angle to prevent things from being inserted that shouldn’t be inserted! That’s what makes it unique from any other shredder I’ve seen or used! There’s also a separate credit card slot, but when I used that I didn’t like it because it didn’t shred my credit card well - but when I put it through the regular slot, it shredded it into crosscut micro shreds, just like it did with papers - so that’s no big deal. I can still shred discs in the credit card/disc slot.I’ve worked as a Fraud Analyst for years, and believe in shredding, shredding, shredding! Having this Sentinel Pro FMC120P 12-Sheet Micro-Cut Shredder means that I can send my Amazon Basics 12 sheet shredder to college with our son this fall - so he can shred, shred, shred!I highly recommend the Sentinel Pro 12 Sheet Micro Cut Shredder!

I LOVE the Basil collection of Mrs Meyer’s products! They smell SO refreshing and clean! I grow basil in my own garden because of its aromatic qualities as well as for cooking. From the site: “The basil herb is known for its uncanny ability to ease the nerves and perk up the senses — a handy combination!” It makes you want to clean!Our kids wash their hands more frequently because they like the natural smell.I buy the refills of the Everyday Cleaners as well as the hand soaps. Both container  - the Everyday Cleaner Spray bottle, and the Hand Soap pump bottle hold up for use time and time again!These are very reasonably priced products for the high quality, gentle products which clean really well, and smell OH SO Wonderful!I’ve also used these products outside to clean our patio furniture cushions and glass table top. It also cleans up the baby pool and patio like a breeze, and some of the products seem to have bug repellant qualities! The geranium seems to be especially good at this - real geraniums are bug repellants - so it just makes sense! Our neighbor cleans his bird feeders and bird bath with Mrs Meyer’s products - he says it’s bird safe (I don’t know - I don’t have birds, but he’s never had a problem!)The scent in the Basil Everyday Cleaner comes from basil oil, parsley oil, and black pepper oil. The part of the product that cuts through grease comes from birch bark extract.I haven’t had a chance to try all the various scents because I haven’t found all of them, but I look forward to trying them. I’ve never tried one I didn’t like.I highly recommend Mrs Meyer’s Products!

Astragalus - called huang qu in traditional Chinese Medicine, has been used in many other TCM formulas that serve as primary defense mechanisms for the body. Besides using the herb in supplements, it’s often used in cooking because it’s nourishing and strengthening - esp. when people are sick. In TCM it tonifies the spleen - when illness causes fatigue.Astragalus is a foundational herb in Traditional Chinese Medicine. The root is an amazing supplement - which our entire family swears by especially during cold and flu season, but during any time of physical or emotional stress. Astragalus supports deep immune function and liver function, it also helps the body adapt to stress. Somewhere I read that if you take Astragalus during a virus, you won’t get that same virus ever again during your lifetime. I don’t know if that’s true, but we take it when we begin to feel sick, and we avoid most of the colds and flus that go around w/o getting flu shots. Our college age kids always take a bottle back to college with them, and call home for more when they run out!It can be purchased as a capsule with dried powder from the root, dried root powder, or the roots can be purchased and you can make a decoction from boiling the root in water - it’s made strong by boiling for an extended length of time.This is one of the herbs that will always be in our cabinet, and that of all of our kids!

N-acetyl cysteine is a major detoxifier in the human body. In studies it has demonstrated liver detoxification benefits. It also helps remove environmental toxins including tobacco and other types of carbon-monoxide smoke, alcohol, and environmental pollution.It can be used by those concerned with liver toxicity associated with long term use of OTC anti-inflammatories (NSAIDs), which can damage the liver. It’s very effective at removing aluminum and other heavy metals from the blood stream, and the organs.Experiments have shown that NAC prevents the buildup of aluminum in the brain, preventing aluminum toxicity. Aluminum has been suspected in Alzheimer’s disease - something I’d like to prevent - so I’m willing to take extra supplements in order to avoid it in my lifetime.NAC is an amino acid which has also been found to have some anti-depressant qualities, but like some other serotonin producing products, doesn’t appear to increase the likelihood of serotonin syndrome.I will continue to take this supplement. It’s very inexpensive, and for the benefits, or potential benefits, it’s worth every penny!

I’ve read some really interesting and fascinating books about religion over the years. “The Vatican Prophecies”, by John Thavis did not disappoint.Thavis, explores many issues in his book, "The Vatican Prophecies: Investigating Supernatural Signs, Apparitions and Miracles in the Modern Age." It’s not at all a long book, and it’s told in an interesting way, which delves into these issues in enough depth that held my interest. It was so readable and well told that I read it straight through without putting it down the first time. Then I found myself reading through the chapters again, often several times to soak it in. Thavis doesn’t try to sway you one way or another, he just presents the various balanced views, and you are left to your own thoughts - which is why I read and reread chapters, and parts of chapters.I found the chapter on miracles most engrossing. The Catholic church doesn’t have a monopoly on miracles - they happen all the time. IMO, the fact that we’re even here is a miracle! As someone not raised Catholic, reading the book reinforced my beliefs about much of what once seemed a bit different. To some it’s even controversial. Most of the topics aren’t synonymous with the Catholic Church, it’s just that the Catholic church is more rigorous before recognizing something as miraculous - it has to be. One of those issues surrounds the visions in various parts of the world.The Catholic Church doesn’t have a lock on visions either, many people have visions of the departed - maybe not of Jesus or Mary, but visions none the less! Some of those people are called religious, some psychic, and unfortunately some are labeled mentally ill (if indeed they aren’t). What is different is the degree to which the Catholic Church goes to authenticate visions, miracles, angelic happenings, the demonic, and other supernatural things.  Most people approach these topics with a sense of cynicism to one degree or another. The Church has  processes that are followed in order to authenticate visions and miracles. Right or wrong, the Catholic Church is mired in processes it must follow in order to avoid fraudulence and people who would take advantage monetarily. Although I don’t know why anyone in their right mind would put themselves out there in that way if it wasn’t authentic - with the throngs of people flocking to the sites of visionaries, miraculous events, and healings, and the upheaval it places on their lives and their communities!The book gives us so much in six chapters, Each chapter gives specific examples regarding each topic. And although it’s not a long book, there is the right amount of detail given to each topic. There’s insight into the inner workings of the Vatican, and how it  responds to, investigates, and makes decisions regarding the supernatural.It’s understandable that so much time is given to authentication because of the size and age of the institution which is the largest religious organization in the world.I recommend this book to anyone who’s interested in learning any more about how the Church goes about verifying (or not) things miraculous, and the inner workings of the Vatican.

This app is cute and fun to use. All of our kids have, or still do love Adventure Time, and its fun being able to draw the characters.I suppose then by tucking them in a lunch, hanging them in their room, or even sending one in a letter to one of our older kids.  : )

I purchased these after my husband burned his hand on our grill.So far, so good! He's been able to use them, I have, and two of our kids have as well. They even worked for our 12 year old - they weren't overly large, and didn't make handling things clumsy for any of us.I recommend these for anyone handling really hot things coming out of the oven or a grill.

Of the many Cobalamin co-factors I've tried, while this one is very reasonable priced, it takes much longer to dissolve than the other bioavailable cobalamins - methylated, adenosyl, and dibencozide forms of B-12.I'm rating it 3 stars because it's a viable option for those who need to take one or both of the co-factors. For those who need to take Methyl B-12, and like the Swanson, it's probably as good as the other 5 mg products.There are more people unable to absorb B-12 through food than are probably aware, making supplementation with one or both of the co-factors better than trying to get the needed amount through food. It's currently estimated that 30% of adults are unable to absorb B-12 through diet, which can lead to fatigue, anemia, and current research at the University of Oxford shows that vitamin B-12 deficiency can even lead to brain shrinkage. Research is also suggesting a link between vitamin B-12 deficiency and Alzheimer's disease.I have a Vitamin B-12 deficiency which led to a form of anemia that causes overwhelming and unrelenting fatigue. Because of the Vitamin B-12 deficiency my red blood cells don't develop as they should, and can't carry oxygen as needed throughout my body. I've used either oral drops or sublingual B-12 that dissolves more readily. Either or both of the B-12 co-factors - Methylcobalamin or Adenosylcobalamin, or the two combined - Dibencozide, are bioavailable and absorbable orally.  Others brands I've tried, which I found dissolve more readily are:  the 5 mg Methylcobalamin from Source Naturals, the 3 mg Dibencozide from Country Life. The other co-factor, Adenosylcobalamin - is the only way Vitamin C is contributed to the Krebs Cycle.  My preference is a  non-GMO/Organic product.

So far so good. I've found the Silk'n Blue to be a really great alternative to both prescription and OTC medications for my skin problems. What I especially like with regard to that is that I don't have to worry about side effects and adverse reactions with medications, as well as allergic reactions - such as contact dermatitis all the way to anaphylactic reactions. I've even had paradoxical reactions and in one case with a pretty common medicine had Stevens Johnson Syndrome - which no one would ever want!I feel very comfortable that I'm not going to have any of these reactions with the Silk'n Blue - I haven't had any problems with it so far, and I'm finding my skin slowly clearing. My husband suggested I treat one area and leave another - so I can visibly compare the difference. This was a great idea, so I decided that was how I would go about comparing how well the Silk'n Blue is working for me. (I will post pictures IF they're not too embarrassing!)I like the warmth of the Silk'n Blue on my skin. It's a very gentle, soothing warmth, I've never felt any burning. The time investment isn't much more than applying medications, and I feel that I'm doing something both safe for my skin, and good for my skin. There's no smell as there often is with medications for the skin.As I said, I'm slowly beginning to see positive results with the Silk'n Blue on my skin. I would recommend this to anyone suffering from hormonal acne (or any other type of acne).

Both a panel discussion and wonderful rich story telling documentary about mythology, metaphor, and tradition as the glue that binds all of humanity for the ages. It's also about how connectedness, dialogue, and the value of everyone's own personal story is vital and transformational, and we're all called to respect one another and our stories, and it's the refusal to see another's rich traditions, history, and point of view that's leading to all the breakdown in society, inhumanity, and war. It's a call to action ... A choice as to whether we choose to take part in life and be a part of the changes that will make the world a better place, or a choice to retreat into despair and a lack of connection with others.

I am one of those people who has to take the co-factors of B-12, not Cyanocobalamin, and I have to take the co-factors in pretty high doses for it to be effective for me. I've been taking Source Naturals Methylcobalamin for a long time - a couple of years at least, and I;m really happy with it. I put it under my tongue and it dissolves really well. It tastes good too - so no complaints there! It gives me a bit of a boost in energy and my B12 on my bloodwork has been better since I've been taking the co-factors - which was the whole point of taking the sublinguals - energy, better bloodwork, and avoiding shots - which are usually Cyanocobalamin and didn't improve my bloodwork.I would recommend Source Naturals Methylcobalamin for anyone with a B-12 deficiency or the MTHR genetic problem.*the only one tiny thing I don't care for is the red dye - if I brush my teeth within an hour of taking it, my tongue is red, and when I rinse, I spit red, but I can live with that because it's the only issue I have. ...And NO I DON'T have a problem with the miniscule amount of sugar in this product! ; )

I'm used to taking regular sublingual NADH or ENADA NADH, but it's EXPENSIVE!!!  This is NOT a sublingual, but it seems to work pretty well and it's quite a bit less expensive, so I'll either stick with it, or go without NADH! I had to become really familiar with supplements - I've had some pretty serious health issues for about 30 years, and western medicine has utterly failed at helping.  I've had to find things that would help me the most. I use a combination of Ayurvedic medicine, herbs, amino acids, whey protein, and vitamins.This supplement, for me, has helped me with fatigue. So I will continue to take it because anything that helps the fatigue is a good thing. There's nothing worse than being 50ish, and feeling like you're 80!This formulation of NADH also contains ribose - which I would take anyway, and although the dose is small, and the NADH is not sublingual - which is not the way I would normally prefer to take it. This is affordable, and seems to help somewhat, so it's better than paying way too much and agonizing over sublingual NADH, or taking a lesser dose of NADH and not being satisfied with that.I take supplements for a host of autoimmune disorders where I need  a boost to my mitochondrial energy. I've tried to add them in gradually ... one at a time so I can tell if they help or not. I know some people would prefer to take NADH sublingually - generally I would as well, but I haven't found it it to be an issue with this particular supplement. Since it's a capsule, I open it up and put it in a very small amount of water stir, and drink, and I haven't had any issues what so ever.I would recommend for those who would supplement with these two supplements, or people who need a subtle boost in energy - not a miracle - works over a period of time - approximately 3 months to really tell whether it's helping.

This movie was SO genius - I would think anyone would end up appreciating it on some level. It was one of the most bizarre movies I've ever seen - I had to admire the writer, because of the way he showed you how very fragile the human psyche can be, and how interconnected our experience.The two main characters question their own reality and that of the other, which is made more difficult when they seek to find each other and can't, and yet they know things about the other which is seemingly impossible. It's all very mind boggling!  I'm not sure if this movie is  described as sci-fi, but it's certainly a real mind bender - very different, but one of those movies I know I won't forget, and I don't say that about movies very often!I don't want to reveal any spoilers, but I will give some basics ... there are two primary characters, one male and one female. They seem to be stuck in what I'd say are parallel, but alternate realities. They experience the other without being able to physically being able to reach the other, but at a certain point feel an almost desperate need to find the other.One is sane but is written as crazy and begins to feel crazy and runs from the craziness. The other is good and just but feels bad, and takes on the guilt and shame of a lifetime - that causes them to seem locked in a prison of their own being from which they can't escape. As desperation sets in for both of them, they frantically want to save the other.The devil is in the details.Yes, I would definitely recommend this to anyone who's a fan of cult movies.

These earring are pretty and sparkly. When I opened the bubble wrap envelop, I pulled out a nice black box - which held a black flocked earring card that had a little pocket on the back. I make jewelry, and I've never seen a earring card like this - with the little pocket on the back - I suppose it was so you could either put the earrings on the card, or in the pocket on the back, I'm not sure. The box itself was nice - black on the bottom, bright blue on the inside top. It's the type of packaging I'd use for my own jewelry - except for the "made in China" sticker on the bottom of the black box.As for the earrings themselves, they are pretty, and I would wear them except for the fact that they were SO incredibly uncomfortable! They're lever back earrings and they were extremely difficult to put in my ears. I've never had any problems with french wires or any other ear wires, but these were SO much thicker, and the wires are flat - it's not what I'm used to, and it's not anything I'd use when making jewelry, or buy.Lever backs are often poorly made and break really easily. I can honestly say these are well made and had a nice spring to them. The two pieces aligned perfectly every time, and there was never any sign they would break.For people who like lever backs I would recommend these. For people who prefer ear wires I would recommend staying with ear wires.

This is one of my favorite therapeutic yoga videos. It's very well done in that the asanas, while not held log enough, are well done, and shown accurately. I had seen videos by Kanta Barrios prior to viewing this one, and while some may not be comfortable with both the voiceover as well as the length of each pose, the stretches, poses, and relaxation shown are excellent as a springboard for your own yoga practice. Each part can be done for the length of time desired either by pausing the video, which is what I did initially, or taking each part and extending it on ones own once familiar with each part.Be prepared with relatively standard yoga accessories - block, mat, strap ...This is a good video for those who have minor back problems, but don't expect a quick fix. This is more of a lifestyle change - incorporating stretching and healthy exercise into the routine of those with back problems. (As well as learning to cool down into relaxation after exercise.)

The Moonlight Rocking Sleeper Deluxe gently rocks babies - soothing them when they’re fussy, or helping them drift off to sleep when they’re sleepy. The way the sleeper is made, the baby is cradled almost like they’re being swaddled - it cuddles them in a way putting them down in a crib can’t unless they’re swaddled in a blanket.  Some of the other rocking or vibrating sleepers sit at an angle so it’s a little more difficult to put a newborn down for fear they’ll slid down in the seat, but with this sleeper the baby lies flat, and you strap them in with a 3-point harness, so there are no worries that the baby is going anywhere … but to sleep.The sleeper stands firmly on sturdy legs and yet folds pretty easily for portability. The vibrating unit comes off when you don’t want to use it (It only has one speed - which you might want to use sparingly to preserve batteries - although it does shut off automatically which is really nice. Most units don’t have that feature.)The best feature, when putting baby down at night to go to sleep is the starry light projector with lullabyes. Baby can be put down and learn to drift off to sleep without being bounced or walked by a person which is a better way for baby to go to sleep and better for mom and dad’s backs! The musical unit plays 5 lullabies, but it also plays nature sounds as well. You can set it up a bit if baby goes down fussy, but you can set it on low if you want the music or nature sounds to be very gentle - there are 3 volume settings.During the day, when baby is more alert, but you need some time to help the other children, or get something done quickly, you can fold the unit and bring it to where baby can be in sight and turn on the mobile - which has two floating toys and is easily removable.The fabric comes off for easy washing, but be careful not to dry on hot or they won’t fit back on. Either air dry, or dry on air fluff.This is a great unit especially for new parents, but it’s also great for busy parents and grandparents as well. We highly recommend!

This was one of my least favorite mascaras unfortunately. Remember Tammy Faye Baker? Imagine the mascara she would've used, and I imagine this would've worked perfectly for her ... although I don't think she was striving for the "Manga" look!On first impressions, when pulling the brush out of the tube, the brush is slathered with thick mascara. I really think this mascara could be better if it had a better brush, but the brush that's in the tube has short, stumpy brush that offers no separation. I felt I ended up with a sloppy mess on my lashes, which I didn't like at all. Did you ever put on mascara and feel your vision was darker? I felt that way after the first time I applied this mascara.In order to apply and get any semblance of lash separation, you really have to scrape quite a bit of mascara off of the brush ... if not one's lashes would end up not pleasingly covered with mascara - clumpy, gloppy, no definition. When applied it's just too thick. I realize this is a volumizing mascara, but there has to be some definition to the lash - if not it doesn't enhance anyone's eyes!In order to get any sort of pleasing look, scraping the wand wasn't enough. I had to swipe the brush through a paper towel - which I hate to do because mascara should only be in the tube or on the lashes - anywhere else could increase chances for bacteria. However, because this mascara is so thick it couldn't be applied straight from the tube.I also tried scraping the wand and then using a lash comb vertically to just remove a bit of the excess mascara and give a bit more separation, but all of this was just too much work. More work than I'm used to in a mascara!One other think I didn't like was I found the mascara irritating to my eyes. I wouldn't take away any stars for this because I do have sensitive eyes and I've found thick mascaras tend to be more irritating because tears, even normal tears make the mascara more susceptible to running into my eyes - so take that with a grain of salt.I don't feel I can recommend this mascara because it was just too thick and the brush wasn't one I'd want to use.

This is a good, basic intro to puppy/dog training. It's a bit superficial and doesn't go into great depth, but covers all the essential topics for a new puppy owner. I especially like the tips and advice for kids and puppies. Excellent reminders! The instructions for teaching a dog not to jump up are good, but I would add that teaching a dog to sit instead of jumping up is helpful - then you're replacing a bad habit with a good one rather than just teaching the dog not to jump up.For .99 cents, this Kindle purchase is a no brainer. I bought this on audiobook and found the narration pleasant with good emphasis in the right spots. The information is spot on for the basics. For in depth info when you need more help, I like The Puppy Primer by Patricia McConnell and Barron's Dog Training Bible.

My puppy loves this toy! He chews on it and also plays tug-of-war without losing interest. I like that it's made in the USA and the vanilla scent is pleasant. The inside curves are a bit flimsy, so I can see a retriever breed or other enthusiastic chewer might wear this out quickly, but my standard poodle will probably have this toy for years. And when it wears out, it will be worth it to buy another one since he enjoys it so much.

The size Large is plenty big for my fifty pound Standard Poodle. She loves the bees and they're great for fetch and tossing in the air. She's fascinated by the bees hiding in the hive, but she hasn't figured out the hide and seek game. She just gingerly extracts a bee and takes it to her chair to play with it.Our new puppy loves this! He plays fetch with the bees, tug of war with the wings and rests his head on the hive when he's napping. The squeakers conveniently get his attention when he needs to be redirected.Very soft, well stuffed, easy squeakers, everything seems well made. I'll have to put this away when my mom's dog comes for a visit since she ruins stuffed toys, but my dog will enjoy this without tearing it apart.

I love this Rose Water! I recently tried buying a less expensive brand because I liked the fancy lid with a pump dispenser, but it turned out to be Rose Water Oil and smelled like the Dentist's office. I won't stray again! This product is 100% Pure Rose Distillate and it smells incredible (if you like roses, which I do).I make my own facial toner using 1/2 oz rose water, 1/2 oz witch hazel and a couple drops of NAN Baby Skin essential oil. I have a tiny scar from a clogged pore I messed with and I think this toner is helping it go away since roses are beneficial for treating scar tissue. Highly recommend and will keep buying it!

This is 100% "Rose Water OIL" rather than the "Pure Rose Distillate" that I was looking for. It smells like the dentist's office and nothing like roses. I've been happy with the Rose Water by Skin Daily that I was buying, but this was a little cheaper and I like the lid with the pump so thought I'd try it. It might be a fine product for a Rose Water Oil, but it's not at all what I expected it to be so I'm not happy with my purchase.

Very well written and I love the layout with lots of pictures and captions. The puppy psychology is helpful, relevant and easy to grasp. The training plan is completely step-by-step and seems fool proof if followed correctly. I was skimming "Barron's Dog Training Bible" while reading this and learned from that book that Dr. Yin's training method is called "capturing" since you're trying to capture a behavior a puppy will naturally perform (like sitting). I like the theory of this method, though I don't have my new puppy yet so haven't practiced it. I'm more familiar with the training method called "luring" where you hold a treat to lure the dog into the desired position (like sitting). It seems to me that a combination of training methods will ultimately be best over the long term (at least for my comfort level), but Yin's book will get any puppy off to a great start!I have a couple small points of disagreement, but these will be a matter of personal preference. I'm currently reading the autobiographical "A Dog Walks into a Nursing Home" (which I highly recommend) and when considering training methods for her seven-year-old Labradoodle to become a Therapy Dog, that author, Sue Halpern, came across the suggestion to provide all food in a "Kong" feeding toy. Halpern basically pokes fun at the emphatic use of Kong specifically and moves onto another trainer's book, so I had to chuckle when the topic came up in this book. Dr. Yin is also a proponent of NEVER using a dog food bowl and the dog earning ALL food as rewards or getting it out of a food toy or puzzle. Sorry, I just don't agree with this. It seems to me that dogs have a basic right to food and water and shouldn't have to ALWAYS work for it. Sometimes? Yes. Treats? Always should be earned. My two cents, but I'm not a vet or an Animal Behaviorist and Dr. Yin is both.Secondly, I've quickly and successfully housebroken four dogs in over thirty years and NEVER used paper or potty pads in the house, even as a 'just in case.' When I worked, I came home during my lunch hour to let them out and play with them so they were never cooped up for more than four+ hours. I've read other experts say paper training is confusing and dogs need to be clear that outside is the ONLY place to go to the bathroom, and I agree. I'm watching my sister potty train (or not) her year-old Yorkshire Terrier and he consistently pees on his potty pad and then proceeds to poop all over the house. What a disaster! Dr. Yin emphasizes over and over to be vigilant and keep the dog with you while potty training (totally agree - this works!). But she also mentions laying down paper in a playpen area as needed, and I personally wouldn't do this. Again, only my two cents, and that's about what it's worth since I'm not an expert.Other than these two points, I think this book is brilliant! I'm sitting with a stack of a dozen dog/puppy training books and this is one of the only ones to hold my attention from cover to cover. Very practical advice with lots of detailed photographs.

This isn't my first rodeo. I've lived with six dogs over the past fourty-plus years and will be shortly getting a new puppy. Since I haven't had a puppy in ten years, and I'd like to enjoy living with a very well-trained dog, I'm reading through a dozen dog/puppy training books I've purchased or borrowed from the library. This one did not impress me, at all. She lost me at 'no one should ever own a pure bred dog because they have terrible health issues.' (I'm paraphrasing.) I'm not a breeder, but I felt like the section on why pure breds have health problems was an insult to responsible breeders, especially those who ship new breeding lines over from other continents just to infuse new blood into their breeding programs. Her argument basically states that since AKC restrictions create such a small breeding pool, there is inherent inbreeding in pure breds. That's like saying people who live on small islands shouldn't have kids. Responsible breeders test for a number of health issues before even breeding their dogs. But she goes on to admit mixed-breed dogs have health issues too.....Then when you get to the section on "How to Find a Good Breeder" she writes:"A second source of breeder referrals is word of mouth [the first source being AKC's web page]. This could mean your neighbor who has a nice dog, though nice dogs surprisingly often come from unpromising sources." What? All my dogs have been nice, even the ones rescued as adults. It's not a crap shoot...well mannered dogs take effort and training. That's why I'm reading books on the subject! Way to shoot down the hopes of a potential pet owner before they've even brought home their new puppy or dog.Maybe the training tips are great. I wouldn't know because I felt like I was reading a book by "Debbie Downer" and set it aside for more promising material. I LOVE "Barron's Dog Training Bible" and "Perfect Puppy in 7 Days" held my attention from cover to cover, though I don't agree with everything. I'll review more books as I get to them. Rating three-stars since I read so little of the book, it hardly seems fair to rate lower since I really can't judge. For those of you still interested in this book, my husband skimmed through it and says it seems geared towards urban dwellers, in case that's helpful to you in your buying decision.

Having a powerful blender that can handle ice crushing as well as smooth blending of ingredients for cooking/baking was important to me. After careful research I bought a Ninja pro blender and have been extremely pleased with its performance.  I was so happy with it that I recently bought the BL660 blender set with Nutri Ninja Cups so that I could also create quick smoothies.  It has been so convenient to be able to make a quick custom blended drink without a lot of mess or clean up needed.  Simply fill the cup with your favorite ingredients (I like strawberries and bananas!), attach the blender lid, snap it into the base and after a few pulses you have a delicious drink! I can drink straight out of the Nutri cup with the lids provided and after I just rinse out the cup and blender lid and drop it into my dishwasher.  Couldn't be easier!The extra large 72 oz blender jar has plenty of power to create the smoothest beverages, purees, and batters. I like that the blade unit comes out easily and can be also placed in the dishwasher. But be sure to watch those edges when handling it as it is really sharp! The lid is easy to use once you notice the small marking in corner to align to the proper spot on the blender jar.  This ensures that the lid is locked on completely and safely while using.  The lid is a very tight fit and seals completely for zero leaks so it can be somewhat difficult to pull off.  A gentle and consistent pull on the handle will get it to release.Overall, I am extremely pleased with this blender set as it meets all of my needs, has plenty of power and is easy to take apart and clean.  Highly recommended!!!

I love this book and have read it many times. There are many reviews, so thought it would be most helpful to review the two audiobook versions, since I own both and listened to them recently.Abridged: narrated by the delicious Richard Armitage with his sultry baritone voice. He's a talented actor, so his expression and pacing are excellent. He also creates distinctive voices and accents for each character which always increases the enjoyment of listening to a story. This version is 4+ hours, where the unabridged version is 12+ hours, so that gives you a good idea of how much has been cut. I think the editor did an outstanding job, my quibble is that the Abridged version spends as much time on the prosy Edward Yardley as it does on our hero, Lord Dameral. It cuts a number of scenes and shortens conversations between Venetia and Dameral. It also cuts out quite a bit of Nurse's pontificating and somewhat diminishes the servants' importance in Venetia's household. My other quibble is the music played in between some chapters. The first time through I thought it was charming, but on later listenings I was impatient to get back to the story. Buy this version for the stellar narration and/or if you prefer a shorter book to listen to.Unabridged: narrated by Phyllida Nash, a British stage actor. Her voice bares a striking resemblance to Judi Dench, which made me wonder if they grew up in the same area or attended the same school at some point? As a classically trained actor, her pacing and expression are excellent. She does a good job of making her voice lower for the men, though most women aren't the best at this (other than Rosalyn Landor, whose natural voice is very deep). Nash uses different accents for servants versus upper class characters, though the voices she creates aren't as distinctive as Armitage in the Abridged version. Overall her narration is excellent and I thoroughly enjoyed it.Favorite line in the Unabridged version which isn't included in the Abridged... Venetia says to Edward: "Your encomium unwomans me!" Ha!  Buy this version for more of Heyer's wit and humor which is hard to capture when cutting out 2/3 of the book. This version is also available on whispersync, which makes it a bargain!My Top Ten books by Heyer:Venetia (Regency Romances) - best romanceFrederica (Regency Romances) - best all around, best family, best humorFriday's Child (Regency Romances) - best coming of age, most cant expressionsRegency Buck (Regency Romances) - best descriptions of Prinny, Brummel and BrightonCharity Girl (Regency Romances) - best heroThe Grand Sophy (Regency Romances)- best heroineDevil's Cub (Historical Romances) - best scene (between Duke of Avon and heroine), best abductionThese Old Shades (Historical Romances) - best revengeThe Foundling - best travel adventure, duke in disguiseMasqueraders - best swashbuckling

This is not one of my favorites by Heyer, but I've listened to it multiple times. The narration by Richard Armitage for this Abridged version is outstanding. His character voices, expression, pacing, and accents are all perfect. And who can resist his deep, sultry baritone?The story is excellent, but I drop it a star because the plot makes me cringe everytime I listen to it. Sylvester, Duke of Salford, and his wicked looking eyebrows inspires Phoebe to write a gothic romance casting him as the villain after he arrogantly cuts her at Almacks. When they discover a social connection through her grandmother and frequently end up in each others' company they form a friendship and possibly more. But when Phoebe's book gets published and her identity is discovered as the author, Sylvester is justifiably hurt and furious. Phoebe has a tough road ahead of her to win back his admiration and achieve a HEA. As always, Heyer includes an excellent cast of supporting characters, humor and beautiful turn of phrase. She's always a pleasure to read!Here are my Top Ten by Heyer:Venetia (Regency Romances) - best romanceFrederica (Regency Romances) - best all around, best family, best humorFriday's Child (Regency Romances) - best coming of ageRegency Buck (Regency Romances) - best descriptions of Prinny, Brummel and BrightonCharity Girl (Regency Romances) - best heroThe Grand Sophy (Regency Romances)- best heroineDevil's Cub (Historical Romances) - best scene (between Duke of Avon and heroine), best abductionThese Old Shades (Historical Romances) - best revengeThe Foundling - best travel adventure, duke in disguiseMasqueraders - best swashbuckling

We have squirrels running around our roof and scratching at the eaves, waking up my daughter in the middle of the night. This pest-eliminator solved the problem! We placed this in her room in the outlet closest to her window (and the eaves the squirrels were scratching) and they stopped messing around that area so she could sleep undisturbed. Very pleased with this product!* received a sample product in exchange for an honest review.

We placed this light in our coat closet and love the light it provides upon opening the door. Installation with self-adhesive tape is very simple. We've been using this for a couple months and are satisfied with the brightness and durability. It occasionally does not come on when the door is opened, so rating four instead of five stars. This light is about six inches long, so if you have a long closet or hallway you may want to install more than one, but one is perfect for a coat closet.* i received a sample product in exchange for an honest review. I would recommend this to friends and would purchase it myself.

Seduction: Sophy is darling and makes this book enjoyable. I love how the ladies of society try to immitate her artless fashion disarray, with untied bows, slipping shawls and loose ribbons. Ravenwood is autocratic, annoying and a bully when it comes to getting his way, but Sophy does a good job of managing him. She's no door mat, thank goodness. Overall I liked this book but didn't love it and wouldn't read it again.Surrender: I can see why this book only has an average rating of 3.5 stars on Amazon. It is totally lacking romance. Thankfully I checked this out from the library, so I didn't pay for it. And I'm also glad this wasn't the first book I read by Amanda Quick or would be the last. This book isn't terrible, I just didn't enjoy reading it. The premise of an heiress falling for a fortune hunter is standard fare, but the heroine vacillates from intelligent to hare-brained, and the hero turns out to be a scold. He's not a bully since he's kind of a push-over for her, but he's constantly lecturing. Even the ending, which is supposed to be the HEA, is really an argument about why each of them were justified in their bad behavior. Not very pleasant reading. I'm giving three stars because it is well written and the plot is pretty good, but the characters ruined this one for me. Attraction plus adventures does not equal romance.

I can see why this book only has an average rating of 3.5 stars on Amazon. Thankfully I checked this out from the library, so I didn't pay for it. And I'm also glad this wasn't the first book I read by Amanda Quick or would be the last. This book isn't terrible, I just didn't enjoy reading it. The premise of an heiress falling for a fortune hunter is standard fare, but the heroine vacillates from intelligent to hare-brained, and the hero turns out to be a scold. He's not a bully since he's kind of a push-over for her, but he's constantly lecturing. I'm giving three stars because it is well written and the plot is pretty good, but the characters ruined this one for me. Attraction plus adventures does not equal romance.

Ravenwood is autocratic, annoying and a bully when it comes to getting his way, but Sophy does a good job of managing him. She's no door mat, thank goodness. Overall I liked this book but didn't love it and wouldn't read it again.

The book opens with Lady Katarina being kidnapped and taken to a brothel where she's put on the auction block. Lord Dalbury buys her and is told she's an actress, so he thinks her sob story is part of the "fantasy" that was being auctioned. This might have been a five star book for me if Dalbury had acted more honorably during that first meeting. Loretta Chase sets up a similar scenario in "Viscount Vagabond" but the hero reluctantly concedes to the heroine's pleas for help and scores big points for acting like a real hero. For me, Dalbury had a steep challenge to overcome his ungentlemanly behavior towards Kat in the brothel. The author does an excellent job of describing both sides of the situation, so the reader can sympathize with both Kat and Dalbury, but still......Kat challenges Dalbury to a sword match to avenge her honor and prevent her brother from dueling.  The result is she ends up marrying him and is determined to make him miserable. She occassionally feels guilty about the hurt expression in his eyes and acknowledges that he's doing everything he can to make it up to her. The author does a good job of balancing Kat's vindictive behavior - just when I was ready to turn against Kat and side with Lord Dalbury, Kat would apologize or throw him a bone. You have to read the book to find out how he finally wins her over - there's plenty of groveling and wooing.Once their marriage gets on track, there's still more to come. The villain (who I predicted right away) isn't finished yet and has one more plan to enact. There's also the mystery of Lord Dalbury's missing sister, which is covered in the second book of this series. All of the strife between Kat and Dalbury could have weighed down the story, but Kat's fiestiness and Dalbury's charm and determination give the book an upbeat feel with plenty of optimism for the HEA we expect.

Wow! This book moved along at a brisk pace with no annoying repetitive inner-monologues. There are a few secrets that get slowly revealed and keep the reader guessing about what the characters are up to and what's going to happen next. The ending is predictable since we romance readers expect a HEA, but the "how" is well developed. Lots of intelligent dialogue and thoughtful details make this character-driven book a pleasure to read!

Harriet is a charming, hard-working heroine who's been living a life of drudgery and destitution, trying to keep herself and her Aunt fed with a vegetable garden, eggs from their chickens and shooting game on her dilapidated country property. The Marquess of Arden and his cousin Bertram stumble upon their home after getting lost on their travels. Arden is very kind to Harriet and her Aunt, and Bertram shows an interest in Harriet. After enjoying a very pleasant visit with lively conversation, Arden leaves them a basket of delicious food and fine wines.This makes them realize how badly they have it - they are lonely with no visitors and almost starving - they decide to travel to London to show up on the doorstep of Harriet's rich, selfish sister. The sister, Cordelia, is one of the most heinous type of villains. 1) Harriet and her Aunt are under her roof so they can't get away from her cruel treatment and cutting remarks. 2) Sometimes Cordelia pretends to be nice, so her behavior is erratic and confusing. 3)  Family is supposed to help each other, so Cordelia's cruelty is especially alarming.The Marquess of Arden is an OK hero. He's consistently kind to Harriet, but it takes him a while to get on board with the romance. And he does a lousy job of protecting Harriet from Cordelia and eventually a second villain which I won't spoil by revealing. Overall the plot is very good, with many opportunities for Harriet to prove her worthiness as a heroine, including rescuing a duchess from a fire and other exciting events. Readers who like a lot of action should be entertained! There is not the humor I generally expect in a Chesney/Beaton book, and the villains are pretty dark, but the good characters are the focus of the story and they carry the day in the end. Overall a satisfying read that I'm glad I read once, but probably wouldn't read again.

I liked both Julian and Viola - there's a good amount of character development, especially for a novella. The book takes place at Julian's country estate where Viola shows up out of the blue from America. They have been writing letters for several months and she mistakenly thinks he wants to marry her. After they get this misunderstanding straightened out, he invites her to stay and do some sightseeing before returning home. Of course he falls in love with her over the course of her visit. Overall a nice, quick read.

I like "us against them" partnership stories where the hero and heroine are working together to solve a problem or a mystery. And since this is a romance, of course they fall in love with each other along the way. This book includes an excellent balance of plot development and character development.We get to see Emma grow from a resourceful but somewhat demure woman to someone courageous and independent. Luke is a victim of child abuse and as his story slowly comes out he's able to overcome many of his demons through Emma's love and support. The mystery of searching for Mortimer is well done. The twist is excellent - I didn't see it coming. This book includes multiple explicit scenes which will be good or bad, depending on the reader. Since I know the mystery I probably wouldn't read this again so rating four stars.

"Bedroom Games: 1" is the "get excited while you are spooked" sort of read. There is Pamela, the protagonist, who likes to play games with her lovers. There is also a serial killer on the loose, who just claimed his fifteen's victim. He too, likes to play "games."It's hard to avoid spoilers, so suffice it to say that there is constant tension throughout the story that builds up towards the finale. An observant reader will notice how the authors juxtaposed the serial killer and Pamela, as if hinting that there's really a thin line between "innocent" fun and sinister obsession.This is a masterfully written story that suggests, teases, and leads the reader while letting her imagination wide open to the possibilities. Make it a drinking game: Every time you get spooked while reading this story, take a shot of whatever gets you through the night. I bet you'd be flat on your back by the time you turn the last page.Recommended.

Texas Jack's Famous Sweet Potato Recipes is the third book in the Texas Jack's brand of the bestselling series of recipe books. Texas Jack's Famous Caramels Secret Recipe Book and Texas Jack's Famous Pralines Secret Recipe Book have been selling like hot cakes; this book holds the same promise.This book is all about the sweet potato. We have all seen it in stores--it's that weird-looking thing that looks like an overgrown orange-ish potato with a little sting on one end. Yet, very few of us know what to do with this curiosity, at least here on the West Coast.By the looks of it, Texans have tamed this tuberous root, and are making enough dishes out of it to serve a wedding. This book has recipes for sweet potato pies, casseroles, cupcakes, cornbreads, biscuits, and mashed and hashed sweet potatoes; in other words, you name it, it probably has it.All the recipes are simple to follow and the preparation process is detailed, including the guide on how to select potatoes while you buy them and how to prep them for cooking. My favorite recipe in this book is the Southern Style Hash Brown Sweet Potatoes; and yes, it is the simplest. I am a guy, whatever.One important thing to note here is that the sweet potato is one of those so-called "super-foods" that are really good for your health. It has just about the highest level of beta-carotene, that is a precursor to vitamin A, a very important vitamin that many of us lack. Sweet potato also has a very special protein called "sporamin" that prevents oxidative damage to our cells. Basically, what I am getting at, is that sweet potatoes are good for us. Just make sure you add a little bit of fat (oil or butter) to it when you are cooking or serving it, just like in these recipes; it will help with the absorption of all this good stuff.As usual, a great Texas Jack's brand recipe book. Recommended.

Tor, short for Torbrek, or more accurately, Torbraya, since the main protagonist is a girl (no spoilers here,) was raised by her grandfather, Attalor, to become a Knight, one of the Hundred. They lived poor but proud, and Tor held the sword before she learned how to say "sword". Fast-forward to her 18th year, and we see her as a member of a rebel "Loyalist" army, serving in the cavalry, and hiding her gender.Tor goes on a quest to rescue a princess guarded by a fearsome dragon. Xantilor, the dragon, turns out to be a pretty reasonable chap. This is when Tor's adventures begin in earnest."Torbrek...and the Dragon Variation" by Lexi Revellian doesn't present us with caricature characters who are either good or evil. Well, perhaps with a possible exception of the Corfe, king Skardroft's spy master. Instead, we see shades of gray, how one person could be good to some people and terrible towards others. Scardroft and, to some extent, Jervaid, are good examples of this, and as such, are much more memorable characters for it.The book reminds me slightly of "Alanna" by Tamora Pierce and has a slight feeling of "Berserker," the anime at the beginning. Nothing as bloody, obviously, "Torbrek" is a light read, just something in presenting the main heroine and the circumstances she found herself in. If someone mentions "Star wars," on account of the kingdom taken over by a tyrant and a mysterious order of knights opposing him, I would like to say: this is as common a premise as could be; not like Lucas invented it. It just works.Good, light YA fantasy read.

"Vampires: Romance to Rippers. An Anthology of Risque Stories" is, self-explanatory, a collection of "risque" vampire stories. A couple of the pieces stand out:"The Making of Marea" by Scarlette D'Noire is a short story that describes a "making" of a vampire. Sounds like we've read this before, right? Well, here's the thing: as long as these stories are freshly told, have unexpected plot twists, and craftfully written, we'll be chasing the high again and again. The story is set in a plantation, where Marea, an ex-slave girl, is an object of desire of both the Master, and Delano, the vampire. Delano turns Marea, hoping to bind her to him. Sounds simple, but it isn't. Marea is not a "simple" girl, not a plaything to those who have more power. Read on to find some nice plot twists and get yourself surprised. It's a very neatly constructed story set in the vampire lore.Charity Parkerson's "Double the Sin" is a short story that is an interlude for her "Sinner's" series of novels. It tells the tale of a love that was almost lost, found again, and the protagonists reunited. In a very steamy action, that should come with a medical warning, I might add. Ms. Parkerson's short stories are usually the pick of the bunch. It seems that it doesn't matter what she writes: erotica, romance, etc., she handles the format extremely well. She could probably write a recipe book and we'll be talking about the story structure and trying to find the hidden allegories in it as we write our reviews. Good stuff, as usual.The rest of the stories are pretty good as well, competently written, and will appeal to the broad vampire-loving audience. Check out "Hot Dark Comfort" and "My Vampire Lover."The book starts with prefaces that give us a "behind-the-scenes" glimpse into the evolution of "vampire" in literature, especially in romance.Altogether, a solid anthology. 4.5 stars.
