It seems that it doesn't matter what she writes: erotica, romance, etc., she handles the format extremely well. She could probably write a recipe book and we'll be talking about the story structure and trying to find the hidden allegories in it as we write our reviews.Good stuff, as usual.

"The Making of Marea" by Scarlette D'Noire is a short story that describes a "making" of a vampire. Sounds like we've read this before, right? Well, here's the thing: as long as these stories are freshly told, have unexpected plot twists, and craftfully written, we'll be chasing the high again and again.The story is set in a plantation, where Marea, an ex-slave girl, is an object of desire of both the Master, and Delano, the vampire. Delano turns Marea, hoping to bind her to him. Sounds simple, but it isn't. Marea is not a "simple" girl, not a plaything to those who have more power.Read on to find some nice plot twists and get yourself surprised. A very neatly constructed story set in the vampire lore.

The premises of these three short stories are deceptively simple:✔ A masquerade ball, of the "naughty-nobody-knows-your-name" sort. All morals, shame, and inhibitions are left at the door. An invitation to an encounter with a stranger.✔ Nightly "conversations" with a friend she'd never actually met. Can a friendship made online lead to something more?✔ An unexpected meeting in the park.However, the execution is nothing but. The switching of the scenes brings the switch of the points of view, so the reader can explore feelings and desires from multiple protagonists. The subtle interplay is visible to those who appreciate the craft of the well-written short story; the eroticism it brings is a step above the usual erotica fair that is flooding the bookstores. Through the stories, the protagonists also come to some realization about themselves.To coin a phrase, this is a "thinking person's erotica."Recommended.

A light-hearted science fiction is a rare beast nowadays. Long gone are the days of Harry Harrison and  Keith Laumer. So, when we have a chance to read something that is upbeat, free-flowing, and entertaining, we should take it."Hard Luck Hank: Screw the Galaxy" is one of such books. The main protagonist and POV character, Hank, is a "mediator." When negotiations between various unsavory characters come to the point of pointing guns at each other, the parties involved hire him to arrive to a more "peaceful" and less expensive resolution. As Hank says:"There's a reason people hire me. It's not because I'm a genius. Or an expert marksman. Or because of my stunning good looks. No, it's because I actually listen."Being bulletproof also helps. Hank is a "level four mutant," whose specific ability is an almost impervious exterior and fast regenerative powers. His services are in great demand: he lives on Belvaille, a most remote space station of Colmarian Confederation, where "overwhelming majority [of its inhabitants] were involved in illegal activities or were wanted as criminals."Sometimes, there are problems that even Hank cannot solve easily. Like killer robots, Dredel Led, that came for a visit to the station to shoot it up a bit, or a mysterious brother/sister combo, who are on the ran from everyone and think that Hank is their new best friend.Well, Hank is doing the best he can, under the circumstances. As the station's newspaper describes his various adventures: "Everything had looked grim, no hope of survival, and then I showed up, looking calm as could be, eating a sandwich."This novel is a light read, with some good one-liners. If you are looking for a light-hearted Sci-Fi, you found it.

Balloon is a morbidly obese man who looks at the world with a "look of dim-witted stupidity." His only "friends" are Tom Starley and Russ Gibson, people of normal weight (for Texas,) who keep their acquaintance with Balloon mostly for the entertainment value, him being an easy target for their jokes, sarcastic insults, and "scientific" probes into "the mathematical improbabilities of Balloon's ability to stand upright and walk." Completes the cast an epically rotund "dream girl." Balloon "loved her with an insatiable desire.  She hated him with an equal passion.  She called herself Victory."Things are not looking up for Balloon. However, something changes. Balloon acquires an ability to guess anything correctly. Of course, the problem is--he might not know what questions to ask. His "friends," however, are there to help. "Just guess where we can find a lot of money that doesn't belong to anybody," they ask. Obvious, right? However, there's a bigger question that awaits Balloon's answer--how to cure Victory's dad of a mysterious illness that makes his nose bleed and will end in his head exploding.This might require a bit more doing. Like traveling to another galaxy to obtain a "ball of power" that has been zealously guarded by the locals for thousands of years.I would like to say: Much respect for making such an unlikely "hero" into someone I ended up routing for by the end of the book. While the first part of the book was mostly jokes at Balloon's expense, the second part picks up rather nicely. It becomes a mixture of "Three Men in a Boat (To Say Nothing of the Dog)" and "Space Balls," with some "The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy" thrown in. I don't want to give any spoilers, you'll see what I am talking about when you get to the Sombrero Galaxy, Zaxmorthia.The dialect Balloon uses might be a bit problematic for the uninitiated. I'd rather see a little more plain-spoken Balloon with a few linguistic quirks thrown in to spice things up than a full blown Southern dialect. I did get used to it soon enough, however."Balloon Boy and the Porcupine Pals: Antihooliganism" by Mort Gloss is a rather entertaining,  Sci-Fi/Satirical adventure that affirms that "size parallels greatness." Fun read.

Note: this is the third book in the series. To avoid possible spoilers, check out Outview (The Inner Movement) and Outin (The Inner Movement) books first."Outmove" picks up the story of Nate Ryder and the spiritual "Awakening" of the Human race some time after the dramatic ending of the "Outin." He is almost nineteen, he is the formal leader of the Movement, that since "had grown into a worldwide revolution," and his life has never been more complicated.Lightyear, the organization that has been hunting Nate and his friends in the previous book, has been defeated, its leader, Luther Storch, dead. The victory came with a price of many deaths and losses, and brought new problems: "Lightyear had just been a tiny division in an organization old with power, deep with connections and stunning in its coldness and greed--Omnia." The conspiracy Nate has been fighting against became a full-blown worldwide takeover by this ancient power broker.With its almost limitless resources, Omnia can seemingly counter most anything Nate and his merry band of mystics and awakened can come up with. What is worse, the Movement is split into two factions: the main one, that takes the path of non-violence, and the Inner Force, the violent faction within the Movement, that holds to the idea that ends justify the means."Outmove", the third novel in the "The Inner Movement" series, is much more action-filled than the two previous books. There are narrow escapes, prison breaks, plane chases, you name it. The battles are fought across times and dimensions, between the multiple incarnations of the same souls; the multiple possibilities of the outcomes become the prize. This is also where it gets pretty trippy. Even if you have been following in amazement the complex weave of metaphysical into the nature of reality in the two previous books, this one beats them all. Death is no longer the thing to fear, it's just a transition. Except for one possible death, Nate's. If he is to die in this incarnation, on this earthly plane the "Awakening" will fail. Nate "was king, bishop, knight and pawn in a multi-dimensional chess game that would decide the fate of humanity."Some of this book reminds me of the Zelazny's novels. The handling of multiple realities inside a single narrative is a tough thing to do, but Brandt Legg does it pretty darn well. A few parts really stand out: the President Taft bit was brilliant, for example.There is also a tighter integration of the spiritual and such concepts as personal and societal freedoms, population control by the powers to be, public opinion, etc., in this novel. As things come to a boil, and the shadowy forces make their move, we can see that those little parts of our freedoms we give up right now in exchange for security are not so little after all, they are simply a first step that leads to loosing more and more of our freedoms down the road. Our belief that "If you aren't hiding anything, you don't need privacy. You only need your right to privacy if you have something to hide," is a group complacency born out of fear, passivity, and lack of information. "Outmove" makes this point rather clearly."Outmove" is a fast-moving yet thoughtful read. As always, it will appeal to the New Age crowd; however, with this installment, it will find a much larger audience among those readers who prefer to think for themselves. Recommended.

Space Rovers, The Pilot Episode, is a first in what hopefully to be a long series of humorous Sci-Fi novelettes. The author, Philip Gottschalk, mentioned at the end of this book that he wrote 50 episodes altogether, formatted as screenplays. Now he is rewriting them as novelettes and will be publishing them as they are ready.More than a few chuckles in this book and a good number of laughs. The jokes are pretty darn good:◕"Harlow had a scrunch on his dour, English face that made him look like he was sucking on a lemon-flavoured wasp-sting."◕"You want to shoot the crap out of some aliens, don't you, Harlow." "I'm not picky, sir. I'd shoot the crap out of anything at this point."As you might probably guess, Harlow, the security officer, is one of my more favorite characters here. But the jokes are not limited to him alone:◕"Apparently, Nutt determined, the creature spent most of its day in the gym working out.  The rest of the time it was probably eating the other gym members."◕"I want the new registration, deluxe model with fancier chairs and elevators that go up as well as down."While at first the story reads as a Star Trek spoof, the characters do stand on their own after a while, with the only briefest of references to the original, mostly subtle. This way the story can be read on it's own for the jokes alone, or as a funny spoof for hardcore Star Trek fans.

These little guys are lifesavers if you, like me, have a lot of adapters that you are trying to hook up into one power strip. You probably cannot see it in the picture but one pair is a double plug - you can plug one adapter into the cable itself and the other one right on top of it. It stands 1 1/4" tall so it should clear most regular plugs. These extensions are of different lengths (depending from where you measure):✔ Regular plug variety is between 12-13"✔ The double plug is between 12-13"✔ The right angle plug is the longest at 17-18"So, plan accordingly. I also don't think these are rated for heavy equipment like refrigerators, etc. However, these should be good enough for most TV sets, computers, game and entertainment systems. Unless you have an industrial-rate amp installed for your speakers, these should work.A bit expensive at current price but it does pay for itself in the long run - you'll use up fewer power strips. I got my first set in 2008 and still use them ever since.☆☆☆☆

The thoughts of a great (1) wizard, Mulogo, are recorded on these pages by his humble (2) scribe Ludaceous Vaer Mordicanum, Lesser Under Understudy, Apprentice Wizard 3rd Order, etc., ect.While this lowly scribe does, at times, and most inappropriately, attempt to make light of the wiser, more experienced, and obviously superior in every way Mulogo, who is the greatest wizard of his Age (3), the profound truth of the words in this Treatise cannot be denied by a mere common man (4).Some of the passages might prove useful to even the most commonplace and boring of readers that do not posses even an iota of magical prowess. Take, for example, the chapter aptly named "On Combat (and Sometimes Avoiding It.)" It is clear that Mulogo, being a mighty wizard (5), would phrase it so - "avoiding it sometimes." Yet to readers who are keen to pick up on even smallest of clues, the meaning will be perfectly transparent and the chapter will read more as "On Combat, and Avoiding Thereof." A sage advice to us all.The chapter "When Griffins Attack" might not seem as containing information that a regular person could use in everyday life but judging it by the name alone does not do it justice. It also covers manticores, wyverns, spectres, and other common pests.To sum up this great work of wisdom so profound yet so accessible even to the most unwashed of masses, allow me to leave you with these two small yet very important gems of an advice that could be glimpsed, among others, from reading this volume:✔ A. If you are currently employed as a disposable henchman (6), you might want to reconsider your career priorities.✔ B. Always check that your boots are in a good working order (7).➨ Notes and Annotations:◕ 1. As is plainly apparent from Mulogo's own self-description.◕ 2. Humble and Ludaceous are not synonymous.◕ 3. See 1.◕ 4. Or a woman, child, an apparition, or any other being, be it corporeal, astral, or in between.◕ 5. See 3.◕ 6. The politically correct term is "Hench-person".◕ 7. This is generously assuming that you actually can afford to buy a pair.Disclaimer: I received a copy of this treatise for purposes of a review.

The recipes in "Texas Jack's Famous Pralines Secret Recipe Book" range from a traditional Pecan Praline to elegant Amaretto Pecan to exotic Mexican Chili Mocha Pecan. The book also has recipes for Almond, Coconut, Agave, and even Raisin Pralines. Cookies, Fudge, and Brown Candy are covered as well.The book talks about the history of Texas Jack, which gives it a unique flavor for a recipe book. This is Texas Jack Vermillion, by the way, not to be confused with Texas Jack Omohundro, who, while famous in his own right, had little to do with pralines.The recipes are easy to follow, with well outlined ingredient measurements, and have handy advices for amateur chiefs as myself. The book is neatly formatted and has a clickable table of contents. This is my personal quirk when it comes to Kindle recipe books - clickable table of contents is a must for me. I would love to see more pictures included in the book - these pralines look positively mouth-watering.A lovingly-made, history-rich addition to my Kindle recipe book collection. Recommended.

In my humble opinion, "Bully Eater" is closer to the manga than to comics in its form. When I opened it up the first time, I automatically started reading right to left, mange-style, until I realized that the panels are arranged in Western format, left to right.There are two chapters in this edition that set up the story of Isao Akio, his meeting with Tien Lung, and all the broken teeth, limbs, ribs, you name it, that are to follow.Good, strong lines translate well to Kindle and other ereaders. Well executed backgrounds add to the atmosphere very nicely - this is something that Western mangakas need to learn more from their Japanese counterparts. The character designs are expressive, especially that of Tien Lung. The fight scenes, so far, have been pretty short for a martial arts comic / manga, most likely to get more of the story on the pages. Hopefully, there are going to be more fighting in future installments.The images are formatted for traditional Kindles, meaning that they are slightly smaller than the screens of large Kindles, like HD model, or iPad, for example. I think it should be possible to make two versions of the book, one regular and the other one high-resolution."Bully Eater" chapters 1 and 2 is a very impressive debut by mangaka Raymond Brown. It's a nicely told, well drawn beginning of a story that hopefully will get continuation very soon.

These might not be the finest mechanical pencils I've ever used - that distinction goes to great but somewhat expensive Pilot Dr. Grip Limited - but for the price, you are getting a really sturdy and precise drawing machine with Paper Mate Titanium.The grip is wide enough to reduce stress from a prolonged use. You can drop them no problem, they are designed to withstand abuse. The eraser is adequate for most situations for a built-in. You probably have good erasers separately anyway if you use pencils a lot. At about $3-4 a pop, these are a good buy.

There is a virtual plethora of "How To Sell Books on Kindle" that is available. I've read and reviewed my fair share and I figured out a simple test on how to determine if such a book contains good, up-to-date advice: Simply look at the book's rankings. If it's relatively high, like this book has, you are certain to get at least some useful information from it - the author obviously knows what she/he is talking about. If it's low, like a few books I am not going to mention, skip it."The Kindle Publishing Bible" by Tom Corson-Knowles falls into an "intermediate" to "advanced" range of books that teach you how to succeed selling your book on Amazon. Certain assumptions are made by the author that the reader should already possess at least a cursory knowledge with publishing on Kindle. This is not a problem, in my opinion. Think about it this way - you might go through a few books that will teach you all the basics and then get to this, more advanced material. Or, you could just do a quick Google search to figure out a few things that are mentioned but not explained in depth. Your choice.The book is a bit of a stream of consciousness. In addition to the book-selling strategies, there are also certain productivity tips, like "Frictionless Writing," and general observations on the state of modern book publishing, quote:◕ "There's a war out there in Kindle publishing. It's "every author for himself" (or herself) - at least that's how most of your competitors look at it. But I've found that it just doesn't pay to do things unethically."This theme of doing things "ethically" is present throughout the book. It's a refreshing approach and one of the reasons I am giving this book high marks.Also, kudos to the author for saying the following about Amazon's Top Reviewers:◕ "Treat them like a professional and they will provide you with an invaluable service."This is a solid advice and one that many authors, publicists, and book agents nowadays ignore completely - I speak here from the experience.All in all, this is a good book on Kindle publishing, and, despite my minor criticisms, it is worth reading. There are some books that are better organized but few that are written with this level of conviction. Solid 4.5 Stars. Recommended.Disclaimer: I received a copy of this book for the purposes of a review.

First, the ingredients and the serving size. This information is not included in the product description so I thought I'll put it here.Serving amount is two tablets.✔ B-Complex:Thiamin-Vitamin B1 5 mg 300%Riboflavin-Vitamin B2 9 mg 500%Niacin 45 mg 225%Vitamin B6 9 mg 450%Folate 400 mcg 100%Vitamin B12 120 mcg 2000%Biotin 300 mcg 100%Pantothenic Acid 45 mg 450%✔ Herbal Extracts (They give these funky names but you can still see the ingredients):Optimal Stress Response 140 mg:Chamomile (flower); Lavender (flower); Eleuthero (root); American Ginseng (root); Hawthorn (berry and leaf)Immune Support Response 82 mg:Astragalus (root); Elderberry (berry); Shiitake (mushroom); Cordyceps (mushroom); Reishi (mushroom); Maitake (mushroom)✔ More Herbal Extracts that go by the name of Superfoods and Spices here:Organic Spinach (leaf) 155 mgSoy Lecithin (non-GMO) 132 mgOrganic Blueberry (fruit) 95 mgTurmeric (rhizome) 6.4 mg hydroethanolic extract and 1.6 mg organic supercritical extract 8 mgGinger (rhizome) 3.2 mg hydroethanolic extract and 0.8 mg organic supercritical extract 4 mg➨ Now, the review itself.This is a pretty darn good B-complex supplement. Good ingredients. The pills are not too large to swallow, which is a plus in my book. It's a bit on the expensive side but I am sensitive to B vitamins so I have to be careful which ones I take.The "Superfoods" added here are in quantities large enough to help the absorption of B vitamins but if you are into these "Superfoods", you might consider taking some other formulation in addition to this.➨ A couple of observations (from my experience) on vitamin B complex in general:✔ The quality of the ingredients, the components, and the amounts, play a big role. Sometimes taking a cheap, grocery store variety B complex might lead to results that are opposite to what we usually expect from taking these vitamins. So, be careful and observe how you react to it, especially if you have some neurological disease - migraine, anxiety, etc.✔ If you take a single vitamin B for whatever reason - B12, B6, whatever, please keep in mind that all the vitamin Bs act in tandem. You might actually develop deficiency of other B vitamins if you concentrate just on one. So, you might consider taking a good B complex instead.✔ Vitamin B complex included in most multivitamins is usually not of sufficient quantity and quality to have as much effect as a dedicated vitamin B complex.As for New Chapter Coenzyme B Food Complex, I've been taking it for a couple of years already. Every time I try to economize and switch to cheaper brands, I can feel the difference. Recommended.

Update August 5th 2013:Shenzhen Knives rep. contacted me via email. They have redesigned the knives to include a different handle.They offered to send me a sample for testing. I am really curious to see how the changes in the design will work out in practice.I am provisionally changing my rating to 4-stars, pending the actual review. Any company that goes as far as to actually try and improve a product because their customers asked them to, does deserve some brownie points, in my humble opinion.I will test the knife for an extended period of time and then post an updated review on the new blade, so stay tuned in._____Update April 5th 2013:Shenzhen Knives rep. contacted me in this very thread. That shows that they care. That's a plus for the company. Would be interesting to see how this develops. I'll keep you posted._____The ceramic blade on these paring knives is, in my opinion, is superior even to Kyocera Revolution. And that is saying a lot - Kyoceras are usually my brand of choice. These Shenzhens seem to keep the edge longer, and I like the fact that the blades come to a point, unlike Kyocera's rounded tips. I also haven't managed to seriously chip any of these yet, which is a common problem with most ceramic knives.However! The handle needs to be constructed better. It feels nice in the hand, it's ergonomic, etc., but, look at the place where your index finger would be - that place is too thin and is the reason why I had a blade break out of the handle on two of these knives. I know that I am a large man with big hands and it is difficult for me sometimes to control the amount of force I apply, but seriously, the last time this happened when I was cutting an apple...So, why not a one star rating, you might ask? Because, the blades are excellent. If this company reinforces the handle just a little, this would be the best ceramic paring knife on the market under $20. So, lets hope someone from the company that produces these reads it and perhaps we will see an improved version on the market shortly. If they need a tester, my email is in the profile. Lets try and improve this product, we'll all will benefit from it.

This is just about the best knife sharpener I've owned. Easy to use and relatively safe. I have an old paring knife I use for most jobs in the kitchen. It's some cheap Taiwanese-made deal I bought way back in the 90s. One good thing about it is that the steel is softer than on most modern kitchen knives. So, a few swipes on the carbide cutting heads and the knife is good so slice anything.I recently found that the ceramic rods on the other side actually work with my Kyocera ceramic knife. It doesn't make it factory-sharp but good enough for use.Do make sure to rest the sharpener on the table vertically, with the side you want to use facing up. Hold it down firmly by one of the flanges. This method is safer and gives more control over sharpening than holding the knife in one hand and swiping the sharpener down the blade with the other.One last note - this CCKB model seems to be discontinued. No worries. CCKS model is pretty much the same thing. You can either search for "Smith's CCKS" or get it as an Add-On item here: Smith's CCKS 2-Step Knife Sharpener

Excellent piece of writing by Bill Redban. The book captures all of Ronda Rousey's key moments in her life thus far. My favorite part was her fighter profile. There were many details in book that I did not know about. The author has a clean writing style that keeps the reader engaged the entire way through the book. Highly recommend to anyone out there that does not know Ronda Rousey or anyone that wants the inside scoop on her life.

I purchased the Inogen One G3 System as I have a need for oxygen on a daily basis. When I was researching a portable oxygen unit in every category the Inogen unit came out on top. The machine is very small and portable and very lightweight which makes carrying the unit easy. The Inogen unit is very quiet and does not disturb my husband when we are watching television. The price was very reasonable for the quality I received from Inogen. Very handy that it comes with a carry bag as well a car charger I would highly recommend this Inogen oxygen unit to everyone that has a need.

Yes, I officially don’t regret spending on this. It’s absolutely terrific and my hair looks and feels amazing nowadays. I dye my hair often so it gets brittle and looks dry, but now it looks just as healthy as someone who has never dyed their hair in their lives. After the third time the difference was mind blowing. Will make sure to recommend this to everyone from now on :)

If you have read Nora Roberts Blood Magick, The Cousins O'Dwyer Trilogy picking up a copy of Book*Sense's summary and analysis only makes sense. The summary and analysis really does help you to understand the book in a different way the author presents it. I have found now since using summary and analysis books from Book*Sense that I can really completely understand the storyline.I would highly recommend this Book*Sense summary to anyone that has read or plans to read this Nora Roberts book.

This is the second book I have read in this series. Reading another in the series really did help me with following along in Captivated By You. The books are easy to get into and give a most thorough summary and analysis of the book by Sylvia Day. If you are a lover of romances, like I am you will absolutely love this. Looking forward to reading a few others from Book*Sense.

I have been using the Massage Roller Ball for 3 months now and just love this product. The roller ball fits comfortably in the palm of your hand for easy use on all areas of the body. I am an active runner and tend to have aches and pains after long marathon runs. I use the roller ball after intense workouts and i allows me to relax. The Fitness Lifestyle Company has developed a really great product for athletes and anyone else that suffers from body pain or simply just to relieve stress.I would highly recommend the Massage Roller Balls to everyone.

This is a very impressive piece of writing by Marianne Ryan. On reading the first few chapters I was amazed at the amount of research and details that the author has poured into this book. Solid information can be found on each and every page. My favorite section in the book was the section on Understanding Your New Body. It is a big change for any women whether its your first or third child, each time is a different experience and this book prepares you for everything you will encounter.  I was able to personally follow the guidelines for exercise in this book which has allowed me to lose all of my "baby weight" and regain my original form.I highly recommend this books to all current and future mothers or to someone that may have a daughter, sister or friend that is or will be giving birth. What a life changing book.

What a genius product these high heel protectors are. I find they are absolutely great for walking on slippery surfaces whether a slippery floor or outside in the rain. The high heel protectors are super simple to apply to most sized heels. The high heel protectors are clear and are not even really noticeable on heels of any colors. The price point on these heel protectors is very reasonable. This is an overall excellent product by Zipwaze.

I am just ecstatic that I have discovered this neck firming cream. I have been looking for some time now for a product that would actually do what it says it will. After using the Puressant best neck firming cream for 2 weeks faithfully I am extremely pleased with the results. I really had an issue with sagging skin under my chin. Nothing has ever come close to helping, that was until I ordered and used this product. Myself and my husband can both notice a considerable difference in how toned my under neck area is now prior to the use of the cream.I really love that this cream does not have a strong scent and it is perfect for sensitive skin and regular use. I encourage all women out there to not hesitate you will see great results from using this cream. Happy customer!

This was an excellent piece of writing. The story was summarized perfectly. The author Liane Moriarty's fine attention to details show consistently in this summary and analysis. I would highly recommend to anyone looking for a summary of What Alice Forgot.  Great read!

Our most recent purchase of this theater seat was exactly as we were expecting. The design of the furniture is modern and has a great feel. We had been referred to the Theater Seat Company by a co-worker of my husbands. He told us about the great service he had so we thought to give it a try as well.The service agents were friendly and helpful and helped us to decide on this set for our room design. We found that this particular set would especially benefit us because we have small children and it is a very durable design. 3 weeks later and it is holding up so well. We are glad they gave us good feedback for our purchase. Highly recommend.

I found this Bellema Mango Pump after taking a quick look around online. It seemed to be just what I was looking for. My daughter does not seem to eat alot but the doctors said she is perfectly fine. I did not want to lose my milk flow so was advised that I should pump and freeze for future use.The pump is super easy to use and cleanup is a breeze. Very helpful for someone that is needing to pump their extra milk.The soft silicone cushions make pumping comfortable and not painful at all. I really like this Bellema pump. 5 Star for sure!

After the birth of my premature son he was just too small to breastfeed. A nurse at the hospital suggested that I try and find a Bellema Professional Care pump. I was able to find one and am so happy that I did. The double pumps allows for a consistent milk flow and it takes less time that that of a single breast pump.The suction area of the pump is powerful enough for a perfect milk flow but does not hurt during or after a pumping session. I would encourage all new mothers to try the pump it will save you so much time in the long run.

I have very sensitive skin so I was not sure how I would react to this NuLight Gel. After my first use it felt great on my skin. I have been suffering with dark circles under my eyes for so long but have been unsuccessful to find a product that would be gentle enough to use. My dark circles have now faded quite a bit and my husband even noticed that the circles had diminished. I really love this product and plan on trying some others in this same product lineup.I am comfortable saying that others will most certainly love this product also.

I am so happy a friend told me about this product. After just one week of use the NuCell Anti-Hair Loss Serum is making my hair thicker and has a great shine. It is very easy to apply and only a small amount of product is needed each time. The price is exceptional for the quality of the serum you will receive. Highly recommend to anyone with thinning issues or if you just want a healthier look for your hair.

Wow! What a great novel. The author Paula Hawkins has really captured the readers interest with this piece of writing. Upon reading I was able to get into the book right away not like others that take so much time for the story to get started. The storyline kept me engaged the entire way through the book and I was on the edge of my seat through the entire book. The book always kept me wondering what was coming next.Overall I really loved reading this book and look forward to reading more by Paula Hawkins in the very near future. I will not give any spoilers but just say that if you are looking for a good thriller filled with suspense this is the book for you.

Recently purchased this selfie stick for a camping trip we were taking. Love the fact that it is so compact and can easily to carried in a backpack. The length of the extendable rod is perfect for taking some great shots. We took a really cool picture of three of us sitting on the edge of a cliff on our hiking trip. We were able to use our cell phones as well able to hook up our GoPro for some unbelievable shots on the lake cliff jumping. Highly recommend.

I just love my new waterproof iPhone 6 case. I was at a friends house for a pool party and accidentally dropped my phone in the pool. What a life saver the Aobile case was. The speaker sound great and I love how I can use it as a docking station as well.  Its very compact making it portable and great for travel. I love how they are so easy to wash and dry.  I just hand wash them with dishwashing soap and hang dry.  I did receive these at a discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

It has all the features of a normal sling backpack but folds into a small sack making it very packable and portable. Its very light weight and water repellent. Great for cycling, hiking, traveling light etc. Has plenty of features and pockets.  I especially love the purple color and its true to color.  I'm very happy I received this in exchange for honest and unbiased review.

The additional suction cups work really well to hang and dry bath scrubbers.  My kids really like to cute little bath toys that come with this set. Eye Pillows By Happy Wraps® (Amethyst)This eye pillow really make you feel like you are at a spa.  It great for migraines and also if you have to shift your days for work.  I did received this at a discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

Katrina, stepdaughter of the Alpha of her pack, is taken hostage by a rival shifter pack. Maddox, the Alpha of the rival pack, may have ulterior motives for kidnapping Katrina. There is a lot more going on than meets the eye.What worked - The writing flows well, with minimal grammatical errors. I liked Katrina and Maddox. I thought both characters showed noticeable growth over the course of the book. Interesting subplots, and a sneak peek at the next couple in the series.What didn't work as well - the villains are a bit one-dimensional, but hey, it's a short book...in the great, big scheme of things, this is a minor nitpick.Bottom line - I really enjoyed Taken by the Alpha. If you like hawt shifters and snarky, strong willed heroines who are all about saving themselves rather than waiting for the rescue, I would recommend this title.

Very Brief Synopsis - George gets dumped and starts a blog about the tribulations of relationships. Her sister begs her to move back to Marsden to help care for George's young niece. George doesn't want to. She does, anyway. Then George runs into her teenage love, Casey, and madcap antics ensue.What worked - Down on Love is well written. The story flows well. There is a ton of snark.What didn't work as well - Firstly, this is not a romance. This is woman's literature (or chick lit, if you prefer). George is a hot mess, and is trying to find herself. She gets input from her harpy of a sister - seriously, Sera (the sister) needs meds. So. Mean. Over-the-top, unbelievably mean. And the entire freaking town, which drives George crazy, and is the reason she never came back to her hometown once she left. Frankly, I can't blame her. So all of these people are up in George's business, and Casey's business. Casey wants to date George, but she can't because she has become a neo-virgin, whatever that means...How do I really feel - Well, a 29 year old woman who acts as flighty and immature as George makes me wonder what the heck Casey sees in her. He keeps saying how smart and how strong she is, her sister keeps saying how strong George is (usually screaming it at her, in the midst of an argument)...I didn't see any of that. She pushes away a perfectly nice, sincere guy who is on board with her crazy, for flimsy reasons. She cuts and runs rather than growing up, or being strong. Not smart.I get the "Town as a character" trend. In some cases, this trope works. This is not one of those cases. There are too many townsfolk, most of them not very nice, we get a line here or there about each character...I gave up trying to differentiate.There is no romance. Let me repeat - no romance. George spends most of the book trying to get away from Casey. There is one abortive date attempt. Physically, there is one kiss, maybe two, and a behind closed doors scene.Bottom line - If you want to read a story about a woman who is trying to figure out who she wants to be, this may work for you. If you are looking for a character who actually shows some growth before the last 3 pages of the book, you may not care for this. If you are looking for a hot romance, this may not work for you at all.

I picked up this novella as a freebie. I like PNR, as a rule, and Shadow's Passion sounded interesting.Very Brief Synopsis - Not your typical shifter/vamp/angel trope. In this world, there are Shadows and Wardens. The two groups are working toward the same goal, to eliminate the threat of the Vorati, a demon species that possesses the souls of humans. Seems the Vorati are starting to organize and plan, something that is new to them. One of the Oracles has seen that the Shadows and the Warders need to change things up in order to defeat the demons. (This is not a spoiler - it is in the Prologue)What worked for me - Terrific storyline, great pace, intriguing PNR twist. The writing is superb - humorous, detailed, distinct voices for the characters, terrific flow. Wrapped up as a standalone, but left the over-arcing plot to carry on the series. In other words, yes it is a series, but no stinkin' cliffhanger.What didn't work as well - Not quite the level of world building I would have liked. Yeah, I know the story played out on a mountain in the middle of nowhere, but do humans know about Shadows and Warders? I got the vague impression of no...Then again, this is a novella, albeit a long one, so my questions may be answered in the next book.Gimme Romance - well, I really liked Gabe and Celeste together, even though it happened pretty quickly. Again, novella... I thought they brought out good qualities in each other, and were a good fit. Gabe is ever so alpha,  with a tragic past, and Celeste has been alone for a long time, in exile for an incident beyond her control...both struggle mightily with guilt. I liked them a lot.Bottom line - I am all set to dive back into this world. I have been reading a lot of not so great books lately, it seems, so boy, was I appreciative of the fact that Shadow's Passion was very well done. I would recommend this to anyone who is looking for a well written novel with an interesting twist on PNR.

First things first, and the reason for the lack of a 5th star - The box in which the wipes are stored is a very flimsy quasi-cardboard thing. It is not in the least bit substantial, and I paid the devil trying to get the tab in the slot for closure. I am not necessarily in favor of plastic, but a container with a little more substance would be appreciated.As to the cleaning capability of the Clorox Triple Action Wipes, no complaints at all. Although I do think they are overreaching with the whole "Clean the whole room with one cloth". If you dust daily, or maybe every other day, and have a small room, with no pets...okay, maybe then one wipe will clean a whole room. For those of us who are not compulsive dusters, you can probably count on 2 cleaning the room.I was most impressed with how the wipe grabbed up all of the dust on my TV stand, with one pass. The stand is black, and seems to attract all the dust in the immediate available area. I have a real love/hate thing going with that stand...the Clorox Dust Wipe may tilt the balance firmly to the love side.I have tried MANY of the comparable products on the market, and this one is, hands down, the best one I have used. The surface of the wipe is a little sticky, not so it sticks to your hand or to the surface, but it does grab the dust up without spewing the dust particles back out into the air. There is no residual dusty smell, either.Bottom line - I like this product, and will be incorporating it into my cleaning routine. It actually works, with one swipe, no wiping at the same spot over and over. I would absolutely recommend the Clorox Triple Action Dust Wipes.

So I sat down with my Kindle at 11am, and did not move except for necessary breaks, if you know what I mean, for the next 6 hours. Soaring is everything I love about KA. Strong characters, with a level of realness that is unparalleled. Seriously - unparalleled. KA just nails the feelings, with a word, a nuance, a carefully placed action...and this reader felt the pang of heartache, and tasted the joy of the moment.Amelia is trying to make amends to her children after the breakup of her marriage. She's in her late forties, alone in a new town, and figuring out who Amelia is. She's an heiress on both sides of her family. Amelia is the poor little rich girl who only wants someone to love her. Amelia is determined to make something good of herself internally. She's feisty, warm, and she doesn't walk away from a fight. The details of her struggle to adjust to her new reality were spot on. As was the "attractive" comment, and the feelings it evoked.Mickey is a newly single dad, working a job he doesn't like, while volunteering at the local fire station, which he really likes. Mickey is all about his kids, all about being the provider, the protector... And our boy is good with his naughty words, too...Swoon! Loved his devotion to his kids. Loved how he took care of Amelia. A KA Hero for the record books, is Mickey.Most of the conflict comes from external sources...the kids, Amelia's ex, Mickey's ex. Some, though, was the internal struggle for Mickey as he tried to process that taking care of someone did not necessarily mean paying for everything. The conflict was, again, realistic, and handled beautifully. There were no insta-fixes here. The story builds in a believable way. The blending of the two families, the money issues, the ex's...maybe a little too easy, but still within the realm of the possible.The writing is warm, evocative and emotionally charged. As usual with a KA book, I laughed, I cried ugly, ugly tears, I cheered...I wanted Amelia and Mickey to get their HEA, and they worked for it. Loved the inclusion of Josie, Alyssa, Jake, Con and Sofie from The Will.It's KA, what can I say? Loved this one, and no doubt will be reading it again. Highly, highly recommend

Celia Kyle is a master of the short novella. She throws the reader right into the action, making the most of the words on the page. Seriously, 46 pages, and I felt like I knew Jennifer and Brett. Tailing her is funny and hawt. Brett is hugely fun as a good time guy who has just had his world rocked by his strong willed mate - to watch this Beta go crazy when Jenn walks into a room full of his men wearing only a towel...good times. Jenn is an independent girl with a temper of her own. Her reaction to Brett's ex was hilarious!If you are looking for a very quick, sexy, funny read, grab up Tailing Her.

I've liked Porter and Kenzie throughout the series, and love how Porter doesn't let Kenzie get away with her brattiness. Porter knows there is an underlying cause for her behavior and is determined to help her. Kenzie is a complicated girl, with long buried issues. She is frustrated that her usual tactics don't seem to work on Porter, and she isn't interested in sharing her past.This Club Sin novel is really well done, with a lot of depth. The conflict is internal and there is an external component, as well. Kenzie pushes back against being helped with either. Kenzie is not an easy heroine to love, but I admired her strength, and how she struggled to find relief for her depression. Porter was patient and insightful, and his feelings for Kenzie were apparent.One thing that didn't work - At the end of the book, Porter is trying to figure out what exactly Kenzie is looking for from him. He and Aidan set up a test of sorts...I thought it was kind of juvenile and out of character.Bottom line - I have enjoyed the whole series, and really liked Tamed. Some delicate issues are handled well, and I was rooting for Porter and Kenzie to get their HEA. I would recommend this title.

Anti-relationship sports radio host Grayson and on-air relationship psychologist Noelle are directed to combine forces for a hybrid radio show to boost ratings for their station. Given the fact that the two really don't like each other, this is unwelcome news. When they start to spend time together, they realize they have more in common than they thought.Due to his parents having been married a collective 6 times, Gray is not a believer in happily ever after. Noelle's experience is the opposite, as her parents were happy together. The premise is a little simplistic, the story is not anything new. On the other hand, the writing flowed well, and I liked the characters.Bottom line - If you like enemies to lovers stories, Tell Me Something Good is cute and readable.

Wonderful office romance between Gabriel, a driven ex-rugby player turned company savior, and Charlotte, a survivor of a terrible attack. Gabriel, or T-Rex, figures out early on that there is a lot more to Charlotte than meets the eye. Throughout the book, Charlotte morphs from a scared mouse who jumps at shadows, to a empowered young woman who sees her own worth.Though it takes a while for Charlotte to open up to Gabriel about her issues, he knows he wants her, and displays admirable patience in pursuing her. His restraint as they navigated their way to a physical relationship showed the depth of his commitment to Charlotte and to their budding relationship.Favorite moments - watching Charlotte take back her power was amazing. It was clear from the beginning that Gabriel was in it for the long haul, and he showed this dedication in a million little ways. This was not an insta-fix...Gabriel and Charlotte worked hard to overcome Charlotte's issues, and the work they did just seemed to cement their bond. Loved how Charlotte mouthed off to Gabriel and didn't allow herself to be bulldozed by his strong personality. And Gabriel loved that, too! Loved how Gabriel kept repeating that smart girls were his catnip.The humor...Although Rock Hard deals with some serious issues, there is wonderful humor throughout. Some snarky comments, some laugh out loud funny moments, some bittersweet smiles...great balance.Bottom line - Well, it's Nalini Singh, so you know going in that the writing is stellar. The story flowed beautifully, and was realistic and thoughtful. The topic of assault was handled with sensitivity and care. I really cared about these two characters. Highly recommend.

Okay, this is review number 787 or something, so...I am essentially writing this for myself. Mainly as a reminder not to give up. What do I mean? Well, I started The Will not once, not twice, but 3 times before it finally clicked with me. Once I clicked with the book, though, it clicked in a big way.Josie, or Josephine - Having lost her beloved grandmother, she comes to the tiny, coastal town of Magdalene, Maine to settle up the estate. We get hints about Josie's past history of abuse - from her father, from an ex...But even before those hints, we know that Josie is buttoned up tight, all about control and holding herself distant from everyone and everything. Then she meets Jake, and Jake's kids, and finds all that distance melting away.Jake is a classic KA Hero. Yes, that capital "H" is on purpose. Jake fully believes in taking complete care of those who are in his life, regardless of the cost to himself. Jake runs a strip club to pay the bills, and a gym to fulfil his passion. He moves slowly with Josie, so slowly that she doesn't even see it. Loved the fact she thought she was dreaming, then realized her dreams had come true.The kids - Awesome. Ethan is adorable, Con is a young Hero in training, and watching Amber grow to recognize her worth was wonderful. Loved The Taylors, too.There is the usual baby mama drama, but Josie sorts that out. There is young love drama, and Josie sorts that out. There is other, more spoilery stuff that I don't want to give away...I can't put my finger on why I love KA's work so much. I think it is realism with just a touch of the fairy tale. And the sexy times are ever so sexy...and real. No props needed (not that there is anything wrong with kink), but yeah, you can put yourself in the middle of the scene and feel like it could, or has, happened to you. And the scenes are heartfelt and delicious.What didn't work quite as well - Josie wasn't really perfect, so I can't pin a Mary Sue on her, but she was fixing everyone, left and right. Her interference was global and non-discriminatory. And in a way, it made sense. Josie was so closed off herself, and unable to fix her issues, so she concentrated on everyone else's issues. She was very honest, let's put it that way. Classic avoidance of interpersonal relationships, she crushes for 20+ years on her boss, yet never acts on her feelings.Bottom line - I freakin' loved every little thing about this story, good and bad. I laughed until I snorted, and I cried ugly tears, sometimes within the same page. No, it isn't perfect. Yeah, you could argue that the MC's share traits with other KA MC's. I do not care. Not even a little bit. I stayed up until 3am to finish The Will. Can't even remember the last time I did that. Probably for a Rock Chick or 'Burg book. No question, I will be reading it again.

Kit is back, in more ways than one. When we join the story Kit is getting ready for a costume party at the Council, at which there will be vampires. That scene sets the tone for the whole book, really. Kit is fighting her way to a new normal. She and Damon are trying to find their way back to each other, too. In addition, Justin enlists Kit's help to locate missing loner NH's (non-humans), and someone from Damon's past re-emerges, hoping to be part of his future.What worked for me - Every. Thing.In the first 3 novels, Kit is held captive by her fears. She braves her way through some excruciating circumstances, but her fear dictates her actions. In Edged Blade, Kit is more accepting of her faults, and she is noticeably more comfortable in her own skin. She has faced the fire, and though she was burned, she is healing. She wants to heal, and acknowledges that there may be some steps backward on the journey, but she seems okay with that. As always, she is tough, and smart mouthed, and she does the right thing rather than take the easy way out. Her open admittance of her feelings for Damon was oh, so awesome. LOVE Kit.Damon has been so careful with Kit that it is making her crazy. Look out once Kit convinces him she neither wants nor needs to be handled with kid gloves. Once our boy gets on board...whew! A book and a quarter of tension will make a kitty go a bit wild! Lol! Damon shows Kit in word, in action and in deed how he feels about her. He marks her as his, and the depth of his commitment to Kit is never in question. LOVE Damon.Because Edged Blade is written by J.C. Daniels, the conflict is not one-dimensional. There is a twist I never saw coming... So well done.We learn a little more about Justin, and his feelings for Kit. And Colleen's feelings for Justin. Chang and Abraham get a lot of face time. We get just a smidgen of Doyle. The ending is a bit of a cliffhanger, but not in such a way as to leave you cursing. The missing NH's are the cliffhanger part of the story. Most of what actually happens in Edged Blade is tied up within the novel.Bottom line - Although UF is not my genre of choice, I am 100% addicted to this series. It is smart, edgy, well drawn with an interesting mythology, and beautifully flawed characters who are trying to do the right thing. J.C. Daniels (aka Shiloh Walker) does emotion better than just about anyone else out there. The story flows beautifully, moving from heart-stopping action to laugh out loud humor to believable drama without missing a beat.If you have not tried the Colbana files yet, you could probably start with Edged Blade, but do yourself a favor and start at the beginning. Excellent series. If you like Ilona Andrews' Kate Daniels or Jeaniene Frost's Cat and Bones, try this. Highly recommend

Awesome little speaker! I received this product in exchange for an honest review.The IBSound IPX7 Waterproof Bluetooth Shower Speaker has a powerful sound for such a little item. It measures about 3 inches diameter, and is about an inch high. The suction cup is also powerful, allowing the user to stick the speaker on the wall, and unstick it when finished.The speaker took about 2 hours to charge up, and runs for about 6 hours total use time. There is a handy light on the unit to let you know it is charging. The speaker's design is sleek and modern, with a cool reflective ring.Engaging the Bluetooth was effortless with my Samsung Note 3.Bottom line, this product is terrific. Great for use in and out of the shower. Great power, great look, and easy to set up. Total win!

I am a huge Cynthia Eden fan, and I have read most, if not all, of her backlist. It is always a good day when a new title is available, and Confessions has all of the normal Eden goodness.This is a second chance story. Grant and Scarlett were high school sweethearts. Grant joined the Army, became a Ranger, and as such, saw a lot of darkness. Grant didn't want to hold Scarlett back, and let her go. Ten years later, Scarlett is in deep jeopardy, and she calls Grant on his parting promise to always be there if she needed him.Confessions is the set up book for a new series, The Battling McGuire Boys. Ms. Eden seamlessly introduces all 5 of the brothers, and a sister, into the story. Given the number of players, this could have been a confusing mess. Instead, I feel like I have a good handle on the personality of each of the cast members. Good world building and background, setting up not only Confessions, but the books to follow.Grant and Scarlett are both wary, both a little world weary from their experiences. They are still incredibly attracted to each other, but their history is a looming specter. The struggle to put the past behind them and move toward a future together was so well done.  I felt their anxiety and their need for each other clearly. The conflict was believable. I thought Scarlett showed the right amount of doubt and reticence concerning the feasibility of her and Grant reuniting. Though the romance happens kind of quickly, it is believable since we have knowledge of the history of the couple.The suspense was well done, and kept me guessing almost until the end.Bottom line - I would recommend Confessions without reservation, as well as any other Cynthia Eden work. Great plots, hot romance, terrific flow...you can't go wrong!

I have a history of high blood pressure in my family, so I thought that I should begin taking my blood pressure regularly to be sure that I was healthy. I was really excited to see how easy this device is to use and thought it would be the perfect solution.The QardioArm comes in a small package that is easy to throw into your bag or briefcase if you want to transport it. I pulled it out and read the included instruction page that tells you how to download the app and how to turn on the device. One thing that got on my nerves is that the small instruction page didn’t tell me that I had to touch my device to the QardioArm to get it to work. I had to delve into the bigger instruction booklet to find out how to connect the device. I feel like that would have been easy to include on the small page that is supposed to help you set up the QardioArm quickly.Anyway, once I figured it out, using the QardioArm was very simple. You simply unwrap it to turn it on, wrap it around your arm, touch your phone to it, and press the “Start” button on the app. The reading takes about one minute. I like that the device keeps track of each of your readings so that you can easily see if your blood pressure is improving or getting worse (there is also a guest mode included if you want to let someone else use the device without it tracking their results).Overall, I think the QardioArm is a much better way to keep track of your blood pressure than lugging around a huge blood pressure monitor and writing down your results. I like that it connects directly to a device that most people already have (a smartphone) and that it is so easily portable. If you need to keep track of your blood pressure at home or on the go, you will probably enjoy this product.

When Sophie faces a threat to her safety, she immediately turns to Lex's firm for protection. It is clear someone is fixated on Sophie, and Lex is determined to keep her safe. He is also determined, after longing for her since he saved her life some 6 months ago, to take any opportunity to get closer to Sophie.Lex and Sophie had horrific childhoods, but both have channeled that into successful careers. I loved both of these characters so much, separately and together. Both so afraid of love, yet they can't deny their attraction to each other.Lex is fiercely protective of Sophie, as her attacker could be anyone. The identity of the attacker remained a mystery until the end, for me.Sophie is a strong shero, even when she is scared. She is almost brittle with anxiety, but her attitude never wavers.Bottom line - love Cynthia Eden's work, and Want Me is no exception. Strong plot, strong characters, a good mystery...Want Me is a win!

First a little background - I am 49, and coffee is a way of life for me. My natural tooth color is not a brilliant white, to begin with, so I have been trying out different products over the last few years. No, not products, really. Toothpastes, including several of the Crest line of whitening toothpastes.I have been using the Crest Pro Health HD Two Step Toothpaste for a week now. After comparing before and after pics, which I am not going to post, because that is just kind of yucky, I would say my teeth are at least 2, possibly 3, shades whiter. Noticeably whiter, as in people have remarked on it.The whitening is the reason I tried this product, no doubt. But honestly, the best thing is how clean my teeth feel, even first thing in the morning. My teeth still have that just brushed feel.I have used the Pro-Health product as per the instructions - one minute with the HD toothpaste to loosen plaque, then one minute with the Step 2, which is the whitener. The Step 2 has a peroxide base, but the taste is very mildly minty. Due to the peroxide content, I was a little concerned. I have sensitive teeth. No worries, though. I have had no problem with pain or sensitivity at all.Bottom line - The Crest Pro-Health HD Daily Two-Step Toothpaste appears to do what it advertises. If it can lighten my teeth, I feel confident in recommending the product.

First, a little background. I have 2 dogs. Both dogs shed. A LOT. So vacuum cleaners are an important part of my cleaning routine. In the interest of full disclosure, I have had a Kirby G5 for many years, and I love it more than I can say. But it is heavy. And it is a pain to switch out the attachments, and empty the not inexpensive bags. So I have been on the lookout for a bagless vacuum for the day-to-day cleaning needs. One with nifty attachments is a serious bonus. When this came up as a Vine offering, I snatched it up.I have been using this pretty much daily for the last 3 weeks, and here is what I have observed. On the first use,  I had actually been out of town for a few days, and my hubby is not as vacuum crazy as am I. So I lugged the Dirt Devil out of the box, snapped it together (this process was very quick and easy, although the set up is detailed in the manual, if you have an issue) and gave it a go. After vacuuming about a quarter of my living room (12x17), I had already emptied the dust cup three times. I had to pull clumps of dog hair down because it had gotten lodged above the cup, even though the cup was not full. I gave up, and ran the Kirby, figuring it wasn't really a fair test.The next day, and every day since, I have been able to run the Dirt Devil, averaging 1-2 dust cup drops per day. (As stated, my dogs shed A LOT. Plus they are in and out of the house all day, dragging in dust.) I feel like that is perfectly reasonable, and the cup is pretty easy to empty. It pops right out,  you carry it to the trash bin, hit the button, and the bottom drops away, allowing the dirt to fall out. I do occasionally have to grab clumps of hair from above the cup, but not often.The unit comes apart so you can carry the canister around as you use the long wand on cobwebs, or curtains, or air vents. You can attach the sweeper attachment for dusting wood-type furniture. The cloth got kind of dirty, quickly. Again, I have dogs, so this may not be an issue for some people without constant mess makers running about the home. The cover is washable, though and I like being able to dust the entertainment center with the vacuum!The upholstery attachment is awesome! Yes, the dogs are allowed on the tan couch. Both dogs are black. Just imagine... It is so easy to just slap the attachment onto the wand, run it over the furniture and watch the hair get sucked up. So much easier and less expensive than using a lint roller.I am very impressed with the suction power on this unit. After using the Kirby, my standards are pretty high in this category. Even when the dirt cup is near the full mark, the Dirt Devil performs very well.There are two things about this vacuum that make me a little crazy, which is why I gave it a 4 star rating. The cord is not in a good position. It is too close to the hose, and hard to wrap. I mean, how-on-earth-am-I-supposed-to-get-my-hand-in-the-right-position-to-complete-this hard. Secondly, the upholstery tool holder is not the right size. It is too small to house the tool properly, so I just leave it on the shelf in my closet until I need it.Bottom line - other than the two smallish complaints, this Dirt Devil is a winner. Great power, good overall design, easy to use and a really nice price point. I would recommend this product with no reservation.

Ripper takes up some few years after the Thieves series ends. Kelsey Atwood is a self-admitted lazy PI, not really exerting herself to grow her business. When a member of the shifter community approaches her to locate a missing college student, she reluctantly accepts the job. This is the beginning of a whole new world for Kelsey.Oh dear goodness, this was such a most awesome read. Kelsey is head strong, and determined. She has some daddy issues, for good reason, as it turns out. Kelsey has some self-destructive habits that she uses to self-medicate. She has amazing instincts, and a lot of heretofore untapped skills...I feel like I can't say too much without giving it all away, and I absolutely refuse to ruin your discovery of each delicious morsel of this book. A lot of life changing events happen over a narrow window of time, and it leaves Kelsey reeling, not knowing who to trust.Grayson Sloan is an interesting mix of paranormal, that I also don't want to spoil for you. He is head over teakettle for Kelsey, even before he meets her. But there are a LOT of secrets in Gray's world, dark secrets that affect Kelsey in more ways than she can possibly imagine. Gray is very straightforward about his feelings and his intentions toward Kelsey from early on. Gray learns quickly that he can't control Kelsey's actions, and he tries very hard to be as supportive as possible.Kelsey is growing into powers she didn't even realize she had, and as she does so, she learns that she has the attention of a lot of the supernatural community. And that is not a good thing.An interesting take on the Jack the Ripper story.The humor is strong in Ripper, though the book will probably be funnier if you have read the Thieves series. That said, it isn't necessary to read Thieves in order to understand the events in Ripper. Ms. Blake fills in the blanks nicely. For those of you who have read Thieves -  Some of Dev's and Dan's scenes with Kelsey are hilarious. Some are quite serious and frightening. The trio's twins, Lee and Rhys, add a lot of humor, and Neil is his usual hilarious self, especially when he is defending Chad to Kelsey.Bottom line - Ripper is an awesome read, with an incredible world and terrific mythology.  As someone who is not a big fan of UF, I absolutely adored Ripper. The conflicts were believable and the resulting actions made a lot of sense. I am a huge fan of Lexi Blake, and would highly recommend any of her titles.

I have been using this Black and Decker Thermal Coffee maker for a few weeks now. Often, I use it several times a day. I am what can be deemed as a coffee addict. Not so very long ago, I replaced my old coffee maker with one made by the Mister. I hated it, every single cup, every single day. In fact, I had stopped using it and was relying strictly on my Keurig. Not the most economical choice.The thing I hated about the Mister was the taste(always scorched) and temperature of the coffee(always scorching). I know some people prefer to have their coffee so hot as to scorch the tongue, but I am not one of them. The temperature of the B&D coffee is, with the addition of half and half, absolutely perfect. Hot, not burning, with a smooth, rich taste. And thanks to the carafe, the temperature and taste stays perfect for about 2 hours and 30 minutes. Any longer than that and some of the heat is lost.The top of the carafe twists on and off easily for cleaning and filling. I love the wide mouth, as you can get a sponge down into the carafe with no problem. I have found it easier to use a measuring cup to fill the reservoir, as I was spilling a good bit onto the counter when using the carafe for that task. I am not the most handy person, so that could be a personal issue. The unit is rather small and sleek, taking up minimal counter space. It wipes off easily. The clock is easy to set, and I love waking to my coffee already made. Another advantage, for those with vaguely OCD tendencies like myself, is once the coffee cycle is complete, the unit cuts off. No more worrying about "Did I cut off the coffee maker before I left the house?"I have tried all of the brew strengths, and have settled on Strong, although all are good. The Strong is, of course, stronger than regular, but takes less time to brew than Bold. If I am in a hurry, I use regular, because I can get 8 cups in about 8 minutes. The Strong setting takes about 12 minutes for 8 cups, the Bold setting, about 16 minutes.So bottom line - Clean lines, wide mouthed reservoir, perfect temperature, consistently smooth taste...Not a complaint in sight! I LOVE this coffee maker!

This is not my first encounter with Ms. Ryan's work. I have read several of her books, across genres. I am writing this review as a reminder to myself that her writing style really doesn't work for me. Why, you might ask? Great question, and one I have spent undue time trying to figure out.First, what did work for me - I liked Austin and Sierra. I thought they were a good fit, I liked how they were together, for the most part. I liked the extended family. The family characters are strong and each had their own voice. There was some humor.What didn't work - HERE THERE BE SPOILERS - The dialogue, almost all of it, felt off. Stilted, too formal, like something innately important was missing. This was especially true during the smexy times. Too...porn like, for want of a better term. "Oh, baby, yeah, that's what I want..." type of thing. It just left me going "Ewww".  Not sexy.Caricature characters - Austin's ex, Sierra's ex's parents, the mean customer...So very one-dimensional.  Not believable.HERE COME THE SPOILERS - BE WARNED-This book is like cliché soup. Hot tattooed alpha - check. Damaged heroine in danger - check. There are crazy ex almost-in-laws, a bat crap crazy ex girlfriend, 2 marriages in trouble, a hidden pregnancy, a died-too-young detour, a cancer scare and a secret baby. I think I missed some, but these are the clichés that immediately come to mind. Oh, oh yeah. And BDSM. I was waiting for the zombies, I swear. And the thing is, Ms Ryan called herself out on this several times in the book. (And btw, the book is only 257 pages. So just imagine....) Any one (ONE) of these many and myriad tropes woulda, shoulda, coulda been the plot. All of them jumbled up together, within the confines of 257 pages became, you guessed it, jumbled. My head hurt trying to keep up.END OF SPOILERSThe other thing, which may be realistic, but who wants too much realism in their romance? I didn't like the push-pull from Austin toward Sierra. Every time he had a crisis (refer back to the spoiler section)he pulled away from her. Sierra didn't deserve that.So why do I keep trying to read this author? I want to like her work. I like her subject matter, there are parts that are funny, I am in awe of all the storylines she tried to juggle here. Sadly, I just don't think we are a good match.Bottom line - If you like a fudge-ton of tropes all rolled into one book, with all the angst that goes with that, this title will most likely work for you. The primary characters are well done, though the secondary characters falter. This is the first of what looks to be a many book, each with its own HEA, series. No cliffhangers here. If you prefer your clichés to be one per book, you may want to pass.
