It's surpising how many very nice wallets are made that can only hold money and two or three credit cards.If you're like me, and you want a nice, leather wallet than can hold eight cards and a license, this one is worth trying.

Heart-wrenching, analytical, well-researched, non-judgemental, informative, and throroughly engaging. Required reading for every mountaineer, armchair or actual.I read this book in about three days and I would have read it straight through if time had permitted. I haven't had a book do this to me for a long while. Last book I had I couldn't put down was Andy Weil's novel, The Martian.Denali's Howl is unique in that the author's perspective is both personal and journalistic. He was there as a young boy, curious, mystified, awed by his surrounding and the work of his father, who was the Park Superintendant at the time. There's a perfect balance in this book of storyteller and story. It's free of writer ego, of unsubstantiated opinion, of heavy-handed commentary, of speculative writing. if you read Junger's The Perfect Storm, and you, as I, were jolted by Junger's ego-centric narrative, you know what I mean.I highly recommend this book. I was ready to start it over after reading the last line.One correction: Mt. Washington is in New Hampshire, not Maine.

Very disappointed that the launch pad that arrived was not the one shown in the picture. Also disappointed in packaging, launch pad fit, instructions, and the fact that all the components, engines, wadding, were not included with each model.

I used to be an Estes rocketeer when I was a kid and so it was natural for me to want to get my granddaughter into it. I bought this classic model for the same reason everyone else did, because it reminded them of the very first model they built and brought back great memories. All I can say is, I'm disappointed in the Estes brand. Instructions are minimal and in multiple languages. (I'm not an English snob but I didn't find the instructions in English very detailed.) The rocket seems less than it was back when I first got mine many years ago. My first Big Bertha had a payload section. This one does not. Rocket came bagged in a clear plastic bag and not a box. I still don't know what rocket engine to get because it wasn't obvious right off the bat in the instructions. I also think it's kind of  cheap not to sell the model and the engine and recovery wadding all together. When you buy a model, all the needed parts should be included. Lastly, my model did not come with any decals.

There's not much you complain about here with this camp light. Solidly made. Works as advertised. Decent price. Plenty of illumination for what it is. For the record, I got this at a discount in return for an honest review. The company asked for no special favors.On the plus side, it's lightweight, robust, clicks on and off with a solid connection, and is made of mostly impact resistant plastic. The battery compartment is in the bottom under a screw cap that is not weather sealed with an O-ring. By the looks of it, I would call it weather resistant but not waterproof.The light cast is your typical automotice LED hue. I would call it, not indoor warm and fuzzy. Instead, it has that alien moonlight look to it, not comfortably atmospheric but very easy to work under. The light also sort of has a hypnotic effect when you stare right at it because it has all these lenses in it; it's not so bright that it hurts your eyes when you look directly at it. What I'm trying to describe is a lantern that has been designed to throw enough light into camp to be useful but not so much light that staring at the source temporarily ruins your night vision. It's a balancing act, really.I plugged in the three fresh AA batteries and turned the light on. I left it on outside in 48 degree F. weather for 12 hours. The light looked just as strong at hour twelve as when I turned it on.The handles are ferromagnetic. Does this mean they are not stainless? No. Not necessarily. Does this mean they will rust more quickly? No, not neccessarily. Sorry I can't be more specific. Some stainless will rust over time.Bottom line. Nice camp light. Decent price.For the record, I received this item at discount in exchange for an honest review.

My granddaughter will love these. We have not yet tried them on the road but they seem to fit snugly on the frame and handlebars. Anyway, they came with two sets of batteries, very nicely packaged. It makes a nice gift item because of the packaging. Typical bicycle type of light with three settings: fast flash, slow flash, and continuous. Just click the lens once for each setting and once for the off position. There is a rubber O-ring that seals the battery compartment and the threaded cap seals tightly. Based on this, I would suspect it's pretty resitant to water intrusion. It's hard to tell what kind of seal there is between the outside of the lens and the battery compartment. The lights are held in place with an adjustable rubber strap. Included with the purchase are two replacement straps.Seems like a pretty good deal to me at the current price. ($5.95 at the time of writing this review.) In fact, it seems like an amazing deal.Some people have noted that the straps are not universal to all handlebars and bike frames and don't fit tight enough aganst the frame or handlebars. I didn't have this problem but if I did I don;t think it would be that hard to jury rig a solution.Note: I received these at a discount in return for an honest product review. No conditions were suggested or implied.

I'm not the belly pack kind of guy but this is a nice, simple, well made and comfortable carryall for a phone, keys, I.D, and cash. Zippered pouch for phone and cash. Pouch with velcro flap for keys. Another smaller pouch without a flap for, well, I don't know what, something you wouldn't care too much about if it fell out, or something that would fit snuggly, lipstick, lip balm, that sort of thing. The material is soft and durable and the elastic strap and clip are heavy duty. It has a sport feel to it and I think joggers and bicyclists will love it. It also seems to be priced right. I used to run and hated carrying anything in the pockets of sweat pants or running shorts. A belly back sure solves this problem.Full Disclosure: I was given a discount on this product in return for a product test and a review. I plan to give it to my daughter-in-law, who's an avid runner.

I received one of these as a gift to test and review. As far as comparisons go, the only other ones I have ever used are the ones you used to get for free from the airlines when you traveled overseas. They don't give anything away for free on airlines anymore, unless you're in first class. Anyway, compared to the ones from the airlines, this is a lot softer and a lot bigger. It also has a sewn in nose piece for added comfort. You get a little light bleeding though around the nose but after awhile of wear I figure the mask will mold itself to your face. It's very soft. Very comfortable. I can safely recommend it for people who sleep with these things.

I received one of these grinders at reduced price in exchange for an honest review and some honest feedback regarding the product's value and functionality. Turns out, it's a very nice spice and/or coffee grinder with an all stainless steel housing and grinding arm and a set of ceramic grinding discs or burrs. Perfect size. Not too small. Not too big. Solid feel. For the money as advertised ($15), it's an incredible bargain. I've considered buying much more expensive grinders at the local coffee emporium but never wanted to pay so much for a manual hand grinder. Some of them were $60, and I can't imagine them being any more functional than this one. Then again, I love stainless in the kitchen.You can adjust the grinder to whatever size grind you want, although, as someone else mentioned, trying to get too powdery or fine a grind might cause damage to the ceramic parts inside. Also, when I took the grinder out of the box, took it apart, and sniffed the inside, it had a distinct manufacturing smell to it, like a new car smell. My advice is to wash the thing in the dishwasher, or thoroughly in the sink, before using. I'm probably stating the obvious here so I apologize if I'm insulting anyone's intelligence.Botttom line, in my opinion, this is an awesome coffee or spice grinder for the money.It's also the very first ceramic burr grinder I've ever used, and so I have to wonder how practical it is to use for different spices AND coffee. Will the ceramic cutting components take on the flavors of the grounds over time? Isn't ceramic somewhat porous? Not knowing the answer to this, and not wanting to risk mixing flavors of crushed red pepper and Kona coffee beans in my shiny new grinder, I plan to use it for coffee and spices that can go with coffee, spices like mint, cardamom, cinnemon, vanilla. Even if the flavors don't completely wash out of the ceramic, I'm sure whatever flavors remain will add depth to any cup of coffe made from the grounds.

Wife loved this. She had bought one from another company a while back and last night compared the two. See photo below.This spiral slicer did a much better job creating spiral slices, and it came with a little brush for cleaning. As we all know, cleaning these types of kitchen devices can be a chore. The little brush is a nice touch.In the photo: The spiral cucumber slices on the right (from the other brand) are less solid and formless than the ones cut with the The Very Healthy Spiral Slicer Spiralizer (on the left). The ones cut with this spiral slicer are larger and actually have the desired shape. Both slices were cut from the same cucumber.The slicer on the right in the photo (the other brand) has a cap that locks in place while The Very Healthy Spiralizer does not. You would think it would be better for the cap to lock into place. Actually, no. This slicer held the product and spun it better than the slicer with the locking cap did.For the record, I received this as a gift to test and review. The company asked for nothing other than an honest review.[Photo Description: This Product, The Very Healthy Spiral Slicer Spiralizer is on Left; Competing Brand is on Right.]

This is the second one of these I've installed on my truck. First one lasted about five years. It's a seamless fit with the OEM version. I have to figure they're identical although I can't say for sure. The lock lever on both the one's I've purchased would not work the door lock properly. I don't know if it's because the throw isn't long enough or because something inside is hanging up. I don't know if it's the Dorman door handle mechanism or the door itself. I've given up trying to figure it out. In fact, this truck has been nothing but trouble for 15 years. 2000 Chevy c/k2500 crew cab with 99,000 miles. Ten to fourteen mpg if I'm lucky. Crappy brakes. What haven't I replaced? And now the tranny is giving me problems. Bottom line: I'm glad the door lock doesn't work. I'm hoping someone comes along a steals the damn thing.

I'm going to compare the iGearPro 8GB Digital Audio Recorder to the Sony-ICDP620-Digital-Recorder, which I bought four or five years ago for about $75 and is now (at the time of writing this review) available here at Amazon for about $164.Right out of the box, you'll like the solid feel to this little iGearPro recorder. It's all metallic, and it's small. It has as solid a feel to it as my Sony recorder, maybe even more solid.It's more compatible with Windows and Mac than my Sony.It has 16x more memory than my Sony.It has a USB rechargeable battery while the Sony requires two AAA batteries.The controls, while minimal, are so much easier to use than the controls on the Sony. (I have, for the most part, retired my Sony to the trash bin.)Neither device accommodates an external microphone.My iGearpro played my recorded voice back in mono on only one ear bud. I don't know id this is a problem with the ear bud, or if the device only records in mono. The device does have two microphones. (I'll test this later and get back to you.)Both the Sony and the iGearPro could pick up voices from 15' away. I thought the sound quality of the iGearPro was indistinguishable from the playback quality of my Sony.Sony has more additional controls for dictating than the iGearPro, but they're so hard to use they're basically wasted.Neither one is really a look-free device. In other words, you have to see the buttons to know what you're pushing. That said, the Sony being larger, it's probably a little easier to use when moving between different recordings or sessions.In terms of just starting and stopping a recording, the iGearPro is much easier to use, one push on the record button to start, two pushes to stop.Neither device is very good for recording music a distance.Sony ICD620 - $164.00iGearPro 8GB AVR - $25.50Full disclosure: I received one of these free to test and review. The company asked for nothing other than an honest review.[Update:] My earbuds came damaged or with one side not working. I tested them in an ipod and I had only one ear bud working. But given that the ear buds have a stereo 1/8" mini-plug, it's assumable that the device plays back in stereo. Also, because it has two microphones, one on each side of the device, I think it may actually record in a kind of virtual or simulated stereo.

I received one of these free to test and review. It's like the 5th power bank I've received or ordered, and it was one of my favorites until I lost it. It's around here somewhere, but dang if I know where, which is something to consider if you're thinking about buying one of these. I'll explain in a minute.As all other reviewers have noted, this is a sleek, ultra-thin, battery bank charger for your mini-USB connectible device. Because it's so thin, it can't accommodate a full USB connector. Instead, it uses a mini- to mini- cable for power bank to device charging and a standard USB to mini-USB cable for charging itself. A single cable with two mini-USB plugs and a standard USB plug is included with the battery bank.This thing was just a tad too long to fold into one side of my wallet, nor did I really want to carry it there because I worried about bending it, crushing it, or getting it wet. If you saw my wallet or followed me around for a day you'd understand my concern.I carried it in my breast pocket, which is where it was when it disappeared. Trust me, this thing is thin, light, sleek -- and slippery. I was replacing the inside door handle in my truck, going in and out of my garage and basement, bending over tool boxes, cursing General Motors under my breath while wrestling with the inside door panel and it's power plugs; one minute the power bank was there, the next it was gone. Dang, I really like this thing.So, word of caution: It's easy to lose because of all the things you'll like about it, namely, its size.

I got this toy organizer for free from the company in order to test and review it for Amazon. They asked for no special consideration other than an honest review.My first reaction when I took it out of the bag was that it didn't look like much. The bag is made from a sturdy material but it seems kind of small, and the quality of the suction cups don't appear to be as rugged or functional as, say, the ones you'd find on a mobile device mount for your car. I then read some of the reviews on Amazon and there were complaints about the suction cups not holding. I didn't have this problem. With an empty bag, the suction cups held fine for me on my fiberglass shower wall. I then gave the organizer to my wife's coworker, who has two little kids and two other shower organizers -- my granddaughter is a little too old for toys in the tub.My friend's coworker likes this organizer and says it's better than her others. She says the suction cups hold fine for her and continue to hold. She likes the hooks for washcloths, which her other organizers don't have. I asked her if she thought it was worth the price and she said, yes.

I was offered one of these to test and review and jumped at the chance. I have three vehicles. 2000 Chevy K2500. 2008 Chevy One Ton 15-Passenger Van, 1999 Acura 3.2 TL. So far, I've just had it in the Van. Do a Google search for the OBDII socket location for your vehicle. Plug in, download app, hit the connect button. It's that simple. Wait for the data dump. Good graphics in the Android App. This is a very useful Bluetooth device at a reasonable price. I can recommend this for gadget freaks, backyard mechanics, car and truck nuts, and nerds who generally want more info than they probably need.

I really like this briefcase/bag. It's masculine and well made. It has a great vintage look to it. The buckles you see in the photo are attached to magnetized button snaps, so you have the quick-snap open/close option and also the adjustability of the buckles. You have another two magnetized button snaps holding the flap itself in place. All the leather is thick and of a very nice quality and the brass rings are heavy duty. There is one zippered pouch on the back of the outside of the briefcase. This would be a good place for a map, phone, airplane tickets, anything you might want quick access to. Flip up the leather flap and you'll find a heavy duty zipper. Open the zipper and you have an inner area divided in half by another zippered pouch that can just fit a stack of 8-1/2" by 11" paper. A Mead 10-1/2" x 8" college Neatbook-Notebook slides right in and zippers up easily. The main inner sections of the briefcase are long enough and wide enough for legal-size 8-1/2" x14" papers. A FedEx Priority or Express Mailing envelope is too big to fit. On one side of the middle zippered main pouch is an open section with small organizer pouches for pens and small pads; on the other side is another open section and another small, zippered pouch area. The latter would be good for phone, small tablet, power bank charger, recorder, etc.Full Disclosure: I received one of these as a gift for test and review purposes. The company asked for no special favors in return.Honestly, I really like this bag/briefcase. It's well made and priced competitively. If you like this style of briefcase, I think you will be very happy.

For the record, I received this as a gift for testing and review purposes. The company asked for no special favors in return.As others have mentioned, this is a nice, little backpack, with a "cute" color scheme. I know it's cute because wife says it is. Coincidentally, she had been looking for a little backpack to use when we go hiking or on long walks. She had been looking for an alternative to her purse, which she carries everywhere, and which was something I had been giving her a hard time about. Why? Because she's always telling me to watch it while she goes to the bathroom, or "Don't forget to lock the doors of the truck, because her purse is in there." And I'm like: "Why did you bring your purse? We're eighty miles from the nearest store." Or she'll ask me to keep an eye on her purse when it's sitting on our restaurant table six inches away from my right hand. How can I not keep an eye on the purse when it's right in front of my face? But I digress...She likes this backpack. The pack is light, but made from quality materials, and it has padded straps. There is plenty of room for books, papers, a laptop, and it has a nice zippered pouch on the inside and two side pockets for water bottles. It's perfect for my wife because she can dump the essential contents of her purse into the zippered pouch and carry a sweater and/or windbreaker and water. I wouldn't put keys or anything metallic and sharp into the zippered pouch area. Phone, wallet, money, makeup, divorce lawyers contact information, stuff like that.Because the backpack doesn't have a belt attached to it, I would not recommend it for someone who is doing serious mountain climbing. For the same reason, if you work as a bicycle or motorcycle delivery person on busy metropolitan streets, you'll probably want a pack you can secure to your torso at multiple points. All of its cuteness won't do you much good if the pack slides sideways while you're trying to avoid a bus or a rock slide.Anyway, my wife likes it, and that's all that matters.

I took one star off because I think these glasses (at $5 apiece) are a little expensive, and I took a half star away because I think they could be a little thicker, particularly around the rims. That means I"m giving them 3.5 stars and rounding up to 4-stars using the clickable header above.You want the truth, these are a ton better for wine or cocktails than using the real cheap plastic throwaway cups you buy at the dollar store. We use those, too, and we wash them by hand in the sink so we're not completely wasteful. But you only get a few wash cycles out of the cheap plastic cups, and even after two wash cycles, you're starting to get suspicious about cleanliness.These cups have some major attributes for the beach, pool, camping, boat, etc.:1. They're manufactured in the USA (YAY!)2. They're perfectly clear, so you can tell if they're dirty.3. They're dishwasher safe (top rack) so you don't have to worry about them melting or deforming. I don't have a pool and don't usually bring a dishwasher camping, but this is still an attribute.4. Impact resistant and BPA-free plastic.5. Ergonomic. As others have said, nice thumb hold.6. Wine does look good in them.7. Way more classy than the red plastic cup.Lastly, Govino advertises these glasses as "Wine glasses," and this implies that they're not for children. Just to be on the safe side, and as a word of caution, I do think the rims are on the thin side for children. Kids are often jabbing themselves in the mouth with their juice cups, or running and drinking. They could cut their lips with these.[Note: I received a package of these for free to test and review. There were no expectations for a positive review requested or implied.]

I have three other mop and broom holders so it's not hard for me to make some comparisons between this one and the others.First off, all three work by the same basic principle. You slide the handle into the notch with an upward motion and the broom or mop handle is held in place by gravity and friction. That's about it for similarities because each holder has its own design for doing this. Of the ones that I have, this one is the best. It's the only one that  has rubber on the movable lever arms that hold the handle in place. It's the only one with hooks in addition to the lever arms. It's the only one with a reinforced aluminum mounting bar (the others are all plastic). And it's the only one with good spring action.The holder comes with two stainless screws and two sheet rock anchors. Personally, I would not mount anything like this in sheet rock. Eventually, you will put more weight on this rack than you should, and the anchors will pull out of the wall. My advice, for what it's worth: if you're not mounting it directly into solid wood, use a backing board that will span the framing studs behind the sheet rock. I know, I"m probably stating the obvious.It's not the sexiest or most exciting item you'll buy this year, but it will get the job done.I can't comment on value except to say/repeat that it is the best of the four that I own. It's nice when a company tries hard to make something better.For the record, the seller gifted me one of these mop and broom holders to test and review. They asked for no special favors in return.

Not much more I can add to what has already been said about this cable. I like Foxnovo products, and while I got this free to test and review, I owe nothing to the company. Anyway, it's up to par with everything else I've ordered or been given free to test and review from the company. They stand by their products, and seem to stick to high quality manufacturing and engineering. This is a good dual purpose cable. I doubt it will do you much good if you don't have an iPhone or other Lightening connectible device.

This is a powerful, precision engineered battery pack for USB charging of mobile devices that require four different types of plugs. I won't rehash what the manufacturer states on the product page except to say you can trust Foxnovo. The battery charger comes nicely packaged and includes a very sleek cloth carrying case for battery pack and accompanying charging harness and cables. I have charged my Android cell phone once from a nearly complete discharge and just plugged it in again. Battery pack still shows a 100% charge, four blue lights.It takes a while to get this battery to full charge because it holds so much. Don't rush it. When you get it in the mail, put it on charge right away. It may take a few hours.With the aluminum alloy housing, the high quality construction, and the company's guarantees of overcharge and overheat protection, the device has an Apple products look and feel to it. It matches my iMac and my wife's Macbook in color and styling. It fits right in on the desk. However, it's not really a desktop device. I use it as such because all my USB ports are taken with drives and other accessories, and I like to be able to grab my phone and battery pack and go when I need to go and not have to worry about leaving with a half-charged phone.I have another power pack/USB charger, but it does not have anywhere near this capacity. My other one has some interesting features, like a recorder and a flashlight. However, it's more of an emergency, one time charge only kind of device. This thing will charge two devices simultaneously, and it will be able to charge multiple devices on one charge. How many? I'm not sure. But I started charging my phone when I started this review. Phone was down to 10% and it is now at 85%. The Foxnovo FP10 is still giving me four blue lights.I got one of these devices for test and review purposes but I have no problem recommending it to people who want on-the-go device charging from a small battery pack. It's well made and good-looking. The carrying case is a very nice bonus.

Would I have bought one of these things on Amazon if I hadn't been offered one to test and review? Probably not, because I didn't quite know what it was until I had it in my hand. I thought it was a water bottle that floated and had a light in it. On the product page, the seller calls it a Solar Camping LED Lights Lantern. On the box, it's called a Drifting Bottle Light, a Universal Solar Multi-Bottle, and a Drift Bottle. What this is, in fact, is a waterproof, floating, storage bottle, with a light and a solar and USB rechargeable battery.Now if you're a camper or a kayaker, or, perfect, a kayak camper or canoeist, you know the value of waterproof storage. You also know the value of having light on the picnic table or near the campfire when you don't make camp as early as you originally planned and end up having to fix dinner after dark. And, most important, you know the value of packing light. Here you have a collapsible waterproof storage container that floats, has a light on it that can be recharged by a USB connector or the sun, and a handle for hanging on a tree limb, tent pole, or snap line.It's made out of silicone, so it's soft, and it comes in a variety of bright colors, although the pink that I got isn't the most vibrant. The screw-top lid houses the battery, charging port, solar panel, and on/off switch, which controls two levels of brightness or a flashing light for emergency use. Care should be taken with the silicone material as silicone is susceptible to certain chemicals and excessive heat.This is a great gift for an avid camper, kayaker, backpacker, or small boat enthusiast. It's a terrific, multi-function waterproof storage container for your cell phone, emergency supplies, first aid stuff, or all of the above. When not in use, it can be compressed to a fifth of its normal size. What you don't want to use it for is carrying liquid.As I said, I received this item for test and review purposes; there were no expectations for a positive review requested or implied.

1:18 Mins When I first got mine in the mail I thought it was broken because the ball joint wasn't already in the socket. The instructions showed it pre-mounted in the socket. The instructions also stated that the fist step in the assembly was to mount the base, ball, and socket part of the mount into the actual phone cradle part of the mount. On my unit, this part was already attached. Anyway, I contacted the company by email and they immediately answered and told me to just push the ball into the threaded socket. I was dubious because of the size of the ball but it went in just fine. Here's the thing, though: If you get yours in the same state of assembly as mine, follow these steps:1. Slide the nut, threaded side down, over the ball so the threads are facing the threaded socket in the base. The nut will only thread onto the socket while facing in this one direction. Look at the nut closely. On one side, the threads go all the way to the edge, on the other side they don't. The side with the threads all the way to the edge is the side you want facing the socket.2. While the nut is over the ball, and while the base is firmly situated on a solid table, push the ball into the socket. You might want to keep the protective plastic on the suction cup while you do this. Wallah! You're in business. (See Video.)Anyway, I love the way the ratchet drive holds the phone in place, It's solid, and variable, so you can uses it with all size phones.This is a nice car mount for a phone. I have no problem giving it 5-stars.For the record, I was sent one of these to test and review.

Chalktastik Liquid chalk markers. What's to complain about here? The markers arrived on time. I followed the directions for priming, tried them on my glass sliding door, and wallah! Super vibrant colors. Then the big test. Do they wipe off cleanly? Yes they do. Do they create airborne chalk dust? No they don't. So far so good. Do the kids like them? Yes, kids LOVE them.So, regarding the manufacturer's claims on the product page, we're batting at least .500 right out of the box. The only things I can't confirm are the two claims about longevity and non-toxicity. I haven't been using them for very long to be able to determine the first, and now way, no how am I going to taste these things or let my dog chew one up. For that matter, I don't care what anybody says about something being non-toxic, don't let your kids lick these chalk markers, and don't let them use the markers on their skin or bodies. IT SAYS RIGHT ON THE PACKAGE THEY ARE NOT TO BE USED ON POROUS SURFACES. What does that tell you? It should tell you that if your kids use them on your white, $2000 couch, you may have a hell of a time getting out the bright. vivid, vibrant colors. (Btw, if you do get them on hands and fingers, the liquid chalk washes right off with soap and water. On a wooden deck or porch, no. The porous wood will absorb the liquid chalk.)That caveat aside, these are great colors, and they are a lot of fun to play with on a glass slider or other hard, non-porous surface, even a chalk board. I gave hen 5-stars because I really do love them for the colors and the easy clean-up.For the record, I was sent a package of these to test and review for Amazon. No favors were asked for or expected.

Honestly, when I got this thing in the mail to test and review I didn't know what it was. I took it out of the box and thought it looked well made. It came with a short USB charging cable and a multi-function USB to device charging cable, and it had an 8gb micro drive in it. A quick scan of the box told me it was a voice recorder, multi-device charger, and flashlight. I tried to turn it on and it was dead. No biggie. I plugged it into my laptop for a charge and it quickly registered power. It has indicator lights that tell you its charge state in percentages at 25% increments. Getting it to full charge took some time but I liked seeing the progress of charge on its indicator lights. I mean, my kindle doesn't even tell me what the charge state is, only when its fully charged.The directions for this thing are kind of weak. Obviously, English is not the first language of the person who wrote them. Fortunately, the device is easy to figure out. As soon as it was charged, I tried the flash light. It's a pretty decent light in a pinch. Don't try to scare off Cujo with it. Next test...charging. I charged my Samsung Android, a Kindle, and my i-Pod, but not without recharging the device in between the latter two. It actually charged my i-Pod and still showed 100% charge afterwards. But when I plugged in my phone it immediately went to a blinking 75% charge, which probably means it took somewhere between 25% and 37% of the device's power to charge my completely dead i-Pod. I charged both my phone and the i_Pod on one charge and still had power left in the device. Phone had about 25% charge in it at the time. Given that bit of info, I'd say you can charge two, maybe three i-Pods on a single charge. Maybe two mobile phones if they don't have huge batteries in them. For the record, the device kept turning off before my phone actually indicated it was fully charged. [Update I've been using this for a week now and I have to correct the above. It will only charge one maybe two i-pods. And, sitting all by itself unplugged in a room of 65-70 degrees F., it does self-discharge some. I had it fully charged and left it for a week on my nightstand and it lost 25-50% of it's charge. When I plugged it into my nearly-dead android phone, it would not fully charge it, only bring it to about 50%.The two outlets are power in and power out. Near as I can tell, using one disables the other. You can't have the thing charging a device and have it be charging at the same time. I say this because I just plugged it into my iMac and when I did the phone stopped charging. It's one or the otherThe voice recorder is pretty good. Recordings are in WAV format. On a Mac, open with Quicktime, not iTunes. Simply plug in the device, wait for it to show up on your desktop, open the drive, and you'll find two folders. Open the Recordings folder and right click the WAV file, then choose Open With Quicktime. The second folder is a utilities/preferences folder and it contains an .exe file. Eject the drive before disconnecting. I haven't tried it on my PC but I'm sure it's a simple process with Windows Media Player given they're WAV files.[Update: The recorder is very sensitive and it does not have a limiter in it. If you are recording loud noises, like a concert, it will come out distorted unless you are very far away. To figure out how best to record those higher decibels you'll have to do some experimenting.]I'm not sure I would have purchased this device had I not had a chance to use it. And at first, I thought, why? But I spend a lot of time off the grid in far off woodsy places. Granted, you don't have unlimited charging capacity, but if you're only going to be off the grid for a couple or three days, this device gives you a lot of options. I can see it being really useful to a backpacker or a sailor in a small boat. Too bad it's so fragile. According to the directions, you don't want to get it wet, don't want to drop it or treat it too harshly; don't get it too cold or too hot, either. If you plan on taking into a hostile environment, you should get a waterproof case or bag for it.In fairness, I'm taking off a star because the instructions are so limited, and also because of all the caveats about taking care of it.All in all, I really like it, and I plan on keeping it with me. I can't wait for a friend with an iPhone to tell me his phone's almost dead. I'll whip this thing out and say: "I'll charge it for you."

I received this product in the mail in exchange for an honest review, so here goes.It's a solid, well made, selfie stick with a handle-mounted bluetooth button and your typical phone holder attachment at the other end. It folds up conveniently and I would highly advise storing it and transporting it in the fully collapsed position. Like all sticks, it has a telescoping pole. Once this section of the stick is bent, your selfie stick is pretty much done for. With this stick in the collapsed position, the phone mount and the telescoping portion of the stick are completely protected.The instructions are minimal but the device doesn't require much in the way of setup. Hit the button on the stick to turn it on. Wait for the flashing blue light. Make your phone discoverable in bluetooth mode. Choose the device's handle (mine was something like winnona) and you're done. Put the phone in camera mode, aim, hit the button, and wallah! You're a Twitter star.Bear in mind, this bluetooth device is a recently manufactured item, which means it may not work right with older, smart-challenged phones. I have a Samsung SCH-S720C. My phone - compared to an iPhone or a Galaxy - is like comparing a Willys Jeep to a Cadillac Escalade. The phone linked up great, but when I hit the bluetooth shutter button on the stick, my phone went into settings mode. The bluetooth button would not trigger the shutter. My wife's phone is a ZTE and slighter newer than mine. It also linked up fine, but when you hit the bluetooth button, the first thing the phone did was zoom in one notch. Second time you hit the button it snapped the shutter. This may or may not be something you can change inside the phone. I tried to find a settings or preferences window for the camera in my phone and failed, and there's nothing in the instructions for the stick to get you through this problem. Bottom line, the stick may not be backwards compatible with older smart phones. Doesn't mean it's not a great product. Just means that if you have an older phone running an older, outdated OS, you'll want to do some research before you buy.

This is a nice looking charger. Solidly built, made out of high quality, impact resistant plastic. It looks good on a desk because it has a modern design and a stand-up base. The power cord is also solid and although not particularly long should get you to where you need to go, which, for most of us, is a power strip/surge protector under the desk. The manufacturer put the converter in the minitower instead of having it as part of the power cord. I really don't like it when you need two sockets worth of space in order to plug in a bulky converter/power cord. Not the case here. Thank you GRDE.You will notice this thing has a tendency to charge your device quickly. This is because it's pumping out a maximum of 2.4A per port using imbedded communication protocols that intelligently determine optimum charging criteria. It's kind of a detection/feedback thing, and it means you're suppose to be getting the optimum charge for whatever device your using. Not all devices like the same charge. Samsung and Apple use their own protocols and like a 2.4A charge at some specified voltage. This device detects these things and adjusts accordingly. Supposedly. All I can say is I've charged two Android phones, a Kindle, and an Ipod without problems.

This is a very nice light. Well constructed and attractively priced. I was sent one of these for testing and review purposes but I assure you that getting it for free had nothing to do with me giving it 5-stars. I honestly can find nothing wrong with it. It's a great camp light for the money. Would be great for boating, backpacking (it's very light), in a truck camper, tag-along, on or over a picnic bench (suspend it from a branch or tent pole). Use it while working under a hood, in the bilge, or around a campfire, you name it. The device in the closed/collapsed position is for traveling or storage. When you slide open the top part it clicks the light on, which has a warm, easy-on-the-eyes hue. There are plenty of other LED camp lanterns out there, some with dimmer switches. I have not tried them all. In fact, I have not tried anything other than the old, noisy, white gas Coleman lanterns and the problem prone 6V battery lanterns. This, for the money, puts all those to shame. Anyway, if you need a light like this, go ahead and buy with confidence. You can return it, because the company offers a 100% satisfaction guarantee against fault or defect. One final note, there's a compass built into the top. It's a nice touch, and maybe, just maybe, if you're lost in the woods, and the light and compass are your last resort, they just might help you get home. But if you head into the woods with a couple of Snickers bars and only this lantern and its built-in compass to guide you, I feel sorry for you.

I was offered one of these lights for test and review purposes and jumped at the chance. Company asked for no special favors in return, just a fair review, so here goes.It's not very rugged. You'll notice this right out of the box. It's contained in a thin, hard plastic housing. But the design is cool. It uses a pressure or friction fit between the actual light and the light's mounting bracket. It's effective, although I have to wonder if it will be tight enough to hold all its positions under all conditions, e.g., outdoors in the cold winter months, when things tend to shrink.It would have been nice if they had put an o-ring or gasket in the battery compartment. However, the seal between the two plastic halves that comprise the battery compartment is very tight. I mean, it's tight enough to keep out rain water.As I said, the light itself pressure fits into it's plastic mounting bracket. The bracket has one screw hole for mounting against a wall. I mounted it on the column holding up my porch roof. As soon as I approach the bottom of the stairs, the light comes on. As soon as I open the front door from inside, the light comes on. It's bright enough to light my porch stairs and front door area, but not so bright that it blinds you when you look directly at the lenses. It casts what I would call a warm bluish light.There's a 3-position switch inside the battery compartment. Off-On-Auto. I've been using auto. Given where the switch is located, and given the somewhat flimsy plastic housing and its tight fit, it's not something you want to change frequently. It just seems to me the more you open and close the housing, the greater the chance of breaking it.I know I have been critical about its construction, but I like this light and plan to buy at least two more. Once you put one up, you'll think of a bunch of other places to use them. Like inside the garage or in a closet that isn't wired for a light. Mount it high on the wall and you won't even know it's there until it comes on.Another cool thing about the pressure fit, you can just reach up and pull out the actual light part and take it with you as a spot or flash light.

This is the second IBSound product I've been given to test and review. The first was a waterproof, bluetooth shower speaker, and I'm happy to report the speaker continues to function without issues. I have no doubts I will get plenty of use out of this charger as well.This is a plug-in-and-use device. It's solidly built. Nothing rattles when you shake it. There's a pistil-grip finish to the outlet end of it, which is a nice touch. Unobtrusive and clean-looking. It's a dual USB port device -- charging cable(s) not included -- that is advertised as a dual 2.1A @5V charging device. For the record, my device is stamped 5V 2.1 A, but the face of it where the two ports are has one port stamped 2.1A and the other port stamped 1.0A. See the photos. (Sorry for the quality but I'm taking these pics with my phone.)Obviously, the 1.0A charging port is going to take longer to charge whatever it is your charging. Probably about twice as long. On the other hand, if you have an older phone, etc., with an older battery, and the battery doesn't reach full charge at 2.1A, you might see if you can get it to fully charge at 1.0A. Sometimes this works and sometimes it doesn't .Meanwhile, it's possible that the IBSound sample I received is an outdated model, because if you look at a close up of the charging device shown on the product page you will not see the 2.1A/1.0A stamps that I have on mine.I took a star off for this even though I'm happy with the two "different" charging ports. You may want to check this when you take yours out of the box. If you have modern devices, phones, laptops, Kindles, tablets, you may want the two 2.1A charging ports, and you should get it, because that's what the company says you're buying.Here's a little tip. The device doesn't have a protective cap on it -- and neither do the ports on your laptop, phone or tablet -- but if you tend to throw this in a dirty glovebox like I do, and you want to keep dirt from getting into the ports, just use a plastic bottle cap. It's an almost perfect fit. (See photo.)

I'm giving this item 3.7 stars. It probably deserves 5-stars, but what do I know about these sort of things? I'm a guy who works outside and isn't big on cremes, lotions, or for that matter, grooming. My hands look more like canned hams. My wife uses lotions, but she doesn't really like oily or greasy things. This lotion is oily. I mean, it says "OIL" right in the title, so one would expect it to be, you know, oily.My pump nozzle didn't work. I primed the living daylights out of it and all I got for my trouble was a sore palm, which I then treated with the Rosehip oil. Did I mention it's oily?Seriously, I have rough hands and this oil softened them up immediately. I don't particularly think about having soft hands but if I did I would use this more often. In fact, I plan on adding this stuff to my tackle box when I go fishing, see how it works in terms of making my hands more leathery and useful, like when I'm paddling the canoe around, or chopping wood. If it doesn't attract blackflies or mosquitos, I think I'm going to like it. I wish the dispenser nozzle worked.The Lavender Oil, well, that's just not a very macho thing to admit to using, so I'm not going to mention it, except to say, that I just took a strong whiff of the bottle and it helped clear my sinuses. It comes with an eye dropper and I'm guessing you use this stuff in the bath. I haven't taken a bath since 1956.Given my review, you're probably wondering why I ordered this product. Truth is, I didn't. It was sent to me for review purposes, with no expectations expressed or implied. The sellers asked for nothing but an honest review in return for the free sample.

I bought this and the rest of the set as a wedding gift for my friend's son and daughter-in-law. I never got a thank you note (kids, right?) but I did hear back from the parents who said the kids loved them. I had had the items drop shipped so I never got the chance to see them. But just the other day my wife ordered the mug to give as a present to her boss. It arrived today.It's bigger than I thought it would be, and it's very authentic-looking. I really like it. Would I drink from it? Hell, no. It's made in China and the paint is brightly colored. It probably has uranium or polonium in it. I'm kidding, sort of. I mean, it doesn't glow in the dark or pick up transmission from outer space, but it would have been nice for the company to have included a written guarantee stating that the product is free of lead and other harmful materials. It's also square, like the tardis, so drinking from one side will leave you with a lap full of your favorite beverage.

The manufacturer sent me a pair off these gloves for review purposes, and when they arrived, my wife immediately latched onto them. She works in an office and her hands and fingers get cold and achy when she's using her computer, especially in winter. These are absolutely perfect for that type of work. Just look at the picture and you can tell what to expect in terms of coverage. Good coverage over the wrist and palms but with open ends at the fingertips. As far as the material and stitching are concerned, don't think of it as opera attire. However, the material feels durable and functional. I think they'll hold up well. There is an elastic quality to these, and when I have them on my hand, tight as they are in mediums, they tend to hold my hand into a naturally relaxed position, in other words, hand curved naturally as if it were holding a small ball.I seriously doubt a pair of gloves is going to cure any one of arthritis, especially rheumatoid arthritis. I'm over 60, and my fingers are gnarled and misshapen from years of outdoor work on the ocean and martial arts training, but they don't hurt. If your hands hurt, I don't think you should expect anymore than modest relief from these gloves. But keeping your hands warm and relaxed and making sure you have good blood flow is always important. I think a pair of these gloves, fitting snugly but not so tight that they restrict blood flow, can be very beneficial. I plan on buying another pair for myself now that my wife has confiscated these for herself.For reference, I usually wear large gloves and have room to spare. I can fit into a medium rubber dish washing glove with some difficulty. My wife has very small hands and she thought the mediums were a good fit for her. You may want to choose your size accordingly.Although I have never tried any other glove like this for comparison (other than those I have made by myself by cutting of the fingertips of wool gloves), this is a completely honest review and no effort was made by the company to sway me one way or the other.

Full disclosure: I was offered one of these devices for review purposes and have been using it in a small house in the north woods of Maine for over four weeks. The seller asked for no special favors in return, only an honest review. So, here goes...These types of devices aren't easy to review. I mean, how can you tell it's really working? It's not like rodents are going to leave you a hospitality card on their way out the door. "Loved the instant oatmeal in the cupboard, the half PB&J your kid left behind the couch, and the boxes of tissue paper, but that annoying ringing in my ears the whole time I was here really irritated the hell out of me and my family. We'll never come back to your establishment." Signed, Red. S.I have a small vacation home in the woods of Northern Maine and that's where I decided to test the Hoont Electronic Rodent and Bug Repellent. I drove up after being away for about 5 weeks, just after a big snowstorm, when there was about 4' of the white stuff already on the ground. The house was completely covered in snow and I had to shovel and snowblow my way in. When I backed into the driveway I was greeted by two chipmunks who thought they owned the place. Remember the squirrel that terrorized Chevy Chase and his family in the movie, Christmas Vacation? Yeah, like that. Only these were outside. They hadn't been inside. But that did not stop them from running around my house, under my deck and porch and attached shed and charging me as if I were the intruder. One of them climbed a snow bank and for a second I thought he was going to launch himself into my face.When I got in the house, I was greeted by a few spiders. We typically get a lot of spiders and ants, big and small. Fish eating spiders can get pretty big and fearsome looking. It was still a little early for the big fish spiders and carpenter ants.I plugged in the device and got to work on the house. The next day, my two "chip punks" were running from tree to tree about ten feet away from the house. The following week they were gone. I have no idea if the device had anything to do with their departure, or if they just didn't like me.The following week I still had spiders. The weeks after, still spiders. Week four, I detected a noticeable difference in the number of spiders. No spiders in the tub, whereas, the three weeks prior, I was greeted by two or three in the tub every weekend.The big test will be ants. I haven't had any indoor issues with mice or chipmunks, so, other than the anecdote above, it's hard to say what, if any, rodents the device is actually repelling, but every year we have major ant problems. I'll post back here when I have something further to report.Structurally, mechanically, the thing appears flawless. It has been running solid for over four weeks. You can't hear anything unless you put your ear to it, then you hear a couple of clicks. Two indicator lights tell you it's working.I wish I had something more definitive to say. I hate poisons, traps, etc., love animals in general and don't want to hurt them, but the interior of a house is man's domain, and chipmunks, mice, bats, etc., have their domain. If this Hoont Electronic Repellent device can work even a fraction as well as the manufacturer claims, I'm all for it, because it will keep me from having to kill things.

Bought two of these switches in a single year. Won't last through a winter. If there is any risk whatsoever of this float switch being frozen, take it out of the boat or you're just going to be buying another one. If the issue isn't ice, it's oil, or diesel fuel, or bilge cleaner, or whatever is in your bilge that's not water. Another problem I noticed: If the bilge switch is inactive for a long time, FAIL! If you have a boat that's running frequently, and the switch is cycling on and off a lot, that's good for this switch. Keep it moving, keep it free of contaminants, and it will do well. I had an oil line burst in my boat at the dock. Shut the pump off, cleaned the bilge, tried the pump switch: FAIL! I had the switch ice up this winter. Brand new switch. Maybe triggered twice in it's life. After it iced up: FAIL!

... is not what you might think.HERE BE SPOILERS, I promise you. Consider yourself forewarned....I mean it...OK, don't say I didn't tell you...According to Interstellar - the movie, the single most powerful force in the universe is not found in the atom. It's not subatomic, not even in the minutest building blocks of nature yet to be discovered. It's not described by gravity, electromagnetism, or relativity. It's not the force that binds nuclei together in the atom. Nope. The strongest force in the universe is love. Who knew? I mean, Einstein wasted a lot of time trying to unify relativity and electromagnetism. He would have been better served watching reruns of Friends, or Make Room for Daddy, which was probably more his style because he died in 1955. Or did he? Maybe he traveled into a black hole like Matthew McConaughey, and now he's in some timeless void in space just waiting to be rescued.There's a point in the film when the cliches start to poke you in the eye: the unforgiving daughter mad at her father for leaving her and not coming back like he had promised; the reckless son angry at the world; the benevolent mentor-doctor character; the mysterious ghost that's not all that mysterious; the ridiculous choice to land in the shallows of a giant ocean on a planet orbiting a black hole; the insubordinate crewman without the good sense to run in the face of danger; the obligatory third act fatality; and the crazy-ass last act wild card that arrives just in time to really screw things up. For me, it's like The Planet of the Stupids in the third act. Suddenly, sense and logic take a back seat the classic b-movie operatives, where everybody in the film makes really bad decisions. You would think, on a mission of this magnitude, where the fate of humanity hangs in the balance, certain well-established procedures and standards of protocol would take precedence. Nope. It's pretty much a "what do we do now?" guessing game that culminates with Ann Hathaway's character convincing the captain that the only rational choice left is to follow the power of love, a truly Interstellar revelation that comes at us without much foreshadowing. Btw, shout out to Huey Lewis.OK, so I didn't hate the movie. I'd probably see it again for all the things it got right. It's beautiful, the actors do a respectable job, I liked the idea of the end if not the actual mechanics of it, and I liked the visual stuff with the wormhole and singularity.One thing that I truly did not like was the score, and the fact that I had to keep my finger on the remote control's volume button for the whole movie. This thing is just not mixed that well, and if you're like me, and have trouble hearing dialogue in movies, you'll be better off with closed captioning on. The score intrudes on dialogue, as does some of the audio effects. I read somewhere that Nolan did this deliberately because he wanted to provide a more realistic experience. Say what? Hey, Chris, if this is true, please don't do it again. It's scifi, not 60 minutes.

Island of the Lost is a fascinating shipwreck survival story written by a knowledgable author who can turn a proper phrase for a sea story. Unfortunately, I found myself bogged down by the narrative structure. For example, on page 106, without any foreshadowing or any warning whatsoever, the author begins to tell the story of a second set of shipwrecked sailors. Instead of tying the two stories together from the start, or finding some common thread, she simply adds the second shipwreck in the ongoing timeline. It's really jarring. For over 100 pages you're following the travails of the crew of The Grafton, and then you turn the page and suddenly, in the very next chapter, you're being introduced to The Invercauld and her crew. I also found the character descriptions and character studies on the antiseptic side, which made it hard for me to find something, anything, to which I could anchor some sympathy. Frankly, it was hard for me to root for any of these guys. Another thing that irritated me was the author's choice for chapter headings e.g., "Eleven: Jaws of Hell." Kind of hackneyed. if you ask me.In my opinion, the book would have been better with a strong intro/forward (providing the glue or thread to merge the two narratives) and chapters designating the ship's names and dates to which the events of the chapter corresponded. She could have alternated between the two this way, or written two different books, or one book with two separate sections. Any of the above would have been an improvement to tacking on a second narrative 106 pages into the book, but I think I would have preferred alternating the two narratives chapter by chapter, a structure that might have given us something more to root for.

Not much more to say that hasn't already been said about this reasonably priced tablet. I will say, I don't think the battery is all that robust. When I use I can almost watch the battery power icon move. But I bought it for my wife and she likes it a lot and would probably give it 5-stars.

Review of the James Dickey 112 Gaming Mouse ((http://amzn.to/1Fof8w7))I typically use a trackball or trackpad on my iMac desktop, my Lenovo laptop, and my Macbook laptop, but I was offered one of these devices for review and thought I would give it a try. It's now my preference for the Mac desktop and the Lenovo laptop, which, btw, is running Windows 7 Pro. I would use it on the Macbook, but it's too hard for me to break the trackpad habit on the Mac laptop. No matter what, I always go back to it.This thing is billed as a gaming mouse. While I am not an avid gamer, I know a little about the variety of devices out there, and they can get pretty expensive. For the money, this thing has a very nice mouse feel under the hand. It's light to the touch, lights up nicely (there's an on/off switch for the light if you need to run in low voltage mode), and it moves freely across a pad. It's plug and play in all computers and therefore needs no special drivers.There are six buttons: left click, right click, middle click (on the scroll wheel for up and down),  forward and back (buttons 4 an 5), and a dpi switch (3 settings: 1000, 1600, 2000). The buttons are all set to a factory default when you take the mouse out of the box, and these defaults will work differently on different platforms and in different games. Some games don't use buttons 4&5 so you'll have to map these buttons, or so I'm told. I don't know much about mapping keys to mouse buttons.On my computers, out of the box and for browsing and working, the left. right, and scroll defaults work exactly the way you'd expect, but the middle default works differently in different browsers, and the forward and back button don't do anything. I downloaded X-Mouse Button Control software from CNET and used it to program the forward-back buttons (4 & 5) and the middle button. The forward back buttons now control my volume and the middle button turns the cursor/pointer into a hold and drag so I can move the window around on the screen with the mouse.There is no disc or instruction manual included but if you're a gamer you probably already know what to do and how to do it. The X Mouse Button Control software is free and easy to use. As far as mapping keys to buttons goes, you're on your own with that one.As others have said, the mouse has a very long USB cord, which is great for me because I use it with my laptop in my recording studio, and the way I have things set up the mouse can't be too close to the laptop.

Very nice shower head. Well made of solid, non-corrosive materials. The acrylic base is quite thick. Ideally, it should be mounted in a shower stall so that the shower head itself is parallel to the floor. This way you get the full raindrop effect from directly overhead. In order to do this most people will have to use a different shower arm than the one that comes standard for most showers. You want a shower arm that comes straight out from the wall. Or you can just buy a shower arm adapter designed for a rain shower shower head. The latter will just thread onto the end of the standard shower arm and have a coupe of hinged joints. I have one of the latter but decided to try it in a different shower. It worked just fine set up on a regular shower arm, but I don't think it looks as good as it does when it is parallel to the floor. As such, I plan on moving it to the master bedroom shower and retiring my old all metal rain shower head. It's really quite a nice looking shower head, the type of thing that could win a design award, and it adds a classy touch to any shower. 4-3/4 Stars (Full disclosure: I received one of these shower heads for free for review purposes. It really is a nice shower head. You won't be disappointed.)

You can tell just by looking at the picture on the product page this money belt or belly pouch can hold quite a bit of stuff. It's very well made, too, out of lightweight nylon. It seems sturdy and durable. Good thing to take on a jog or...if you work as a mule for a drug cartel -- no, no, just kidding. In fact, don't even think of it as a secure carryall. If you wear it on the outside of your clothes, some scoundrel will know right away where you're carrying your valuables and it will be no problem for him or her to sneak up to you and rip all your valuables off your waist. If you wear it under your shirt or jacket, and keep it completely hidden, that's a different story. I tried it against my skin and while you know it's there it's not uncomfortable. However, I'm a former security consultant and I can tell you it's OK to carry something hidden under your clothes, unless you make it obvious by the way you walk or adjust yourself that you're carrying something under your clothes. You do the latter and suddenly you mark yourself as a candidate for theft, because now you've told the world you have something worth hiding. As a side note, I used the pouch the other day to keep an ice pack against my lower back. I know, not what it was made for but it worked.

Works exactly as described. Great case and the ability to answer calls and get texts without opening is very nice. I had a little worry when I couldn't get my iMagnet dock to hold it, then I realized you have to fold the case open (so the front sticks to the back) and then it adhered rock-solid! A little smooth finish and I do wish they didn't stamp that silly name on the front.

Using these for our hummingbird feeders (also bought on Amazon) and they are perfect.Nice quality and they came in white, which was perfect. I also got two of them for about what others charge for one.
Fantastic socks. Comfy and soft, stretchy and warm.

I have to wonder if there weren't some issues with a production run that a few people have experienced.My wife and I have been using Tidy Cats' clumping litter (3 or 4 different formulas) for probably 20 years with zero issues.We foster and rescue cats and currently have 15 full-time residents, half of which are indoor only. We learned a long time ago that cheaping out on the litter is a mistake.We have found Tidy Cats to be the most dust-free of the bunch, with excellent clumping.However, we do not use the standard litter pans most people have. We make our own covered pans out of large plastic storage bins with lids. I cut a round hole, slightly larger than our fattest fur-child, in the side or end - about 6 inches up the side. A full 27-lb. pail of Tidy Cats goes in each of the six containers we have in 3 different locations and they are all scooped twice a day.After that, we add a couple of measuring cups of fresh litter to each one every day or so and it keeps them working great.This is critical, as the clumping agent Bentonite is used up and must be replenished with fresh scoops. I wish I could buy a big pail of pure bentonite to add instead.We also sanitize the boxes and completely replace the litter periodically, but we only use an average of about three large pails a month total.

Just finished the second book and really loving this series. Characters are engaging and believable and the storyline(s) are well-crafted.Add to that the fact that Kalquist is a remarkably talented singer/songwriter and writes a new song for each book and you have quite the package here. Kalquist's songwriting is evocative and beautiful, much like her Kindle works and you should definitely sign up for her newsletter and download the MP3s of her songs. Get them here: http://www.autumnkalquist.com/music/I am excited to see what she has up her sleeves, literarily and music-wise, for the future!

Excellent feeder, the hummers love them. The ant moat on the top is a great new feature my old ones do not have.8 oz. is just enough to ensure that refills will be needed every few days with an active population. You need to thoroughly clean and refill these things  regularly.

I haven't enjoyed reading a story this much in a long time. Literally could not stop reading it once Parzival found the first key. This was definitely written for people of my age, evidenced by my neck getting sore from nodding my head at all the 80s references. Apparently Ernie and I share a lot of childhood favorites and that, combined with a rollicking storyline and plenty of interesting wrinkles, made this an instant new favorite for me.I am really looking forward to the film as the Hollywood fx guys will be able to faithfully represent every scene I can think of with no problems. I have to highly recommend this to anyone between about 35 and 60 with a fondness for that time period.
Necessary accessory for the Modulus! Since the Nerf guns only come with a handful of ammo, grab some of these very attractive blue rounds for when the generic white ones are gone.

This is a very nice piece of recreational firepower. Great price, fast delivery and the look on my grandson's face when we opened the huge box from UPS was absolutely priceless. He had been talking about the Nerf guns he and his friends back home play with and they all have one or more of the different models, but NO ONE has the Modulus yet. His grandmother and I decided to arm him as well as he could be and ordered this little beast to be delivered while they were here on vacation. This will certainly gain him some massive reputation once he gets home and is able to deploy with his buddies!We also got the 75-pack of ammo since the 10 rounds that come with it will almost certainly be gone in a week or less.
Fantastic, amazing, incredible. Seriously, this is a terrific flashlight and has the great worklight built in.Add the magnetic base so you don't have to hold it and you have got one fine tool.

What a fantastic phone for less than $200! This thing is so fast, every app is open as quickly as I tap it. The display is the best I've ever seen and the pictures I have taken so far are so far superior to my two previous phones (LG G2 and Galaxy S4) that there is no comparison. I use my phone as a Stereo/Speakerphone/NAV system and the 5.5 inches is substantially better-looking than any others I have had too. I don't miss the 4G and I am not using the second SIM slot, but I know it is there if I need it. Supposedly, there is even a ROM that supports US LTE, so I may just flash it before long. Also, no NFC support, but I never really found a compelling reason for it either.In fact the only real issue I have found with this phone is the nearly complete lack of accessories available, even with shipping from China. What the heck Lenovo? This is such a game-changer in the mid to low-priced phone sector that you could really blow things up if you tried. I am having a hell of a time finding a case/cover that I can use with my magnetic car dock or even an alternate dock. Lenovo really missed the boat on this aspect.Anyway, terrific phone, with all the power you need (IMHO) for a really nice price.

More terrific prose from Hugh. I was going to wait until he finished and released Pt. 5 and buy them all, then I found out I could borrow the first installment for free. Great idea. Very enjoyable and quick read, with a storyline that promises to yield some great action. The things I particularly like about Howey's work are usually not very mainstream points. In this one for instance, I got a real kick out of the fact that the research about the lighthouse picture was assumed to be "binged" and not (as 99% of the world might say) "googled." I don't know why that specifically resonated with me.The other thing that keeps bringing me back to Howey's books is the writing and editing. I can't remember the last time I saw a typo or grammatical/usage/tense/syntax mistake in one of his stories - if ever. Contrarily, I can't remember when I last downloaded a Kindle book from ANYONE ELSE that did NOT suffer from ... let's just call it what it is - crappy writing/editing/publishing. Having to mentally correct an author's  use of the English language while reading a supposedly "finished" work really offends me and colors my opinion of that author. I give beginning writers a bit of a break, but let's be honest - if you are publishing something for public consumption, it ought to damn well be ready. The truth is, most of the stuff I see is just not. Hugh, however, always delivers.

Thoroughly enjoyable and quite different from most time travel fare.A quick read (first volume anyway) and hard to put down. A mostly fresh take on the usually formulaic time travel trope that had me engaged from the first few pages until I finished it later that day.

Typical "copied and pasted" information from other people's work and not from the "author's" own knowledge. In places, it even reads like a bad translation from some other language to English. Also the author is apparently clueless enough to think that there are "warm blooded" fish you can raise. That would be difficult since the first truly warm blooded, or "endothermic" fish (Moonfish) was JUST DISCOVERED to be so. It is a Pacific deep-water fish so you will not be raising them in your aquaponics project. (Some tuna and sharks can warm their muscles - but it is not the same).So basically, nothing new or revolutionary or even all that educational here that you couldn't surpass with a simple Bing or Google search.Good thing it was free or I would be demanding my money back!

The mouse is OK, but is kind of sluggish in recovering from screen saver rest.I have to roll the mouse wheel a couple of times to get it to respond at all. That being said, the precision on this thing is great and the buttons work as expected. Single AA battery has my old one beat, but we'll see how long it lasts.

Recipes are decent, but many of them are not truly "dump" recipes.Any directions besides "pour/dump into pan" makes it NOT a dump recipe.Also the number of ingredients in several of these take them right out of the "amazingly easy" category too.

Best pita chips I ever had from a bag. Their naked flavor is the best for dipping hummus, but this is the one for pure snacking. Just the right sized serving too. However, with this flavor, you'd better not be on a date or have a meeting with anyone where you have to get close to them. The garlic is pronounced and delicious and persistent.
Quality is about what I expected, I guess. Low-end tool with decent construction.I imagine it will last a couple of years before it starts getting loose.
This is a very nice, solid keysafe. Easy to set up and easy to use.Seems like this will last quite a while.

Having almost 5 acres of land, with a good bit planted in flowering shrubs, fruits and seasonal potted plants, we do a fair amount of watering. Due to that, we go through sprayers. Most of the bargain-priced sprayers last a year or two, but inevitably the low price is explainable in the low quality of manufacture and the inevitable failure of the piece.This sprayer feels like it will last a while. Quality materials and a solid, reliable feel. The water control works flawlessly, with no sloppiness between settings. I also really like the front trigger design. It is less fatiguing to my arthritic hands and just feels better than the standard spray nozzle. I expect to get quite a bit of use out of it.The hose hanger was not a deciding point in my purchase, but was a nice extra as I had just bought a number of high-end expandable hoses to use at various locations. It holds 100 feet of expandable hose with no problem. Forget the thermometer though, it is not as accurate as my wild-assed guess about how hot it is outside. It reads about 20 degrees off from actual, and so is pretty much worthless. I don't know if I just got a lemon or if they are all that bad, but it doesn't really matter as I didn't buy the nozzle for that.The extra rubber washer was nice to have thrown in too.

Solid little drive and quite a bargain when I bought it.More than big enough for any OS you want to install, the drive performs well and has room for plenty of applications and data too.My boss said "man, it is so quiet you can't even hear it spinning!"We all thought that was pretty funny. His jokes are not usually that great.

Not great and not effective for clearing drains. Might work for a toilet, but I doubt I will risk it.The design is such that it is quite easy to get a face full of the nastiness in the pipe you are trying to clear. It does seem to have some decent pressure, but after the second or third pump, you will probably have liquid in the cylinder, which will shoot out the top on the upstroke. It has been put away for (some unimaginable) emergency use only.

You really do need to read the instructions and play with this BEFORE you need it or you will embarrass yourself. It functions quite easily as you expect to pull things (I used it to get a broken golf cart into the trailer for a trip to the shop.) Getting it to unspool is where it gets tricky. The tiny instructions accompany smallish and vague illustrations, but if you are smart enough to operate basic mechanical devices, you should be able to get it eventually.The price was right, just over $30, and it got here in two days (love dat Prime!) and it was the perfect solution for the one need I had for it. I highly recommend this for semi-light duty work without reservation.

This bag was bought to be a carry-on for airplane flights and it works perfectly for that purpose. My wife says it held everything she needed for her short trip and it looks terrific! Highly recommend.

I am a fairly normal-sized man (5'10") and wear 34 waist pants. These things were made for some kind of freaky thin giants apparently. They are literally long enough to cover my entire foot when sitting down in them. You really shouldn't have to alter lounge pants, I think.

Amazon really needs a "no-stars" rating.I have to say I am pretty disappointed in this product in several ways.First, it is listed as non-toxic, etc.I disagree. This stuff will absolutely choke you with its fumes (no surprise considering the acid main ingredient.) I could not stand within 10 feet of the area treated for quite some time.Second, it is supposed to convert the rust and I suppose it does ... technically. However, what is left behind does not appear ready for any kind of surface treatment or painting as it leaves a nasty white residue among dark spots that are sticky for days.Will be going back to Ospho, which has always worked - just doesn't come in a spray bottle. So much for convenience!

Giving you 5 stars even though the writer/journalist in me wants to gig you for typos and usage errors.First off, #5 of your 10 reasons needed a real editor's help. If you are going to use archaic terms, it is only effective if you are accurate. There is no such thing as "daring-do," the term you are looking for is "derring-do" and the term usually implies a wanton carelessness in addition to the primary meaning of adventurous or bold.Also, the glaring error a previous reviewer mentioned, "your own organ tree" in the Orange Jelly recipe should be corrected.I have not read through all the recipes yet, but I am sure there are others however, I am not here to be a pain.That being said, this is a terrific guide to the title subject. Small-batch preserves are the only way to go in my opinion and Joe has put together some truly idiot-proof recipes that promise to yield good, consistent results. There is a nice variety and he discusses more than just the recipes to round it out.As a former chef and lifelong maker of homemade jams and jellies, liqueurs, sausages, jerky and other goodies for gifting, I can vouch for this: Joe knows what he is talking about. Several of his recipes are identical to my tried-and-true, reliable "go-to" recipes that I have used for decades so I can tell you they are good ones! I especially like the marmalades.I highly recommend this to anyone who is experienced in home preserving and beginners alike. There is something for everyone here and I look forward to his next publication.

Great little knife (very sharp) and it works as advertised. I've never seen a "real" one so I can't say if it is "counterfeit" or not, but I really don't care. For $5 each shipped, it is a decent little find.Obviously though, the idea of a knife in your wallet is interesting but not terribly smart if you travel.Please remember to put this in a checked piece of luggage if you plan on traveling via air anywhere.If you forget, you may just enjoy the "special attention" of some very enthusiastic TSA workers.

Wow, what a delicious cuppa! I get the chocolate, some nuttiness, some caramel and it is so smooth and tasty you want to chug it down.Makes an amazingly good iced coffee drink too (obviously) and I have even tried it on the espresso setting and it is kickin!Even my wife, who does not generally like flavored coffees said that she really enjoyed this.Will be buying it regularly, so it would be GREAT if it was PRIME too!

Melted the first day.
