Dangerous!Received this and plugged into PC to charge.Light went off indicating full charge and I used it twice successfully.Had it sitting on my desk and when I picked it up to go out for a smoke found the top hot.Opened it to find the element glowing and the plastic housing melting around it.Thank god it was not in my pocket of sitting on a stack of paper when this happened!

Have this on repeat in my car and am finding new gems each time I play it. I wouldn't really classify all of it as "prog rock" but enough of the tracks take me back to Yes, ELP and other old Pprog rock favorites to make it worthwhile. Also, one "non-prog" track is stuck in my head right now - "Drive" by the amazing Anneke van Giersbergen is a real treat for the ears. The love cut of "Grace" by The Devin Townsend Project is also a standout.Highly recommend this.

My literary life anyway, for sure. But also many facets of my personal life and indeed, my personality. This was a "turning point" read for me and changed my literary tastes for the next 30 years easily. I cut my (fiction) teeth on Robert Heinlein's "juvenile" books, starting with "Have Space Suit, Will Travel" and including pretty much everything he ever wrote without exception and leaned toward authors of Heinlein's calibre - Asimov, Clarke, Bradbury, etc. - for all my recreational reading.But when I was about 13 or 14, I found an old copy of "Sirens of Titan" in a used bookstore for a quarter and got just because of the (original) cover. The story though, caught me up and drew me in. I am not going to try to synopsize the story, many here already have very nicely. Suffice it to say, I devoured it. My favorite line from the book is Constant's answer: “I was a victim of a series of accidents. As are we all.”  The Church of God the Utterly Indifferent was also a favorite premise for me.After "Sirens" I read everything I could find of Vonnegut (which was again, pretty much everything he ever wrote. "Cat's Cradle," "Slaughterhouse Five" and the amazingly good short story collection "Welcome to the Monkey House" were all also fantastic, but "Sirens" remains to this day the one I re-read at least once a year. And I enjoy it just as much every single time.Do yourself a favor, read it in one weekend ... or one sitting if you are wired that way.If you have a good sense of humor and an appreciation for a well-told story, you will not regret it.
I gave these to my wife as they are worthless driving a car. Slippery does not begin to describe it.

Love it, the 1920X1080 resolution is just right for my main desktop at work. Takes up little desk space and looks just right from 2 feet away in my chair. Everything is clear and readable with very few issues.Update: After living with this for a few months, I am taking away a star.I use this as a computer monitor and feed it with a nice high-quality HDMI cable from a pretty high-end video card.The image does not fill the screen and I am losing out on several inches of diagonal display.The product pictures shows it nearly filling the screen, but mine is nowhere near that.Searched a few forums and found a couple of suggestions, but nothing works.Good thing the boss reimbursed me for it since I use it in the office. If it was my money, I probably would have returned it.

Very nice-looking and sturdy rack. The shelves are just the right size for smaller pots and a couple of lids. Fit just right where we needed it and looks terrific and way more high end than the price justifies. This is a very attractive piece and will fit in well with a black/stainless color scheme.Not too much fun to mount though for sure. Believe all the advice about getting decent toggle bolts to mount it, you need them. You also will need someone to help with installation. Worth it though, for what you end up with.
Can't really say much more about these than they just work perfectly. Cookies and biscuits just come right off with no effort. Easy cleanup and look great besides. A must-have in my kitchen!

First off, putting a grilled porterhouse steak on the cover of a Thai cookbook just boggles the mind. Does "Logan" live in Colorado?Seriously, the recipes are decent, if a bit generic. Most of these can be found with a simple web search for "thai recipes" and were obviously NOT edited for readability. But anyway, what IS up with that cover? ... just can't stop pondering.The thing that kills me is that 3 out of the 4 previous "reviews" were pretty obviously written by the same person. I have many years of editing other people's literary work and it was pretty easy to spot. I really have a problem with shilling in any form. I don't like the turn Amazon publishing has taken. It is becoming a cesspool of badly-written and sloppily-compiled publications that are promoted with artifice.I feel badly that the other real reviewer wasted his/her time on this like I did.

Decent lamp with a terrific, handy novelty (outlets) but they really just missed "great" by a little bit.I saw that the translucent shade bothers some reviewers, but I had no issue with it. Especially when I realized a quick coat of rattle-can spray paint could change the color and make it more opaque, while matching my style.The two electrical outlets are fantastic and I keep a USB charger block in one and leave the other free for future needs.Unfortunately, Normande missed the boat on the true utility of this thing.The size of the base belies the height of the lamp and it looks a little stubby to be honest. If I didn't have a stereo speaker to sit it on, it would not be able to point down to illuminate more than about a square foot of my desk.Yes, I saw the dimensions before buying, but I really liked the design otherwise so I took a chance and it worked out acceptably.However, if they had made this 6-8 inches taller, it would have deserved 5 stars and I would have bought several more as gifts.

Same stale lolcat and icanhazcheesburger memes that have been circulating for years and years.Do a google or bing photo search for "funny cat pictures" and you will get millions of results. In fact, you will get more in one page of search results than in the entire "book" listed here.Honestly sick of people trying to make money off of other people's creativity by copying and pasting into the Kindle format.It is about time Amazon came up with some bare rudimentary guidelines for what deservers publishing or not.This, simply put, does not.

I also received this free in exchange for a review. But my takeaway was slightly better than the previous reviewer.I actually enjoyed the story, despite the weaknesses. Bob was right in that the story seemed to change focus without warning and additionally, some of the main characters were so formulaic as to be slightly detrimental to the story.However, it was an interesting premise at its root. I think with some great editing and a bit of rewriting, it could be a 4-star or better. Taking the Christ-like behavior of the President out would be a big start. Additionally, the cloak-and-dagger behavior of the feds and the inherent implied goodness of the disabled vet are a bit over the top, in my opinion. A lot of that seemed to telegraph what was coming so I was not really surprised at the ending.That said, I still enjoyed it and look forward to more of McKinney's efforts.

At the current price ($22.04), we're paying roughly 52 cents per bar. These are good for a quick snack, but the 90-100 calories won't leave you feeling like you ate a full meal. I'll describe the taste of each one for you.-------------------------Pastry Crisps, Blueberry:Each package has 2 crisps inside. The outer pastry has a crunchy and slightly doughy texture, like a light Pop-Tart. The pastry is coated in white frosting and the blueberry filling has a consistency like jam. You'll taste more of the pastry than the blueberry filling.-------------------------Pastry Crisps, Strawberry:This also contains 2 crisps per package. The strawberry filling is the same kind of sweet jam texture, but again, you'll taste more of the pastry while eating this.-------------------------Cereal Bars, Red Berries:Each package contains one bar with a chewy granola bar consistency. The top is covered in white frosting, and there are sweet red berry chunks throughout the bar. The bar itself is somewhat sticky, and if there is a lack of icing, it can fall apart pretty quickly after removing it from the package.-------------------------Cereal Bars, Chocolatey Pretzel:This time around, the chocolate coats the bottom of the bar which holds it together better. The chocolate is very tasty, but I found the pretzel had an almost soggy texture which took some getting used to.-----------All in all, if you're looking for breakfast bars which can double as an afternoon snack to buy in bulk, these are a good choice. Out of all of them, the only one I didn't care for was the chocolate pretzel.

I haven't used a blender in quite some time, but Black & Decker made it absolutely simple to start blending my own smoothies.This comes with two 20 ounce jars, 2 lids and a "FusionBlade".It couldn't be any easier - just load up the jar, screw on the FusionBlade, turn it clockwise in the base unit until you hear a click, press the power button in, and let the blade do the work. The unit has a wide base, and I found it very stable: there was no shaking, no rattling, no base unit moving around on the counter.  Once everything is finished, just unscrew the blade and put on a travel lid, and you're done!Cleanup is simple too. The jars and blade are dishwasher safe. If you put a small amount of dishwashing liquid and some warm water in the jar, you can clean two birds with one stone.One recommendation I would give? Keep the liquids near the "top" of the blender when preparing your smoothies. I found the blades need some help when trying to chop frozen foods first.For example: I mixed a cup of ice, 1/2 cup of yogurt, honey, a banana and several frozen strawberries for my smoothie. At first, the blades pureed the strawberries but it formed a layer of frozen goop and the rest of the ingredients couldn't get through. Once I added a small amount of milk, this broke up the layer and the rest slid down into the whirling blade.It comes with a 2 year warranty and the instructions give a basic smoothie recipe.If you're looking for a smoothie / milkshake maker and you don't want to spend the money on a multi-function blender, this is a great alternative.Recommended!

PROS:+ Simple setup+ Excellent sound quality+ Long charge lifeCONS:- Not 'truly' wireless for the PS4.-----------------------------------The main things I look for with gaming headsets is ease of setup, headset quality, and clarity of chats during game sessions. I'm glad to report that Turtle Beach's PX4 headset surpassed my expectations in each of these areas.EASE OF SETUP: - I'm the guy who can't plug in a toaster the right way unless I have detailed instructions. Turtle Beach must have known I would be reviewing this headset, because the directions couldn't have been any simpler to follow. They provided screenshots of the setup screens for the PS3, PS4, and multiple versions of the Xbox 360. If I can connect this, anyone can.HEADSET QUALITY:The earpieces were very comfortable, and the mesh kept my ears from feeling sweaty during late night Destiny raids or Netflix marathons. I thought the detachable boom microphone was a great idea, it doesn't get in the way if I don't want to chat.The charging cord for the headset is 13 feet long, which makes it easy to charge the headset whether you're playing a game or watching movies.Speaking of movies, I was recently watching 'Radio Free Albemuth', and there was a segment with low-level music which I didn't hear during a previous viewing without these headphones. And of course, I tested the headphones with movies such as 'Tombstone', 'The Matrix', and 'Watchmen' - all of them sounded excellent with no audio popping or dips in sound quality.The 15 hour headset charge claim held up - I was able to watch 11 episodes of The Blacklist on Netflix and the sound didn't cut out at all.CLARITY OF CHATS:From the get-go, this headset provided me extremely clear chats for all my gaming sessions. I could hear other players without any problems, and they could hear me just fine. No crackling, no cutting out, it was clear as crystal. I could increase or decrease the game volume as well as the microphone volume with a turn of the dials on the right earpiece, or the Talkback cable for my PS4, and it couldn't be simpler. The voice commands for the PS4 come through loud and clear through the microphone.CONS?The only drawback I see to this headset is the need for the PS4 Talkback cable. If you're looking to use chat features or Playstation voice commands, the cable has to be connected to the controller, so this headset isn't completely 'wireless'...but this is a minor point.FINAL THOUGHTS:I feel this is definitely worth the price. It's easy to set up, the sound quality for games and music and movies is superb, and the long charge provides uninterrupted entertainment sessions.If it's within your price range, I highly recommend this headset.

I've always thought of Robert De Niro as an amazing actor, but after reading this book, I also see him as a smart investor, a thorough researcher, a restaurant buff, and so much more.I was thoroughly excited to read this book - I've watched Goodfellas and Taxi Driver and Casino more times than I could ever possibly count! I wanted to learn more about the man, and read about the movies I've missed over the years. Over the course of 500+ pages, I got to follow along and watch the only child of Robert De Niro (Sr) and Virginia Admiral grow up to become an example of true excellence in American cinema.Shawn Levy's book takes us on a journey with each role for Robert De Niro, on stage or screen, lead role or bit part. Once he agreed to a role, it was completely fascinating to see how much work he put into understanding his character. Robert would learn to speak different languages, conduct interviews, learn how to drive different vehicles, research illnesses to see how they would affect him, he would extensively mark his scripts with copious notes regarding character motivations and emotions, and so on.We've seen Robert willing to change his body structure to fit certain roles - most people think of his body shaping for Taxi Driver or Raging Bull, but if there was only one role I'd pick to prove how serious he took his craft? His choice of Max Cady in Cape Fear: Robert spent $5,000 to make his teeth look unhealthy, and then spent another $20,000 to have them fixed after shooting was completed!From this, it's plain to see Robert didn't just play a role...he BECAME his role. He was also able to keep his ego in check - it was quite common for Robert to suggest removing lines from his roles, rather than requesting to add more. Robert De Niro may be many things, but he is not egotistical.However, he is very, very private. Robert declined to be interviewed for this book (hence making it an unauthorized biography), but the information packed in these pages was gleaned from various archives and correspondence with over 4 dozen people. I applaud the efforts of Shawn Levy - this could not have been an easy task, since Robert De Niro wants to keep his life his life (as his mother would say). We were quite lucky to get a few glimpses into Robert's personal life, his past and present relationships, and his children.Robert De Niro has managed to give the world several decades worth of entertainment through acting, directing, and he's also improved New York and other areas with his real estate deals.There's a long list of movies which Robert De Niro rejected over the years, and they could be debated as either smart box office bomb dodging, or missed opportunities. For example, I can't quite see Robert De Niro eating tiny corn in 'Big'...but I could absolutely see him screaming at Tom Cruise about him not being able to handle the truth in 'A Few Good Men'.If you've ever wondered how method actors do what they do, give this book a read. There's a lot to enjoy, right down to the footnotes.Very highly recommended!

Robert Bausch's novel "Far As The Eye Can See" takes us on a journey from 1869 to 1876, following the adventures of a young man by the name of Bobby Hale. He spent a few years as an enlisted man, but he's not looking for war anymore...he's looking to find his destiny out in the Big West.In the beginning of the novel, Bobby Hale was a simple man who made snap decisions - he'd shoot first and not even get around to asking questions later. His lack of understanding the language of American Indians got him into trouble many times, and he'd have to scramble to keep himself from getting killed, by both the Indians and the Army as well. Bobby spent time living in the wilderness learning how to hunt & trap, but he still knew the value of a good night's sleep in a regular bed after a fresh shave and a haircut. His descriptions of food were so detailed, I could practically taste the sowbelly crisping over the fire and smell the black coffee being prepared. He didn't care much for King Lear, though.This novel seemed to perfectly capture the mindset of a simple man from this time period. Death seemed to lurk around every corner, whether it was from the barrel of a gun or the tip of an arrow. The biggest struggle seemed to be maintaining any kind of humanity with the events Bobby witnessed, or took part in.Bobby wasn't portrayed as being completely noble - far from it. His moral compass took a few sharp turns here and there, but on the whole, he would do the necessaries to protect the people he cared about. I grew to like him because of his moments of reflection after some particularly gruesome events - and I enjoyed watching his attitudes change as the book progressed up to the Battle of the Little Bighorn.There's a lot to enjoy in Robert Bausch's tale of Bobby Hale, and if you like stories about the Big West or this time period, I hope you'll give it a look-see.

I've been chasing this fool all the way to The Loop! I might have let him go, if he didn't threaten my sister. Looks like he's approaching a traffic intersection...let's just use my phone to switch the lights aaaaaaaaand...[collision]...PERFECT. He won't be driving anywhere now.Wait...what? He's trying to escape on foot?!? Not over THAT bridge, he isn't. [Hacks bridge control]. Two hits with my baton ought to send him to dreamland...*thwack* *thwack* Let's see what his cell phone has to say. [hacks it, eyes grow wide with horror]--------------------------------------This it what it feels like to be inside the mind of Aiden Pearce, the protagonist in Watch Dogs. He's got a marvelous little device that can see the digital footprints of everyone's life in the great city of Chicago. Aiden's got vengeance on his mind, and he's got the tools to carry it out.PLOT:The game starts off simply enough, Aiden Pierce has to escape from Wrigley field and avoid getting captured by the police. Once he does, he's on a mission to find the people responsible for killing his niece 11 months ago. After catching his breath in a safe house, Aiden starts following the bread crumb trails throughout the city of Chicago and neighboring Pawnee. No one can hide from him.GAMEPLAY:Watch Dogs is a free-roam game in a 3rd person perspective set in Chicago, which has recently been outfitted with a supercomputer called The ctOS. It's connected to everyone and everything, and hence, so is Aiden Pierce.Using his cell phone called The Profiler, Aiden can change traffic lights, burst steam pipes, hack into vehicles, stop violent crimes from happening, and much, much more. He's able to jump over fences and cars and obstacles using parkour, similar to our friend Ezio from Assassin's Creed. His weapons are numerous, including IED's, grenades, pistols, machine guns, sniper rifles, etc.However, Aiden's actions aren't without consequences - if he steals a car, chances are someone will call 911. If he commits too many crimes, He'll be recognized on the street and people will report him, making the game more difficult.Aiden can earn money by hacking unsuspecting people or completing certain tasks. This money can be used to buy outfits, weapons, order vehicles, etc. There's an online component which allows the player to race against other people or even invade someone's game (similar to Demon's Souls), but watch out - the prey can become the predator if they discover what you're doing!If you're the type of person that doesn't like jumping right into the main missions, you can opt to explore Chicago and get swept up in a tidal wave of minigames and side missions.Want to play poker? You can do that.Want to burn rubber in a street race? You can do that.Want to swipe a rocking tune from someone's cell phone on the street? You can do that.Want to track down a serial killer? You can do that.Want to do checkins, similar to FourSquare? You can do that.Want to spy on the darkest secrets of unsuspecting citizens? You can do that.Want to fly around Chicago on bouncy flowers? Yes...you can even do that.I never found myself struggling to find things to do in Watch Dogs, because Ubisoft gave me a game overflowing with secondary activities. I could have spent a solid month without touching the main missions.The game won't let you unlock certain skills until you get far enough in the main missions, and that's the PERFECT bait to get us playing through them.SO WHAT DOES WATCH DOGS MAKE YOU THINK ABOUT?While the game centers mostly on hacking and accumulating wealth to unlock weapons and outfits and side missions, the overall theme (to me, anyway) is about privacy, and its confusing nature. People want privacy, yet they freely give information to social networks and GPS tracking systems. With the press of a button, Aiden Pierce can learn your worst habit. He'll know if you do searches for the word "bondage". He'll know if you purchased used underwear online. He'll know if you're making 80,000 per year, or living off your disability checks. He'll know if you're recovering from cancer, or collecting comic books.It's Setec Astronomy all over again, but the little black box is now called The Profiler.There's also an exploration of the dark side of voyeurism. This was covered in the movie Sliver, but Watch Dogs takes it out of the apartment building and gives it a citywide scale. We can watch anyone we want, and some of those things are very unsettling.TROPHIES:There are 40 trophies to earn in Watch Dogs. The largest chunk of them are dedicated to the Collectibles missions, such as finding all the Songsneak tunes, hacking all the ctOS towers, checking in to all 100 City Hotspots, and so on.The rest are split between the Main missions, Side missions, Investigations, Minigames, and Online contracts.Some of the more frustrating missions are the QR Codes - these are similar to the Riddler challenges in Batman: Arkham City, where you have to line up the picture just right.However, I feel the "Social Lubricant" trophy is the hardest one to earn. If you're a trophy junkie, this one is best saved until you've completed everything else in the game.GLITCH REPORT:Playing with Version 1.02 -The glitches I came across during my month of gameplay were very few and far between:The first was my first jump off a building on Spider Tank, I landed but somehow couldn't move. After I was killed, the glitch never happened again.The second was during an attempted hack. I was on foot, and my target was in a boat speeding away. The game gave me the option to fast travel. I chose to do this, and I appeared in the middle of the city...in a speedboat...hovering over the concrete.The third one happened on my way to a mission - I jumped over a fence and the game froze, I had to reboot the game. It didn't happen again after that.The last glitch happened after losing a drinking game with a character. The whole screen went black so I had to reboot. This glitch hasn't happened again.Four glitches in a month's worth of gameplay? That's not bad at all.WHAT WOULD I HAVE IMPROVED?There is so much already in Watch Dogs, it's hard to think of things to add. Since I'm a sucker for multiple endings, I wish Ubisoft could have added a couple which depended on Aiden's reputation status, because this would increase the replay value of the game.However, I could think of one item to remove...the "Focus" ability, which was nearly useless. I only used it once, because it was automatically triggered during a mission. Watch Dogs didn't need "Bullet Time" - it already has its place in the Max Payne series.Oh, and I hated the drinking games. Quick Time Events are annoying enough, but playing them with sluggish controls to simulate being drunk is an exercise in frustration.FINAL VERDICT?I would have happily spent the standard new game price ($60) to purchase Watch Dogs. It's extremely rich in content, allowing players to get lost in side missions for days at a time. Once players dive into the main story, it's engaging enough so it doesn't feel tacked on. Even the ancillary characters are likeable, and that's rare to pull off in a video game. Lots of detail went into this game, right down to the hotspot checkins - you can discover facts about Chicago's past you might never have known before.If you're looking for a sandbox game and you feel Grand Theft Auto might be a little too overwhelming, give Watch Dogs a try. It's by the same company that gave us Splinter Cell and the Assassin's Creed series, so they know how to write a solid story and give us a protagonist to cheer for.Just don't be surprised if you look suspiciously at people on their cell phones after a few weeks of playing. ;-)Highly recommended!

Here's the review, in my wife's words:"This towel fits really nice. The velcro works GREAT, It doesn't slip, I don't have to constantly pull up on this towel to keep it in place, like I usually do with a regular towel. It's comfortable, I can move around easily in it, and it doesn't fly open while I'm walking, the velcro holds it in place. It's really soft!"She washed the towel before using it for the first time - it didn't lose any texture while washing and remains very comfortable and soft. We'll see how this holds up after 10+ washes or so, and what it does to the velcro...My spouse is 4 ft 10 inches tall and this towel fit her well. Her only complaint? She wishes it was made of a slightly thicker material.Recommended!

Wonka claims there are millions of gummy combinations in each bag, and I'm inclined to agree. When I go into the bag, I never know if I'm going to get a sunflower, sunglasses, a bicycle, a paw print, a bow tie, a ping-pong paddle, or something completely different!There's a few different gummy types - there's the standard gummy that we all know, in several different shapes.Then there's a gummy with a "foam backing" - it doesn't add much to the taste but it's a nice change.The real treat is the jelly-filled gummy, my daughter absolutely loves these!**I've uploaded a picture to the "Customer Images" section for you to look at.**If you like gummy snacks, this one is a great choice for the kids - each dip in the bag yields a surprise!

As several others have mentioned, I had difficulty getting this drive to work. This device ships without the charging cable, and according to other reviewers, the charging cable is required to get the Firmware update to work.I've had to contact customer service twice, so far.The first time: I called on Thursday, July 24th and the person I spoke with, Jacob, was very helpful. I didn't have the serial number with me, so he gave me his personal email address to send him my information. I did this after I got home, and he replied within one minute with a UPS tracking code. The adapter arrived by Monday.--------The second time: I called on Monday, July 28th. The person I spoke with was named Joseph. I advised I was still having problems getting the unit working. He took my phone # and advised me I would receive a callback within 5 minutes for a technician familiar with this issue. After waiting 35 minutes, I called back and hit their after hours message, which states they are only available from 7am to 5pm Pacific Standard Time.The techs seem friendly and they want to help, I'm hoping to get further assistance soon...updates to follow.--------The third time: As of July 29th, I'm happy to report that my review has been upgraded to a solid 4 out of 5.I got an email from Bill Rathbone, the senior product line manager. He set up a time to talk with me after work and walked me through updating the drive and linking it to my HTC One phone. His knowledge was vast, and he was able to help this old man through resetting the drive, updating the firmware, and even advised me to check out the forums on the Corsair website.Clearly, this product is a labor of love for him...and it shows.After successfully linking up, I was able to download my iTunes library onto the drive and I have plans to back up my video and photo files as well. Dragging and dropping the files into the drive? Easy as pie.If I was grading this product on customer service _alone_, it would get a solid 5 out of 5 because the representatives were always helpful, professional and pleasant.As it stands, the drive is great but the lack of the charging cable and the initial stumbling I had with the app setup dropped it down one star.Don't give up if you can't get it to work on your own...call 888-222-4346 and go directly to tech support, they're consummate professionals!

Having read several books by Philip K. Dick, I was looking for another one to sink my teeth into. I asked one of my coworkers which one I should try next, and this was his response:"I really like his work, but all his robots and futuristic tech terminology can get overwhelming after a while. I think you'd like 'Confessions of a Crap Artist' because it's based in contemporary time [1958]. It's regular fiction, not science fiction - but it's just as dark and disturbing as one of his apocalyptic future stories. Check it out."With that, I ordered a copy and dug into it during a recent vacation.We start off meeting Jack Isidore - He's the primary source of information for the events we're about to witness. Throughout his life, Jack has collected various items relating to science and science fiction. He's the square peg that doesn't fit into a round hole. He's been called many things: A nut. A screw-up. And most recently, a Crap Artist.Fay Hume is Jack's sister. When she sets her sights on something, nothing can change her mind. She has a unique gift/curse of having long term plans but makes most of her decisions in the present for her immediate enjoyment. She's overly concerned with her societal image, and knows how to manipulate people into getting what she wants, whether it's a new car or a nice house in the suburbs.Charley Hume - He runs the local iron works, and is married to Fay. He built an expensive house in the suburbs for them to live in. He's prone to fits of rage when asked to do anything he feels is beneath his dignity. He medicates his anger with trips to the local tavern.Fay and Charley decide to take Jack into their home - and for a time, it seemed to work. Jack takes the housework responsibilities that Fay doesn't want to do, and Charley thinks are beneath him. Jack cares for their children [Elsie and Bonnie] and convinces himself that he's providing valuable services to the family in exchange for well-cooked steaks, and a roof over his head.However, Jack begins to notice that his sister's idyllic family life is anything but. He starts to document everything and watches their lives spiral out of control while he cares for the children, tends to the animals and makes breakfast for everyone.This is a fascinating story which is told to us through the viewpoints of Jack, Fay, Charley and Fay's lover, Nathan Anteil. The format is easy to get used to, each chapter is dedicated to one person's viewpoint and we learn more about each person through their interactions. I ended up finishing this book in two days, and enjoyed it thoroughly. In a strange way, it felt like I took a break from reading PKD because this was such a departure from his usual writing style. I wish he had written more novels like this.Recommended.

I'll admit, I reacted like many people when I first heard about this game: "Minecraft? Isn't that the game where you build things with blocks? Where's the fun in that?"When I decided to play it and review it, I was amazed at the reactions I received - not from my friends, but from their children! They couldn't WAIT to tell me their stories about fishing and building minecart tracks and fighting Creepers with diamond swords and battling the Enderdragon...I hadn't even played Minecraft yet, but they were all excited for me to start!GAMEPLAY:Minecraft is an open world game where you create your own gameplay experience. Initially, it looks very simple - you play as an adventurer in a block-style format, and you need to gather items and mine for rare ores to craft items for your adventurer to survive. There isn't much of a story to speak of, and while there is a "boss battle", you don't have to fight it if you don't want to. During the day, you can see animals and interact with them - horses, sheep, cows, pigs, wolves, and many more. You can dig and uncover rare ores to fashion new weapons, armor, tools and construction materials.However, when nighttime rolls in, you need to beware: there are several creatures which hunt you down - spiders, zombies, skeletons which shoot arrows, and even the dreaded Creeper - a monster which explodes if you linger too closely!You can play in a peaceful style where no monsters chase you and you aren't in any danger, but this limits your gameplay experience. I decided to play in survival mode, to get the full effect of the game.WHAT WAS IT LIKE, PLAYING FOR THE FIRST TIME?I was afraid I'd be overwhelmed, but the tutorial mode was extremely easy to follow. It showed me step by step how to get wood from a nearby tree and do some basic crafting. Once this was done, I gathered more materials and put a crafting table together. I fashioned a crude pickaxe for mining and made a wooden sword to protect myself from invaders. With my confidence raised, I created a new world and found a nice stretch of land where I decided to make camp.I thought I was so smart, building a fence to keep out intruders, only to discover I forgot to make a fence gate! I couldn't jump over the fence, so I had to dig under it like Charles Bronson in The Great Escape...which brought a lot of laughs to my child. While I played, she told me about all the dangers I would be facing. I asked how she knew all of this (since she'd never played before), and she answered with a chuckle: "Come on dad, EVERYONE knows about Minecraft!"TROPHIES:There are 29 trophies to earn in Minecraft, most of which are creation based. You'll get a few right off the bat by creating various tools and weapons, but some of them (such as killing the Enderdragon or riding for 500 meters in a minecart) will take considerable time and effort to earn.In all honesty, this is probably the first time I've played a PS3 game where I haven't been concerned about earning all the trophies as quickly as possible - and I'm one of the biggest PS3 trophy junkies you will ever meet. My enjoyment of Minecraft comes from creating the best game experience for me...whether it's building a house, fighting a skeleton, crafting new armor, cultivating crops, or finding some of those rare jukebox records!SO...HOW DO YOU LIKE IT?Well, I've come a long way since my first Minecraft session. I've made a well-fortified house with stone walls (zombie proof), a crafting table in one corner and a furnace in the other. On the opposite side I've put three large storage chests, stocked to the brim with various items in case I meet an untimely death from any monsters that roam the wilderness. I have torches which hang on the opposite wall from my bed, so I can drift off to sleep peacefully.While I play, I have the choice of listening to the Minecraft music (which is quite soothing), or I can play any music I've saved to my PS3. I can fish while listening to "Sittin' on the Dock of the Bay", tend my crops while playing Pink Floyd's "Learning to Fly", dig for rare ores to the tune of "Canary in a Coal Mine"...the options are pretty much limitless.Even when I'm not playing Minecraft, I'm thinking about Minecraft. I think about mining for rare ores and creating new structures. I think about finding a new area and setting up a house before the night sets in. Even now, while writing this review, I'm thinking about finding the next secret Minecraft has waiting for me.But most of all? I'm thinking about my nephew's face lighting up like a Christmas tree when I tell him about my first steps into this world of limitless creation. He's quite the fan, having made a Pinewood Derby race car modeled after a Creeper, and his last birthday party was Minecraft themed.I've become "The uncle who plays Minecraft" - this allows my nephew and I to have fun discussions which weren't possible before I jumped into this game.FINAL THOUGHTS?If you like your video games with scripted starts and finishes, plenty of action or lots of shooting, Minecraft might not be for you. However, if you're looking for a fun game to play by yourself or with family members which encourages creativity and imagination, Minecraft is definitely the way to go.Very highly recommended!

Very few books pique my interest with just a dust jacket description. However, the one for The Frozen Dead pulled me right in. It promised a tale of revenge and madness, and it delivered on both these points, and many more.In the beginning, the story felt a little disjointed. The brutal murder of a horse? A new job at an institute for the criminally insane? What could this mean, and how would it all be connected? When one question was answered, five more sprang up in its place. The good thing is, the story was able to develop at a steady place and it was able to hold my interest for hours at a time. I couldn't put this book down because I wanted to reach the next revelation, the next clue, the next piece of evidence...I'll give my impressions of the two main characters:Martin Servaz was a captivating character for me because he wasn't a supercop. He had fears as well as flaws, he'd quote Latin in one moment and forget his gun the next. He'd scour over a crime scene, then he'd think things through and come back when he got a fresh idea. As he figured out what was happening and how all the pieces connected, it became clear to us (the readers) without feeling contrived or forced.It was a treat to watch Diane Berg grow as a character during her brief time in the Institute. She was eager to impress at her new job, working with dangerous patients in Unit A, interviewing a brilliant but deranged sociopath...this drew parallels to the relationship we saw between Clarice Starling and Hannibal Lecter in The Silence of the Lambs. I felt Diane's character didn't get as much growth as Martin Servaz's did, and I wish she could have shared the limelight a little more.I can't remember a time when I ate up a murder mystery novel as voraciously as this one. I read over 325 pages in one day. The characters were likeable, the story was intense, I could almost see the sweat dripping off people's foreheads as they faced their most terrifying fears. Bernard Minier has a gift (curse?) for unsettling descriptions - there were more than a few scenes which made me cringe after I read them.There's a lot to love in this story - secrets, betrayal, murder, revenge, and more. If you like your murder mysteries to keep you guessing with lots of plot twists, you'll be happy with The Frozen Dead.I wouldn't be surprised if this book gets optioned into a movie within a few years.

PROS:- Interesting premise- Wide range of powerupsCONS:- No checkpoints (except boss battles)- Awful password system- Low replay valueAs of 2014, this game is officially old enough to drink, and you'll probably want to after playing it for a while.The first 20 pages of the instruction book tells a very convoluted tale set in a futuristic world. The game starts with you being miniaturized and injected into Tiron Korsby, the president of Cybertech Corporation. Microscopic invaders have been injected into his body from a rival corporation known as Axiom - your goal is to reach Korsby's brain and destroy the Axiom invaders you encounter along the way.There are 5 levels to travel through - according to the instruction book, they are The Cephalic Vein, the Left Lung, The Superior Vena Cava, The Carotid Artery and The Brain. Strangely, when playing, one of the levels is renamed to "The Femur"...???From the onset, you'll learn how aggravating this game can be. Your ship has an infinite number of standard shots, and if you kill certain enemies, you gain powerups such as double shots, triple shots, flamethrower shots, etc. However, these powerups don't last very long. When you shoot, your weapons fly directly in front of your ship - the sound of your gun firing is louder than the noise of you hitting an enemy, so it's difficult to know if you're doing any damage at all. If you die before reaching a boss battle, you have to start the level from the beginning.All enemies move in a predictable pattern - as you play levels over and over (which you will, since you'll die a lot before reaching the bosses), it eventually becomes easier to predict their movements and avoid their fire.The most frustrating level is the 3rd, where you have to destroy a ship heading for Korsby's heart on a suicide mission. If you fail to destroy the craft before a certain point, it flies into his heart and kills him, ending the game. The ship flies all around the screen and rarely stays still for very long. The only way to defeat this enemy is to predict the ship's movements by playing this level over and over again.The password feature is infuriating. If you lose all your lives, you are taken to a password screen which presents 4 rotating symbols. The screen with those symbols lasts for roughly 30 seconds and then the code vanishes.**Thankfully, if you start the game again and select the "Password" option, the most recent code will be input for you.**While the graphics/music and boss battles for this game were impressive on the Amiga, a lot was lost in translation to the Sega CD. The grainy FMV footage is hard to see, the music has clearly been downgraded, and the boss battles are slow and predictable. Once you defeat the final boss, you'll be treated to one of the most boring endings to a video game since "Total Recall" for the NES. There's little to no replay value with this one.This game appealed to me because it took a lot of memorization to defeat and it's fairly rare - but for some gamers, rare doesn't always mean good.If you're an old-school gamer looking for an enjoyable shoot-em-up for the Sega CD, I'd personally recommend Sol-Feace - it's similar to the R-Type games and it'll provide a lot more enjoyment than Microcosm.

I've been a Gatorade fan since my youth (which is a Pepsi product), but recently our family has been bringing home Powerade drinks from its competitor, Coke. I decided to give this Mountain Berry Blast a try through Amazon's Vine program.I found this drink was slightly sweet and the berry taste was pleasant - it didn't taste overly sugary, and it didn't leave a bitter aftertaste. It tastes ok at room temperature, but as other reviewers have mentioned, it tastes better when chilled.I was a little put off by the amount of calories (130) and sodium (250 mg) in a single 8 oz bottle. If you're watching your salt intake, try Powerade Zero because it comes in a 12 oz bottle and only has 150mg of sodium, with zero calories.FINAL VERDICT?I enjoyed this drink after a run or a long walk, it hits the spot and tastes very refreshing. I'll probably stick to Powerade Zero, but if you enjoy new flavors of Powerade, give this one a try.

8:08 MinsIn this video I show you how to pair the Get Together to your phone, and I also play some music for you.PROS:+ LOUD when you want loud music, with very little distortion+ Simple to connect to various devices, strong Bluetooth signal+ Easy to move from place to placeCONS:- Can't adjust the bass- Portable, but no carrying strap/handle?- No protection for the woofers?

Being a video gamer for over 3 decades, I knew I had to have this ice tray the second I saw it.It's simple to use, and the silicone keeps the pieces from cracking when you remove them. I've chilled many a drink with these, and plan to use it many more times. I recommend removing the square cube first, it makes removal of the other cubes much simpler.**I've uploaded some pictures in the "Customer Images" section for you to look at.**My only complaint? It's too small. This tray is about the size of a CD case and it only makes 9 ice cubes, which disappear pretty quickly if you have more than 4 people over for your retro gaming parties.If another variation came out which could yield 15-20 cubes, I would happily shell out more $ for that.Don't be surprised if you find yourself arranging the cubes in your drink. :-)

I was sent a 24-pack of GURU through Amazon's Vine program, and I wanted to see how this "Natural Energy" drink worked on me.The smell and the taste of this drink is completely unique. The best description of the smell I can provide is...it smells like "watermelon tea". As far as the taste goes, it's harder to describe. It has a slightly sweet tang, which disappears rather quickly. There's a nice little carbonated kick which tricks my brain into thinking I'm having a soda, but without the usual overload on sodium.Keep an eye on the carbs, though - you get 25g per drink and 25g of sugars. This contributes to the 100 calories per can.I like the slim can design - 3.6 less ounces than a standard soda, and I never found the need to gulp down my drink.I had these over the course of a month and drank one in the afternoon around 3pm. It gave me just enough energy to keep my eyes open at the office, and they didn't make my heart trip-hammer or disturb my sleep schedule hours later.If you're looking for a powerful burst of energy, there are plenty of drinks out there which will give you what you need, such as 5 Hour Energy Bottles - but if you just need a push to start your morning or finish out your workday, GURU will get the job done for you.

I ordered these razors for my spouse through Amazon's Vine program, and here's what she had to say:"Whether you use soap, shaving cream or nothing (I tried all three), I couldn't feel the blade and I got a very smooth shave. It's easy to handle, it doesn't pull on my hair, I've been using the same razor every day for 30 days and I haven't had to switch to another razor yet. The only thing I didn't like? It's a little on the bulky side, I'm used to using the Bic Soleil Shimmer Razors which have a slighty slimmer design.I'd definitely recommend it. The first time I used the razor, I wasn't sure it was working until after I stepped out of the shower - a definite plus!"And there you have it. Tested and approved!

I am no chocolate expert - but I figured I'd give this chocolate bar a try through Amazon's Vine program.Since this is a 70% cocoa bar, I was expecting it to taste more bitter than a regular chocolate bar, which it did.The initial taste of the chocolate was very rich, but I found it had a flaky texture, which I am not used to tasting. There was also a noticeable waxy aftertaste. I had to eat a strawberry (or 3) to cleanse the taste from my mouth.There are several health benefits to eating dark chocolate (such as decreased blood pressure, lower risk of cardiovascular disease, etc), but for me, this came down to a matter of taste.While the initial taste of the chocolate is slightly bitter and very rich, the waxy aftertaste will keep me from coming back.

Changing light bulbs is one of those home maintenance tasks I can do without. We've been replacing our fixtures with longer lasting bulbs, and I decided to review this through Amazon's Vine program.There was a noticeable difference in brightness in our kitchen hallway when I replaced this bulb - the frosted cover gives the light a warm glow without being overpowering.Our previous one was a Satco S3870 130V 60 Watt A15 Medium Base Light Bulb, Clear which lasted about 5 years. I'll be interested to see how long this bulb lasts.According to the package, the bulb has a 5-year warranty if you use it for 3 hours per day at 120V. If it doesn't last for at least 5 years, return the UPC and the register receipt with your name & address to:GE LightingProduct Service Department1975 Noble RoadCleveland, OH44112Once this is done, GE will replace your bulb.The only negative I can think of is the price. Sure, there are cheaper bulbs out there, but this one balances out the high price point with their warranty and the claim of 13+ years of use.The next time I should have to change this out is 2028 - here's hoping it lasts that long!

+ PROS:+ An enjoyable 'gritty reboot' of the Tomb Raider series+ Borrows gameplay elements from Batman: Arkham Asylum and the Uncharted games+ Upgradable skills and weapons for the main game and multiplayer mode- CONS:- Tomb puzzles are almost too easy- Several missable trophies which can require another playthrough- Multiplayer mode is unbalancedPLOT:Our introduction to Lara Croft isn't the battle-hardened Lara we've come to accept over the years - this is an origin story. It's her first journey, on the ship Endurance. Ignoring the advice of her companions, The Endurance heads into the Dragon's Triangle. The ship is pulled apart by a violent storm leaving the survivors stranded on an isolated island. Lara is separated from the others and wakes up in a room filled with human remains, but manages to escape while a cave collapses around her. As Lara emerges on the side of a cliff, she sees the skeletal remains of ships on the shore below.She's wounded, tired, and alone...and her adventure is just beginning.GAMEPLAY:As with other games in the old series, Tomb Raider is presented as a 3rd person adventure game, with some stealth elements. When we first start out, we have no weapons, no special skills, and no tutorial level to practice jumping in Lara's mansion, as we had in the 1996 version. No, we're put right into the action here. We have to learn how to hunt, find weapons, and scavenge for upgrades.Lara can upgrade 9 different survival skills, 8 hunter skills, and 7 brawler skills. Throughout the island, there are hidden tombs which hold treasure maps, and other goodies.Some areas are inaccessible until we unlock certain upgrades (such as the shotgun for blasting through obstacle blockades, or the rope arrow to access certain areas).In combat, we can either use long range weapons such as a bow or a shotgun, or we can get up close and personal with a pickaxe or a well-placed arrow to the knee. There are some Quick Time Events during battles which allow Lara to perform finishing moves, or special attacks to weaken her opponents.The Quick Time Events also happen during cutscene transitions - so Lara might have to dodge a tree limb, avoid falling over a cliff, or punch someone with a well-timed press of a button.  No rest for the weary.Lara also has an ability called Survival Instinct - with the push of the L2 button, Lara can perceive nearby animals, hostiles, and even collectible items.This is the first game in the Tomb Raider universe which offers a multiplayer mode. There are three campaigns:(1) Team Deathmatch, a player-versus-player combat mode which lasts up to three separate matches.(2) Private Rescue, where the survivors have to take medical supplies to a specific area, and the scavengers need to reach a certain number of kills, all within 10 minutes.(3) Cry for Help, where the survivors search around and retrieve batteries for defended radio beacons while being hunted by the scavengers.TROPHIES:There are 51 trophies to earn in this game. Most of them revolve around collecting items like GPS caches, upgrading all your skills & weapons, finding all the hidden tombs, hunting certain animals and using specific weapons to rack up kills.**NOTE: If you're a trophy collector, 3 of them are missable in this game, so be sure to look up the requirements before you start playing!**15 of the trophies can only be earned in multiplayer mode. They run the spectrum from killing two people with one explosion, to reviving a teammate, to buying all upgrades & character models.PROS:I wasn't sure what to expect with a 'gritty reboot' of the Tomb Raider series, but I was very pleased with the result. I was able to identify with this character much easier than her 1996 counterpart. In that game, Lara was shooting bats and bears with her two-handed pistols (and their infinite ammunition) before 10 minutes had passed. Here, I didn't even start with a knife!This game uses the same dynamic as Batman: Arkham Asylum. When you first start out, you're not the battle-hardened Lara - she's scared, and she's inexperienced. I got killed more times than I care to admit. But while the game progressed and Lara became more accustomed to using her skills, I found myself becoming a more skilled combatant, which lead to me enjoying the story all the more.In the Uncharted series, we've been able to see all our collectible treasures in a separate window, and Tomb Raider also lets us do this. We can rotate the items or reread documents at our leisure, just like Drake. The folks at Crystal Dynamics clearly saw what worked for the games by Rocksteady Studios and Naughty Dog, Inc., and brought those elements together for an enjoyable Tomb Raider experience.I liked the upgrade system here. You have to gather experience by either hunting, exploring or combat. You can also use salvageable materials to fashion better weapons. I upgraded my survivor skills first to live off the land and gain experience faster, but there are excellent benefits to becoming a more efficient hunter or brawler.CONS:Firstly, I didn't find the tomb puzzles very complicated. Many of them require the player to pay attention to elements like timing or weight-distribution. A seasoned Tomb-Raider player from the 90s might find them overly simple, but for a person that's never played any of the previous games, these puzzles will present a few challenges. However, once you solve one, the others are very similar.Next, the trophies. A few of the trophies can only be earned during the single-player story. Because this game auto-saves, if you complete the game and miss your opportunity, you'll have to start the game all over again. There are three confirmed missable trophies, but thankfully, there's more than enough guides online to walk you through getting them. If you're not a trophy hunter, this isn't too big of a problem.Finally, the multiplayer mode. In my experience, this mode was horribly unbalanced. The first few times I played, I was matched up with opponents anywhere from level 31 to level 60, while I was a lowly level 1. My enemies had perfected their skills of jump-shotting around corners and under bridges, and could take out enemies on a rope slide with one arrow.But me? I was having trouble figuring out basic elements like swapping between my rifle and my grenades!As I slowly improved, I found that 95% of my quick joins to multiplayer put me into Team Deathmatch, which seems to get the most traffic. It's hard to get a bead on someone when they're jumping around like Peter Cottontail, and when you're a low-level player, this means your weapons will have a slow reload time...so you'll be used as target practice for the more experienced players.THE GLITCH REPORT:Thankfully, my game experience had very few glitches.In one sequence, Lara had to fix an elevator. When I fixed it, I couldn't get inside the elevator without instantly dying for no apparent reason.My next glitch came in the Summit Forest, Lara's Survival Instinct stopped working and I had to reboot the game to fix it...going back to the main menu didn't correct the issue.The last glitch was at Shipwreck Beach...everything was in slow-motion when I arrived. I had to reboot the game and thankfully this didn't happen again.FINAL VERDICT:I thoroughly enjoyed this gritty reboot of the Tomb Raider franchise. The main story was pretty linear, but there was more than enough backtracking to pick up missing objects and optional challenges to give it an open-ended feel. The combat was easy to adapt to, the music was epic, and the scenery was absolutely breathtaking.I didn't care for the multiplayer modes, but I would highly recommend this to adventure gamers, especially folks who like the Uncharted series.Rated M for blood & gore, intense violence and strong language. Several of the death scenes are very graphic in nature - parental discretion is definitely advised.

I can remember seeing The Texas Chainsaw Massacre at a friend's house on VHS when I was 22. I didn't remember much, but I remembered it scared the [redacted] out of me, and then some. I've seen many horror movies since then, but none of them tapped into pure fear the way this one did, and I wasn't sure why.When Gunnar Hansen's book became available to review through Amazon's Vine Voice program, I jumped at the chance to read and review it.Why? Because I wanted to know how this movie was made, from start to finish. I wanted to read stories of what happened behind the scenes. Most of all, I wanted to know what it was like for Gunnar Hansen to be a part of a movie that continues to entertain horror fans and draw crowds at conventions, decades after its release.The novel starts out with Gunnar Hansen dispelling a lot of the rumors right off the bat. He then proceeds to go through each scene in the film, from start to finish. He talks about his audition, getting his boots fitted with 3-inch heels, and how he could barely see out of his Leatherface mask. This led to a few mishaps on set, such as slamming his head into a door jamb and knocking himself silly, falling in the woods with his chainsaw still running, being driven to near insanity while filming scenes in 100+ degree Texas weather, and much more.Gunnar's writing style was very easy to follow. While he writes his memories of a scene, he intersperses stories about what happened before, during, and after those scenes. I got more than a few chuckles as he recalled the acres of marijuana growing behind the house, I was terrified as he described cutting into a table near an actor's head with a real chain saw, and I felt my skin crawl as I read about the scene with Sally's blood at the dinner table.As I read on, I started to remember why this movie scared me so much...it felt a little too real. When I watched it, I felt like it was a documentary or a snuff film, as if the wall between fiction and reality had been shattered. The way Gunnar tells it, this is what happened to the actors while the film was being made!Since TCSM was a non-union film with a low production budget, some stunts were improvised (like the gunpowder in the truck), most of the actors did their own stunts, and Gunnar had no stand-in as Leatherface. These facts make the movie all the more horrifying. It's truly amazing that no one was hurt or killed during the making of Chain Saw - In Gunnar's words, "It was pure luck-dumb, idiotic, inbred-toothless-country-boy-banjo-twangin' beginner's luck."So after roughly 164 pages (16 of which were excellent photographs), Gunnar wraps up his recollections on set. He then proceeds to go into post production stories, the new opening graveyard scene, waiting for his first check (which was a FAR CRY from his expectations), the reception of the film, the lawsuits that followed, and he even got to flex his literary muscles by talking about horror vs. terror, Gothic tales, and more.All in all, Chain Saw Confidental was a thoroughly enjoyable read. I kid you not, the night I finished reading Gunnar's book, this was my next Amazon purchase: The Texas Chain Saw Massacre [Blu-ray].And yes, it still scares the [redacted] out of me.Texas Chain Saw Massacre fans, rejoice! This is the book you've been waiting for. The rumors are squashed, the realism exposed, and the W.E. Slaughter family will have some good barbeque waiting for you.Very, very highly recommended.

9:08 MinsIn this video I show you what comes in the box with the Tylt Tunz speaker, I show you how to connect it with an audio cable as well as Bluetooth, and I play some music for you.**WARNING - I have the speaker on high volume while playing songs from 2:21 until 2:47!**PROS:+ Big sound from such a small speaker+ It's very easy to set up+ Charges your cell phones up to 50%CONS:- Bluetooth reception can be spotty at times-----------------**NOTE: If you want to avoid the startup and shutdown noise, plug an audio cable into the "aux in" port.This will work even if it's not connected to another device.

PROS:+ Only takes 3 hours to charge, as opposed to Sony's 6 hours+ A great low-cost alternative to the Sony PS3 headset+ Clear sound receiving and sending+ Comfortable fit, adjustable  ear hook and microphone placementCONS:- It's only fitted for the right ear- You have to use the charge cable with this product, PS3 cords won't work- Mute does not show on the PlayStation 3 screen------------------------------------------------Gioteck seems to have done their homework and improved on their previous EX-01 and EX-02 headsets. When I game online, I want to make sure that other players can hear me, I can hear them, and I can mute without too much hassle. The EX-03 meets each of my requirements.FIRST IMPRESSIONS:I was irritated by the small font in the instruction book, but that's a minor gripe.Pairing was a little cumbersome, I had to scan my headset to register it as a Bluetooth device, whereas my Sony PS3 headset was recognized by connecting it with a USB cable.PROS:I was happy to see it only took 3 hours to get a full charge on the EX-03 headset, my old Sony PS3 headset took 6 hours to fully charge.There were 3 earbuds included, and I used the smallest one. The earbud focused the sound inside my ear and was very soft, which was a vast improvement over my Sony PS3 earpiece.When I played Little Big Planet 1 and 2 and Splinter Cell: Blacklist, all the other players could hear me without any problems, and I could hear them loud and clear.The ear hook and microphone extension were easy to adjust to my comfort level, and even after a 2 hour stretch of gaming, this headset didn't cut into my ear or feel heavy with prolonged use. The volume up and down buttons were easy to use.CONS:The Gioteck EX-03 headset is only fitted for the right ear, so the lefties are out of luck on this one. It even says in the instruction manual "Unfortunately this is not possible." Truth be told, I rarely use my left ear for headset usage, but The Sony PS3 headset gave me the option to switch if I wanted to.Don't throw away the box thinking you can use your Sony cables to charge this headset - you have to use the charging cable that comes with it, nothing else works.When I put my headset on mute, there wasn't any visual indication on my PS3 screen (which does show up for the Sony PS3 headset) - instead, I would hear two descending tones about 4 seconds apart. If I wanted to turn my mic back on, I had to press the power button and I'd hear two ascending tones to indicate it was back on.MY VERDICT:On the whole, this is a very crisp and clear headset and does exactly what I want...allows me to hear and be heard without any discomfort. If that's what you want from a gaming headset (and you don't want to spend the extra $ for a Sony PS3 headset), then this one will get the job done.Recommended.

I'm a simple guy when it comes to popcorn - I want it to taste buttery and not too salty, and I don't want kernel shards sticking to the roof of my mouth. I'm happy to say, Jolly Time popcorn satisfied each of my requirements.This was a welcome change of pace from our usual popcorn, ACT II Butter Lovers Microwave Popcorn and Pop Secret Homestyle Premium Popcorn.HOW DID IT TASTE?This popcorn was excellent. It had the perfect balance of butter and salt, there was no need to add anything to it. Each family member of ours gave it two thumbs up, after we snacked!HOW DID IT POP?The popcorn we're used to (mentioned above) usually has between 10-15 unpopped kernels. However, Jolly time only had 3-5 unpopped kernels with each bag we tried.PRICING?This does cost more than our usual popcorn - but since we get more fully popped pieces, it's worth the extra $.ANY CONS?My spouse advised the bag didn't open like a standard bag of popcorn does, you almost have to put your hand into the bag to get it to fully open.FINAL VERDICT?If you want more popcorn for your pennies, this is an excellent choice!

+ PROS:+ Colorful levels jam packed with platforming gameplay and humor+ Hilarious fun for one or more players+ Unlockable levels, heroes, creatures and challenges- CONS:- Some levels/gameplay can be frustrating for younger gamersPLOT:Rayman (our cute little hero with no arms, legs or neck!) has been asleep for 100 years, along with his friend Globox and the Teensies. While they were sleeping, the Bubble Dreamer's nightmares got more powerful, and so did the magician (from Rayman Origins). Rayman and friends are woken up by Murfy who tells them about the Teensies and the 10 princesses getting captured by the nightmares and the 5 dark Teensies.  From here, Rayman and friends set out to defeat their foes and rescue their friends.GAMEPLAY:Rayman Legends combines elements of platform gaming and "endless running" platform gaming. Rayman can jump, use his ears as a helicopter to slow his falls, wind up and deliver a big punch/kick to his enemies, and even throw fireballs on some levels. There are several checkpoints within each level, so if you perish before reaching the end, you keep all the Lums and Teensies you collected...a sigh of relief to all the old-school platforming gamers.The goal of each level is for Rayman to rescue as many Teensies as possible, while also collecting Lums. Some of the Teensies are in plain sight, but you'll have to search around to find them all. At the end of each level, you receive a reward based on how many Lums you collected, and how many Teensies you saved. You can also earn scratch tickets, which give you a random reward such as 1000 extra Lums, a Teensie, a creature for your collection, or new Rayman Origins levels.The levels are either standard platforms, where you have to search around for the King and Queen Teensies and their 8 children, or there are shorter levels where you only have to gather 3 Teensies. Some of the levels allow you to take a relaxed pace, while others have a creeping wall of fire or rapidly sinking quicksand which require you to run as fast as you can to reach your goal. You'll also have Murfy show up from time to time to lend a hand with cutting ropes, moving objects, and even tickling enemies!Eventually you can unlock "Invaded" levels, where you have to rescue 3 Teensies as fast as you can, trying to reach the goal in under 40 seconds.There's a growing trend in Ubisoft games to have daily/weekly goal rewards for playing their games. We saw this in Splinter Cell: Blacklist (a decidedly different game), and it's also present in Rayman Legends. You can participate in daily and weekly game challenges. Instead of earning money to purchase weapon upgrades, we earn Lums to unlock new levels, new heroes, new creatures, and more.It's a fun little dynamic that keeps me playing each day to get my daily reward of Lums...after all, the last hero costs 1 million Lums to unlock, and every little bit helps!My descriptions may sound a little daunting, but I feel anyone who picks up a controller will fall in love with this quirky little character. Old school platform gamers (like me) and new school gamers will find challenges throughout each level.TROPHIES:It's an interesting mix of trophies for Rayman. If you just want to finish the game and defeat each boss, you'll end up earning about 15 to 20 trophies. However, there are roughly 30 more trophies to earn which will push your gaming skills to the limit. There's a trophy for collecting all 700 Teensies, collecting 1 million Lums, unlocking all 10 princesses, earning all the bronze/silver/gold cups, and even a few that require defeating your friends in some online challenges.PROS:I love the vibrancy of each and every single level in this game. Even if I'm getting killed by monsters, I find myself saying "Aww, they're so darn CUTE!" As soon as I picked one level to become my favorite, it wasn't long before another one took its place. I found myself laughing out loud at the pop culture references in Rayman Legends, such as:- The "goodbye" scene from Terminator 2- The "laser field dance" from Ocean's 12In all honesty, every boss level was hilarious. Each one is set to a musical number. If you know the song, it'll be that much simpler. From a castle onslaught to the tune of "Black Betty", to a Mariachi version of "Eye of the Tiger", to an underwater excursion to the tunes of "Woo-Hoo", I found myself dropping the controller during these levels because I was laughing so hard!My child loved going through the levels in two-player mode because if one of us screwed up, the other one just had to "pop the bubble" and we'd be back in the game. It really showed the benefits of teamwork.Collectibles? There are SO MANY in this game. Teensies, Lums, Scratch Tickets, Heroes, levels of Rayman Origins, Creatures...everything I find seems to unlock something else. It's the game that keeps on giving!CONS:I'll preface my "con" by saying this: Rayman Legends does a fantastic job introducing players to the gameplay. It's relatively simple to learn how to make Rayman jump and use his helicopter ears, and any good platform game requires its players to be able to judge distance and speed. You'll spend most of the game getting used to this, and might be lulled into a sense of the game being too easy.With that being said...By the time you reach the Olympus Maximus levels, you'll be hit with a few frustrating old-school platforming tricks, such as the infamous "Up is down, right is left" sections. You'll have to navigate screens with flipped screens, which are mercifully short, but take a while to navigate.The really fun/frustrating ones are the bonus "Living Dead Party" levels. These are the previous boss levels with the music converted to an 8-bit format, and so is the gameplay. This means the screen will fade in and out, pixilation will swell and shrink, and there are no checkpoints...you have to do the entire level in one perfect run.Old school gamers are used to "flawless run" requirements, but younger gamers might get frustrated after playing through most of the previous levels with checkpoints.WHAT WOULD I HAVE IMPROVED?The designers did such a great job with this game, I can't think of anything else I would have added. It's all here: personal accomplishments in single-player mode, help from family & friends with 1-4 player mode, online challenges, world rankings, it's all designed to strengthen our bond with Rayman, and I wouldn't change a thing.FINAL VERDICT:There's so much to enjoy here. Saving Teensies is especially fun, and the Lums accumulate as you get better and better and unlock more levels to explore and more heroes to battle evil with. There's a certain kind of joy that comes with hearing all the saved Teensies talking and laughing as you pass them by.I would definitely recommend this game for old school platform fans of games like Super Mario Bros. or Sonic the Hedgehog, and I also feel it's a great way to introduce younger gamers to the platform genre. Enjoy!

This worked extremely well on the high-traffic areas on our carpets. Food stains, scuff marks, they all came up with very little effort.The instructions were simple to follow - just spray the affected areas, wait one minute, then rub with a cloth/towel. After it dries, vacuum the area, and you're all set.One particular stain on our basement carpet was due to fingerprint dust getting spilled from our child's detective kit!We tried 3 different cleaners and nothing worked, but this kut right through the krud.Highly recommended!

In preparation to clean our shower stall this morning, I happened across a bottle of this. I sprayed a few times in one stubborn mold-ridden corner and worked on another task for a bit. When I came back 5 minutes later, the mold was gone. No streaks, no scrubbing needed, it was completely gone.This cleaner cut my average cleaning time by more than 1/2.It ate through mold and built-up soap scum pretty much on its own, I had very little scrubbing to do. I was able to clean 2 bathrooms in less time than it usually takes me to clean one!This product does contain bleach, and there's plenty of warnings on the back of the bottle if it gets in your eyes, on your skin, on your clothes, or if inhaled/swallowed. The bleach smell is pretty powerful, but it's a small price to pay for cleaning power like this.I couldn't have asked for a better mold & mildew remover.Very highly recommended!

9:08 MinsIn this video I show you what comes in the box with the Tylt Tunz speaker, I show you how to connect it with an audio cable as well as Bluetooth, and I play some music for you.**WARNING - I have the speaker on high volume while playing songs from 2:21 until 2:47!**PROS:+ Big sound from such a small speaker+ It's very easy to set up+ Charges your cell phones up to 50%CONS:- Bluetooth reception can be spotty at times-----------------**NOTE: If you want to avoid the startup and shutdown noise, plug an audio cable into the "aux in" port.This will work even if it's not connected to another device.

It's clear that a lot of time and effort went into making "World War II in Numbers". Almost every type of graph imaginable can be found within its pages about troop numbers, casualties, Gross Domestic Products of Axis/Allied countries, Top 10 costliest battles, and so on.The book is split into 6 chapters, some getting more attention than others:(1) Preparation for War(2) Land Campaigns(3) Weapons and Innovations(4) In The Air(5) At Sea(6) CostsIs there a lot of information? Yes. Does this book grab my attention on military history? Yes. However, there were some inaccuracies which kept me from enjoying it to the fullest.For example, on page 50 about Dunkirk: Operation Dynamo - there were no evacuation statistics for May 31st; the entire day was absent.Another item that bothered me was page 60 for Operation Barbarossa - this book states the Army Group Center had 52 divisions, but according to a few other sources I checked, it was 49 divisions. A small difference, but still significant.As a few other reviewers have mentioned, the most glaring error was found on page 197, the section on Hunting the Bismark. It read "With the 22,000-strong Kriegsmarine crew in the water" - but the compliment of the Bismark was only 2,200.A few errors are expected here and there in books, but when it comes to military history, I expect high levels of proofreading.All in all, I liked the graph layout, since they made the numbers leap off the page in greater detail. However, because of the errors throughout the book, I found myself doubting the numbers which were presented.

I'm a pretty simple guy when it comes to Bluetooth headsets. I rate them on the following:(1) Ease of setup(2) Comfort on my ear(3) Length of charge(4) Ease of phone appI'll give you my impressions how this headset measures up, I used this on my HTC One X.SETUP:On my smartphone, I went to the Bluetooth menu, and it recognized the headset and paired right away. No code entry was required, but depending on your phone, you might need to enter a pairing code (which is provided in the instructions). I then downloaded the "My MotoSpeak" app, which was very easy.When you flip the mouthpiece down, a voice will announce: "Phone one connected. More than [x] hours of talk time."COMFORT ON MY EAR:This is a very, VERY comfortable headset. The headset can be adjusted to fit either the left or the right ear with easy adjustment, There is no need to remove and reattach the hook.I've uploaded a few pictures to "Customer Images" for you to look at.It can pivot up or down to your comfort level, and it didn't feel heavy on my ear.LENGTH OF CHARGE:A full charge gives you 8 hours of talk time. I typically this headset for about 45 minutes to and from work,  and I have over 6 hours of my charge left.EASE OF PHONE APP:This is the big selling point for this headset, My MotoSpeak (Current version is 3.0.57).The app allows you to do hands-free sending and receiving of text messages. If you don't have the headset in, you can still have your phone read messages aloud, but sending messages is harder without the earpiece, unless you speak loudly. You can add an optional signature line to your messages, but I disabled this.If you get a text while driving, there's a blip on the earpiece and you'll hear:"Text from [person's name], Listen now?"You can say "Yes" or "No".If you say yes, the message will be read by a female voice. Once it ends, the voice will say "Reply?" And you can say the following: "Yes", "No", or "Repeat" to repeat the message.After speaking your message, it will read your reply back and then say "Send the message?" and you can say "Yes" or "No". If everything's fine, I pick "Yes" and the message is sent. If it didn't recognize what I was saying, I'll pick "No". It will then say "Try Again?" and you can either choose "Yes" (which allows you to rerecord your reply) or "No" (which closes the message).When you press the button on the headset, it will say "Say a Command". If you say "Text [name]", the phone will repeat the name you spoke and then say "Opening Text message. Say your message". At this point, you're ready to go.No voice recognition software is perfect, but this one is very accurate for me. Heck, it recognized the word "gobbledygook" - and any headset which can do that is top notch in my book.ANY DRAWBACKS?Well, it's mainly the app I have issues with. If I get a call and someone text messages me, the message will not be read to me when the call is over. It would be nice if a future version of this app has a menu option to listen to the most recent message.I also found this is not compatible with Google Voice on my phone, so I have to turn off the headset if I want to do updates for Twitter or Facebook.FINAL VERDICT?Overall, this is a very comfortable Bluetooth headset. It is easy to set up, comfortable, and holds its charge. The app needs some work, but 3 out of 4 isn't bad.Definitely recommended.

I've been pretty happy with the Scotch-Brite products I've used. This product is very similar to the Scotch-Brite Stainless Steel Cleaner, but it came with a hard plastic tool instead of a spongy tool.Our stove is 5 years old and it's taken a lot of abuse with various sauce stains and general wear & tear. Since I had fairly good luck with the other product, I decided to give this one a try.First off, the Frustration-Free packaging is exactly that. Opening the box couldn't be any simpler.The self-adhesive pads are very easy to apply - just put them on the bottom of the applicator and you're ready to go.There was a LOT of cleaner on the pads, and I used a paper towel to clean away the excess once I finished the job.
