Well, I gave our Yorkie half a stick immediately after a bath as a peace offering.  He sniffed it for a bit, maybe thinking poisoning was next on the list after being duped into a bath.  Once he realized it was legit, he gobbled it up quickly.  Actually, it';s more like he inhaled it.  I gave him the second half, same result.  He then followed me around the house, hopping on his hind legs to beg  for more.  So, yes, I reached the conclusion that he loves them.  Based on the texture, aroma and appearance, they seem like doggy a version of of Slim Jim.  The ingredients seem safe: beef, salt, citric acid, cultured dextrose, paprika, black pepper and garlic powder.  It claims to contain no corn, wheat, or soy. Our little guy can sometimes have an intolerant belly, so it's good to know there's nothing funky in the ingredients.

The PX24 comes with an in-line amp that boosts sound and offers features primarily geared toward gaming such as surround sound and superhuman hearing which reduces overall noise and amplifies quieter sounds such as footsteps, rustling leaves, etc.  Gaming sound quality is very good.  The virtual surround sound delivers in both primary and ambient gaming sounds.  The remote is battery powered via non-removable rechargeable battery.  A micro-USB charging cable is included.  The amp has a toggle switch to choose between preset console and PC/mobile sound profiles.  The headset sounds very good on gaming consoles and PC’s during gaming.  Use of the amp is optional but it noticeably enhances the sound.  It’s not just a gimmick and I can’t see using the headset without it.The headset is comfortable despite slightly firm foam cups. I don’t feel the inner panels making contact with the ear which is good. There is no excessive pressure nor discomfort during long periods of use.  A four-hour Little Big Planet session confirmed this fact. They also easily adjust to fit heads of all sizes.  The flexible boom mic can easily adjust to any position and sounds pretty good.  The very flexible mic design allows the most adjustment options for positioning the mic just right. Mic sensitivity and overall voice quality are both very good as well.Although the headset works well for gaming, I found them a bit lacking for listening to music on my PC and my iPod.  These are engineered primarily for gaming and it shows.  During music playback, highs are semi-flat at best and bass is non-existent and the sound sometimes suffers distorttion or briefly drops out altogether for a split second on lower frequency sounds when using the amp.  Without the amp, music is just too flat and dull sounding compared to other headsets or even a set of earbuds.  I would recommend these exclusively for gaming rather than dual purpose use for gaming and music.  Otherwise, a very good quality gaming headset that won’t break the bank, especially considering the features that are included.

This headset fits comfortable for long periods.  The ear cushions are made of firmer material than the pads on some of our other headsets.  Pressure is decent on ears and top of head.  Despite being a little on the firm side, there is never any discomfort, even during marathon gaming sessions.  I’ve owned headphones with softer pads but tighter or awkwardly fitting frames that felt much worse than these, even after short periods.They sound really good with a nice even balance.  No tone ever overpowers another.  I listened to several songs through them and even from a music source in another room, they sound quite well playing music.  There is no excessive vibrating bass, nor piercing highs nor flat mids.  Gaming sounds are great too.  Whether its an action game like Bloodborne or a music based game like Osu, these phones do a good job of bringing the game to life and creating a truly immersive experience.  They also do a good job of blocking unwanted outside noise.  Besides having great sound quality, the mic is nice and loud. It’s far better than the mic on the PDP afterglow that this replaced.The wireless range is decent as well.  I can easily walk from room to room while listening to music on the same floor without any noticeable loss of signal strength.  Battery life so far has been impressive.  We can easily get a few days filled with several hours of gaming out of a single charge.The Corsair logos on the sides stylishly glow multi-colors and the safety manual is hilarious. Really, it is.  Make sure you read it.

The Nest cam is small and sleek yet heavier than its deceptively lightweight appearance.  The bundled insert promised that after installing either the iOS or Android app, setup “should only take a minute. Literally.”  My setup was closer to thirty minutes primarily due to bluetooth issues, app crashes, account creation and the camera failing to show up in the app after setup.Once finally up and running, I found performance to be a mixed bag.  Video quality is quite good, even in night vision mode.  Streamed footage is crisp and sharp, especially on high resolution mobile devices.  You can pinch-zoom live video.  Streaming is generally good but is sometimes laggy, even with strong network connectivity on both ends. Sound is so-so.  The sound being picked up by the camera is very quiet regardless of how high I set the volume on my device.  On the other end, anyone in close proximity to the camera can hear me clearly when I activate the two-way talk feature.  The Nest app, while generally good, can be buggy at times, either crashing randomly or not detecting active cameras.  The camera does tend to get very warm during use as I discovered when I attempted to relocate it right after shutdown.The Nest Cam does not record video to a local source. Video is streamed, stored and accessed remotely on the company’s servers.  I would prefer a local recording option like a micro-SD card or NAS recording at the very least.  Nest offers paid subscriptions to access recorded video.  The prices vary depending on length of subscription and desired number of days for retention of footage.  Currently, 10 and 30 day retrievals are the only options offered. The subscriptions start out relatively cheap (e.g. $10 for 10 days, 1 camera).  However, prices could easily and quickly skyrocket depending on the number of cameras used and desired retrieval duration.  Make sure you research the prices thoroughly before investing in multiple cameras.I hope Nest considers offering an onboard or local recording option.  Without it, the Nest is practically worthless as a true security device, even with a subscription. I know you can download video for your own offline archiving but in all honesty, who is going to do that every one, ten or thirty days?  This is a nice quick and dirty solution for live streaming whenever you want to do a spot check on your residence.  Beyond that, unless you ante up for a subscription, I don't see much more benefit.  I currently own a Logitech Alert camera system.  It's over five years old and still works like a charm.  Each camera has its own 16gb micro-SD card capable of storing several months worth of data. Logitech offers a subscription service too.  However, with local recording capability, unlimited motion sensor alerts, IR night vision, a robust desktop app that automatically archives footage from the cards wirelessly over the LAN and a pretty reliable mobile app, I've never needed to subscribe to it.  I could pull recorded footage from 2010 if I wanted to do so.  That's what I consider a good security solution.

This powder smells delicious, like the boxed cake mix.  That's about it for the pros. I really tried to give this powder a chance despite the high sodium amount. However, the longer I used it, the more I began to dislike it. The consistency of the powder is softer and more powdery than typical protein powders.  It has a similar feel to flour. Once mixed, the shake is very thick.  Many times, even with adequate fluid, it wouldn't mix fully. I typically find myself swallowing chunks of unmixed powder despite vigorous shaking. The first time I used it, I initially mixed it with 8 ounces of almond milk.  That is normally enough for my other protein powders but not this powder.  The shake was so thick, it was undrinkable.  I was away from home and out of milk, so I added 4 ounces of water to the shake to thin it out enough to be drinkable. Make sure you mix it with at least 16 ounces of fluid and shake for a long time. Initially, I didn't think the taste was too bad. It wasn't good by any stretch but tolerable. However, the longer I used it, the more I began to really see how bad it truly tastes.  It's now to the point where I force myself to chug it down because I find the taste disgusting. It's too salty, too clunky and tastes like salt and flour mixed with water.  For vegan protein, I'll stick to my Vega Sport. I figured I'd finish this off rather than having it go to waste but I don't know if I can tolerate it much longer to be honest.

My daughter just entered her sophomore year.  The new version of the SAT will be live by the time she’s ready to take the test, so I want her to begin preparing for the new SAT as soon as possible.  We have used Kaplan guides in the past for the (still current as of this review) SAT and found them very helpful.  My oldest two children were accepted into very good schools using Kaplan SAT prep guides as part of their study and preparation tools. This version addresses all of the relevant sections in the new test: math, reading, writing and language.  It also includes a section for the soon to be optional essay.  There is one practice test in the book and two additional online tests are available after you register the book at Kaplan’s web site. Answers to the practice test questions are provided along with explanations.I like the essay section not only for the prep tools and the guidance offered.  Students may be inclined to skip the essay once it becomes optional on the new SAT.  Many students may not know for certain if any schools they ultimately apply to will require an essay.  I agree with the book that it’s better to have the essay completed and in hand.  It doesn’t hurt to write the essay.  The essay section is just as comprehensive and helpful as the other sections.  The book doesn’t merely gloss over it.  There is also a writing section where you can practice forming and writing the essay.The guide comes with a money-back satisfaction guarantee but it’s rather weak.  If you don’t like the book, you must mail it to Simon and Schuster within 90 days of purchase.  You also must include your original receipt and a fifty word or less explanation of why you are unsatisfied.  The book is pretty large, so factoring in return postage along with everything else, I doubt many people would go through the trouble even if unsatisfied.  On the bright side, we’ve been satisfied with Kaplan study guides, so the guarantee is mere eye candy as far as we’re concerned.

Bought this for my daughter during Amazon's "Prime Day".  She loved it initially but one of the crystals inside popped loose and got stuck in the date window.  I read other reviews about jewels popping off but figured "not us".  WRONG.  Not only is it unattractive and annoying, but it's also not covered by the warranty.  Movement and mechanical malfunctions only, nothing cosmetic.  So this will be my last Relic watch.  I plan to wait until Black Friday and get her a better quality watch.  Thankfully, my daughter is a sweetheart and keeps telling me not to worry about it, but it's still upsetting when a gift from the heart fails within 60 days.These jewel encrusted watches seem cute but they're not worth the trouble.  Buy something a little less gaudy with less chance of non-covered "cosmetic" defects.

I’ve always felt that a true pure entrepreneur is the person who dreams, conceives, hustles, builds, fails, rebuilds, learns, succeeds and grows or sell to start all over again.  Most if not all of the successful business owners that I know personally learned by doing, failing, trying again, failing, learning from their mistakes as well as mentors and/or role models, trying again and finally succeeding.  I remember talking with one of my more technically challenged friends who owns a pretty successful brick and mortar business.  He mentioned how he was working on a completely unrelated service oriented website.  Here’s a guy who doesn’t even know how to install Windows on his own PC talking about launching a web startup despite already owning a successful business.  That’s entrepreneurial thinking.  Technically Most of us are what the author refers to as “wantrepreneurs”.  We read the same books, watch the same TED talks, listen to the same podcasts and utilize the same tactics for startups, funding and  business culture.  As the author shares, many feed into the concept of broad entrepreneurship being a new concept ushered in by the Millennials.  The current startup craze became all the rage with the advent of web 2.0 and, social media and mobile devices.  This has resulted in a mindset of likeness, entitlement and lack of individuality.  In a nutshell, this book is about breaking away from what the plugged in world would have you believe to be the norm and think differently.Besides telling his own personal story of success, offering numerous real world examples as well as mentioning the aforementioned millennials, Tabok mentions how we are pretty much dumbing down by repeating the same patterns that enable the few to get rich and continue to widen the wealth gap.  We waste our time on social sites that simultaneously drain our earning ability while enriching the site’s owners.  This is a reason why I have myself abandoned Facebook (and chose there title for my review).  His seven rules for accomplishing goals may seem pretty obvious or even as if you’ve read them before (you have), but people just don’t take them seriously.  In all, he spends the bulk of the book basically explaining how if you’re ever to get anywhere, stop thinking like those around you, stop conforming to norms, be willing to take risks, be disciplined and trust yourself. Establish the proper balance between life and work and always remember to take care of yourself.  The car can’t run at top efficiency if you fail to properly fuel and service it. Most of all, be an effective leader and blaze your own trail.I found this to be a good read and was specifically intrigued with his views about the role that the Internet can play in the life of a modern day entrepreneur. However, as I say about every business book I review, there is no magic formula for success.  Use this advice as a guide or map but ultimately, your success or lack thereof will depend on you and whether or not you take action.  These books share the mindset of successful people.  It’s your job to cherry pick the valuable traits that you can assimilate into your life as long ass they work with your personality, energy level and abilities.  We’re capable of much more than we think when armed with proper knowledge.

This is a decent quality ball for the price.  It's easy to dribble and shoot with large or small hands.  It has good bounce and handling ability on a wide range of outdoor surfaces.  It's the perfect playground ball.  It's not slippery or awkward feeling at all.  It has a nice grippy rubbery surface. The first ball I received had the a part of the orange coating peeling off.  I returned it as defective and ordered a replacement.  The second ball was fine.  After numerous trips to the court, including dribbling on the way to and from the court, the surface of this ball is still perfectly fine with no peeling.  That convinces me that the first ball was just defective.  Defects can happen to any ball, even the $100 "Official" NBA leather balls. If you're shopping for an outdoor ball, avoid costlier balls and just grab this one.

This unit replaced my Sony BDV-E770W home theater system.  That system uses 5.1 channel speakers with proprietary plug-in connectors, so I had to invest in a new set of speakers.  After relegating the older system to my bedroom television, I connected this to the family room TV and  splurged on a new set of 7.1 speakers. Sound quality is top notch.  Besides home theater, this is definitely the new way to play music.  The first half of my life was spent listening to vinyl records, cassette tapes, an 8-track cassette for a short time (man, was that awful..)  and then compact disks.  The second half is the era of digital music and streaming.  So as someone from a bygone era, I can appreciate how everything is consolidated into one device and gone are the days of multiple piece “stereo systems”  (receiver, turntable, tape deck, CD player, equalizer, etc).  Obviously, sound quality is going to depend on the type and the quality of your speakers as well as the speaker wire.  You don’t have to spend a ton of money on overpriced items. You can get equal or better quality at the right vendors and avoiding certain designer brand names.  I invested in 7.1 but you can use 5.1 as well.It may seem minor but my fave benefit of this receiver is the five in, single out HDMI ports.  One problem I had with the BDV-E770W was the lack of HDMI out.  I didn’t know the importance of this at the time until using up all four HDMI ports on my TV.  As our system grew to include in addition to the BDV-E770W, a cable DVR, a PS4, a Wii-U, and an Apple TV, we found ourselves one port short.  I thought of purchasing an HDMI switch but good luck finding one with even a scant hint of reliability based upon reviews.  Then this beauty of a receiver came along for review and solved my problem.  The HDMI ports are labeled to enable different systems, game, Blu-ray, cable, etc.  I currently run a PS4, Apple TV, Wii-U, Cable DVR and even added a Roku to the mix.  Apple TV and Roku seem redundant but they’re not.  Rook gets many channels Apple TV does not.  Speaking of Apple TV, we usually use that instead of Airplay because it interacts flawlessly with our iOS devices and Macs.  We don’t use Android devices, so Googlecast streaming is no big deal to us.  However, we have several close family members who are Android devotees, so it’s a good feature to have when those relatives visit and want to stream from their devices.  Wifi connectivity with my router is flawless and I had no issues with setup, configuration or use.If you need or want manuals for the receiver, go to Sony’s main web site, (just add a dot com after their name. Very simple), click “support”, then click “manuals, specs & warranty” (or any of the other support options), enter STRDN1060 in the search box click “Go” and you will have every manual, guide or quick start at your fingertips.  You’d be hard-pressed to find many devices include full blown manuals in the box, especially the smartphones, gaming consoles, tablets and other electronic devices this receiver supports.

8/27/15 update: Well, I've been taking this product regularly for over a month. After decades of discomfort, zero relief from numerous GI docs and pretty much giving up any hope of having a normal digestive system, I feel great! All of my digestive issues have disappeared. That's not hyperbole, it's fact. You name it, I've tried it. Zantac, Prilosec, Compazine.... Nothing worked. I've been scoped so many times, I should have a wing of the endoscopy clinic named after me. GI docs were little to no help. "Stop eating leafy foods", "stop consuming dairy", "it's just something you unfortunately have to deal with".  One GI doctor actually told me it was perfectly normal that I was taking up to eight pills of Immodium daily to prevent the production of gastrin. After a month on mastic gum, my stomach feels as normal and healthy as it did nearly 25 years ago. That's the last time it felt normal.  I can now eat pretty much whatever I want without disastrous consequences afterward. No more taking Immodium before each day trip as a safeguard. The best part is I haven't experienced any side-effects whatsoever. If you have stomach issues, do yourself a favor and try mastic gum.  Even if it's not Jarrows, just try it. I do plan to stick with Jarrow. If it ain't broke, don't fix it.  I never heard of imastic gum before it was offered to me through Vine but I plan to continue using it regularly.  I'm about to order a new bottle after I finish this update. That's what prompted me to update and add that fifth and well deserved star.I am the perfect candidate to try this product.  I have suffered with stomach issues for decades.  At times, my stomach pains were painful enough to end up in ER.  I wasted valuable years being misdiagnosed with the generic condition "I.B.S" (irritable bowel syndrome).  I got so tired of that diagnosis that the acronym took on an entirely different meaning in my mind. Every time I'd hear another doctor say "IBS", I'd think to myself "yep, you sure do."  I finally received a proper diagnosis a few years ago.  The problem is that by then, the damage was already done.  As a result, one of the conditions I now suffer from is low stomach acid.  This results in an overproduction of gastrin which causes tons of discomfort.  I have been taking care of myself and eating a diet suited to my condition.  However, I still have occasional days where overproduction of gastrin makes for a miserable experience.  I was offered the opportunity to try this mastic gum and decided to try it out. I'm not looking for short-term or immediate relief of temporary discomfort.  I'm looking for an all natural method to help with long-term maintenance and symptom prevention.I have been taking the mastic gum for nearly two weeks now.  After decades of suffering, I'm not going to immediately crown anything as the miracle cure.  However, so far, the mastic gum tablets have been doing pretty good.  I haven't had any bad stomach discomfort (intense pains and cramps) since I started taking it, so that's a definite plus.  I also noticed, and I'll put this delicately, a difference in the bathroom.  I won't get into all the explicit details but let's just say things run more smoothly from start to finish.  I have no sudden urgency to go, no inability to go nor do I go too frequently as I routinely experienced before starting the gum.  I'd like to continue to see improvement for at least an entire month before I accept mastic gum as a long term tool for relief.  I really like the improvement in my digestive comfort that I've experienced so far and have every intention to continue taking it for the foreseeable future.  With that being said, it's not a cure-all.  I still eat a diet appropriate for my condition and make sure I get adequate water and fiber daily.  IF not, even the mastic gum can't prevent certain discomforts.  I've already found this out firsthand when I didn't get enough fluids or fiber one day in particular.The pills are rather large and the bottle instructs to take two at a time on an empty stomach (1000mg).  I started with one until I was certain there were no reactions, side-effects or intolerance.  I can personally swallow both pills relatively easily but they are pretty large. There is a slight plant-like smell but no taste through the capsules containing the powder. The bottle has a two month supply (120 500mg pills).  It contains no gluten or dairy and is vegan safe.

These buds are pretty decent sounding for the price.  Although they don’t sound as good as the $120 buds I bought my wife this past winter, they easily beat out my iPhone bundled OEM buds.  The bass, while noticeable, isn’t deep or heavy.  It sounds fairly decent for a set of inexpensive buds and balances nicely with the treble and midrange.  However, I have to clarify that the bass doesn't always sound good.  The higher the volume, the better the bass sounds.  At lower volumes, it tends to sound flat or disappear altogether.  Overall sound seems pretty crisp although the gel caps can occasionally cause friction noise while moving.The buds fit nicely in my ear and stay put with little or no movement even when I’m active.  I’ve exercised with them while constantly moving my head and body without any issues with the buds popping out.  Besides a perfect fit in my ear canal, the cord is just the right length to reach from my iPod in my pocket to my ears without the buds popping out due to the cord being to short or he buds being ripped out due to the cord being too long.  I’ve purchased numerous bargain buds from Amazon, from as little as $7 to roughly the same price as these.  These buds are among the better sounding of the bunch.  They’re pretty decent sounding for budget priced buds.

I picked up this set for under thirty bucks on sale.  For the money, it's a hard to beat value.  Sound is good, not great but definitely not bad.  There is no static or interference and voices are loud and clear.  The sound quality isn't absolute top notch crystal clear like it was on the > $100 phones I typically bought in the past.  However, given that I spend very little time talking on landlines anymore, it is more than adequate.  The speakerphone is also nice and clear and not muffled like it is on some other inexpensive phones.  The batteries last several days between charges, even with moderate use. Most of the ringer tones are nice and loud.  That means you don't have to choose a ringer tone that you may like a little less than another simply because it's the only loud tone.  The illuminated keys make the phone easier to use not only in dim lighting but even in regular lighting.  Lastly, it has built in voicemail autodialing and message waiting indicator that work nicely if you subscribe to home voicemail through your telecom carrier. Of course, nothing is perfect, so there are a few cons, nothing major.  I wish the LCD backlight were just a tad brighter or even adjustable.  I can't even tell if it's illuminated in moderate light.  The LCD also doesn't have much contrast.  My old Panasonic handsets were much more contrasty by comparison.  I could see the data on the LCD from across the room on those handsets whereas this phone has to be within 3 feet for me to read the LCD while illuminated and closer than a foot to adequately read it when not illuminated.  Adding to this issue is the fact that the phone does not have any flashing LED lights to indicate when you have voicemail messages awaiting retrieval. Then again, neither does my iPhone, so I'm already used to that inconvenience.  The menu system can be a little confusing to navigate at times.  When I use the directional pad to check caller ID or access the directory, it's hard to tell one form the other.  You have to push up to access the phone book and down to access caller ID.  The natural inclination is to continue pushing the up button to cycle through the phone book.  However, the correct method is to push up and then push down to cycle through.  You can still cycle through by pushing up twice, but the phone beeps indicating an error before proceeding.  It just feels a bit clumsy.  Speaking of funky buttons, if you are on speakerphone and push "Talk" to attempt to switch to the handset, it disconnects.  You have to push the "Speakerphone" button.  This has resulted in more than one episode of phone rage after spending (or more like wasting) up to an hour on hold only to inadvertently disconnect the other party when they finally answered.So far, I am very happy with this phone, especially for the price.  The only thing I miss from my old Panasonic is the audible caller ID.  It was very convenient to know who was calling without looking at the handset.  It almost made telemarketers and other annoying callers somewhat tolerable.  Other than that, I'm very satisfied with this phone.

As a Hoover SteamVac user for many years, I'm hard pressed to find anything particularly different about this machine compared to the consumer-grade version. The design of my last purchased consumer-grade Hoover, the Hoover SteamVac Carpet Cleaner with Clean Surge, F5914900, is fairlly similar, except the consumer model has an accessory hose included.  Suction and cleaning ability are about the same.  Operation and water tanks are the same right down to the fragile plastic side latches on the water return tank that I really dislike.  The extraction motor has the same amp rating. Other than a 35-foot orange heavy gauge power cord, I am honestly hard pressed to find anything that truly sets this apart as a commercial steamer.Having said that, I've always loved the performance of my Hoover SteamVacs.  They are super easy to assemble. Two screws w/nuts, a philips head screwdriver and two minutes of time is all it usually takes to assemble.  Hoover SteamVacs have also been very good and reliable cleaners for me over the past two decades.  They helped me clean after several kids and a few dogs over the years.  This commercial cleaner so far seems just as effective at loosening and removing soil from carpet as the aforementioned consumer grade SteamVac.  I also own a Bissell ProHeat.  The biggest difference between Hoover and Bissell is primarily the tanks.  Bissell uses a single tank system with an interior bladder inside the tank for the clean water and the remainder of the tank used for the dirty water return.  Some are completely turned off by the design but I didn't find it that bad.  From a convenience and efficiency standpoint, the two tank system is better, especially when you need to dump any unused cleaning solution/water.  It's easier emptying tanks on the Hoover than the Bissell.  The biggest complaint I've encountered over the years on the Hoover vac has always been sudden loss of suction.  More often than not, it's caused by a poor seal on the water return tank or other opening. The one upside of the commercial version lacking the extension/accessory hose of the consumer version is the fact that it results in fewer potential leaks which could lead to dramatically decreased or complete loss of suction.I guess the only thing left to compare is durability.  As much as I  loved my Hoovers of the mid/late 90's and early 2000's, my last Hoover, the above mentioned consumer Steamvac was purchased in 2013 and broke within a year.  One of the plastic retaining clips on the side of the bottom tank snapped off.  It wasn't worth the attempt to repair, so I tossed it and began using a Bissell I had lying around.  I'm happy to be back to using a Hoover and curious to see if the commercial version is more durable.  Seeing the same plastic retaining clip on the commercial steamer doesn't exactly fill me with confidence but we'll see how it goes.  Honestly, if you are truly looking for a bonafide commercial steamer, I'd suggest looking for just that.  There just isn't enough about this commercial Hoover to justify recommending it over the much cheaper consumer-grade SteamVac.

I have used numerous vacuums over the years, both commercial and consumer.  Of the few commercial vacuums I've used the past 16 years, I never purchased any that included attachments.  For my particular needs, I never needed them on my commercial uprights.  I wanted models built like tanks with strong reliable motors, headlights and magnetic bumpers on the front for picking up paper clips, staples and other hazards before they got sucked up and potentially damaged the vacuum.  The consumer grade vacuums I use at home have all the fancy attachments and other bells and whistles.  My work vacuums were alway workhorses.  I prefer the basic but powerful and reliable vacuums at the office.  I'm vacuuming around desks and chairs, not inside sofa or love seat cushions like I do at home. I need something that can take a little abuse and withstand daily use in a commercial environment.This vacuum is extremely lightweight.  The body is primarily built of plastic.  Despite the lightweight feel, it is capable of handling occasional accidental bumps and knocks against furniture.  It does lack some of the commercial vac features that I prefer, like the aforementioned light and magnetic bumpers but it does have a thick industrial grade interchangeable power cord.  In fact, the cord feels like the heaviest part of the vacuum.  Although the included 35' cord is already long enough for most uses, I swapped it out with my own 50' cord.  Less plugging/unplugging.  The bag housing is a sturdy mesh fabric and unzips for very easy bag monitoring and changing.  The power button is illuminated was well as the high/low suction button.  The wheels are nice, large and grippy on hard surfaces.  I could honest push this thing all day long.  In addition to being light, the motor is so powerful, at times it almost feels like a self-propelled because you can feel the suction pulling the vacuum a bit.The star of the show is the motor.  I use commercial vacuums in large open areas that see a lot of traffic.  Suction is my number one concern.  I want to clean several rooms with wide open spaces as quickly and in as  few passes as possible.  In many small businesses, the employees or the owners do the cleaning rather than outside cleaners.  The last thing I, or anyone else, wants after a hard day of work is to be forced push a heavy ineffective vacuum four or five times over an area just to pick up all the debris.  The suction on this thing is insane. One pass is usually all it takes to get a nice clean carpet with no noticeable traces of debris.  I definitely didn't expect such performance out of something so light but the heavy duty cord suggests the motor drains some serious amps, and the suction power confirms it.  In that regard, the light weight is very misleading compared to the suction. Despite the effectiveness and power of the motor, it is also very quiet. The vacuum has a check bag light in the event the bag fills up or the nozzle clogs.  It also has a failsafe where the brush stops spinning to protect the belt in the event of a clogged nozzle. Bag, belt and brush roll are all user serviceable and replacements are easy, requiring nothing more than a philips head screwdriver at most.For the price/performance ratio, I really can't see a downside to this vacuum.  Obviously, if you require attachments or other bells and whistles, this probably isn't your vacuum.  The motor is also probably overkill for home use and doesn't include the attachments typically needed for home cleaning.  However, if you're a small business owner who doesn't contract out for office cleaning, this is an effective and powerful cleaner at a decent price point.  It's basic in design and function but for many businesses, that's all we need, as long as it cleans well.

This headset is very comfortable with soft cups that cushion the ear with virtually no pressure.  It’s  corded and plugs into an adapter that plugs into the port on the bottom of the Xbox One controller.  The adapter is similar to the factory bundled Xbox headset adapter.  Both have buttons that allow you to adjust volume and mute the mic.  This headset also allows you to mute sound through the cups.  The headset also comes with another cord that has an adapter that can split the single consolidated mic/sound cord into separate mic/headphone cords.  This makes the headset compatible with dedicated mic/sound ports, such as those found on computers. The microphone retracts in/out of the left cup and is flexible to be bent to a preferred angle.  There is another mic mute button on the left ear cup  The headphones adjust but they don’t open as wide as some others that I’ve owned.  If you have a large head or a substantial amount of hair, these may fit tight if at all, even at the widest opening.I’ve tried and owned numerous gaming headphones, from cheap sub-$40 models to high end models costing $300 or more.  I’ve learned that price isn’t always a true indicator of quality or sound.  These headphones are moderately priced, so although I wasn’t expecting the absolute best sound experience, I figured they’d sound a little decent.  Needless to say, I was a bit disappointed the first time I connected it to my Xbox One.  I kept hearing popping and crackling noises through the headset.  I heard the distortion while navigating the main Xbox One menu as well as in-game.  I tried the headset in a computer as well as an iPod and did not hear the sounds.  The sound quality of the headset while playing music is very good.  Not only did the popping and crackling disappear but the sound was clear and distortion-free with nice tight bass.  They also did a decent job of blocking outside noises.  I tried the headphones again with my Xbox, even after the latest system update and I still get the crackling and popping sounds.So, that leaves me in a little bit of a dilemma trying to rate the headset.  I’d give comfort, build and sound on iPod and PC a solid four.  However, if this headset were purchased exclusively for use on my Xbox, I’d likely give it a two or even one star because I am unable to eliminate the popping/crackling sound.  I can’t definitively fault the headphones because they work well in other devices. However, I also can’t definitively blame my Xbox or the controller because the cheap OEM bundled headset works just fine.  Taking everything into consideration, the fairest rating I could give was a three-star.  I read other reviews to see if anyone else experienced the distortion and apparently it doesn’t appear to be common.  Maybe I got a dud set.

There’s no nice way to say this.  Lightning cables are junk.  They fall apart, constantly.  It doesn’t matter who manufactures the cable, they are inherently flawed in their design.  For whatever reason, the rubber sleeve is extremely fragile at the portion leading up to the lightning connector.  It frequently rips and falls apart.  The cords damage very easily.  You don’t have to abuse the sleeve to make it rip.  Simply moving the phone around or attempting to use it while it’s plugged in can cause the cable to rip apart eventually.  Anything other than extremely careful use will usually result in a ripped cable eventually.  Apple users are some of the most devoted and forgiving in the business and even they almost universally slam lightning cables, primarily due to poor durability.  I have lost count of the number of cables I’ve replaced due to this problem.  I'm one of those extremely careful users and even I have had several opportunities where my cable could have ripped, usually by accidentally and slightly tugging on the cord while my phone was charging.  Normally, such a minor "abuse" wouldn't hurt most phones,, but these protecting these cables is like protecting a carton of eggs.  My wife and kids constantly use their phones, so they go through these cables like crazy.  None of us experienced these poor durability issues with the old 30-pin connector cables.  We had one or two fail due to bad connector pins but the cables themselves were very durable.I gave up on Apple's OEM Lightning cables long ago because ironically, they seemed to be the most unreliable brand of all.  They're also not exactly cheap.  Among the aftermarket brands, I have generally had good luck with Belkin Lightning cables.  They're usually thicker and more durable than Apple's cables. However, I’ve recently had two relatively thick Belkin cable sleeves rip apart along the rubber sleeve right before the lightning connector.  That's the same exact spot where all of the other cables ripped and failed.  I was offered the chance to try out this 90-degree angle Belkin cord and figured it was worth a shot to see if it makes a difference.  The cord is about the same thickness as Apple's OEM cable but feels more firm than the Apple cable.  I haven’t had it long enough to speak about long-term durability but so far, I like the design because it helps prevent pulling on the cord to remove from the phone. Almost every cord that I’ve lost has come apart near the lightning connector.  In redesigning the connector on a right angle, I'm hopeful that Belkin has found a way to reduce stress on the cord and finally offer a solution for the cord ripping issue. Believe me, I will be back to report if I have yet another cable fail prematurely.  Based on the fact that this cable pretty much forces you to pull the lightning adapter out by the connector and not the plug (unless you're completely reckless), I admittedly have some optimism that it might just last.  I've given the cable to one of the busiest iPhone users in our household.  The cord will be used regularly in multiple environments both at work and home as well as frequently swapped between wall and vehicle chargers.  I actually want it to be abused as much as possible so I can determine relatively quickly if it can withstand the rigors of what I consider reasonable normal use.  I hope it does.  It's a shame that I still have four fully functional 30-PIN connectors from older iPods and iPads.  One 30-pin cable is over seven years old and outlasted the iOS device itself.  However, out of ten Lightning enabled iOS devices, only two still have functioning original OEM Lightning cables.  The others have all had the cables replaced at least once, some multiple times.  I really hope Apple finds a new format or improves the design ASAP.  Until then, I hope this Belkin can prove to be more reliable.  The cord is manufactured in China (for those who may be curious to know) and is MFi certified.

I just gave this bag to my high-schooler to use. The bag it replaced, a High Sierra, was starting to show signs of age, wear and tear.  The Dell Bag is a little smaller than the High Sierra but does have some nice features.  For one, it seems to be built more for travel or active use.  It has a sizable pocket in the rear that should accommodate most laptops up to 17” and the middle compartment has a pocket sized perfectly for a standard 10” tablet.  The tablet will rely on whatever surrounds it for protection, so pack wisely.  The cushioning surrounding the laptop compartment is adequate and the rear of the bag is more dense and rigid than the rest but lacks a firm insert like many other bags have.  The Dell bag is also a tad smaller than the High Sierra bag.  The exterior is 100% polyester and has a glossy appearance compared to the more fabric-type appearance of the other bag.  The upside is that it also seems to be more water-resistant than the prior bag.  The bag has several compartments, clasps and other features to help accommodate active lifestyles.  It's versatile enough for active adults or students.  Hopefully, the durability matches the intended design.  We'll see how it fares over the upcoming school year.

We already use MAM, so we’re familiar with the design and features.  We’ve never had any problems  feeding with this bottle. The vents keeps the milk flowing easier and steadier with fewer stops caused by insufficient flow.  Our biggest concern isn’t colic but reflux.  The MAM bottles are doing well at keeping both issues in check.  MAM bottles aren’t the traditional three piece design.  There are several pieces and it comes apart at the bottom as well as the top.  That means more parts to assemble/disassemble for cleaning and longer prep times for feeding.  Also, if you’re not careful to properly align the threads, you will encounter issues with leaking.  This particular 5oz bottle includes a slow flow nipple, best for newborns.

Well, I was a little apprehensive about this book prior to reading.  I currently enjoy the whacky humor of Cracked and have followed it for decades, since the days when it was in magazine form and competing against the likes of Mad and National Lampoon.  Although I was a little unsure what to expect and admittedly had moderate expectations, Brockway actually wrote a very entertaining book.  The action gets started immediately on the very first page and from there, it alternates between calm and mayhem as we time hop between 1977 New York and 2013 Los Angeles following the actions of our two protagonists, Carey and Kaitlyn.  The detailed synopsis in the book description does a good job of outlining the plot, so I won’t rehash what you already know about the story.I’ll share my feelings about the book instead.  The pacing and character development are pretty decent although they can seemingly appear to be a little fast at times.  For instance, at one point, it instantly jumped from one character wondering what’s going on and fleeing from the strange events and beings to that character suddenly becoming a karate roundhouse kicking version of Buffy the Unnoticeable Slayer.  Once you understand Brockway’s time-hopping flow, things make more sense.  Brockway does a nice job of connecting the dots into a cohesive story and the end result is a fun, interesting and ultimately enjoyable book.  The Unnoticeables does have plenty of gore and sexual references (some of which are pretty strong).  Anyone who has ever watched and enjoyed an R-rated slasher flick will find nothing shocking, alarming or offensive within the pages.  In fact, some of Stephen King’s earlier works contained more gore and even more shocking sexual content.  I don’t think I’ll meet much opposition when saying King is also considered to be arguably the greatest horror writer of modern times.  So, unless you’re really faint of heart  (as in pass out at the slightest sight of blood), you needn't worry about being offended.  As for the book itself, I enjoyed it immensely.  It's been a while since I enjoyed reading horror.  After the aforementioned King decided to start moving out of the paranormal horror realm and into the thriller/horror, there was a void that actually went unfilled until reading this book.  I tried reading Koontz but just could't get into his style.  The Unnoticeables was genuinely fun to read and captivating.  It says it all when you sit a book down to take a break and immediately pick it back up and continue reading.I liked this book enough to check out some of Brockway’s other books.  I’m currently reading Everything is Going to Kill Everybody.  That one has more of a Cracked feel to it and more reminiscent of the crazy lists that Cracked frequently posts.  It's a fun book but the Unnoticeables is definitely in a class of it’s own as a true horror/fantasy/science fiction type novel.  At 286 pages, including acknowledgements and other beginning non-story content, it can easily be completed in a day and is a worthy read for science-fiction and horror fans.  I like Brockway’s carefree humorous writing style.  You also gotta love a guy who starts his book off by dedicating it to everyone who basically predicted his failure.  On one final note, I am reviewing an advance preview copy.  Therefore, it’s possible that some of the content or formatting may have changed in the final published version. I seriously doubt anything changed drastically enough to sway my opinion of the book but it’s still worth mentioning.

The short list of features on this lightweight no-frills iron include an ample sized water reservoir, non-stick soleplate, auto-shutoff, self-cleaning, 8.5 foot swivel power cord and variable steam.  The weight and ergonomics of the iron are a great for those looking for a lighter iron.  I personally prefer a heavier iron but that’s purely a matter of different taste.  This iron will satisfy most day to day ironing chores and is perfect for a limited living space such as a dorm room.  The heat and steam are suitable for any material, even more wrinkle-prone materials like denim and 100% cotton.  The light weight enables it to be more easily used on a variety of surfaces such as a mattress, for those without an ironing board.  It is also easy to store away thanks to a very manageable size and weight.

This soft and very comfortable mattress topper is a significant improvement over the primarily protective topper that was already on our bed.  I washed the original topper and now keep both toppers installed because the other has a more substantial liquid barrier.  I’m a bit of a klutz, so I like having a strong spill-proof barrier.  Both fit my mattress perfectly and work well together.  This topper remains cool and doesn’t absorb or reflect body heat while laying on it.  Although warmth is a good thing during the cooler months, I prefer warmth from the covers above me, not below.  You can always toss aside a comforter if it gets too warm. I’ve had many plush toppers and this one is among the softest and thickest of the bunch.  It doesn’t match the plush feeling of a memory foam topper but it will improve the comfort of most mattresses, especially those without a  pillow-top.  I don’t know hoe well it protects against fluid spills but the liner doesn’t appear to be as leak-proof as the topper beneath it, at least not when visually comparing the protective barriers.  Actual effectiveness could be different, so take that visual observation with a grain of salt.

These headphones are very cheaply made. They're basically constructed with a cheap plastic head band, low quality foam and thin paper. Everything is glued together.  They fell apart as soon as I took them out of the shipping bag.  The foam and paper separated and peeled away from the headband.  This happened on one side first and then the other.  I bought them for my daughter and she hadn't even had an opportunity to see them before they fell apart.  I began a return with Amazon but for eight bucks, it just wasn't worth it.  I'd considered building a pair myself but realized I'd spend at least eight bucks on supplies.  So I canceled the return and plan to glue everything back with stronger glue and hope it can withstand a couple days at max of cosplay.  I certainly don't expect anything more than that.

I got this base coat for my wife to try.  The first thing she had me do was feel the difference between an untreated nail and a treated nail.  I could tell the treated nail was slightly harder and less flexible.  She said she was satisfied with the strength and ability to help her prevent chipping another nail like she had recently done.  She also mentioned that it works fine with her nail polish.  She assured me that strength, appearance and performance with nail polish were the most important attributes.  The first day she wore it to work, she purposely didn't wear gloves so she could test how well it protected her nails.  She has a very hands-on intensive job and frequently chips her nails.  After that first day, she had no chips and her polish still looked freshly applied at the end of the day.  She's happy with the protection it offers.

El's 1986 solo album was but far his best in my opinion.  Gemini was nice too but this self-titled solo debut has the more memorable songs than any follow-up effort.  Lost Without Her Love Always is is number two among my top three fave solos ever by El.

El's 1986 solo album was but far his best in my opinion.  Gemini was nice too but this self-titled solo debut has the more memorable songs than any follow-up effort.  Love Always is is number three among my top three fave solos ever by El.

El's 1986 solo album was but far his best in my opinion.  Gemini was nice too but this self-titled solo debut has the more memorable songs than any follow-up effort.  Someone is definitely my top fave solo effort by El ever.  It's probably my favorite song sung by him even if you include his days as a member of Debarge.

I actually bought this along with Sahalmar's greatest hits album.  This is exactly what it says, the 12-inch collection.  For us pre-CD babies, there was once a time when radio played the album version and the delay version, AKA the 12-inch LP.  Hearing the longer versions of my Shalamar faves like Night to Remember brings back a lot of memories.  Loved this Shalamar back then and still love the group 30 years later.

This umbrella is a compact size.  It’s good more for portability rather than maximum protection from the elements.  I previously carried the long umbrellas because they open wide and provide adequate protection for tall guys like me.  I tend to have fewer problems with water draining down the sides of larger umbrellas and onto my legs and back like I do with smaller umbrellas.  Larger umbrellas also tend to be stronger and more solidly built.  The downside to larger umbrellas is that they are a pain to stow away both in the vehicle and while out and about.  Given my current limited need for an umbrella, a smaller model is now sufficient.  If you normally require a large umbrella and plan to use it extensively, this umbrella may not be wide enough.The vents seem like a good idea and, most importantly, don’t leak.  I haven’t had any severe storms to test them and I am seldom outdoors long enough to do so anyhow.  I usually go straight from garage to indoor parking on work days.  I primarily use umbrellas for the pit stops along the way.  However, there are days where I make longer outdoor runs or just hang outdoors for events.  I've encountered some spring rain but thankfully, nothing serious yet this season.  The most I’ve encountered so far was light to moderate rain, no severe storms.  If I do get a chance to use this in windy conditions and it fails to live up to the billing, you'll be the first to know.The construction seems 50/50.  The canopy material and ergonomic rubber grip both feel nice and sound.  The push-button to open works well.  The ribs seem to bunch up and get stuck during the opening and closing.  I had problems with the ribs on the very first use.  I have to be very careful to avoid bending or snapping them.  The clumsy action and fragile appearance of the ribs doesn’t particularly fill me with confidence and makes me wonder how long they will last.

After removing the Sculpt from the box, I noticed there were no detailed instructions included.  I found a “Getting Started” insert that had some very basic tips and a URL that guided me to a web page where I was able to view and download the manual in PDF form.The first thing I did was replace the included 3 foot mini-USB charging cable with a 5 watt AC smartphone charger.  It gave me a little more length to work with so the devoice wouldn’t have to sit on the floor while charging.  After ensuring the adapter worked and the unit was charging, I allowed it to charge for several hours.  There really isn’t any observable indication of charging status while it’s in the cradle.  The edges glow red and the screen displays a charging icon when you first sit it in the cradle but both turn off after a few seconds.  You simply take it out of the cradle when you believe it’s fully charged.After allowing the Aim to charge, I decided to get to work measuring muscle mass and body fat.  First, I filled the little included spray bottle with distilled water (not a requirement but advisable from my past experience mixing water and electronics or appliances).  Then I downloaded and installed the iOS Skulpt app on my iPhone.  The companion app is attractive and very well designed.  It’s one of the better quality apps that I’ve seen a while.  Upon launching the app, I was instructed to create an account and enter some basic body info (weight, height, gender, age, and right or left handed).  After completing the initial setup, it prompted me for an initial measurement.  I then powered on the Aim.  The display is bright and clear.  It’s not high-res but not blocky low-res either.  It fits nicely in the middle and is vivid and clear.  It took me a second or two to get the hang of measuring, mainly due to ensuring the skin has good contact with the wet sensors.  I found that adjusting the position of the meter and/or pressure against my skin helped if it had a hard time establishing a reading. Nevertheless, taking measurements is fairly simple and the companion app does a splendid job of demonstrating exactly how to take a measurement and alerting you when to continue.  I spray the contacts with water, press the Aim against the indicated muscle(s) in the manner shown in the animated example and wait for the solid green light.  From there, I click the “Got It” button on the smartphone (it appears when a measurement is correctly taken)  and move to the next measurement.  After all measurements are taken, the app and device both inform me I’m done and display my MQ (muscle quality) and body fat percentage on both devices.  That’s it. Nothing complicated.The results are pretty accurate and consistent with prior body fat measurements that I had performed  as well as my body fat caliper.  This device is a great motivational tool for workouts.  If you’re working out effectively,  the MQ should gradually increase and body fat percentage should decrease even if the mirror or scale don’t necessarily show a dramatic or immediate transformation.  My entire family measured themselves with the meter.  One note, results don’t sync in guest mode.  My wife and teens only wanted the one reading out of curiosity.  If they decide to measure regularly, I will set up extra users. The Aim device can accommodate multiple users but the app can only accommodate one user at a time.  Each additional user needs their own app. I use it every day to keep myself motivated and pushing for better results from my workouts.  The only thing that I’m not particularly thrilled about is the water requirement.  The Aim tends to get soaked with water running along the sides and coming in contact with all metal contacts, including the charging contacts.  On one occasion, I was about to place the Aim into the charging cradle when I noticed a tiny drop of water seep from one of the sensors.  I thought I had thoroughly dried the device and ensured that no remaining water was present but I was obviously wrong.  I think it seeped from the side of a sensor.  I now allow the Aim to sit and dry for an entire day before charging, especially since I’m using an AC wall adapter instead of a USB port.  It may be overkill but I don’t necessarily need daily readings, so it’s no inconvenience to me to play it extra safe.

So I own a 3 season cabin in Wisconsin. It's starting to get quite cold at night, and when it gets cold, the bed gets really cold. I put this heated mattress pad on the bed. It was very easy to put on and fit my extra think mattress with no problems. The cords were easy to snap in place and there was plenty of cord to place the two control units where I wanted them. I turned one of the controls on to 4 (out of 10) and then read on the couch for a while. When I crawled into bed about an hour later it was all toasty and nice. The zone I left turn off was very chilly. It was so nice to get into a warm bed. There is also a timer that you can set to turn the unit off after a number of set hours. The control unit lights up, but the light goes out after a minute or so which was good thinking on the designers part. I love this thing. It's going to allow me you use my cabin well into the winter and not freeze at night!Notes:- I could not feel the wires through the sheet.- Fits extra think mattresses- Easy to put on and set up- Nice long cords to allow for any placement you want- Timer on control unit will turn the pad off after a set number of hours- Light on control unit turns itself off after a minute or less- Well built.

This unit is sweet. It lets me enjoy music instead of counting my laps and continually calculating how many more laps until I can quit. This is designed for swimming laps or distances and listening to music when doing so. It is not for playing in the water at the beach, running in the rain, or taking a shower. If you understand why you need goggles when swimming, then you are not a swimmer.It was very easy to get music onto it. The magnetic dock was a nice touch and snaps the player in place by itself. There is plenty of space for your music. I put the straps of my goggles through the slots in the player and adjusted it until it felt right. It doesn't have to be in any one perfect place to work. It's very forgiving. I also wore earplugs to keep the water out of my ears and this enhanced the sound even more. When my head was under water it sounded it's best. It was very pleasant swimming being able to listen to my music.Other people here at the office swim as well and are very excited to try this player out so I will be passing it around.I can't recommend this unit enough for anyone who swims distances and missed their music. It is very well made, easy to use and sounds great.Notes:- Made for serious swimmers. If you are not wearing goggles when you swim then this isn't for you.- Excellent sound quality- Does not need to be perfectly placed on your head to sound good- Works even better with ear plugs- Very easy to put music on- Magnetic dock works great and is an excellent idea- Easy to use controls- Very well made and solid- Plug the dock directly into your PC like other devices it might draw too much power from your USB hub.- Charges quickly and has a long battery life.

This remote is AWESOME! I set aside a block of time to get this setup and working and didn't need most of it. So then I got to sit and play with it. I also have the Harmony One and 700. They are both great, but setup one these older models was nowhere near as easy as it was on the Elite. The new setup software works very well. The hardware allows for many different home theater setups. You can even select various combinations for what device sends the IR signal. The remote feel great in your hand and is fun to use. I’m not going to want kids to touch it and I’m going make sure my hands are clean as well!Bottom Line:  This is the best universal remote I have ever tried. It’s easy to use, flexible and high quality. The setup is easy to do and allows for flexibility in how you set it up. I recommend this remote. I will be changing over my home automation to a format that is compatible with the harmony.Setup:- I used the PC software to setup my remote since my phone battery was almost dead. It took me about twenty minutes to set it up. It went so fast I was almost disappointed since I love playing around with these types of devices.- First it downloads a system update. Then walks you through the setup.- The software allows you to import settings from an older remote, but mine was too old and I wanted to start clean.- Once the hub is connected to your network, the setup program will scan your network for connected devices and let you add them.- Entering model numbers is easy. If you get close it suggests the correct one. It knew when I entered the remote model number and told me!- Activities were painless to set up. I knew my Source and Input numbers from the old software so everything went smoothly.- I put the hub in the back of my room to see if it would work from there. It did. It was unable to hit my Xbox, so I used advanced setting to change the Xbox- There are also to IR blasters for use in different types of setups.- IR only, RF is not supported (so DirecTV boxes need to be in IR mode)Usage:- I love the look and feel of this remote. It has heft.- I love the favorite channel feature. You can add up to 50 channels to the screen. They have their logos and look great.- Charging cradle looks nice and is easy to get remote in and out of- Very easy to change between menus.- On remote help works very wellNotes:- Feel great, looks great, works great.- Can be set up to use a combination of the hub and remote to send IR signals- Touch screen is top notch.- If you have multiple Harmony remotes you might need multiple versions of the software and multiple accounts.- My lighting home automation isn’t compatible with the Harmony so I will be switching to a format that is so I can use the Harmony to turn them off and on.

For the most part, I think most people choose a protein bar because of taste.  I had the chocolate peanut butter which tasted great, soft and chewy like a brownie, with a little bit of nut taste and crunchiness.  As far as macros are concerned, mid-level amount of protein, fat, and carbs (20g/6g/16g respectively) versus other bars, but it is smaller than the others and will not make you full.  The price is not bad, when you buy the box it works out to less than $1.50 per bar.  I think it’s a great bar to throw in your gym bag before your workout so you’re not bloated or for after to get you through until you can get a real meal.  I think after I finish my current box, I’m switching over to this.

This garden is really cool. It was super easy to set up. My 11 year old daughter was very excited to do it. She read the instructions and did everything herself. The instructions are very well done. It comes with 6 pods all ready to grow 6 herbs. The unit will tell you when to add water and plant food. A pump runs to move the water but we never hear it. The light is very bright. It's like the sun is coming through the window. We have an open floor plan and I can see the light from my upstairs bedroom. I adjust the light cycle time so it doesn't stay on so long. The garden is a nice size and looks great on the counter. After 7 days our plants are sprouting already.The light adjusts in height so you can move it as the plants grow. The instructions recommend the best method for keeping all the plants the same height and when to harvest. We are looking forward to cooking with our freshly grown herbs.Notes:- Easy to setup. My 11 year old daughter did it all herself.- It comes with the first set of 6 herbs.- Very bright. Lights up my downstairs and I can see it from upstairs. Had to adjust the time so I could sleep.- Started growing in a week.- Very quiet can't hear the pump.- Has indicator lights for when to add water and food.- Light adjusts so you can raise it as plants grow.- Very well done detailed instructions- Looks great on the counter.- Fun for the entire family.

This Chrome book is top notch. It is very nicely built and very high quality. It is fast, has a great display and the battery lasts a long time. The keyboard lights up for use in the dark. It comes with a 16 gig solid state drive which you will find under Downloads in the drive app. It also accepts an SD card for more storage as well as any type of USB 2 or 3 drive you want to plug in.When I first turned the unit on, it needed to connect to the internet. I already had a Google account so I used that. It updated itself and restarted. It pulled in all my setting that I use for the Chrome browser on my work and home computer. That means it has all my favorites, saved passwords, etc. It's really nice. It took me a little bit to get used to the track pad and keyboard differences. The help app was very helpful and got me up and going. I'm really liking the track pad now. The Chrome Web Store has tons of free apps. You can put the ones you use the most down on the "shelf" and order them anyway you want.Know What you need and What you are Buying:A Chrome book is a laptop that runs the Chrome operating system. It is an online type computer. There are things you can do without WiFi but they are limited. Know what functions you want to do before you buy your Chromebook. You can do a lot on a chrome book and they are expanding that list every day. But there are still some things you may want to do that aren't supported yet. Do your research. If most of the things you want to do are on the web and you have access to WiFi where you will be using it, then this might be perfect for you. And this Toshiba version is a very good one to start with.General Notes:- This is a well made solid quality unit. It feels good, and looks great.- Keyboard lights up for use in the dark- Comes with 100 Gig of Google drive free for 2 years. Redeem offer on Chromebook.- Like other reviewers said, the screen is amazing. Sharp, clear, and bright- Very fast- Battery charges in just over and hour and can last up to 8 hours.- Battery time left is very accurate.- Fan hardly runs and it is very quiet.- Built in web camChromebook Notes:- Delete Key = Alt Backspace- You find your 16 Gig Hard Drive under Downloads in the drive app- Use the Help app on the Chromebook it does help- Most apps need WiFi to run. Check the web store for ones that work off line.- Videos must be streamed, or in one of the formats Chrome can currently play- I'm excited about eventually being able to run Android Apps on Chrome books. They are working on this.Track Pad:- The track pad can do everything you just need to know how. Check the help.- Swiping the track pad with 2 fingers will scroll.- You can tap or push the pad down to click.- Tapping with two fingers does a right click.

This set came packaged 3 boxes deep. First the shipping box, then another brown box, then the box with the printing. It was in perfect condition. The two boards Velcro together and have handle to allow you to carry it. The boards are slick and the bags slide some but it seems to be the same as most of the other commercial sets I've played on. They are not indestructible. You need to treat them well so they will last. The bags seem to have a plastic bag of sand inside them. I like the feel and thought they flew well. I think this is a decent starter set and a nice choice to all along to the game.Notes:- Came shipped 3 boxes deep. Arrived in perfect condition.- Boards Velcro together with handle for carrying. Bags go in between.- These are the slippery type boards.- Bags seem decent quality. There is a bag within the bag. Feels like sand inside.- Seems about medium quality.- We had a lot of fun with them.

This is a really nice watch. It is big, but not too big. It is very solid and has good weight to it. It has front and back windows into the inner workings of the watch. You can see the gears moving. I find myself taking it off to show people.  It is very well done and looks great. The band is a very nice leather. Not the kind you should be getting we even though the watch is water resistant to 99 feet. This just protects it from getting caught in the rain or spills. I would treat this as a business casual and dress up watch. I won't be working in the yard with it on, it's too nice. I feel extra dressed up when I'm wearing this.So I have to admit I couldn't figure out how the band worked. I had to come look at the pictures on Amazon where I saw that the main clasp unfolds to extend the band and allow you to put it on and slide the leather band into the buckle with the pin. It works well once you know how. I didn't want to force anything and break it.Bottom Line: This is a great looking and feeling watch. It would make a great gift for yourself or someone else. I speak to how it will hold up over time but in no way does it feel cheap.Notes:- Manual wind. Didn't quite make it 2 days on a wind.- Clasp unfolds to allow sliding it over your wrist- Comes in a very nice box- Windows on the front and back of the watch show the inner workings- Is an excellent conversation piece- Would make a kick butt gift- Very solid feeling and heavy- Looks very classy on my wrist- Water resistant to 99 feet but leather band isn't the kind you would want to get wet.

The SKLZ heavy ball is a great item for training, especially if you start practicing with the heavy ball then go to the regular ball, which ends up feeling like a toy.  There is no weight listed on the ball but I’m guessing it’s about 3 lbs. which is enough to feel a difference but not heavy enough to make you seem like you’re weightlifting.  The ball is made of rubber that has good grip, it won’t slip out of your hands and sticks to your fingertips.  Another great thing is that it’s an indoor/outdoor ball because using it in the house will not make people in the home very happy.  We’ve used it in the driveway, garage, and basement so far the ball hasn’t lost any grip.The three people to use it are dad, a 14 year old daughter, and a 9 year old daughter.  Both kids have been playing basketball for their schools (the older one being her 5th year with the school and club and the younger one is in her first year at school).  We were able to use it for dribbling and passing drills, where they noticed a difference when using it for 5 minutes then switching to the regulation ball.  For the chest passes though the younger one would drop it more because she was a little afraid of the weight coming in too fast.We have a portable hoop (filled with sand) that has a poly-carbonate backboard.  Shooting at it is not recommended because the backboard flexes and the whole hoop shakes.  For  me and the older one layups were ok and with more repetitions I could see this as helping with bringing the ball up quicker , but too heavy for the younger one.  If you have access to a real basketball gym then maybe shooting at the glass backboard would be ok, but I imagine when it comes down on the hardwood it would be pretty loud.  We did use it to just shoot in place and you can feel the muscles working to get the ball to go up in the air and have some backspin.Overall it’s a great training tool and I hope to see some improvements in my kids games over time.

I've owned and reviews a lot of shavers. This one ranks near the top. I really like it. It is solid, feels good in my hand, and most importantly gives a great shave. It shaves close with no irritation. The comb works surprisingly well on my beard. It has plenty of power. The trimmer is easy to use as well. This unit is Wet/Dry which makes it very versatile. It also means it is easy to clean. It does come with a large automatic cleaner/charger. BUT you can also just use soap and water and run the shaver. Then rinse. That is my preferred method. No buying detergent and no big unit sitting on my sink.I was a little disappointed that the battery indicator light doesn't show battery level. All 3 lights just blink at once when the battery is close to needing a charge. Not a big deal I guess. It does not come with a carrying case, but a hard plastic cover that protects the foils and power button. Not sure how will this will work in a cosmetic bag when traveling.Overall I love this shaver and recommend it.Notes:- Great shave. No irritation. Easy to hold and use.- Comb works great on my beard- Trimmer is powerful- Not very loud- Wet/Dry which is awesome- Charges fast- You can use the included washing/charging station or just wash it yourself with soap- Comes with only enough detergent for one wash you will need to buy more- No carry case but there is a hard plastic shell that keeps it from turning on- Battery light looks like it's 3 segments but they all just blink when battery is low. It is not a level indicator.

I had no problem cutting food or cardboard. The bottle opener isn't the easiest to use, but works in a pinch and is nice to have. Comes apart for easy cleaning. We use this at our cabin and it is just perfect for use there. Very good value.

I've tried at least 10 different preworkout supplements over the last 5 years. Here is my personal experience with them in general:- I would build up a tolerance to them. So I needed to cycle on and off and between brands.- If it sucked the first couple of times I tried it, it never got any better- Some tasted like crap some were ok- Some mixed well and some did not- Some screwed up my sleep- Some cut my appetite- Some made me all tingly or itchy from the Beta Alanine- 5 Days a week is too much for me to use one=======> 360 PRE First Workout <=======- Mixed well, and tasted really good. I was really impressed by the taste. I actually liked it.- Walk to gym is about 8 minutes from my office. I was sweating by the time I got there and it was cool outside.- No tingling or itchy feeling- Started to feel good and happy. Ready to hit the weights.- Warmed up with cardio. Sweated a lot more than normal. Went at a higher pace than normal.- Bench - was able to do more reps. Kept going even when it got hard.- When it got hard I found that I would laugh during the last couple of reps and push on.- I did more sets than normal and did not quit as early.- When I quit my shirt was completely soaked with sweat. Not normal.- Felt slightly aggressiveI have to admit that I am a sand bagger. I stop a few reps before I should. I let that little voice in my head control me when it says quit you are tired. Stop running and walk. That's enough reps, that's enough sets. Today using 360PRE I found that I didn't listen to that voice at all. I couldn't really even hear it. I kept going and did a lot more than I have in a quite a while. I ended my workout ehausted and it felt great! So far I have had no adverse side effects. I plan to use 360PRE 2 to 3 times a week. I will update this review as I use it more. As of now I think it is great.

This is a good looking solid cup. It is metal and insulated. It does not sweat so your hands will stay dry. My beer stayed cold through the last drink. Drinks with ice stay cold a long time. We didn't make 8 hours, but definitely a good 1 to 2 hours. I recommend this cup and am thinking about getting an entire set.Notes:- Well made solid metal cup with plastic cover- Does not sweat- Needs to be hand washed- Kept my beer cold down to the list drink- Plastic rim is nice to drink from- Looks cool

The Headboard came extremely well packaged. Not only was it in a normal shipping box, but it also had two 2 inch pieces of cardboard on it, one taped to each side of the box. It does take two people to carry it up stairs. It's not extremely heavy, just big.Assembly: Once unpacked, you lay the two large pieces side by side. There is one dowel that goes between the pieces and then you push them together. Next you put a stabilizer board on the top and the bottom using four screws on each one. Make sure you have all the holes on both lining up before you tighten them. Then comes the big billowy cover. It fits snugly so take your time and work it on each side inch by inch. Finally the slip cover goes over the first cover. It slides over pretty smoothly. Then you attach it to your queen or double size frame using the 4 included nuts and bolts.The headboard transformed the room and does look really classy. I am impressed by the look and feel of it. The only downside is the price. It seems quite steep for just a headboard. Other than that, it is really nice.Notes:- Very well packaged- Had no Major issues with assembly- Looks very luxurious- Expensive

The first thing I noticed was how heavy the box was when I picked it up off the front porch. I knew it was cast iron but was still surprised. It comes very well packaged to prevent damage during shipping. The casserole is very beautiful and well made. It can be used on the stove top and in the oven. It doesn't come with any "instructions", so I checked the company website. It said that this model does not need to be seasoned. It also recommends 300 degrees for best in oven cooking results since cast iron transfers heat so well. For best results skip the dishwasher and hand wash. Wood and plastic utensils are recommended as well.I tested it out on the stove-top frying sweet potatoes in olive oil. It worked great. Only minimal sticking to the pan and heat transfer was excellent. Be careful since the handles can get hot since they are cast iron as well. Clean up was very easy. I used a plastic brush with soap and did not have to scrub. Be sure to dry well after washing. This is the nicest best quality dish I have ever owned. It looks and performs impressively. Take good care of it, and it will last a lifetime.Notes:- 300 degrees is the recommended oven temperature- No seasoning needed for cream enamel surface version- Skip the dishwasher and hand wash. Dry well.- Use wood or plastic utensils for best results- Very well made and high quality- Easy to clean
