I've been testing a lot of blue tooth portable speakers. The main things I look for are USB Charging (no external wall wart type charger needed), decent battery life, good base and volume. The TDK life checks all these boxes. In addition it has nice 360 degree sound, shock resistance for accidental drops, and water resistant for rain and spills. This unit is well built so you can throw it in your backpack and not have to worry about it getting damaged. There is also a master power switch you can turn off for storage and to prevent accidentally turning it on when it is packed.I was impressed with the sound from this small and light of a unit. I found the base to be decent, and I am ok with the volume level. There are louder speakers, but not at this size and price. I really like how tough it is and the sound field. No matter which way you point it, it sounds great. This will be the speaker I use outside now due to its toughness and water resistance.Notes:- 360 degree sound was impressive for this small unit- Base is very good- Top volume is decent for a speaker this big- USB Charging- Up to 8 hour battery life- Splash resistant so you don't have to worry about a light rain- Shock resistant and well built OK to throw in your backpack- Easy to pair blue tooth devices, even easier with NFC- Press and hold Power button for 3 seconds and the volume level leds will show battery level- Has Aux in jack

0:23 Mins I found this knife to be useful, fun, and cool. I carry it in my backback. I do agree that it is too big for everyday pocket carry, but it has a clip so you can put it on your belt. The flshlight is very decent something I've come to expect from coast. I was disspointed at first with the polycarbonate handle. It seemed wrong for a knife at this price level. But the more I use it, the more I like it. I'm okay with it now. There is a thumb hole on the blade for one handed open. Once I oiled the junction where the blade meets the handle, I was able to snap it open with one hand. Pretty sweet. See the video.Bottom line: I really like this knife and so far with the experience I've had with it, I reccomend it highly.Notes:- I thought the handle was weird as well, but I've come around to liking it.- It is a bit bulky for a pocket knife, so I use the belt clip instead.- I really like the flashlight knife combo. I find it useful and cool.- After a bit of oil, one handed open is prettly slick.- Nice and Sharp- I am a big fan of Coast Flashlights this one is no exception- Light has two brightness settings- Standard interior spring to unlock blade once it is opened.- Excellent Coast packaging as usual.

I wondered how well a battery operated trimmer could do compared to the corded model I have. After testing it all over the yard, I was very impressed at how it performed. I trimmed the same bushes I did a year ago using my corded hedge trimmer. The Oregon model kicked butt. It was smooth, quiet, and easy to use. It cut through all the branches I threw at it including ones over one half inch thick. I was able to hold it for a long time without getting tired from the weight. I could use it in all positions (vertical, horizontal, upside down) very nicely which allowed me to sculpt the bushes the way I wanted. The battery has a 4 segment lighted charge level indicator right on it. You push a button and it shows you how much batter you have left. This is awesome. It comes with a heavy duty plastic sheath for the blade as well as the batter charger. The batter goes in and out of the unit very nicely. It snaps in when you push it, and pops out when you push the release button.My unit was delivered in perfect condition and doesn't have any issues with the unit turning on. This is perfect for my size yard. I don't have to pull a cord behind me anymore, or deal with another loud messy gas engine. The run time of up to 60 minutes is also enough for me so that I won't have to get a second battery which is a bit pricey.Notes:- Excellent power for a battery operated device- Had no problems with shrub branches up to 1/2 inch- Very quiet when running- 4 LED Battery level indicator directly on the battery itself- Heavy duty plastic sheath for the blade- Decent weight. Not too heavy- No issues with turning the unit on- No cord or gas engine to deal with- Battery can hold it's charge for months- Up to one hour of run time on a full charge

This is my first hammer stapler and I really wish I had had it before for installing the roof on my cabin and shed as well as the plastic vapor barrier. This unit lets you pound the staples well into the wood. The squeeze type gun I used failed to put the staples deep enough a good part of the time and all the squeezing can cramp your hand. This tacker is easy to load and easy to handle. It feels really good in my hand and has good weight to it so you can bang out those staples like mad. Note that you do need space to swing this tacker in order to use it. In confined spaces like between rafters, you may have to use the old gun type stapler. You also have to be sure not to swing to hard and dent the surface you are stapling into.Overall I would not do a roofing type job without this type of tacker and this model works very well.Notes:- Easy to load- Solid with a good heft to it.- Comes with 5000 staples which is nice- Packaged in a larger box so the staples spilled out of their box- Staples go into the wood very well better than squeeze type guns- Ideal for roofing/tar paper installation

0:11 Mins I installed this on the door to our garage as a replacement handle. The garage door is always closed, so we never lock that door anyway. The handle installed in about 30 minutes. The instructions were very well done. I measured the thickness of the door and it was 1 3/4 inches, so I had to adjust the handle for use with that width. It comes preset for 1 3/8. This was easy. Then I measured the backset (distance from center of hole to edge of door) this distance tells you which of the 2 included latches to use. I needed the longer one. Things when together quickly after that. This door always had a bit of a rattle when it was closed, so I bent out the tab on the included strike plate until the door was snug when closed.The Push Pull Rotate:The PPR is a really cool idea. This makes opening the door with your hands full of grocery bags very easy. I was impressed with how smoothly this worked. Note that this is an interior door handle. It has a push pin lock like bedroom and bathroom doors have. In an emergency, you can use a paperclip or the included "key" to unlock it. I did the Pull and Rotate in my attached video. I'm very happy with this handle set.Notes:- Fits standard 1 3/8 and 1 3/4 width doors.- Fits both 2 3/8 and 2 3/4 backsets- Installs in about a half hour- Detailed instructions help a lot- Has interior/bathroom door type lock with pin hole on other side to open- Nice quality feels solid and well built.

This is the second product that I have used from BulkSupplements. I found both supplements to be of very high quality. There are now fillers. I am very happy with with this product. I got the 100 gram size and it is a good deal. It comes in resealable heavy plastic envelope. The L-Tyrsine has a slightly sour taste. Very slight. I drank it by itself to test taste and solubility. It dissolved completely in water. I felt an energy increase and a bit of a sense of well being. I will continue to try Bulk Supplements for other things I use as well.

I am very happy with with this product. I got the 500 gram size and it was a really good deal. It comes in resealable heavy plastic envelope. I have used other brands of Beta Alanine before and this one is on par with all of them. It had very little taste if any. It dissolved completely in water. I felt the familiar tingle/itch and my workouts were great. I will try Bulk Supplements for other things I use as well.

This novel is set in a London where the Germans won world war two. We follow the main character, Rossett, who has become for all intents and purposes one of the enemy he fought in the war. He now works for the Nazis. He does his job without thinking at all about what he is doing or why. He is just existing. Until something different happens one day....I really had fun reading this novel. I liked the characters and the action. I can still see some of the scenes in my mind. They were well done. Rossett is an awesome character. At times though it seems that Rossett survives and continues on when his injuries should slow him down at least. This bothered me a little but I was able to let it go and still enjoy the book. There is a big build up that Rossett is trying to make up for the bad things he has done. Searching for redemption if you will. I felt this got a little lost in the action. I also had trouble with the ending. I felt a bit cheated. Maybe it was a setup for some sort of sequel.In the end I enjoyed it very much right up to the end.Notes:- The alternate reality worked for me- I was able to follow the plot and the various characters and groups- The main characters seemed real to me and I cared about them- The main character does seem a bit superhuman carrying on with wounds that would stop anyone else- I really enjoyed it, but had trouble with the ending- Reads fast and was hard to put down

This is an excellent projector and I am impressed with its image quality. The first thing I did after opening the box was to go to the website Epson suggested in a flyer inside the box that explained Color Brightness. I only really knew about overall brightness expressed in Lumens. This projector is 3000 which is a lot brighter than my last one which was only 2200. The EX7230 also has a color brightness of 3000. It makes a huge difference. The colors look amazing. Other projectors can have a similar White Light output, but less color brightness, and they will not look as good. The next thing I was excited about was the fact that the projector comes with its own padded carrying bag. How nice is that!One of the sources we used was an iPod touch and the Netflix app. You need the adapter cable for video out from the iPod. This used the composite inputs on the projector. The projector automatically found the active input and selected it. We projected it up onto the wall. I noticed that the image was square even though we were projecting at an angle. I found out that this projector has automatic vertical keystone adjustment. Very nice. It also has 8 different color modes. We were projecting onto a wall that wasn't white. The Blackboard color mode adjusted for this and it looked really good. The sound wasn't too bad either coming from the projectors internal speaker. You would need something else for larger rooms and places with background noise.We then hooked up a Blu-ray player and played some true HD content. The movies looked awesome. I am very impressed. PC content looks amazing as well.Browsing through the menu structure, I found a lot of new and improved settings compared to the projector I bought 8 years ago. I suggest reading through the manual so you know all the different things you can do. For example some of the color modes support Auto Iris which will optimize the image based on the brightness of the current scene. Another feature is the PC Free Presentation. You can plug in a USB thumb drive (or any supported USB storage device) and the projector can project the supported picture and video formats.Specs:- Resolution: 1280 x 800 (WXGA)- White Light Output 3000 Lumens- Color Light Output 3000 Lumens- Projection Distance 32 to 320 inches- Focus and Zoom Adjustments are Manual- Lamp Life 5000 hours- Supports wireless LAN Adapter sold separatelyNotes:- The Color Brightness is amazing. Blue Ray Discs look amazing- Comes with padded carrying case!- Full HD- Easy to use Remote Control- Focus and Zoom are manual slides on the projector and easy to use.- Projector is quiet when running.- Speaker is ok for close quarters. Not enough for large rooms.- Supports USB drives for slide shows. File types supported: jpg, bmp, gif, png, avi with pcm sound- Automatic Vertical Keystone correction is really nice!- Multiple input connections for a variety of connection options- Product Manual: https://files.support.epson.com/docid/cpd4/cpd40965/index.html

Both my daughters love Adventure Time and went nuts when this BMO came. They loved how cute and well made he was. The attention to detail is very impressive. The packaging has wonderful artwork on it and it is a shame to throw it out. I am told by my two experts that this BMO is ACTUAL SIZE. Judging by their reactions, I would say this toy is more than a hit.Here is the review from a happy owner:BMO is a pillowBMO is a broPlaying with your BMO will even help you grow!*BMO is softBMO is smoothBMO goes SQUISHlike the lips of a cuddly puffer fish!Hug BMO and give him part of your sandwich,it will increase his bandwidth!(This BMO toy is great. Get it. You won't regret it.)*= growth is found in your overall level of happiness

This was my first Sigma Force novel. It sounded so good that I got it to read even though it's well into the series. I didn't seem to miss anything by starting at this point in the series. I probably didn't know the characters as well, but there was nothing confusing, the novel was pretty much self contained. There is a lot of action in this book. The characters are easy to like or dislike. I felt like I knew the characters by the end of the story. I could picture the action and the settings very well. I enjoyed that. According to the author, the science in the book is based on fact and not too far out of the realm of possibility. That is cool and scary at the same time. This seemed a lot like the novel adaption of a great action movie. It was never boring and a lot of fun. I recommend this book for anyone that likes action thrillers.Notes:- Lots of Actions- Science Fiction / Science soon to be fact- Appendix in book describes the actual science- Reminded me of James Bond Stories- Characters are very likable- Very Easy to read. Time flew while I was reading.- Multiple plot lines added to the excitement- Seemed like a book adaption of a good action movie

This is a very cute little popper. My 10 year old daughter was very excited when it arrived. She opened the box and put it together. There are just 3 parts. The measuring cup that is also the top of the unit/butter warmer, the main shoot, and the read hot air popper. We measured the max amount of popcorn and dumped it in. The we put some coconut oil into the melter. We turned the unit on and the corn started popping in less than a minute. It was all popped in under 3 minutes. When I picked up the melter to pour on the coconut oil, the cup was a bit hot. Didn't burn me, but enough to surprise you. Before any of the corn started popping, 5 or 6 unpopped kernels blew into the bowl. Just a side effect of all that air blowing around. Then the corn started popping and it was fun to watch it all blow into the bowl. Use a big bowl to catch the corn. It makes more than you would think, and the bigger bowl will minimize any corn that wants to make a run for it.We had a lot of fun with this popper and it works well for us. We think its a pretty good deal.Notes:- Popcorn was done in less than 3 minutes after turning the unit on- Cup with butter was pretty warm, be careful when pouring melted butter on the corn- Use a big bowl to catch the popcorn to keep them from getting away- Cord stores inside the popper.- Fun looking unit- Kids love it- Doesn't need oil so it's healthy- 5 or 6 unpopped kernels blew out as it popped no big deal

This is a two serving size George Foreman grill. It comes with one small drip tray. The drip tray just sits on the counter so it can move around on accident. We made two chicken breasts at a time. The first two were a little thick. I didn't get them unfolded like I should have. So they took a couple minutes more than the 9 minutes the manual said. The second set cooked in the 9 minutes. The chicken was excellent. Brown on the outside and very juicy on the inside. Very tender. The grill did get pretty dirty and the grease cooked on. The manual says not to use nonstick cooking spray so I didn't. It was pretty tough to clean then. I had to scrub. Next time I'm going to brush on oil.Meal 2: Raw, not frozen turkey burgers. Unit heated up and green light went out in about 2 minutes. Sprayed unit with olive oil spray from Trader Joes. Cooked burger for 5 minutes. Then put cheese on and held the top cooking plate close to cheese but not touching. Cheese melted nicely and fast. Burger was excellent. Grill cleaned up a lot easier with the spray. Still had to scrub a little, but a lot less than without the spray.Overall, I was impressed with how good the food was it cooked. The nonstick wasn't the best but I'm going to use oil next time. It just took me 4 minutes of cleaning to get it clean. I also like the two serving size. It is an attractive unit as well.Notes:- Small 2 serving Size- Heats up quickly. Mine was faster than 4 minutes.- Cooked our chicken in the 9 minutes like manual said- Didn't use nonstick spray (like manual said) and it took some scrubbing to clean- I like the size- Chicken was brown on outside and juicy on the inside very tasty!

I was thoroughly entertained by this novel. I lost track of time on multiple occasions and almost missed my stop on the train. I was completely pulled into the story. An hour would go by and I wouldn't notice. I haven't been this entertained by a book in some time. It was so much fun to be completely taken away for awhile. I was sad when it was over, but I have a feeling there will be more... For me this rates five stars.I liked the short chapters that alternated between two linked story lines, one in the past, and one in the present. When one chapter ended I wanted more of that plot line. Then two paragraphs into the next chapter, I was excited to be back on that story line. I felt the writing was well done and the descriptions full. I came to really like the characters and feel that they had personalities. I even became attached to the dog!This book is excellent entertainment and I recommend it as such. It contains magic, sorcery, and witchcraft. It takes place now and in the late 1500s. I thought the two story lines were well woven together. I will be waiting for the next book by Rebecca Alexander. I think she did an excellent job with this novel.Notes:- I was thoroughly entertained and lost track of time on multiple occasions while reading this- I loved the characters both past a present and even the dog!- Short chapters that skipped between two story lines worked well- This was an extremely fun read- Well written with a lot of detail- The magic was well handled and believable- Very hard to put down- Not every novel needs to be classical fiction

Ok, I'm going to review these based on the price point of the set. You get this set basically for the price on one "good" frying pan. I got the entire 14 piece set. The one egg wonder pan is tucked into the dutch oven. The pans look cool with the bright white ceramic nonstick coating on them. They are light but not to the point of being flimsy. The handles are pretty sturdy plastic. I would not put them in the dishwasher or in the oven. It says you can, but I am pretty sure this will greatly reduce their lifespans.I used the large frying pan and scrambled eggs with cut up steak. The first thing I noticed was that the pan heated up faster and hotter them my thicker frying pan. This let me reduce the heat and start cooking faster. It was also funny how hard it was to see the egg whites against the white pan. The pan is extremely non stick. The eggs didn't stick anywhere. I could have cleaned the pan with just a paper towel. It basically just rinsed clean. When I cooked chicken breasts I was able to turn down the heat. The lid handle stays very cool. The chicken cooked very well. Cleanup was again very easy.I am impressed with how these pans perform. I cannot as yet comment on the long term durability. If they don't last very long, then I would lower my star rating. They seem to be an excellent value. I would recommend them for a first set, as a gift, college kids, divorced guy starting over, . . .Notes:- Heated up very fast and got very hot. I use gas and did not notice any hot spots.- Eggs and chicken both cooked faster than in my heavier pans. Reduce the heat to cook at the same rate.- VERY non stick. Eggs came out very easily. Could wipe clean with a paper towel.- Light weight. Not a heavy duty set.- White ceramic coating looks great.- Plastic handles stay cool but I would not use them in the over or dishwasher.- Found all 14 pieces including One Egg Wonder hidden in dutch oven.- Can't comment on long term durability yet.- The included utensils are fairly sturdy and work fine
I was not able to use this to boot (for reinstalling).  That was the main thing I wanted it for.  Probably it works fine as a general CDROM drive, though.

So far I've only used the steel one (for cleaning threads on steel pipe) but it works great. They are a great size and it's good to have a brush of each hardness.  Never know what you will need to clean.
We use this to charge our phones and tablet.  Charges two things at a time and does them both really fast.  I definitely recommend this.

The TV has a great picture and the smart TV features work really well--super well-designed.Why 3 stars?  Because it's freaking delicate and can't be repaired.  My-three-year-old hit it with a plastic toy and the LCD broke instantly (the plastic screen is still intact, only the picture doesn't work).  This was a couple of weeks after buying it.  Not covered under warranty and it can't be repaired for less than the TV costs.  I purchased a replacement of the same model but I'm having a piece of acrylic hung in front of it.  That was expensive enough that it really traumatized me.If you don't have kids or any moving objects in your home, this may not apply to you.  In all other respects it's a really great and functional TV at a low price.Few other things I don't like:1. The sound is really bad.  Like, really bad.  Plan to get a soundbar immediately.2. There is only one button on this TV and it does everything.  You have to hold it down for 2 seconds to turn it off.  Unfortunately it rocks to the side so you often end up cycling through inputs rather than turning it off.  The button is also wholly inadequate for controlling the various smart TV functions.  Heaven help you if you lose the remote.3. I don't care for the motion interpolation.  These days all the TV's have it, but it makes action look terrible and unrealistic.  Actually other TV's do it more aggressively, so maybe I should count this as a plus.

I love this device.  We get a lot of brown-outs here and they have caused damage to some of my equipment, so I wanted a device to power my home fileserver, which runs linux.  It doesn't consume many watts but those hard drives are pretty expensive to replace, to say nothing of the costs of digging files out of backups when data is lost.Anyway, this device is a nice size and price to protect one important computer.  And it features automatic voltage regulation (i.e., it protects against brown-outs, not just black-outs).The cyberpower software works perfectly with linux.  Installs really easily and then you just run a command and you can monitor and control the UPS, see when the last power event is, and even see how many watts your computer is drawing.  I haven't had a blackout long enough to see if this will shut down my computer safely if need be, but I'm sure it will because it flawlessly does everything else.

The only problem with this hard drive bay is that it doesn't work.  It isn't recognized at all by linux (I tried it with several different hard drives on several different machines running different versions of linux).  Sad, because every other USB-SATA hard drive adapter in the world works perfectly with linux, and I did kind of want one that worked with two drives at a time.There is a paper included urging you very enthusiastically to email Orico customer support before returning or anything.  I emailed them but they never responded.  That sort of adds insult to injury.I returned this.  Clearly not a very good company and definitely not a good device.

Unfortunately they dropped the ball on this one.  Good concept, good actors, good budget.  The writing, though.  The writing.  Very inconsistent in mood and quality.  This needed to go through a few more rewrites.An example writing element that is crap: stories have to have reasonable bad guys.  Like, guys you can imagine doing what they are doing.  You can totally see a nerdy tech dude stealing some embryos and accidentally breaking the park, as was done in the first movie.  How about a random security guard that thinks velociraptors have significant military value and unleashes some that are clearly not fully trained on a situation that clearly does not call for small predators?  Not so much.  Hollywood hates the military enough that they assume they can write a character that makes no sense whatsoever as long as they associate him with military.  Very lazy and poor.
It's ok.  My wife liked it more than I did.  The original is much more charming, but this isn't a horrible sequel.

I use LED lights all over my house, all of them daylight balanced (not "warm").  These are the only LED bulbs I have run across that put out poor quality light.  The brightness is correct, but the colors are just awful.  Much bluer than typical daylight balanced bulbs, and very monochromatic.  The room looks like it's in black and white.  After just a minute or two you will start to feel unwell when subjected to these. These are kind of like the way LED lights used to be back when they were a brand new technology and hadn't been improved to the point that they were feasible to put in a home.  Simply put, they are not white--they lack enough colors of the spectrum to fool the eye.These are so bad i am going to have to return them.  It's sad, because I really like the size and brightness of these (most LED lights seem to be much brighter than the incandescents they supposedly replace and the directionality makes them seem even brighter) but at the end of the day, this is the light I have to live in.  These bulbs make everything look terrible and you will feel terrible if you spend any time under them.Avoid.

I really like this friction mount.  I use it with my Garmin 2589LMT and it works great.  Much more convenient than trying to work the suction cup (which tends to fail after a while).  I wish it wasn't so bulky but I guess it wouldn't work well if it wasn't.

This is a fun action movie.  If you like action and you like snipers, this is perfect.  Mark Wahlberg is perfect for this role.Sometimes I think of action movies as a one-time watch thing.  While this is not deeper or more fun than a typical action movie, I have found myself rewatching it more often.  I guess because snipers are cool.

I'm very happy with this outlet.  I bought it to replace a gfci outlet in my bathroom that had paint all over it that I couldn't get off.  As I went to get it I thought it might make sense to have a nightlight as well--I have small children that pull nightlights out so it has to be built in.  This is a great solution.The nightlight runs only when it's dark.  Now, that's kind of all the time because bathrooms are almost always dark (no windows).  Anyway, this has an LED light built in and it's reasonably bright.  You can definitely use the bathroom at night to this light without turning on the actual light.  The light is bluish white.The outlet works fine too and was easy to install.  Pretty much like any GFCI outlet.  It has the holes in the back where you insert the wires and then you turn these screws to get it in place.  I like this better than the holes that automatically grab wires and the outlets that require you to wrap the wire around a screw.Anyway, good item, if a bit pricey for what it is.

I really like this charger.  It charges my phone SUPER fast and it's small.  One odd thing is that it produces an extremely high-pitched hum as long as it is plugged in (even if it is not powering my phone).  The pitch is high enough that my wife can't hear it but I can.  Probably won't bother other people but I unplug it when not in use.
I like it real well.  Good to have one that can charge the phone fast.

I have two of these and they work pretty well.  They put out a pure white (on the blue-ish side) light and turn off if a bright light is shined on them.However, I also have a cooper industries one (which is $5 more) and it is a better product.  It has a brighter but adjustable light--so you can make it as bright as you want--at its highest setting it is very bright indeed.  More importantly, the cooper one is never on during the day or at any time when I don't want/need it.  It only turns on when it is dark enough that a night light makes sense.  The levitron ones turn on when things are a little dim--in the shadows, in the early evening, etc.  The levitron ones are just on a lot more than I would prefer.  They were cheaper, but it wasn't really worth it.Small bone here: the levitron one also has the ground and hot attachments pretty close together.  I would prefer the hot on the other side and ground next to white.  But that's a small bone and hasn't actually been a problem for me

I really like this product.  Very easy to find, keep straight, and keep track of.  Also less of a tendency to get tangled somehow.  I use them for phone chargers, which I have all over the place because I hate not having them when I want them.  If I buy more microusb cables, they will be this brand and package.

By giving it three stars you might think I'm saying I'm really unhappy with this product.  I guess I am, but not because it doesn't work or there are manufacturing or material problems.  The problem is the concept.  I really like the concept of not having to get just the right number of outlet, GFCI, and light bulb gaskets, but in practice I think it's better to get the product that's actually made for your application.Punching out the part you need out without disturbing the rest is a little bit of a pain.  You can do it, but sometimes you end up with little bits of foam hanging off and it's definitely not as airtight as a regular gasket would be.  I was thinking it would be good to use this for other boxes, like ethernet, phone, cable, or empty plates (over access boxes).  Yeah, it kind of works, but not great.  The holes are not in the right places for the screws in those cases and the punch-outs aren't the right size/shape.  This really is just for outlets, GFCI, and switches.Someone mentioned that these are thicker than some other gaskets.  That is true, by just a little bit.  However, that's not a good thing.  You'd think thicker means more insulation or a better seal, but the opposite happens, I think.  They don't allow you to screw the plate in as close as you want and then the edges of the plate don't come down and seal all that well.  This is especially a problem for outlets, which have only one screw in the middle rather than one on top and one on bottom.  I actually think thinner and maybe a little larger would work better.If you want to be really anal about insulating outlets, in particular, you can take the punch out part and stick it onto a babyproofing plastic insert and plug those in.  Well, you can do that with the regular brands.  This one, the punch out sections have a piece that tends to fall out (where you would have punched out for a switch).  Again, you can make it work, but it's not as nice as the ones you get with a dedicated outlet gasket.These work, I guess (I have now done my whole house with gaskets like this and the duck brand ones and I'm not 100% sure it makes any difference), but if I had it to do over again I would just buy the outlet ones, the switch ones, and the GFCI ones and have a few extras around.

This bulbs works well.  It's a pretty pure white.  Not so white that it's daylight balanced, but not as yellow as an incandescent.  I use it for the stovetop light under my microwave.  It fits and works in that application.  Notice that this is an E17 base, which is smaller than a regular base, but bigger than candelabra.  Basically you only see them in appliances, it seems like.The part that you'd think is glass is actually rubber or rubberized plastic.  That was a bit odd.  Also, my microwave has a setting for turning them on dimly and they work (not all LED bulbs are actually dimmable).Why only 4 stars?  It's not as bright as you'd expect.  I have 7 watt LED bulbs (which actually consume more like 8 when I test them) all over my house and they are at least 10 times this bright.  I have an LED nightlight that consumes like 1 watt that seems brighter too.  I mean, it works, but I was just expecting it to be brighter.

This is your basic electrical plate for GFCI or decorative switches.  It's the white version.  Same product you get everywhere.If you have problems breaking these by overscrewing, go for the nylon ones instead at a slightly higher cost.  Otherwise there is really nothing to decide here.

I'm pretty happy with this nightlight outlet.  I got it because I have small children who like to pull out and otherwise mess with night lights.  That's dangerous and also always results in my nightlights getting lost.I previously purchased the levitron one of these...looks the same but it's $5 cheaper and it is noticeably dimmer.  The levitron would be good for a smaller room but I wanted something with more light, for a big room.  I moved the levitron around the corner and am now happy to see this flooding the room with light.It's adjustable, which is nice.  You should be able to make it work in whatever configuration you want.  The light is on the yellow side of white while the levitron is on the blue side.  Both are LED.The initial setup of this guy was a bit of a hassle.  Hold the button down for 15 seconds (or more) and it flashes, which changes it from always on or always off mode to the mode where it sense darkness.  Hold it down while the light is on to adjust the brightness.  Sounds simple but it's confusing because it's not responsive.  Pressing the button turns it on and off.  It communicates back by blinking.  Overall, I would have preferred some mechanical switches on the back to set the mode.Anyway, once you have it set up, it works well.  It doesn't turn on and off instantly like the levitron.  There's a delay.  Also this unit requires a much darker room before it turns on.  All the lights have to really be off and it has to really be dark outside.  Anyway it works well for my use and I recommend it.I'll probably keep this one in the great room and get a couple more levitrons for places I want to light up but that don't require as many lumens.  This is adjustable, but why pay more for a product that puts out more light if you don't need the extra light?

This is a pretty nice door closer.  It closes the door firmly but doesn't allow it to slam.  I have mine set up with the bulky part on the door and the little arm above it (which, I think, is the standard configuration) but it can be set up on either side and even under the door jamb.  Good quality materials and workmanship and the little adjustment screws make a big difference in how fast or slow the door shuts.  Should be configurable for almost any taste.The main thing about this closer that was unexpected and possibly a negative for some is that it puts a lot of pressure on the door.  After installing it, I tried the door and thought it was fine but my wife came over and couldn't comfortably open it with one hand.  The kids (ages 2-6) can't seem to open it at all so far.  This item puts a lot more closing pressure than most door closers.  If you have kids or wimpy people going through the door, I'd suggest going with one with a smaller spring.  The internet says spring size 3 corresponds to 5 pounds of closing force.  Either this is a bit higher than that or five pounds is more than we think it is.  I'd suggest spring size 2 or even 1 for most people based on my experience with this product.The arm also rubs across the top of the door, but that would be the fault of the installer (me).  I was so worried about the two connections being too far apart that I put them too close together.  I'll have to adjust my installation.By the way installation was fine.  My only issue was that it turns out my door is metal stuffed with styrofoam.  I could have sworn it was wood.  Anyway, the instructions are all snooty and say you have to tap metal doors for machine screws.  I have never even seen a tool to do that.  I used the regular screws and it works, but some day it will probably fall on my head or something.  Maybe they could figure out a better way to attach to metal doors--one that doesn't require fancy tools.

I needed these for one particular shelf in my walk-in closet that is just the right height to nail me in the head.  I'm happy with them.  They are very thick and bouncy.  Much more so than I expect.  I could bang my head on the corner as hard as I want now without a problem.They come with little papers with several pieces of double sticky tape on them.  I guess I don't see why they can't just put adhesive on the interior of the foam itself, covered by wax paper.  Maybe some people only want to adhere one side.Anyway, very good quality child(adult)-proofing corner protects.

I'm very happy with this deadbolt.  I use it for the door between my house and garage (which is the one we end up always using).  I put it up high so my little kids can't get out during the day.  I had to do everything, including drilling all the holes.  It wasn't too hard and turned out great.  A few things to note:1. You don't need a circular hole cutter for this.  Usually when you do a door, you use those 2 1/8 hole cutters to make a spot for their doorknobs and deadbolts but the template here actually wants a square hole and recommends cutting it with four cuts through with a smaller bit, like 7/8 inch.  I purchased a hole cutter for this project and didn't use it.  guess I'll take it back.  Though to be fair, maybe the hole cutter would have worked...making the third drill hole was a pain.  I ended up using a smaller bit to cut out some parts to make it fit right.2. Setting the combination is extremely easy and foolproof.  I think I have read of people having trouble, but the design must have changed.  To change the combination, they have turning switches on the back.  You use a little screwdriver (included) to turn them so the ones you want in the combination face out.  That's it.  Nothing to mess up, really.3. In order to switch this from a left handed door to right handed, there's a pin you have to pull with needle nosed pliers.  It required a surprisingly hard tug to get out and it was hard to get a grip on.  It worked, though.  That was the only adjustment.4. As some people may have mentioned, the order of the numbers/letters you press doesn't matter.  That dramatically cuts down the number of unique combinations.  Still too many for a normal crook to get through by trial and error (5811 possibilities, by my calculation), but if you are interested in high security, you should look elsewhere.So how is the operation?  Pretty great.  From the inside, there's a little handle you turn one way to lock it and the other way to unlock it.  Unfortunately there's no indication of whether it is locked or unlocked when you just walk up to it (with a normal deadbolt, horizontal means locked and vertical means unlocked.).  That would have been a nice feature.  But anyway, locking and unlocking from the inside is super easy.From the outside, you turn a little knob one way to lock and enter the combination and turn the other way to unlock.  This door doesn't automatically lock when the door is shut.  You always have to lock it if you want the door locked.  Just like a regular deadbolt.Fit and finish are great.  It's pretty sturdy and functions well.  I'm sure an attack with a crowbar or something would take it down fast, but anyone with that kind of determination could get through any of my doors or windows pretty easily.  Regardless of how strong it actually is, it looks very strong and unbreakable.  Reasonably good deterrent.I think I'm going to swap out the door handle for one that doesn't lock at all and rely exclusively on this for security through that door.  That way I will never be locked out.  I may buy another one of these for the back door.  My kids are always sneaking out of that one as well.

Well, it's a piece of plastic and four screws.  My car doesn't have holes for a front plate and I just moved to a state that requires front plates.  I was inclined to drill a few holes and screw the plate straight on.  My wife insisted that instead we get a mounting kit.This kit is basically a piece of plastic and four screws.  Not really much of a point, actually.  I ended up using the four holes as a guide and drilling through the bumper, then screwing through the license plate, mounting kit, and bumper.  That's basically what it's intended for.As far as I can tell, this doesn't serve any functional purpose except maybe to prevent the license from rattling around or scratching your paint.  A bit of shelf liiner would have done the same thing.Still, it works.  Attaching a license to a car (even if there are no pre-drilled holes) isn't rocket science.The kit recommends that you get a frame (sold separately) and a clear plate cover (sold separately).  I didn't.  None of this stuff is needed, frankly.
Took a long time to arrive but works well.  Now my cable line doesn't poke out toward the TV stand so much.

These are pretty basic keyboards and mice.  The keyboards are pretty flat and lightweight.  Pretty quiet keys with relatively little key depth--not quite like a laptop keyboard but close.  The mice are pretty standard optical mice.  Everything here is pretty much what you expect.The real nice thing about this item is how economical it is.  Totally worth it.
Comfy, stretchy, flexible, blocks the light. Protects from jellyfish.  This is a great swimming hood.

With most LED bulbs I tend to go down from the rated wattage equivalent.  LED's tend to be brighter than you expect.  Not so with these...I wish had I bought brighter ones.  Their heat sink is also quite large and they don't give off very diffuse light.  I mean, they work and are fine, but not as attractive as a candelabra bulb usually is, nor is the directionality of the light very good.
3 HDMI cables of good quality for a good price.  What more can you ask?

These switches work well.  I use them to control a light and ceiling fan where I had only a small box.  The only downside is that it has a very loud click when you switch it on.  I mean, really loud.The main competitor to this I see is Levitron.  I have a couple of the Levitron version of this as well.  It has thinner switch levers with uncomfortably sharp edges.  It's also loud.  Maybe a smidge quieter and requires a smidge less force, but overall the Cooper version is much better.  The nice round edges on these switch levers is pretty important.I don't know why no two gang switches like this are quiet.
These cables work well for me.  No complaints.
These filters work well in my fridge and make the water taste great (from tap it's pretty nasty here).  This was the most economical place to get them by far.  Thanks, Coral.
Great cables.  Very short.  Only useful when two small devices or ports are real close together, but it really helps cut down the cable clutter.
This cable works and looks good.  What more could you want.

I installed this in my garage so I won't have to fumble for a light.  It has worked very well.  There are controls for how long the light will stay on, how bright the room has to be before it will not turn the light on, and how wide an angle to look for before working.  It has a switch at the bottom that allows you to force it to be on or off as well as a motion detector.And it works reliably.  That's the most important thing for me.  Fits in a standard decorative outlet location and was easy to wire up.By the way, don't forget to set the control for how long the light should stay on.  The factory setting is 15 seconds.  Good for testing but that's about it.

This is a great tool.  First, if you don't have a cordless drill/screwdriver, get one right away.  They are so great.  I regret the years I used my hands for screwdriver stuff and a drill with an extension cord for drilling.  I guess I was scared of batteries being lame like they were some years ago.  This and other cordless drills are the first and most important power tools in your arsenal.  Leave the extension cord in the garage.I labored hard to decide whether to purchase this or the matrix drill.  Their matrix drill looks more or less like this but it costs less and the tip can be removed and replaced with an impact drill, reciprocating saw, and a bunch of other tools that are pretty inexpensive.  Neat idea.  I finally decided to get this instead because it's a better drill and screwdriver.  I'll buy those other tools separately.Why is this better than the matrix drill and other drills in B&D's lineup?  This drill has significantly greater torque and speed.  It also has two speeds.  Remember, a cordless drill is part drill and part screwdriver.  For the screwdriver, the (relatively) slow speed is imperative.  For a drill you want it to be able to go super fast if needed.  That's what you get here.  This model is more powerful, faster, and slower than the matrix or other B&D models.  It's their best drill.Couple of other nice features:  It has an LED light on it.  The light comes on when you lightly press the trigger, before the drill starts.  So you can use it to position the drill or screwdriver.  Very nice.  And it's nice that it has a little holder for the most common tools you use, a flathead and Phillips screwdriver.The drill is surprisingly small overall.  Much smaller than my old corded drill (which was itself a rather small model).  Nevertheless it has a lot of power and speed.  It's also pretty noisy.  I guess all drills are, but this one has a higher pitched whine than I'm used to and the overall motor noise is greater. Bit surprising.  The handle is also quite small around.  It works well with medium and even small hands.  Much more ergonomic than older models.  The handle and everything else around is rubberized and feels durable.20 V Max is the new Black and Decker standard for lots of their tools.  They have a ton of power tools that use this type of battery, and they also have a bunch of yard tools that use it.  All interchangeable, so there's a good chance you will have a good use for the second battery.  This battery last a long time so unless you use your drill a LOT it's not going to run out while you are working.  Anyway, the batteries don't look like in the picture.  They are black with orange lettering to match the drill.  They are 1.5 Amp-Hour batteries.  This was actually a surprise because my Black and Decker weed whacker and leaf blower came with a 20 V max battery but it is a bigger, 4 amp hour model.  They are interchangeable, but somehow I thought there was only one size.  Not so.  Of course, those yard tools need a lot more power than this.  But if you really need a long lasting battery, I guess you could get yourself a fat 4 amp hour battery and drill like crazy.  My week whacker can work for a surprisingly long time on a charge.As I mentioned above, this drill can go very fast and slow.  It does seem to have a little more inertia than my old drill.  That is, when you stop drilling abruptly, it jolts your hand more than I'm used to.  Definitely plenty of torque for even very intense jobs.  If this has problems, you have a very special need and should get an impact drill or something.The keyless chuck is great.  No more having to dig around for the key in order to change bits or screwdrivers.  I haven't had any problems with it slipping or anything.  It's quick and easy to use.  This drill also can take a half inch bit...larger than the 3/8 bit limit most drills around have.There's a switch on top that takes you from setting 1, with lots of torque but slow speed (for screwing) to setting 2 with lots of speed (for drilling).  The drill sounds the same regardless of which setting you use, so it may not be obvious that one setting is going around way faster.This drill also has a clutch, so it can work like a torque wrench.  It has 22 settings for how hard you want the drill to work before it will stop (cheaper drills have fewer or none).  You can also set it to not slip.  That's 23 total by my count.  I don't see where the  24 comes from.  Anyway, it's way more than is needed, but just another way to know this is their serious drill.The switch to change spin direction is a little harder to flip than I'm used to, but it works.  There are arrows on the side indicating which way is selected, but they aren't all that obvious.  Anyway I always give it a little test spin before doing my thing just to make sure I have it going the desired direction...always have.What else can I say? This is a great drill and a great screwdriver.  It's better than the others from Black and Decker and highly functional overall.  I would have liked the matrix functionality (to change the tip to impact drill or other tools) but it's better to have tools that are good at a few things than ok at a lot.

Love these mattress frames.  Will never go back to using a box spring.These hold you at just the right height and make a lot of room for storage under the bed.I like to but a bit of shelf liner on them so my mattress doesn't slip off, though.

Love this drive, and how cheap I got it.  The computer I am using to write this review is using it.  I find this to be the perfect size.  If you have a ton of large files that exceed the comfortable capacity of this drive, better to keep them on a server somewhere than on your desktop.This has been reliable to me and seems fast, but it's not easy to compare the speeds of SSD drives.  They are all real fast.

These are great bulbs at a great price.  I have them in many locations in the house.  I actually find LED bulbs to be *significantly* brighter than their rated watt equivalents.  These are best where you would use a 75 or even 100 watt incandescent bulb.  In most locations, I prefer the bluefire 40 watt equivalent bulbs.  They are slightly less bright, but still brighter than a 60 watt incandescent.

I use this to shower my small children.  2.0 GPM is not really a water saving setting.  It's normal high water shower flow.  Having said that, it's perfect for those who want a normal shower head.  Works well and doesn't leak.  Nice long hose and good aesthetics.  What else can you ask of a handheld shower head?
This light impresses me.  It's metal and the holder is really good quality.  Much better than expected.

I've been very happy with this Dremel.  I actually returned a battery powered one because I hate buying power tools and then having their batteries wimp out after a few years.  A/C powered is the way to go.

It works.  I had to wraps some black tape around the clear ring around the white light because it shines brightly and disables my night vision.  Otherwise it's fine.  This is cheap stuff but it works and it won't get stolen.

This light is a step above what I expected.  It's metal, not plastic.  And the thing that attaches it to your bike actually works well.  And it comes with a case.  You can also dial it to make it a spotlight or a more diffuse light.  The switch is in the back and it's very positive.I just wanted something to stick on my bike so I don't get run over.  I've had several brands and they have all been really cheap stuff from China.  This one is significantly better constructed.

These batteries and this charger worked for me.  I've never timed them to see if they last a long time.  The OEM battery doesn't last all that long either, so having several and a charger is the way to go.These batteries are shorter than the OEM battery.  I would guess that means they have less capacity as well.
No problems here.  It cuts pills and stores them in the little compartment below.  Fit and finish could have been a bit better (the lid is a bit off-center) but it doesn't affect functionality.

I wanted to love this scanner, but at best I like it.  If I was buying again, I would probably get the same one but I wouldn't be as elated the second time.Here's the thing: when you have this plugged into a windows computer through USB, it's a super scanner.  Fast, accurate, can do a lot of stuff. Excellent results every time.  But that's not why I bought it.  There are scanners all over the place that can do that stuff.  I wanted one that could connect to my wireless network and scan directly to a shared network drive, save to a USB stick, send to my email, and work with my linux computer.  Very few scanners can do all of that and they are typically large and expensive.  So in a sense this is a very special scanner: just what I was looking for.Unfortunately, when you scan to a network drive, you can't do all the things you can do from the windows interface. For example, you can scan to color or black and white, but not greyscale.  The black and white for this scanner doesn't look all that great, so I would really prefer greyscale.  Only works with windows.  But that's not how I use the scanner!  There are lots of other stuff it can do when connected to your computer that it won't do in standalone mode.  The speed when you use it with a windows computer is extreme.  It can pound through paper.  But when you use it in standalone mode, it's not nearly as fast.  At least in standalone mode, if you move up to 600dpi you lose the following: auto-detect paper size, blank page removal, deskew.  The scanner can do all sorts of good things, just not at the same time.These things bothered me a lot when I first got it and was eating through the mountain of documents I had sitting around waiting to be scanned.  Now that I only scan new things coming in it's no big deal.  Still, it wouldn't have taken much for them to have given the standalone scanner the same functionality as the scanner when it's connected to the computer, minus OCR, I guess.  This scanner is special because of its standalone capability and for no other reason.Ok, so how about the typical complaints about this scanner? Well, there's only one roller and it's short and in the middle.  If you load the paper crooked or it doesn't grab right, it can easily go in crooked.  That's happened several times.  Only with single sheets. If you do a stack, the papers on top hold the one being scanned down and it works fine.The other complaint people have is that it pulls multiple pages in at a time and jams or skips a page.  This has happened to me twice in many hundreds of pages, so I don't think it's much of a problem.  Really, the key is to prep the paper the way the manual tells you to.  Make sure the pages are not stuck together, then set them up so that the earlier pages stick out slightly more than the later pages.  It's not hard and results in a good scan.Last complaint is usability.  You have to set up these shortcuts to do anything.  You can't just walk up and press buttons to get the scan you want.  That's pretty annoying.  The purpose of shortcuts is to save time, not to allow functionality that can't be had otherwise.  Well, anyway, you set them up and it works ok.  But again, there are certain things you can't set in the shortcuts.  For example, you can't set a shortcut to do a single-sided scan.  Only double, with detection.  If you want a single sided scan you have to use the shortcut and then go to options and change it.  Every time. That's a pretty basic usability problem.  I mean, you can get it done, but they haven't really set things up so it's easy.This is no professional level scanner.  It's a compact, light duty scanner.  As such it doesn't pull paper as reliably as a professional office scanner.  But no one expects it to.  Personally I think the hardware is great for what it is, and the software is workable, even if not perfectly convenient.I've actually complained a lot in this review.  It's not because I don't like the scanner.  It's a good scanner and gets everything I want done.  It's just so close to perfect without being there.  They could probably make this a fantastic scanner with a firmware update.  The roller issue couldn't be fixed so easily, but as I said, it's not a big problem.  If I wanted/needed a super-reliable and efficient scanner for high volume, I would have shelled out the money and space for one.========== Edit a month later ===============When this scanner is run in standalone mode, it's just too hobbled.  When I first got it it would do scans at 600 dpi if you specified the paper size instead of using auto and if you did color.  But I did a network refresh because it wasn't connected to the network and it deleted some settings.  Now it won't scan at above 300 dpi regardless of other settings.  I change change this here or in the web interface.  600dpi is always greyed out.The hardware for this scanner is ok, but the software is just so heinous and it is purposely limited in really annoying ways.  I regret purchasing it.  Wish I had returned it right away.  Already threw away the box but thinking of trying some kind of return anyway.

This is an interesting little key ring.  I'm very pleased with it (I previously used regular string as a keychain but I ended up cutting it whenever I needed to lend the keys to someone.Couple of things I notice about it:1. Yes, it's flexible, but not very.  It's actually quite a stiff and thick metal cable.  It works fine as a keychain and is flexible enough to be comfortable in the pocket, but if you bent it hard I'm sure you would kink it.  Not sure why such a thick cable is needed, but I'm not an engineer.2. I like this clasp.  You have to twist and pull.  And when I say twist, I mean you have to twist a long ways.  That's why people say you have to make this thing into a figure 8.  It's more of a hassle than some key rings, but once you do it a few times it's easy enough.  If I were the type of person who took keys off multiple times a day I wouldn't want these.  However, I only remove keys very periodically.3. I do wish the clasp was a bit shorter.  That portion of the ring doesn't bend.  On the other hand, if it were shorter it would probably be hard to remove.4. Size is good.  I only keep like 5 keys on there and I was afraid it would be too long.  I'd say if you have 10 or fewer keys, this will work for you.  It's not overly big.Overall a great key ring.  Worth the purchase.

I sleep in earplugs every night and have for years.  I've used a ton of brands and this is the best brand and model I've used.I used to think one earplug was pretty much as good as the next but now I know that is not true.  These are special for a few reasons:1. They are a little shorter.  This could be a bad thing in some use cases, but for sleeping, it's nice to have shorter earplugs because they don't stick out and press against the pillow.  They also are less likely to make you sweat in your ear (yes, it happens).2. They exert less pressure on your ear.  When you wear earplugs for a long time the pressure can get quite irritating.  These are the most gentle earplugs I've used.3. They are softer than other earplugs.  They squish up and go in easily.  I guess pretty much all earplugs are easy enough, though, so while this is different, it's not necessarily better than its competitors.4. They conform more easily to your ear.  Lots of earplugs try to push your ear canal into a cyclindrical shape.  These just fill up the empty space comfortably.5. They make a good seal.  Much more than other ear plugs, their pliability allows them to fill all the crevices and stop the sound coming in.  I *think* it might be possible to get better sound absorption by a denser earplug than these, but only if you can get it to fill and sit just right.Overall these are better than any other brand I've used.  I wish the color was less earwax-like and the shortness takes a little getting used to (might not be everyone's preference) but overall they are highly recommended.
This product works for me. No complaints and it's really small.

I don't think someone from my generation would have the imagination to design a book this way, or to include a photo feature about a Supreme Court Justice's "swag." But fundamentally this is a wonderful book about the difference an individual can make. The book's breezy style has a deeper and more serious significance, as well.I was touched by many things in this book, not only the courage of Justice Ginsburg's opinions, or the loving handwritten note from her dying husband, but even by the photos illustrating her close friendship with Justice Scalia, one of her ideological opposites - it's rare to see such a mensh in these times. The format is terrifically creative for this sort of subject: the NY Times reviewer aptly described it as being "as if a scrapbook and the Talmud decided to have a baby." The latter comes in especially for the way the book's margins are used for commenting on everything -- not just for the obvious connections to a Justice who is Jewish. (Apropos of that, though, one thing did puzzle me: the recipe for pork in milk at the back. Breaking two of the Jewish religion's food taboos at once -- isn't that a little gangsta? Was that the idea, or is the whole thing a joke? And actually, one other thing: the publisher's subject classification on the back cover is "Fiction." Aside from the recipe, I hope not.)I now live in Japan and teach comparative constitutional law there. Pretty much no one, including most law professors, can name the justices of the Japan Supreme Court, who are chosen for their anonymity, their conformity to a certain social background, and their timidity of thought. And throughout its nearly 70-year existence, the JSC has always upheld laws and regulations that limit civil rights. One reason I got this book was to be able to show my students how completely different the relationship between a country's Supreme Court and its citizens can be. In most countries of the world, a book like this would be inconceivable. While I'm not saying that many other Justices deserve such a tribute, this book should be a great reminder for Americans how lucky you are not only to have Justice Ginsburg, but also to be capable of such affectionate engagement with your government.

This book isn’t the exercise in applied analytic philosophy one might expect on the basis of its being published by Cambridge University. Rather, it’s a fierce and at times flowery defense of the enterprise of astrobiology, and especially of the search for extraterrestrial intelligence (SETI), by one of the more prolific and imaginative members of the SETI community. Critics of either of those fields get a pretty sharp drubbing from the author (MMC).SETI and, to a lesser extent, astrobiology are some of the areas of scientific inquiry most influenced by literature: until we actually meet an alien life form or an ETI (which may be “postbiological,” @174), science fiction remains one of the best resources for imagining different scenarios. I thought MMC made good use of this literature throughout the book, and I also enjoyed the use of of paintings by René Magritte to illustrate the difficulties of distinguishing the natural from the artificial when it comes to identifying just who the ETs are, if we ever do encounter them (Chap. 8). Still, I thought there were many topics he didn’t address, such as the nature of a civilization, that would be appropriate in a more thorough philosophical approach to this topic.The writing style is quite different not only from usual philosophical writing but also from usual scientific writing, and was something of an obstacle for me. I admire MMC’s skill given that apparently English is at least a second language for him. But the tone has a sort of Edwardian ornateness about it, e.g. there is a philosophical dialogue with a character called “Simplicio,” on more than 20 occasions various people are called “distinguished” something or others, books are often “remarkable” or the objects of some other adjectival hyperbole, and paragraphs often have a circuitous flow. It became very tiring to get to the nub of what MMC was trying to say: maybe because I went out to brunch on the weekend I read it, I couldn’t help thinking that the book’s insights were hidden under way too much Hollandaise sauce.The book includes a very extensive and useful list of references in addition to endnotes. The index, though, is not so helpful: e.g., to find “postbiological” you’ll need to know the name of an author who pursues this topic (Stephen Dick, under ‘D’), because there isn’t anything about it under ‘P.’ And shame on the folks at CUP: Bad enough that they couldn’t recognize the gibberish Greek “quotation” from Thucydides (@41; it is utterly meaningless as printed, and would have botched the original even had it been spelt correctly), they should have at least been suspicious about whether the Latin expression “Hic Rhodes, hic salta!” was really an “old Greek saying” (@107). (In fact it’s the author’s mangling of Karl Marx’s mangling (“Hic Rhodus, hic salta!”) of Hegel’s uncomprehending quote of Erasmus’s Latin translation (“Hic Rhodus, hic saltus!) of a line from one of Aesop’s fables, which was in Greek.) In sum: if you can tolerate its excesses, the book will help you find a lot of the more thoughtful literature on astrobio and SETI.[POSTSCRIPT: You can find a more soberly written and more thorough philosophical analysis is David Lamb's "The Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence" (Routledge 2001). It lacks the imaginative touches of MMC's book such as reference to paintings, and lacks the more recent references you can find in the book under review -- but it also lacks MMC's intrusive cheerleading for "transhumanism." Ultimately Lamb was more helpful to get me up to speed about some of the key philosophical arguments in astrobiology.]

The idea of this book is original and intriguing: to go back to classical Roman authors (Cicero, Sallust, Horace) to find inspiration for a post-Occupy form of republicanism. Unfortunately though, I found it very hard to get into the book — in fact, I was unable to finish the whole thing, despite being very accustomed to reading political theory, and also having several years of distant but not entirely rusty Latin under my belt.I’m posting a review for two purposes: first, in the hope that someone who reads this can direct me to a more succinct and straightforward presentation, if one exists, of the book’s thesis; and second, to give a heads-up to other readers who may be coming to the book from a different disciplinary or philosophical orientation. I come from more of a law and politics background than a lit crit one, and in recent years probably read more European scholarship than American. Maybe those factors have something to do with why I was so put off the style of presentation in this work. In giving the book four stars, I’m trying to give the book the benefit of the doubt, since I don’t know how to allocate the blame for my difficulties fairly as between my own limitations and the book’s.The author (JC) seems to draw the most intense inspiration from Cicero among classical authors, and from Hannah Arendt among modern ones. I confess to having a real antipathy for the prose style of each of these authors, plus some other reservations about Arendt, so this may be a situation where my own mishugas (3rd declension?) was the main impediment to my enjoyment of the book. And as JC admits, another problem is that Cicero was a spokesman for the power of the wealthy in Rome, so it takes a lot of explaining to transform him into a hero for the 99 Percent.On the other hand, I didn’t do much better with the chapter about one of my favorite Roman historians, Sallust. The main problem was that the discussion of his texts is chopped up between long digressions endorsing or sparring with points made by modern scholars, sometimes several of whom are discussed within the space of a single paragraph. JC also makes frequent references to painters and modern literary authors (e.g., Cézanne and Henry James), which are imaginative touches that I appreciated, except for wishing that they didn’t interrupt the discussion of, well, Sallust.A different type of difficulty comes up in JC's discussion of one of Horace’s bawdiest satires (Sermonum I.ii.). The poet recommends having affairs with freedwomen instead of other men’s wives: while he’s having sex with such a woman he doesn’t have to worry that her husband will come home, she’ll jump up, and he (Horace) will have to run out with an undone toga and barefoot; “It is wretched to be caught,” he advises us.  JC takes issue with another author who had said “Horace has no real issue with adultery: his argument is against stupidity”: “This reading takes us in the wrong direction,” says JC, “privileging the notion of a coherent subject that [sic] has a goal of self-government through self-knowledge. We should attend more carefully to Horace’s suggestion that judging others is violent and deceitfully seductive, not in so far as we fail to know ourselves but rather in so far as we trust too blindly in the redemptive power of self-knowledge” (@133). I couldn’t find anything quoted from Horace up to that point where he suggests that judging others is “violent” or “deceitfully seductive”: this seems to be imputed to him through JC’s personal reading. But more than that, her comment struck me as taking very broad humor way too seriously, and importing into it all sorts of theoretical concepts (such as “subjects”) that probably modern academics can see much better than typical readers, ancient or modern. (Cf. Jerry Lewis movies and the French film theorists of the 1960s.)Even if Horace did have a serious intention beneath his slapstick, a weakness of this book's very heavy and intricate reading is that there isn’t any attempt to show that Horace’s intended audience would have understood the satire in this way; nor is it claimed that this reading of his work had historical importance because it was adopted by someone like, say, Machiavelli, Locke, the Framers of the US Constitution, etc.. Without such anchoring, you're thrown back to the position that a text can mean almost anything that an imaginative critic can pull out of it. And while that might sometimes be a defendable position, it begs the question of why Horace's satire provides a better vehicle for this message about self-knowledge and republicanism than some other piece of literature, apart from the accident that Latin literature is JC's academic specialty.On a more prosaic level: the book has true footnotes and a list of references, a welcome departure from the recent university press fashion of endnotes only. However, I ran into at least one footnote citing only to a Kindle "location," without a corresponding page reference. I own a print copy of the book in question (from Cambridge UP), but the citation was meaningless to me. Kindle-only citations would be a very disturbing trend. Probably the simplest way to avoid them would be for ebook publishers, especially university presses, to include real page numbers in their electronic versions; in the meantime, they should require authors to include page references, even if they also include a "location."JC says in her concluding paragraph, “I have sought to offer practical tools for civic education by articulating learnable _practices of knowing the world_ that characterize late republican texts. These practices arise from close reading, and I hope it is clear that the purpose of laying out my own readings in detail is to put the interrogative ethos that fuels them on display as much as to advocate for their content” (@208; emphasis in original). I totally agree about the importance of civic education, but only an academic could believe that the sort of analysis presented in the book could a practical tool for educating anyone outside a ridiculously elite audience. Even as a book of theory, more directness would have been helpful. Just this month alone I've read three books of theory that were truly exciting (Norberto Bobbio's "Destra e Sinistra," "Construir Pueblo" by Íñigo Errejón and Chantal Mouffe, and Christoph Möller's "The Three Branches"); none were easy, the theses were diverse, I didn't agree with any of them 100%, but each of them presented its arguments clearly. I was looking forward to this book's continuing that streak, and maybe even improving my opinion of Cicero, but neither of those happened. Perhaps if in a future work the author would concentrate less on demonstrating her erudition and more on communicating the urgency of the classical texts in a down-to-earth way, she could get more readers to share both her “interrogative ethos” and her enthusiasm.

Some important statistics about this book: the P-to-E section of this dictionary runs to 674 double-columned pages, while the E-to-P section is 40% bigger, at around 942. My unabridged monolingual Michaelis dictionary (Brazilian) runs to over 2000 triple-columned pages a few centimetres taller and a kilo or two heavier than the present volume, so this imbalance certainly isn't because there's any shortage of vocabulary or denotations in Portuguese. And although it has fewer entries overall, the Collins Concise dictionary manages to keep the discrepancy between the two sections within less than 10%. While it's certainly larger than other P/E dictionaries currently in print, and contains both Brazilian and European usage, it seems to be a dictionary better-suited for translating from English to Portuguese rather than the other way around. Multinationals looking to adapt their instruction manuals when selling into Brazil and other Lusophone markets might be well-served by this tilt.But even gung-ho globalists who are used to the performance standard set by, say, the the unabridged Collins French/English or German/English dictionaries — which are comparably priced — will be very disappointed with this work. For example, if you translate business writing from English into Portuguese, you won't find basic terms like 'tender offer,' 'leveraged buy-out,' 'put' (the right to demand that a counterparty buy an asset from you), or 'call' (the right to demand that a counterparty sell an asset to you). All of these are in the Collinses I mentioned, together with much more.Conversely, if you’re mainly interested in reading contemporary Brazilian literature and song lyrics, as I am (along with law and social science), you're also going to have some frustrations with this book. In the P/E section there are a few text boxes here and there that explain some of the names of political parties, a few popular music styles, etc. But despite these, you’d never know that “balanar” connotes dancing, and the book definitely ain’t got that “suinge.” The ubiquitous colloquial adjective “legal” is defined with an affectless “good” (it’s more like “terrific!”) If you prefer your beer cold, you’d never know that in Brazil you ask for “um chope estupidamente gelado”(or be able to figure out what that is if offered one).  If you read a headline about a “Tuiuiú na Copa” you’d never know be able to find out that the first word denotes a large bird native to the Pantanal region, much less that it’s also the nickname for a person from that region (who in this case is playing in the World Cup). The E/P section does include some familiar four-letter words and other obscenities, but the translations aren’t symmetrical, e.g., an F-word expression gets turned into an S-word expression when you back-translate the Brazilian equivalent; and I was puzzled by the translations of some other common obscenities and non-vulgar pejoratives that Oxford doesn’t blink at but that send Amazon’s automated Brain Police into conniptions even with some letters replaced by asterisks (honi soit qui mal y pense, Amazon!), so I can’t identify them here. Even if you are simply reading the very polite Brazilian constitution and run across the term “Distrito Federal,” you’ll need to look elsewhere to find out that this is the area around Brasília — whereas “District of Columbia” and many similar proper nouns are in the E/P section. And while you'll be able to find the translation for "Azerbaijão" (surprise: it's "Azerbaijan"), "Iemanjá" and other important Brazilian cultural references are missing.To my annoyance, I found better translations of several terms mentioned here in either my Collins or my Larousse paperback concise dictionaries -- which means I can't free up shelf space by packing them away. And if you have the aging but indispensable Chamberlain & Harmon "Dictionary of Informal Brazilian Portuguese" (1983), don't even think of setting it aside.So the best I can say is that if some dire circumstance constrains you to have only one Portuguese-English dictionary, this book is certainly better than a concise dictionary, and much better than any made-in-Brazil bilingual dictionaries I’m aware of. But that's something of a contrived compliment, since for all but the most conventional work you're going to need other dictionaries to supplement this one. Anglophones still have a wait, it seems, for Portuguese to be on a par with other Western languages when it comes to resources for translators and the culturally curious.

This is a dense and stimulating book about constitutional theory, written from a comparative point of view. Discussing not only national contexts but also the EU and general public international law arenas, it’s a rare examination of the meaning and purpose of splitting the powers of government among legislative, executive, and judiciary branches. The author (CM) is a leading German constitutional scholar who spent time studying and teaching in the US; this is an original work in quite clear English that elaborates on a couple of earlier works he had published in German. Even though most of the examples relate to a European or North American context, I found a lot to inform my thinking about the constitutional situation in Japan, where I live and teach.Despite the “checks and balances” narrative most Americans learn in school, that’s only one possible form for the separation of powers. As CM shows in Chap. 1, France, England, the US and Germany each exemplify a different style of separation. The theme that underlies them all is the tension between individual and democratic (collective) self-determination. Only a system that facilitates and guarantees both, says CM, can enjoy legitimacy. The judiciary tends mostly to protect individual freedom (since its main function is to consider cases involving individuals), a properly-functioning legislature exemplifies democratic freedom, and the task of the executive is to link the two.
