For CM the true rationale for the separation of powers “is not the repression and facilitation of political power, but rather the organization of a model of law-making in which individual and democratic matters of self-determination gain equal recognition” (@109).The discussion of legitimacy is approached from a general and philosophical perspective in Chap. 2, then applied in Chap. 3 to certain national-scale issues (including the regulation of administrative bureaucracy, dubbed by some other writers as the “fourth branch”), and then in Chap. 4 to the specific institutions of the EU, to issues of federalism generally, and also to public international law regimes such as the UN and WTO. A final chapter offers a brief and sometimes withering assessment of some other concepts, such as “governance,” that are floating around in the modern discourse about separation of powers.Note that the book focuses on systems that are considered to be democracies: it doesn’t discuss states such as China, the Soviet Union, most modern Middle Eastern states or military governments in Asia, even though most of those countries have constitutions that pay at least lip service to a three-branch structure; and despite the cover, Brazil is mentioned only once, in passing. Some of CM’s arguments, such as his concern about the democratic deficit when a dedicated constitutional court is very active in protecting the basic rights of individuals (@134-139), seemed shaped in response to the German situation — on the contrary, I think such a court might be a very welcome thing to have in Japan, for example. But CM emphasizes that he’s not proposing a “one-size-fits-all model” (@139), so the occasional German spin doesn’t reduce the usefulness of the book as a source of ideas for readers elsewhere.As mentioned above, CM’s argument is extremely dense, and I think impossible for most readers (myself included) to fully absorb on a first pass. While his writing style uses little jargon and usually avoids twisted syntax, it consists mostly of declarations made with confident certitude, one after another after another, without solicitous pauses for the reader who may have fallen off the pace — something like the first time I tried cross-country skiing, with a friend’s family who’d each been practicing the sport since childhood. Chapter 2, the most abstractly philosophical, was especially difficult for me to focus on, but it started to make more sense when I went back to it after having read the rest of the book.The book has a bibliography as well as true footnotes, not endnotes. (Though the tone of these usually matches the serious tone of the main text, I did enjoy one footnote's reference to "the continuously imprecise" 'State of Exception' by G. Agamben.) That it’s already two years since the book’s original publication without a single Amazon review nor, to the best of my knowledge, any comment in a US law journal or law prof blog is a testimony to the parochial mentality of the US legal academy, which is given to churning out books about “liberal democracies” (plural) based entirely on the jurisprudence of the US Supreme Court. I believe this book’s ideas and arguments are important, and deserve to be widely read and discussed. Suffice it to say: I’ve got books in almost every significant area of my home and office, but I’ve made a slot for this one on a shelf within arm’s reach of my desk.

This is a very readable, not-too-difficult, but not at all easy, introduction to a difficult topic. The authors (DS/CN) aimed to pitch the book between Scientific American and the technical literature. At this they succeed, but that’s something like aiming between the top of a shopping mall and low earth orbit. It would be more accurate to say that the presentation is somewhere between SciAm and an undergraduate stat mech textbook. There’s no way, for example, that you can read this book and tackle the famous review paper on the topic by Binder & Young (Rev. Mod. Phys. 1986) unless you already have a good number of math and physics courses under your belt. What the book can give you, though, is a road-map to many of the topics that paper covers.It will also give you an overview of some applications of the mathematical apparatus of spin glass research to other areas (Chap. 6). Here I really appreciated the authors’ taste: they avoid trendy topics in economics or social physics, and stick to more reasonable fare: computational complexity, neural network computation and the protein folding problem. Cf. a paper on the arXiv about the spin glass physics of custody battles involving parents who either have more 2 or more children with multiple exes, or have children with one or more exes and are involved with a partner in a similar situation — not only is the problem contrived but it’s very unlikely in real life to be entrusted to physicists.The survey of applications doesn’t end the book, though. It’s followed by a chapter on short-range spin glasses, a family of models distinguished from those that assume an infinite spin glass, such as the Sherrington-Kirkpatrick (SK) model, which are discussed earlier. This chapter is slightly more demanding mathematically, and the authors even suggest it’s skippable altogether — though I’d advise against that, for a few reasons. First, if your math can handle the earlier chapters it can probably handle this one;  second, this chapter is referred to several times in the conclusion. And third and most importantly, this material supports the conclusion’s point that it might not be justified to push analogies too far between different types of complex systems (or “quasi-complex” systems, as the authors believe spin glasses to be, since the latter aren’t adaptive). There might not be any “universality” in the behavior of complex systems — at some point, important behavior may be sui generis.Unfortunately, history shows that such insights will do little to discourage statistical physicists from branching into family counseling, or economists from spinning their very successful tales. For example, it’s been observed for years that the equilibrium models that underlie macroeconomics and some aspects of microeconomics as well are nonsense — a point made elegantly in this book, though without reference to economics, when the authors point out that a system that’s strongly characterized by its past is a system that’s out of equilibrium (@45). Of course even spin glass physicists use unrealistic models, like SK. But those physicists don’t make or influence any decisions that could affect your life, like whether to fire you, how much to pay you, or what should be the economic policy of the country as a whole. Even the financial crash of 2008 wasn’t enough to convince economists who hadn’t foreseen it that their models were wrong; the impact of this book on that issue is likely to be somewhat more modest.When I wrote to the authors to ask about a couple of points that had confused me, they both responded immediately, warmly, and effectively. Some of my questions grew out of my misreadings, but there are a couple of points a reader might want to keep in mind. One is that what makes the hierarchical tree in Fig. 5.6 “ultrametric” isn’t just its structure, but also the particular metric used with it. The other is that although the various models aren’t written with an express dependence on temperature T, there is a factor of exp[-E/(k_B)T] buried in there (see sec. 1.5). The absence of explicit T-dependence confused me when Chap. 6 started talking about adjusting T as a parameter; maybe this will be more clearly expressed in a future edition.The book includes a useful bibliography, though a little hard to scan because it’s organized in order of citation as in some science journals like Science or Nature, rather than alphabetically as in mathematics or some non-science fields. The index isn’t adequate: for example, ‘information’ is mentioned often in the text in various senses of that word, but none are indexed. The authors told me they’d done it themselves, because a professional job is expensive — since another Princeton U Press book I read recently had an even more amateurish index, I suspect that Princeton’s contract terms with its authors might be a little too greedy, shifting the indexing cost to them without regard to the impact on the book’s users. That’s a very minor point that’s not so pertinent to whether you should read this book. If you’re new to spin glasses, you should.

This is the sort of book only a law professor, current or aspiring, would pick up, much less finish. In fact, since most American law professors have no interest in comparative law, most of them will ignore it, too. Nonetheless, for a book in such an uncharismatic genre, it’s pretty good.The premise of the book is to encourage researchers in comparative law to be more thoughtful about the range of methodologies available to them. The author’s approach is patient and careful. Most of the book (Chaps. 3-9) focuses on teasing out the many ambiguities hiding the two key questions, What is ‘comparison’?, and What is ‘law’? It turns out that these concepts aren’t so easily pulled apart, especially when one recognizes the difficulty of maintaining the position that laws are rules, plain and simple. I found some of the chapters about methods of comparison — esp. the chapters on structural comparison and hermeneutical method — to be particularly well presented; e.g., if you’re afraid your grip on legal positivism, Hohfeld’s model of rights, duties, powers, etc. or Kelsen’s pure theory of law isn’t so solid, here you’ll find nice, clear descriptions in just a couple of sentences each.Along the way, one learns of some astonishingly dumb, dogmatic positions that famous comparatists have taken, among them: always start from the assumption that the systems you’re comparing are similar, and if you find that they don’t resolve an issue in the same way from a functional point of view, you’ve probably done something wrong; don’t waste your time comparing legal systems from the same tradition (civil law, common law, etc.); the categories used in English law are exactly identical to those in the Digest of Roman law; and even if some cultures didn’t or don’t have a concept of “rights” (like ancient Athens), all people have had rights, at all times in history and in all places. The author names and shames, but I leave that for you to discover when you read the book. The last two chapters present a series of dichotomies one should keep in mind when planning a comparative analysis —- a framework for the very undogmatic, “pluralistic, dialectical” approach the author encourages you to adopt.The book has some limitations. Maybe not surprisingly for a book in the European Academy of Legal Theory Monograph Series, it’s very Eurocentric, focusing especially on such European issues as harmonization (which constitutes universalization, the opposite of comparison, in the author’s view). As a result, certain uses of comparison, such as in developing legislation for practical domestic use, don’t get attention. The concrete examples (of which there were a bit too few, I felt) tend to come from the traditional textbook favorites of commercial and tort law — the same topics emphasized in the comp law textbook I studied from more than 30 years ago. Nothing about such modern mainstream fields as, e.g., intellectual property or privacy law — and my own main interest, constitutional law, is dismissed with an adverb when the author notes that “only” constitutional lawyers would be interested in Kelsen’s model, @101. Ironically, the text hews to the dogma of comparison between but not within traditions: all examples are based on that old chestnut, contrasting common law with civil law, but never, say, English vs. Scottish (much less American) or German vs. French. Also adding to the retro flavor is that the most modern “-ism” the book discusses is structuralism, whereas I know French comparatists in their 40s who speak a much more Foucauldian idiom, and maybe they already sound like old fogeys to their students.That said, the book makes welcome use of a wealth of French sources as well as English ones. The prose is earnest, a bit wordy perhaps, and some anecdotes or examples are repeated once or twice too often (such as Marie-Laure Izoche’s analogy that the purpose of a playing card only makes sense in the context of the full deck), but you probably aren’t expecting a ripping yarn when you pick up a book like this anyway, and this one is generally free of jargon and tortured academic syntax. Far more useful than slogging through one of those gigantic and pricey “companions to” or “handbooks of” the subject, this is a helpful, concise and cost-effective introduction to the philosophy of comparative law.

I'm not a mathematician and no longer a student, just someone who reads math occasionally for refreshment. I picked up this book as part of my summer break reading, and found it perfectly suited to an enjoyable couple of days. Although it claims to be directed to an audience of grad students and professionals, I'm far away from either qualification: having read a book or two about knots and pieces of books about graphs in the distant past was enough to enable me to enjoy most of it.Most of the book relates to material published jointly or severally by the authors in the past couple of years, especially concerning the group action of duals and twists on ribbon graphs. Many of the pertinent references are on the arXiv and more than a few date from between 2010-2014, so the material is still very current as I write. However, the book is a synthesis and refinement, not just a repetition, of that material. It's richly illustrated, so you can learn a lot from trying to reproduce the diagrams. The pictures alone are already very suggestive of how embedded graphs are connected to knots and links. (I also really liked the authors'  phrase "twisted duality" -- geometrically apt, but maybe also a useful metaphor for marriage counselors and other therapists?)I do recommend though that you know something about graph and knot polynomials, which are of great interest to working mathematicians. My knowledge was more than zero but epsilon-sized in this area, and I wound up skimming large chunks of the algebraic proofs showing how various polynomials (e.g. Tutte, Penrose, Bollabás-Riordan, Jones, and HOMFLY, plus Kaufmann bracket) were related to each other and/or to the authors' "transition polynomial". The book's treatment of these topics is self-contained but only in a perfunctory way, despite (or perhaps because of) the topics' importance for many readers.I read this in the paperback edition. Thanks to Springer for allowing many illustrations in the print book make effective use of color. The list of references is good, the index is mostly adequate, and the number of typos average or less for a typical math book. The one drawback is that the price is a little steep for a thin book like this; but it's still pretty good value compared to some Springer Briefs in other fields. (I bought mine at a discount during the publisher's annual Yellow Sale.) Assuming you have the background mentioned above, this book is a fun and visually stimulating way to engage with current mathematical research, even for undergraduates and amateurs.

This review is based on using this book as a reference, not on reading it all the way through. One of the strengths of the book is its discussion of the classification of surfaces. It also has a great deal about "voltage graphs," a/k/a gain graphs, a topic that apparently was hot in the 1970s and 1980s, but that you won't find mentioned in modern textbooks like Diestel, Bollabás or Bondy. (While the two latter books have short sections on electrical networks as an example, a voltage graph was a much broader concept.) As of the end of August 2015, I found only 25 papers on the arXiv that mention voltage or gain graphs in their abstracts, spread over a more than 10-year period.That's not the only indication that the vocabulary and research areas about graphs on surfaces have come a long way since this book's publication date in 1987 -- in particular, you won't find anything about such current areas of interest as the application of graph theory to knots and links, nor anything about Tutte, Penrose, etc. polynomials, even though these ideas had already been published prior to the book's appearance.The lack of answers or hints to exercises is definitely a drawback to self-study, despite what another reviewer has proposed. The book has both a "References" list and a "Bibliography," though the difference between them isn't clearly spelled out. (The Dover edition has a supplemental bibliography from around 2001.) There is a subject index only - no name index, so, e.g., you won't be able to find references to Tutte or anyone else very easily.What really moved me to write this review was the deterioration in Dover's printing. I've been getting their books since the 1960s, and although the books stopped being bound with thread in the 1980s or so, this year (2015) I've gotten a couple of Dovers that really shocked me. This is one of them. The print is fuzzy and unpleasant to read, the paper has a lot of show-through, the product feels bulky: it looks like your usual lousy academic press digital transfer job. And the book doesn't even describe itself as being printed: it was "**Manufactured** in the United States by Courier Corporation." I've bought plenty of Dovers since 2000, when Courier acquired Dover (before being itself acquired by R.R. Donnelly this year); but either it's only recently that they shifted to lower printing quality, or else I had a long string of luck in getting earlier-printed shelf stock. The copy of Gross & Tucker I got was printed in 2013, and another title I got that was even worse than this was from 2015. Prices are jumping up, too, though this particular title is still reasonable as I write. It's worrying to think that Dovers could soon be bad value, thanks to corporate "efficiency," i.e. greed.

This book has a lot of useful material and serious reflection on an important topic: the excessive degree to which our public policy is oriented toward boosting GDP. I've been engaged with many similar topics relating to economic growth for much of the past seven years or so --- which is as long as it took the author (DP) to write the book -- and I still was able to learn a number of new things from it.The book's greatest strength is the quality of historical research that went into it, which is featured in roughly the first half of the book. Among other things, DP consulted the archives and personal papers of both Robert La Folette, Jr. and Simon Kuznets. The former was the US Senator from Wisconsin thanks to whom the US would commission its first estimates of the national income during the Depression; the latter was the future Nobel-winning economist who led the effort to compile those estimates and who in the process laid the foundation for the GDP metric. A lot of this historical detail was new to me. And it's very timely to be reminded about the humanity of La Follette, whose more famous successors as Wisconsin Republicans have included Joseph McCarthy (who defeated La Follette in a primary) and Scott Walker. The book also made me realize the important contribution of the 1944 Bretton Woods agreement to the discourse of development; I'd been under the mistaken impression that this was a postwar discourse only. DP's historical treatment is strongest in the early 20th Century through early post-WWII years. His emphasis throughout is on how GDP (then GNP) and the system of national accounts came to be standardized in the non-Communist world. The treatment is sketchier about how GDP growth came to be a priority for national policy from and after 1949. For that part of the story, one might consult the historical discussion in Walter Arndt's "The Rise and Fall of Economic Growth" (1978) and Lorenzo Fioramonti's "Gross Domestic Problem" (2013), which approach the issue from somewhat complementary angles.The second half of the book focuses more on the problems GDP-based growth causes in the world today, and why GDP isn't the appropriate metric to help us escape from them or from problems like global warming and inequality. DP proposes that we use a mix of new indicators that more directly measure things that are important to us -- and that the choice of these indicators be accomplished more democratically than was the case with the adoption of GDP. Personally I agree with DP that GDP-led growth is causing many problems and can't solve lots of others, though I wasn't entirely convinced that new quantitative indicators will be either a necessary or a sufficient part of their solution. However, DP's general approach does have a lot of support among those who criticize economic growth (including many in Continental Europe, outside the mainly Anglophone spotlight of this book).DP's writing style is serious but pleasant, and never academic. Unfortunately, though, the book could have been edited more crisply; and since DP tells us in the acknowledgments that he had a life-threatening illness after finishing the manuscript, I suspect it was the publisher's team who dropped the ball here. Some historical chapters begin with introductory digressions several pages long that make it hard for the reader to keep the thread of the story; these might have been better had they been pared down to a few paragraphs, and the rest of the material moved elsewhere. In addition to repetition of themes, there's sometimes repetition of words, as when we're told that "By today's standards, the government of 1931 was very tiny" (@72) and the same thing almost verbatim at @85. Some factual errors/inconsistencies escaped notice, as when we're told that GDP measures volume of production (@273) or the totality of goods and services produced (@3), even though DP spends much more time on correct explanations of what GDP measures (e.g., Chap. 7 and a very interesting discussion of the meaning of "final" goods and services in Chap. 10). Some words are used without much attention to their multiple connotations, particularly "measure" (as a noun) and "distribution" (in the context of income). A "measure" can be a metric, or it can be a plan or course of action, but which sense was meant wasn't always evident to me, especially when I ran into the oxymoron "qualitative measure" (@223, 230); I think "measure [i.e., metric] of quality" was meant. Similarly, it was a shock to see that GDP measures "distribution" of income (@94, 312n43), when it famously tells us nothing about how income is distributed among the population; I'm guessing this was a reference to distribution of contributions to national income across product and service sectors. There even was a running typographical glitch, when DP's own double-indented bullet-point lists were put into the same tiny type as block quotes from other people, thereby taking the punch out of precisely the things DP considered most important. An alert copy editor should have picked up almost all of the problems I've mentioned here.The book includes more than 70 pages of discursive endnotes (i.e., they talk about a lot of important stuff, not just citations), plus a good bibliography. The index, though, while looking adequate at first glance, isn't so good when put to use. The publisher used a lot of tricks of the trade to save paper, including too few subject headings (resulting in long strings of page references without much indication of each one's importance) and misuse of page ranges (such as "110-15" for "Japan," which makes it look like there's a detailed discussion of the subject there, when actually all the references are very minor, they aren't related to each other, and Japan isn't even mentioned at all on p. 114). An even bigger problem is that the notes aren't picked up in the index at all: to a reader using the book for reference or reading it non-consecutively, or to a prospective buyer looking it over before buying it, this makes DP appear to have neglected many important issues that he in fact does address. Again, this is a cost-cutting trick -- but to add insult to injury, there are four blank pages following this index, a waste of an extra 40% capacity. All in all, though, while the presentation sometimes inadvertently clouds rather than clarifies, this book has a good deal of valuable information and thoughtful analysis for the patient reader interested in GDP and growth.

This book is an interesting and imaginative attempt to justify a right of writers and readers to literary freedom, based on the "capabilities approach" of Nussbaum and Sen (hereafter, the "CA") and certain human rights articulated under public international law. Among other things, it means to be a practical application showing how the CA can lead to different results from the usual "negative rights" approach to free speech, represented by John Rawls and the rest of the liberal Kantian tradition, among others.One of the more interesting chapters uses the CA to justify government support for "high" art, a/k/a capital-C "Culture." An even more urgent motivating problem for the author (HKM) is what to do with speech that incites others to violence, including (but in her view not limited to) genocidal violence. Her proposed solution is that instead of censoring such hate speech, the state should provide means for the targets of such speech to "speak back" against it -- i.e., fight it with more freedom of speech, instead of with restrictions on free speech. As she admits, though, this slim book isn't able to deal with many potential issues with this approach, such as determining when the right of speaking back is triggered, and how to resolve conflicting claims over who may exercise it.It helps to have some familiarity with political philosophy to get the most from this book, though a reader lacking that might be able to pick up enough from the context of the discussion. There are also some references to literary theory, though often the purpose is to make distinctions from the usual theoretical point of view, as in the cases of Theodor Adorno and Roland Barthes. (When discussing the latter, though, HKM maybe rushes too quickly over the distinction between authors and writers -- you may need to reach, as I did, for a dictionary of literary theory to catch her idea.) The writing style is light on jargon compared to a lot of other works on literature and politics. But the tone is that of an academic thesis, with lots of paragraphs explaining what's ahead and more paragraphs recapitulating the the same material once it's been presented, rather than a fiery polemic.I certainly had a lot of questions after reading this book, including not only the ones HKM mentions but also about such details as whether minority linguistic groups within a society have a right to require translation of literary works. And although I'm sympathetic to the CA, especially (like HKM) in Nussbaum's version, when HKM reminds the reader that all capabilities have to be enabled simultaneously or else none of them are enabled I had the uncomfortable thought that the CA might be like the "free market": a sort of perfect state that's unattainable in practice, so all sorts of unfalsifiable utopian claims may be made for it. Still, despite the unfinished nature of the argument, I found HKM's idea of using the CA to derive distinct practical results from the usual Rawlsian approach to be very stimulating, and a good reason to read the book.

This book has some excellent aspects and some major drawbacks. Its best features are a very broad coverage of topics relating to comedy throughout history, and almost 20 pages of references and recommendations for further reading. The author's (MB's) juxtapositions of works from different periods and genres is sometimes very stimulating.MB's style, though is too clever by way more than half: it's a constant patter of allusions, quips, gratuitous references and supposed insights that too often dazzle rather than inform. E.g., MB mentions "a confederacy of dunces" in the context of a Shakespeare character (@67): the phrase comes from Swift or, if you prefer, J.K. Toole, neither of whom are discussed there at all -- it's just a gratuitous wink. Or: "When Mark Twain noted that `reports of my death have been greatly exaggerated,' he hit upon a good epitaph for comedy, for the mode suggests that death as the final outcome is itself something of an exaggeration" (@109-110). What does this mean, exactly? If it's comedy's epitaph, that means that comedy itself could die, an eventuality that even MB never suggests; but if it were to die, there wouldn't be any exaggeration. And why bring up epitaphs at all?: Twain's epitaph is something else entirely, and rather sentimental. MB's brilliant glibness too often dissolves into non sequitur or other sorts of thought-eddy that distract the reader; page after page of these rococo touches gets old very quickly.The book's other disturbing feature is that MB's taste in comedy evidently runs to the sadistic. The mild family sitcoms of the US Baby Boom years, or the animal-loving antics of films like "Fierce Creatures" (to say nothing of the pleasant plotless meanderings of much Japanese TV comedy) don't seem to be on his radar. Maybe the tortures inflicted in Voltaire's "Candide" are an important aspect of that tale's message (@83), but it's a bit much to be told that Jonathan's Swift's cruel joke about a flayed woman is "gorgeous" (@99). Similarly, after quoting an Evelyn Waugh passage mentioning how a caged fox had been killed in a British private club by being pelted with champagne bottles, MB notes, "This is more vertiginously, comically delightful than just a satire on the bottle-throwers (satire is often a way of saying that you care, but in Waugh's fiction caring itself is satirized)." (@89). I can imagine the expression on fictional detective Inspector Lewis's face were he to read that while investigating MB, who teaches within Lewis's jurisdiction at Oxford -- and I'd agree with the policeman.The book has quite a few jokes and quotes with four-letter words and/or sexual overtones, so if that would bother you, be warned. (Not that it affects my rating: I thought the funniest joke in the book was an almost-unquotable one-liner from Sarah Silverman, who BTW is also mentioned often in Oxford's VSI on Humour.) This has many ingredients of an excellent book, but sadly after the first few pages it becomes unpleasant to read. Traditional British understatement would have been much more effective.

This review pertains to the Howard Augenbraum translation published by Penguin (2006). I'd been expecting this novel to be mainly of historical interest, but it turned out to be quite enjoyable as well. There's a surprising amount of satire and sarcasm, as well as red-hot indignation, that comes through in this translation. (And a day or two after I finished reading it I saw the Archbishop of the Philippines interviewed on the BBC, which brought home that there's a great deal in the novel that remains topical, too.) Of course you may encounter some slower patches: for me, these were mainly some detailed descriptions of religious festivals. And some plot elements, such as the central romance, may seem rather quaint. But the whole thing compares favourably to a good Sir Walter Scott novel -- with a lot more political spice, to boot.The Penguin edition includes numerous endnotes to explain many allusions to local foods and customs, Latin tags, etc. (though I think the translator was a little shaky in his French and Latin in a couple of places). My one very tiny criticism is that a glossary would have been a better idea for most of those entries, since some terms in Tagalog and other languages appear often in the text but are defined only in the endnote attached to their first appearance; moreover the endnotes depart from the format used in most other Penguin Classics by not identifying the bit of text to which each note refers, making it difficult to read the endnotes pro- or retrospectively. But all in all, a very diverting read even for a reader like me, who lacks any personal or professional connection to the Philippines; I'll definitely read the sequel.

Reading this book about "ecocriticism" made me recall a word I had to learn during one of the duller stretches of 10th grade English: "congeries," meaning a heap or aggregation of disparate items. That's pretty much what this is: the book's 20 chapters cover a wide selection of topics, but even reading it cover to cover didn't give me a more coherent idea of what ecocriticism is than I had before.Apparently the term not only takes in criticism of fiction, poetry, and drama, but also of non-fiction genres such as essayistic nature writing and science popularisations. On top of that it also often seems to morph into things like ontology (e.g., Chap. 6, which questions the ontological status of human beings as distinct from machines) or sociology of science (e.g., Chap. 15, which raises the question of what counts as good science). Unfortunately, the book doesn't present a clear case for what critiques of climate science or sociobiology *as such* have in common with critiques of Wordsworth, Mary Shelley and *essays about* climate change or sociobiology, even though all of these topics come within the book's ambit. Sometimes TC even muddles these distinctions, as when in a discussion of Stephen Jay Gould's essays he suggests that the notion of punctuated equilibrium is "idiosyncratic" to Gould and does not warrant the "public authority" his essays give it (@171) -- I suspect many paleontologists might differ with this.That's not to say that critiques of science and critiques of literature couldn't have anything in common. For example, it seems plausible that you could apply some form of discourse analysis to scholarly scientific papers, conference proceedings, journalistic reporting, advertising, etc. no less than to literary and popular genres. It's too bad that TC doesn't explore such avenues more specifically. Had he done so, a title something like "The Cambridge Introduction to Environmental Discourse" might have been an appropriate frame to help the reader see how all this stuff could hang together.As it is, though, the book's approach isn't unifying but kaleidoscopic -- with all of the connotations of fragmentation and disorientation that metaphor suggests. Very possibly TC doesn't deserve most of the blame for this incoherence: a lot of it might have to do with diverse camps of humanities scholars all trying to jump onto the "eco" bandwagon, as Education ministries in the UK and elsewhere demand they provide evidence of their productivity, competitiveness, and relevance. Whoever is to blame, though, the reader who's new to this field can't be faulted for concluding that "ecocriticism" is more about fashion than about synergy.On the plus side, TC's perspective isn't entirely Anglophone, as he brings in some German touches with discussions of philosophers Martin Heidegger and Hubert Zapf and fiction writers Christa Wolf and Wilhelm Raabe, among others. (TC seems eager to exculpate Heidegger of racism (@59), something not really feasible when this book came out and now much less so with the 2014 publication of his "Schwarze Hefte" [black notebooks]; at the same time he refers to Heidegger's being perceived as an archetypical "eco-fascist" (id.), a term not defined until two chapters later (@74), leaving me wondering whether the humor was intentional or inadvertent.) Of course the Three Musketeers (Foucault, Deleuze, Guattari) also make an obligatory appearance, along with D'Artagnan (Bruno Latour).Unfortunately, TC accepts Latour's definition of "political ecology" as the paradigmatic one, thereby ignoring an older and more fruitful line of thinking put forward by André Gorz, Ivan Illich, Jacques Ellul and others. He also ignores virtually the entire sustainability literature produced by economists. Some of this, particularly Robert Solow's notion of weak sustainability and the dialogue about discount rates led by Nicholas Stern and William Nordhaus, is very directly relevant to topics in the book, such as the "rights of the not-yet-born" (@110). And for someone who is quick to point out the political implications of most arguments, it's a pity TC lets post-humanism off without any criticism of its implications for democracy (Chap. 6). When writers like Timothy Morton read "Frankenstein" to mean that "the task becomes to love the disgusting, the inert and the meaningless," and that "the most ethical act is to love the other precisely in their artificiality" (quoted @ 70), TC raises no question about who makes the decisions to release these monstrosities into the world. Just because crazed billionaire Tony Stark-wannabes have the ego, desire and resources to do so doesn't mean that we should all have to suffer the consequences.I suspect that the misleading title of this book came at the insistence of some CUP editor, given that the title of the series in which it appears is "Cambridge Introductions to Literature." If only that person could have applied the same gung-ho spirit to fixing the presentation of references, which is extremely inconvenient for a book of this sort. Unless you read the book in chapter order (as I did) and read all endnotes assiduously and with a photographic memory (as I did not), you'll find many endnotes just give an author surname, a short title and a page number without any indication of other bibliographic information (as happened to me almost all the time). I had to resort to Amazon's "Look Inside" feature to find full information for some of the notes that interested me, which often was buried 20 pages or more prior to where I was looking: e.g., the full cite for Chap. 14, note 15 on p. 224 is findable only as note 15 of the Introduction, on p. 204. The nature of a book like this is that many readers will read chapters selectively and/or in multiple sittings over an extended period of time, and/or will look up only those notes that they need to. All abbreviated references should should have indicated the location of the first citation or, better yet, there should have been a full bibliography to accompany the notes.The text is also decorated with a number of unattractive and unfunny cartoons that add neither insight nor humor. I'm somewhat generous in my star-rating, since it's possible that the book's flaws are a faithful reflection of the field itself, and that those who are caught up in the glass bead game of academic literary studies might benefit from this work's presentation of their professors' preoccupations. But I emerged from the book much more skeptical about the enterprise of ecocriticism than when I entered.

This is simply one of the best books I've read in the past couple of years, in any genre. It's full of warmth, humour and insight. There's no comparison to some other writerly lectures on literature, such as Nabokov's volumes, which I tried to read many years back: this one is totally unpretentious, the text preserves the spontaneity of the lecture hall (including student questions in each of the eight talks), and Cortázar sounds like he was a real human being. In addition to saying many interesting things of a literary nature -- such as about the special qualities of short stories, and the distinctions among the comic, the humorous and the playful, among other topics -- Cortázar provides some great descriptions of the political engagement of both writers and readers. A pair of more formal texts in the appendices expand on this political theme.Most chapters focus on short stories, often quoting them at length, but there are also discussions of the processes of writing "Rayuela [Hopscotch]" and "Libro de Manuel [A Manual for Manuel]." Since a number of the stories were unfamiliar to me, reading them along with this book was a very enjoyable immersive experience. If your Spanish is weak, don't worry. I'm very poorly self-taught in the language, but at least in the expository passages Cortázar's Spanish was clear enough for me to make it through with great pleasure and interest, including being able to laugh at (I think) the right places. The passages from his fiction were of course more difficult to read cold for someone as unlettered in Spanish as I am, but in most cases I'd read the stories beforehand in English or French translation before tackling the original versions here. Now that I've finished it, I really miss it, and I know it will take me several days before I can let go enough to get absorbed in some other book.

I'm new to narrative theory, and I came to this book looking for insights that will help me to talk about literature with college students, rather than to teach or write about theory itself. The book's wide range can certainly make for interesting browsing, and the various "navigational aids" are helpful, at least in the print version I'm using. Many articles, though, seem like lapidary summaries of their respective topics by contributors who are talking more to their peers and grad students than to poor shnooks like me who perhaps naïvely think of an encyclopedia as someplace to get an overview of the basics.Despite this book's very generous scope (which is the main reason I give it four stars), in any work of this type there are nits one can pick. I was disappointed that most of the entry "Japanese narrative" focused on works from around 1,000 years ago, with the 20th-21st Centuries getting barely a paragraph, and no mention is made of Japan's unique position in the worlds of graphic narrative and keitai (mobile phone) fiction. An entry on "magical realism" isolates Julio Cortázar's pertinent writings to 1951-1956 for reasons not immediately transparent. And while there's a long essay on "Law and Narrative," the juncture of politics and narrative is hard to find, even in the index.A more serious problem is the relative lack of sample quotations to illustrate some of the entries on specific elements and techniques of narrative. At first I thought this might be because the publisher required authors to obtain permissions for all quotes, as many publishers do, but Taylor & Francis's policies for authors seem to recognize that fair use and fair dealing exclusions from copyright make such a burden unnecessary. So I'm figuring that the paucity of examples is due either to perceived space limitations or to the fact that they just aren't theoretical enough. Either way, it reduces some articles' pedagogical value for the uninitiated, albeit while enhancing their value as aids for the sleepless.

This review relates to the Hanson/Messick translation: I was led to this book by a glowing review in TLS. I found my own reaction was favourable but much more moderate. From an historical point of view, it may have been quite bold and important for its time. As a story, though, it's stuck somewhere between being 2- and 3-dimensional. In particular, the characters weren't so well developed, other than Inés herself. Her interior monologues make it clear that the male protagonist was chosen as a lover because he satisfied certain emotional needs of hers, but that doesn't necessarily make him more interesting for the reader. The ending, too, was disappointing. For those with an interest in literary theory, the text has many diverting aspects, such as its use of symbolism, feminist themes, descriptions of nature, and variations in voice; in fact, these features are so easily accessible that the book could be a sort of textbook case for budding comparative literature scholars. Fortunately, the book is sufficiently well-written that one gets pulled into the story on its own terms, and the descriptions of the setting were very evocative. The text is supplemented by some turn-of-the-century postcards from Constantinople, which might have added more if they had been rotated on the page so that they could be reproduced in a larger size. I read this as some fictional/English-language relief in the middle of working through a large non-fiction volume in another language, and found it a refreshing change, quickly read, yet substantial enough to be memorable.

Back in the 1970s, the US edition of "Hopscotch" -- part of Avon's series of several dozen mass market paperback translations of major Latin American authors, a literary project unimaginable today -- featured on its cover a melancholy caricature of the author, Julio Cortázar. Maybe I wasn't alone in getting the impression that he was a depressing read. Decades later, when I finally sat down to read him, though, I discovered my big mistake: although his writing isn't typically optimistic, it's often incredibly funny.This book from 1975 is a great example: farcical even for Cortázar, but with a serious edge as well. The story, narrated in the first person, includes panels from an actual issue of a Mexican comic book featuring the anti-hero Fantomas. The comic's story line drew on Fantomas's friendship with "Julio, Octavio, Alberto and Susan" -- as in Cortázar, Paz, Moravia and Sontag, major late 20th Century authors much better known by the general public back then than they or writers of comparable quality are today.  There's also a wonderful sequence of panels where Fantomas's "civilian" alter ego explains Bertolt Brecht to his socialite girlfriend, Ira von Fürstenberg (also a real-life person). The comic's plot revolves around a fanatic's scheme to destroy the world's literature, both by making books disappear and by physically threatening authors. (The full comic, issue 201 of "Fantomas, La amenaza elegante" [Fantomas, the elegant menace], is available online in Spanish from a blog called "mundofantomas;" it includes some additional enjoyable panels about Brecht, especially.)Somehow Cortázar transitions from his finding the comic book at the Brussels train station to his actually being friends with Fantomas. Eventually the comic's panels fall away and Cortázar the character is pulling Fantomas into the work real-life Cortázar was doing as part of the Second Russell Tribunal, which was investigating the brutality of several Latin American military regimes. The task is shown to be beyond even Fantomas's capabilities. The real Tribunal's findings are included as an appendix to the book.One can criticise some aspects of Cortázar's political engagement as naïve: e.g., his admiration for the Cuban Revolution, without acknowledging its harsh treatment of dissidents. But the military brutality in Chile, Argentina, Uruguay, Brazil and elsewhere that he decried was real. In any case, he's never so shrill about politics as to lose his self-deprecating sense of humor, such as in relating his unsuccessful attempts to attract a blonde sitting across from him in his train compartment, or how he paced around in his apartment "smoking in the manner one learns from suspense films."Given the book's genre-bending storytelling, it's no wonder this translation has been published through Semiotext(e), a literary theory journal. It's too bad the price is relatively steep for such a slim book. My copy of "Hopscotch," printed in 1975 when an oil crisis was inflating the cost of ink, had a cover price of just $2.95; that comes out to under $12 in today's dollars, for which you got 570 pages, not 87. But considering how much I enjoyed the book compared to, say, some movies I've paid to see in theaters, I didn't regret the bargain.

Perhaps because this book was published during the military regime in Brazil, I've run into several sources saying it's *about* the military regime in Brazil, some as sober as E. Bradford Burns's well-respected "History of Brazil." Actually, there's little or nothing in this book to tie it specifically to Brazil's situation in the late 1970s, when it was written. For the most part, the book reads as very contemporary, except for the absence of cell phones and other marks of modernity. The social problems portrayed are unfortunately timeless, and the author's sense of humor arrested in perpetual adolescence.The two central stories focus on the demi-monde of hookers (often with hearts at least partly of gold), pimps, crooks, prisoners, etc. and how they exploit each other and are oppressed by brutal police. The title story, a fantasy fable about a glass prison run by scientists, is a sort of cross between "1984" and the classic 19th Century novella "The Alienist" by Machado de Assis, whom the author acknowledges in the story. It can be read in hindsight to refer to life under the junta, but it's no less at home in today's universe of CCTV cameras, drones and "Big Brother" as an entertainment series. (But Machado's story, too, is very pertinent to now, and much more fun.) There's also a shallow story about a businessman who fantasizes he's a sexy beast, and a last story involving some fictitious histories of Brazil. That one has a lot in common with John Barth's "Sot-Weed Factor" (complete with archaic spellings, in the translation at least), set in a couple of framing narratives (another Barth trick).The lack of period historical color did disappoint my own expectations, but isn't the reason for "disappointing" in the title of the review. Rather, that's because the book is incessantly about violence, usually sexual, even as it seems the author is trying to be funny. He's certainly imaginative: each chapter tries a different narrative technique, some of which work well (particularly the second chapter, "Friday Night/Saturday Morning"), and he makes creative use of parentheses (both the punctuation and the rhetorical trope). But ultimately the constant brutality becomes too oppressive -- to the reader.

The marketing of the Penguin edition translated by Boyle and Woodard is what moved me to write this review. Penguin's marketeers claim that Fasti is a "subtle but powerful political manifesto;" B&W expand on this theme in their introduction. This piqued my interest in the work, but I was frustrated once I began reading.Maybe Ovid wasn't hiding his jokes and barbs by the standards of his day: for all I know, his contemporaries would be smiling ironically or even rolling on the ground with laughter as they read. But for a reader of this edition to appreciate those bits requires something approaching a professional Latinist's erudition. If the political aspect of the book interests you, be aware that to a great degree it's not visible from the four corners of this work. Mainly its based on (i) what Ovid *omits* from the book (e.g., failing to mention Augustus or members of his family in certain contexts where they might have expected it), and (ii) what Ovid says here *taken together with* what he said in other of his works, e.g. Ars amatoria. Even the example about Jupiter and rape mentioned in the blurb, which seems to be in Ovid's entries for Feb 5 through Feb 12, is rather subtly expressed in the poem's text -- I might easily have passed it on a first reading if B&W hadn't mentioned it in their introduction.In other words, even if there's a political message written here in secret ink, so to speak, usually you'll need to bring in UV lights, lemon juice and other stuff to be able to read it. And often, you'll need to bring your own. While the translators are generous with apparatus (maps, an outline summary, almost 250 pages of scholarly endnotes, a glossary), this material isn't really focused on bringing into relief the political reading for which B&W argue. In particular, the endnotes don't highlight this big picture: although abundant, they tend to focus at a more micro level on specific events, names, places, and calendrical matters. The Introduction is the reader's best guide, but by its own admission it cites only a few examples -- hardly enough to make a "manifesto."So I wasn't entirely shocked to find, after some digging with a search engine, that the political reading of the Fasti is still quite contested among modern classical scholars. Many don't accept it, and even some who do read it as more pro-Augustus than, as here, anti. This edition is itself a manifesto of an academic sort. That happens all the time in scholarship and I can grant it's legitimate, though I wish I hadn't mistaken the sales pitch for something more neutral.There's another issue, too. The Fasti's subject, a festival-by-festival discussion of the calendar, prevents the poem from flowing along as beautifully as, say, the Metamorphoses. Nonetheless, for me this translation made things even choppier. Maybe in the belief that they were making things simpler for the reader, B&W use a lot of full stops where they don't occur in the original (or at least, in modern editions of the original text accepted as authoritative). The result is often a string of disconnected sentences, sounding at times more like oracle than narrative.Here's an example, from 4.275-280 (with Latin from the 2014 Latin/German edition published by Reclam, based on the 1988 Alton et al. edition of Ovid's text, published by Teubner -- the same as used by B&W):A thousand hands gather. A hollow ship painted/ With burnt colors holds the Mother of Gods.She is freighted through her son's water most safely,/ And nears the long strait of Phrixus' sister.She passes wide Rhoetium and Sigeum's beaches,/ Tenedos and Eëtion's old realm.mille mane coeunt, et picta coloribus ustis/ caelestum Matrem concava puppis habet.illa sui per aquas fertur tutissima nati/ longaque Phrixeae stagna sororis adit,Rhoeteumque capax Sigeaque litora transit,/ et Tenedum et veteres Eetionis opes.Notice how B&W use four sentences against Ovid's two, suppressing Ovid's "et" ("and") and using periods instead of more liquid commas -- all the more unfortunate since what's being described is the passage of a ship. The choice to begin each line with a capital letter (by no means obligatory in English) chops things up further, especially when the syntax carries over into a new line, as in the first two lines quoted (275-276). I found that it was often easier to get the sense of the translation by looking at the Latin, instead of the other way around. Maybe such roughness is a trade-off for the technical tour de force B&W achieved: tracking the original couplet-by-couplet and usually line-by-line, while sticking to a standard couplet of 12 + 10 syllables. But for the reader who wants a smoother understanding of what Ovid was talking about, a prose translation might be clearer in many places. (That's the case at least with the inexpensive Reclam, if you read German. I haven't yet checked the Oxford Classics English-only edition, nor the Loeb, whose English is from the 1930s).My deduction of stars relates mainly to the gap between the "political manifesto" Penguin promises and its actual accessibility to the average reader, even one with some Latin; but the prickly translation is part of the reason, too.

This is a very uneven book, but worth reading for at least two reasons. One is the author's (JL's) snapshot of the current, and very twisted, Silicon Valley psyche. I inhabited the silicon end of the Valley (semiconductors and electronics) for more than a decade before leaving in 2007. To learn that nowadays the person who'd be next in line to me at Kepler's or sitting next to me at my favorite bubble tea place might be spending his or her zillions on research into transhuman immortality or attending Singularity University at a NASA facility I drove past daily (@325-331) made me lose my nostalgia fast.Even if you've never lived in the Bay Area, the other reason to read the book is for JL's perceptive and entertainingly cynical analysis of the dark side of the "free" online business model. I read this book more or less concurrently with Jeremy Rifkin's "Zero Marginal Cost Society," which is a Leninist utopian interpretation of precisely the same model. Where Rifkin sees a coming global collaborationist society in which everything is a commodity at near-zero price, resulting in the "inevitable" collapse of capitalism and private property, JL sees greater and greater concentration of money and power in the proprietors of a small number of "siren servers." JL's vision is not only more plausible, but more authentic: unlike Rifkin, a B-school professor, "futurist" and cheerleader, JL has had a creative role in many of the innovations he describes.JL's affirmative arguments aren't as strong as his critiques. His main proposal to counter the growing power of Google, Facebook and others is to require micro- or nanopayments to you whenever someone uses information about you, or  uses your design or other creation. But you'd have to make a payment when you use someone else's creations, too. There are at least two key issues here: defining the subject matter of the micro- or nanopayments, and fairly attributing the subject matter to its sources. Is the subject matter the same as that of currently protectable copyright/patent/trademark/likeness rights, with an additional category for personal data? Or does it include any idea I might express, even if not currently protectable under an IP regime? As far as I can tell, JL inclines to the latter, including, e.g. translations of phrases, which might not be copyrightable by usual methods (and which are often based on someone else's other work in the original language, in any case). So suppose I come up with a translation: how much of that idea is truly mine, and how much does it come from something my high school Latin teacher taught me? The same problem affects even conventional inventions: how can I separate my idea from the ideas in many of the books and articles I read before, which I couldn't have understood without some trick in my Physics 151 lecture notes, as explained by my prof, who got it from somewhere else, etc. -- and by the way, let's not forget the whole family tree of math classes I needed to understand that bit of calculus in there. Do all of them get paid (at least, if they're still alive)? Also, is it really "humanizing," as JL claims, to put every aspect of human creativity into a market-based intellectual property regime?In addition, JL's understanding of economics is somewhat haphazard. E.g., he tosses around terms like "value" and "wealth" without ever saying what he means by them. JL draws the Laffer curve upside down, with correct axes but as a U-curve (@149), perhaps misled by a belief that equilibria have to be stable; the correct version is an inverted-U with a maximum (an unstable equilibrium) purporting to optimize tax revenue as a function of  tax rate. And he believes that "future intents of borrowers" constitute "assets" that "no longer exist" when borrowers "do something other than promised," thereby "making it possible for banks to fall apart when people don't pay their mortgages back" (@33). Actually, a proper mortgage transaction would give the bank legal claims against seizable assets that are worth enough so that the borrower's inappropriate actions or changed intentions can't cause much damage. If the deal comes back to bite the bank, usually it means the bank should have been more prudent before making the loan -- or shrewder afterwards, by passing the risk on to another party, as often happened in the lead-up to the Lehman Shock. (BTW it turns out that, contrary to media mythology, homeowners'  mortgage defaults per se weren't a direct cause of bank failures during the Great Recession, according to a recent paper by Antonis Antoniades of the European Central Bank appearing after this book was published.)Ultimately, JL's solutions ring too much of "if you can't beat 'em, join 'em": fight monetizers by monetizing yourself. A further discouragement is that, as other have observed, the book is poorly and self-indulgently structured. Nonetheless, JL's puncturing of the usual sunny, Disneyland portrayal of the commercial Internet and his well-aimed satirical jabs at Silicon Valley culture are genuine rewards of putting up with this idiosyncratic hodgepodge of a book.

I have a much more moderate view of this book than some other reviewers. The book was written in the early 1960s. Back then, physicists were assumed to be interested mainly in finite groups, and these take up a lot of the book. The symmetries involved tend to be geometric symmetries in 3-space, e.g. of molecules, crystals, rotation of light, etc. The more generalized notion of symmetry commonly spoken of in physics classes today, based on Noether's theorem and connected to conservation laws, is missing from this book. Most of the applications are in chemistry and crystallography (though not necessarily solid state physics -- e.g., Bloch's theorem is mentioned only in passing, more than 80% into the text). Classical mechanics, quantum field theory, and particle physics are all absent. So is much of the vocabulary that a student today might be interested in: Lie groups aren't mentioned by name, nor are orthogonal groups, linear groups, Galilean groups, Lorentz groups, SU(n), SO(n), etc. etc. So are some of the usual math text topics, such as quotient groups and Sylow theorems.The book is written in straight exposition without definition/theorem/proof, and without exercises too. But it's written in a more formal and pedantic style characteristic of the "Father Knows Best" era, when scientists smoked pipes and wore neckties under their lab coats -- very top-down, not the more eye-to-eye style of some textbooks today. Also typical for its time, the presentation is heavily reliant on all sorts of typographical tricks. On the plus side, the book has relatively many illustrations.I bought this book based on some of the reviews on this page. I teach in Japan, and was hoping to find something I could recommend as a first math/science book in English to some aspiring grad students who are interested in particle physics, but who aren't yet so strong in groups or other algebraic structures. Sadly this didn't fill the bill. Regardless of English ability, if you're, say, a physics undergraduate who's interested in elementary particles or cosmology, and you're new to groups but allergic to pure math books, I think this could be a frustrating place to start. While the opening pages might have some useful information and visualizations, so do the early pages of some pdf introductions to group theory you can download for free, and those are written in a more contemporary style. If you're interested in chemistry, the early chapters of "Symmetry and Spectroscopy" by Harris and Bertolucci (available in a Dover edition) provide a much more user-friendly way to learn about groups. That said, as other reviews evidence, the book might be useful for some audiences. Crystallographers and others who work with finite groups might be one, and very gifted high school students who are thirsty for knowledge but who lack the need and impatience to dive into the contemporary math or physics literature might be another.

Several decades ago, I took Harvard's music history survey course for non-majors (non-"concentrators", in Harvard-speak), taught by the late Elliot Forbes, a Beethoven scholar. Near the end he devoted a class to jazz, and especially to the music of saxophonist "Charles Parker," whose name his fine Boston Brahmin accent elongated elegantly and ludicrously. Notwithstanding that the editor hailed from Cornell and Chicago, this book captures that old Harvard spirit: a nod to the popular, but only in the most dignified way -- Chaahles Paahka, never Charlie (metaphorically speaking).It's hard to figure out the vagaries of such genteel taste. Several genres of American popular music have their own entries, among them rock, rap, hip hop, and even "acid rock" -- but forget about chill, grunge, lounge, alternative and electronica. From Brazil, chro, samba and bossa nova appear, but nothing about afoxé, axé, forró, frevo, Música Popular Brasileira, or Tropicália. From Mexico, son and mariachi, but not banda or ranchera.  Maybe something is buried in there about the music of Hawai'i or other Pacific islands, but I couldn't find it; nor anything about the music of Haïti, either (aside from a passing reference to méringue in the article on Dominican merengue). Other genres, such as (Algerian) raï (here written as "rai") and (Greek) rebetiko are mentioned only in passing in entries about regional music, without any description of what they are; ditto for dangdut, which in this work is spelled "dang dut" even though it's never spelled that way on any of my cassettes or CDs from Malaysia and Indonesia. Speaking of that part of the world, you won't find a drawing of a gamelan ensemble, either. Balalaika and bouzouki get their own entries, but are omitted from the group portrait of lutes, as is the oud (to find a verbal description of which you need to know to look under " 'ūd ," since there isn't any cross-reference under 'O'). The entry on rumba entirely omits mention of its Mediterranean version (rumba gitana, made popular by the Gypsy Kings, Paco de Lucía and others); lambada, the forbidden dance, is strictly verboten -- and limbo is in limbo.Even the more orthodox entries are hit and miss. The list of famous names omitted from the entry on "Film Music" is as along as your arm, among them Nino Rota, Ennio Morricone, John Williams, Jerry Goldsmith, Lalo Schifrin, etc., etc., etc.  Various famous classical pieces have entries, but the criteria are hard to fathom. All of Stravinsky's ballets rate, as do Hindemith's Das Marienleben and Mathis der Maler, but not the collective Les Mariés de la tour Eiffel by Les Six, nor such popular works as Le boeuf sur le toit or La création du monde by Milhaud. Among post-war operas, you'll find The Rake's Progress (Stravinsky), Billy Budd (Britten) and Death in Venice (Britten again), but not Einstein on the Beach (Glass) or Nixon in China (Adams), nor even Olivier Messiaen's monumental Saint François d'Assise. Messiaen, who taught Boulez, Stockhausen and scores of others, and who continued to compose major works into the early 1990s, is represented only by entries for two works from the 1940s: the Quatuor pour la fin du temps (not Quartet for the End of Time) and the Turangalila Symphony (not Symphonie Turangalîle). More appalling than this linguistic inconsistency is that Messiaen is entirely absent from the entry entitled "Twentieth Century, Western art music of the." As long as you want to look up the Right Sort of Thing, this is a great reference.

This book performs a valuable service by emphasizing government's crucial role in both directly and indirectly structuring markets. Sad to say, ever since some point after the Nixon Administration all too many Americans have forgotten that role. The author (AM) presents his thesis with many examples ranging from political philosophy to the design of water systems and typewriter keyboards, in clear and jargon-free prose.The solutions he proposes aren't always persuasive: e.g., he advocates a National Companies Act as an antidote to state laws like Delaware's that are very favorable to corporate management, but doesn't consider that, given that 60% of the Fortune 500 are incorporated in Delaware (@113), a federal corporations law is likely to look very much like Delaware's, or even more pro-management. And the connection between markets and some topics wasn't always so clear, e.g. in the discussion of prisons (@174-175; Bernard Harcourt's "The Illusion of Free Markets" (Harvard 2011) might have helped to put a finer point on this). Still, the range of topics is very imaginative, and should open the minds of many readers.I'm very much in sympathy with AM's broad purpose, so I don't want to be too negative about this book. Because of that sympathy, though, I was really hoping for a tight argument that would be hard to attack -- and was all the more disappointed by the frequent slackness I found instead. Here are a few examples of inaccuracies and semi-accuracies I was able to catch:(a) First, the book's neatest sound-bite: "'There is no difference between Google and San Francisco,' said Harvard Law prof Gerald Frug]. They are both corporations -- 'bodies, empowered by government to do stuff.' [¶] Let's say that again. There is no difference between Google and San Francisco. No difference between New York City and IBM. No difference between Albany and Acme Insurance." (@94.) AM calls this notion "astonishing" and he's right -- because, pace Prof. Frug, it is utterly wrong.Let's neglect for the moment any differences among the corporation laws of the various states: Google and IBM are formed under something called the Delaware General Corporation Law and California has a Corporations Code, so for the sake of argument we can treat them as the same thing. And let's also ignore the fact that, uniquely in California, San Francisco is both a city and a county (unlike, say, Los Angeles, where the city and county have distinct borders). Nonetheless, SF isn't a "corporation" formed under a statute similar to the one to which Google and IBM owe their existence: it's a charter city under Title 4 of the California Government Code. As such, it has quite a few powers and responsibilities that Google, IBM et al. lack.Even if you don't know California's law codes, a moment's thought will reveal the silliness of the assertion. Can Google issue parking tickets? Assess and collect taxes? Throw you in jail? Do you have to buy your right to vote in San Francisco elections? Does anyone pay people who move out of SF and give up their rights to vote there, the way selling shareholders receive money or other consideration? If the city disincorporates, do you have any legal right to a share of its assets, as Google's shareholders would if it dissolves?People who go to the beach on the Fourth of July aren't lizards just because they happen to be vertebrates who like to lie in the sun. Cities and corporations may have something in common, but that doesn't prevent them from being very different creatures. Even by standards of general-audience nonfiction, this passage goes beyond oversimplification into the realm of misinformation.(b) In Chapter 3, AM complains about the common law, calling it judge-made and undemocratic; he also claims (@35), "It is profoundly difficult, although not impossible, for the legislature to pass laws that overrule common law." That's simply not the case. Legislatures pass such laws all the time; any obstacles are political, not legal. Moreover, a great deal of common law winds up getting embodied in legislation. See, e.g., the California Civil Code, and the commentaries to the various versions of the Uniform Commercial Code that have been enacted in all 50 US states. As for the democratic character of judge-made law, in addition to the power of the legislature to change the rules ex post, in most US jurisdictions judges are either elected directly, or are appointed by democratically-elected officials.In that respect, judge-made law is a lot better than arbitration, which involves private adjudicators who are immune from all forms of democratic intervention. Arbitrators are typically lawyers or current or retired experts with ties to the rich and powerful, and have the leeway to apply their own judgment, which might or might not be in conformity with statutory law and case law. In a string of recent decisions by the Supreme Court under Chief Justice John Roberts, the Court has upheld the right of big companies, professional service providers and others to force you to accept arbitration instead of having your day in court. But instead of complaining about arbitration's truly undemocratic character, AM mentions it only in its international context, where he oddly considers it to be aligned with regulation by sovereign states (@228).(c) In several parts of the book, AM discusses the political philosophers Thomas Hobbes and John Locke. Unfortunately, he often quotes them out of context, or relies on a paragraph about them from a 1929 treatise about common law by Theodore Plucknett, instead of looking at the originals. E.g., AM twice quotes Plucknett to the emphasize a contrast: Hobbes, we're told, believed all law to be a command from the State, whereas Locke believed in natural law (@40, 184). AM also mentions that Locke's arguments rely on G-d but Hobbes' do not (@183), and he objects to Locke's countenancing the possibility that there could be a "natural" relation of master and slave, citing to Locke's Second Treatise on Government, Chap. 7, § 85 (@183). In fact, though, Hobbes talks about natural law at length, including how it's coextensive with civil law, a/k/a the commandments of the state (Leviathan XIV, XV, XXVI.8). He also mentions that every man has a natural right to every thing, "even to one another's body," i.e. slave ownership (XIV.5), and that even as a subject of a commonwealth one retains a natural right to protect oneself if the state doesn't (XXI.21). And Hobbes talks an awful lot about G-d in Leviathan Parts III ("Of a Christian Commonwealth") and IV ("Of the Kingdom of Darkness"). AM cites only to Part I ("Of Man"), so he seems to have missed the bulk of the book. Meanwhile, Locke's Chapter 4 ("Of Slavery") makes it clear that his notion of justified slaveholding is very narrow, deriving from conquest of opponents in a just war.These examples are drawn from areas with which I'm relatively familiar, like law and political philosophy. Maybe AM has his facts in better shape when he touches on topics closer to his own professional comfort zone, like urban planning; I'm necessarily agnostic on that point.On the production side, thanks to U Texas for going against the Zeitgeist and providing both endnotes and a bibliography. To sum up, if you're shocked or intrigued by the idea that there isn't any such thing as a "free market," you can benefit from reading this book. Just be careful before you start quoting some of its more specific arguments.

This small book -- it can almost fit into a shirt pocket -- is an outstanding piece of rhetoric in support of economic growth. While economics textbooks seem to take for granted that economic growth is a good thing, this book lays out numerous reasons that will appeal to both secular and Christian readers. With its calm tone, its acknowledgement that some opposing viewpoints "contain elements of truth," and its hopeful message, it comes close to the 1980s-era tour de force of Rose and Milton Friedman's "Free to Choose." It will persuade many, many readers. And skeptics about economic growth should read it, to find out what they're up against.It is, however, Goliath's message - not a dumb, brutal Goliath prone to violence but a clever, slick Goliath schooled in public relations and the levers of power. The publisher is the American Enterprise Institute (AEI), an ostensibly nonpartisan think-tank funded by, among others, the Koch Bros. that nonetheless supplied many members of various Bush Administrations, and on whose Board of Trustees now sits former Vice-President Dick Cheney. The usual neoliberal themes of strong property rights, rule of law, reduced government intervention, market freedom and lower taxes are sounded often. Like the works of the thinkers whom it criticizes, the book contains many elements of truth. Unfortunately, they do not add up to a whole truth: there are misleading statements on almost every page.To be fair, I should note: if you are one of those folks who posted a 1-star review of Thomas Piketty's "Capital in the 21st Century" without having read that book, you will **love** this one. Even if you don't read it either.Here is a slightly more detailed critique:1. The book's core argument is roughly as follows (along with the sources cited, or, if no citation was given, pertinent page numbers): Growth is good for the poor (Dollar & Kraal 2002). Inequality in the US has been exaggerated (Burkhauser & al. 2012), and even if growth does increase inequality that's no excuse for not helping the poor by pursuing growth (@10, 42). Redistribution of income in poor countries is futile (@16-17, 31, 68). Growth helps clean up the environment (Dasgupta & al. 2002), and in any case environmental protection and preventing global warming are no excuses for abandoning the moral imperative of helping the poor by pursuing growth (@59). Materialism and lack of concern for the poor are "inherent in free human communities," and are not the result of, or exacerbated by, economic growth (@67, 77).2. Selective citation is the authors' main forensic technique: they tend to support their claims with at most one citation to the economics literature for each major proposition. They also omit to tell the reader that every one of the cites they choose is heavily contested in the economics literature. The Dollar & Kraal study in particular, which was originally published as a World Bank working paper in 2001, has been challenged by numerous scholars both for its statistical methodology and for its inappropriate inferences of causation. (A few critiques you can find online with a search engine: Nye & Reddy 2001, Foster & Székely 2001, Lübker & al. 2002, Amann 2002, Ashley 2007.) Once this prong of Noell & al.'s argument is recognized as shaky, so must be their dismissals of environmental damage and rising inequality as arguments against growth, since they claim that growth's benefits to the poor outweigh those other harms.Another example is their claim that "the existence of the EKC [environmental Kuznets curve] is well documented," citing solely to Dasgupta & al.'s paper, "Confronting the environmental Kuznets curve." The EKC is the basis of the argument that as per capita GDP continues to increase, pollution first gets worse and then gets better. However, EKCs have not been confirmed for all forms of pollution, including greenhouse gas emissions, particularly when one takes into account that richer countries have offshored much of their manufacturing to China and elsewhere. Nor do EKC studies focus on groundwater or soil contamination, some of which persists for more than 100 years. Some citations you might look up include Wagner (2008); Stern (2004); Webber & Allen (2010); Sinha (2010) (to find the references quickly, combine your search on those names with "EKC" or its spelled-out version).When the authors credit economic growth with reducing infant mortality rates, they prudently mention only the UK, France and Japan (@5-6) -- thereby avoiding the inconvenient truth that more than 45 other countries have lower rates than the US, including Greece, Hungary and Cuba. To support their claim that growth is good for health, they cite Robert Fogel, a Nobel economics laureate; naturally they don't mention the work of Simon Szreter, Stephen Kunitz or Angus Deaton, who show that economic growth is neither necessary nor sufficient for improving public health. And sometimes their citation doesn't even rise to the level of "selective": to evidence their assertion that "sometimes simply defining and enforcing property rights can clear up a pollution problem," the authors offer as support the Disney film, "WALL-E" (@50).I expect that the authors or their defenders might protest that in a short book such as this one can't get into all the nuances of academic controversies. No doubt that's true; so why make the book so short? Or one could adopt the authors' technique and write another book about economic growth with one cite per proposition, too -- and come to a conclusion 180 degrees opposite to the authors'.3.
