[This was at a village, and does not count the countless Poles living in the ruins of Warsaw and other large destroyed cities.] No wonder that the new Polish owners were not exactly thrilled when the presumed-dead former owners turned up alive to reclaim the property.Especially sad are the photos which show the abject misery (and disease) of those who had been expelled from the Kresy or returned from Siberia. (p. 41, 114, 115, 116, 117). Obviously, the German expellees, the VERTRIEBENE, were not the only ones who suffered because of the Big-Power-decreed expulsion/resettlement processes.

The author surveys the claims of nations and nationalities in some detail. Unfortunately, he treats all the conflicting claims on a more-or-less coeval basis—as if all the claims had equivalent credibility and support.I focus on a few items of lasting interest.THE POLESIANS—A SEPARATE NATIONALITY?In the past, Poles commonly thought of the Belarussian identity as an amorphous one. For example, Roman Catholic Belarussians were, in some way, considered Poles. Russians, on the other hand, tended to treat the Belarussians (and Ukrainians) as just another branch of the Russian peoples. Interestingly, however, some Russians thought of at least the Polesians as a separate nationality. Kolarz comments, (quote) In North-eastern Poland (or South-western White Russia—which term we use entirely depends on our political sympathies) is to be found another linguistic and ethnological curiosity, the “Pinchuki”, who live in the marshy country of Polesia or Pinshchina (around the town of Pinsk) which is one of the areas contested between the Poles and the Soviets. They have a number…Polish statistics record over 700,000 of such Pinchuki who are simply described as “locals”…the “Pinchuki” are not a Polish invention but were recognized by Russian ethnographers long before the first World War. (unquote). (p. 17).JEWS AND CONFLICTED IDENTITYKolarz writes, (quote) Secondly, there were Jews whose assimilation had been complicated by the fact that they lived in a multi-national country or in an area of mixed language. In such cases it very often happened that Jews between two censuses or over a longer period withdrew form one ethnical group and attached themselves to the other. In some towns of Bohemia and Moravia, for instance, from the end of the nineteenth century onward, and ever-growing number of German Jews have changed over to the Czech nation. On a smaller scale the same thing happened in Slovakia, where a part of the Jews gave up their membership in the Magyar ethnical community and became Slovaks…Finally, there were the Jews who were indifferent to the rival claims of nationalities, and these were the majority. (unquote). (p. 23).Now consider the implications. Roman Dmowski, while always realizing that some Polish Jews become genuine patriotic Poles, pointed out that most Jews (of eastern Europe) had no real attachment to the nations in which they lived. Even those that did often did not remain that way. He cited the example of Hungarian Jews as ones whose assimilated status, and patriotic identification with Hungary [including that of the Israelitish Magyars], turned out to be a chameleon-like ephemeral loyalty. He feared that the same could happen with Poland-identifying Polish Jews. Kolarz's statements, quoted above, though not presented as such, indicate that Dmowski's concerns had some foundation.

This work provides basic information on the geologic history of Chicago. It then covers topics as diverse as the flora, insects, birds, and animals of the Chicago area. It also touches on the Native Americans who lived in the area.Perhaps the most fascinating item is the map of the Chicago area before settlement. (pp. 12-13). Most of what is now Chicago was prairie. However, the first 1-2 miles east of the Des Plaines River and Chicago River were woodlands. Interestingly, the area situated between the west branch and east branch of the Chicago River was oak woodland.One shortcoming of this work is the profusion of maps that are too small. For this reason, the symbols put on them (as, for example, the sites of remnant and restored prairies) are not very informative.A bibliography is provided for further reading.

Czesto dzisiaj jest wybielanie Niemcow w roznych srodowiskach. Jest powszechne od-Niemczenie Nazistow. A jesli chodzi o zbrodniach Niemcow w Drugiej Wojnie Swiatowej, czesto skladano winy na jednego "wariata"--Hitlera.Prawda jest zupelnie inna.Niemiecki barbarzynstwo oraz ludobojstwo byly czynny dlugo przed Hitlerem i Nazistowskim ruchem. Ta ksiazka opisuje Niemiecki ludobojstwo lokalnego ludu, Herrero i Nama, w poludniowo-zachodniej Afryki, na poczatku dwudziestego wieku. A nie caly 40 lat pozniej, te same metody byle stosowane przeciwko Slowian, wlacznie Polakow, w imieniu lebensraum.Prosze zobaczyc moja szczegulowa recenzje. Uderz: The Kaiser's Holocaust: Germany's Forgotten Genocide and the Colonial Roots of Nazism.

The events described in this work occurred in a German colony in present-day Namibia in the early 1900's.HISTORICAL BACKGROUNDUnlike most indigenous peoples experiencing colonialism, the Nama (Hottentots) and Herero had not retreated into the hinterland or died-off from diseases. (p. 75). Nor were they impoverished in their dealings with the colonists. (p. 116). Despite a severe recent wave of rinderpest and other maladies, most Herrero peoples had bounced back into their pastoralist lifestyle. (p. 101).GERMAN RACISM AND GENOCIDEAs the 20th century began, intermarriages between Germans and locals were increasingly scorned as forms of RASSENSCHANDE (racial shame). (p. 244). Based largely on Social Darwinism, the old idea of "white man's burden" was replaced by a concept of ruthless exploitation. The destruction or enslavement of the lower races was converted into an aim, rather than effect, of colonialism. (p. 113).General Lothar von Trotha sought to exterminate the Herrero people by surrounding 50,000 of them, in an area 20 miles by 30 miles, with his military forces. (p. 142). No distinction was to be made between civilians and soldiers. Some of the Herrero survived by breaking out of encirclement and then enduring life in the desert. Others agreed to serve the Germans as laborers.GERMAN EXCULPATIONS: FALSE EQUIVALENCIESIn all the German concentration camps put together, the mortality rate was 40%-60%. (p. 220). For comparison, the death rates in the British concentration camps of the Boer War amounted to about 30% of those incarcerated: 39,000/130,000+ (p. 160)[Other sources indicate 25% or less]. The crucial difference, as the authors call it (p. 194), was that Kitchener's camps functioned to deprive the Boer fighters of support from the civilian population. The German camps were established AFTER the Herrero were already defeated, and had no ability or desire to resume fighting. (pp. 194-195).Shark Island may be considered the world's first death camp. By early 1907, 70% of the German-incarcerated Nama were dead, and a third of the remainder were reckoned close to death. (p. 217). The deaths were deliberate, and not from simple negligence (p. 219), and the closing of the camp was for political, not ethical, considerations. (p. 226). The prisoners' labor was an objective secondary to their extermination. (p. 220).Although Hermann Goering, during the Nuremberg trials, tried to relativize the Nazi camps by equating them with the British concentration camps during the Boer war, the comparison was patently ridiculous. All of the colonial camps were dwarfed by the later Nazi concentration camps, which would result in the death of 11 million people and the enslaving of an additional 6 million. (p. 342).COMPARE WITH GERMAN GENOCIDAL RACISM AGAINST SLAVSExpanding the context beyond South-West Africa, the authors allude to the HAKATA: "As old antipathies towards the ethnic Polish population of Prussia...became increasingly racialized in the later nineteenth century, schemes to strengthen the `German element' of the population and prevent the `Polonization' of Prussia were proposed." (p. 89). The eventual Hitlerian dream of a de-Polonized German Poland was seriously considered in the late nineteenth century: "...the Pan-Germans also breathed new life into old concepts and began privately to debate the idea that Poland and the Baltic states might be `acquired' by Germany and colonized...Extreme as their policies were, the men of the Pan-Germanic League were not figures of the lunatic fringe. The league was a highly respectable, even intellectual organization. Its leading members held seats in the Reichstag; others were academics at the nation's most respected universities." (p. 90).In contrast, the WWI and WWII German conduct towards eastern Jews was very different: "The OSTJUDEN, the Eastern Jews who were the main translators for Ludendorff's army, were the same communities who were systematically murdered in their villages and town squares by the Nazi EINSATZGRUPPEN twenty-six years later." (p. 270). [This confirms Polish complaints that the WWI-era local Jews were active agents of the German enemy.]By the time of WWII, the "white man's burden" had become a distant memory: "In the Nazi East, there were to be no missionaries and no schools. The Russians, Poles, Ukrainians and others permitted to remain would be slaves with no hope of manumission or education. The only technological advances made available to them would be abortion and contraception, in an effort to keep their populations down to acceptable levels." (pp. 337-338). [How ironic that Polish liberals today are causing a "self-genocide" among Poles]. Also, "By the summer of 1941 the Nazis, and millions of their followers, had come to regard the Jews, Gypsies and Slavic peoples of the East in ways that were little different from how the SCHUTZTRUPPE and settlers of German South-West Africa had regarded the Herrero and Nama four decades earlier." (p. 328).Actually, and not considered by the authors, German racism against Slavs exceeded that against the Herrero and Nama. Africans guilty of killing whites were hanged; whites guilty of killing blacks were sentenced to only months in prison. (p. 119). In contrast, a German could kill a Pole with complete impunity. In addition, Hitler said that, if forced to choose between them, he would rather rule over Negroes than Poles. Please click on, and read the Peczkis review, of Prelude to the Final Solution: The Nazi Program for Deporting Ethnic Poles, 1939-1941 (Modern War Studies).WHERE DID THE EPITHET "HUN" COME FROM?In 1900, the Kaiser travelled to China to exhort the German troops fighting against the Boxer Rebellion. Thinking that no one in the west would learn about it, he incited the German troops to kill mercilessly, take no prisoners, and make themselves a reputation as fearsome as the Huns of long ago. The Germans, though never even facing serious opposition, massacred thousands of innocent Chinese peasants. Word did get out, and thus the term `Hun' became synonymous for German. (pp. 105-10). In 1914, the German Army systematically murdered 6,000 Belgian civilians in reprisal for sniper fire. (p. 273).

This work challenges the prevailing neo-Darwinian interpretation of evolution. He suggests that evolution depends less on natural selection acting on random mutations, and more on the interactive properties of living things.Author Alan Bennett provides a history of evolutionary thinking--a history that long had predated Charles Darwin and his ORIGIN OF SPECIES. The author then focuses on eugenics, and its role in 19th and 20th century thinking. For this reason alone, this book is a boon to students of the history of biology.The author then gets into Neo-Lamarckism (epigenetics), self-assembly of matter, the Complexity Theory of evolution, and much more. His ideas are interesting, but they often come across as speculative. Nevertheless, they provide much food for thought.

The obvious theme of this work is Polish-Ukrainian-Jewish coexistence in Lwow (Lviv). This work is full of information, and I focus on a few items of historical--rather than cultural--interest.SOME INTERESTING FACTSLwow (Lviv) was not founded by Danylo, as commonly taught. It long had preceded him. In fact, it is much older than anyone had imagined. Archeological evidence, cited from a Ukrainian-language source, indicates that the site of Lviv has been continuously inhabited since the 5th century A. D. (Yaroslav Hrytsak, p. 48).After the 1908 assassination of the Viceroy of Galicia, Andrzej Potocki, by a Ukrainian, there was a transfer of Greek Catholics to Roman Catholicism. This was because Polish-speaking Greek Catholics did not want to be identified as Ukrainians. (Philipp Ther, p. 276).The most important Jewish political party in interwar Poland, the Bund, had, in the author's words, "a Marxist orientation." (Philipp Ther, p. 266). Obviously, Jewish support for Communism had been much broader than membership in the Communist Party and its front organizations.Most of the remainder of my review concerns the assimilation of Lwow's Jews.JEWISH ASSIMILATION: A CONSEQUENCE OF JEWISH MODERNIZATIONThe centuries of Jewish separatism and self-imposed apartheid (my term), based on Talmudism and rabbinism, were becoming increasingly unsustainable. Jews could not effectively function in the modern state while living in medieval-style isolation. Assimilation was an obvious remedy.Assimilationist Polish Jews condemned modern Jewish nationalism (Zionism and Bundism) as a new form of self-imposed isolation---for "trying to create a modern, national Jewish ghetto". (p. 237).JEWISH GERMANOPHILIA AND ASSIMILATIONAfter the Partitions, some of the Jews began to assimilate--but to German, not Polish, and they became tools of the Austrian rulers of this part of Poland. Author Waclaw Wierzbieniec quips, (quote) For a Jew in Lviv the route towards emancipation and Haskalah led through Germanization. (unquote). (p. 226). In addition, (quote) One of the most important aims of Austrian officialdom was to assimilate Jews not to the local Polish or Ukrainian communities, but rather to Austrian culture so that they would contribute to the Germanization of Galicia. (unquote). (p. 228).The foregoing Jewish Germanophilia can very much be generalized. The author comments, (quote) Similar tendencies appeared throughout Central Europe, where the popularization of the German language among Jews was concomitant with the emergence of a Jewish renaissance. Almost without exception, emancipated Jews came from educated circles where German was the basic cultural language. (unquote). (p. 228).Until the 1870's, Lwow's assimilated Jews had gravitated to German--not Polish--culture. (p. 243). However, even as Galicia's Jews began to Polonize, only part of them identified with the Polish cause. The rest of them, while outwardly Polish, recast their Jewish identity in this Polish garb, and often became supporters of socialism, Zionism, etc. (p. 236). By the 1920's, Zionism had a greater impact on Polonized Jews than did a pro-Polish orientation. (p. 241).The Polonization of Galician Jews, however infrequent and however usually outward in nature, was a late development. Wierzbieniec comments, (quote) In the 1880s a majority of the Lviv Jews did not know Polish, and it was only at the beginning of the twentieth century that knowledge of that language had so increased that sessions of the religious council could be conducted in Polish. (unquote). (p. 235). Parallel developments occurred, at about the same time, in other Jewish centers in Austrian-ruled Galicia. (p. 235). However, the acculturation of the Jews, to Polish ways, never gained popularity among the mostly-Orthodox Jewish masses. (p. 235).Jews did not turn, in appreciable numbers, to the Polish language until after the resurrected Polish state had become a fait accompli in 1918. Even then, the Polonization did not come from Jewish initiatives. Instead, Jews had largely been driven to Polish by the prevailing circumstances--the use of the Polish language in public schools, the administration, and the armed forces. (p. 243).MOTIVES FOR ASSIMILATIONAlthough Wierzbieniec does not put it in these terms, he makes it obvious that assimilation of Jews to Polish-ness had generally been driven less by some newfound love for Poland and more by a spirit of self-advancement and opportunism. This is obvious as the reason that Galicia's assimilated Jews had increasingly shifted from German to a Polish. He writes, (quote) The Jewish intelligentsia that had previously gravitated to German language and culture in order to participate in the broader cultural, social, and political realms now recognized the Polish language as such as means. (unquote). (p. 233).A utilitarian spirit is also evident in the fact that Jews who assimilated did so to Polish rather than Ukrainian ways. He writes, (quote) The assimilation of Jews to Ukrainian culture had only an occasional or even incidental character, as it did not offer the possibility of social and economic advancement. (unquote). (p. 232).JEWS WHO BECAME POLISH PATRIOTSDuring the 1848 Revolution, some of the maskilim supported the Polish side. However, they were only a small group of Jews, mostly intellectuals, while the Orthodox masses remained indifferent. (p. 230).Movements among Galicia's Jews to identify with the Polish nation, and to support her national aspirations, were even more uncommon than outward Polonization. For instance, the Agudas Akhim [Covenant of Brothers; PRZYMIERZE BRACI], which lasted only from 1882 to the early 1890's, had only 178 members in Lwow in 1884. Attempts to open additional branches in other Galician cities failed, with the exception of Przemysl. (Wierzbieniec, pp. 134-135).Interestingly, Jewish historian Wilhelm Feldman, one of the leaders of Agudas Akhim, tacitly echoed Endek sentiments about Jewish essentialism and its quasi-immutability. He alluded to the difficulty of even Polonophile Jews to fully become Poles, (quote) "A future scholar will not remain unmoved looking at the image of a handful of young people emerging around 1880 from the mass of half-Germanized and half-Asiatic Jewry, with a white eagle on a banner held in their mighty hands." (unquote). (p. 235).Wierzbieniec blames Polish disinterest, and continued Polish anti-Semitism, for the marginal status, in Jewish eyes, of the Agudas Akhim, and its demise. Ironic to this, the Agudas Akhim blamed continued Jewish intransigence for Polish anti-Semitism. Please click on, and read the detailed Peczkis review, of Diaspora Nationalism and Jewish Identity in Habsburg Galicia.1930's POLAND: JEWISH ADVANTAGES AND POLISH ANTI-SEMITISMThe pre-WWII period is commonly painted, for Poland's Jews, in hues of black. It was not. Wierzbieniec writes, (quote) In spite of widespread anti-Semitism in Lviv society, Jews were free to open their own schools and participate in the politics and governance of the city. In the early 1930s, 25 Jews sat in a city council of 130 members. They designated their own representative to the city's deputy mayor...Jews constituted a significant group in the secondary schools and academies of Lviv...In the early 1920s, over 40 percent of the student body at the Jan Casimir University was Jewish. (unquote). (p. 242).The latter figure must be kept in perspective. Jews were only 10% of Poland's population.SUFFERINGS OF THE KRESY POLISH EXPELLEESFast-forward to the end of WWII:Much has been said about the privations of the German expellees (VERTRIEBENE) from places such as Silesia, and how this was supposed to be collective retribution against the Germans for losing the war. However, the Poles, who were supposed to be on the winning side of the war, also suffered greatly after Churchill and Roosevelt consented (at 1943 Teheran) to the Soviet grab of Poland's eastern half (Kresy), and the Poles faced expulsion. German historian Phillipp Ther, who wrote about both the German and Polish VERTRIEBENE, described the experiences of the Polish expellees from Lwow, (quote) The journey from Lviv to the areas of resettlement often lasted several weeks. The trains were largely without heat, were not supplied with food, and were often stopped and plundered. Reports from Upper Silesia show that about a quarter of the expellees were so ill upon arrival that they required immediate treatment. (unquote). (pp. 283-284).

ESSAYS ON POLISH-JEWISH RELATIONS, by Joseph Orlitzky, is the English-language citation of this Polish-language work. My review is based on the original 1983 edition.Author Jozef Orlicki covers a broad sweep of Jewish history in Poland. His work was published while Poland was still under Communism, and it reflects this fact in the “class struggle” terminology it sometimes uses.SOME INTERESTING FACTSA significant number of Polish Jews were ennobled, and given the armorial. Orlicki (p. 10) estimates that hundreds of Polish Jews were ennobled during the First Republic.Some Jews supported Poland in her January 1863 Insurrection. Most did not. (pp. 21-23).Zionism and Folkism (Bundism) were forms of 19th- and 20th-century Jewish nationalism. Both were hostile to Polish national aspirations. (e. g, p. 26, 80). In fact, a number of quoted articles in the Litvak (Litwak)/Yiddishist newspapers expressed undisguised enmity towards the prospect of a resurrected Polish state. ((pp. 36-37).In the years leading up to Poland's regaining her independence (1918), Jews constituted 3-4% of the soldiers in Pilsudski's legions. (p. 35). However, they were under-represented in comparison with Jewish levels in Poland's general population (10-15%), and this contrasts with the Jews' over-representation in anti-Polish movements such as Communism.THE MINORITIES TREATYThe so-called Minorities Treaty of circa 1918 would have granted Jews special rights, and effectively made Jews a separate, parallel nation (a Judeopolonia) on Polish soil. In 1919, Wojciech Korfanty asked if the Polish minority in Germany (such as that in Westphalia) could even imagine such special rights and nation-within-nation privileges. (pp. 40-41). Muttermilch, an educated and assimilated Polish Jew, pointed out that the Minorities Treaty had nothing to do with the protection of the rights of Jews as a religious and cultural minority. These were rights that Poland's Jews already freely had. It was all about Jews having a set of special, separatist rights: Of their own political parties, their own government-funded schools, their own government-funded court system, and even their own parliament. (p. 45). [If that is not nation-within-nation privilege, then what is?]THE 1918-ERA POGROMSDuring the Lwow (Lviv) pogrom of 1918, the Austrian newspaper, DER ABEND, gave a fantastic Jewish death toll of 3,000, even though the actual Jewish death toll, from all war-related causes, was 68. (p. 42). Bernard Hausner, a member of the Polish parliament and also member of the religious-Zionist Mizrachi political party, took his fellow Zionists to task for inflaming the situation by (using modern parlance) rushing to judgment on the pogroms, by greatly exaggerating the Jewish death toll, and by otherwise acting disloyally to Poland. (pp. 42-43).In fact, much of the worldwide Jewish press greatly exaggerated the pogroms, and awfulized the situation of Jews in Poland. [Sound familiar?] Orlicki [Orlitsky] provides several examples of this. (pp. 44-45). Muttermilch, an educated and assimilated Polish Jew, condemned the egregious pogrom over-hype in the Jewish press, and exposed this as part of a politicized agenda of furthering Jewish separatism and special-national rights for the Jews in Poland. (p. 45).THE 1937 SCHECHITA LAWIn Poland, nearly 100% of animals were slaughtered in accordance with the dictates of Jewish ritual slaughter. In other European countries, it was 2-4%. (p. 54). The use of schechita in Poland greatly raised the price of veal—by an annual rate of 18 million zlotys. (p. 54).The schechita law of 1937 did NOT, as often mischaracterized, in any way abolish schechita itself. It only restricted ritual slaughter to those towns where the Jewish population was over 3%, and restricted Jewish butchers to selling ritually-slaughtered meat in selected stores. (p. 54). Clearly, the claim that the schechita law was an anti-Semitic affront to the Jewish religion, though often presented as such, was manifestly false. It had a sound economic basis, as elaborated below.The schechita law of 1937 eliminated the jobs of an alleged 100,000 workers. These included schechita butchers, transport personnel, salesmen, etc. (p. 54). Obviously, these occupations had largely been of an economically-superfluous, make-work nature.From all the above descriptions, a number of conclusions are in order. It is evident that ritual slaughter, in Poland, had been very much out of step with the modern animal-slaughtering procedures of other European nations. In addition, it had been a hidden tax that had supported the Jewish religion. Finally, it had supported a chain of unproductive, arguably-parasitic middlemen, and had thus burdened all Poles with unnecessarily high prices for meat.THE SHOAH SUPPRESSED?Author Orlicki has a detailed description of the Nazi German-made Holocaust. He is unambiguous about the fact that Jews were targeted by the Germans, and that they had been targeted because they were Jews. Many modern Holocaust materials would have us believe that the Holocaust had been deliberately forgotten in the first few decades of post-WWII Poland, and that Jewish deaths were merely subsumed under such narratives as "Polish citizens" and "victims of fascism". Orlicki's work is yet another refutation of that ridiculous canard.

This work is much more than biography. It offers a pulse of the state of Judaism in the late 19th and early 20th century. It focuses on the life and the ideas of Rabbi Avraham Yitzhak Kook, whom author Mirsky describes as “a colossal figure in the English-speaking world.” (p. ix). Kook was born in tsarist Russia, and then lived in Palestine and England.The author sagely notes that the Litvaks (Litwaks) were as much a marker of Jewish cultural orientation as they were of geography. (p. 16). [Author Mirsky’s reasoning has a parallel in Polish (notably Endek) thinking. In Polish eyes, “Litvak” had a typological, and not solely geographic, meaning. It referred to those Jews who were particularly hostile to Polish ways and/or Polish national aspirations.]The author portrays Rav Kook as an original thinker. Though Orthodox, he had positive responses to the secularist and the Zionist tendencies among many Jews of the time. For example, traditional Judaism’s relationship to modernizing tendencies should not be solely antagonistic, but dialectic. (e. g, p. 39). Instead of rejecting Zionism, Kook wanted to combine it with religion, as exemplified by the Mizrachi. (p. 233). Kook’s “softness” on heresy, and his accommodating spirit to modern trends, earned him the ire of other Orthodox Jews.OLD PEJORATIVE TERMS USED FOR CHRISTIANSRav Kook was antagonistic towards Christianity, particularly its otherworldly aspects, as described by Mirsky, (quote).…(Kook) saw the Christian abandonment of the world as downright demonic, and the gravest heresy of all. “MINUT [the Talmudic term for Christianity] abandoned the law, planted itself in the imagined attribute of mercy and kindness, which destabilizes the world and destroys it…” (unquote). (p. 130). (The content in brackets is the author Mirsky’s).Many Orthodox Jews of 20th-century Palestine dealt with Rav Kook in the harshest terms for his deviations from Orthodoxy, even juxtaposing him with Christians, and doing so in a venomous manner. Mirsky comments, (quote) But the vilification of Rav Kook never let up, especially among members of the Agudat Yisrael youth movement, who heckled him, attacked him in posters, and at times threw buckets of water in his face as he walked down the street…On March 23, 1932, the eve of the holiday of Purim, the Jerusalem chapter of the Agudah youth staged a mock trial in which Rav Kook was tried for heresy. Next, they mutilated him in effigy as the youngsters danced around and sang…the billboard rhetoric against him reached a new pitch, “That man, the MIN (that is, Christian), hypocritical, flattering, like a pig rummaging in trash and raising a stink…” (unquote). (pp. 203-204). I will not complete the quoted sentence because it has pornographic connotations. The explicit definition of MIN as Christian, in the parentheses in the quoted statement above, is in the text of Mirsky’s book, and not something that I had added.Let us examine the implications. Many commentators would have us believe that the references in the Talmud, to idolaters and heretics, do not apply to Christians, at least to modern Christians. From the above quoted statements, it is obvious that they most certainly do—even in the 20th century. Clearly, Polish scholar Feliks Koneczny, in his JEWISH CIVILIZATION, had been correct in identifying MIN as one of the derogatory Talmudic terms that are in fact applied, by Jews, to Christians.HELPING JEWS EVADE MILITARY SERVICERav Kook lived in London during WWI. Here is what he did, (quote) On arrival, he [Rav Kook] became the leading rabbinic figure of England’s eastern European Orthodox community. A stranger to established Anglo Jewry, he found himself bumping up against settled ways. After signing one rabbinic ordination after another to save young men from conscription, he was called in for questioning by Scotland Yard; police investigators had noticed that many of his “rabbis” were in fact not religiously observant. He was let off with a stern warning but kept on, unimpressed by invocations of the moral significance of the British war effort. (unquote). (pp. 140-141).The informed reader may realize that the Jews of Poland frequently attempted to avoid military service in the Polish Army. The reason (or exculpation) was the unwillingness to serve in the army of a state that had anti-Semitism, and which failed to give Jews the rights that they were entitled to (or that they thought that they were entitled to). However, whatever could be said of Poland, this could hardly be said of philo-Semitic England, yet evasion of military service by Jews took place just the same.There is more. The objections of many Poles (notably the Endeks) to the so-called Minorities Treaty included the concern that Jews would be emboldened to evade service in the Polish Army on putative religious grounds. The actions of Rav Kook are one example of this.

I LED THE BRYGADA SWIETOKRZYSKA OF THE NSZ is the title of this Polish-language work. My review is based on the original 1984 edition.This action-packed memoir covers the prewar period, the 1939 campaign, guerilla actions in the region of Kielce, and the fascinating march across SW Czechoslovakia, ahead of the advancing Red Army, to a meeting with Patton's Third Army.The NSZ (NARODOWE SILY ZBROJNE) considered the Soviets an equal enemy with the Nazis, and opposed any fighting for them. Polish-Soviet cooperation had brought bitter fruits. The disarming of A.K. (ARMIA KRAJOWA) soldiers, the killing of their officers by the NKVD, and the betrayal of the 1944 Warsaw Uprising were taken as self-evident indicators of the folly (even criminality) of existing Soviet-allying Polish policies. (e. g., p. 58). [Barring hindsight, it isn't so simple. Failure to fight the Germans on behalf of the Russians would've played into the hands of Communist propaganda, which insisted that non-Communist Poles aren't really substantive participants in the anti-Nazi alliance, and have no significant standing among Poles. It would probably also have extinguished whatever slim chance there still existed for effective western support for a non-Communist Poland.]Soviet-sponsored Communist GL-AL bands were well-armed, often led by Russians, and of many nationalities (p. 65, 80-81). They regularly murdered AK and NSZ members (pp. 114-116), identified others to the Gestapo (p. 188, 192), robbed, raped, and killed Polish villagers (p. 109, pp. 127-128), and needlessly provoked German reprisals against local Poles. (p. 65). (The large-scale Jewish involvement in the Communist GL-AL, and in bandit bands, clarifies recurrent charges of the NSZ killing Jews).The NSZ strategy was to fight only when it, or surrounding civilian populations, were in immediate danger from Germans, the GL-AL, or bandits. (p. 64, 73, 81). The goal was to conserve its strength, and that of the Polish nation, in anticipation of Brigade participation in a future western-Soviet war. (p. 144, 173).Polish guerillas could successfully attack German units in surprise attacks, but were insufficiently armed for sustained, open combat against them. The Commander correctly predicted that AK units would be unable to break through the German encirclement of Warsaw to aid the Uprising. (p. 79).Ironic to accusations of the NSZ being anti-Semitic, it was singularly responsible for saving a few hundred Jewish women from certain death. This occurred on May 4, 1945 at a small women's concentration camp near Holyszow (Holysov), located about 25 km SSW of Plzen (Pilsen). (It was a sub-camp of Flossenburg concentration camp.) The barracks housing the Jewish women were surrounded by gasoline-filled cans, ready to be torched upon the approach of Allied armies. The Brigade took the camp by surprise (pp. 158-163), taking many Germans prisoner (p. 223), and freeing the 1,000 women of various nationalities (p. 151, 189). Later, the French government rewarded the Brigade for these heroics. (p. 259).General George Patton played a key role in preventing the Brigade from falling into the hands of the Soviets. (p. 225, 260). Fortunately, he didn't share the rosy view of the Soviet Union then held by most Americans.The Communist smear campaign against the NSZ included--surprise--the media charge of it being fascist (p. 172), and this has been picked up by many Jewish memoirs that I have read. Accusations of NSZ-Nazi collaboration are falsehoods. During the westward march, agreements with German forces were purely of the nature of local truces (pp. 141-145), facilitated by the increasing German reluctance to die in a losing war against a non-strategic objective. The Brigade was allowed to march through the Czech Republic, not Germany. Pointedly, the Commander repeatedly refused German enticements for the Brigade to go back and fight behind Soviet lines. (p. 147, 149). In his memoirs, Communist Mieczyslaw Moczar lied about the Commander begging the Germans to stop shooting at him (p. 235, 242).The Reds didn't stop with propaganda. After Germany's defeat, they tried to kidnap or assassinate the Commander at least twice (pp. 178-179). Later, in 1950, they unsuccessfully framed him before a French court, trying to get him extradited as a war criminal merely for having fought against Communists. (p. 185).

Really smooth action. Punches holes like a champ. I've punched holes through laminated cardstock without any issue. I've seen where some people have complained that the little mushroom part is too small, making this difficult to flip pages over without manually pushing them to one side. I feel that this not a design flaw but is the result of getting disks that are too large for the number of pages. Yes, the Levenger gives a larger mushroom, which makes it easier to navigate the rather large arch produced by a relatively empty disk. However, I've filled mine up most of the way (not anywhere what I'd call stuffed), and the pages move quite easily. I can grab a stack and just flip them from side to side without any pages catching on the disks.The locking latch feels a bit cheap and plastic-y, but the rest of the punch is nicely designed and hefty, with the cuttings tray being easily withdrawn and deep enough to hold quite a bit of punch outs.

I can't use most costume earrings as I have an extreme sensitivity to the metal alloys in them. As such, I tend to stick with gold plated. Having lost a beloved bezel set of CZ earrings, I looked here to find a replacement. These fit the bill. They do get cloudy rather easily from just everyday handling and oils in the skin, but that's normal for CZ, so I can't really take off any stars. They're quite brilliant while clean and still pretty dazzling even after a few days. Just the right size too (not gigantic but not so small as to not be noticeable); I've already received several compliments. Prongs are set evenly. Posts are straight. The box they came in is gorgeous. Shipping was fairly quick. I am satisfied with my purchase.

Addis have the smoothest joins of any needles I've tried, including the knitter's favorite: Knitpicks. In fact, I ordered these after doing the two-socks-on-two-circular method on a KP and Addi needle and became frustrated every time I had to work my stitches over the small overlapping lip of the KP join. I use one sock rocket and a regular Addi for the blue/gold cord combination which makes it easier for me to remember which needle to use. Couldn't be happier.

As always, ChiaoGoo comes through for me. This is like my 12th CG needle, and I'm always pleased with the quality. The etched sizing info makes it easy to grab the needles you need, and the carbonized bamboo is much easier to glide yarn across than unfinished or even waxed bamboo...though it remains "sticky" enough that you don't have to worry about stitches falling off.

I use these for my two chihuahuas as they have relatively small bladders, and, like many people, I work 8+ hours a day. I had tried regular cat litter but read that a lot of people did not recommend as it might cause unhealthy build-up in their digestive systems if they ate it. Plus, they tend to dig in it (both treat it like beach sand and would try and roll in it as well). Purina's Second Nature was the first litter I tried after the traditional clay stuff fell flat. It wasn't bad, but the pieces were so large that my smallest little chihuahua had trouble with her footing and so would avoid like the plague. I saw the Yesterday's News litter and thought maybe it would be better as it's a good bit thinner than SN (though I kept the Second Nature litter pan since the sides weren't too high, especially at the entrance, and was easier for my dogs to step into...not to mention large enough to prevent missteps). So far so good. Started with the fresh scent, but it's virtually useless at controlling odor, so now I save money by just buying the regular. It's not awful, but it can get a bit ammonia-y. I scoop daily and wash the box once a week. In between, I sprinkle baking soda on the more concentrated areas where my dogs prefer to pee.  The main reason I deducted a star from my rating is that it's a bit wasteful. The pellets are quite thin and easily fall through any scoop size. Once wet, the pellets break apart easily. So scooping and shaking does nothing but redistribute soiled pellets more evenly amongst unsoiled ones. I've since found that using a thinner layer works best as the urine goes all the way to the bottom and scooping the entire section doesn't take away as much unused litter. I'll have to monitor my use more closely and will edit this review to include information on how much litter lasts for how long.Update: I know line the bottom of the pan with a pee pad and scoop a very thin layer of litter on top. Doing this has extended the use of a bag to three times what it use to, though you do have to factor in the additional cost of the pads. However, another positive to using pads under is that it's a LOT easier to clean up. I simply grab each order and lift.

Comfortable design for human hands...most clippers of this size have holes that are too small. However, the blades aren't sharp enough. I use these on my tiny chihuahuas, and they put a lot of pressure on the nail. I got these to replace another set that I had which grew too dull, but at least those started out sharp at some point. These just came too dull/weak from the get-go.

I love this canvas lunch bag. I've had a ton of lunch bags. Igloo, EasyLunches, Everest, Rachel Ray, BuiltNY, etc... My last lunchbag was a Thirty-One thermal tote that I got rid of once the thermal foil started separating from the outer fabric. Actually, that seems to be a weak point for quite a few bags I've had. Well, this is the one that I'm sticking with. Don't get me wrong; it's not a perfect bag for every situation. If insulation is a priority, then I'd go with something else as this has none. But it's that simplicity of design that I love so much.The soft sides make it easy to conform. I can shove this into my micro-fridge at work without much ado and without taking up extra space other than the size of my food containers. Though the base is smaller, it accommodates larger boxes because it's so unstructured. It's lightweight. Easy to wash (just make sure to use cold water). You can even personalize it (I did with some embroidery). The velcro layer on top holds well, and the little cotton cord is easy to grab or hand about your wrist.

Nice little mat. Works great. Cuts are invisible after use, and the color is a nice departure from the camo grays and greens. The smaller size makes it easy to stow away in my craft box but still allows ease of use when working on pages for my Filofax or Midori. Really happy with the thrown-in blade too. Sharp with plenty of refills stuffed into the shaft. Very happy with my purchase.

I was really afraid that I would have to write a negative review for this pen. I had the hardest time getting it to work when it arrived. Using the bottled ink converter and warm water seemed to finally do the trick. I was very pleased with this pen once I started using it. From a couple of other comments, I was worried that the barrel would be really cheap feelings, but it's actually not. It has a nice matte finish that gives it a sort of carbon fiber feel to it. It's lightweight, but not so much that you don't feel the pen is stable. The ink releases faster than I'd imagined, so I'll have to practice a bit to get the hang of things, but it's a real pleasure to write with.

Bottle arrived in perfect condition. No leaks, thank goodness. The shade is the newer and reformulated Australian Rose shade...a deep purple that reminds me of a dark wine stain. It's still quite lovely and looks well in my oxblood colored traveler's notebook.

Flimsy. Just a bunch of really light tubes. Not too attractive. Plus, the levels are shorter than expected. Won't fit some of my shoes and is awkward getting heels out when the level is full. I've now disassembled and re-purposed it as a drying rack.

I purchased this after seeing all of the positive reviews and glowing recommendations on the internet. I'd had a French press, but I was tired of all the unscrewing and cleaning involved...not to mention the fear of cracking the glass either through a careless misstep or extreme temperature fluctuations from pouring hot water into a cold (in the winters we keep the house very chilly) carafe. So the AeroPress seemed perfect. Plastic. Easy to clean. Coffee to go "whoohoo!!!" about. Huh...not so much.Is it easy to use? Maybe for most...not for me. Took me forever to align the plunger properly. It would tilt. It would go in crooked. And I felt like I was having to exert a lot of force, which is something I never noticed from all of those demonstrations. Perhaps it would have been better once the Aeropress was "broken in" a bit, and I do admit that it seemed the plunger went in easier on the second go, though I still felt like I was having to exert more force than I'd like to that early in the morning. However, the coffee it produced was beyond revolting. Let me be clear: it was NOT the grinds. It's the same stuff I've drunk for the past couple of months. There's nothing "off" about them. The only new factor in this equation is the Aeropress. And it made my coffee taste nasty! Some sort of weird fishy taste permeated the brew. I tried it again...same results. It's now in the box to go to Goodwill.

When I purchased my Global knife, I was very happy with its performance but noticed that, after a couple of years, it had lost some of its keen edge. I was looking into the idea of shipping it off to sharpen it when I decided to do some research on the issue. A few Youtube videos later, I realized that I didn't need to sharpen it by sending it off and grinding it down. I needed to "realign" the edge. I decided on a ceramic sharp stick as I wasn't sure what the hardness of my Global was and figured the ceramic would be fairly all-purpose. Once it arrived, I promptly began honing my knife with a few passes. I thought it would be hard to get the angle, but it really does follow the shape of your knife's edge. I immediately noticed a huge difference. It really is amazing. At the slightest hint of dullness, I pass my knife over the sharp stick and it's instantly transformed into scalpel-like precision. I am very, very happy with my purchase.

I recently purchased a beige and charcoal toile comforter and when I saw this, I just knew it would be a perfect accent pillow...and it is!I was a bit worried when someone else posted that the material was super rough/coarse. Even though I only plan on using it as an accent pillow, I am sensitive to very scratchy and abrasive surfaces. I'm glad I went ahead and ordered it though b/c I personally don't find it scratchy at all. It's stiff b/c it's some sort of burlap weave, but the material itself is very smooth. It feels like really thick linen, which if anyone has ever held a new linen shirt (real linen...not that linen-like stuff), you'd know that it's no Egyptian cotton. But I like the rigidity and lack of sheen. Just looking at this little owl's sleeping face makes me sleepy. LoLVery happy with the quality of materials and the quality of the print. Ecstatic about how it looks on my bed. The colors match perfectly.

Update: Finally figured out how to add those pictures.I have a super tiny kitchen and needed just one or two little pops of color to bring some life into it without also hauling in clutter. Found some beautiful turquoise blue kitchen towels and mitts, so when I spied this on Amazon (combining my love for both turquoise blue AND owls), I had to have it! It's been one of my favorite purchases for my new apartment.It's a little smaller than most utensil crocks, but this is clearly illustrated by picture in which it's holding pencils and by the measurements given. I was aware of the size, but I only really use my wooden utensils, which have very slim handles and a light weight, so it was perfect for that.I just adore this little owl. Wish Amazon still allowed buyers to post their own pictures. I'd love to snap a shot of this little guy on my counter. It really brightens up my kitchen, which is done in all blacks and beige, and draws your eye to it.

I should have listened to the other reviewers because everything they said was true. Point of fact: if it wasn't a near impossible feat to box this up and return it, I would do so in a heartbeat. I purchased this sofa and its matching loveseat because I needed something that could be delivered without a 1-2,000 dollar minimum purchase, was attractive, and could fit in a small space. I suppose, in hindsight, it did meet all of those criteria. However, comfort was (I thought) a given. Especially since my last sofa was an under 400 purchase and very comfy indeed. Not so, boys and girls. Not so.First, the pros: attractive and easy to assemble. Love the shape. Love the fabric, which is a soft corduroy.Now the cons...actually, only one huge con: it's super uncomfortable! I don't know what kind of springs they have in this, but I can feel them in the seat. Not only that, I can actually HEAR them when I sit and even when I use my hand to exert just a little bit of pressure. My friend was there when I did this and was LoL at how much twanging it was doing. Plus, the seat and back cushions are strangely conjoined so that when you sit, you find that your back curves out...which causes horrible back fatigue. In order to sit without agony, I find that I have to push myself all the way back with some force and wiggle in until I find a position that doesn't hurt. In fact, I'm trying to make this short and sweet b/c my back is still killing me from last night's foray onto Serta sofas. As far as I'm concerned, this couch and loveseat were a 700 dollar mistake. As soon as I save up the money, I'm going to purchase another sofa/loveseat. All I know for sure at this juncture is that it will definitely NOT be a Serta. In fact, considering the main problem with this sofa is the cushions, I think I'll be avoiding anything Serta for the foreseeable future.12-29-14 - It is now five months later, but the cushions are already showing signs of compression. I cannot emphasize just how disappointing this purchase has been.

I don't know anything about the quality of this item as I have no frame of reference. So don't be affected by the star rating if you are looking to compare brands. As this is my first time eating this type of licorice (which is an import item), I can only give a review on my personal preference.The good: the flavor was excellent. Strong and with a nice salt/sugar coating that really complemented the licorice.The bad: the texture. Ugh! I could not get over how soft these were. It was like eating stewed plums. Licorice flavored stewed plums.Seller was excellent though. The star rating is no reflection on them whatsoever.

I got this for a friend's little girl's b-day. She liked it, but I think the adults were even more enraptured. All day long I'd hear "it smells JUST like ___." The scents were amazing. None of that little-round-sticker nonsense that a lot of the scratch and sniff books have fallen back on. And though I love the Mr. Smith scratch and sniff books, this one blows it away. The scents are much more true...the smog scent literally smelled like gasoline and motor oil, it was fantastic. In the Smith books, some scents are super light (the banana) or just smell like one part of the whole (the spaghetti smelled like plain garlic), but Animal Gas really did capture all of the smells perfectly. I'm actually thinking of buying one for myself to add to my vintage collection.

I can understand if this was for a side salad, but as a main salad container, it's much too small. The design is nicely thought of. I like the fact that the salad ingredients can be stored separately, especially useful if you don't want to get certain ingredients soggy, but the bottom container holds maybe a cup of lettuce and the dressing container barely fits 2 tablespoons of light ranch. Now for pasta salads or salads that have a heavy protein component (such as tuna, chicken, or egg salads which require a smaller bed of lettuce), I think this would be o.k. However, the salads I eat are not meat or carb heavy (maybe 2 oz of protein per salad). The bulk is vegetables, and I need a good sized container in order to get full and stay full for a good 4-5 hours after eating. This just isn't going to do that for me.

I teach, and I have a hard time organizing papers for efficient grading. With multiple classes and multiple assignments, the paper stack grows and grows until I end up with what looks like a Stephen King manuscript. Tried just using the paperclip method, but papers would escape, or the clips would snag on other assignments. Plus, the papers would shift and become crumpled or unclipped in my tote during the trip from school to home. I then began using a plain accordion file, which worked out well, but the flap was cheaply made (it basically bent the plastic back) and would have to be held back or else pop me in the face and cover the opening, and it didn't hold quite as much because the flap (again with that flap) didn't provide much headway for the papers and would pinch the top of the accordion file when I started filling it. So when I saw the Mead, I knew I had to have it.First of all, it's extremely roomy. Because the zipper allows for a good 1/2 inch of room above the papers, it doesn't pinch them in or become warped/distended. In fact, there's so much room at the top that I'm actually able to insert manila folders inside, which is great because I can ensure that important documents (like tests) are kept completely separate and don't run any risk of getting misplaced. The tabs pop up to be visible over large stacks of work. There's a little clear section in the very front where I can put whatever rubric I'm using for that week. I label a tab for each class and have a section for keys and makeup work/no name papers. It's fantastic. Really well made. No snags with the zipper. No issues with the tabs or any other part of this item. Plus, the color is just too cute.

I had been looking for a casual/unstructured, everyday tote. While I already have a decent selection of handbags, my one black purse is more of an office type of bag, and I just don't feel comfortable slinging it across my arm for a trip to the gym or during dress-down days. Plus, since I've been putting in some extra hours at work, I've had to bring in more items to prep for grueling 10-12 hour days. This tote has tons of room. Admittedly, it's a bit of a rummage to get at everything, but I don't see that as a flaw. I mean, if I want a large, unstructured bag, it sort of comes with the territory.The leather is very supple, which is as functional as it is pretty b/c the straps tend to stay on my shoulders better than leather that has a glossier finish. The hardware is very nice too. I originally had my heart set on the previous model with the gold hardware and zipper, but I'm glad those were sold out. The gunmetal offers more flexibility with regards to my jewelry, and it's not as flashy as the gold, which makes it easier to dress up or down. I had some concerns on whether or not I was actually getting gunmetal (the pictures look sort of silver, especially the O-rings attaching to the straps), but it IS the gunmetal version...which is especially lovely. I didn't quite know what to expect from that description; I thought maybe it was a deeper stainless color, but it's actually a lovely dark metallic grey. Reminds me of hematite or malachite. Eye-catching without overpowering the rest of the purse or whatever accessories you choose to pair with your outfit.All-in-all, I think this is going to be my go-to bag for quite some time.

I really like this pitcher as the fast flow system allows not only for a quicker fill-up but more space. Most other pitchers have almost equal space devoted to both the reservoir and a refilling section...obviously b/c most people don't want to sit there for longer periods of time waiting for their pitchers to become full. With the fast flow Filtrete, I can set my faucet to a medium drizzle, walk away, and come back when I see it's almost full. It doesn't take long.I can't say how this filter holds up against heavily chlorinated water. We have a well, and the water it produces is pretty good. I just use this as a finishing touch to clear out any impurities or sediments. I like the slim design, and I like that the spout closes. Some of the Brita filter pitchers do not have a closing spout and, as a result, the water can become tinged with the flavors of the fridge. I'm not a huge water drinker, so it's not like I refill this thing everyday. If you do, then the lingering flavors wouldn't be a problem as it doesn't have time enough to sit and absorb.So why three stars? Because the filter is impossible to find at my local stores and buying online isn't economical. Part of it seems to be that the style of the pitcher has changed. While I cannot find the long/rectangle filters (or even the pitchers) anymore, there's lots of the round filter and round pitchers. One of the few things I liked about Brita was that most filters worked in most pitchers (with only a few exceptions) and the style has mostly stayed the same.If it wasn't for the fickle nature of its design and the subsequent difficulty in getting filters, I'd have easily rated this 4 or even 5 stars, but performance isn't everything. Convenience (especially for regularly replaced parts) is a factor as well.

Love the idea of a cordless keyboard and, for the most part, it's lived up to its promise. No more cords getting in the way. No more hogging usb ports. Fairly extensive battery life. However, there is one glaring detractor that, to me, is worth deducting two stars. It doesn't register all of my keystrokes...at least not when I'm typing fast. When I slow it down to around 25-35 words per minute, it registers everything, but I typically type in the 60-65 wpm range. When I do type faster, it skips letters. At first I thought it was me. That perhaps I was making keystroke mistakes, so I tested it by typing out a simple refrain using few keys and that I was positive I was maintaining accuracy on, and it was still skipping letters. Very frustrating to be typing and have to constantly go back and fix typos every few words. I'm actually wondering if I should go back to using a corded board again.

I've never had luck with lip balms. From the expensive Kiehl's to your average cherry Chapstick, none of them really worked for me. In fact, I'd find that the waxy texture and/or odd taste would keep me from naturally licking my lips and eventually lead to over-drying...quite the opposite of what I bought them for. Well, this year I started noticing that a LOT of my female students were using the EOS lipbalms in class. Sort of hard to miss the egg shaped container. I curiously asked about it and was given rave reviews by them. Not usually one to take fashion and makeup advice from teenagers, I went on a limb and purchased during my next trip to the grocery store. I bought the strawberry sorbet, and while it doesn't exactly taste like strawberries or sorbet, it does have a nice fruity scent and a slightly sweet taste. However, the icing on top is that it works great. The balm is fast absorbing. Unlike others that lay on your skin, this seems to be absorbed, leaving behind slightly moist and dewy lips. Only small downsize is that the dispenser is a rather shape and size, which makes it a bit difficult to fit in some makeup bags. However, on the flip-side, it makes it easy to find one-handed in your purse. So it evens out in the end.

After finding my beloved Gold Toe was going to el cheapo route and not having any luck with other brands, I'd pretty much resigned myself to socks that I considered wearable but not comfortable. I almost didn't buy these Balega Comfort socks, despite their high price and high number of positive reviews. I'd listened to the same reviews with regards to some Thorlo socks and had been severely disappointed. However, I figured one pair wouldn't break the bank and ordered anyway.So glad I did. They are a bit pricey. Much more than your average mass retail store sock and even pricier than what my beloved Gold Toes use to be, but they're worth it. Some of my love for Balega is based on preference; I love a sock that is very elastic and molds to my foot, especially in my arch. I love it to have some thickness to it, especially in the heel and under the ball. I don't like threading/seam bunches in the corners of my toes. I like socks that are soft but not fuzzy/pilly...more of a well-used cotton type of soft. The Balega Hidden Comfort gave me all of these.Every time I order from Amazon or need a few more dollars to meet the free shipping requirement, I just throw another pair of these in. Can't have enough of them.

I purchased this not based on the price (which is admittedly very affordable) but b/c of the strength of reviews. Reviews which I had hoped would lead me to the type of bank deposit bags I was used to dealing with when I worked in retail. Nothing fancy...just thick plastic pouches of blue, green, or black. However, while this bag matches them in size, it does not match them in quality. This bag is thin and cheap feeling. I'm no fortune-teller, but I have my doubts as to whether it will last us through my class's multiple fundraiser and dues collection each year. Not that it seems like it would just fall apart, but the zipper doesn't feel too impressive, and the plastic/vinyl material itself is maybe 1/3 the thickness of what I'm use to working with.I'll use it b/c it would cost more aggravation and trouble to return the thing, but I wouldn't buy again nor recommend to anyone that they do so.

I have a wide head. I'm talking basketball-wide. Most hats don't fit. Those cute little terry-cloth bathbands don't fit. Tried using a plastic headband once and had it snap just from trying to fit it around the old noggin. Thing cracked in two and sent pieces flying. I wear eye glasses and always have to purchase ones with hinges on each side that flex out. Yes, my head is that round. So when I'd read that these are a bit roomy, I thought I'd hit the jackpot. I have to say this for these glasses: they are gorgeous. Perfect shade of brown transitioning flawlessly down the lens. Glamorous shape and gorgeous carrying case.However, they were too big. Imagine my shock at finding this out. Years of snapping headbands and not being able to try on cute little horn rimmed glasses and I luck out on a pair of lovely shades that keep falling down my face. Who would have thunk it? So I'm returning, though I really don't want to. If only these were just a wee bit smaller...though that makes me wonder just how huge someone's head has to be in order for these to fit well.

I wanted a cosmetic case and had my eye on this one by Rebecca Minkoff. I'd seen others online, and I liked the cute little sayings on the bag. I have a RM purse and love the quality of the leather it's made from and was not disappointed to find that this pouch also came in a very soft and supply pebble-grained version. It's also really big. You can't tell too much from this photo, but it's much broader than my hand with fingers splayed and almost as tall. Similar in size to a large makeup bag but not as deep. It easily fit all my makeup (including a rather large compact), my travel sized brush, an EOS lipgloss egg, a small B and BW hand sanitizer, a small bottle of Neutrogena hand lotion and still had some room for more items if I'd wished. One thing though, it's a very loud pink. I'm talking fry-your-retinas HOT pink.

I purchased the RM Cupid in Sea Green. The picture shows an almost baby-blue color, but in reality the Sea Green is more of a teal that is slightly darker (and more of a peacock-y) color than the photo. Very popular color these days and adds a nice visual pop to almost every outfit.The item design is exactly as pictured, and the leather is very nice. Unlike some other brands, it's very soft and supple and has a nice equestrian leather type of smell. Some leathers smell chemical-y, but not the Cupid. I had horses when I was young, and the feel in my hands and the scent in my nose brings back memories of cleaning bridles and saddles gone soft with wear and oil. The hardware is nice too. It's a unique color...sort of a very light gold. Perfect in that it can look like it goes with either gold or silver without leaning too far in one direction. Little details like the fringe on the main zipper and the push clips on the side to detach the longer strap really add a nice touch. The strap comes notched on the second hole, and I find that it lays perfectly at a little below my waist. The bag contours nicely to my hip, even with it full of items, and the shoulder strap stays in place...very important feature for me as I have sloped shoulders and hate constantly having to push straps up.There are plenty of pockets both inside and out of the purse, and the interior fabric is a nice black/off-white print. Unlike other purses I've seen, the exterior pockets on both the front and sides are actually of a decent size to place items in. The two smaller pockets on the inside (for cellphone and whatever else) are a little too small for me, but that's because I have one of those big, honkin' Otterbox Defender cases, and to be fair, they don't really fit in any purse's cellphone pocket. The zip pocket on the opposite side inside the bag is big enough to fit my glasses or a large phone. And the interior compartment is very large as well. I was a bit worried at first that the top of the bag wouldn't expand enough in either direction to make removal and insertion of items easy (a problem I'd had with a small Speedy 25 bag), but the opening is, in fact, plenty wide enough. There is more vertical space than I really know what to do with, but the plus size is that my ipad (complete with cover) fit easily. There is only one small drawback to this purse and that is that it can get a bit heavy. I put my ipad, my wallet, my makeup case, and a small card case in this morning, and it was pretty weighed down.

Ever go to the salon for one of those cute bobs (long or short) and leave with the softest, lightest, bounciest hair imaginable? Then you try to recreate it at home and end up with a flat mess. That was me. I've been through countless round brushes...each time with whatever sales associate telling me I needed to get the one with the straight plastic bristles b/c of my thick hair or (when that failed) to get the one with tourmaline or 24 kt. gold and any number of odd suggestions. I thought maybe it was the hair dryer I was using and went through three different models with all sorts of diffusers and attachments. Finally, out of desperation, I turned to shampoos and styling products. A sticky, dry, oily while later, I pretty much gave up and decided to grow it out and channel my inner flower child. Then one day I got a haircut and the stylist had a brush that was just amazing. Gripped my thick hair without any problem but instead of pulling hard on any tangles (I'm tender-headed), it softly brushed through them like sheets sliding against each other...leaving behind a slightly billowy and very voluminous result. She couldn't remember the company that made her brush or even what size it was, but I examined it carefully and then came on Amazon to track it (or its closest relative) down. Enter the Nexxus Volume Effexx. Built just like her brush (for all I know it IS the same as hers), this brush has the longer and more rigid plastic bristles paired with a shorter boar-like one. The result is that it grips even the thickest of hair and then "whips" it up a bit to create lovely volume.I used it for the first time yesterday, and I received so many compliments at work. Everyone was asking me what I did differently or if I got a new haircut. Just one run-through with this brush gave me a beautiful soft curl (yes, a bonafide wavy curl) at my bang area. And the rest of my hair just felt so smooth and light, capturing perfectly that salon-like bounce and feel. Also, the brush is very comfortable to use: light-weight and with a super soft handle that gives you both comfort and traction so as to reduce your grip and relieve hand-pain.Can't say enough about this brush and would recommend to everyone. Oh, and I purchased the jumbo btw.

Why oh why did I not find this brush years ago before I plunked down over 100 dollars on a Mason Pearson brush? Because this little punch of bristled power out-performs the Pearson easily. I was worried about using the Phillips because I have very thick hair and must soft bristled brushes cannot go through all the way to the scalp. However, this one did and easily I might add. Also, I have dry scalp and found that the rounded tips of these bristles don't aggravate my skin or cause flaking. It doesn't produce nearly the same amount of flyaways and static as my plain Goody's brush, and does a really good job at smoothing my hair without flattening it. I thought the size was a little too small, but it actually works out just fine and, as a result of its tiny size, fits into my cosmetic bag rather nicely...which is good b/c I hate keeping a brush in the main body of a purse as it tends to deposit hair at the bottom. Nothing like going in to grab a bit of something and coming out with numerous strands of hair sticking to everything you own.Highly, highly recommended.

I love, love, love Pride and Prejudice. I love the book and especially adore the 1994 BBC miniseries. However, a part of me always wanted to interject a little bit of naughty with all that reserved, Edwardian nice. Enter Mr. Darcy's refuge. A nice little bit of fluff that has our two leads doing a bit more than sharing a brief kiss in a carriage, this story helped fill in some gaps previously attempted only by my imagination. However, it's not a five-star endeavor. For one thing, it's a bit too Barbara Cartland for my tastes. I mean, I want a more visceral response and a lot more passion, but I could have done without that 1960's type of romance novel drivel. Like Darcy musing on several occasions that Elizabeth was now his, his, his... Or when he starts fantasizing about her eyes and the passion he knows is in her as he is trying to rescue a child trapped under a fallen tree branch. I'm sorry, but I just don't see that really fitting in with Darcy's personality. Wool-gathering while saving a little boy and dealing with all manner of disaster? I think not.Still, I don't regret buying it. So three stars it gets. I did think it was o.k. Not really like, not love, but it was well enough to keep me occupied (and with a couple of smiles on my face) for an evening.

Beautiful purse. The color is gorgeous: I purchased it in buff. It's the perfect neutral. Leather is soft and has a nice smell. However, the style of it (with the grips being so close to the body of the purse) doesn't allow for much in way of storage. Basically, the upper half section has to remain free of items for it to lie comfortably against your body if you carry it on your shoulder b/c your arm has no choice but to rest on the body of the bag as the straps are so short. And it's pretty heavy. I loaded up two small cosmetic purses, a bi-fold wallet, a small bottle of hand cream, and my kindle; and the purse was already uncomfortable on my shoulder and heavy in my hands when used as a satchel. I think the style of this purse is fantastic and it really adds elegance to any outfit, but it's not really good for actually hauling things around...more an exclusive accessorizing piece than a handbag. Maybe you could tote a few odds and ends, but you don't want to fill it up too much (even if you have the strength of Hercules) b/c the body is not so wide, so putting in a lot of items would cause the sides to bulge and make it lose that sleek/streamlined appeal as the top puckered and gaped.Oh, and I would have at least given it 4 stars, but I was disappointed with craftmanship. There was beige paint smeared on both gold knobs at the top of the purse. One was pretty much halfway covered. Am returning it and will continue my search for something fashionable AND functional.

Nice enough wallet. Really nice leather. Hardware is a bit oversized and larger than appears on the website. For example, the zippers are HUGE. The studs are the size of large pearls. The small front pocket does unzip but seems more decorative as the space inside is pretty small. Be warned that despite its luxurious leather and gold rivets, this wallet is very low key. The leather is super supple and floppy. Almost cloth-like. That's what really drove me crazy about this wallet. I didn't like the idea of not being able to open the change department without grabbing some material to keep the zipper from just pulling the material over on itself.  Oh, and the zipper doesn't go all the way around all corners. It stops short at the very last lower right hand corner...not by much but enough that the wallet doesn't lie completely flat when unzipped. The style comes off very laid back and casual. It's a Birkenstock sort of wallet, if that makes sense, and just not what I want. I returned it this afternoon.

I'm so glad to have rediscovered Teresa Medeiros. I'd pretty much given up on the author after I'd read a few of her books that just didn't interest me. Nobody's Darling was my shot in the dark, and it hit the bulls-eye. Reminiscent of the leads in Heather and Velvet, Billy and Esme share a somewhat tempestuous relationship, but there's enough humor and unambiguous love/desire on both of their part that make you eager to turn the page and see where their stubbornness and passion lead them.The prim music teacher who drips civility and Eastern breeding yet yearns for passion. The outlaw who has played the cards his family and lifestyle have dealt him but aches for tenderness and respectability. A misunderstanding brought them together (Esme thought Billy had murdered her brother in cold blood and then hired Billy to track Bart down once she realized her brother was alive), but there was no misunderstanding their attraction for each other...and me for their journey towards love. I tell you, Billy Darling just about makes up my ideal man. If it wasn't for those dissolute brothers of his that is... He is strong, direct, warm, passionate, and he will do just about anything to keep a woman from crying. I loved their story so much that I actually choked up a bit when it ended, in spite of the expected "happily ever after" note. Because by the time I got to the epilogue and read about Esme and Billy's great, great granddaughter, I couldn't help but mirror her wistful musings of what it must have felt to be on the receiving end of Billy's love.My Darling indeed.

Fancy Pants is a bit dated (surprised they didn't harp on shoulder pads), but that's not what turned me off. After all, I can still read Sheldon's Master of the Game and appreciate plot elements without getting bogged down in the 80's culture. However, what really made this book a wall thrower was that the hero was a downright nasty jerk and the heroine was some sort of ninny ruled by her genitals and zero brains yet mysteriously still ends up a millionaire in some sort of pre-Paris Hilton radio act.Since almost the first minute we're let into Francie's internal thought processes, I became disgusted at her shallow perceptions and her bimbo-like naiveté. And the so-called hero? Ugh! When he wasn't feeling sorry for himself, he was treating others like complete crap. I have no idea how these two formed some sort of emotional attachment to each other. It was hinted at in the book, yet I certainly didn't feel it. She seemed to look at him as a meal ticket and he at her like she was a lost kitten and sex toy rolled into one.But what really infuriated me about the novel was what happened after Dallie finds out about Teddy. The man was a cretin. An utter barbarian who lashed out with anger to his own kid, made him afraid of him, and let known his disgust at the boy's lack of athletic skills. It didn't matter that Teddy had a gifted mind and a compassionate heart (both of which he sneered at and chalked up to being a "sissy"). No, he was a failure as a son b/c he couldn't throw a football around. I mean, for goodness sake, he actually scoffed at and belittled the kid's food allergies. Oh yes, let me emotionally bully my kid into eating food HE'S ALLERGIC TO so he can possibly DIE but I'll feel better b/c he'll be acting like a real man should. Bah! And after all this...after sensing that something horrible happened to her son at the hands of this man...Francie still manages to lust after Dallie and wind up in his bed within a day or so of getting her son back. Sorry, but if someone kidnapped my child and treated them in such a foul manner, I'd be hard pressed to be civil to them, much less sleep with them or (horror of all horrors) decide to enter a relationship with them and just make my child deal with the fact that this guy will be a part of our lives now. I realize that Dallie has rights with regards to Teddy, and I don't approve of Francie keeping the kid a secret, but the words "supervised visitation" should have been the first words on her lips after her son was returned to her. Jeez, the first night she sees Teddy, there's a huge scene with Teddy flailing away at Dallie's leg and screaming that he hates him. Her son is in immense distress and yet she stands there and does nothing. Nothing! And not 30 minutes later she's chattering away at how lovely the paintings are in Dallie's cabin. I swear this woman is unfit!So, to chalk things up: If you like a heroine whose only quality is that she's pretty and has an accent, if you enjoy heroes who wallow in self-pity and bully small children (and slap grieving women)...then Fancy Pants is your dream come true.

I am surprised at the low number of reviews for this book and hope that more people are inspired to read it, as it is one of my favorites. I simply love Prudence and Sebastian. Two characters who seem to have been made for each other. The story begins pretty much in full action, with Prudence surprising (and foiling) a robbery attempt by Sebastian in his guise as a notorious highwayman...by screaming his true Christian name, which happens to be the name of her beloved kitty cat. Sounds corny, but it works. From then on it's witty banter and clever flirtation as Sebastian falls head over heels for Prudence but has to keep away as he is determined to marry for money and the poor girl has none.I love a heroine who stands on her own feet. Passion is well and nice, but it shouldn't eliminate every single brain cell a person has in their body. The fact that Prudence still retained some of her wits even as Sebastian used all of his substantial charm on her was noteworthy. I especially enjoyed her zingers regarding the origins of his name and the condition of his poor pistol. Add to that a charming cast of characters including Prudence's over-sexed aunt (who takes pride in what she mistakenly thinks is Prudence's fall from grace and then "rewards her" with a lecture in the art of everything sexual), a sly fox of a man whose own mother mutters prayers and hides the silverware when he's around, and a charming ball of fur who always seems to be in the right place at the right time.Oh, there are faults to be sure. Our hero has a few un-heroic thoughts now and then (not the good, sensual types either). And there are too many red herrings and unimagined conflicts which exasperate the reader (secret formulas, secret heritages, the occasional fainting trollops, a Robin Hood reference or two, and endless misunderstandings and bungling by both H/h etc...). Plus, Mederios has this grating habit of not keeping facts and continuity in check. I've noticed it in the other reviews where readers have brought up plot elements that were simply dropped or contradictory. I didn't notice huge mistakes really...I just became annoyed that a bit of information hinted at with regards to Arlo and Prudence was never brought to light, especially as it directly involved Sebastian and his opinion of her. Plus, there is the fact it takes one character years to understand a huge "mystery" without any additional evidence and nothing to indicate to the reader how he came upon this epiphany.Also, Mederios can be a bit hard on her heroes. I'm not sure if all of them are like this, but I've noticed that in a good deal of her books, the hero gets treated a bit harshly from time to time. Sebastian might put Prudence through the ringer, but he comes out of their encounters a bloody and bruised himself and almost shot a time or two.Despite its flaws, I had to give it five stars.
