Any novel that I have to read in a single sitting, pausing only to adjust seating position and grab something that I can eat while continuing to eat, is a five star novel in my book. I only wish I could recommend Mederios as a writer. While I loved Heather and Velvet, I've tried and rejected all of the other books in her stable. It seems, so far, that this is the only one that really appealed to me with its careful blend of humor and character appeal.

I loved, loved, loved Bewitching, and I felt so sorry for the Earl of Downe. I couldn't wait to read where he would find love and healing for whatever horrible thing was casting a shadow over his life. I pretty much knew he was going to be paired with Leticia Hornsby, and I was fine with that. The few glimpses we caught of her in Bewitching had me curious, and the comic relief brought about by the gentle ribbing Downe received for her antics were endearing. I wish I could say these feelings stayed with me as I read their story.To be blunt: Letty was one of the most annoying heroines I've ever come across. The klutziness I could handle; it was even funny at times, though it did get old after a while. But did Barnett have to make her so stupid? In one scenario, they've just been kidnapped by smugglers and thrown into the hold of a ship...all after Letty startled Downe's horse and pretty much caused him to cosh his head and knock him out cold. Within minutes, she's proclaiming her love, closing her eyes and dancing to invisible music (in the hold of this nasty ship with gun-wielding villains on the other side of the door), and trying desperately to get Downe to close his eyes and daydream too. And he finds this bedlam-like behavior endearing? He must have jostled his brain a bit in the fall. And it gets worse. She shoots him. Shoots him! This after she endangers their lives with her big mouth and small brain...and he brushes it off as yet another hair-brained Letty thing. Bullet holes being like mosquito bites, I suppose...with only a resigned sigh to show that he even acknowledged being shot by her. Ugh! I don't know who I was more disgusted with: idiot man or idiot woman. I finally knew this book was unredeemable when I realized that I was cheering Richard on whenever he was cruel to Letty and getting upset when he rambled on about how guilty it made him feel. Honestly, the dog was probably the most likeable (and intelligent) character in this novel.Throw in one of the most disappointing reveals I've come across (Lindsey's The Pursuit coming in a close second) with regards to what is eating Downe up alive so badly that he's killing himself with self-loathing and alcohol (it's so lame a reason that you'll be shaking your head in disbelief), and the finishing touches are put into place for this train wreck of a story.

I absolutely love the Bridgerton family that Julia Quinn has created. They're so full of life and love. Readers had been told in other novels that Francesca was from a different cut of cloth than her brothers and sisters, but I hadn't expected her to be quite so...so bland...and for the love of me, I couldn't figure out why Michael was head over heels in love with her. I'd much rather have explored a possible attachment to Eloise (though I did love reading To Sir Phillip, with Love).The premise of Francesca's widowhood (without taking the easy way out and making her marriage to John loveless) was a bold undertaking, and I think Quinn handled most of that aspect well, in terms of the delicacy of such matters. The only part I found distasteful was Francesca's behavior after her miscarriage and her need to lash out at the one person who loved her and her late husband and had been good friends to both. I suppose it can all be chalked up to the horrible weight of grief, but it seemed like a betrayal all the same. The rest of the book was just a snooze-fest. Francesca doesn't have any personality. Even the other Bridgertons were more sedate in this novel than their usual boisterous selves. It's as if there were a pall thrown on everything and everyone. The novel even hosts its conclusion in the rain at a cemetery. A nice little nod to the overall feel of this book, if I do say so myself, as it was a grave error to have read this little piece of unbuttered toast. Quinn should have just let Francesca's story be untold, paired Michael with another Bridgerton sister, or kept this as a very, very short story in one of those seasonal anthologies.If you fell in love with the fire and passions that were present in the other novels, then I suggest you not open the covers of this one. It would be like dousing those flames with a bucket of lukewarm water. Boring Frannie. Boring (though admittedly very sensual) Michael, forever mooning over this little milksop of a woman. I kept waiting for some little firebrand to come along and really throw some passion his way. If it wasn't for some very fine, verbal foreplay, I'd have given this just a single star.

I think this is one of the most sexual/sensual/hottest novels JD has put into print. The layout isn't perfect. The ending was a bit rushed...with Amanda displaying a chameleon-like turnabout and Hank making declarations that weren't really explored in the previous chapters. Still, there was plenty of humor, and the steamy interludes were worth a rushed ending or two.Amanda Caulden's father owns a large ranch which employs a number of field laborers. Apparently, there is discontent about the way he treats and pays them. Enter Hank Montgomery, an economics professor that happens to despise civil injustices and is determined to establish a union. Seeking to sway Montgomery to his side, Caulden pushes Amanda towards Hank as both a distraction and to keep tabs on Hank's activites. Amanda's life is tightly controlled by her domineering father and tutor/fiancé, and she resents this disruption of her daily routine. As for Hank, after he practically falls for Amanda at first sight, he sets out to wake up his sleeping beauty and show her the truth about world around her...including what goes on between a man and a woman.I loved Amanda's confusion in this. I loved that she struggled and didn't give in quite as fast as JD's other heroines do. I find that Deveraux's women are ruled a little too heavily by their passions and sometimes find myself flabbergasted that they would so quickly forgive things that would have me slamming doors and spitting nails. Amanda even managed to get a few digs in as she pointed out Hank's hypocrisy in a few places. He's not a perfect hero. At times he's un-chivalrous and as domineering as those he's trying to "rescue" Amanda from, and despite his intense physical attraction to Amanda, the reader is often left wondering what he truly feels for her. However, their chemistry is undeniable, and their pig-headedness definitely creates some interesting situations. If it wasn't for that rushed ending, I'd have given this five stars. However, I just can't get over (without spoiling anything for you) how things can go from A-Z in three chapters or less. Would I recommend though? Absolutely. Trust me, you'll never look at a broom closet the same way again.

I decided to use this vegetable steamer because I love roasting vegetables like squash, zucchini, etc but I have never tried to steam them. Well, I'm so glad I tried this one out! This made squash so delish!! This steamer is great quality and seems to be very durable.It expands pretty big to fit all different size pots and pans that you may have.  Also, it is dish washer safe so yay for easy clean up! With this bundle I also got a vegetable peeler and a E-Book with alot of recipes! Overall, I've very happy and impressed with this steamer. I am now a fan of steamed veggies. And I high recommend this steamer bundle!Disclosure: I received this product at a discount  in exchange for an honest review.

I recently just graduated nursing school and realized that I had completely ruined my teeth by drinking so much coffee. I used to have such awesome white teeth but all the coffee stained them. Also, I like how they come in separate packages so that if I would like to use them while I go to work I can. Overall, these are great. I have always wanted to try out mesh bags for my laundry but never got the chance to. When I got the opportunity to try out these bags I couldn't pass them up. Wow! I tried Cellucor C4 Pre-Workout because I felt like I needed something to give me a "boost" while working out. Well, this was it! I take this about 30 minutes before my workout. I decided to try out these Anti-Nausea Motion Sickness Relief Wristbands because I suffer alot with nausea. Usually I will use my prescribed medications but, I hate how groggy they make me. So, I did as the instructions say which is to apply them 30 minutes to 1 hour before your car ride. This has been a great product for me thus far.  I have been using it for several days now mainly for hydration and moisturizing.  The smell and texture of the product is very nice.  I was amazed to find it to be a very light…almost fluffy cream that isn't oily at all. The other promises of stretch mark & scar defense are added bonuses but I was happy for the results it has on my dry areas alone.  I've tried other Aloe products in the past but they have always been infused with other products that seem to create a greasy gloss on my skin.  This one, however, has not done that for me.My wife and I have both been sharing this jar and she has been pretty pleased with it as well.  She too has commented on the moisturizing effectiveness of this product.  She also likes that it doesn't have a strong oder.  For me, the product has done quite well over the past several days with helping me control my dry/flakey skin in the morning without the oily effects of other products that I have tried.

I love tea and coffee.  The debate continues on the pros and cons of drinking tea and coffee but I was excited to try this product because it is formulated specifically for healthy purposes.  According to the label on the bag, this detox tea has been custom created to "increase the quality of your sleep, remove the unwanted toxins inside your body, and increase your energy level".  Well, I think most of us would like something that can do that.  I especially like the idea of "removing unwanted toxins"!  The product is also caffeine free, which is great because I probably get a little too much of that with my regular tea/coffee intake.The package arrived in great condition and the bag that the tea is contained in is designed, obviously, to keep the freshness in.  It kind of reminds me of those bags that coffee comes in at the store.  Upon opening it, the smell of the tea was very pleasant but the look of the contents reminded me of some of my yard work after using a chipper.  There are several photos provided by other reviewers that show the bag…the contents of the bag, multiple angles of the bag, and the product actually in water.  I think these numerous photos do the product plenty of justice that will allow you to understand what your getting here.  Looking closely at the contents, you can actually see the ingredients of herds, fruits, and berries used to create the mixture.  I like this as opposed to grinding it all up into some sort of fine "mystery powder".  At least I can see the actual ingredients being used here.  After seeing the one photo of someone dumping it into a cup loosely, however, I decided that I didn't want to strain the product through my teeth as it floats all around in the cup and opted to go find a tea ball instead.Following the directions, I put one tablespoon in a cup of hot tea and let it seep for a few minutes.  The taste was pleasant and I was pleased with the aroma.  I was worried that this stuff would have some weird taste/smell to it because I've tried other teas in the past and just did not like it at all.  Letting it seep longer and adjusting the amount of water will certainly affect the taste so you can certainly experiment.I've tried the product for a few days now and although I can't immediately say that I feel "detoxed", I can say that I have felt a bit more energetic during the day when I've had a cup in the morning.  What I really like about this particular product is it's pleasant taste and aroma.  I also like the fact that I can see the ingredients and that they didn't grind everything up into a fine powder.  Using a tea ball helps reduce the amount of floating material in your cup and the healthy properties of the ingredients do look promising.  Used on a regular bases and with proper diet/exercise, I would recommend trying this product to see if it works for you.I was provided a free sample of this product to try for an honest review.

Well, the Christmas holiday is fast approaching and my family was recently complaining that my "music for the season" was seriously lacking.  To be honest, my holiday music has primarily consisted of the Windham Hill Christmas compilations with mostly instrumental tunes and I think everyone is getting a little tired of those.  So, I decided to go about and start getting some of those holiday classics that my family is asking for.  It's quite challenging actually when you are looking for this type of music because there are so many choices/collections to choose from.  In an effort to find the most wanted songs without having to purchase several different albums, I decided to start with this one first.  I actually had my family write down the Christmas songs that they like the best and luckily this one has all of those and a few extra.  I also decided to pick up a 20th Century Masters Bing Crosby holiday CD as well to really round out the festive music for this year.  Luckily, these albums are offered at a real great price here on Amazon.  Most can be found for $5 or less.  You can see from the product's description that this particular album contains some very familiar tunes and the ability to sample them here, at least for this CD, was great too.  I've noticed that you have to be careful when shopping for holiday music because some of these collections do not contain the original versions or the artist that we are familiar with singing them.  This one sounds great to me and I am excited to begin constructing my new Christmas playlist this year and keep the family happy through the holidays!  It may not contain all of the songs that you may be looking for, but it sure can help to get you started like me!  The recordings sound great and it's offered at a fair price too!  I recommend.

This is a score that I've been waiting to get a CD copy of since the movie was released.  It jumps around in price and it sat in my wish list until it dropped reasonably enough for me.  The album cover looks different from what they are currently showing on Amazon but I actually like the CD cover better which has the silver Terminator skull (with red eye) against a black background.  Call me crazy in this digital age but I still prefer to purchase my music on CD.This is my third score by Lorne Balfe.  I've previously enjoyed his work on "Blackwood" and "Sons of Liberty".  Balfe is part Hans Zimmer's score production company known as Remote Control Productions.  It is home to quite a few composers who are mentored by Zimmer and he often collaborates with many on various projects.  After hearing the past few Terminator scores and not really finding them that interesting, I had high hopes that this one by Balfe would finally bring the scores back from the past and into this future.  I am happy to say that this one certainly does just that.  Lorne Balfe successfully pays tribute to Fiedel while also developing his own themes and style to the score.  Fiedel's epic themes can be heard in a few cues like "Better Days" (track 2), "It's Really Me" (track 12), and most prominently in "Terminated" (track 22).  Balfe's interpretation of the theme in the last track is really outstanding and it's something that fans have been waiting for.Balfe has created his own original score but you can hear hints of the classic Terminator sound throughout the music.  The composer achieves this through his use of similar keyboard effects, percussion, strings, and heavy brass instrumentation that he spins & weaves into a sound that becomes distinctively familiar to fans of the iconic music from the early films.  To Balfe's credit, he does not merely give us only a repeat of that which has already been done, but he also develops new themes and electronic "riffs" of his own that are quite enjoyable.  I really liked the thematic music in track 11, "John Conner" and I also enjoyed the new and unusual electronic sounds found in "Family" (track 17).  There are few cues that give Balfe a chance to slow things down a bit like "Sarah & Kyle" (track 5) and "Alcove" (track 13) but this is largely an action heavy score.  Like Fiedel's previous scores, however, I found this one to be full of interesting effects, sounds, rhythms, and ambience that makes for an entertaining listen.  I like scores that allow you to mentally picture a scene and I would say that this one does just that.  Listening to pieces like "Sacrifice" (19) does this quite well.  The big swooping crescendos as one character saves another and the almost angelic sounding strings praising the heroic deed can certainly give you the mental images found within the music.I had to wait a long time to finally get a copy of this but it certainly was worth the wait.  The CD contains 22 tracks and runs around 1 hour and 12 minutes.  There is a 12 page CD insert that contains track listings, production credits, orchestra credits, and a special thanks section from Balfe, Zimmer, and Paramount Pictures.  There are plenty of photos from the movie as well.  Some are two page spreads, full pages, and several smaller photos.  This a great score from Balfe and I appreciate the nod to Fiedel's music, as well as, the excellent original music too.  I recommend!

I was given the opportunity to look over this bracelet offered by Mondaynoon and I must say that my wife really liked this one.  There are quite a few photos provided by other reviewers and I think they do it justice.  The only thing that the photos don't really capture is the sparkle that the crystal and bracelet itself has.  My wife really liked it and found that the combination of "rope like" and metallic band gave the bracelet and very unique appearance.  It looked great on her and will also be very complimentarily on several outfits she has.  My wife is really very picky about jewelry and I don't think she would of ever purchased something like this herself but after trying it on (and playing in front of the mirror with it), she has now found something "pretty" that she ordinarily would of never considered.I am more into the craftsmanship of things so I really gave this a close inspection.  The large crystal stone is set into place well and I don't see any crooked or "higher on one side" problems.  The surrounding "diamond like" crystals that surround the edges of the larger stone are all in place and really give this bracelet it's sparkle when it catches the light.  The "rope" portion of the band is secure and snug.  It loops over the hook quite well and I even had my wife try to shake it off to see if it would stay on.  She is the expert on wearing jewelry and after several attempts trying to get it to "fall off", she seemed pretty confident that it would stay on.  I'm not saying that it will remain faithfully secure to your wrist under all circumstances however!  The silver portion of the band is polished quite nicely and it too does a great job of catching light.  For the price and quality, I think this is a pretty good deal.  I like the way it catches light and the unique (at least to me) design.  I never thought my wife would of liked this one but she does.I received this as a free product from Mondaynoon for an honest review.  It's actually quite nice and I recommend checking out the many photos posted by other reviewers.

I was given the chance to sample two rings from MNH and this one is definitely my favorite. One of the things that I like the most about this particular ring is the really cool 3D looking black decorative band that circles the outside of the ring.  The photos can't really capture the effect it has but it's really neat.  The design reminds me of looking closely at the threads of a rope.  It looks really nice.  This is my first experience with Tungsten Carbide rings and I was surprised at how solid these were.  They certainly don't feel cheap to me and I like the weight of them.  They are not heavy and do feel comfortable to wear.  It's thicker than my previous band and that will take some getting use to.  I was excited to try these out because my current band has been through a lot of abuse over the years.  It's been bent, scratched, and it's very dinged up!  It has fallen off my finger several times as well because of wear and tear.  When putting this side by side with my previous one...this one looks more much more solid and attractive with it's modern look.  It can never replace the memories of the first band however so I am glad that I've found something that will enable me to "retire" the old ring before it gets completely destroyed or lost.I am not one who likes to spend a lot of money on jewelry for myself.  My wife has offered to replace my current ring with other expensive ones but I just wasn't interested in doing that.  I think that this is a very attractive, solid, and reasonably priced ring.  I recommend!MNH offered to send this as a free product for an honest review.

This is a really nice ring.  The first thing I noticed was the weight of it.  It feels pretty solid but not too heavy.  My wedding ring is bent up, scratched up, and doesn't look so great when you compare it next to this.  Now, I'm not one that goes out seeking expensive jewelry for myself and I'd much rather spend the money on other things.  My wife offered to buy me a more pricey ring to replace my current one but I was never really interested in spending that kind of money on one.  I much rather spend the money on the "upgrades" that she wants.  Something like this looks really nice, feels really solid, and looks like it can take a beating with the work that I do.  I really like the "rose" color on the inside too.  The ring arrived just like the one pictured and I think the photos provided by the other reviewers do it justice.  They've pretty much captured every angle and close up to give you a good look at it.I was pretty impressed by this ring and I think if your looking for something to replace (or retire) you current ring without breaking the bank...then this sure is an attractive and affordable alternative.  It doesn't look cheap, slides right on finger smoothly, is very solid, doesn't feel too heavy, and is priced nicely.I was provided this ring to sample for an honest review.

MarlJohns offered the opportunity to sample one of their products and this 22oz shaker bottle is actually pretty good.  For the price, your getting a bottle that has quite a few uses to it.  Use it as a standard water/juice bottle, shaker for protein, and it includes two detachable storage attachments for either protein, snacks, and vitamins.  The two detachable storage attachments come in two different sizes that provides multiple uses to fit your needs.  They are attached by twisting them onto the bottom of the bottle.  You can easily attach one to the bottle and still take the other with you in your gym bag because they provide you with a lid that is interchangeable between the two.The bottle itself is plenty tough because I accidentally "tested" it by dropping it on the garage floor.  It didn't break/crack so I was glad to see that.  The bottle looks solid black but if you hold it up to the light, it is actually transparent enough so you can see the liquid inside.  One side of the bottle has a measurement gauge on it and having it to be semi-transparent is helpful when putting your mix in.  I also gave it the shake test and tested for leaks.  Everything worked perfectly and I detected no leaks from the cap or lid.  The orange mouth lid gave me some concerns at first because when I went to shut it, it seemed to pop off too easy.  Upon closer inspection, I noticed that this was my fault because I wasn't actually snapping it all the way down.  When you go to shut this particular lid (the orange mouthpiece lid), make sure you push down on it until it snaps shut.  I also recommend not trying to twist the bottle lid too tight.  The bottle and threads are all plastic and doing this could wear down the actual threads themselves.  Twist it tight...but don't go crazy on it!  I also like the fact that the mouth of the bottle is a large size which helps when your drinking your own concoctions of mixed health drinks.  The shaker ball does a good job of mixing the powder up but understand that this isn't an electric blender here.For the price, build, quality, and features of this particular bottle...I would honestly say that this a pretty good deal.  The bottle has multiple uses and the added storage attachments give it even more added benefits.  I recommend.

I was offered the opportunity to take a look at one of Mondaynoon's products and my wife choose this particular set.  She really liked the design and color of these items (necklace, earrings, and bracelet).  I also like that Mondaynoon offers this as a set and for the quality/build of the pieces, I think that it is fairly reasonably priced.  They arrived in a black velvet bag with each piece individually wrapped.  The necklace even had an extra piece of plastic wrapping to protect the stone.  All of the pieces were in excellent condition and after inspecting each one very carefully, I am satisfied with the look, feel, and quality for the asking price.  I looked for kinks in the chains, imperfections in the stones, sturdiness of the clasp, and other dents/dings etc.  I couldn't find anything wrong with these.  My wife is pretty picky about jewelry and refuses to wear anything she considers cheap looking.  When this arrived, I basically handed her the package and watched for her reactions.  She was pretty pleased with these...so that is saying a lot!One key feature that my wife and I love about these particular pieces is how the crystals really catch and sparkle in the light.  She loves the gold stone color (which to me, looks like a very light greenish gold color) and wearing this as a set really compliments a particular outfit of hers.  Having three individual pieces to mix and match with other pieces of jewelry of hers is a definite plus too.  She really likes the set and for the price, look, and quality of these, I'd say that they are a pretty good deal.I received this product free or at a discount for honest review.

I was recently offered the opportunity to choose a dress from the Azbro collection sold here on Amazon at a discount for a review.  Out of the list of choices, my wife selected this particular one because of it's uniqueness.  The sleeves and style of the dress are very unusual and eye catching.  It kind of reminds me of something you might see a movie star walking the red carpet with.  The dress arrived in great condition and was packaged well.  It's made out of 100% polyester...so don't go expecting silk here.  The seams and stitching are all nicely done.  We felt like the material and build of the dress was nicely done for the asking price and we really liked that this particular outfit came with a necklace to really give it a very dramatic effect.  The necklace is metallic and really makes the dress stand out for sure.  Wearing something like this will certainly catch people's attention because it is so different.  I personally think my wife looks great in it.  We ordered a small size and my wife is 5'1" and weights 110.  It fit her perfectly.  It wasn't too small, short, or tight.  It has a classic and modern look to it but will probably only work for very special events.  For those who like to turn some heads...I'd recommend this very unique and cool looking dress to you!I received this product at a discount for an honest review.

What kind of score do you give a character who is stuck on Mars...alone, and little chance of survival?  This one.  I read that some say that it rips off Zimmer's "Interstellar" score while others complain about it sounding typically "spacey".  Well, the film does take place on a distant world and I certainly wouldn't want it to sound like a Saturday morning cartoon.  That's kind of like saying that a western score sounds typically "western".  Granted, there are those avant garde scores out there that might take a period piece with vikings battling it out to heavy metal guitars and techno beats, but generally soundtracks tend to musically capture the atmosphere in which they are set.  I personally think that this one by Harry Gregson-Williams is spot on with this particular survival story set on the planet Mars.I haven't seen the movie yet, and to be honest with you, I rarely see the movies before I hear the score.  This is not by choice, because I would love to rush out and see these films first, but it just happens that I usually end up getting the scores for films before I actually see them.  I have found that this has sometimes given me a unique perspective of the story before I actually go to see the visuals on the screen however.  I've seen the movie trailers and I have a pretty good idea about the storyline, but if the score is good...it can tell the story just as well.  This score does just that.  It certainly isn't an action score and you won't find music that has a heroic character fighting off hordes of green little men.  The music is more reflective and lonely.  It's also has a beauty hidden underneath that occasionally appears in tracks like "Crossing Mars" (track 11).  This particular piece has a slight hint of a futuristic pioneer crossing a vast empty desert.  A keyboard producing a echoey guitar like sound starts the piece backed with electronic wind like ambience.  A french horn begins to build the orchestra gradually into a mighty landscape sound as I imagine the camera pulls back to show the grand scope of the red planet.  This is what I like.  Music that produces visual images and tell a story on their own.  The entire score is pretty reflective of what the character must be going through.  It's very easy to listen to and I've had it on repeat all day at work.  It isn't bombastic and mostly very soothing.  It's great thinking music for sure!I suppose what gives it a "spacey" sound is the composer's use of electronically produced music.  He uses some very old 80's sounds in a few of the cues.  Some of the sounds reminded me of early Patrick O'Hearn music (who's music I also love) and Jack Wall's "Mass Effect" score.  Tracks 3 and 5 really have that "Mass Effect" vibe to them.  I really liked track 7, "Sprouting Potatoes", with it's combination of cello, strings, and really fluid electronic sounds.  "Hexadecimals", track 10, has a classic early keyboard/syth sound to it.  I think the composer's choice to bring some of these sounds back is what might have people comparing this score so much with "Interstellar".  Zimmer's score used an even older keyboard, the organ, and gave us a very entertaining and interesting "space" epic that is truly fascinating to listen to.  That score, in my opinion, was very sharp, intense, and dynamic.  I know it had some "floaty" space music too, but the organ definitely had the spotlight and really gave the sense of the grandness, immensity, and mystery of space.  Harry Gregson-Williams uses electronic sounds with a more softer and subtle approach to capture a story of one man's attempt to survive on a distant planet.  At times, the score has such a lonely and sad sound...almost as if someone wants to give up. Tracks like "Crops are Dead" (track 13) have choral voices lamenting a requiem like depression.  It would be an awful movie if we just watched the main character give up however, and track 14, "Work the Problem" has a more upbeat tech thump to it as the protagonist works to push through the obstacles and survive.  I think this is a fine score by Harry Gregson-Williams and it does a great job of telling the story through music.  It has a "space" sound to it and I don't think it's fair to say that it rips off Hans Zimmer.  This score is very easy to listen to and is most certainly enjoyable outside of the film itself.This particular "Amazon Exclusive" release is really nice because you are getting two discs for a really good price.  The first disc contains the songs from the film, which can be bought by itself if your not interested in the score, and the second disc appears to be the only place to get the musical score on CD.  I prefer to own my music on CD and transfer it digitally myself.  I see all the complaints from those who bought the digital versions and complain about the sound quality.  Well...not an issue here.  Nothing beats a good ole fashion CD in my opinion!  These "Deluxe Edition" soundtracks must have been made popular by the success of "The Guardians of the Galaxy" release.  The songs on disc one are pretty good and have some classic tunes from Vickie Sue Robinson (Turn the Beat Around) to Gloria Gaynor (I Will Survive).  Disc one does contain "The Martian Score Suite" which captures some of the highlights from the entire score itself.  There is an 8 page CD insert that contains track listings, production credits, a few landscape shots of Mars, and a back cover photo of Matt Damon in a scene from the the movie.  There are two pages dedicated to "notes from the composer" where Harry Gregson-Williams explains his inspiration for the music of the film was largely based on the poem "On the Nature of Things" by Lucretius.  The composer takes select tracks from the score and supports them with lines from the poem and in a sense uses these words for the foundation of his music.  I guess where I listen to the music and see the story, the composer is reading the words of this poem...and hears the music. I've found this to be really enjoyable soundtrack and nicely priced for a CD version that contains 2 discs of music from the film.  I recommend!

Guys get pimples too you know.  Now personally, the case that these tools come in doesn't really work for me but thats alright.  It's what on the inside that counts!  The pictures that the other reviewers have posted do the product justice.  You're getting some pretty well made instruments here that are designed to help you clean/clear out one of life's annoyances...blackheads and pimples.  I will tell you that these are not not little magic wands that you can wave over your face and look as perfect as the girl on the box however.  If, like me, you've never used something like this before...do your research first!  The whole point of these things is to safely clear out your pores without scaring or scratching your skin.  We've all done it before right?  Squeeze a pimple/blackhead so hard that your fingernails dig into your skin and cause a scar?  Well, these tools are designed to help prevent that from happening.Even before this kit arrived, I began looking into how they are actually used.  There are several videos and websites with illustrations that can show you precisely what to do.  The improper use of these things can do just as much or even more scaring to your skin if your not careful.  After studying up on these instruments and learning how to use them properly, I was "lucky" enough to have a pimple on my shoulder to test my new found knowledge out on.  Using one of the tools to to encircle the pimple with, I gently rocked it back and forth and presto...cleaned it right out.  You should also note that cleaning your skin before and after can really help with this process as well.  As with any tool, I recommend cleaning them after each use too.The tools themselves seem to be well made.  The box claims that they are 100% hygienic, rust-free, corrosion and stain resistant.  They seem to pretty decent to me.  The case holds them all fairly well but I think I'll just keep them in my shaving kit.  My only concern with this kit is the lack of information about the individual tools themselves and what they are specifically used for.  A small insert that contains information/descriptions of these or maybe links to specific websites that could educate those who are using a product like this for the first time would be beneficial.  It is also important to note that these tools will not work for all acne problems.  As we all know, some pimples are just too monstrous and evil!  For what they are and if used properly, I think these are nice little devices to add to arsenal in the war against acne.  Just make sure you go to battle with a plan...do your research!I received this product at a discount or as a free sample for an honest review.

Ever wonder how many steps you take during one day?  After those long days at work, my wife and I have gone into those long debates on "who's job is harder" and the ever so popular "I bet I am on my feet longer than you".  When presented with the opportunity to try out this particular product, I couldn't help but to think that this little device would finally settle the argument!The SMARTFLY arrived well packaged and included a belt clip, lanyard, instructions, and an extra battery.  The extra battery was a nice little bonus that I wasn't expecting to find in the package.  It's one of those CR2032 batteries, which are easy enough to find in the big box stores, but it was still nice that an extra one was included.  The device itself is very lightweight and when you slide it into the belt clip, you can't even tell your wearing it.  I also liked that it tells the time as well.  I one of those last few people on Earth who actually wear a wrist watch and I don't have my phone permanently attached to my body.  My watch died, so over the past few days, this thing has been my source for time.  Setting the device up, however, left some questions.  Following the instructions, I correctly set the time, weight, and target steps.  I was also able to set the device so that it reads in inches and the stride calculations.  There are two screens, however, that I cannot for the life of me figure out what they are for and/or what they are requesting me to input.  The instructions are not very "step by step" clear in this regard.  I searched on line for additional setup instructions and I found a very similar device, Ozeri 4x3 sport, but finding the instructions for that model (which looks exactly like this one) proved to be and endless quest as well.  Oh well, I seem to have the time, weight, preferred measurement reading, and stride set in so now it's time to see if this thing will correctly measure my steps.Walking around the house, I would go for about 30 steps and check to see how well the device was doing.  It was accurate within 1 to 2 steps.  I did this several times with various amounts of steps and it remained consistent throughout the test.  I reset everything and put it on for work the next day.  Throughout the day at work, I would randomly check the device, take 10-30 steps and check for accuracy again.  I would say that I was pretty pleased with how it functioned.  Using the "mode" button, I was also able to see the estimated calories burned and the progress to my goal (which I set to 10,000 steps).  I ended up that day with nearly 8000 steps (6am-10:30pm).The device will automatically shut itself off after a few minutes of inactivity and will resume again once movement is detected.  It basically begins to pick up right where it left off.  I also noticed that it doesn't always actively count each step as you are watching the screen.  For example, you might take 10 steps and you won't see it count each step on the screen, but when you stop...it will register 10 steps.  It does seem reasonably accurate, and for this I was pretty pleased with it's performance.  The cost of the device seems to be pretty reasonable compared to others like it and it certainly is interesting in knowing how many steps you take for certain activities.  I'll be interested in knowing the steps taken in future hiking excursions when we go camping.  I haven't given it to my wife to try out yet...I'm almost scared to.  What if she wins?  Then we wouldn't have any complain/compare talks when we get home!The device seems reasonably priced and works well for my purposes.  It also appears to be relatively accurate within 1 to 2 steps and I appreciate the belt clip, lanyard, and extra battery.  I was able to setup the basic functions that I needed to get it working but the instructions are not step by step clear, in my opinion, and need to be clarified.  Some of you who have had experience with these devices might not view this as a problem and might be able to figure it out better than I could however.  I'm sure they make some more expensive and fancy ones out there...but this one seems alright by me.I received this product at a discount or as a free sample to test for an honest review.

Everyone I know, who owns an iPhone, has some sort of tempered glass screen protector.  Like you, I've seen many phones dropped and the glass is completely shattered upon impact (iPhones 4-5).  Supposedly the newer iPhone models (iPhone 6) has a better designed screen to help prevent this?  I'm not sure, but I certainly don't want to take any chances or assume anything.Upon inspecting this particular screen protector, I'd have to say that it was packaged well and arrived without any issues.  It comes in a hard cardboard sleeve and the screen protector itself is wrapped in an additional foam sleeve.  It also comes with a package containing wet and dry wipes to clean and prep the screen.  Also, there are three "Guide Stickers" (not sure what those are for) and another sticker that has "Dust-absorber"  written on it (which states that you use that to clear dust from the screen).  This one has an illustration that demonstrates how to use it.  The screen has a protective film on it that is easily removed by pulling a small tab and it is clearly labeled as the back of the screen protector.The cardboard sleeve that the product arrived in has a series of four pictures that show how to attach the screen protector to your phone.  The process was pretty easy.  The package states that the device has a 9H strength rating, Oleophobic coated, drop protection, fingerprint proof, and blade proof.  It isn't fingerprint proof because I can clearly see my fingerprints on it...but they are easy to wipe off.  I would call it more of a fingerprint resistant application here.  The screen itself is pretty flexible, not fragile, and has a sense of strength to it.  It certainly will provide a first line of defense against a drop on a hard surface.I would say that this is a pretty affordable way to protect your screen on an expensive phone.  It's easy to go on and was packaged well.  I appreciate that it has cleaning materials in the package but I would suggest offering some written instructions for those who may have never used one of these before.  It isn't fingerprint proof but does offer some resistance to excessive prints all over the screen.  I would say that personally, I'd feel confident that this would provide some protection against scratches and hopefully some harsher falls.I received the product free or at a discounted rate for an honest review.

There are a whole lot of iPhone accessories out there and you definitely need to think about what it is that you specifically need that will suit your needs.  Some choose what I call "battle tank cases", which are large and bulky.  Many of these offer water protection and major falls.  They are very expensive, obviously, but they also have big drawbacks.  Ever try to plug in an additional accessory only to have the "battle tank's" shielding prevent you from doing this?  How about removing this thing from your pocket and having to dang near rip your jeans apart to remove it?  It offers great protection, at a cost, and works well for some people.  There are, of course, plenty of other variations of cases that offer protection and the cheaper they are...the less protection you get.This particular case isn't going to protect your phone from a great fall, nor will it prevent water from seeping into your phone.  It doesn't claim this however, but I do believe that it would protect the phone from a shorter "shock" fall.  It's made out of a rubbery material that has the most protective material around the edges.  This also helps to keep the phone snug inside of the case and I can say that it certainly does this.  It fits quite well and when removing it and inserting it into my pants pocket, it didn't slip off or crunch up.  I asked a few buddies of mine at work to take out their phones so we could compare cases.  One guy had a "battle tank" and most of the others had something similar to this one except theirs had thicker rubber side walls that made their phones fatter.  When I showed them this one and asked for their opinions they gave me their pros and cons:Pros:1.  Thinner:  Easier to take in and out of pockets.2.  Case makes phone feel secure in hands...won't easily slip out of hands.3.  Liked the transparent look of this particular one.  (Funny how most want a particular phone color only to hide it in their cases)4.  Confident that the case will keep the phone (back) from getting scratched up.5.  Is easy to remove.6.  Buttons and ports are easily accessible.Cons:1.  Concerned about a harsher fall in the parking lot or on other hard surfaces.To be honest...they are concerned about that with their own phone cases too.  None of us really could afford going out in the parking lot and putting all of these to the ultimate test however.  I think when pairing this with a tempered glass screen protector, however, you'd be in a lot better shape.  This case only covers the back and sides of the phone...so getting a protective layer on the front glass is a definite must.I think for the price, your getting a case that will definitely protect from scratches, help reduce the shock of a fall, and gives you the convenience of a thinner, less bulky, phone.  They come in multiple colors, but I like that this particular one is transparent so you can actually see the phone.  I think that when coupled with a screen protector, this can give you a low cost piece of mind.  I would not recommend for those of you who are clumsy and maybe have dropped (destroyed) a phone or two in the past.  You might want to seek out a "battle tank" option.I received this product at a discount or free to sample for my honest opinion.

My Rambo collection is finally complete!  There are just some soundtracks that I find myself playing more than others and music from the Rambo movies is certainly one of those.  Jerry Goldsmith created so many memorable themes in his career and the ones found in the Rambo soundtracks have always been some of my favorites.  Unfortunately, the only copy I had of the Rambo movie soundtracks was "First Blood" produced by Varese Sarabande in 2000.  It contains only a fraction of the complete score and although I played the heck out of it, I always felt like I was missing so much great music.  I ended up finally getting "First Blood" and "Rambo III" produced by Intrada Records and "First Blood Pt. II" and "Rambo" (Brian Tyler) produced by Silva Screen Records.  These seem to be the best made copies of these scores that are available now.This particular score is probably my favorite of the four.  It is during this time in Goldsmith's career that he is tinkering with electronic syth sounds in his scores and he does such a masterful job of blending this "new sound" with a large orchestra.  His marriage of this new technology to the classic sound of the orchestra truly gave Rambo an iconic sound that fits the character and the age in which these films were created.  Goldsmith's themes developed for these films were so great that I think that even playing them on a banjo would of been just fine however!  This Silva Screen Records release is an expanded edition of the original soundtrack which contains previously unreleased tracks like "The Map" (track 2), "The Pirates" (track 6), "The Camp/Forced Entry" (track 8), "River Crash/The Gunboat" (track 10), "Bring Him Up/The Eyes" (track 12), and "Village Raid/Helicopter Flight" (track 18).Silva Screen Records has also included an 8 page insert that basically takes each track and describes the scene in which it was created for.  There are a few photos from the film and a brief description of their attempt to squeeze the best possible sound out of the original source tapes in which this was taken.  They say that despite being recorded in 1985, some tape hiss and distortion occurs.  They also go on to say that some of the tapes had to go through a "slow oven bake" process to restore the tape.  That sounds really weird and I have no idea what that means but I am just thankful that they took the time to produce a really great sound and rescue these scores from total destruction.  It would be awful to lose wonderful music like this!This particular release was manufactured in 1999 and still seems to be pretty easy to find for now.  There are 21 tracks on the disc with a little over an hour running time.  The last track the vocal track "Peace in our Life" sung by Frank Stallone.  If you are looking to build or add on to your Rambo soundtrack collection, then I highly recommend adding this one!

I have to admit that I am always a little skeptical over the claims that makers of vitamins put on their labels.  Nonetheless, I still take a multi-vitamin everyday in an attempt to be proactive about supplementing my diet with some "good stuff" for the body.  I've read in places where "experts" say that most of us are throwing are money away on many of these products while others claim otherwise.  My wife and mother-in-law are vitamin and heath food gurus who know a lot about this kind of thing and when this arrived my wife quickly inspected the label and began describing the benefits of the various ingredients contained within these tablets.  She seemed to be pretty excited about it and these certainly contain things that my typical vitamins do not.  This particular supplement is more focused on assisting in the development of healthy skin, hair, and nails.  It does contain some of the more familiar things like vitamin C, and E.  Upon inspecting the label, the product is made in the USA and claims to be composed of natural ingredients.  The product does contain Soy however, so please take note of that if you have particular allergies. The packaging was good and the bottle cap was sealed with a plastic wrap like what you find in the store.  There was also that typical cardboard paper cover sealing the top opening of the bottle.  Cotton balls were also inside the bottle.  I did not find the smell of the tablets to be that unpleasant.  I took two of these with my meal and did not notice any bad aftertaste.  There are 60 tablets within this bottle and the directions say to take two of these a day with a meal.The bottle that I received was manufactured on 7/2015 and has an expiration date of 7/2017. The company that makes these has a website that you can visit and they have a YouTube channel with several videos about the products they make.  It appears that many have had some pretty good success with these so I am excited to see if I notice any differences/benefits over the course of time.  Only time will tell of course.  My impressions of this product are good.  My wife says that they've put some good stuff in these tablets and likes the fact that this particular product is geared towards skin, hair, and nails.  I didn't mind the taste or smell of the tablets and I liked the information that I was able to find out about this company through their website and videos.  I like the fact that this item is manufactured in the USA and I feel good about supporting hardworking companies that want to make quality products.  I plan on adding this to my daily routine and will be sure to update.I received this product as a free sample for an honest review.  My own personal opinions are based on my initial impression of the product, packaging, and additional information that I could find out about DermaSafe.

Picked this up for a costume piece and I am pretty pleased with it.  Searching for one on Amazon can be quite the daunting task because there are so many manufactures, styles, prices, and quality.  I didn't need one for paintball but I wanted it to look fairly authentic, good quality, and at a decent price.  Thankfully, reading the reviews on Amazon eventually brought about the decision to go with this particular one.  It comes exactly as pictured and the other reviewers pictures helped in determining if this was going to work or not as well.  It's made out of a pretty hard thick plastic and I can see why those who participate in paintball activities would like this.  Up close, you can tell that it isn't metal or ballistic grade material, but further away...it looks like the real deal.  Some sort of steel/metal rivets hold the chin strap and head mesh in place.  The straps themselves seem to be the weakest piece of the helmet.  They definitely are not the thickest quality straps out there but I think they will perform well for what I need them for.  The adjustment buckles are made out plastic and this doesn't look too robust either.  Make sure to set the straps correctly so you don't have to keep making adjustments and don't go ripping this off your head in a fit of rage when someone gets the best of you in the game!The helmet is quite comfortable to wear and is light on your head.  It looks great and at the time that I purchased it, the price was $15.  It's going to work great for me as a costume piece, but I think with the proper care, this would be excellent in keeping those paintballs from giving you a headache.  The pictures from the other reviewers and the one in the product window are very accurate.  The high review feedback was also a plus in helping me choose which helmet to go with.  I recommend.

This is a great collectable CD offered by BSX Records.  I also picked up James Horner's "Battle Beyond the Stars" released through their label and both CDs come with plenty of bonuses, nice liner notes, and quality sound recording.  This particular release showcases Horner's music while working with Roger's Corman's studios.  This happens to be Horner's first full science fiction/horror score and it was during this time, early in his career, that his music shows a tremendous amount of influence from the the greats like Laurence Rosenthal, John Williams, and especially Jerry Goldsmith.  It's no secret that Horner was often criticized for "ripping" off other composers, and sometimes himself (using his material in other films), and he admitted only to a strong influence from these artist.  The extensive liner notes provided in this release, as well as, "Battle Beyond the Stars" touches briefly on this subject.  You can definitely hear similarities to Rosenthal's "Island of Dr. Moreau" and Goldsmith's "Alien" score here in cues like "Main Title" (track 1).There is plenty of originality here to be found in the score as well.  Horner's score gives the Roger Corman movie a big budget sound that is very entertaining to listen to on it's own.  It has that 80's science fiction/horror vibe to it and it's very interesting to see the young composer "get his feet wet" with the development of this particular piece.  The score is very ominous, creepy, and atmospheric.  The mood of it really gives you the visualization that monsters are coming for you out of the ocean.  I highly recommend this for fans wanting to hear some of Horner's earliest work because you can really hear the development of a fine composer here.There is some cool bonus material added to the disc. Selections from Christopher Lennertz's score of the 1996 remake are included here as well.  I never knew they even made a remake of this film.  Lennertz's score follows Horner's closely and you wouldn't even know it was from a different composer.  The bonus material blends right in with the original quite nicely.  The last track (19), contains nearly 10 minutes of outtakes "extracted from the out-of-print Image Entertainment Laser Disc isolated score" (quote from liner notes).  With great artwork, liner notes, photos, and bonus materials...this becomes a nice little package for Horner fans and those who like to own collectable soundtrack CDs.  I recommend their release of "Battle Beyond the Stars" which can also be found here on Amazon.  Both releases are limited to 1000 copies and they have been out since 2011 so copies might be getting smaller and may be soon hard to find.  "Humanoids From the Deep" contains 19 tracks and runs about 57 minutes.

The most recent Danny Elfman scores that I've picked up are from "Fifty Shades of Grey" and his collaboration with Brian Tyler in "Avengers: Age of Ultron".  I was glad to see that he was selected to score the "Goosebumps" movie because this is the type of film music that Elfman tends to do very well.  His work with Tim Burton, as well as, a host of other similar film projects has certainly allowed him to establish himself as the premier composer for this genre.  Fortunately, Elfman has been able to prove himself as quite the capable composer in other genres as well.  His portfolio is quite extensive with action, animated, romance, comedies, and thrillers.  My personal favorites are the Batman scores and his unforgettable music for Edward Scissorhands.When listening to "Goosebumps", Elfman fans can quickly identify the familiar sound the composer incorporates into his scores.  Elfman uses musical tools like bells, chimes, choral voices, "march like" percussion and the bass clarinet like a master.  His use of these become a musical fingerprint for the composer and for those who have been listening to his music over the years will recognize his distinctive tone.  Another thing that I've always liked about Elfman is his ability to develop a great theme and not being scared to use it throughout the movie.  The score opens with "Goosebumps" (track 1) and it is here that we first hear the Elfman theme.  It isn't the TV show theme...so don't go expecting that one.  This theme really establishes the mood of the score which I would sum up as being spooky, fun, comic, and adventurous.  One very unique instrument that Elfman incorporates into this theme is one that is usually associated with early science fiction movies.  The Theremin, with it's high pitched tones, adds a really cool "spooky" sound to the theme and Elfman uses it in various moments throughout the score.  You'll find the main theme decorating the music all along the way and this makes some of the more action oriented pieces a lot more interesting to listen to on their own away from the film.I haven't seen the movie yet, but it must hit the ground running because there is a lot of action music here.  These particular sequences are like musical roller coasters with plenty of big drops, fast turns, and barrel rolls all along the way.  All of the "stuff" that Elfman throws into these pieces is what makes them fun to listen to.  There are also so great slower moments in the score as well like "Camcorder", "Confession", "Ghost Hannah", and "Hannah's Back".  These are nice little emotional bits that Elfman treats nicely with strings, piano, and woodwinds.  The movie must not have a lot of time for it however because they are quick.Tracks 18-29 are labeled as bonus material and I found these to be some of the most interesting pieces on the album.  A few of these pieces sound more character oriented, lighter, and slightly comic.  Others are more action/escape music like "Werewolf" and "Fun House" that do a pretty good job of giving you the mental visuals as to what is happening to the characters dealing with these obstacles along the way.The CD contains 29 tracks and runs 1 hour and 5 minutes.  It is released through Sony Classical and contains an 8 page insert that has photos, orchestra credits, production credits, and track listings.  I really like the cover art on this one too."Goosebumps" certainly has the Elfman sound to it and fans who have been enjoying his work over the years will appreciate this.  He's developed a great theme for the score and he cleverly uses it, as well as, other unique instrumentation to keep things interesting.  While maybe not as emotionally thematic as a "Edward Scissorhands" or sing song like "Nightmare Before Christmas", this is a score that fits this type of film well and is enjoyable to listen to on it's own.  I recommend.

First of all let me say that like many of you, I grew up watching the Charlie Brown cartoons and looked forward to them every Halloween, Thanksgiving, and Christmas.  I also developed a strong connection with the Peanuts characters and the music of The Vince Guaraldi Trio.  You can't help but to think of the Peanut characters without it.  Can you imagine the enormous pressure Christophe Beck is feeling right now?  Believe me, if there ever is a composer who takes over the scoring for Star Wars...they are going to feel the same thing.  OK...they are probably going to be even more stressed, but this Peanuts score is a pretty big deal too.  I think the producers of this movie/score know this too and thats why we are finding at least 3 of the original tunes inserted here.Now, when I heard they were making this movie and that Beck was going to compose the music, I was extremely curious if he was just going to imitate the "Trio" sound or was he going to go into an extremely different direction altogether.  The best that I can describe this score is that Beck has orchestrated a score that fits this particular style of film but there is also plenty of homage to The Vince Guaraldi Trio throughout.  I personally think that animated film music has got to be some of the most difficult to construct for a movie.  It is utterly critical to get it right because it has to reach in and touch the imaginations of both adults and kids.  When it matters, Beck finds ways to connect the classic sound from the TV movies to this score.  You hear the wonderful use of the piano in cues like "Charlie Brown in Love" and "The Library" (tracks 8 & 10).  We also hear Beck's arrangements of the classic tunes like "Linus and Lucy", "Skating", and "Christmas Time is Here/Christmas is Coming".  In these cues, there is enough Vince in it to keep it cool with a twist of Beck to make it fresh.  "Carnival Panic/Linus and Lucy" (track 15) has a more upbeat drum beat (and an organ) while "Skating" (18) is done with Xylophones, jazz bass, and drums.  Beck handles the sacred Guaraldi music with care and his interpretation isn't blasphemous...it becomes a celebration of the great musician.Beck also has some wonderful original music here as well.  Please...please listen to "Pen Pal Partners" (track 16), "Good OL' Charlie Brown" (track 17), and especially "Linus and Lucy" (track 20).  Oh...that last track...my goodness...that one alone is worth the CD.  Makes me think more of Charlie Brown than Linus and Lucy however.  It's just absolutely beautiful.I think that a score acts like a music soul for a movie and we as fans have associated this inner energy to characters and stories that we hold dear.  The Vince Guaraldi Trio's music definitely connected us with these glorious hand drawn cartoons of yesteryear.  Beck's music brings a new energy to the Peanuts story but never disregards the foundation that The Vince Guaraldi Trio established.  For me personally, the original music will never grow old and never fade away.  That music fit the TV movies perfectly, but I don't think it would transition completely well with the style and presentation of this particular theatrical release.  I think if Beck would have attempted to regenerate and imitate the sound of the original TV movies, fans would of still been upset.  I'd much rather leave that sound connection with those shows and appreciate Beck's approach with this new 2015 computer animated Peanuts movie.  The score contains some "action" music to fit the scenes where it needs it and these action cues is what is throwing everybody into a rage I think.  I've seen the trailers for the movie and this film differs a lot from the old TV shows in this regard. I'm not quite sure if Charlie Brown is as popular in this day of Sponge Bob and Frozen...but this movie looks to reintroduce him to our children.  But as I said before, when it matters...when the familiar "emotions" of the characters and "philosophical" moments spring up...Beck pays a lot of tribute to Vince.  This is what would of put me in "outrage mode" for sure.  I knew when looking at these movie trailers that we weren't going to get another Vince Guaraldi Trio album...but if I at least couldn't hear a connection to it somehow, then I would of been upset.  Take "The Assembly" (track 11) for example.  Yeah...your not going to hear much at the beginning except what some might call "typical animated action music", especially if your only listening to samples of the score.  But give it a minute...wait for the part where, I assume Charlie Brown sees the little red haired girl? The music takes a slow jazzy turn and it's got a Vince vibe all over it.  It's short and sweet, but that just makes it ever so more powerful when you do catch a glimpse of it.  This is what I can appreciate about this score.  Charlie Brown is a pretty emotional little guy but the great thing is that he handles it so well!  Beck has captured these moments in the music brilliantly.  I strongly suggest checking out this score even if just for those particular pieces because they are just beautiful.The movie looks to be a great one and I am excited to take my young son to go and see it.  I introduced him to the older TV specials and have successfully passed down the tradition.  He likes Snoopy the best, of course.The CD version of this score has 20 tracks and runs for a total of 48 minutes.  There is a 12 page insert that has plenty of photos from the film, song listings, production team credits and the lyrics to Meghan Trainor's "Better When I'm Dancin".  The score also contains "Thats what I Like" by Flo Rida featuring Fite.  There is also a brief director's note from Steve Martino.  Interestingly enough he states, "Our challenge, to create a film that shows reverence for this history but does not just repeat what has come before".  I haven't seen the movie yet...but as for the score, I believe that Christophe Beck has done just this.

I was surprised to see that another Hitman movie was released.  I had seen the first one that came out a while back and thought that it was pretty decent and entertaining but wasn't aware that they were attempting to reintroduce Agent 47 to film again.  I haven't seen this newer version yet but it should be interesting to see how it compares to the earlier one.  I played the first two Hitman games years ago and found the game and score to be great.  I purchased the La-La Land Records 2 disc release of the scores for the first two games back in 2005 and really enjoyed those composed by Jesper Kyd.  The one thing I really liked about those is that every track represented the different locales that Agent 47 was currently engaging his target in.  Agent 47 seemed to be everywhere in those two games and the music by Jesper Kyd complimented each of these missions.  I've never acquired the score for the first film that was released in 2007 composed by Geoff Zanelli but looking at the reviews for it on Amazon, it appears that fans liked it.  What interested me the most about this particular release is the fact that Marco Beltrami was putting the score together for this one.  I've enjoyed a lot of his past work and was eager to hear his musical interpretation for this film and it's familiar character to gamers everywhere.Beltrami has dabbled in just about everything.  From action movies like "Die Hard", horror films like "The Woman in Black" to westerns like "3:10 to Yuma", he certainly has built quite a repertoire.  My personal favorites by him are his two western scores "The Homesman" and "3:10 to Yuma".  So here we find him back in action movie land and the music put together here for this newest version of Agent 47 would satisfy the character well.  I honestly can't imagine any other sound for a movie like this.  I knew exactly the kind of music I was getting here even before I put the disc in.  Electronic drones/buzzes?  Check.  Thumping techno beats?  Check.  Lots of it?  Check.  I mean come on...the guy is a sharp dressed killer going around doing his thing, he certainly deserves music like this.  The beats/rhythms are awesome and you really can picture Agent 47 in action.  Check out track 4, "Point Blank".  It's a great piece that could give you a speeding ticket if you listen to it in the car.  "Tube Tunnel", track 8, is pretty cool too.  Makes me think of the way I wish I could drive during rush hour!Beltrami does give us a theme here for Agent 47.  He first introduces it slightly in track 1, "The Agent Program".  We hear it occasionally throughout the score but it is showcased more in tracks like "Point Blank", "The Powers of an Agent", and "Camera Shy".  It's a great little theme and I guess this is the only problem I have with the score is that I wish it were used a tiny bit more.  Some of the action cues (which there are many) tend to be more forgettable because they sound like they could be in 100 different action movies.  The times in the score where we do get to catch our breath are nice however.  Thankfully, we are introduced to another theme that occurs in these moments.  "Katia's Theme", track 3, is where we first hear this and you'll find it again in slower cues like "Botanical Gardens" (track 14).  These cues tend to drift off and become more ambient than memorable however and never really have a chance to develop for me.  I don't necessarily fault Beltrami for this however because he is putting the music to the scene and let's face it, people don't go to an action movie expecting Shakespeare!The CD is released through La-La Land Records and contains 20 tracks that give you a running time of about 58 minutes.  There is an 8 page insert that contains quite a few pictures from the film and production team credits.  Beltrami brings in a host of talent to help him with additional music for the score (probably most of the electronic stuff you hear in it).  Additional music is credited to Miles Hankins, Wlad Marhuets, Brandon Roberts, Ceiri Torjussen and Marcus Trumpp.  Beltrami's trusty sidekick, Buck Sanders, is lending a hand too.  The orchestra is the Deutsches Filmorchester Babelsberg (German Film Orchestra) which is based in Potsdam, Germany.

This is one of those scores that I had been wanting to add to my collection for quite some time.  It's one of James Horner's early ones and it's fascinating to listen to knowing now that Horner's career would steadily grow and his skills as a composer would develop over time.  As a young composer just starting off, Horner was finding his identity among those like John Williams and Jerry Goldsmith.  He took such liberties with these influences that he was often accused of taking a little too much from their work and incorporating it into his own.  There is no denying that these influences exists in his work and you can also hear him borrowing a lot of material from himself in his early scores.  What makes this particular soundtrack so interesting is that it clearly is a test run for one of my favorite scores by Horner, Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan.Battle Beyond The Stars was created in 1980 and two years later Horner would compose Star Trek II which would catapult his career and enable him to do bigger films and become the recognizable composer that he is today.  Listening to Battle Beyond the Stars is kind of like hearing an early demo/remix of what would eventually become Star Trek II (and Star Trek III).  Battle Beyond The Stars is performed with a 62 piece orchestra and doesn't quite have the larger sound of his later bigger budgeted films but Horner demonstrates his talents, even at this young age, in pulling the most out of them.  The score isn't exactly a clone of his future Star Trek score and Horner does develop some original themes and material that remains exclusive to this particular film.  In my opinion, it does seem that Horner cleverly extracts the best moments of this score and reworks them into bigger/better pieces for Star Trek.  Many would probably say that Horner was cheating and not being original, but now knowing that much of this material would be incorporated into the Star Trek score I am thankful because I couldn't imagine that film any other way!  This is definitely material that shows the evolution of James Horner.  It also clearly shows how he was influenced by Jerry Goldsmith when you hear track 2, "Malmori Rear Guard", and compare it to the first Star Trek movie.Battle Beyond The Stars is a great score on it's own.  Yes, I find myself often drifting off to Star Trek II when those moments appear in it, but there are some great old school thematic science fiction fun happening here too.  Roger Corman was lucky to have this composer for this film because Horner really pulls out a big sound from this orchestra and gives audiences a great 1980's science fiction adventure score.  The main title for the film can stick in your head very quickly and whenever I wasn't listening to this score today, I found this theme playing on repeat in my head!The CD version of this score is presented and packaged very well by BSX Records.  Not only have they included the score from the film but they also give you Alan Howarth's sound effects that were used in the movie as well.  Tracks 18-51 includes ship fly by sounds, interiors of ships, laser blasts, and computer voices.  They also include Howarth's "Gelt's Chamber" juke box music from the film (track 17).  BSX completes the package with a 24 minute piece (track 53) that was released previously for Silva Screen Records.  This is the concert version of the film's main theme that was created in 1998 and performed by the City of Prague Philharmonic Orchestra.  There is also a 12 page CD insert that is packed full of photos and detailed liner notes concerning the film's history, James Horner, and Alan Howarth.  This release reminds me a lot of those old GNP Crescendo Star Trek CDs that also contained great liner notes, sound effects, and sometimes stickers!  I also want to note that BSX Records also has Horner's "Humanoids From the Deep" score which they also did very well.  Battle Beyond The Stars contains 53 tracks and runs about 1 hour and 11 minutes.  It's a fabulous score to listen to and appreciate.  Horner's career was at it's early stages here and BSX Records does a great job in presenting this material to us a collectable package (which is limited to 1000 copies according to the back of the CD).  This was released in 2011 so I am sure the numbers are dwindling down...so pick this one up!  I recommend!

Here's a score that I didn't think would ever be released on CD.  I preordered it back in August (2015) and after multiple delays, It finally arrived in October.  Bear McCreary, who is a very accomplished and talented composer, seems to be the "titan" of TV soundtracks these days.  Some of his work includes "Battlestar Galactica", "Black Sails", "DaVinci's Demons", and the ever so popular "Outlander".  Steve Kaplan shares the credit of composer for "Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D." and I am not very familiar with his work.  McCreary has been quite busy and I am sure with his involvement with multiple TV shows going on at the same time that he certainly needs the assistance.To be honest, I've only seen a few of the episodes from this show and while I enjoyed them, I mainly purchased this score because I love to hear Bear McCreary's work.  In the few episodes that I have seen from the show, I immediately began to appreciate the thematic "hero" music that McCreary graciously sprinkles along the score.  I love hearing a recognizable theme when I am watching movies or shows like this and that is one thing that this TV soundtrack surely has.  The busy violins and big brass brings a heroic sound worthy for the Marvel universe and it's characters.  Also, when listening to this particular score, you appreciate the composer's desire to bring a big film sound to the small screen.  Looking through the credits found in the CD liner notes, McCreary/Kaplan use a lot of musicians to bring this sound to us.  From instrument soloist like Steve Bartek (guitar) to vocalist like Raya Yarbrough, the composers have taken great care to spice up this score and give it all they can.The composers have selected a variety of pieces throughout the series to include on this release and I am sure that serious fans from the show might be missing some things, but I think they've done a good job at least giving us a variety here.  Thankfully not all the selections here are action oriented sequences.  "Alien DNA", track 11, features Raya Yarbrough and is quite a haunting and mesmerizing piece that builds to a hair raising climax.  Yarbrough, who McCreary also uses for the "Outlander" series, has a wonderful voice and it's good to see that McCreary use that talent well.  Could we be seeing another Hans Zimmer and Lisa Gerrard partnership here?  "Helicopter Rescue", track 15, might sound like an action piece from it's title, but it is a very dreamy/relaxing piece that I find myself playing often.  It begins to pick up in tempo near the end of the piece and closes out with percussion and a big orchestra.  There are a few  upbeat electronic pieces in here as well like "The Big Bang" and "The Rising Tide" (tracks 17 & 18).  The score seems to have it all...even a cello concerto!  Track 9, "Cello Concerto", features soloist Eric Byers and is a great piece to add to this collection.  I think my favorite track from this CD is "Showdown at Union Station" (track 2).  This is a rather lengthy cue (nearly 7 minutes) that has a little bit of everything thrown into the mix!The CD contains 18 tracks and runs for a total of 1 hour and 18 minutes.  There is an 8 paneled insert that contains orchestra/production credits, special thanks, and plenty of photos from the show.  The score is very thematic, fun to listen to, and has a variety to keep everything interesting.  The big movie score sound is really awesome and the incorporation of so many different musicians and soloist is a real bonus.  I recommend!

Let me guess, a bad neck while sleeping probably brought you here.  Me too.  Yep, some weeks back I woke up with a painful surprise in my neck.  It isn't the first time it has happened.  Usually, I will just deal with it and over time, maybe a few days, everything will work itself out and I am back to normal again.  This most recent neck ache would not go away however.  I would even wake up at night and find my neck contorted in such a way that I was just making things even worse.  There would be no self healing if I couldn't put my head in a position that would allow it to heal.  So, like many of you are probably doing, I went on a quest to find the holy grail of pillows.
