If you have arrived at the end of your journey...or if you are just beginning, I'll tell you that there are many pillows out there and all of them claim something magical by resting your weary head on them.  You wouldn't believe how complicated pillow shopping is.  I can tell you that no review will help you find the right one.  I guess the reason we have so many different pillows out there is because everyone is so different and finicky when it comes to a product like this.  There are pillows that will cost you hundreds of dollars, some are filled with water and some with bamboo.  There are thin ones, fat ones, misshaped ones, feather ones, cotton ones, memory foam and NASA probably has one filled with cloud vapors.  The problem is that you are going to have to try them for yourself and find whats best for you.Being a side and stomach sleeper, I started my quest by narrowing down the search to pillows that claimed support for someone like me.  I tried the "wavy mountain memory foam pillow" (that is not the products name...I don't remember what it is called) that cradles your head and I also tried a flat pillow.  Neither one seemed to help.  Looking on Amazon, I stumbled across this one and was intrigued by it's design.  It was definitely something that I had never tried before.  The good thing is that it wasn't too expensive and I was getting desperate.  I tried to find this particular pillows in some of the big box stores to at least put my hands on it but I could not find anything like it anywhere.  So, I guess I was destined to gamble with this thing.Upon arrival, I inspected the quality of the pillow and was pleased with that.  The stitching was well done, it was clean, and I didn't notice any horrible smell.  I wouldn't say this pillow is "soft".  Other pillows that I purchased throughout my journey, had a feeling of sinking right down into them and some were like rocks.  This one is firm and it's innards has that stuffing that you find in craft stores.  It feels and looks like that poly-fil fiber.  I found some of it stuck to the pillow fabric when I removed it from it's plastic bag and I can also see it through the white material that holds it all together.  The garment tag also states that it is made out of 100% Polyester Fiber.  Anyway...if it works...I don't care if it is made out of seaweed...I'll try it!  Trying it out for the first time was a little odd.  I tried the "Larger Neck Support" side and turned it around to try the "Smaller Neck Support" side.  The larger neck side actually seems softer allowing your neck to sink down nearly level with the "hole" area.  This also enables the lower areas of the pillow to support the sides of your neck a bit more.  I decided to use this approach as it seemed more comfortable to me.  I also noticed that when I am sleeping on my side that if I angle the pillow a bit that this helps me achieve a more comfortable position as well.  I am trying to avoid sleeping on my stomach because I think that is where a lot of my problems are coming from.  I've been using the pillow for a few weeks now and although I cannot say that I am completely healed, I am doing better.  I can now turn my head to back the car out of the driveway a lot more comfortably!  So is it the pillow or me being a bit more conscientious of how I am sleeping?  Who knows, maybe a combination of both.  I found this pillow to be comfortable for me to sleep on.  The "hole" area allows my head to rest down and my neck appears to level out when using it.  I do angle it a bit for comfort.Well, that is my adventure.  There are probably better ones out there but honestly I can't afford to try them all.  This one was more unique than some of the ones that I tried and it seemed to be what I needed.  Waking up in the middle of the night, with massive neck pain, and noticing the positions that I was putting my neck in gave me the idea that I needed something to sink my head and help hold my neck in place.  Of course, when we are sleeping, some of us toss around quite a bit and we are never truly "settled" into one place all night.  I can tell you that I am waking up a lot less at night and after a few weeks of use, my neck feels a whole lot better.  I can't say that I'd recommend this pillow...because we are all different sleepers...but I can say that it worked for me.

It's been a while since I've purchased a Thomas Newman soundtrack.  I think the last one that I picked up by him was "Skyfall" (James Bond) and I really didn't care for that one too much.  This, however, is the kind of film that Newman does best.  "The Green Mile", "The Road to Perdition", and "Shawshank Redemption" were truly remarkable scores.  One of my favorites from him is "Meet Joe Black" however.  Thomas Newman, who is the son of the great film composer Alfred Newman, has scored many films over the years but this is his first with director Steven Spielberg.  It's well known that John Williams is Spielberg's composer of choice but unfortunately Williams couldn't score this film due to illness.  John Williams, who is 83 years old, has actually composed every Spielberg film except one, "The Color Purple" which was scored by Quincy Jones.  I think Spielberg's decision to go with Newman was a great one.  Newman really has a knack for films like this and although I will forever be eternally curious as to what a John Williams score would of sounded like for this film, I am pleased to say that this really is an outstanding soundtrack.I haven't seen the film yet, but I am eager to do so.  The story is based on the true events of Lt. Francis Gary Powers and when the Soviets shot down his U-2 spy plane.  Track one of the score sets the tone with brief old school cold war "Hunt for Red October" sounding music.  The Soviet choir is haunting and beautiful.  The next track, "Sunlit Silence", sounds heroically American and must be Powers flying high in his U-2 spy plane.  It's a great serene and graceful piece that really musically paints a scene of a high altitude flight.  Newman incorporates plenty of musical references throughout the score to represent the Soviets, Americans, and espionage.  Newman has always composed some fantastic piano music for films. His use of piano and woodwind instruments is a great choice to highlight this sense of spies and espionage throughout the score.  Track 6, "Lt. Francis Gary Powers", is one of the most unique in the score.  It sounds like something you'd hear in a horror film.  It's pretty intense and I am guessing that this might be the Soviets interrogating Powers?  The climax of the film is the trading of spies and Newman captures this historical event perfectly with "Glienicke Bridge" (track 13).  There is a lot of atmospheric tension music that gets more agitated with piano and Russian vocals about 6 minutes in.  This is the most lengthy cue on the album and it runs for nearly 11 minutes.  The music is really well done here because you can literally close your eyes and see this scene take place.  The track ends in "victory" with a fanfare of military drums, big strings, and brass.  The last track, "Bridge of Spies" (track 15), basically presents the musical essence of the entire score, so you'll hear many of the themes and sounds established throughout played here as the end credits roll.The CD is released through Hollywood Records and contains 15 tracks that run a total of 49 minutes.  The score seems short to me...I guess they probably use a lot of period music throughout the film as well?  The CD comes with an 8 paneled insert that contains some great pictures from the film, as well as, orchestra/choir credits, and production team credits.  There are also some "special thanks" from the composer and interestingly enough...he thanks John Williams!  As I mentioned before, this is the type of score that Newman excels at.  He has done a great job here.  The music really does a great job of expressing the movie well and I love Newman's piano work here...and the cool Cold War Soviet sound too!  I recommend!

This is a movie that is high on my "really want to see" list.  I didn't get a chance to see it in the theaters so I'll have to wait for it to be released on Blu Ray.  It seems to have gotten a lot of mixed reviews with some hating it because they feel it is "insulting to other cultures" and those who love it feeling that it is an "intense action that will keep you on the edge of your seat".  I guess I'll have to wait and find out for myself.  Owen Wilson plays an American engineer in Southeast Asia who find himself, along with his family, caught up in the middle of a political uprising.  I remember seeing a show on TV that shared the true stories of tourist overseas who were either kidnapped or found themselves in very similar circumstances and it was terrifying to think about.  Judging from the movie trailer and from what I've read about this film, it appears that this movie attempts to bring such a nightmare to audiences.  Marco Beltrami and Buck Sanders take on the challenge of pulling at your emotions and forcing you to feel the intensity of the story all through music.  This is definitely a "run, hide, fight, run, hide, fight" score that will have you sweating by the time you reach the end.Beltrami and Sanders have shared "composer" titles before in films like "Max Payne", "Don't Be Afraid of the Dark", and "The Hurt Locker".  They've actually been working together for quite some time really.  Sanders has collaborated with Beltrami since 1997 and I think they first worked together on the score "Mimic".  Sometimes he acts as a producer, musician, or composes additional music.  Their time together, no matter what role Sanders takes, has yielded some fine music over the years.  Nearly every Beltrami score has Sanders somewhere in the credits, so their partnership goes back several years.  For this particular score, the duo has essentially created a horror score.  Instead of monsters/demons however, we find a family in what appears to be a "no escape" political rebellion in foreign land.  The action steams along at a brisk pace and the composers capture the sounds of Southeast Asia through traditional instrumentation and percussion.  Track 6, "Coup Coup Roux", makes good use of the cultural sounds of the region putting the audience right there in the geography of the story.  The piece starts like a growl and steadily grows in intensity with this steady "thump, thump, thump" beat that makes the piece a bit nerve wracking.  You'll hear this steady "thump, thump, thump" rhythm used quite a bit throughout the score.  I bet it does a great job of amping up the tension in the movie...the only problem is that when you are trying to sit at home and enjoy this score outside of the film...it can amp up your tension as well!  This is probably not the score to take to the office and play in the background while you work.  You'll be yelling at everyone by the end of the day.  I would reserve this for the treadmill folks or you runners out there.  You will definitely get a workout with this one.  As a matter of fact, the score only takes a few breaks from the action.  It's only when the characters find "refuge" that you will also.  Cues like "Rooftop Refuge" (track 10), "Brothel Refuge" (track 19), and "Broader Refuge" (track 25) give you and the characters a chance to catch your breath.  There is nothing thematic about the score.  There really seems to be no time for that in the music as it's main focus is to throw you in this situation with the characters.  You don't really have time to get to know them...just "run, hide, fight" alongside!The score is a mix of traditional sounds/instrumentation of the region, electronics, strong percussion, and even some very nice piano (for the slower cues).  The percussion work really stands out in this score and really gives you the sense of trying to escape a bad situation.  The composers provided a score that runs right along with the story given to them.  This unfortunately will make the score probably a little more difficult for listeners to enjoy outside of the film.  I do think that those who appreciate more percussive scores will enjoy this however and those of you looking for some great "running" tracks can certainly find plenty here.  The slower, "take refuge" cues are more ambient than thematic and I know when I pull this score out again to listen to it, my first thought will be the "thump, thump, thump, thump" rhythm that you hear so often throughout the action sequences.  I wish there could of been more time to develop some more thematic sequences and the "breather" cues are over too soon.  Beltrami and Sanders have really done an outstanding job of musically capturing this horrible scenario and letting the audience feel the anxiety of the situation for sure.The CD version of the score is released by Lakeshore Records and comes in a digipack with their traditional limited edition "gold sticker" of only 1000 copies made.  There is a four page insert in the front cover sleeve with a two paneled picture of Owen Wilson and Pierce Brosman.  The back page contains music production credits.  There are 27 tracks and the total running time is 56 minutes.  The last track on the score is a song entitled "Take Care of You" and is sung by Jim James.

This is a product that I've been wanting for a long time.  I'm sure many of you, like me, have probably searched online and have read a lot of horror story reviews about these devices.  Some don't last but a few charges, don't work, etc.  I am happy to say that after testing this device, I am confident that it will perform it's intended job.  I've always wanted one of these things mainly for camping trips.  It's one the problems I have to figure out each year.  I don't do any social media stuff...but I do like the convenience of having a phone around for emergencies.  I am also still using an iPhone 4S and over the years the battery life has certainly diminished.  We also live in an area that is prone to power outages due to storms.  We had a tornado hit our area a few years ago and it knocked our electricity out for a week.  Throw in a couple of hurricanes and ice storms too.  We now have a generator, but I don't mind a backup gadget such as the Idaye charger.It came packaged very well with plenty of protective gear to keep it safe on the mail ride over.  It comes with an instruction book and a USB cable that allows you to charge it through your computer or laptop.  When I started charging it, 3 out of 4 lights were on showing that it came shipped with at least 75% of a charge.  I noticed that some other reviewers have mentioned various charge levels when theirs arrived as well.  I "topped off" the charge through my computer and the include USB cable, which took about an hour because it was already nearly full.  I first charged my iPhone 4S that had a 50% charge and that took about 1 hour.  I next charged my Kindle, which was completely dead, and that took about 2 hours to charge.  After charging both devices, I still had 50% power left over.  One thing that I did notice is that when you  are charging a device, the blue lights on the Idaye only blinked for a second or two and then they turn off.  They do not blink during the entire charging process.  I kept checking on it every so often (turning my phone on) to see if it was indeed charging my phone and it most certainly was.Charging it back to full capacity takes about 8 and a half hours through my computer.  I tried using old Apple wall chargers on this and they will not charge the device correctly.  All four lights on the unit will start blinking after about 10-15 minutes (which I guess is a signal that something is not charging properly).  I had to use my computer to charge it up correctly.  I guess I'll have to find a non-Apple wall charger and see if that works later.  It does not have pass through capabilities (which allows it to charge both your device and the charger).  It also has a power button on the side that you have to push in order for it to start charging your device.  Pushing the power button when nothing is plugged in will cause the blue lights to come on letting you know how much charge you have in the device.  It also has "Smart" capabilities which according to the instructions, "maximizes compatibility with Android, Apple, and other devices by enabling charge speeds of up to 2.4A amps.  It has a large capacity at 18500mAh and allows for quite a few charges.  The device itself is very sleek, small, and easily portable.  One would have no problem at all with slipping this in a brief case of a backpack.  It isn't that heavy to me and feels pretty solid and well built.  It is functional and the price is really good.  I did not notice any excessive heat build up during any of the charging.Camping, "out and about", or for emergencies...I think this is a great little device to have.  As with all batteries, time and frequent use will diminish the life and power of the device so it will be interesting to see how well it holds up.  The instructions state that "No expense spared - constructed with Li-Polymer Battery".  I honestly have no idea what that means in the world of batteries...but like my iPhone 4S, all things will eventually come to an end!  Anyway, from what I can tell about this device and the experience that I've had with it so far, I would say that it is a well built little charger with plenty of power, nice design features, and will be great for my needs.  I recommend!I received this device at a discount for an honest review.

Great hose!  Light weight and flexible.  It comes with the necessary rubber washers to prevent leaks and I really like how Purelux packages their items.  They have plastic protective fittings that go over the ends of the hose and everything comes wrapped inside a cardboard box.  I am currently using this hose with the Purelux "Torch" shower head and the shower arm bracket.  The whole system is working wonderfully and I am very happy with the quality of their products.  They are affordable and well made.  I recommend!I received this product to test for an honest and unbiased review.

I am using the Purelux Adjustable Hand Shower Arm Mount in conjunction with their "Torch" shower head.  The device was very easy to install and provides adjustment capabilities for my shower head.  It comes with plenty of pipe thread tape and that is definitely a bonus that I wasn't expecting.  I really like how it "lifts" my particular shower head up and lets the water fall down on you rather than it aiming directly in your face.  There are rubber washer seals inside to keep the water from leaking.  It works perfectly with the shower head that I have (which is also made by Purelux).  The whole system is really affordable.  The shower head, bracket and hose will cost you around $30.  I recommend!I received this product to test for an unbiased and honest review.

The 12 Monkeys soundtrack is what I would call some great "thinking & creating" music.  It's dark, moody, atmospheric and provides some nice mellow down tunes.  The producers of the CD have complied 23 cues of music from the TV series onto one disc and upon sampling some of the tracks I felt that this was very nice working music.  I like having music like this in the background to make life a little less mundane and it helps to get the creative juices flowing too.Trevor Rabin and Paul Linford have collaborated together to give us the soundscape of the time traveling TV show.  The insert that comes with the CD has a note from director Terry Mutalas which he states that he is a long time fan of Rabin's music scores such as "National Treasure" and "Enemy of the State".  Upon talking with Rabin about the show, he did his best to describe his musical vision that included bells and chimes.  He goes on to say that within two weeks, Rabin had worked out the main theme of the show and it was exactly what the director wanted and it's what you hear on the title sequence on the CD.  The first track, "I Am the Clock", is a great piece that really does set up the whole tone of this science fiction conspiracy story.  The score is like a dark investigative crime drama with a slight twist of horror mixed in.  The collaborating composers did a great job incorporating the importance of "time" within the music as well.  Many of the cues use instrumentation to simulate a clock's ticking and/or give the sense of time.  Other cues are more echoey, sad, and mediative such as one of my favorite tracks entitled "Art of War" (12).  The last track, "The Cycle is Complete" is a bit more epic sounding and is accompanied by a choir of voices.  Another great track is entitled "Katarina (Jones's Theme).  I was out on my back deck playing this with the sun going down...totally awesome.  The great thing is that the score never gets too bombastic and so nonsensical that is becomes a distraction and ultimately a "noise fest".  Rabin and Linford have set a musical tone for the show and it remains consistent throughout the score.  There is plenty of tension, atmosphere and some great diversity in instrumentation.Some might be turned off by the score.  Your not going to get this music and say to yourself, "Hey...I am going to sit down and jam out with the 12 Monkeys score".  I could probably do that with Jurassic World or Star Wars...but not this one.  This is more of a "mellow out...replace background noise with something more interesting and possibly fitting" music.  As I mentioned previously, it can also be some awesome inspirational and "creating" music.  Fans of the show will surely enjoy this collection.  I've amassed quite the soundtrack collection over the years and I find myself listening to scores to recount favorite scenes from the movie, play "arm chair" director, envision my own scenes, color the background noise of reality with something more interesting, and relaxing.  This particular score will probably go into the later two categories.The CD is produced by Varese Sarabande and contains 23 tracks with a total running time of 1 hour and 2 minutes.  The CD also contains a 4 page insert with pictures from the show and a brief note from the director.  The back cover contains credits for score production, tracks and lists the many instruments performed by the composers themselves.The Perseids meteor shower is tonight, I think I'll take this out with me on the back deck and wonder at the infinity of space & time.  I recommend!

The CD insert has a note from composer Jeff Beal where he recounts having visited the ruins of Masada a few months prior to being asked to compose the music for the TV miniseries.  His trip to Masada definitely inspired his creativity because his score for the show paints a musical picture that, as a stand alone piece of work, gives the listener a wonderful soundscape of the story.  Across the two CDs you find wonderful atmospheric and emotionally infused music using traditional and ethnic instrumentation.  The score is accompanied by haunting and beautiful vocals that really brings the culture, time period, and emotions of the story to life.Jeff Beal is certainly no stranger to TV soundtracks.  He has an impressive resume of material and has consistently been able to deliver on a variety of subjects and stories.  Many will know him for his work on "House of Cards" but I became familiar with him on his "Jesse Stone" TV scores (which they really need to release on CD again).  Once I saw that Beal was doing the score for this series, I went ahead and pre-ordered the CD and I am glad I did.  Beal doesn't disappoint with this one.  The score has a great authentic feel to it and it is what you'd expect from a movie like this.  I am very pleased to say that Varese Sarabande, the record label that produced the CD, did a great job of putting this together.  Although I appreciate this label very much for bringing otherwise unobtainable scores to audiences, they tend to give the "bare bones" of scores with little extras.  With this particular release, they give you two CDs packed with music from the show.  The total run time of the score is 2 hours and 29 minutes.  Disc 1 is the more emotional and thematic with the music setting up the characters and the impact of the Romans in their lives.  Disc 2 moves into a slightly more action oriented theme as the Romans grow ever so closer to the besieged Jews at Masada.  The tone of the music in Disc 2 gets more desperate and Beal does an excellent job at musical capturing this part of the story.The score is quite enjoyable to listen to as a stand alone work and I find it to be very relaxing back ground music for work.  Beal has done an excellent job at demonstrating is versatility as a composer and continues to impress.  The CD release of this score is a limited edition with only 1000 copies available.  For those of you who like to truly own your music and want a CD copy, I suggest you move fast.  Like so many of Beal's scores, they are usually released in limited numbers and become expensive to obtain later (wish I had a copy of the "Stone Cold" score).  The CD is available currently through the Varese Sarabande website for $16.98 and Amazon third party sellers.  The CD comes with an 8 page insert that contains a note from Jeff Beal and photos from the series.  There are 27 tracks on Disc 1 and 24 on Disc 2.  With a 2 hour and 29 minute runtime, there is plenty of music to enjoy here.  It's a wonderful score and I recommend!

What a fun score to listen to!  Christophe Beck has done an amazing job with this one and it is quickly becoming one of my favorite of the Marvel scores.  I just got the CD today and I've been playing it all day.  I really like the very catchy main title theme.  I went out to do some errands today and as I was listening to this in the car, I couldn't help to notice how much this "heist" music really fits into the world of ants as well.  I mean think about it.  Ants are always on a heist job!  They are sneaking around and always on some kind of a mission.  The music fits perfectly.  As I am driving around, I couldn't help to notice how this music fits into our own busy world as well.  The busy fast moving pace of life and our own little "missions" seem to fit very well within the context of this music.  Beck has given Ant-Man a wonderful main theme and fortunately he plays with it throughout the score.  It is easily recognizable, catchy, and one that I hope is used in future movies and/or appearances of this character.  The Marvel movies rotate composers a lot and sometimes these themes can get very muddled.  Speaking of themes, you do hear the Avengers theme briefly in the score (track 9 - "First Mission").I loved Beck's approach to short choppy notes that not only work well with the comic heist bits within the movie but also because they fit so nicely within the insect world as well.  Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov's piece "Flight of the Bumblebee" is an example of this (there is a track on the CD called Flight of the Bumblebee - it is not the Rimsky-Korsakov piece).  You can't help but to visualize a bee in flight and I find that to be true in some of the cues for the Ant-Man score.  Beck's score is plenty diverse however in that you can find comic movements, heroic fanfares, action, and emotional pieces.  This truly makes this score enjoyable to listen to as a stand alone piece of work.  The variety and nature of the music is what makes it perfect for enjoyable listening throughout the day.The CD contains 31 tracks with the last four being done by Camilo Azuquita, Roy Ayers, The Commodores, and HLM.  Out of the last four tracks, the HLM one entitled "Pink Gorilla" is my favorite.  It's a fun techno sounding dance number that sounds really cool.  Another favorite of mine is Beck's "Tales to Astonish" (track 27).  A guess the title is a nod to Ant-Man's first appearance in comic books and with this we get a great little Ventures sounding surf music.  It's a great fun way to close out the score portion on the CD.  The total run time on the CD is 1:05:20 so your getting plenty of great music here.  The CD comes with a 8 paneled insert that contains pictures from the film, track listing, and production credits.  The CD is released through Hollywood Records.It's a great score and I love Ant-Man's theme music.  Beck certainly made some great creative choices here and the connection between comic heist music and the insect world really works.  I recommend this one!

Revenge stories have been around for a long time and the movies that are successful in bringing these stories to our screens do so with great presentation, story, and character.  The movie is beautiful with it's locations, sets, props, and costumes.  The story is brilliantly ugly with the unfortunate circumstances that the main character finds himself in.  I thought the set up for the film was perfect.  A good man who has a beautiful wife and son...hasn't seen them in seven years and on the day he is finally reunited with them....wow...TRAGEDY!  I don't want to give any spoilers but as events unfolded, I found myself almost too squeamish to watch.  I couldn't help but to think, "Man...if that was to happen to me"!  It doesn't stop there because other things follow that drive the character to his ultimate destiny of confrontation to those who have done him wrong.I really enjoyed the film and knew nothing about it until I saw it on Amazon's new releases for Tuesday.  I watched a trailer online and decided to go for it.  I've always loved western films and although this story is a familiar one, I thought the presentation here was excellent.  The setup of the characters at the beginning was very well done.  Seeing these events unfold made me curious as to how the main character was going to handle this.  As he obtains justice for one tragedy, another soon finds it's way into his life and this propels the story further and he eventually meets the ultimate villain in the story....and what a villain he is!  There are some very brutal scenes in the film especially where this bad guy is concerned!The acting was very well done and I am impressed with Eva Green!  What a gorgeous actress.  She doesn't say a word throughout the entire film and has to rely on her eyes, facial expressions, and body language.  Again, I don't want to spoil what part her character plays in all of this, but you'll find her character and Eva Green's performance to be outstanding.I really enjoyed the film and was impressed by the acting, music, setting/scenery, and story.  I thought that the main character was very realistic and not too much of a "super-hero gunslinger".  It's a beautiful looking film and it looks amazing on Blu Ray.  For fans of the western genre this is a must see film!

I really enjoyed Henry Jackman's work on "Big Hero 6".  It was an amazing score and I was excited to hear what he had in store for "Pixels".  Before popping the CD in, I was really expecting the score to reflect the arcade sounds and music from the video game characters in the movie.  I was very surprised to hear otherwise.  The score has the rich full sound of an orchestra and choral vocals.  There is certainly nothing wrong with that because Jackman is a very accomplished composer that has impressed me many times before!  The score is big...almost epic at times.  The choral voices add an extra magical effect to some of the pieces and you can tell that this music is perfect for reflecting the action, comedy, and zaniness of this story's premise.  I haven't seen the movie, but in watching the trailers I can see how this music by Jackman would blend in perfectly.The problem is that the score, while nicely done, becomes a little less interesting to listen to as a stand alone piece.  The score doesn't really delve into any emotional depth or character pieces because it doesn't have to.  It's a score for a big action comedy and the music that Jackman has created here is designed to reflect just this.  There are a few very short emotional pieces that Jackman manages to squeeze in however.  They are very short and hardly have time to develop but this is no fault of the composer.  He's writing music to support the story he is given.  The pieces are "Unconditional Love", "Sweet Spot", and "High Score".  These are some of my favorite tracks from the score but I also enjoy listening to "Centipede" as well.  "Centipede" is a great action piece that has several movements and is very reflective of Jackman's skill as a composer.  There is a bonus track that is really fun to listen to entitled "Arcaders '82".  This last track is what I was really expecting the entire score to be like.  It definitely has that "80s" sound to it and is a fun piece to listen to.  It would of been cool if more of this sound could have been used a bit more in the score.The runtime of the score is pretty short at a mere 39 minutes.  I assume this is because other music is probably being used in the movie for certain scenes which reduces the amount of music that Jackman has to score.  The CD comes with an 8 page insert that contains pictures from the film, choir credits, orchestra credits (Hollywood Studio Symphony), and production credits.  The CD is released through Varese Sarabande.  From the look of the pictures and the trailer, it seems like it would be a fun movie.  It hasn't been getting a very good response from some but I'll have to see for myself.It's a big score that is designed to reflect more of the onscreen action only.  It doesn't have time to support some emotional inner turmoil and develop individual thematics.  It's music for a comic science fiction action movie starring Adam Sandler.  Jackman gives what he's suppose to with what he's working with.  Unfortunately this will make it a little more difficult for many to enjoy on it's own.  I do wish something more unique could have been inserted in other areas of the score such as what we find in the bonus track because I think that would of made everything stand out a bit more.

If your not familiar with composer Reinhold Heil, chances are you've probably heard his music before.  He  has worked on several TV series such as "Without a Trace", "Legends" and "Awake".  He also contributed on the movie score for "Cloud Atlas" with Tom Tykwer and Johnny Klimek.  Heil's specialty is his custom made electronic sounds.  The CD insert for the "Helix" soundtrack contains a statement from Heil where he says, "Some of my weirdest sound creations were a natural fit for this show".  I'd have to agree because there are unique sounds aplenty within this score.  Heil uses various synthesizers, computer tech, and his own "homemade sample creations" to capture the atmospheric and ambient sounds for the show's environments.  I've only seen season one, which takes place in an arctic research station.  The first disc from this CD contains highlights from season 1 with 33 tracks.  The music is very fitting to this eerie and isolated place and the custom sounds that Heil generates contribute greatly to the mood of the story.  You can't help but to picture the long corridors, hidden passageways, minimalistic "research station decoration", and cold air when you listen to this first disc.  The second disc focuses on season 2 which takes place in an entirely different location.  I haven't seen this season yet but from what I understand it takes place on some mysterious island.  The music reflects this locale change with slightly more percussion work that almost sounds tribal at times.  Heil continues to explore and expand his imagination with even more crazy random sounds that sneak into the music providing a jolt of surprise, mystery and energy.  How much weirdness can you squeeze out of a synthesizer anyway?  A spooky music box tune makes it's appearance occasionally in some of the cues and this must be of some importance within the story of season 2.I should also point out that Heil implores the talents of other artist to help him achieve his musical tapestry of "Helix".  Ayana Haviv provides some very haunting and beautiful vocals for both seasons.  For season one, she lends her voice on "Find Me" and for season 2 it's "Kool Aid".  Heil also uses cello and viola work on a few cues with my favorite being track 20 from season 2 entitled "I Can't Believe Michael Did This".  The musicians for this great music are Marshall McDaniel and Michael Levine.The score for Helix is very successful in creating the atmosphere for the show.  It's moody, creepy, mysterious, and picks up in intensity when needed.  It is not a melodic score and your certainly not going to walk around in the grocery store whistling a tune from this.  Well, I guess you could have that creepy main title music that reminds me of a bad gameshow.  Your probably not going to exercise or jog the neighborhood with this stuff either (unless you want a brand new interpretation of your surroundings).  I'd recommend this score for those of you out there who are writers, painters, poets, or those who just appreciate soundtrack music (like myself).  This music would certainly inspire the next great mystery or horror novel!  The strength in this music is that it excels in creating imagery.  The cool thing is that it isn't a collection of random noise tracks that drone on and on for an hour.  Each cue is unique and interesting in it's own way and Heil has done a fascinating job of sharing his weird custom made sounds within the world of "Helix".The CD is a 2 disc set that contains season 1 on the first disc and season 2 on the second.  The first disc runs 69:18 and disc two runs 65:03.  Together, your getting about 2 hours and 15 minutes.  The CD also contains an 8 page insert that includes pictures from both seasons, details about the stories from both seasons, composer comments, and production credits.  The CD is produced by La La Land Records and they always do a great job in bringing soundtracks like this to film score fans.  Those of you that have enjoyed the series will certainly like this collection as well.  I wouldn't wait too long because these CDs are usually only for a limited time and numbers.  Enjoy the music or use it to inspire your own creations....I recommend this score!

There is a small acknowledgement in the CD insert from James Horner and in this statement he thanks Antoine Fuqua (director) and John Houlihan (music supervisor) for "giving me the freedom to try out some pretty modern textures of music".  Southpaw is the 35th soundtrack that I have by James Horner and although I haven't heard all of his scores, this one is certainly unique when compared to the ones that I have by him.  Horner has certainly had his share of criticism in the past but with scores like Southpaw and The Wolf Totem (which I discovered last month), the 61 year old composer was still full of creative energy and his work was continuing to evolve.I haven't seen the film and I have to admit that when I first opened the CD, I was half expecting to hear something like "Rocky" or a sports movie french horn fanfare that shows the underdog working his way to the top.  I later learned (by reading the synopsis of the movie), that this is more of a "fall from grace" where a series of tragic events deals a tough blow to the main character.  James Horner's music is very reflective of this and you won't find any fanfares or exercise music here.  The score is reflective, melancholy, and has a subtle tension that grows throughout.  At times, I found the score to be relaxing and having an almost "meditative" quality to it.  Horner has always been impressive with his piano arrangements and you will find that he makes good use of that skill throughout this score.  The main theme is so simple, yet truly powerful.  The really amazing thing is that this almost subliminal approach with the theme has different emotional impacts depending on the other instrumentation/sound effects that Horner uses to surround it.  Horner experiments with a more modern electronic sound throughout the score and this combined with his more traditional approach has some very cool emotional effects on the music.Track 1 (The Preparations), introduces you to the theme.  This haunting and simplistic piano appears throughout the score and Horner (as mentioned previously) surrounds it with different emotions as the story unfolds.  The great thing is that Horner, in his experimentation, never tries to let the modern electronic "textures" overpower the more traditional sounds we are use to hearing from him.  The elegant piano work and modern tech blend together quite beautifully.  I am sure that some credit needs to go to music arrangers Simon Rhodes and Simon Franglen for this as well.  Horner has worked with these two arrangers on several films and this trio's collaboration has produced some great results.Things get a little different when you listen to track 6 (Suicidal Rampage).  This one is a roller coaster ride that truly reflects this cue's title.  It contains all of the emotions from the first five tracks with the inclusion of some very disturbing and scary fits of energy.  The electronic effects and sounds musically paint a picture of painful emotional instability.  Again, I haven't seen this movie yet but I imagine that this music is symbolic of the intense "fall from grace" that the main character endures.The score moves us out of the emotional chaos into track 6 (Empty Showers).  It's a little eerie but then shifts to a peaceful piano (theme) that is calming.  My favorite track is the next one entitled "Dream Crusher".  It's a more traditional orchestra piece that is both sad, beautiful, and moving.  I can just hit repeat and daydream all day with this one.The big climatic music for the score can be found in track 13 (Hope vs Escobar).  At 2:27 in, it sounds like the lions have been let loose from their cages and the battle begins!  The 8 minute cue goes through various tempo and rhythmic changes that, I assume, reflect the big confrontation at the end of the film.  From listening to this piece, I get the sense that there is some flashback moments as well.  I guess I'll have to wait and see how it all plays out in the movie.I have been really impressed with Horner's score because it gave me exactly what I didn't expect.  It's a very emotional score that is very fitting for a story like this.  It looks to be a great film and I am excited to hear how the music fits in with the story.  On it's own, I found the score to be very enjoyable and many of the tracks are unwinding/relaxing.  Many have said that this is James Horner's last score, but I've read that he actually finished work on the upcoming film "Magnificent Seven" directed by Antoine Fuqua as well.  So, we might be hearing some more music by Horner in the future.  Be sure to check out "The Wolf Totem" too.  It's a wonderful score that is quite impressive as well.The CD has 14 tracks with a total running time of 53 minutes.  It comes with a 12 page insert that contains some great pictures from the film and a few credits for score production and a brief word of thanks from James Horner.  The score is released through Sony Classical.  I've noticed that they have also come out with an additional soundtrack for the film that contains the vocal music from the film.  Thank goodness they decided to release two separate soundtracks.  Sometimes they really shortchange the score if they are released together.  I did notice on the other soundtrack that there are two score tracks entitled "A Cry for Love" (parts 1 & 2).  They are pretty short and seem to be basically arrangements of "A Cry for Help" (track 8) on the score release.James Horner has given us some truly amazing film music over his career.  I became a fan when I first heard Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan.  He will be missed but he leaves a legacy of wonderful music for generations to enjoy.  I highly recommend this score!

A while back when the new Robocop movie came out, Pedro Bromfman scored the film and included some of Basil Poledouris's original Robocop theme briefly within the soundtrack.  I had never been able to find the original score for Robocop as it resurfaces every few years and then disappears because of limited runs.  The prices for the CDs obviously get very high and out of my price point so I was very excited to finally catch a re-release this time around.There are quite a few mixed reviews here listed for various versions of the releases so I wanted to clarify that this is the 2015 re-release done by Milan Records.  A few years ago, Intrada Records released a version that contained four previously unreleased tracks:  Have a Heart (2), O.C.P. Monitors (3), Nukem (10), and Big is Better (20).  Thankfully, this version by Milan has those missing cues as well.  In fact, this version by Milan Records is the exact same version that was released by Intrada a few years ago.  It has the same track listing and run time of about 57 minutes.  The only difference between the two versions is the package presentation.  Intrada is well known for putting together very nice collector editions of the media they release which includes really nice pictures on the disc and 20 plus page CD inserts that contain historical information about the film, scoring, and composer.  This particular release by Milan is pretty bare bones and comes in a digipack with no insert.  It does have a picture of Robocop on the inside cover and the disc itself has no picture on it...just black.  The CD itself, however, sounds great on my system and it is awesome to hear the Robocop score in all of it's 80's action/science fiction wonder!  I've always been a fan of Basil Poledouris and film score junkies and fans of Poledouris need a copy of the original Robocop score in their collections.  I'm glad that Milan records re-released this one because otherwise I'd have to pay a lot more to get a copy of it.  I prefer to own physical CDs rather than having everything digital so this looks quite nice in the collection and sounds great in my system.For those of you new to this particular score, I highly recommend this.  Poledouris was a fine composer who unfortunately left this world all too soon.  My favorite soundtrack of all time was composed by him, "Lonesome Dove".  I also am a big fan of the "Conan" scores and "Flesh and Blood".  Poledouris uses a combination of a full size orchestra mixed with very cool sounding 80's gizmo tech to musically bring Robocop to life.  The Robocop theme is a great one and can really get stuck in your head too.  I have found myself whistling the theme for the past few days now.  The score for this film comes and goes so if your interested in this one, you'd better pick it up now before it disappears again!

I usually steer away from movies that deal with robots and A.I. because I've never been impressed with how they present the story.  The only reason why I watched this one was out of sheer boredom with nothing else to watch.  Holy cow, I'm glad I did because this was an amazing story.  Without knowing anything about the movie, except for the fact that it deals with a robot/A.I. of some kind, I gave it a chance to hook me and it surely did.  It's not your typical artificial intelligence gone crazy and robots attacking the world movie and it's not an action romp with explosions and flying cars.  This is a story told with just a handful of characters and it hooked me with my own questions of the possibility of creating artificial intelligence such as this.  Other movies of this genre have never really gripped me with some of the questions and believability of this scenario.  It's very well done and I found the filming, pacing, and acting to be quite incredible.  The story kept me guessing throughout and I never really predicted the ending as the way it played out.  The score for the film is also amazing and really does an incredible job of giving this story a tone/mood that is quite fitting.Without spoiling the movie for you, I will say that this film kind of reminded me of "Frankenstein" a little bit.  Isn't it funny that movies that have the issue of "man creating life" always end pretty bad for "the creator".  The movie makes you wonder if we ever will have the capabilities to create robots with advanced intelligence and what repercussions it will have on mankind.  The topic has been explored for a long time in certain movies and it seems like it is the same old story told over and over.  "Ex Machina" was done very cleverly however and even though I kind of knew where this was going, there were surprises and I just really enjoyed the presentation of the story for this particular film.I'm glad I went into this movie knowing very little about it.  I love science fiction movies but have never really enjoyed many of them dealing with this particular subject.  "Ex Machina" was a great treat for an otherwise boring afternoon and it gave me something to realistically think about when considering the implications of creating robots/artificial intelligence.  I'd recommend giving it a chance and see it for yourself.

I always look forward to the soundtrack scores for the Batman video games.  Nick Arundel's main theme for the Arkham City score is still one of my favorite Batman themes even when compared to the movies.  It's great to hear that theme used again here in various ways in Arkham Knight.  This particular score is listed as Volume 1 and you are getting 27 tracks that run a total of 1 hour and 8 minutes.  The score's last track (27), "Crowd Control", does end abruptly and gives the entire thing a very unfinished feel to it.  I'll be looking forward to how it concludes in Volume 2.The score sounds great and contains a blend of action music (mostly done by Arundel) and a blend of ambient "investigative" music.  At times, the score tends to get really frightening and you would think that it's from a horror film.  Track 17, "Dark Skies", is an example of the more scary side of the score.  The great thing is, the score definitely has the "Arkham Knight feel" to it.  The music fits so well with the story and characters that you can't help but visualize this world the music helps to establish.  I haven't played the game yet but I've watched the demos online and it certainly is impressive.  My favorite track is 24, "All Who Follow You".  I don't know what is happening here in the game...but I like the theme treatment in this particular piece.This is another great score in the series and if you've been following along, you certainly won't be disappointed.  The score for this particular game does sound a bit darker than the others and you can defiantly tell that it isn't quite finished yet.  I assume that this release covers the music from the first half of the game and maybe Volume 2 will conclude the story?For those of you who like to have a physical copy of the score, Amazon offers a CDR of this release.  I have always been impressed with this program offered by Amazon and have bought a few of these in the past.  Typically, their "pressings" of the disc are really quite professional looking.  You'd never tell that it is a CDR burned on demand for you.  They come packaged looking like something you'd buy from a real record company.  However, recently Amazon seems to be getting a little slack in this department and are cutting some corners on how these CDR discs look.  In the past, you'd have a picture stamped on the disc, a back cover with the track listing on it, and better organization of the liner notes etc.  The last two CDRs that I have purchased (San Andreas & Arkham Knight) share the same problems.  You still get a CD insert on the glossy paper, photos from the game (or movie), but no picture on the disc and the back cover on the CD case is basically blank.  The track listing is done in a weird way too.  The track listing begins on page 2 and because there isn't enough room to put the last track on...they insert it on page 7 by itself.  If they continue to look like this, I'll just burn the things myself.  All of my Batman video game scores are CDRs and this one by far is the cheapest looking one.  I just always liked owning physical copies of CDs and I was always impressed with Amazon's packaging of these.  Just wanted to throw those thoughts out there for those of you who have bought these in the past as well.

I've been looking for some traditional Bluegrass/Folk music lately and I came upon this particular collection by Craig Duncan.  The album is all instrumental and that was the primary draw for me here.  It's hard to find versions of these songs that uses the traditional instrumentation.  I've sampled a lot of them and many of the ones that I listened to are done by just brass bands.  I wanted to hear these songs performed with the fiddles and banjos that are typically associated with them.Craig Duncan has over 90 albums that range from Polkas, Bluegrass, Folk, and even Celtic music.  He has even done Bluegrass versions of Beatles songs!  He primarily produces music CDs for the gift shop market but also performs with his various musical groups in a wide array of events and galas.  He has a website where you can even book him for weddings!  Duncan is a very accomplished musician and on this particular recording he is credited with playing the Hammered Dulcimer and Fiddles.  He is accompanied by 7 other musicians who play various banjos, guitars, bass, and whistles.  There are 15 tracks here and the running time on the CD is about 45 minutes.  A four page insert is included that contains music credits and additional information concerning other albums by Duncan.The CD sounds great and the music/songs here are some very popular selections from the period.  "Dixie", "Bonnie, Blue Flag", and "Lorena" are all here and played by some great musicians that Duncan has assembled.  The only issue I have with this particular recording is that the songs sound a bit too pretty.  It's as if I where listening to some professional musicians in a concert hall.  Yeah...they are using the traditional instruments of the period but it is missing a bit of the passion behind the music.  I did stumble across another group of musicians who seem to capture that passion that I am speaking of.  The 2nd South Carolina String Band has a few albums with traditional folk music of this period and they sound great.  There is singing in these versions but they are wonderful and really have that "knee slapping" vibe to them.  I would say that Duncan's album is more relaxed and has a bit more of a "sophisticated" approach to these songs.  My favorite from Duncan's album is the last track entitled "Shiloh Hill".  It's a great tune and wonderfully done.  Be sure to check out 2nd South Carolina Band too.

The other day I was digging through a stack of old vinyl records that I had picked up from a yard sale and found a box set that contained four records and it was entitled "Great Movie Themes Vol. 1".  It was released by London "Phase 4" records and upon listening to it I was really memorized by some of the old classic scores that it contained.  Among them were selections of "For Whom the Bell Tolls", "The Big Country", and "Breakfast at Tiffany's".  The latter selection was one that I found myself repeating the most.  Now, I've heard "Moon River" before but it certainly has been a long time.  I remember watching the movie on VHS tape years ago and loved the moment when Audrey Hepburn sang the tune.  I decided to finally get a copy of the score and was delighted to see that Intrada Records had released a version.  I'd seen the RCA version in used stores and bargain bins for years but never picked it up.  I'm glad I waited.  I've been collecting and listening to soundtrack scores for a long time and I've always been very fond of the Intrada Records label because of their dedication in bringing complete and previously unreleased scores to fans of the genre.The original RCA recording is approximately 30 minutes and it doesn't even contain Hepburn's vocal of "Moon River".  This Intrada Records release contains this and gives you the entire musical score from the film.  Other later releases for "Breakfast at Tiffany's" boasted that they had the complete score...but not so.  This particular release contains 1 hour and 19 minutes of music and much of it has never been released before.  This particular version contains the complete "Where's the Cat" cue which according to the liner notes by Douglass Fake is the "most stirring orchestral crescendos and codas in all film music".  It's pretty powerful indeed.  Remember the scene at near the end of the movie when Hepburn tosses her pet cab out of the taxi and into the rain?  Peppard (Paul) goes out to get the cat and Hepburn (Holly) runs after him.  They find the cat and Hepburn/Peppard embrace (with cat in-between them) and the music explodes with a chorus and big orchestral version of "Moon River".  It's here on this release!There is a 24 page insert that gives a lot of historical info about the film and the music.  The two contributors in the liner notes are Douglass Fake and Jeff Bond (author of "Danse Macabre: 25 Years of Danny Elfman & Tim Burton").  Both authors provide a wealth of information concerning the movie, score, and Mancini's process for developing the music.  There are plenty of pictures from the movie and publicity photos in the insert as well.  The folks at Intrada have even gone out of their way to include the piano practice pieces that you hear in the background scene where Holly's neighbors "contribute to the overall ambience of sophisticated apartment life" (pg. 20, Douglass Fake).It's a great release and Mancini's music sounds wonderful on the CD.  The producers of the CD have really done a great job in bringing to you the best audio possible.  Mancini's music on the score is both fun, comical and even serious.  It's a great party CD and would provide some wonderful "Cha Cha" dancing music to entertain with.  I'm just enthralled with the "Moon River" melody and love to hear how Mancini tinkers with it throughout the score.  Very impressed with this release and I applaud Intrada again!  Now...that melody from "For Whom the Bell Tolls" was a great one too.  I guess that is what I am on the hunt for next.  I've heard that maybe Varese Sarabande might have a good recording of that one....hmmmm.

This movie sure has been getting a beating!  I'd never heard of it until I was checking out whats new for "New Release Tuesday".  Pickings were slim for this week and this seemed to be the only promising movie so I went with it and really enjoyed it.  Yeah, it has it's slow moments and I agree that we have seen this story in various iterations before...but it was still fun to watch.  While watching the movie, the score grabbed my attention and I thought that it really fit the film well.  I don't specifically try to pay attention to a film score when I am watching a movie nor do I try to purchase every soundtrack for every film that I watch.  If there are particular moments in the film where the score really starts to stand out to me, I will usually investigate further by sampling tracks and reading reviews.  I was disappointed to see that this score was only being released digitally because I prefer to buy physical CDs instead...but I liked it enough to download it and make my own backup copy.Martin Tillman & Satnam Ramgotra are part of the Hans Zimmer empire known as Remote Control Productions.  Zimmer has amassed quite the collection of very talented composers, arrangers, conductors, and musicians.  Tillman and Ramgotra team up to bring us the music for a tale of revenge and while it isn't as good or as thematic as Hans Zimmer's "King Arthur", it still manages to be a worthy listen.  There is a theme here in the music and that is what originally caught my attention when watching the film.  It is ever so slight, only consisting of a few notes, and it's simplicity is what makes it stand out so powerfully within the context of the movie.  You can hear it in the opening track entitled "Eviction".  You'll hear variations of it pop in and out on tracks like "Advantage", "Last Knights" and "Capital".  The score is a mix of musical drone, drums, drone and drums, melodic pieces, and haunting vocal tracks featuring Natacha Atlas.  The drone pieces can be the least interesting  but do a great job of building tension in the movie.  Pieces like "Construction" and "Traitor" are examples of these.  They tend to provide a more ambient effect and can be pretty relaxing to listen to on their own however.  There are times when the score shifts in some really cool percussion movements like track 4 ("Battle") and track 9 ("Castle").  I think my favorite tracks are those that feature the mesmerizing vocals of Natacha Atlas.  At times they are soothing and others just hauntingly beautiful.  The composers were smart to use her on a number of pieces throughout the score.  She provides her voice on 7 tracks and each one is great.The score isn't a loud action noise romp and it certainly isn't a thematic epic.  At times it is a menacing growl where the thought of revenge boils deep in the characters.  It also has moments where a slight theme develops showing that heroism hasn't been defeated and the vocals of Natacha Atlas reminds us of the pain throughout it all.  I think it's a good score and worthy of my purchase...even if I did have to get it digitally.  The digital download gives you 18 tracks for a total running time of 1 hour and 4 minutes.

After a rather traumatic movie experience as a child courtesy of Old Yellar, Where the Red Fern Grows, and Bambi...I've made it a rule to never watch movies that have animals as the main stars.  That doesn't mean that I won't enjoy the music that comes from these films however!  It's been a while since I've purchased a score for an "animal movie".  I think the last one was "War Horse" by John Williams.  I won't go see this film, but I do like the premise behind it.  The training that these service dogs go through and their dedication/loyalty to their handlers is something indeed worthy of showcasing in a film.  I did happen to watch the film's trailer and the stand out scene from that was the dog (Max) attending the funeral of his handler who I assume was killed in action.  What a powerful scene indeed.  Seeing this scene and the rest of the trailer got me curious to listen to the soundtrack.Movies that star animals are designed to elicit a very strong emotional response from audiences.  Animals like dogs, cats, dolphins and horses usually have the biggest emotional impact on viewers.  Unfortunately for me, these films are such an emotional roller coaster ride!  You'll be bursting in tears one minute and laughing/crying the next.  I just can't take it.  Movies of this nature require scores that are just as equally powerful as the stories they are trying to tell.  I think that is why I am at least a fan of the music for these films.Travor Rabin takes the helm to bring this particular stories music to us.  Rabin's past work includes "I Am Number Four", "National Treasure", and "The Great Raid".  I really enjoyed his work with "The Great Raid" and have been anxiously waiting to hear what he has in store for us with this movie.  When the CD arrived, the first thing I noticed was the release's short length.  There are 17 tracks on the album and the total running time is about 38 minutes.  This was a big disappointment because from past experiences with short releases such as this, they are usually over before they have any real time to develop.  One particular cue that I really like is entitled "Bike Toss" (track 4).  It's only 42 seconds long and right when it appears to be going somewhere it abruptly ends.  I'm not sure if this is the actual cut that was used in the film or if this is an edited version for an album release.  This is something that happens quite often when movie scores are released.  They are altered and sometimes hacked up pretty bad.  Not sure if this is what is happening here.The good news is that there is still some great music to enjoy here...even if the entire running time is only 38 minutes.  The stand out scene from the movie trailer where Max attends the funeral naturally gets its own music entitled "Max Rushes Coffin" (track 2).  It's short length will make you want more but Rabin's very solemn and soft approach to this scene will definitely squeeze the tears out of the audience for sure.  Other cues for the score are more peppy and adventurous.  One in particular is "Bike Ride" (track 5).  It sounds OK but it tends to remind me of something like a main title for a syndicated TV show.  As I mentioned earlier, movies like this are real emotional roller coaster rides and Rabin's score reflects this.  Moving from sentimental, adventurous, and dark within a short amount of time.  Some tracks like "Realist or Hero" use a echoey guitar effect like that which can be found in the movies "Lone Survivor" and "Friday Night Lights" by Explosions in the Sky.  I've noticed a trend to use this guitar effect in a lot of war/battle/fight movies.  Danny Elfman's "The Kingdom" is another example.  Two highlight tracks from the score are "Epilogue" (track 16) and "Max's Suite" (track 17).  You'll find all of the major themes created by Rabin here.  They are put together nicely and really capture the musical essence of the movie."Fireworks Display" (Track 6) is another fine piece that is beautifully put together by Rabin.  The first half of this piece plays with the main theme softly and it slowly moves into something a bit darker and sad.  The instrumentation for the "darker" section of this piece uses a trumpet to signify a flashback of war effect.  It's well done and plenty powerful for such a scene in the movie.The physical CD itself comes with an 8 page insert that contains pictures from the film, track listing, and orchestra credits.  The CD is released through Sony Classical.  I wish the released score could have been longer.  It has some great music here and it seems over too quickly.  I won't have any problem listening to these however and enjoying them for what they are.  It is a spirited score that contains a great theme, adventurous music, and stirring sentimental moments.  Fans of the movie will no doubt enjoy listening to this and reliving their time with Max or letting their imaginations create their own adventures.

Joesph Bishara's work has always been very unique and intriguing to me.  Hearing his score for the first Insidious movie made me an instant fan largely because of his technique in delivering something different for audiences.  His film scores are very unique indeed and probably not the type of music that you are going to sit down and relax to or play in the background while reading a book (unless it's a horror story).  I usually like to take my film music to work with me and to play in the background while I'm working.  I probably won't be taking this one!  I would hate to see the effect it has on my co-workers!  So what good is music like this outside of watching the movie?  As I listen to it, I can imagine that a writer or artist (of the horror genre) would be inspired by this as they create something from their own imaginations.  I listen to it mostly to appreciate the artistry and technique that went into creating it.  I also like to use certain selections of Bishara's music when creating my "haunted front porch" every halloween.  Fans of the Insidious movies will love this music because they can take with them probably one of biggest contributors of their horror experience...the music itself.Hearing Bishara's music from the first Insidious movie made me want to investigate more of this composer's work.  I have enjoyed his work from all of the Insidious films, as well as, "Dark Skies", "The Conjuring", and "11-11-11".  There is no doubt that his expertise is with the horror genre and I am looking forward to hearing his up coming project, "The Vatican Tapes".Bishara continues with his experimental soundscape and again impresses with "Insidious: Chapter 3".  I have given this particular score the nickname "Boom Soundtrack" because of Bishara's very frequent use of surprise moments within the score.  He has done it with his other work, but the frequency seems to be intensified here.  When listening to this score, I would often turn the volume up really loud to hear the almost inaudible things that Bishara is doing in the background within the music.  As I was listening intensely to what was going on in the quiet depths of underscoring, I was often blown back to the other side of the room with the surprise "booms" that would occur unexpectedly.  There are a lot of moments like this within the score.  I haven't seen the movie yet, but there is bound to be surprises a plenty throughout the story.What makes Bishara's music so unique is the very unconventional style he uses to submerse the audience in fear.  It's part ambient, electronic, and orchestral.  He uses instrumentation that is very bizarre and quiet frightening to listen to.  Weird sounding violins, random noises, and other things that can be quiet difficult to describe.  The most memorable past composers of the horror genre developed a sound of their own and Bishara has definitely achieved one that distinctly belongs to him.  He may have gained inspiration from ambient artist like Robert Rich but he has pushed further into a musical formula that cooks up the best results for subliminal fear.  Track 17, "Facing Breathing", is a highlight track where Bishara seems to take anything that makes sound and throws it together to create chaotic horror.  It's like dragging your nails across a chalkboard and watching everyone squirm.  He also tampers with creating some very nice breathers for the audience like tracks 3 (Tell of Presence) and track 8 (Questions Left Behind).  These begin to show a more melodic, sentimental, and almost relaxing side of Bishara's work.  He doesn't stay there long however.  Once you begin to relax with "Questions Left Behind" it slowly starts to drift into creepy land again.  Bishara closes this score out with a chilling cue entitled, "Void Figure 7 Ch 3".  I gave it a nickname too.  I call it, "Violin lesson for the insane".It will be interesting to see how Joesph Bishara develops as an artist in future projects.  I am always interesting in listening to his work and I have always enjoyed appreciating his skills as an artist with this particular style of music.  Fans of the Insidious movies will love to have this latest chapter of music from Bishara.I waited several weeks to obtain the physical copy of the music.  I'm not sure why it takes so long...but it was worth it because I wanted to add it to the rest of my Bishara collection.  The CD comes packaged like many of Bishara's other releases.  A tri-fold cardboard case that has a sleeve to hold the CD.  The art work from the cover continues throughout the packaging and there is a song list and credits on the CD sleeve.  The CD contains 22 tracks and the total running time for the album is 43 minutes.

While preparing for summer traveling, I thought it might be a good idea to get a good gun safe for the car.  I picked this one up at Cabela's but currently Amazon has it for $10 cheaper.  Anyway, I must say that the safe feels pretty robust and the "TriPoint" mechanism works great too.  The safe is large enough to accommodate my Colt 1911 45 and a spare clip.  The key works perfectly and turns smoothly in the keyhole.The only fault I can find with the safe is that the security cable doesn't look like much and the washer lug that is on the cable is much too big for the loop to go through (or maybe the cable openings are too small).  There was no way that it was going to go through the loop end of the cable.  I tried a vice and pliers.  So, time for some modifications!  I took my rotary tool and gave the washer a shave and now it works just fine.  I think Hornady spent to much time making a "super washer" and not a better cable.  I've included a picture to show what I did...so be prepared to do same thing.  One more thing that I suggest, when you open the box, mine had a small square piece of black foam (like that on the inside of the safe) that keeps the safe from bouncing around inside of the packaging box.  Keep that piece of foam!  When I shut my safe with the 45 and the extra clip, I noticed that the clip likes to slide around a little inside.  I certainly don't want any extra scratches on my gun.  Taking that extra square piece and placing it over the clip solves that problem and keeps it from moving around.Overall, despite having to do some modifications, I am pretty pleased with the safe.  It certainly isn't a match for some pliers/bolt cutters...but lets just hope the bad guys are not carrying around tool bags with them.  More importantly, it will keep the kids away,  protect the gun while traveling, and appease some states concealed carry laws.

Intrada Records works their magic again to bring us a score that has been on my "most wanted list" since 1995.  Alan Silvestri's score for Judge Dredd was truly impressive and I was so disappointed with the initial Epic Records release when the movie came out.  It was 40 minutes of score music but I felt that they had left so much out.  This version release by Intrada, however, is the complete actual score with plenty of extras.Alan Silvestri's score for the film is outstanding.  He uses a big orchestra, choir, and has some really cool percussion work in the music.  The Judge Dredd theme and the march like percussion bits are some of the most memorable to me as I was watching the film.  The film itself was OK but there is no question that this music by Silvestri is pretty epic.  He does a great job of mixing heroic action adventure, science fiction grandeur, military marches, and emotional elements all in one.  I know this is the recipe for a lot of movies these days but Silvestir's score really adds the flavor here.  Silvestri's "Predator" score and this one are probably my two favorite in this genre by him.The Intrada release was supposed to be out in May 2015 but shipments were stopped due to an error in putting this together.  Apparently the Jerry Goldsmith trailer music on Disc 1 turned out to be a re-recording conducted by Joel McNeely, and not the original version.  Well, you got to hand it to Intrada for getting things done right.  The release was halted while new copies with the corrected track could be placed.  I believe some of the "incorrect" versions were shipped out and those lucky enough to have them probably have a nice collectable on their hands.This particular release comes with two discs which total 2 hours and 20 minutes of music.  Disc 1 contains the complete version of the score and ends with the original trailer music which was composed and conducted by Jerry Goldsmith.  Disc 2 contains all of the alternate takes, and the score from the original 1995 Epic Records release.  You also get a 28 page book that contains tons of info about the film, scoring process, and the recording for this release.  Did you know that the original Epic Records release contains 40 minutes of music that went unused in the original film?  The nearly 70 minutes of music on disc 1 is the actual music (in order) that was used in the film.  Also, David Arnold was the director's first choice for the music since they had collaborated together on other projects.  The producers felt that Arnold was too young and untested for the job.  Jerry Goldsmith was then approached but could not do it because of other obligations.  Goldsmith did agree to write the trailer music however and this was released some 4 months before the films' actual release on June 30, 1995.  The 28 page CD insert has a lot of info like this and more.  Intrada records does a fabulous job of bringing film scores like this to fans.  As of now, this title isn't available on Amazon but I expect it to be soon...unless Intrada sells out of them!It's a great Alan Silvestri score and one that I can finally enjoy in it's entirety for the first time.  I highly recommend!

I've never had the opportunity to see this movie but I can remember as a kid having the movie version picture book and being fascinated by the story and the look of these characters.  I've had the DVD version of this movie sitting in my Amazon wish list for some time now but I've been waiting for the Blu-Ray version to go down in price.  The soundtrack has eluded me for years as well and it's nice to see that Intrada Records has finally released the most complete version of this score by David Shire to date.  Your going to pay a premium a price for this collector's CD but considering the extras, it is indeed worth it.I'd never heard of David Shire before obtaining this soundtrack.  He has primarily worked on TV shows and only a handful of feature films.  He did the original music for "2010" and "Zodiac".  He also composed music for "Saturday Night Fever" and was nominated for a few Grammy Awards. After listening to the outstanding music from "Return to Oz", one might be curious to know why Shire was not offered other feature film projects.  In the liner notes for "Return to Oz", it's stated that "Because of the ill fate suffered by the film, Shire's masterpiece failed to stimulate the global recognition and blockbuster projects he richly deserved" (pg. 21).  It goes on to say that this was the first time Shire was offered such a project and he thought that it would lead to other films as well.  But unfortunately this wasn't the case.  It's a shame because the music, which I am enjoying for the first time, is just outstanding.  As a kid, I could only see the pictures from the film in a book.  Hearing the music that belongs to these characters and their story for the first time is really cool.  The entire score is very thematic indeed.  I think there is something in the neighborhood of nine different themes here.  Each one represents different characters and they really give the magic of life to their personalities.  The music can simply be described as everything you'd expect for a fantasy adventure.  Intrada Records does a fabulous job of sequencing the cues together and in the order you'd hear them in the story.  The music is so good that it essentially tells the story on it's own.Intrada has packaged this together really nicely and your getting a lot here.  There are two CDs with disc one containing the most complete version of the score which includes all the stuff that other versions never did.  Disc one runs a total of 74:35.  Disc two contains alternate takes, revised versions, and the complete 1985 release version.  Disc two runs 76:54.  The CD insert is a 28 page book that contains pictures from the film and a wealth of historical information concerning the film, director, and composer.  With 2 hours and 32 minutes of music and a wonderful 28 page insert, this is a great soundtrack for fans and collectors alike.  It's easy to see why this is considered to be David Shire's masterpiece because it most certainly is a great score for all to enjoy.

My 5 year old son loves finding creepy crawlies so I decided to get this for him this summer.  I was lucky to find it on Amazon's "Deal of the Day" for a great price so that was a bonus as well.  The bucket itself seems to made pretty well, but I'd be careful with it over concrete.  A good drop would probably crack the clear plastic for sure.  The main lid of the bucket and the latch are nicely done and can be easily opened and closed by my son.  It has an adjustable strap for easy carrying as well.
