I was reading the reviews concerning the magnifying lid portion of the bucket and how it doesn't stay closed or breaks off easily.  Upon inspecting this myself, I would probably agree with everyone else that this is probably the bucket's main weakness.  I've decided to leave the little "Look Inside" sticker on it because it helps to secure the mag lid down.  If my 5 year old decides to pull it off, I could easily replace it with some clear tape.  The magnifying glass on top is really cool because it really does work.  Unlike some other cheap plastic magnifying glasses that barely "magnify", this particular one really does a decent job of making objects larger.  The top of the bucket has small holes to let air inside as well.  Very small insects (ants) could easily get out I suppose, so I wouldn't suggest trying to make this a "habitat" for captured specimens.  This is more of a temporary catch and release philosophy here.There are a lot of possibilities with this bucket.  You can collect just about anything and observe it more closely.  Tadpoles in water, rocks, leaves, and insects.  My son should have a lot of fun with this over the summer and it should offer plenty of educational opportunities too.  Let's just hope he doesn't pick up any fire ants and poison ivy!  I recommend.

This is my first soundtrack by composer Cody Westheimer.  My brought my attention to this particular soundtrack was the theme of space.  I love "space" scores and music like this is great to kick back, close your eyes and dream of exploring the unknown.  This soundtrack was in my Amazon recommendations list and after sampling a few tracks, I decided to give it a try.In doing some research about the composer, he primarily has been working on short films and documentaries.  He will be doing a full feature film this year, "Iron Will".  Now, this particular score is for the documentary that was put together by NASA which showcases future deep space exploration programs.  It was an IMAX film presented in 2015 but unfortunately I wasn't able to see it.  It was narrated by Patrick Stewart and received generally good reviews.  The film was only 45 minutes long and the score presented here is 23 tracks with a total runtime of 36 minutes.  So, it is a short score and unfortunately some of the pieces seem to be over before they even have time to develop.  You have to remember however, that this is a score for a documentary and not a full length feature film.  It would of been cool if Westheimer could have developed some of these cues a little longer for a more substantial album release.Another interesting thing to note is that the individual cues themselves can have a lot of variation in them and the score as a whole does not have the consistency of a feature film.  The first 6 tracks are very traditional sounding with full orchestration, for example, and then other more electronic sounds are introduced later in other cues.  Track 7, "Space Science", is supported with electronic percussion and guitars.  Another example is track 15, "How to Build a Spacesuit", which has a funky groove beat going on.  They seem a bit out of place when listening to this score as a whole but they are enjoyable to listen to nonetheless.Some of the standout pieces for me were:An Eye on the CosmosExtended WeightlessnessMars in my BackyardThe Exploring KindRed Planet ArrivalTwo tracks worth mentioning are Westheimer's arrangements of Holst's "Mars" (Track 12) and Johann Strauss's "Blue Danube" (Track 23).  Track 23 might be more of an outtake because of it's slight comical ending and the fact that you hearing people talking and laughing at the end.  The two pieces are arranged after some very popular space classical tunes and are very fitting for a documentary score.These are some of the more developed tracks that really can capture the wonder of space.  Overall, it's a great documentary score and fun to listen to.  The short length and inconsistent variation might turn some others away.  I've organized the score a little differently into a play list and plan to take it with me on my next camping trip.  There are some great star gazing tracks here and laying in a hammock with the headphones on listening to this will be an enjoyable experience.The CD comes with a four paneled insert that contains a blurb concerning the possibility of future space travel and a note from the director/writer of the film, Mark Krenzien.  The CD is produced by Phineas Atwood productions and Lake Shore Records.

We certainly have a fascination with disaster films.  From towering infernos to world wide climate change, we just can't seem to get enough.  Some of these films are better than others and they usually make a pretty decent profit in theaters.  Hollywood continues to push them out and many gladly pay to see them.  We've seen the story before so what is the big draw to see them?  It's probably because they are just fun to watch!  Also, disaster films seduce us with the incredible special effects and you have to admit that Hollywood is getting better with this all the time.  Yes, it's the same story with even better realism.  Now, within those really cool effects we've got to have a story somewhere and with that your going need to support it with music.  Hollywood can spend a lot of money on the effects but the only way to make them "special" and truly stand out is with a soundtrack to make them even more emotionally incredible.Looking through my collection of movie scores, I've noticed that the music for these films can be a mixed bag sometimes.  Some reflect the musical tastes of the time in which they were created while others tend to be gigantic filler music pumped with a large brass section of the orchestra.  There are a few that take the interesting approach of having the music take on the characteristic of the impending doom like that of Laurence Rosenthal's "Meteor" score.  This particular score, composed by Andrew Lockington, is very similar to what Harald Kloser did for "The Day After Tomorrow" and "2012".  It's a pretty big sound throughout the score that blends a lot of action noise with an occasional developed theme.  I'm leaning towards Lockington's score here however because when the theme comes, it's a pretty good one.  I also enjoy his scoring of the more emotional moments in the movie and instead of rushing through these scenes with only a steady hum of the violins, he puts up an effort to give some really heartfelt moments.  Tracks 12 (Remembering Mallory) and part of 13 (Coit Tower Destroyed)  are example's of this.  There are some really great action themes in the score as well that I am sure do a good job of reflecting some big moments in the movie.  One of my favorites in this score is the very epic sounding "Skydive" (track 14).  It's a short cue but a very cool one.  As a matter of fact, the shortest tracks are some of the best in my opinion.  I guess it's because some of the longer ones tend to get a little exhausting to listen to because of the intensity they sometimes reach.  I am sure this has a different feel when watching in context with the movie however.  They can be enjoyed and appreciated on there own but I find myself developing playlist of the shorter cues.  Some of my favorites are "San Francisco" (6), "Main Title" (1), "Skydive" (14), "Extinction" (18), and "I Love You Dad" (21).  Another cue deserving a mention is number 22, "Resuscitation", it's a great combo of theme, action, and emotion that is put together especially well and very fitting for what is probably a big climatic moment at the end of the movie.There are some other interesting facts about this particular score that can be found in the CD's liner notes.  One is that Lockington used seismic wave data from the San Andreas fault and turned it into music.  I just wish there was more of an explanation of this, in the liner notes, and how it was used in specific tracks.  I do appreciate Lockington's desire to create this score in a unique way by using the "music of an earthquake".  I just wish this could of been explored more to give this particular music an even more interesting sound.  To me, the score tends to nestle a little too close with the other disaster scores of recent times and doesn't find a way to "break away".  By no means does it make it a bad score for the movie, in fact, it's a good score with some awesome moments.  I encourage film music fans to hear for themselves.  One track in particular is really shaking things up and that is Sia's rendition of California Dreamin'.  It's a great song for the film and the interpretation fit's very well.  Oddly, she isn't even mentioned in the credits of the CD insert.I like to own physical CDs so I was upset to see that this was a digital release and the only way to get a physical copy was to go through the CDR route with Amazon.  I've purchased other CDRs from Amazon before and I've always been impressed with their packaging of these.  They include picture discs, liner notes, and everything you'd expect with the "look" of a store bought CD.  They sound great and they've been pretty nice to purchase.  This particular CDR was a little more expensive than their other previous offerings however and I was disappointed to see that they skimped a little with this particular package.  They've included some pictures from the movie and recording sessions and there is a note from the composer which is cool but they only have the track listing on the inside of the CD.  The back cover of the CD has nothing.  The listed credits are incomplete and the total package seems a bit plain to me.  It's still a bit better than what I could of done with my CD burner and printer however.The score has a total of 24 tracks and runs about 1 hour and 13 minutes.

I purchased this battery to replace my Midlands which will no longer hold a charge. I have the GXT series and we mainly use them on camping trips. Well, the summer is here and camping trips are fast approaching so it's off to Amazon to find some replacements. There certainly are a lot of options here on Amazon for these batteries (and most batteries in general) and I was originally going to just buy some more made by Midland. These are higher priced however and the reviews for them are terrible. I was glad to see that there were some others that were offered at a fraction of the cost but after reading reviews for several different ones it seems that purchasing any of these "cheaper" batteries is really hit or miss. Well, I took the gamble and decided to go for these.The first thing that I noticed however after inspecting these batteries is that they are not made by Hitech and they are not 800mAh. I had noticed that some of the other more recent reviews had stated this as well but assumed that it had just been a shipping mistake. I wanted to go for the 800mAH batteries because of the battery life increase. The "mAH" stands for milli amp hours and moving from a 700 to 800 gives you about 14.29% more battery life. So, I was a little disappointed to see that these are not exactly what was advertised. I need some batteries however, and because of the great price, I just decided to stick with these. They charged up on my Midland charger just fine. Both lights stayed a steady red while charging and both batteries heated up indicating that they something was happening. I charged them for about 14 hours. It says to charge them for 16 hours but I had to leave for work and I didn't want these things sitting in the cradle all day and explode or catch on fire. I've had them for about 3 days and they are holding their charge well. I've been playing around with them around the house with my four year old and everything seems to be working ok so far.  The batteries have a Fenzer label and not Hitech and it is also important to note that they are not 800mAh.  They do work fine so far however and I will be sure to post updates if I encounter a problem.

The movie trailers for Mad Max: Fury Road were incredibly intense and it looks like the movie is promising action packed insanity throughout.  A film like this will certainly need the octane boost of a powerful action score to keep it moving and Junkie XL is a great choice.  I have been enjoying other scores by Tom Holkenborg (Junkie XL) such as "Divergent" and "300: Rise of an Empire" and it seems most fitting to have this composer move over the world of Mad Max.While I agree that sometimes soundtrack music doesn't always have to sound good on it's own and that every film score isn't a John William's fanfare, I do think that successful soundtrack music can evoke emotions and paint a picture all on it's own.  Believe me, there are some bad scores out there that absolutely go no where and are just noise and there are others that are so distracting that I can't even bare to watch the movie.  I certainly don't listen to movie scores hoping to hear the next Mozart symphony.  Give me some great music and I'll make my own movie while I daydream.  So what does Junkie XL give us?  An exciting score infused with action music that will set you onto an imaginary warpath into the apocalyptic future!  Just as an action movie needs explosions and stunts this score is filled with everything you'd expect.  Thumping drums, epic climatic music, orchestrated power ballads (so you can catch your breath), and futuristic electronic gizmo sounds to make it sound cool.  I love those electronic explosion sounds that you hear scattered throughout some of the pieces!The score opens with "Survive" and it's like a cover to a book.  It let's you know what's coming.  I dare you to turn this one up loud (like I did when I first popped this CD in) because as it moves into the next track, "Escape", it will scare the mess out of you.  I literally jumped...trust me.  There are plenty of great moments throughout and I enjoy listening to how Junkie XL tinkers with electronic and traditional instrumentation to achieve some really cool sounds.  The drum rhythms are marching, war like, and hard hitting throughout much of the score and there is plenty of variety to keep things interesting.  Things do slow down from time to time however.  You've gotta have those moments too in the action movies.  Track 16, "My Name is Max", is one such example.  It's a piece that hums along but never really gives me anything but a...piece that just hums along.  I liked tracks 12 (Redemption) and 13 (Many Mothers) better for the slower pieces.  As I said earlier, I like it when music gives me a picture and track 15 (Chapter Doof) does just that.  The last 2 minutes of this piece reminds me of a "last warrior walking through the battlefield" music.  Track 17, "Let Them Up", is really cool.  It's a great closing piece that is worthy of a hero riding off in the sunset in their four wheeled war machine.  My favorite track for the score would probably be number 10 (Brother's in Arms).  It's a really cool "rally the troops and go to battle" track that is just awesome.So, I'm probably not going to be sipping my cappuccino while watching the birds through the window eat out of the feeder with this playing in the background.  I'll save Mozart for that.  I'll let the "theatre of the mind" create it's own adventures with this one.  I'll enjoy and appreciate the artistry of Junkie XL.  Tom Holkenborg has done an outstanding job here.  Just be careful not to listen to this while driving.  This would not be safe music to play in a traffic jam!  I heard one reviewer of the film say that this was one of the most insane action movies ever made.  Well, I'll have to wait and see the film for myself to see if that is true.  I do know, however, that this score is a good fit for a movie of that description...and that is a good thing!I am a CD fan and it certainly isn't fun having the mp3 world get the better deal here.  The CD contains 17 tracks and 1 hour and 11 minutes of music.  The digital version has 26 tracks with extended versions and bonus tracks.  Most people are probably going to opt for the digital version and I don't really blame them.  Unfortunately this seems to be a growing trend that I have noticed more and more lately with CDs and digital music.  The CD has an 8 panel insert that contains a photo from the film and 3 lobby card like photos of 3 different characters (one being Mad Max of course).  There are also credits to the orchestra and others involved with the making of the score.  The CD is produced by WaterTower music.

I haven't played Bloodborne and I don't even own an Xbox One or PS4 yet.  I am still enjoying all of the games that the older systems still offer.  I do like soundtracks however and the music used to support the action/story in video games can be equivalent to or even better than some blockbuster movies.  Some of my most treasured and listened to scores come from video games and when big titles come out I am always there to check out the music.  Bloodborne has certainly been met with a lot anticipation from the video game world.  I am not sure if the game has meet those expectations but the score is definitely a big hit with me.The score was composed by in house artist from the company who developed the game, "From Software".  They are Tsukas Saitoh, Yuka kitamura, and Nobuyoshi Suzaki.  Cris Velasco also worked on the score but unfortunately his work is not included on the CD release.  There are also two guest composers who worked on the score and they are Ryan Amon and Michael Wandmacher.  There is a digital release that can be found on iTunes that includes Cris Velasco's contributions, as well as, other tracks by Amon and Wandmacher that were not released on this CD.  I think there is a total of four extra songs on the digital version but you'll have to pay for it.  The digital release is priced quite high for these additional songs and the Amazon CD release is a lot cheaper.  The missing songs are:  "Terror" (Cris Velasco), Amygdala (Cris Velasco), "of the Pthumerian Line" (Michael Wandmacher), and "Lullaby for Mergo" (Ryan Amon).  The composers that I am most familiar with on this project are Ryan Amon and Michael Wandmacher.  Ryan Amon composed the music for the film "Elysium" and did an outstanding job for that movie.  Michael Wandmacher did the music for "Piranha 3D" and "Punisher".  The "Punisher" soundtrack is just awesome and it still is one of my most played soundtracks.What brought my attention to this particular video game score was sampling the first track entitled, "Omen".  This track is a great introduction to the score and pretty much establishes the tone for the entire work as a whole.  What amazes me is that while you have so many different artist working on the same score, they have managed to remain consistent throughout the entire thing.  There are no major stylist differences that sound out of place.  You'd never know it was put together by so many.  The tone and style of the score is very epic horror.  It is a big sound filled with a real orchestra and choir.  The orchestra, in fact, is a 65 piece ensemble with a 32 piece choir.  I did an internet search to learn more about these talented musicians/vocalist and found a really cool video of a recording session.  Check out the bald guy in the white t-shirt rocking out with that cello!  He is definitely getting into the music and it's easy to hear why.  The soundtrack is amazing.  It's incredibly big and lumbers at times like a giant smashing through the woods.  It also becomes quite spiritual (in a creepy way) at times and featured vocalist, Melissa Reese, does a great job singing melodies that will make the hairs on the back of your neck stand up.  Tracks like "Cleric Beast" by Tsukasa Saitoh remind me of a classic requiem infused with horror while others like "Moonlight Melody" by Ryan Amon are hauntingly beautiful and yet sad.  It's a great score to listen to but don't expect too many slow reflective moments.  It's all about action of the horror kind and this haunted house score on steroids isn't going to let you close your eyes for long.The score is 1 hour and 12 minutes and contains 21 tracks.  The CD insert is a six paneled trifold that contains information about the artist, song list, and two pictures from the game.  I wish it had included more art work and a list of the musicians/vocalist.  The vocalist are listed as "Metro Voices" but there isn't any title for the orchestra.It's a great soundtrack with some powerhouse horror moments captured here for you to enjoy.  The composers have certainly done an excellent job at collaborating together on this project and I highly recommend this fantastic music!

It's been quite some time since I've seen this movie.  I was five years old when the movie came out but I remember watching it on TV with my father some years later.  We might of owned a VHS copy of it too.  The film looks great in this Blu-ray release and it is definitely the cleanest version I've ever seen.  I'm no Convoy movie expert, but it appears to be an unedited version as well.  I've read some reviews where people complain that certain scenes are missing from earlier versions (such as the DVD release) and I was looking for those particular scenes and they are in this release.  The movie runs 110 minutes while some of the other releases only ran for 106 minutes.The movie, as stated before, certainly looks nice on my HDTV and the sound quality is great too.  The film isn't perfect looking and it still shows some age in certain scenes but I personally haven't seen anything better when I compare it to the TV and VHS versions that I've watched before.  It was great watching it again and brings me back to the days of being a kid and watching Smokey and the Bandit, Dukes of Hazzard, and Cannonball Run.  As a kid, Convoy (and movies like it) was just comic cool silliness with big trucks (or fast cars) "taking it to the man".  Watching it now, I even see an attempt at some sort of heroic message here but the real draw to the film is basically a western using big rigs.  The soundtrack for the movie is just great and I can remember just loving (and singing) the original Convoy song which was the inspiration for the film.  It great fun to see this picture again and it brings back some great memories.This release comes with some great special features too.  The 73 minute documentary entitled "Passion & Poetry - Sam's Trucker Movie" is really interesting.  It goes through all of the trials and tribulations all involved went through during the production.  The actors, producers, and techies speak about director Sam Peckinpah's downfall with cocaine and all of the problems it caused during the production.  It's amazing that the film was ever even released.  The documentary shows the eventual success of the film not only in the US but around the world.  They even show a guy in Germany who was so obsessed with the film that he had a replica of Duck's truck made for himself!  The movie turned out to be very profitable but unfortunately marked the end of Sam Peckinpah's career.  It's a great documentary and fans of the film will surely find it very interesting.  Another 3 minute featurette entitled "Trucker Notes From Norway" has a fan (from Norway) give us a history of the truck(s) used in the film.  This movie sure has a big following overseas!  The 5 minute feature entitled "Injokes, Friends & Cameos" was especially interesting because it contains some great "fun facts" that I didn't know about.  I didn't know that Sam Peckinpah was in the film.  You can see him riding in the back of the truck with the TV guy interviewing "The Duck".  Also, the names of the companies on the trucks are little salutes to the actor's (driving the trucks) previous roles in other films.  Some of you Convoy fans probably knew all of this but I sure didn't.  There are three deleted scenes, but we can only see production stills and images of the script for these because the original footage was destroyed.  The special features are really great and I enjoyed watching all of these after viewing the film.Kino Lorber has done a great job putting this together.  The movie looks great and the special features are awesome.  Convoy fans should pick this one up for sure.

My 5 year old son has been wanting a Batman cape and trying to find them around at the local stores has proved to be very difficult.  Amazon Prime is here to save the day!  The only problem is that there are so many options and manufacturers that picking the one that will be the best can be challenging.  I wanted something that would withstand the playful wrath of a 5 year old and look cool too.  When looking at the choices here on Amazon, I decided to take a gamble with this one.  It cost a little bit more but I liked the fact that you could reverse it and you get a Superman cape on the other side.  Children tend to change their minds quite often and while today it might be Batman...tomorrow he might want to be Superman.I was a little nervous when the package arrived because I thought that it might just be a cheap rag with a Batman/Superman sticker attached to it.  I was happy to find that it was of pretty decent quality.  The Batman/Superman logos are real patches.  It's made out of some very shiny polyester and all of the stitching is done nicely.  Basically, it is two sheets of polyester fabric (one red and the other black) sewn together.  You attach it around your neck through the use of a velcro strap.  The care instructions state that this is to be washed in cold water, hand wash cycle, and to let it dry flat.  My son is 42 inches tall and I was worried that it would be too long for him.  I didn't want it dragging on the ground and him to be tripping all over it.  It falls down to about the top of his calves.The real test was to see if he would like it.  When you pull it out of the package, it looks like it is just a Batman cape.  He was surprised to find out that the reversed side was also Superman.  Now, he constantly changes back and forth between the two.  I'm glad I went with this one and was satisfied with the quality and fit for my son.  He sure is having fun with it as well.

A few friends of mine were talking about this film and recommended it to me.  I pre-ordered the movie and was eager to see it because they were acting like it was the greatest thing ever.  I don't think it was the scariest horror film ever made but it did have eerie moments that will raise the hairs on the back of your neck.  The film does start a little slow and as I was watching it I was thinking about how miserable these characters are.  I stuck with it and things begin to make more sense.  The film has a long developing exposition that sets up the emotional grind that the two main characters are going through.  Many who watch this movie comment on how annoying the kid is.  I think the clever thing about this movie is that you begin to "feel" what the mother goes through and instead of becoming a passive viewer of events unfolding...you essentially become more involved.  The director could of demonstrated annoyances that the mother (Essie Davis) goes through but instead decides to throw the misery in the audience's faces repeatedly.  You can't help but to feel the desperation of the mother and couldn't help but to think what I would do in a situation like this.  Once the creature arrives, you wonder if all of this is sheer insanity but because both characters experience the Babadook, it develops into more of a mystery.  The ending was puzzling at first but if you take a moment, it all becomes very clear.  It is indeed a movie that contains a message but for those just seeking a thrill ride, it might be a little slow in development for you but you'll get there.  I thought the acting was very well done.  Essie Davis and Noah Wiseman certainly know how to evoke reactions from the audience.  I hear people saying, "I can't stand that woman" and "That kid was so annoying...I just couldn't stand it".  Well, reactions like are the greatest compliments for actors.To me personally, the film leaves me with the thought that stress, conflict, and other weights of the world can manifest into things quite terrible.  These issues can stack up inside of us can certainly do great damage and need to be dealt with.  Although we deal with this stuff with the help of family and friends, these negative experiences will always be a part of us in some way.  We all handle our problems in differently and this film seems to explore this with audiences.  I enjoyed the film and it gave us some interesting lunch break conversations at work.The Blu Ray special edition comes in a red sleeve that can open up to reveal what looks to be a page out of the Babadook book.  The film looks great but I do agree with others that you will be adjusting the volume on this a lot.  It can get really soft sometimes and then super loud.  There are also some great extras like deleted scenes, cast and crew interviews, and Jennifer Kent's short film entitled "Monster".  This short film obviously became the inspiration for the movie and it's interesting to watch.  I especially enjoyed the interview with the artist who created the book for the movie as well.  I enjoyed the film for it's developing thrills and the pondering message it leaves us with.  I recommend this one highly.

I saw the trailer for the movie and was impressed enough to pre-order this movie score.  The trailer introduces the audience to a story set during the time of World War II and it is preparing us for a heartfelt story of faith, love, and a child's determination to bring his father back home from the war.  It's a family film that is surely designed to bring out both tears and smiles from movie goers.  With such a powerful premise in a movie, it will certainly need an emotion inducing score to assist with such goals and I was looking forward to hearing what Stephan Altman and Mark Foster had to offer.  So did they succeed?  Well, I'd say that this score is OK.  I'd give it about three and half stars if I could.  It has some really great moments that I get really excited about but just when it is about to sweep me away, a few distracting things happen which I will explain in a bit.I haven't seen the movie yet and I am really excited to watch this one.  The premise of the film is very intriguing and as I said earlier, I was really looking forward to this particular score.  Film music can really make or break a movie.  I've often thought that a great film score is one that you don't really hear while your watching a movie.  It's there working through us almost subconsciously.  I also know that some really powerful scores can give you a story all on their own.  Closing your eyes and listening to one of these can literally give you original stories all by themselves.  The ultimate doom for a score is when it can become distracting.  There are some movies that I've seen where the music becomes so distracting or irrelevant that I just can't even stand to watch it anymore.  When listening to this particular score by Stephan Altman and Mark Foster there is one particular sound that I find extremely distracting and annoying.  It concerns the vocal chorus that comes in from time to time.  They come in with a "da da" version of the melody that seems to fit more of a late 60's romantic comedy film.  It seems to me to be very out of place.  I kinda get the sense that the composers are going for a very playful childlike "imaginative" feel in the music here but it just isn't working for me.  Granted, I haven't seen the film yet and this "interesting" musical choice might work beautifully in the movie but I just have a hard time enjoying the score on it's own with that popping in every now and then.  The melody is beautiful...but when that chorus comes in...I just cringe.  The other musical choices made are great.  I love the use of the various instrumentation such as accordion, guitars, banjo's, and I do love the whistling that comes and goes every now and then.  A good example of this would be track 6, "The List".  I really like this one...but I have to cover my ears when the chorus (now with eerie reverb effect) come in to wreak havoc.  I could do without track 7, "The Fight", as well.  It sounds like a child's version of a spaghetti western and I just didn't like it's approach either.  There are some really awesome moments in the score too however.  Track 13, "The War", and track 14, "The Funeral", are especially moving pieces that are well done.  I like the composer's handling of the beautifully constructed theme here and the tracks that follow are quite nice.  Track 15, "London Learns/Graveyard", is probably my favorite.I honestly have to say that this particular score isn't exactly what I was expecting.  It has it's moments where I question some of the choices made but I guess I'll have to wait and see if these same "distractions" in the music will become annoyances in my viewing of the movie.  Maybe I won't hear them.  Again, the chosen technique may work beautifully within the context of the film and I hope it does.The score also contains two songs.  "When You Find Love", performed by Peter Barbee and Mark Pontius, is track 1.  I didn't really care for this song either but I did like the traditional arrangement of "This Little Light of Mine" by RT Valine (track 9).  The score contains 19 songs and runs for about 48 minutes.  There is a four page CD insert that contains pictures from the film and credits for the score and movie.  There is also another separate insert which is a small card that is a replica of the list that Father Oliver (played by Tom Wilkinson) gives the "Little Boy".  The CD is produced by Milan Records.It's an OK score with some really great moving moments.  At times...it gets a little silly and distracting but maybe it will grow on me.  I might just be singing a "Da Da" version of the theme by the end of the week.  I highly recommend sampling it first before buying to see how you take to some of these tracks.  I am looking forward to seeing the movie and certainly appreciate the fact that movies like this are being made.

I've been researching possible musicals to do at our school and I decided that I'd give this one a try.  It hasn't been done in our area in a long time and it seems to be just what we are looking for.  "Destry Rides Again" was another option, but this one really has some great timeless classics that just stick with you once you start listening to it.  "Doing What Comes Naturally", "There's No Business Like Show Business", "Anything You Can Do", and my personal favorite "I Got The Sun in the Morning" are just phenomenal pieces of American show music that will never be forgotten.  Irving Berlin was surely a master at his craft.  The CD comes with a wonderful 16 page insert that contains the original 1949 LP liner notes, as well as, reissue notes by Max O. Preeo (Editor of Show Music).  The insert gives plenty of trivia and fun facts concerning the musical, it's creation, synopsis of the story and information concerning the major players who brought this show to Broadway.  One interesting fact is that Jerome Kern was originally planned to score the show.  Another interesting thing is that Kern was once asked, "What is Berlin's place in American music?," and Kern responded that "Berlin has no place in American music...Irving Berlin is American music."  The insert was an unexpected bonus with this CD and makes this purchase even better.  It even has an alternate CD cover on the back of the insert but I really like the classic look of the one shown.The CD sounds great and the people behind this release have taken the time to make sure it is presented here in the best way possible.  The track listing is in show order and bonus tracks were added from the 1973 London Phase 4 stereo recording with Stanley Black and the London Festival Orchestra & Chorus.  My favorite of the bonus tracks is the "Overture" for the show.  The 1973 recording also contains "An Old Fashioned Wedding" which is sung by Ethel Merman & Neilson Taylor.  The CD contains a total of 16 tracks and runs about 50 minutes.  Considering the quality of this recording, the well written CD insert, and the great Amazon price...I don't think you can go wrong with this release of the show.  There are a lot of different versions of this particular show and I decided to go with the original.  I am very pleased to add this to my collection and it has become a wonderful resource to assist me while I am shopping around for our next musical.

I just got mine and they are working great.  I didn't have any problems with them not cutting off and the motion sensitivity works really well.  They are plenty bright and I love the fact that I can aim the three light "pods" in different directions.  If you choose not to use the motion sensor, there is an on/off button that you can push to manually turn the light on.  It actually has to different intensity levels where one push is bright and the second push will dim the light down a bit.I was surprised at how much light it produces and it certainly can brighten up a dark safe.  I recommend!

Annie and Ethan were best friends and first loves. But when he got his first hockey contract and had to move, she had to stay at home and long distance did not work out. But now their present lives are about to collide. She broke up with him three years ago and both have unresolved feelings. She had her reasons, but he didn't really understand.He got his hockey dream. She achieved hers of becoming a nurse. But both are missing not only their love, but friendship. But even though they both have unresolved feelings, their lives are still in different places.Annie has some significant issues that keep her emotionally detached at times. Her past has damaged her, trust is hard, and she finds it hard to truly in believe in love. She has fears, insecurities, an inferiority complex, and guards her heart. She can be a martyr at times and sacrifices for others. Oh, and she has a boyfriend too that seems perfect.Ethan is emotional and hot headed. He is not afraid of admitting feelings or pursuing her. But his temper and anger sometimes get the best of him. He has his own issues from his past that affect him as well.Their pasts tie them together and it is hard to resist that pull in the present. But that does not mean their problems have gone away. They live in two different worlds. In their attempts at protecting each other, sometimes they feel the need to sacrifice their own needs. They have to deal with anger issues, anxiety, fears, insecurities, and outside influences. Their communication issues caused complications in their past and present. I really liked them together and could feel their connection in their dual points of view. I was rooting for them to navigate all of their challenges.I liked his brother Manny who was a wisecracking, trouble-making playboy. I can see him as a future male lead. This was a fast-paced, sweet, second chance love story with a background of hockey and a bit of danger thrown in.

Featured review of Mistletoe Misconduct by Catherine Gayle:I am a big fan of Catherine Gayle's Portland Storm series so was excited to get Jim Sutter's story. He is the Portland Storm hockey team General Manager. He is a good guy who takes care of his team, treats them like family, and often gives people that need them a second chance to succeed or make something out of their life. We have seen him do that for his assistant Rachel when she really needed it and for some down on their luck players. But Jim has never forgiven himself for a a mistake he made that cost him his family. He's built his own pseudo family with his team and their wives and is well loved, but he has no relationship with his own son and lost his wife.But when his ex, Elaine sees a profile for Jim on a dating site, the years fall away and she decides to take it as her own second chance.Jim was always good at giving others another chance, but not himself. He has a big heart and is kind, but he beats himself up with guilt over one bad choice and feels unworthy. But Elaine is realizing that she could have fought harder for him too. And she has decided to take charge and be brave. Can she convince him that he deserves love and his own second chance?This was a short, sweet, second chance love story. It moved pretty fast due to it's short novella length for this anthology and it was light on drama and details. But the connection between them was established and was heartfelt. The side relationship with their son Dillon also added depth to the story. And it was fun to get some cameos by some of the characters from other books and we met a new player Chris Hammond "Hammer".  I really enjoyed getting to know more about Jim and seeing others look out for him for a change.Additional note: This collection offers a variety of authors and types of characters that  will make it a fun anthology to have when you need quick holiday pick me ups to make you smile, swoon, and get you the in the holiday spirit. They are of perfect length for fitting in when you have limited time, and for trying out new authors.

Gracie Oliver has a new job and a new outlook on life. Now she just needs a man to take care of her pesky intact v-card issue. Her brother Hayden does not want to hear about his sister seeking out men to date or have sex with. Neither does his best friend, Hudson Stone. Or does he?Gracie has had a crush on Hudson since they were kids. And she has no hope that he ever felt the same way. But when he offers to help with her lack of sex issue and teach her all she needs to know in three easy lessons, it makes her wonder. Definitely not anything she expected and it has the potential to get complicated. And what happens to them after their time is up?This was a short, sweet, sexy novella. It moved fast and was engaging, but  I was a bit disappointed in the rushed ending.  I liked getting dual points of view and I really liked them together. Their connection and chemistry was obvious There was the whole forbidden element since she is the little sister of his overprotective best friend and business partner so it had the potential to get messy. And their hidden feelings added confusion. There was not a lot of drama and angst. It was not as snarky, unfiltered, and funny as Screwed. But I think it was because Hudson's personality was more low key than Hayden's, but still had some humor and was sweet.  I was glad she told Hudson and Gracie's story and  did enjoy getting more with Hayden and Emery.

Colin Sloan wants all of Elle Mariano, but she's not willing to give it to him. She's got her reasons, even though she longs for him too. He's everything she wants, but also has the potential to be her worst nightmare repeated. Colin has tried hard to leave his past behind him, but it just keeps coming back to affect his present.But they both know that their sizzling chemistry and attraction is not going away. So they both have their own strategies on how to play it. He takes risks for a living and in his leisure time, and her life is about minimizing them. They both think they can explore the physical and leave out the emotions, but can they really just be friends with benefits?She has more than just herself to worry about. And his family drama is ongoing. Their pasts affect who they are and what decisions they make at times. Some of the past causes more immediate threats in their present. There are secrets and surprises that are gradually also coming to light.I adored Colin. He is such a good, likable guy who is intelligent, sweet, and protective. But he is also sexy, charismatic, and a panty-melter and dirty talker. He's a risk taker, an adventurer, and an adrenaline junkie. He has had a rough past, but faced it and now tries to rise above. He focuses on a healthy lifestyle and giving back. But the new surprises and stresses have the potential to send him for a tailspin and test his coping skills.Elle is caring, devoted, responsible and fearful. She does not trust easily and is used to being let down.  She has to focus on her son's well being and the needs of the community center, as well as her own. She has made promises to herself and her son, but she also has needs, wants, and fantasies. It is hard for her to take risks or believe that she can have what she wants due to past issues.Together they have a chemical reaction. They run scorching hot (if she is not running cold). They are compatible and good as friends, but they also burn up the sheets (or other locations) when they allow themselves. They challenge each other and push boundaries. But they both know the situation is tenuous at best and they can only live in denial so long.But when life gets real, are they strong enough to push for more or will they crumble before they can really have a chance to begin?Each book in this series has a stand alone romance with a  different Sloan sibling, but also a continuing mystery suspense story unraveling about their family's past that we gradually are getting more answers about. The surprises, secrets, and fall out just keeps coming in this intricate, suspenseful story line that has affected all of the siblings in various ways.I adored Colin and Elle. I could understand their challenges, but was rooting for them. They were a truly fun, flirty, and sweet couple with hot chemistry and a strong magnetic pull, but also had significant challenges. This couple had personal demons and past problems that were triggers for the other and not easy to overcome. Their story builds on the background that has come before in the series. I love the fact that the past family history has had layers peeled back more and more each book. It brings all the stories together in a larger framework. I love the relationship between Colin and his siblings and how each of them is making discoveries about themselves, their shared past, and each other. I also enjoyed Colin and Elle's rapport with the kids at the center.This installment was sweet, hot, funny, and serious at the same time. It was full of longing, lust, love, and passion. It also centered around the importance family and friendship. It also had the suspense and danger component adding more stress and drama. It was about self discovery, pushing boundaries, and figuring out what limits can be dealt with. Sometimes changing strategies and taking risks can lead to the greatest rewards.We got more answers about the underlying mystery in the back story, but the biggest surprising revelation also poses more questions. I am looking forward to more answers and their brother Michael finding his match in the fourth book Sinful Love.

Phoebe Page has moved home to Lover's leap Colorado and right back in close contact with her best friend's brother and her teen crush. She is literally a walking disaster and often seems to find herself in precarious situations. She's trying to live a little and start a new life in her home town.Colton Brody is a wounded Marine vet turned firefighter who is working hard to rejoin the Corps. He's got plans and they do not involve staying home or having a relationship. But he finds a spark with her. And they are both craving a bit of sexy times, but don't want attachments..or don't think they do...A fling...a set expiration date...no feelings...no change in their friendship or with his family....It can work, right?She's a good, sweet, goofy girl, but lets her wild side free with him. They share a witty rapport and humor. He's serious, focused, and likes control, but she distracts him and brings out emotions in him. He's always been a playboy and has never been the type to settle down. He lives for adrenaline and does not let anything stop him. He's got a bit of a bad boy edge, dirty talking mouth, but is finding out that he has a weakness too.Will they find a way to make it work or will they crash and burn?This was a fast, sweet, funny romantic read. I laughed out loud at some of the antics and humorous situations. Phoebe and Colt were funny and likable. I could feel their connection and chemistry. I liked getting both of their points of view.The side characters especially her friend and his sister Daisy and their brother Tucker added comic relief, ass kicking, and advice. There area few more brother Blake and Dylan and a cousin Seth who could also be the subject of more books in this series. The brothers especially all seem to have women problems and Daisy seems to have her own issues as well.

Scarlett Deveareux has returned to Saltwater Springs, SC to start her own bakery. She finds herself in need of help and it comes in the unlikely form of her former boyfriend, Luke Garrity, who now owns his own construction firm. Unfortunately, she left him ten years ago with no explanation and broke his heart. And Luke is still harboring some anger, and they both have unresolved feelings and secrets.They find themselves interacting on a daily basis after a decade apart. Their attraction is still there and it only grows stronger the more time they spend together.Luke is kind, protective charming and loves hard. He is still confused and hurt over their past as he was blindsided when she left. He felt inferior as a younger man, but has worked hard to build a life and take care of those he cares about.Scarlett was wealthy and controlled when younger. But now she is independent minded, starting over, and trying to follow her dreams. But she is fearful of her secrets getting out, hurting Luke further, and of being gossiped about in the small town. She has her own feelings of inferiority and insecurities. And the reason she left still impacts her present and future.Luke wants to come in and save the day and help her recover from some recent questionable choices. It is hard to resist his help and their attraction. They have a connection, history, and chemistry. But she is determined to keep her heart out of it because she is fearful that it cannot lead anywhere permanent. What will happen when all of her secrets come out? Will that be the final thing that will make Luke give up on her?I liked the small town feel and the fun, quirky characters. I could see more stories with some of the side characters like her friends Layla, Shelby, Savannah, local cop Graham and there was even a tease of a mysterious bar owner. Mrs. M was a funny "Old bitty" who delivered some great one liners. I liked getting both points of view.I loved Luke even when he did overreact at times. He could be thoughtful, sweet, and swoony, and also had that sexy alpha male vibe. I liked Scarlett too even when she was guarding her heart and I wanted her to spill her truth. She was caring and kind, but also had a lot of worries. They had the potential to be really great together again, but they had some pitfalls to navigate.This was a sweet second chance story with some heartbreak and pain and secrets, but also joy and hope. I had figured out her big secrets, but there were a couple of things that did surprise me. The epilogue was not what I expected, but I loved it.

This is the conclusion of Logan and Elle's story and begins right after the climactic ending in Blow. They are dealing with the multiple possible threats, issues, and are worried about their safety. They are in the midst of the fall out from various situations.  Logan is trying to figure out what is best for Elle and how to most effectively protect her. Elle is dealing with her constantly changing world and worries about those she cares about. It is hard to know who to trust, who the real enemy is, and what they really want.There are mysteries, secrets, lies, and threats swirling around them. They are immersed in a dangerous world with many variables in play. Not only do they have to protect themselves, but also her young niece who could get caught in the crossfire.It's a race for answers and to try to put together all of the puzzle pieces so they can figure out who is behind everything and how it all fits together. And then to try to figure out a way to end the threats and bring down the antagonists.This book had me guessing trying to put it all together and predict the outcome. But I have to say there were some definite twists and surprises. I was shocked by some events and was wrong about some things. There are so many little connections from the past spilling onto the present as well as multiple parties involved. It was full of tension, danger, and suspense.But at the core of this story is a couple that are broken as individuals, but together have the potential to make each other whole. They have personal demons to face, have to continue to build trust, and deal with some challenging situations. Two people who used to not believe in attachments find themselves desperate to be together, but are afraid that it might never happen or that the possible repercussions might carry too high a price.Logan is strong, fiercely protective, and  possessive. But he is also scared his mistakes will hurt Elle, so has feelings of guilt and wonders if she would be better off without him. He is intelligent, successful,  and also street smart. He is alpha on the outside, but a bit broken on the inside. He has a strong need to be in control and unfortunately his life seems to keep spinning farther out of control. He has made mistakes with far reaching consequences. No matter how far he tries to get ahead of it, his past still seems to catch up with him and affect his present.Elle is tough, smart, independent and loving. She is not afraid to fight for her happiness, but she is also not immune to doubts and fears. She will do anything to protect her niece no matter the sacrifice to herself.I totally adored Logan and thought Elle was a really likable heroine. Their emotional connection was strong, their chemistry was intense, and their passion was undeniable. I was totally invested in their relationship.  They had  a give and take about them that was put to the test as they both dealt with challenging or emotional situations and threats. It was about priorities, faith, hope, and figuring out where they were supposed to be and believing they deserved to have what they wanted. But it was an uphill battle not only with their own personal demons but also with all of the outside influences and hidden threats against them.I liked the side characters of their friends Declan, Miles, Peyton, and also Logan's father and Grandfather. There were some antagonists and shifty characters that were hard to pin down. And there were a a bunch of potentials for who was threatening them. It was fun trying to put all the pieces together and  figure out the motivations and what was really going on.Kim Karr managed to weave a complex, exciting, full, romantic suspense story into these two books. It was multi-layered and had many little connections past and present. It was told in dual points of view that I really appreciated. The characters had depth, complex emotions, flaws, and were likable and passionate, The story line was fast moving despite the intricate details and layers. It was a beautiful and steamy love story layered with mysteries and exciting danger and suspense. I really enjoyed this series and this intense journey with Logan and Elle. This tied up everything I needed it to and even had an extended epilogue.

This takes place right after Sultry Groove. Leah, The Reckless Beat manager and Ryan, rhythm guitarist, shared a kiss that shouldn't have happened (or maybe it was finally time). Leah takes off to Vegas to get her head together and for a diversion...back to where she met an intriguing man who gave her a standing invitation to return. She could use a distraction from the mess she is making by crushing on her former best friend and client.And she does succeed in finding one hell of a distraction, pleasure, and an ego boost. But it does not stop the feelings of sadness, guilt, and hopelessness.Leah tries to get away from her feelings for Ryan and all of their inquiring questions, but also knows Reckless Beat is her family.  This is basically a wake up call for her.  Maybe it is time for her to think more about what she needs vs. everyone else. She and Ryan's friendship has already been battered over the past year. Where will they go after this newest challenge?The Reckless Beat guys and girls are back for a bit. And another familiar guy makes an appearance and brings along a friend too. I liked both of them. I love their family type bonds of the group and the fact that they may fuss and fight but also love each other. Leah sent them all into a tailspin and her choices affect everyone.This is short transition novella bridging Sultry Goove and the final Reckless Beat novel. It was a quick, erotic trip for Leah to find ways to try to forget, but also allowed her time to think about what she plans to do about her situation.I am looking forward to more with Leah and Ryan. This has been building a long time and I have been hoping that each of them could find some happiness.

Sparks, snark, sexual tension and a bit of danger...Chloe Jacobs and Ryan Douglas were both having a crappy night...then it got worse...much worse...then heated up.When they meet again, Ryan is met by an angry, feisty Chloe again. And it will take some maneuvering for him to get her to go out with him. She's sworn off men. She does not want to date athletes and there is a little matter about him keeping a big secret.She is a spit fire. Fresh off her most recent rejection, her sarcasm and man hating behaviors are showing. She loves to challenge Ryan. But under her bravado is an insecure woman afraid of rejection.Ryan in turn thinks it is fun to push and needle her. He's big, burly, bossy, cocky, and sexy. He's everything she is afraid to want and half of the female population wants him due to his celebrity status as a hockey player. He's been burned in a relationship and not ready for another one. And he is still recovering from an injury and needs to focus on keeping his place on the team.Hot and heavy. Resistance, retreat, repeat. They are two people with antagonistic tendencies that set them on fire in the bedroom. It's a battle of wills and both are stubborn. They Fight, Flirt, F***, then do it all again. But will they Fall?Underneath they are also developing more of an understanding for the other's internal motivations. Seeing the good under the sarcasm and sex appeal is a dangerous game for two people afraid of relationships.But their lives are complicated by omissions, lies, and public scrutiny that lead to insecurities, fears, trust issues, and hurt feelings. I liked them both and their witty banter,  but they could be frustrating too. Are these two meant to be together or will they they lose again in the end?This was  fast, funny, sarcastic, sexy and sweet. It was told in dual points of view. I like hockey books so that is always a plus. Her friend Olivia and boss Cole were the subject of the first book in this series Once Upon A Dare and they make appearances in this one, but this one reads easily as a stand alone.

Benjamin Gale III is considered a beast of a boss. He is a demanding, work-a-holic with no real emotional connections. He is trying to keep his family business intact with his place as CEO despite some serious opposition. He is stubborn, determined, ambitious, but no one really knows him.Maggie Donovan is one of his employees with a good heart, sweet personality, wit, and is not intimidated by him. She sometimes even defends him. When they are caught in a situation that could be misinterpreted and used against them, quick thinking leads to a fake engagement.They are from two different worlds. They have different ideas about their situation and how to proceed. They have limited knowledge of the other one. People out to get them, public scrutiny, private attraction, and fears affect their choices.He's alpha, bossy, and used to control.  But she makes him want to lose control, adds fun to his life, and helps him find missing pieces of himself he had locked away. She manages to see into his vulnerable core and makes him want to be a better man. I enjoyed the peeling back of his layers and him finding himself again.She seems shy and quiet at first, but is independent minded and likes to make her own choices. She has a sassy, strong, and protective side too. She even has rules on how a fake engagement should go in order to protect her heart. She is kind and teaches him more about thoughtfulness and generosity, but also is not a doormat. But she is afraid to trust or let him in. She pushes him away a lot because she is tempted by him and he makes her want to not act logical or rational.There is a lot of chasing, running, differences of opinion, temptation, fear of getting hurt, and trust issues. Both will have to open up, trust, and believe if they want a real chance. But their lives have some complications, outside influences, built in differences, and tough choices that need to be made.Can two people conditioned not to trust really give their hearts away? Or will they end up as just another cause of pain and regret?This was a fun, sweet, sexy modern take on Beauty and the Beast with some Cinderella moments thrown in. I loved that Maggie was the one that saw him for more than he appeared to be. And that he was smart enough to see how special she was early on. I enjoyed their dual points of view and their banter. There was definitely some drama mixed in and some antagonistic people that caused some frustration, but it was a quick, engaging read full of sexual tension, drama, and an unlikely romance.ARC provided by publisher in exchange for an honest review.
